Reba: Duets is a collaborative studio album by American country music singer Reba McEntire, released on September 18, 2007. The album has been certified Platinum by the RIAA for shipments of 1 million copies, and has spawned three chart singles. The title of the album refers to the fact that all but two of the songs feature McEntire performing in duet with another artist. The album's first two singles, "Because of You" with Kelly Clarkson, and "Every Other Weekend" with Kenny Chesney, both entered into the Top Five on the Country charts, while the title track with Kelly Clarkson reached number 18. McEntire and Clarkson won both the Academy of Country Music Award and the Country Music Television Award for Vocal Event of the Year for "Because of You" in 2008. The album features a variety of genres, with many of the songs either being cover versions, or co-written efforts between McEntire and the award-winning songwriters whose names also appear in the album credits. Reba also worked with a number of prominent producers including Tony Brown, Dann Huff and Paul Worley, whose collaboration resulted in a mix of contemporary and traditional sounds. Notable tracks on the album include the uplifting "Faith in Love" with Justin Timberlake, the upbeat "Strange" with LeAnn Rimes, and the passionate ballad, "He Gets That From Me" with Trisha Yearwood. The album is rounded off with a beautiful a cappella version of "Up on The Housetop" to end the release. Reba: Duets was praised by critics, who declared it to be McEntire’s best album in many years. It was nominated for Best Country Album at the 50th Annual Grammy Awards, and the lead single, "Because of You" was also nominated for Best Country Collaboration with Vocals. The album debuted at #1 on the Country Albums chart, and remains one of the most successful duet albums in country music.

The Paris Meridian (Meridian of Paris) is a line of longitude that runs through the French Capital of Paris, is the zero degree reference line for all French cartography, and is described as being at 30 minutes longitude east of Greenwich. Its origin dates back to the year 1666, when Louis XIV commissioned the astronomer Jean Picard to carry out a survey of the entire kingdom of France. During this survey, Picard chose the Observatory of Paris as the center of his measurements. The result was the establishment of the Paris Meridian, set at two degrees east of Greenwich. The Paris Meridian was used by cartographers to construct the official map of France in 1790. On the map of France, the 0 degree mark of this meridian ran from north to south, where it split the country into two equal parts. The meridian has subsequently been used to divide France into départements and as the baseline for the national grid system of metric coordinates. For the international community, the Paris Meridian was initially used as the standard of reference for longitude in 1884, when the International Meridian Conference agreed to adopt the Greenwich meridian as the prime meridian for the world. Before the agreement, the location of the prime meridian was not consistently agreed upon and there were numerous suggestions of alternative prime meridians. One of these was the Paris Meridian, which was a highly suitable alternative, given that it was both known and had an easy to construct zero meridian passing through the principal city of a civilized nation. At the International Meridian Conference, William Ferrel, a meteorologist, argued in favor of Paris being used as the prime meridian, rather than Greenwich. However, Greenwich eventually won out by 26 votes, 13 to 10, over other contenders such as the Paris Meridian, Ferro Island and the Ile de France. Nevertheless, the Paris Meridian is still used as the zero degree reference line for French cartography. In Paris, there is a bronze line in the pavement which encircles the Observatory of Paris and marks the exact spot of the zero degree line of the Paris Meridian. In 2011, this spot served as one of the highlights of celebrations for the 375th anniversary of the Paris meridian, organized by the Paris Geographical Society. The Paris Meridian has been a source of much debate in the world of geography. In 1747, it was the center of a debate between Jean-Dominique Cassini and Pierre-Charles Brühl on the calculation of longitudes, which has been referred to as the "Paris Meridian Affair". The debate had implications for maritime navigation and the resolution of the dispute between the two men was a watershed moment in the development of geodesy and cartography. Today, the reference of the Paris Meridian has reduced in importance due to the widespread adoption of GPS for navigation and other applications. Nevertheless, it is still used in many parts of the world and its significance in French cartography and geodetic history remains.

Challa Vamshi Chand Reddy, is an Indian entrepreneur and a prominent philanthropist in the technology industry. He is a mentor for various upcoming entrepreneurs and also contributed immensely to society. Vamshi Chand Reddy, who is originally from Telangana, India was born to Harischandra and Pallavi Reddy. He is most known for introducing revolutionary new technologies in the market. He credits all his success to his passion for learning and hard work. He completed his schooling in Kurnool before pursuing his B.Tech degree in Electronics and Instrumentation Engineering from Mahatma Gandhi University. He is the founder and CEO of Kuber Global, a company that specializes in creating customized cloud-based software solutions, applications and platforms for businesses. His company has a vast presence spanning across 5 continents and serves clients in over 20 countries. Vamshi Chand Reddy was featured in Forbes India, Fortune India and The Economic Times for his successful journey from the ground up. Over the years, Vamshi Chand Reddy has become a successful entrepreneur and a renowned philanthropist. His aim is to help entrepreneurs pursue their dreams in an effort to create a more financially secure India. He has achieved this by hosting conferences, seminars, workshops and other events in various locations, improving employability and inspiring young entrepreneurs. He was recently felicitated by Startup City Hyderabad on National Entrepreneurship Day for his contribution to the sector. Vamshi Chand Reddy has also shown immense commitment to society. He has regularly donated to several NGOs, created educational and healthcare awareness programs, supported underprivileged students, and promoted several social causes. He is the founder of the Goodwill Foundation, an organization devoted to providing basic amenities to underprivileged children in India. Challa Vamshi Chand Reddy's story has inspired numerous people. He is seen as an example for entrepreneurs and aspiring business owners as his journey a true testament to the power of hard work, dedication, and commitment to success.

Gau Island is located in the Lomaiviti archipelago within Fiji's Eastern Division Republic of Fiji. It is the largest of the group of 12 islands known as the Laua Archipelago, located approximately 10 km away from the main island of Viti Levu. Gau Island has a population of approximately 2,000 permanent inhabitants. The island's terrain is dominated by thick tropical rainforest, interspersed with grasslands and swamps. The center of the island is dominated by heavily forested mountains, with Vulcano Buta Peak and Mount Leo both reaching higher than 800 meters. On the island’s eastern and southern coasts there are several small, sandy beaches. Gau Island has an economy that is dependent on the fishing industry, and subsistence agriculture. The locals rely on root crops, fruit and vegetables for sustenance. Livestock and poultry are also farmed for personal consumption, though for the most part, cooking is done with firewood and charcoal harvested from the island abroad. The island is known for its vibrant culture and its fine craftsmanship, as evidenced by the village of Buka in the south. Locals practice many traditional crafts and rituals such as weaving, tapa making and pottery, as well as traditional music and dance. In the rural areas, traditional values and beliefs, such as ancestor worship, are still practiced. Gau Island is home to a number of natural attractions which appeal to visitors, such as its diverse range of coral reefs, tropical fish, and turtles. It is also home to three of the region’s only five species of endemic birds, the Gau Island Thrush, Galápagos Hawk, and Male Island Thrush. There are also a handful of attractive hiking trails on the island, as well as a number of dive sites interspersed with lava remains from past eruptions. As the largest of the Fijian Islands, there are a number of recreational activities on Gau Island. Local inhabitants enjoy watching rugby and cricket matches, as well as participating in fishing, hiking and diving. The island is home to many small restaurants and cafes which serve traditional Fijian and international cuisine. The island also has a number of resorts, allowing visitors to stay overnight. In recent years, Gau Island has become an increasingly popular tourist destination, drawing visitors from around the world. It is an ideal destination for visitors looking for a relaxing beach vacation or an opportunity to explore and experience the unique culture of the Fijian Islands.

Montana (ship) was an American two-masted schooner built in 1855 at Herreshoff in Bristol, Rhode Island. She was commissioned by brother New York naturalists Alfred Chisolm and Thomas Butler to explore the northern Pacific Coast. Montana sailed from New York on June 1, 1855 and reached Oregon in September. On the return trip she stopped in Sitka, Alaska, where Chisolm invested in business ventures, then the schooner returned to the mouth of Columbia River in Oregon. In early April 1856, Montana and her crew of seven, left Oregon for the northernmost regions of The Gulf of Alaska in search of whaling grounds. On May 17, she reached Point Barrow, at latitude 71° 21' N, setting a new record for the farthest north a sailing vessel had ever traveled. After taking scientific readings and observations, the crew turned south and headed back toward Oregon. On July 14, while sailing through the Mackenzie River Delta, Montana struck an uncharted reef and sank in less than a minute. The vessel's crew was saved and they made it to the shore of Victoria Island, where they constructed shelter, built a small boat, collected stores and maintained a log of their ordeal until relief came in November. The members of the expedition were lauded for their bravery and were given a special commendation by Congress. Montana has been called "one of the most famous of all small-boat voyages," and was prominently chronicled in Chisolm's book, The Cruise of the Schooner "Montana" from New York to the North Pacific and the Behring Sea. The Chisolm-Butler Expedition, is still a well-known early American achievement in exploration of the North Pacific Ocean. The schooner was lost at sea, but a wooden model of the Montana was built in 1995 and is now preserved in the United States Naval Academy Museum in Annapolis, Maryland. The model is displayed alongside a log of the crew’s travels and a display plaque. The plaque reads: “In memory of the brave men of the Montana, a vessel built in 1855, which set the record for the farthest north a sailing vessel had ever traveled, and whose crew endured the arctic cold and returned alive.”

Freddie Scott (April 24, 1933 - May 4, 2007) was an American soul and R&B singer. Much of his best-known work was produced by the songwriting team of Lieber & Stoller. Scott was born in Providence, Rhode Island and raised in New York City's Harlem neighborhood. He first started singing at the Greater Nazerene Baptist Church in Harlem and, in the 1950s, he joined a gospel group called the Consolators. After a family member spotted him playing the guitar and singing on a street corner, he auditioned for record producer Jack Richmond. Richmond signed Scott to a record deal with Columbia Records. Scott's first single, "I Don't Want to Cry", peaked at number 13 on the Billboard R&B chart in 1961. That same year, Scott released two other singles, "Without a Word of Warning" and "Lonely Man". While the singles failed to chart, they gained Scott some notoriety in the music industry and earned him an appearance on American Bandstand. Scott's first big break came in 1962 when he released "Cry to Me". The single was written and produced by Lieber & Stoller and reached number eight on the R&B chart. Following the success of "Cry to Me", Scott released the hit single, "Hey, Girl", which reached number five on both the Billboard Hot 100 and R&B charts. "Hey, Girl" secured Scott a recording contract with Shout Records. Throughout the remainder of the 1960s, Scott released several more sides with Lieber & Stoller. Some of his biggest hits included "Hey, Little Schoolgirl", "You Got What I Need", "I Don't Know What I'm Doing" and "Are You Lonely for Me Baby". After this string of hits, Scott moved to London, where he continued to record for a variety of labels, including MGM and Sue Records. In the 1970s, Scott began to focus primarily on gospel music. He released three albums during this time: Walkin' In The Light (1971), For You I Sing (1973) and Prime Time (1975). He also re-recorded some of his greatest hits with a gospel flavor. In 2007, Scott died of congestive heart failure at the Miriam Hospital in Providence at the age of 74. In January 2021, the case of Tang Man Sit v Capacious Investments Ltd, a dispute over a group of companies located in Hong Kong, came before the High Court. The case which was presided over by Justice Steward involved a claim by the Appellant, Tang Man Sit, who sought damages against the Respondent, Capacious Investments Ltd. The Appellant alleged that the Respondent had engaged in fraudulent and unfair trading practices, and that the damages amounted to over HK$20million. The Appellant was the director and shareholder of a group of companies located in Hong Kong which were incorporated in 2016. The businesses of the companies included property development, project marketing, trading of precious metal and currency, and other related activities. In August 2018, the Appellant entered into a consulting agreement with the Respondent which allowed the Respondent to have exclusive access to their information. However, the Appellant claimed that the Respondent used its access to their confidential documents for their own business gain, and not for the benefit of the Appellant. The Appellant argued that the Respondent had diverted business opportunities away from the Appellant’s companies to gain an unfair advantage. The Appellant claimed that through the use of their confidential information, the Respondent was able to secure lucrative business contracts with other parties. The Respondent, on the other hand, maintained that the consulting agreement was not the cause of the alleged losses, but that it was due to the Appellant’s lack of business acumen. The Respondent also claimed that at no time did they misuse their access to the Appellant’s confidential documents. The High Court took into consideration the arguments from both sides and examined the evidence presented. After careful review, the High Court found that the Respondent had acted in breach of trust and had abused their access to the Appellant’s confidential documents. The High Court also concluded that the Appellant had been caused to suffer loss and was entitled to a total sum of HK$20,947,800. The ruling in this case serves as an important reminder of the need for companies to comply with their compliance obligations when entering into consultancy agreements and when dealing with confidential information. It also demonstrates the need for companies to ensure they have mechanisms in place to protect themselves from fraudulent and unfair business practices.

Florian Verhaeghe is a Belgian Paralympic athlete and wheelchair basketball player from Belgium. He was born in Bruges in 1997 and grew up in the Bruges region of western Belgium. He has won seven gold medals at international competitions, including four at the Summer Paralympics and three at the World Wheelchair Basketball championships. Verhaeghe was born with a condition that left him a paraplegic and wheelchair-bound. This did not stop him from leading an active life, however, and he began playing wheelchair basketball on the Belgium national team at the age of 15. He graduated from high school in Bruges and enrolled in the University of Brussels, where he studied physical education. Verhaeghe made his Paralympic debut at the 2016 Summer Paralympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. he helped lead the Belgian national wheelchair basketball team to a Silver medal in the four-team tournament. This was Belgium’s first Paralympic medal in the sport. In addition to his success on the court, Verhaeghe was voted the Belgian Sports Personality of the Year in 2016 after leading his team to a gold medal at the European Championships that year. That same year, he entered the World Wheelchair Basketball Championships in Hamburg and helped Belgium to a Bronze medal performance. Verhaeghe was also a member of the Belgian squad that won bronze in the 2018 World Cup in Germany, and gold in the 2019 edition of the same tournament. Verhaeghe continues to inspire and motivate other people with disabilities to pursue their dreams and overcome obstacles. He has said that he sees his success as an opportunity to help others and to spread a message of hope and courage in the face of adversity. He has also been named as a member of the 2021 Paralympic torch relay team, in recognition of his contribution to wheelchair basketball.

Lillias Margaret Skene (1901 – 1982) was a British international swimming champion and teacher. She was the first female swimmer to represent Scotland at the Commonwealth Games and the first female to coach a British swimming team. Skene was born in Edinburgh, Scotland in 1901 and was educated at St George's School, Edinburgh. She took up swimming in 1917 and quickly rose through the ranks of competitive swimming, becoming the Scottish champion and a British record holder in 1922. She also represented Scotland at the Women's International Five Nations and the Women's International Six Nations swimming meets. In 1923, Skene was selected as the first female swimmer to represent Scotland at the inaugural British Empire Games, now known as the Commonwealth Games. She won gold in the 100 metre backstroke and a silver medal in the 4x100 relay. She also represented Scotland at the 1924 Summer Olympics in Paris. Skene went on to become the first female coach of a British swimming team. She coached the Britain team at the Women's International Six Nations Meet in 1932 and the first-ever Women's World Swimming Championships in 1954. In 1947, Skene was appointed as a swimming instructor at the Scottish Educational Council. She remained in the role until her retirement in 1969. Her teaching included beginners courses that were designed to help people to learn the basics of swimming and lifesaving skills. Skene was well known within the Scottish swimming community and in 1975 was awarded an MBE in recognition of her coaching and teaching services. In her retirement, Skene wrote several books on swimming lessons as well as a novel and a poetry collection. Skene passed away in 1982. Her legacy lives on through her works and the generations of swimmers she inspired.

Windhorse (film), released in 1998, is a Chinese drama film directed by Zhang Yimou. It is set in the early days of the Cultural Revolution and follows a young insurance broker, Pema, whose life descends into hardship due to political upheaval. The film opens with the arrival of Pema, a young Tibetan insurance broker, in Lhasa. Upon her arrival, she encounters a harsh and repressive atmosphere as the Chinese Cultural Revolution is quickly taking hold. Despite the severe restrictions Pema sees, she continues to maintain her faith and her responsibility to her aunt, whom she has come to serve. The story follows Pema as she is faced with a series of hardships due to the turbulence of the time. She is harassed by the local party committee and her attempts to earn a living are thwarted by the increasingly oppressive environment. As she is shifted from job to job and her life becomes increasingly difficult, her plight begins to earn her support from the public, who begin to label her the “windhorse”. Ultimately, Pema is pressured to leave her beloved home in order to escape further persecution, yet she finds a way to maintain her faith in her family and her people. While overseas, she discovers a way to remain true to her mission, and to preserve the spirit of her people. While the film takes us through an emotionally exhausting journey, it ultimately offers us a hopeful insight into the power of resilience, and a glimmer of hope in the darkness of a turbulent period. Windhorse was screened at the 1998 Cannes Film Festival. In the year of its release, the film won multiple awards, including the European Film Award for Best Film, the FIPRESCI Prize for Best Director, and the Grand Prix for Best Feature Film at the Montecatini International Festival of Young Cinema. Windhorse is a powerful film with a striking visual style, engaging characters and strong script. As such, it is a highly recommended watch for fans of Chinese cinema, and for anyone wishing to gain an insight into the hardships endured by the people of Tibet during the period of the Cultural Revolution.

Dennington is a small village and civil parish situated in the Waveney Valley, in the county of Suffolk, England. The village has a population of about 640. It is located about 13 miles (21 km) south of Norwich. The village can be traced back to at least 1050 A.D. and the Domesday Book of 1086, in which it is recorded as Denitone and belonging to William d'Ecouis. Dennington was changed to Deninctune by the 13th century. The village is nestled between two hills, known as the "Dennington Hills" and is known to be one of the most picturesque villages in the area. The church of St Mary, the oldest building in the village, dates back to the 12th century. It is a grade one listed building with a Norman font, 15th century oak screen and a remarkable stained glass window by Edward Burne-Jones. The village has a pub, a post office, a village hall, a primary school and a veterinary surgery. The former Dennington Railway, which was opened in 1887 was closed in 1966. The disused railway line serves as a path for walkers and cyclists and has provided an important ‘green corridor’ for wildlife. The village is home to the Dennington Wildlife and Bird Trust, a nature reserve which spans across two sites owned and managed by the Trust. The reserve consists of coppiced woodland, species-rich grassland, an old quarry and a lake. A wide variety of wildlife and plants can be found at the reserve, including dormice and otters. The village holds an annual flower show and the Dennington Village Society is active in promoting the interests of the local community. There are also regular talks, events and activities by various supports groups, such as Dennington Footpaths and Dennington Youth Group. The neighbouring village of Peasenhall is home to the Peasenhall Peasant, a scarecrow festival, also known as "The Big Scarecrow Weekend", which is held every year in May. In 2018, the village was chosen to be featured in the BBC half-hour documentary series Village of Dreams. The documentary followed local couples, who have been part of the community for generations, and showcased the lives and traditions of the village. The village is served by a regular bus service to nearby towns, with further rail and road links connecting it to Norwich and Ipswich. Overall, Dennington is a beautiful and peaceful village, combining traditional rural life with modern amenities and is home to a friendly and welcoming community.

Marco Passionei (born in February, 1940) is an Italian engineer, entrepreneur and philanthropist. He is best known as the chairman and head of the Passionei engineering company. Early life Passionei was born in Milan, Italy to a wealthy but reclusive family. From an early age he was instilled with a great passion for engineering and a strong work ethic, his parents ensuring that he was enrolled in the most prestigious schools available. Growing up, Passionei also developed a strong interest in the arts and humanities, showing a deep appreciation for culture and the natural world. Career Passionei began his professional career at the prestigious Fiat Engineering Institute in 1957, where he completed a degree in Mechanical Engineering. After graduation, he went on to work for a number of large engineering companies before eventually founding his own firm, Passionei Engineering, in 1965. At first the company focused on developing infrastructure and automation solutions for industry, but it soon grew to specialise in more offbeat engineering projects, with a number of inventions and patents to its name. Passionei's work has allowed his company to become a global leader in various engineering sectors, providing innovative solutions to problems ranging from transport to medical supplies. Philanthropy In addition to his work in engineering, Marco Passionei is an active philanthropist and has used his fortune to support a variety of charitable causes. To date, he has provided both financial and technical assistance to numerous organisations throughout the world, including a number of Italian-based charities. Passionei is widely recognised for his continued dedication to giving back to the community, having been recognised for his philanthropic work by both the Italian government and the United Nations. Personal Life Marco Passionei is married and has three children. In his spare time he enjoys spending time in the countryside, playing tennis and attending operas. He is a keen supporter of the arts and has previously donated a significant amount of money to a number of cultural institutions throughout Italy. Legacy Marco Passionei is an internationally recognised engineer, entrepreneur and philanthropist. He has dedicated his life to providing innovative engineering solutions and supporting charitable causes, gaining him a reputation both in Italy and across the world. His legacy is best expressed by his quote: “I may not be able to change the world, but I will do all I can to make the world a better place.”

Andreas Jonsson (born January 8, 1983) is a Swedish professional speedway rider who has competed in the Speedway Grand Prix series since 2004. Career Jonsson debuted in the World U-21 Championship in 1998, earning 11th place. He won the U-21 World Championship for the first time in 2002 and then went on to take the title again in 2003. Jonsson also achieved success in the European U-21 Championship, taking the title in 2002 as well. Jonsson made his Speedway Grand Prix debut in 2004 and won his first GP title in 2007 when he won the Italian SGP. That season he finished fourth overall in the championship standings, which remains his best finish to date. He has also taken several other podium finishes in the SGP series, including third place in 2007 In addition to his success in the Speedway Grand Prix series, Jonsson has achieved success in both Team and Individual racing. He was crowned Individual Speedway World Champion in 2010, and took the title again in 2011 and 2013. He has also won several Team Grand Prix with Sweden, including the 2014 edition. Outside of racing, Jonsson is also notable for his customised speedway motorcycles which he produces himself. He has gained a reputation for his mastery of the engineering involved in producing these bikes, and is said to be the innovator in this form of speedway technology. In addition, Jonsson has been involved in numerous charity initiatives, aiming to assist disadvantaged children in Sweden and internationally. Honours Grand Prix * Individual Speedway World Championship * Winner: 2010, 2011, 2013 * Speedway Grand Prix * Winner: 2007 Italian SGP * Team Speedway Grand Prix * Winner: 2014 Winner Individual European Championship * Winner: 2002 Under-21 U-21 World Championship * Winner: 2002, 2003

Ted Thorn is an American author, columnist, and retired podcaster. Born in the early twentieth century in the city of Kingston, New York, he graduated from Kingston High School and attended the University of Rochester. He worked as a technical writer and editor, first at IBM and then at the National Council of Teachers of English, in Indiana. He returned to New York and began writing full-time in the 1970s, initially as a columnist for several state newspapers and then as a freelance author. He has written more than 130 books and has contributed to numerous periodicals and other publications. Thorn is best known for his numerous books on popular culture. Among the topics he has tackled are gadgets, videos, the film industry, the internet, computers, the changing landscape of television, and comic books. Other books he has authored are on the topics of astrology, of folk medicine and mythology, of technology, and of many other topics. He also authored several books that explore the relationship between technology and people, focusing on the effects on a variety of age groups, such as children and the elderly. Thorn is founder and host of the long-running online podcast “Ted’s Thinkn’ Tank” offering practical insights on the use of technology in everyday life. The podcast was active from 2003 to 2018. He retired from it in 2018 to focus on his writing and other works. Although primarily known as an author, Ted Thorn is also an accomplished public speaker. He has shared his personal stories and insights with various audiences around the United States and abroad. He is the recipient of the university-wide University Teaching Award for Excellence (University of Central Florida, 2012), the Editorial Excellence Award from the New York Times (2007), and the Excellence in Education Award from the National Council of Teachers of English (2004). Ted Thorn has been an influential author in the realm of technology and popular culture for more than forty years. His works provide readers with deeper insights into the relationship between technology and culture, as well as an understanding of the history of the technologies we use in our daily lives. He continues to write and is currently working on a book examining the influence of technology on society.

William Edward Boeing (October 1, 1881 - September 28, 1956) was an American aviation pioneer and the founder of The Boeing Company, the world's largest aerospace company. He was born in Detroit, Michigan and attended school in Seattle, Washington. Boeing started his career at the age of 20 in the timber business, primarily in the Pacific Northwest. He founded the Pacific Aero Products Co. in 1916, which would eventually become the world-renowned Boeing Aircraft Company. His decision to start the aircraft company stemmed from his love of flying. He was a member of the starting group to fly powered flights in the Pacific Northwest in 1910. Throughout his career, Boeing's vision was to create airplanes that would revolutionize air transportation. His innovative designs resulted in a successful line of models that were significant advances on the aircraft being used at the time. He began developing his own aircraft designs in 1916, starting with the Model 1 Seaplane. He focused on building new innovative planes that were safer, more reliable and more efficient than those of his competition. This was achieved using cutting-edge and modern techniques that he had developed. Boeing and his team continued developing new models and designs for the next three decades, first with the development of the Model 15 monoplane, then the Model 40 and finally the groundbreaking Model 80. The Model 80 was Boeing’s first successful commercial aircraft and it was the first to use an all-metal fuselage. Boeing and his team also continued to make strides to develop aircraft models that could reach unprecedented speeds and heights. He and his team developed the Boeing 247D, the first twin-engine passenger airliner. This plane set speed and duration records and set the stage for modern airliner models. Boeing continued to serve as the visionary behind The Boeing Company until the mid-1950s when he retired at the age of 75. Throughout his company’s history, Boeing was able to leave an indelible mark on the history of aviation as one of its most innovative and influential figures. To this day, The Boeing Company remains one of the world’s leading aircraft developers, a legacy that William Edward Boeing left behind.

. Janssen is a very common surname of Dutch origin. The meaning of the name can be translated as Little John. The name is also found in other parts of the world in varying spellings, such as Jansen in Dutch, Johannsen in Germany, Jansson in Sweden, and Johnson in English. The spelling Janssen is the most common form of the name, accounting for over 20 percent of the total occurrences of the variety of spellings used. The first recorded use of Janssen was in the Netherlands prior to 700 A.D. It was a patronymic surname, meaning that it was derived from the given name of a father or ancestor. From that time on, it has remained a popular surname in the Netherlands, Germany, Sweden, and Denmark, as well as in other countries. The two most common spelling variations of the name are Jansen and Johnson. With the increase in immigrations to the United States after 1650, the name Johnson became more widely used in the country. The Johnson variation seen in the United States today is most likely derived from the Janssen spelling variant associated with European immigrants. Many people with the Janssen surname are now part of a global community. This includes prominent figures such as Johannes Janssen, the 19th‑century German historian, and Cor Janssen, the Dutch film director. Other well‑known individuals with the surname include the Dutch painters Dirck Dircksz Jansz (1562–1609) and Jan Adam Janssen (1615–1709), and the Dutch composer Joannes Antonius Janssen (1765–1837). The Janssen name lives on today. It is a popular choice for parents in the Netherlands, Germany, Sweden, and beyond. It remains a strong connection to the long history of immigrants who have made their home in many countries around the world. With its proud heritage preserved in the names of those who bear it, the Janssen surname will continue to be passed on to generations to come.

The Chausath Yogini Temple, located in the village of Ranipur Jharial in the Indian state of Odisha, is one of the most important archaeological sites of the Indian subcontinent. It is believed to have been built sometime during the eighth century CE and is dedicated to the goddess Mahishamardini. The temple is most notable for being the only surviving example of an octagonal temple from this era. It is also one of the few temples dedicated to the worship of the goddess Mahishamardini. It is also the only temple that has a full octagon instead of the usual partial octagon. The main temple consists of a shrine and a sanctum, both of which are surrounded by sixty-four freestanding shrines, all of which are dedicated to the Chausath Yogini or the sixty-four yoginis. Each of these shrines is intricately carved and is purported to contain a representation of a specific yogini. The design of the temple is unique and is considered to be one of the most important examples of the Nagara style of architecture. The entrance gate is adorned with brahma and gandhara sculptures and is believed to be symbolic of the goddess Mahishamardini's struggle against the demon Mahishasura. The main temple is constructed entirely of stone and brick, and consists of a single chamber. It has an open plan with a central raised platform with four columns, each topped with a carved capital. This platform is surrounded by sixteen small, devotional shrines, each facing an entrance gate. The design of the temple is intricately detailed and includes several carvings related to the teachings of Shaivism. The temple also has a few sculpted panels, which depict stories from Hindu mythology and the ramayana. These carvings serve as a reminder of the importance of mythology in Odisha culture. The Chausath Yogini temple has been declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO and is popularly referred to as the 'Sixty-four Yogini Temple' as it is one of the most important sites from the Pala-Sena era. The temple is an important example of the religious, cultural and archaeological heritage of India and is an important centre of tourist attraction.

Ascot Chang (born 1935) is a Hong Kong-based tailor, best known as the founder of a luxury bespoke tailoring house, Ascot Chang. Ascot was born in Hong Kong to a prosperous family in the clothing business. Growing up, he developed a deep interest in bespoke tailoring and honed his skills by working alongside local tailors. In 1962, he set up his own small tailoring business, which quickly gained a cult following due to the exceptional craftsmanship of his creations. His clientele included celebrities such as Bruce Lee, rock stars like Elton John, and renowned chefs like Paul Bocuse. In 2002, Ascot opened the doors to his flagship store in Hong Kong's Happy Valley. The space houses a tailoring team of 40 members and it is the only Ascot Chang store opened to date. The store is a new interpretation of the traditional Chinese tailor's shop, with 20 fitting rooms dedicated to custom tailoring. Ascot himself can be found in the store, offering his exclusive craftsmanship and design to clients. Ascot has won multiple awards for his extravagant tailoring and dedication to quality. Most recently in 2020, he won the prestigious Men's Fashion Award in the tailoring category. Ascot's designs are recognized for their exquisite craftsmanship, exquisite fabrics and attractive silhouettes, which have been modernised to fit the taste of a global audience. Ascot Chang has been recognized as a leader in modernizing classic tailoring. His work has gained a cult following and is seen as a benchmark for excellence in the industry. His designs feature in numerous editorials and can be found in luxury stores around the world. Ascot remains one of the last pioneers of traditional tailoring and leads a movement of modern artisans, preserving an elegant and timeless aesthetic.

Stefán Sölvi Pétursson (born 2004) is an Icelandic professional footballer who plays as a forward for AC Horsens in the Danish Superliga. Early life and career Stefán Sölvi Pétursson was born in Reykjavík, Iceland. He started his youth career with KFÍ in the Iceland youth league at the age of 11, where he soon became one of the top players. After two years at KFÍ, he moved to the Swedish club IFK Norrköping, where he continued to impress with his performances. He became the youngest-ever player to wear IFK Norrköping's first team jersey whilst only 15 years old. In 2021, Stefán made his first steps as a professional footballer by signing a contract with AC Horsens in Denmark. AC Horsens career Stefán Sölvi Pétursson made his debut for AC Horsens in a 3-1 away win against Lyngby BK on 3 March 2021. His first goal for the club came on 7 April 2021 against AGF Aarhus, helping his side win the game 2-0. In his first season with the Superliga side, Stefán scored 3 goals in 19 appearances. International career Stefán has represented the Icelandic national team on various youth levels and has been called up to the senior team, but he is yet to make his debut for his country. Style of play Stefán is a modern forward and excels with his versatility. He is a very pacy player, but he also has an eye for goal. He is an excellent dribbler and can play both in a wide position or up front. Personal life Stefán is the son of Pétur Gauti Pétursson, former Icelandic international footballer. Outside of football, Stefán is a passionate traveler. In his spare time., he loves to go hiking, spend time with his friends and family, and explore new cultures. External links * AC Horsens Profile (https://www.achorsens.dk/trup/stefan-solvi-petursson/) * Iceland National Team Profile (http://www.ksi.is/mot/leikmadur/?leikmadur=220440) Category:2004 births Category:Living people Category:Association football forwards Category:Icelandic footballers Category:AC Horsens players Category:Iceland youth international footballers

Hunted (2015 TV series) is a British spy drama series set in modern-day London. It follows a secret government agency called The Department which is tasked with catching and bringing down ten rogue agents known as "The Hunted". The series stars Melinda Michael as the leader of The Department, and Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje as the mysterious leader of The Hunted. It aired on BBC One from October 7 to December 9, 2015. Created by Frank Spotnitz, Hunted follows Sam Hunter, an intelligence operative (played by Melissa George) who goes off the grid after a mission gone wrong and is framed for a murder she did not commit. With the help of her new mentor Jack Lampligh (Akinnuoye-Agbaje) and a group of allies in The Department, Sam must elude capture and uncover a conspiracy that could threaten the balance of national security. The series has gained critical acclaim for its writing, acting, and complex narrative, with many comparing it to the popular British detective show Sherlock. It has twice been nominated for a BAFTA award in the Best Drama Series category in 2015 and 2016. Hunted also boasts an international cast, including Adam Rayner (as Aidan Marsh) and Stephen Dillane (as Ian Fowkes) from the United States, Morven Christie (as Zoe Morgan) from the United Kingdom, and Lex Shrapnel (as John Porter) from Australia. The ten-episode series originally aired in the United Kingdom on October 7, 2015 and was released on DVD and Blu-ray in 2016. It has since been made available for streaming on Netflix and Amazon Prime, along with iTunes, Google Play, and other digital platforms. Hunted is the latest addition to a growing list of spy-themed television shows, offering a unique perspective on espionage and the moral complexities of the world of covert operations. It is an entertaining and thought-provoking watch, and one that will no doubt keep fans guessing until the very end.

The Optimists of Nine Elms is a British punk rock band formed in 1976 in London, England. The band is composed of vocalist/guitarist Terry Scott, bassist/vocalist Terry Smith, drummer John Hatfield and guitarist/keyboardist Marianne "Maz" Aylward. The band was formed while they were all at school in London, beginning as a pure punk band, playing cover versions of other punk bands' songs. The band soon began writing and recording their own material, and released their first single, "No Time For Love", in March 1977. This was followed by their debut album, Nine Elms, in mid-1977. The album, which was praised for its witty songwriting and aggressive yet melodic sound, established the band's reputation in the punk rock scene, with the single "Lies That Kill" being a UK top twenty hit. The group's second album, Burn It Down, was released in 1980, and was widely lauded by both fans and critics as a darker, grittier record than its predecessor. The band's live shows were also becoming increasingly ambitious, with seven vocalists and multiple instruments creating an intense and powerful energy. The Optimists of Nine Elms toured extensively throughout the UK during this period, playing gigs in pubs and clubs as well as larger venues including the newly opened 9 Elms Station in London. Despite critical and commercial success, the band's third album, Lost in the Fire, flopped upon its release in 1983. Subsequently, the band split up, citing internal creative differences. Today, The Optimists of Nine Elms's music is still appreciated by fans of punk rock, and their influence can still be heard in more modern punk material. Although the band did not achieve the mass global recognition that the Sex Pistols or other punk acts did, it is regarded as one of the best punk bands to come out of Britain.

Viktor Esbensen (born July 24, 1975) is a Danish entrepreneur and investor. He is the founder and CEO of asset manager ROI Invest & Partners, which he founded in 2014. He has since become one of Denmark's most successful investment professionals and one of the leading names in Danish property investment. Esbensen received his business degree from the Copenhagen Business School in 1997. He then began his career in international banking, spending the first seven years of his career at Jyske Bank in Copenhagen, before working at other banks in Copenhagen, Paris and London. He returned to Copenhagen in 2008 and founded Investment Maeglerselskabet ROI Invest & Partners, where he currently serves as CEO. Esbensen has become known as a pioneer in Danish property investment, having developed a unique and highly successful strategy of diversifying property investments across domestic, international and opportunistic investments. He has delivered impressive returns for his clients, many of whom include high net-worth individuals, pension funds and family offices. Esbensen is a sought-after speaker in both Danish and international circles, and has been featured in important international publications such as Business Insider, Property Investor Europe and Investors' Era. He is also an active philanthropist, and serves on the board of the Danish branch of SOS-Kinderdorf International. Esbensen is married with two children, and lives in Copenhagen, Denmark. He enjoys spending time with his family, and is an avid sports fan. In his spare time he enjoys meditation, music, and travel.

The Bura Irrigation and Settlement Project (Kenya) is a major agricultural initiative in the Tana River area of southeastern Kenya. The project began in 1981 and aims to develop a more organized pattern of land use and settlement on the arid floodplain area of the Tana River Basin in order to better support local agricultural production. The project seeks to turn the Tana River Basin into an economically and environmentally sustainable region by providing improved access to land and water resources and reducing the spread of poverty and malnutrition. The project includes the development of infrastructure, such as roads, bridges and dams, as well as the provision of basic education and health care services to the rural population. The project is also focused on Land Management, Irrigation and Water Resources Development, which are aimed at facilitating agricultural production and improving the environment so that the rural population is better able to adapt to climate change. The Bura Irrigation and Settlement Project is implemented by the Kenyan Ministry of Agriculture and is funded mostly by the World Bank. The project is managed and supervised by the Provincial and District Directors and the Provincial Water Resources Board. The project involves the purchase of agricultural land in the Tana River Basin and the construction of terraces and irrigation canals to allow for better water management and to reduce the risk of flooding. It also involves the construction of roads, clinics, schools and other amenities, such as food storage facilities, to make life easier for the local population. In 2005, the Bura Irrigation and Settlement Project was extended to include eight new villages in the Tana River Basin. The project has seen improved agricultural productivity, increased access to educational and health services, improved nutrition levels among local populations, and better access to clean drinking water. The Bura Irrigation and Settlement Project has had a major impact on the quality of life in the Tana River Basin and has helped to reduce poverty levels and improve living conditions among the local population. The project has also helped to create jobs by providing training to local people in modern agricultural practices and helped to spread economic benefits to a wider group of people.

Michelstadt is an historic city located in the German state of Hesse. It is situated in the Odenwald, approximately 40 kilometers south of Frankfurt, and is part of the Darmstadt-Dieburg district. The city is one of the oldest in Hesse and has a long and storied history. The city is known for its timber-framed houses, many of which were built in the 16th and 17th centuries. The old town center is a designated conservation area and is home to the Rathaus (town hall), an old court, the Christopherus Fountain and numerous sculptures. Other attractions in the town include a Gothic-style Protestant church, which dates from the 14th century, as well as the ruins of Michelstadt Castle. Residents of Michelstadt are known as Michelstädters and the city is home to a variety of cultural and recreational activities. This includes a biannual medieval “Knight’s Fair”, a summer music festival, a Christmas market and monthly farmers markets. The city also hosts the annual Michelstadt Marathon and a historic car rally. The city's economy is largely based on tourism and agriculture, with some manufacturing. Michelstadt is home to a number of manufacturing companies, including hardware manufacturer Scholl, as well as chocolate manufacturer Hildenberg and cider producer Schmitz. The city is also home to the Michelstadt Historical Museum, which showcases the city’s history from prehistoric times through to the present day. The museum also features an extensive collection of artifacts from the 16th and 17th centuries. The city has a well-developed transportation system, due in part to its close proximity to the Rhine-Neckar-Odenwald railway network. The city is also home to the Michelstadt-Erbach Airport, which provides domestic flights to a number of cities. In addition to its tourism and manufacturing industries, Michelstadt also has a vibrant restaurant and nightlife scene, including a jazz club, a theater, several pubs, and several street festivals. Having an ancient history spanning more than a thousand years, Michelstadt is one of Germany's most popular tourist destinations.

Nathan Vaught (born October 15, 1975) is an American musician, songwriter, and producer. Growing up in Omaha, Nebraska, Vaught developed a passion for music at an early age and started playing the guitar at age 12. Attending the University Of Nebraska in the mid-90s, Vaught majored in recording technology while becoming part of the local music scene. In 1998, Vaught received a Grammy nomination for Best Engineered Album, Non-Classical while producing and engineering a multi-platinum selling album at Studio West in San Diego. After moving to Los Angeles in 1999, Vaught worked with Grammy award-winning producers and engineers which allowed further growth as a musician, eventually giving him the opportunity to establish his own production company NV Productions. As a guitarist and songwriter, Vaught has crafted numerous chart-topping tunes for artists such as Nicki Minaj, Daft Punk, 50 Cent, and T-Pain. As a producer he has created chart topping hits for John Legend, Madonna, and Justin Bieber. In 2011, Vaught and his production company were nominated for two Grammy Awards, “Lonely Boy” with The Black Keys and “Get Lucky” with Daft Punk, both of which won in their respective categories. A passionate philanthropist, Vaught often donates his time and energy to such organizations as Habitat for Humanity, MusiCares, and Little Kids Rock. He also hosts multiple workshops and seminars every year for aspiring producers and engineers at the esteemed Berklee College of Music in Boston. Vaught continues to find success and awards recognition in the music industry, along with updated techniques and methods for producing music. His aim is to provide his audience with a sense of joy and appreciation for the art of making music.

J. Michael Seyfert (born 1965) is an American composer and pianist who has written and performed an extensive catalog of solo works, chamber and orchestral works, and multimedia collaborations. He is well known for works that incorporate visual and theatrical elements, especially in works involving collaborations with photographers and fine-art visual media. Seyfert studied piano and classical music throughout his schooling. Ultimately, his musical development took him to the Oberlin Conservatory of Music, where, in the early 1990s, he graduated with a degree in composition. After college, Seyfert continued to expand his musical palette, incorporating individual elements of jazz, minimalism, rock and alternative music into his compositional approach. In the early 2000s, Seyfert composed a suite of works for solo piano, which featured solo works initially created for his 2010 debut album, Burying Light. From then until the present, his musical style has undergone various evolutions, from neoclassical works to post-rock based pieces. His most well-known works are from the "Painted Walls" series, which was a series of multimedia works created in collaboration with various visual media artists, such as painters and photographers. Seyfert has actively performed since the early 1990s, and has performed in such renowned concert spaces as Carnegie Hall, and has his works performed in exhibitions and festivals worldwide. In more recent years, he has developed a more improvisatory approach to performance, largely influenced by jazz, as well as rock and experimental approaches. Awards and honors which Seyfert has received include the Siegfried Kleinzeit and Kenneth Gaburo composition awards, and honors such as the ASCAP award for significant performances. He is also the recipient of the Elise Legrand professional development grant, as well as a grant from the Society of Composers Inc.. In 2017, he was awarded a composer's grant from the Ohio Arts Council. In addition to composing and performing, Seyfert has a number of academic positions, including professor at the Interlochen Center for the Arts, and guest artistic residency at various colleges and universities worldwide. He is also active in a wide array of large and small-scale media projects, including documentary film scoring, and interdisciplinary collaborations.

Gradets is a town located in Sliven Province, Bulgaria. It was founded during the Second Bulgarian Empire and is one of the oldest settlements in the region. It is situated on the eastern slopes of the Balkan Mountains, about 40 km from Sliven, the provincial capital. Gradets is best known for its fortress, believed to have been built in the 14th century under Hungarian rule. It was then given to the Bulgarian tsar Ivan Sratsimir during the early Ottoman period. Over the centuries, it has served as an important defense structure against both Ottoman and Byzantine forces. The fortress is a well preserved example of medieval military architecture and was restored in the 20th century. The town also features a number of other monuments and attractions. These include a 19th century clock tower, a memorial complex dedicated to the fallen of WWI, and several churches. There is also a large museum dedicated to the history and culture of the region. Gradets is a popular destination for tourists due to its cultural heritage, monuments, and attractions. It is home to many festivals and events throughout the year, including the “Open-air Medieval Festival”, “Christmas Fayre”, and “Traditional Overland Race”. There are numerous well-equipped guesthouses and hotels in the area offering excellent accommodation and amenities. In recent years, tourism has become an important contributor to the local economy. With its rich history, monuments, and hospitality, Gradets has become a popular destination for travelers. Gradets is a beautiful town that offers a unique mixture of history, nature, and culture. Its many attractions make it an ideal location for a memorable holiday in Bulgaria.

William Dunn (1958-2005) was a prominent American film director, screenwriter, and producer. He was born in Pennsylvania and was educated at both Yale University and the University of Pennsylvania, where he received a bachelor's degree in film and television production. Throughout his career, Dunn worked in a variety of different filmmaking genres, from drama to comedy to action-adventure. He often collaborated with over 20 actors, composers, and producers to create unique, memorable cinematic experiences. His credits included films such as Transformers, The Fast and the Furious, Road Trip, and The Scorpion King. Dunn's directing career spanned from 1994 to 2005, when he most notably directed four films, each extremely successful in their own right. He directed the 2003 film Daredevil, which starred Ben Affleck and Jennifer Garner; it was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Achievement in Visual Effects. He also wrote and directed the similarly successful 2004 action film The Chronicles of Riddick, starring Vin Diesel. After The Chronicles of Riddick, Dunn directed the 2005 action-thriller Ultraviolet. He had also written and co-produced the film with Dana Brunetti and Ric Kidney. The film, described as a blend of science fiction, action, and social commentary, was met with mixed reviews, but was considered a commercial success when it hit theaters in late 2005. Dunn died of a heart attack in late 2005, shortly after wrapping up work on Ultraviolet. The world of cinema mourned the loss of a talented, inventive filmmaker that had made his mark on the industry. His influence is still cherished today by actors, producers, filmmakers, and moviegoers alike. His legacy lives on through his films, which continue to be enjoyed by audiences around the world to this day. In his honor, a William Dunn Memorial Fund was established by his family and friends, which provides filmmaking scholarships to underprivileged young adults. William Dunn's death was a great loss to the film industry, but his memory and spirit will carry on with future generations of filmmakers.

Shergarh is a small village located in the Tharparkar district of the Sindh province in Pakistan. It lies on the right bank of the Mithi River, around 100 kilometers south of Mithi city. Shergarh is home to a small population of less than 2000 people. The majority of the population is Hindu, belonging to the Warriach, Banyat and other local clans. The village is an agro-based society, and is known for its production of various kinds of crops including wheat, mustard, chickpeas, sesame and cotton. The local language spoken by most of the people in Shergarh is Sindhi but some people also understand and speak the local Thari language. The village is also known for its historical significance. Almost 500 years ago, during the rule of Mir Ghulam Murtaza Talpur, Shergarh was established as a taluka (sub-division) in ROketa District. Later, it became a part of Thar and Parkar district. The famous Hindu temple of Shiva, dedicated to Lord Rama and Sita, is located in Shegrarh. This temple is said to have been built by Mir Ghulam Murtaza Talpur about 430 years ago. One of the most well-known inhabitants of this village was Raja Duleep Singh. Duleep Singh was popularly known as the "Maharaja of Punjab" and also the "Lion of Punjab". He was originally from Nepal and came to Shergarh in 1850. He supported the British Raj and was loyal to the British Raj even before the 1857 sepoy mutiny. Duleep Singh was a great admirer of the local people in Shergarh and frequently visited the village. Shergarh is renowned for its festivities, such as "Nag Panchimi", "Nandi Pujan" and other local festivals. The inhabitants of the village celebrate these festivals with great fanfare and enthusiasm, and these are also attended by people from nearby villages. In terms of education, Shergarh has two schools, one primary and one high school. The village also has a library where students can borrow books, magazines and newspapers. Shergarh is a peaceful village and provides a warm and friendly atmosphere to all who visit it. It is an ideal place to experience rural life and discover the culture and customs of Sindh.

The Arroyo Seco Bicycle Path is a 4.4 mile bike trail located in Los Angeles County, California. The trail runs between Angeles Crest Highway in La Cañada Flintridge and Garvey Avenue in El Monte, connecting the San Gabriel and Los Angeles Rivers. The bike path was announced in September 1971 and work started in 1976. The Arroyo Seco Bicycle Path is a multi-use recreation trail for cyclists, pedestrians, and joggers. The trail runs in a generally south to north direction, beginning at the Angeles Crest Highway in La Cañada Flintridge at an elevation of 1,200 feet. It runs parallel to a railroad right of way, the Rio Hondo tributary, and crosses under the 210 Freeway before crossing the San Gabriel River and ending at Garvey Avenue in the City of El Monte. Along the way, the trail passes through many parks and recreational areas including Hahamongna Watershed Park, San Rafael Hills, and Debs Park. The Arroyo Seco Bicycle Path is generally in good condition with wide, paved paths and bike lanes. The trail is mostly level and has very few hills, making it ideal for beginners, families, and leisure bikers. The path has a number of scenic overlooks with views of the San Gabriel Valley, from the La Cañada Flintridge side to the El Monte side. The trail is frequently used by cyclists who want to get away from city riding and enjoy nature. The trail is popular with locals and tourists alike who enjoy the peaceful setting and easy terrain. In addition to the many parks along the path, it passes several sports complexes and golf courses. During the summer months, the trail is often busy with cyclists, runners, and walkers. The Arroyo Seco Bicycle Path is a great way for cyclists to explore and appreciate the beauty of Los Angeles. The trail provides a unique chance to enjoy the outdoors and get some exercise without having to leave the city.

Terri & Monica were a female R&B duo, composed of Terri Robinson and Monica Boyd, signed to Motown Records in the mid-1990s. Terri & Monica began working together while they were undergraduates at University of California Los Angeles. Their time working together proved to be fruitful as, in 1995, they managed to catch the attention of Berry Gordy’s, founder of Motown Records, son who, after hearing their demo tapes, signed them to Motown. In 1996, their debut album, Between the Sheets, was released followed by the lead single “Ain’t Nobody.” The single would peak at sixteen on the Billboard Hot R&B Singles chart, as well as earning Terri & Monica a nomination for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals at the 37th Annual Grammy Awards. The video for “Ain’t Nobody” peaked at number one on the Billboard Top 40 Hits video chart and number two on Billboard’s R&B chart. The album went on to reach double platinum selling success, selling over two million copies in the United States. The success of their debut single “Ain’t Nobody,” propelled the duo to further success with their second single, “What Do I Do?”, also achieving success on the Billboard Hot R&B Singles chart peaking at number five. The third single, “Take Me There” peaked at number forty-eight on the same chart. As a result of their success, Terri & Monica opened for artists such as Mariah Carey, Toni Braxton, and cotemporaries SWV, and went on tour alongside Monica, Tyrese, and TLC. In 2000, Terri & Monica released their second album, “The Makings of a Mistress.” Despite their returning success, the album failed to reach the same levels of success as their first, and the duo eventually disbanded. Both members of the duo have gone on to have successful solo careers within the R&B genre and have collaborated with other notable singers such as Lauryn Hill and Erykah Badu. Overall, Terri & Monica’s success as a duo was short but memorable, attaining gold and platinum selling albums and recognition from the music industry with their hits. They were successful enough to kickstart their solo careers and remain significant figures in the music industry in recent decades.

Alvin Jones (born June 16, 1998) is an American professional basketball player for the Long Island Nets of the NBA G League. He played college basketball for the University of Nevada. During his four-year career at Nevada, Jones emerged as one of the program's most reliable players, compiling a total of 903 career points. In his senior year, he led the team in scoring (15.3 points per game) and was named an All-Mountain West Honorable Mention. He became the first player in college basketball history to make over 1000 points and 800 rebounds in the same season. Following the completion of his collegiate career, Jones declared for the 2020 NBA Draft. After going undrafted, he signed with the Long Island Nets of the NBA G League for the 2020–21 season. At Nevada, Jones showcased his ability to become a reliable shooter. During his time at the university, he developed a reputation of expertise in shooting from beyond the arc, a testament to his dedication to improving his long-range shooting abilities. While at Nevada, Jones shot 37.3 percent from beyond the arc. He also showcased the ability to drive to the basket and play excellent defense. Off the court, Jones was known as a passionate competitor on the court but also a jovial presence in the locker room. He was well-liked by his teammates and coaches who viewed him as an invaluable mentor and leader. At the professional level, Jones is still developing his game and trying to find a niche. He has continued to hone his shooting expertise and has also worked on sharpening his ball-handling and playmaking abilities. His dedication to his craft is evidenced by the fact that he continues to diligently work on his game in every practice and during every game. Jones is expected to play a key role off the bench for Long Island, but his ultimate impact will depend on how quickly he can make the adjustment from the college game to the professional level. As a young player, he understands the importance of being able to rely on his high basketball IQ and work ethic to help him in the long term. Overall, Alvin Jones is a young and talented player who is just beginning to tap into his full potential. His dedication to the game both on and off the court has been evident, and he looks to be an exciting player to keep an eye on in the future. Only time will tell what kind of impact Jones can have in the G League and beyond.

Thomas O'Beirne (1944-2014) was an Irish-born Canadian politician and lawyer. He was the Member of Parliament for Toronto Centre for a single term. O'Beirne was born in Dublin in 1944, and moved to Canada in 1966. He attended the University of Toronto where he studied political science and law, graduating in 1973. Following graduation he worked with the Attorney General of Ontario as well as a variety of non-profit organisations. In 1977, O'Beirne entered provincial politics and was elected to the Legislative Assembly of Ontario representing the riding of York Centre. He held this seat until 1981 when he sought election to Parliament and was elected in the riding of Toronto Centre. His win in Toronto Centre was controversial, with some alleging vote fraud. O'Beirne denied the claims and was subsequently cleared of any wrongdoing. O'Beirne served one term as a Member of Parliament until he was defeated in the 1984 federal election, in part due to his party's (Joe Clark's Progressive Conservatives) unpopularity. Despite his defeat, O'Beirne remained active in politics and was appointed to Joe Clark's Cabinet in 1986 as the Minister for Public Works and Supply. In later life, O'Beirne moved to Vancouver and continued to practice as a lawyer. He died in 2014 at the age of 70. O'Beirne was a respected figure in politics, and a firm believer in volunteerism and public service. Following his death, Prime Minister Stephen Harper issued a statement praising O'Beirne's lifetime commitment to public service. He was also honoured by the President of Ireland, Dr. Michael D. Higgins, who stated that "Thomas O'Beirne's dedication to the advancement of Canada in the world was exemplary". A memorial service was held at St. Paul's Basilica in Toronto, and O'Beirne was remembered by friends, family and colleagues as a passionate, dedicated and hardworking leader. In 2015, his alma mater, the University of Toronto, honored O'Beirne posthumously by establishing the Thomas O’Beirne Women in Law and Leadership Initiative. This initiative provides leadership programming and financial support for Canadian women who wish to pursue a legal career. It is a lasting tribute to O’Beirne's passion for inclusion and promotion of diversity in Canada. Thomas O'Beirne's thought-provoking life, hard work, and commitment to public service will remain an example for generations of Canadians to come.

Brian Barnes (born August 4, 1935) is a retired professional baseball player who had a successful Major League career spanning from 1965 to 1979. He played the majority of his career in center field and was known for his defensive prowess, earning two Gold Glove awards during his time in the Major Leagues. Barnes was born in April, 1935 in Beckley, West Virginia and was raised in Detroit, Michigan. He attended the University of Michigan and was signed as an amateur free agent by the Baltimore Orioles in 1955. Barnes spent the next eight years in the Minor Leagues before making his Major League debut in 1965. In his rookie season, Barnes played in 134 games and posted a .259 batting average with 6 home runs and 36 runs batted in. He primarily served as a reserve and platoon bat hitting primarily against left-handed pitchers. His best season came in 1972 when he posted a career-high .296 batting average with 11 home runs and 54 RBI's making him an All-Star selection for the first time that season. Barnes won two consecutive Gold Glove awards in 1976 and 1977 as he began to take over the reigns of the number one center fielder for the Orioles. He also was an active participant in the World Series for Baltimore in both 1979 and 1983 though his personal stats were not impressive in comparison to other members of the team. Barnes retired from baseball after the 1983 season having played 19 consecutive seasons in the Majors. He finished his career with 1,184 hits and .258 batting average and had a total of 73 home runs and 492 RBI's. After baseball, Barnes became a successful real estate broker, owning his own business. He was inducted into the Greater Baltimore chapter of the Alabama Sports Hall of Fame in 2004. Barnes is still a popular name in Baltimore and is remembered as a leader on the Orioles throughout his time there. He is also remembered for his dedication and hard work on the field earning him the respect of millions of Baltimore sports fans.

The European Bridge League (EBL) is an international organization dedicated to promoting and developing contract bridge throughout Europe. It is a member of the World Bridge Federation (WBF) and exists as an independent, non-profit organization with the mission "to promote and develop bridge in Europe and coordinate activities." As of 2019, the EBL has 24 full members and 7 associate members and is the official governing body of bridge throughout the continent. The history of the EBL goes back to 1923, when a bridge tournament was held in Lausanne, Switzerland. At the end of the tournament, representatives from some of the represented countries agreed to form the International Bridge League (IBL). The IBL had 13 members, including Belgium, Switzerland, Austria, the Netherlands, and France. The IBL quickly became the main body for organizing, announcing, controlling, and timing tournaments throughout Europe. In 1925, the IBL changed its name to the European Bridge League and began offering player registrations and the accreditation of bridge clubs for the first time. Over the years, the EBL has seen its membership increase as more countries set up their own national bridge organizations. Throughout the decades, it has remained fundamental to the growth of Bridge in Europe, organizing and hosting several international tournaments, such as the World Team Championships and the World Championships for National Teams. The EBL's main objective is to ensure the highest possible bridge playing standards in the countries of Europe and to promote bridge in Europe. To do this, the EBL maintains an effective network of national governing bodies, sponsors international events, and sanctions tournaments. The EBL publishes a monthly magazine called "Bridge Europe". The magazine includes announcements, special notices and articles on a variety of topics related to Bridge in general and the EBL in particular. The organization also hosts an annual European Bridge Congress and runs a European Champions Club (ECC) Tournament held in different locations across Europe. The EBL works in partnership with many organizations both within the bridge community, such as the World Teams Championships, and outside the bridge community, such as the International Olympic Committee. The European Bridge League is currently headed by President Thomas Wirén and General Manager Nicolas Hammond. It is headquartered in Lausanne, Switzerland. The EBL is a major force in the promotion and development of the game of Bridge in Europe and the world. Through its efforts and enthusiasm, Bridge is growing in popularity throughout the continent, making it an exciting time to be a bridge player in Europe.

. Marian Robertson Wilson (May 23, 1917 – September 16, 2014) was an American choreographer and teacher of modern dance. She was a pioneer of modern dance in the San Francisco Bay Area and her work was included in festivals and museums between the 1950s and 1990s. Born on May 23, 1917 in Cleveland, Ohio, Wilson attended the Cleveland Institute of Music. She continued her studies of modern dance and composition at the Juilliard School of Music in New York City. After two years at Juilliard, she moved to San Francisco in 1941 to join the Humphrey-Weidman Dance Company as a dancer. After her time as a dancer, Wilson worked independently as a choreographer and teacher. In 1947, Wilson started teaching modern dance at the San Francisco Dance Library, a studio on Powell Street in San Francisco. It soon became known for its avant-garde programming. It was at the Dance Library that Wilson created some of her most well-known works, including Dances for Concerts (1948), Jazz Standard Settings (1951), and Robotry (1953). Wilson's work was highly influential in the development of modern dance in the San Francisco Bay Area. Her choreography was included in provincial and national festival and performed at venues such as the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, the Contemporary Arts Museum Houston, and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. In addition to her work as a choreographer and teacher, Wilson served as a mentor to many Bay Area dancers and choreographers, such as Anna Halprin and Jean Erdman. She was also a founding member of the San Francisco Dance Archives, which was established in 1989 to preserve the history of modern dance in the Bay Area. Wilson died on September 16, 2014 in San Francisco. She was 97. Today, her legacy lives on in her many contributions to the development of modern dance as an art form.

Egegaz Aliağa LNG Storage Facility is a natural gas storage and liquefaction facility located near the port town of Aliağa, İzmir Province in Turkey, about 70 kilometres (43 mi) north of İzmir. The storage facility is owned and operated by Egegaz B.V, a joint venture between the State Oil Company of the Republic of Azerbaijan (SOCAR) and Turcas Petrol. Established in 2017, the facility consists of two 22,000 cubic metre (790,000 cu ft) above-ground LNG tanks, each with a design pressure of 7.5 bar and a maximum working pressure of 3.6 bar. Additionally, the facility is connected to a 60,000 cubic metre (2,100,000 cu ft) underground LNG storage tank. Combined, the tanks hold enough natural gas to meet the daily needs of 6 million households for a period of one month. The facility has a storage capacity of 140,000 cubic metres (4,907,850 cu ft) and can store up to 90,000 tonnes of LNG. It also features liquefaction and regasification facilities, allowing for the storage and transport of LNG, as well as the rapid expansion of LNG trade between Turkey and the Republic of Azerbaijan. The facility was built at a cost of US$110 million and provides Turkey with greater energy security, allowing it to store and transport natural gas when demand is highest. Additionally, the convenient access to the Egegaz Aliağa LNG Storage Facility has allowed for the creation of a natural gas hub, creating additional opportunities for Turkey’s energy sector, while generating jobs and income in the surrounding areas. The Egegaz Aliağa LNG Storage Facility has been heralded as an important step forward for energy security in the region. The strategic location of the facility, combined with its efficient operation, has made it an integral part of the regional energy industry, allowing for greater energy diversification and reliability, and offering an important option for back-up and seasonal storage. The facility is one of several energy projects in the area, including the construction of a floating storage and regasification unit at the port of Aliaga, which is intended to provide on-demand natural gas supplies to the Turkish market. With its strong focus on safety, sustainability, and innovative technologies, the Egegaz Aliağa LNG Storage Facility helps ensure a safe, secure, and reliable natural gas supply in the region. By providing Turkey with an additional source of natural gas, it helps to further diversify the country’s energy mix, while contributing to the protection of the environment.

Hale Ranch, located in the town of Vista, California, is a large property brimming with history and unique features. It is the home of a picturesque equestrian facility that hosts horse shows, event clinics, and riding lessons, among other activities. The property also features barns, an outdoor arena, pastures and paddocks, a round pen, and miles of riding trails. The history of Hale Ranch dates back to the 1920s, when John and Clara Hale bought the sprawling acreage. The Hales were avid horse enthusiasts and quickly established a premier hunter/jumper facility. By the 1970s, the ranch had become a regional hub of horsemanship, with many of the top equestrians in California training there. In the 1980s, the ranch was sold to new owners and transformed into an arena that hosted a variety of horse shows from small local events to larger large-scale competitions. In subsequent years, the facility increased its operations to include riding lessons, breeding services, foaling services, and more. Hale Ranch has a well-deserved reputation for its top-notch equestrian center and the quality of its horses. The barns at Hale Ranch feature the best amenities and facilities, as well as top-tier equine care. The riding arenas at the facility are excellent, with immaculate footing and a flat, level surface.
