The expansive pastures and paddocks, combined with the miles of trails, offer riders plenty of room to explore and ride. Hale Ranch continues to be a highly-regarded equestrian facility today. The staff members are experienced and knowledgeable, and the professional trainers at the ranch provide high quality instruction and guidance. The facility frequently hosts clinics and special events, making the ranch an attractive option for equestrians of all levels. The beauty, charm, and history of Hale Ranch make it a unique and special place. It has been a fixture in the equestrian community for many years and is sure to remain a popular destination for years to come.

GM Defense is an American defense business unit of General Motors Company focused on providing small arms, military vehicles, and ammunition to the United States and other allied nations. Established in 2018, it is the newest division of GM and is located in Sterling Heights, Michigan. The division focuses on both defense and commercial sales, specifically creating military vehicles to meet customer needs. GM Defense primarily develops technology, designs, and builds their portfolio of small arms and weapon systems. GM Defense offers expertise in automotive engineering, advanced manufacturing, and military-grade protection. Their products include battlefield jeeps, vehicles with reconfigured suspension, and special fire supply and detection systems. GM Defense is a leading supplier to the US military, providing weapons solutions in tactical mobility, unmanned ground systems, mobility kits, stabilizers and more. GM Defense also produces several combat vehicles and systems, including the Joint Light Tactical Vehicle, the High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle, and the Infantry Squad Vehicle. In addition, GM Defense provides life cycle support services for GM vehicles, such as maintenance, replacement, and modifications of components. GM Defense manufactures and offers a variety of small arms and ammunition to the US military, including the M16 rifle and M4 carbine. GM Defense also makes a variety of ammunition for the military, such as armor-piercing rounds, sniper rounds, and tracer rounds. The division is also responsible for providing spares and replacement parts for existing weapons and ammunition. GM Defense focuses on providing the US military with the advanced protection and technology it needs to stay ahead of threats and challenges. The division works with government agencies to create, develop, and deliver the most current and sophisticated solutions. GM Defense is committed to continuous product improvement, utilizing cutting-edge technologies to produce the most innovative and reliable products. GM Defense also works to be socially responsible by committing to ethical practices in their production and by contributing to community initiatives.

Yan Han (born December 3, 1975) is a Chinese contemporary artist best known for his large-scale paintings on canvas. He is recognized for his unique painting style which blends traditional Chinese ink art with abstract elements. Born in Yantai, Shangdong Province, China, he has lived and worked in Beijing since 2001. Han's works often reflect themes of exploration, rebellion, and his own life. For instance, his Blue Sky series is a result of his exploration of the relationship between painting and the infinite sky. His Black & White series is composed of black and white squares which express his views on society and the state of life. In addition to his painting work, Han is also known for his sculpture and photography. His sculptures often explore the relationship between humans and nature, as well as between objects and emotions. His photography often portrays aspects of modern Chinese life. Han has exhibited his work in numerous solo exhibitions both in China and abroad. He has also participated in a number of group exhibitions. His works have been collected by major museums and art galleries including the Beijing Art Museum, the Shanghai Urban Planning Center, and the Guangdong Art Museum. In 2017, Yan was appointed as a Star Creation Plan artist by China Central Academy of Fine Arts. The program supports contemporary art in China and encourages collaboration and exchange between Chinese and foreign artists. Han currently lives and works in Beijing. He continues to explore themes of identity, exploration, and rebellion in his artwork. He has been featured in various media outlets such as CCTV and the Art Newspaper China. In 2019, his artwork was purchased by IBM to be displayed in the IBM office in Shenzhen, China.

Seomun Market (Korean: 서문시장 or 서문 도시장) is a large traditional market located in Daegu, South Korea. It is one of the four great markets in the country, along with Dongdaemun, Namdaemun, and Chilseong Market. Seomun Market is the largest traditional market in Daegu and the fourth largest in South Korea. Seomun Market's exact date of origin is unknown, but it has been known to be around since the 1920s. There used to be a gate called "Seo-mun", which means "West Market Gate", where the market got its current name. Seomun Market started out as a small market selling food and groceries in the early days, but it has since grown to become a large traditional market selling a wide range of products. The market expanded significantly in 2006, covering an area of 28,995 m2 and consisting of some 8,000 stores, making it the second largest market in South Korea. The market has four main divisions: the cloth market, food and groceries, restaurants, and featured brands. The cloth market has various clothing stores, tailors and fabric shops, with items ranging from casual to luxurious clothing, as well as traditional Korean clothing. The food and groceries market sells seafood, fresh fruits and vegetables, dried foods, groceries, other food items and kitchenware. It is the largest of the food markets in Daegu, and is considered to be a foodie paradise. The restaurant section has a variety of South Korean, Japanese and Chinese food stores, ranging from stylish restaurants to lone food carts. As for the featured brands, there are many local stores, including large department stores, special boutiques and shopping malls. Seomun Market hosts various cultural events year-round, such as the Seomunga Festival, the Seomun Night Market, and the Daegu Music Festival. Due to its vibrant atmosphere and competitive prices, the market has become a major tourist attraction in Daegu. In conclusion, Seomun Market is an important traditional market in Daegu and South Korea, that carries an array of products and experiences. It is where locals and tourists alike can enjoy shopping, eating, and various cultural events.

10551 Göteborg is a Swedish town located in the province of Västra Götaland. It is situated on the southern shore of Lake Vänern, the largest lake in Sweden, and is part of the municipality of Skövde. The population of 10551 Göteborg is approximately 5,000 people, making it one of the smaller towns in the province. The town is serviced by the line 5 of the Göteborgs Spårväg, making it a convenient location to live for commuters and travellers. The town is home to two historic churches, the Maria Magdalena Church and the Stora Torg, both of which date back to the late 19th century. There are also a few small museums in the town, including the Skøvde Museum and the Norrala Folk Museum. The manorial estate of Norrala, located near the town, is also a popular tourist attraction and is home to a large collection of artefacts related to the ancient Norse and Svear people. In recent years the town has seen an increase in the number of bars, restaurants and other entertainment venues. 10551 Göteborg is also popular amongst the younger demographic due to its proximity to the larger cities of Göteborg and Stockholm, both of which provide excellent nightlife and entertainment offerings. The town is also home to many cultural events such as the Öxeryda Festival, held every year in June, which features a mix of local and international acts. It is also the setting of the annual 10551 Göteborg International Documentary Film Festival, which attracts visitors from around the world. In recent years 10551 Göteborg has become one of the most desirable tourist destinations in Sweden, due to its peaceful nature, stunning views of the lake, and laid-back atmosphere. Visitors come to explore the town’s picturesque streets, delicious eateries, and range of activities, making it a popular destination for both locals and tourists alike. The town has something to offer everyone, whether you’re seeking relaxation or excitement. 10551 Göteborg is the perfect holiday spot for any traveller looking to explore the beauty of Sweden.

. The 1956 United States Senate election in Illinois took place on November 6, 1956. Incumbent Republican United States Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen won re-election to a third term in office over Democratic challenger Paul Douglas, a former University of Chicago economics professor and United States Senator from 1949 to 1967. Securing 55.90% of the vote, Dirksen defeated Douglas by a substantial margin of 131,188 votes. Dirksen, who was first elected to the United States Senate in 1950, was a popular figure at the time of the election. While not untroubled in his bid for re-election, his large lead in the polls and strong support from incumbent President Dwight D. Eisenhower enabled Dirksen to prevail in the election with comparative ease. Douglas, a Democratic politician, had previously served as a United States Senator from Illinois from 1949 to 1967. He challenged Dirksen’s re-election bid in 1956, and attended a series of political forums and debates during the campaign. His effort failed, however, and he was unable to overtake the incumbent Senator’s commanding lead. In the end, Dirksen’s victory was largely attributable to strong support from President Eisenhower, who campaigned for his re-election bid in Illinois in the months leading up to the election, as well as Dirksen’s well-known popularity among the state’s voters. Dirksen’s victory would represent the fourth of his six consecutive terms in the United States Senate. The election saw moderate voter turnout, with 2,282,863 ballots counted across the state. The result of the election, seeing the re-election of Everett McKinley Dirksen, has been described as a “safe” win. It marked the final United States Senate election in the state of Illinois prior to the ratification of the 17th Amendment to the United States Constitution, which initiated direct popular elections for the chamber. Dirksen’s legacy would endure for generations and, among other things, he is remembered for his leadership in the passage of landmark legislation, such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964. In the following years, he continued to serve his constituents in the United States Senate until his death in 1969.

Betty Hutton (born Elizabeth June Thornburg; February 26, 1921 - March 11, 2007) was an American actress and singer of stage, screen, and television. She was known for her zany comedic roles in films such as The Miracle of Morgan's Creek (1944) and Annie Get Your Gun (1950). Hutton was born in Battle Creek, Michigan, and grew up in the bright lights of vaudeville. Her father (a vaudeville actor and comedian) guided her career until his death in 1940 when she was 19. After his passing, she came under the direction of fellow Battle Creek resident Charles Z. Taft, who instructed her to do more singing and dancing on the stage, instead of her usual funny straight lines. This move paid off, and Hutton soon made her Broadway debut. In 1942, Hutton caught the attention of Paramount Pictures and was signed to a contract. She was cast in The Miracle of Morgan's Creek (1944) starring Eddie Bracken and Dennis O'Keefe. It was a hit, and Hutton appeared in several other films, including Incendiary Blonde (1945), Hold That Blonde! (1945), and Cross My Heart (1946). Her star reached its zenith in 1950 with the musical comedy Annie Get Your Gun, for which she received an Academy Award nomination for Best Actress. The film was a huge success, grossing more than $7 million at the box office, making it one of the highest-grossing movies of 1950. Hutton did not fare as well in the following years. Her star began to wane, and in 1953 she was nominated for a Golden Globe for Most Promising Female Newcomer. Though she had a few hit movies after that, her career was in decline by the end of the 1950s. She left Hollywood for a few years and made a few guest appearances on TV shows, including The Red Skelton Show in 1960. In 1961, she attempted a comeback, but her career never fully recovered. From then on, she made appearances on stage and television, making guest appearances on variety shows and appearing in summer stock. In 1965, Hutton was cast in the Broadway version of Barefoot in the Park, opposite Robert Redford. Hutton was married four times and had one daughter. She died of natural causes on March 11, 2007, in Palm Springs, California. Though her career may have been short-lived, she made a lasting impression on the cinematic world. Her zany comedic roles are still fondly remembered by audiences and will continue to live on in her films.

Apóstoles is a city in the province of Misiones, Argentina. It is the largest city in the province, located at 832 kilometres from Buenos Aires and 130 kilometres from the provincial capital, Posadas. With a population of around 81,000 inhabitants (according to the 2010 census), it is the third most populated city in the Mesopotamian Region after Posadas and Oberá. Apóstoles, formerly known as San Pedro Misiones, is built along the banks of the Uruguay river and is the point of convergence of the three main highways that connect the northwest of Misiones with the rest of the country. This makes the city a pole of attraction in the area, being practically the only urban center between Posadas and the Paraguayan cities. In Apóstoles there is a wide range of tourist attractions, such as the Iguazú River Tour, the Swim Park, the Cellar Museum, the Port of Apóstoles, the Lover's Park, the Shrine of Our Lady of Lourdes and the Piedras Encimadas Hills. The city's main project is the Project of the Apóstoles Port, which aims to facilitate the navigation between the Argentine and Paraguayan ports. The project consists of two port complexes, one of which receives cargo and cargo vessels, and the other that receives passenger boats. Apóstoles is home to multiple sports and entertainment venues, including two soccer stadiums, two basketball courts and two tennis courts. The city is also home to an important convention and exhibition center, which holds a number of national and international events every year. A large section of the city is currently working on green projects, aiming to transform Apóstoles into an eco-city. The project includes the construction of a recycling plant, solar energy generation and reforestation of the banks of the Uruguay river. The city's economy is mainly based on agriculture, livestock and tourism, but recently there have been some industrial projects that have been initiated with the aim of further diversifying the economic activity of the city. Apóstoles remains one of the main urban centers in Misiones, and its efficient network of public transport and its proximity to Paraguay makes it an attractive destination for tourists from all over the world.

Fred Perrett (born c. 1954) is an American electric blues guitarist and singer, who is best known as a longtime sideman for the influential Chicago blues artist Jimmy Dawkins. Perrett was born and raised in the city of Chicago, and was first introduced to blues music by his uncle, the bassist and harmonica player Hubert Sumlin. Perrett began to play the guitar by the early 1970s and joined local blues groups, and soon he became part of Dawkins’ band. In the following years, Perrett went on to play alongside major names in blues such as Eddie Taylor, Robert Nighthawk, and Willie Dixon. Together with Dawkins’ band, he travelled between the United States and Europe, playing the noted blues venues around the world. In addition to his work as a sideman, Perrett has released three solo albums. His debut was the 1995 release What Can I Tell You, which was followed by Remember Me in 2001. The last studio album was the 2013 release Trouble With Me, which featured Dawkins, Hubert Sumlin, organist Billy Branch, and saxophonist Eddie Shaw among other musicians. Throughout his career, Perrett’s musical style has been influenced by the classic electric blues and has been highly acclaimed by music critics. Besides his main influence from Jimmy Dawkins, he is also influenced by guitar legends such as Magic Sam, Otis Rush, and T-Bone Walker. Apart from his musical career, Perrett also holds a degree in civil engineering from the University of Illinois, where he graduated in 1981. He is now married and has three children, and mainly resides in Danville, California. In recent years, Perrett has been active in performing throughout the United States, and in Europe alongside Dawkins’ band. Besides his own albums and tours, he has also been featured on a growing number of recordings, making him a formidable mainstay of electric blues.

Ole Rasmussen (born 9 October 1952, in Aarhus, Denmark) is a former Danish footballer and manager. Rasmussen began his professional career with hometown side Aarhus GF in 1971. He played for AGF for the next seven years, becoming one of the most recognised Danish footballers in that period. Rasmussen helped the team win the 1978 Danish Cup, scoring the decisive goal in the final, 2–1 against AB. Rasmussen decided to leave AGF in 1978 after his father's suggestion, and joined Belgian club R.S.C. Anderlecht in August. He was a prominent part of the team for the next five years, winning the Belgian League title in 1980–81 and the 1983–84 UEFA Cup. He was especially known at the club for his free kicks and spectacular goals. Rasmussen left Anderlecht in August 1983, having captained the team since 1981, and returned to AGF, where he played an additional four seasons. His last professional match was in July 1987, as AGF won the 1987 Danish Cup. After his playing career ended in 1987, Rasmussen became a coach in 1988, selecting young talents and helping them reach the professional level. He managed AGF and the Faroe Islands national team between 1994 and 1996, then returned to AGF in 1997, helping the team win the 1999 Danish Cup. Rasmussen was named AGF's director of football in 2011. Rasmussen was a member of the Denmark national under-21 team between 1974 and 1976. He was not capped for the Denmark national team, but was included in the team's callup on two occasions in 1974. Rasmussen is married to Lotte and has three children. He is also an ambassador for AGF, as well as a consultant for Danish Football Association.

Surya Raj Acharya is a Nepalese film director, who is known for his work in the entertainment and media industry of Nepal. Born in Kathmandu, Nepal on the 19th of August 1975, he started his career in the mid-90s and has since made several successful films and music videos alongside various lyrical pieces. A highly accomplished film director of recent times, Acharya's debut feature film, Maun ( 2007 ) was a runaway box-office hit in Nepal and marked him as an established filmmaker. It was the first Nepali movie to explore the genre of 'Children's Films' which was quite a revolutionary step in the Nepali film industry. After Maun, he went on to make a series of other successful films such as Honda Chha Chhadke ( 2008 ), Swayambhu ( 2012 ) and Mohani ( 2016 ). He has been widely acclaimed for his direction and vision in the field of film making and has also been awarded numerous awards from national film festivals and ceremonies. His interests also include writing and editing, both of which have helped him to gain recognition in the industry. Throughout his career, Acharya has dedicated himself to enhancing the quality of film making in Nepal. In 2009 he founded the nonprofit organization, Nepal Film Community, which strives to connect the film industry in Nepal and create a reliable platform for aspiring Nepali filmmakers. It facilitated an international exchange of ideas and knowledge between Nepal and its neighboring countries, in order to create an atmosphere that encourages the production of high quality work. Apart from an award-winning director, Acharya has also worked on numerous documentaries and TV commercials over the years. His work in the Nepali entertainment business has been highly appreciated and he has managed to make a name for himself as a director who consistently produces high-quality work. Acharya was awarded the Mahindra Excellence in Theatre Award in 2007 for his contribution to the Nepali entertainment industry, as well as being included in a list of the 25 most influential people in Nepali media by Hello FM. He is passionate about bringing fresh ideas to the world of Nepali cinema and pushing the boundaries of film making in Nepal. In recent years, he has been involved in a range of projects including the pre-production for a feature film and commercial production work. He continues to strive to produce work of the highest standard and is an example to young Nepalese filmmakers.

Polysorbate 20 is a nonionic surfactant and emulsifier used in the food, drug, and cosmetic industries. It is a mixture of fatty acid esters of sorbitol and its anhydrides. It has a wide variety of applications, such as being used as a solubilizer in flavor oils and a dispersing agent for fragrances in perfumes and cosmetics. It is also used in some pet foods to suspend and destabilize fats, proteins, preservatives and flavors. Polysorbate 20 is an oily, waxy partially-hydrogenated vegetable oil, consisting of a sorbitol ester of oleic acid. It is much more stable than other sorbitan derivatives, such as polysorbate 80, in solutions up to pH 6. Polysorbate 20 has a melting point of 56-58°C and a molecular weight of approximately 880 grams per mole. Polysorbate 20 can be used to form water-in-oil and oil-in-water emulsions and is often used in both food and cosmetic products. In food products, it is used to homogenize and stabilize oil-in-water emulsions or as an emulsifier in ice creams and bakery products, and as a stabilizer for syrup and salad dressing. In cosmetics, it functions as a surfactant and serves as an emollient and humectant to help form thicker, creamy and glossy textures. Because of its ability to increase the solubility of lipophilic compounds, especially those with high melting points, polysorbate 20 is widely used in pharmaceutical preparations. It is also used to solubilize oleoresins, providing better absorption. In combination with other emulsifiers, polysorbate 20 can be used to clean the skin, or to block certain drugs from being absorbed. Polysorbate 20 is one of the most widely used polysorbates because of its stability, and its ability to stabilize and disperse flavours and fragrances in cosmetics and in foods. However, polysorbates, such as polysorbate 20, can cause skin irritation and allergic reactions in some people and should be used carefully when formulating products. Additionally, polysorbate 20 can hydrolyze, forming lactic and sorbic acids, which makes it unsuitable for acidic products.

Djimrangar Dadnadji (1947 – 2011) was an African traditional chief, farmer, and politician. He was the Chief of Linya, a city in the Ouaddai region of Chad. Chief Dadnadji was born in 1947 in Linya, Chad. He was the son of Vizier Boulaba and Djina Aïchi, who were both farming families. He grew up in a farming village, learning the customs and traditions of his people. As a young man, he worked as a laborer on the farms of the region, and gained a local reputation for being a hard worker. When he was a young man, Chief Dadnadji became involved in local politics. He was eventually elected as the Chief of Linya in the 1960s, and served as the leader of the city for over 40 years. During his time as the chief, Dadnadji was a strong advocate for the rights of the people of Linya, advocating for improved infrastructure and education opportunities. He also sought to improve medical care and health services in the city. In 1998, Dadnadji was elected to the National Assembly of Chad, representing Linya as a representative of the Party for Liberty and Development. He served in the National Assembly until his death in 2011. Throughout his life, Dadnadji was a respected figure and leader in the Ouaddai region. He was known for his dedication to his people and his strong belief in the importance of traditional African values. He was also respected for his leadership ability and his role in the development of the Ouaddai region. Despite his health issues, Dadnadji remained active in politics and traditional life until his death in 2011. He was given a ceremonial funeral in Linya and was buried in his family's ancestral lands. In his memory, the city of Linya has erected a plaque honoring Dadnadji's legacy. Today, Dadnadji's legacy lives on and is remembered by the people of Linya and Ouaddai as a man who devoted his life and efforts to the betterment of his people. He is remembered and respected by many, both in Chad and around the world.

Cupid Childs (born December 10th, 1979) is an American mixed-media artist and activist from Detroit, Michigan. He is best known for his bold, multicolored graffiti and vibrant abstract works, which feature motifs inspired by the visual language of street art. His work often draws attention to social injustices, particularly those related to the African-American experience in the United States. Childs's artistic career dates back to the early 2000s, when he began creating graffiti in the city of Detroit. He was heavily influenced by the graffiti prevalent in Detroit's inner city, including early urban styles such as bubble lettering as well as classic New York City styles like wildstyle graffiti. This influence is reflected in his current work, which fuses his street art aesthetic with the vibrant colors and textures of modern abstract painting. Childs's work has been exhibited in galleries and museums around the world, including the Detroit Institute of Arts, the Flint Institute of Arts, and the Charles H. Wright Museum of African American History. He has also been featured in popular art publications such as Juxtapoz and Hi-Fructose, and has collaborated with nationally recognized streetwear brand Supreme. In addition to his visual art, Childs is a passionate advocate for social justice. He regularly advocates for the value of art in education, and has collaborated with various non-profit organizations to bring creative opportunities to underserved communities. He has also been active in the protests against police brutality and racism, weighing in with powerful artwork that aims to bring attention to these issues. Cupid Childs is an artist who is truly dedicated to creating an impact through his work. His vibrant, multilayered pieces reflect his commitment to amplifying voiceless stories and exploring social issues through the lens of graffiti and abstract art.

Katsuo Tokashiki (born April 8, 1947) is a Japanese singer and composer. Born in Onomichi, Hiroshima, Japan, Tokashiki started playing guitar from junior high school and went on to perform in high school bands. While still in school, he formed a band with a friend in 1966 and released some albums which led to some success. He was then invited to join the band Peacelands, which achieved moderate success and toured Japan until its dissolution. Tokashiki was then invited to be part of the band Bus Riders in 1973, whose commercial success led him to be accredited as a solo artist. Tokashiki then began to compose his own solo albums with the help of friends and band mates. He had seven number one singles on the Japanese Oricon chart, released 16 albums and marked the peak of his success in 1978 when he was invited to perform at the 11th Annual Japan Music Jamboree, singing his most famous song “2PM”. Tokashiki continued to make music up until the late 1980s when he decided to focus on non-performing activities such as production and songwriting for other artists. In 1990, he was awarded a Japanese Academy Award for Best Score for Takashi Shimizu's film Mito Kōmon. As of 2021, Tokashiki continues to be involved with new music projects and has recently composed the music for the films Tengoku e no Kodō (2019) and Hanawa-saki no Iro (2020). His contributions have been foundational in the development of popular music in Japan, with his music being an integral part of the culture for over four decades. He has earned several awards, collaborated with many of the biggest names in Japanese music and is considered a pillar of Japanese popular music.

Max Brito (born April 12, 1959) is an Angolan retired footballer who played as an attacking midfielder. Brito was born in Luanda, the capital city of Angola. He began his career playing for Anchietasound FC, and in 1978 he moved to Primeiro de Agosto, where he stayed for 11 years, becoming one of the team's great players. A year later he was given the opportunity to play for Estrela Vermelha do Sul, in Brazil, and a few seasons after he played for Atlético Mineiro, a team from the city of Belo Horizonte, also in Brazil. He was part of the first Angolan selection chosen to play in the African Cup of Nations in 1980, where the team finished third. He holds the record of most goals scored in the Cup of Angola and was in the national team selectios that participated in the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, where they were placed 5th. During the 1990s he was a coach at Primeiro de Agosto, winning several national tournaments. On July 9, 2015, the City Hall of Luanda paid homage to Brito along with other Angolan personalities in the field of sport and culture. Brito is considered one of the greatest footballers in the history of Angola and is recognized for his dedication and service to the national football teams of the country. He is currently considered a football ambassador of Angola and is often invited to participate in activities related to the sport.

Barnett Bank of Marion County, N.A. v. Nelson was a 1994 decision in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida involving the contract to purchase a home and the right of a creditor to foreclose on the property. The case was decided in favor of the creditor, Barnett Bank of Marion County, N.A. The facts of the case: Debra and Terrance Nelson entered into a contract with a housing developer to purchase a home in Marion County, Fla. The Nelsons knew they would need a loan in order to purchase the home, so they contacted Barnett Bank of Marion County, N.A. for a loan. Barnett Bank agreed to provide the loan with the Nelsons as co-signers. The Nelsons took possession of the home, but within two years had a financial crisis, leading to the inability to make the agreed upon loan payments to Barnett Bank. Barnett Bank then moved to foreclose on the property, citing the loan contract as the legal basis for their action. The Nelsons filed a lawsuit against Barnett Bank, arguing that the loan had been unfairly discriminatory and should be voided. The court disagreed with the Nelsons' argument and found in favor of Barnett Bank. The court found that the loan contract between the Nelsons and Barnett Bank was legal and enforceable, and that Barnett Bank had the right to foreclose on the property. The court concluded that the Nelsons had failed to meet their burden of proof in showing that the loan was unfairly discriminatory. Thus, the court upheld Barnett Bank’s right to foreclose on the property and affirmed the contractual loan agreement between the Nelsons and Barnett Bank. Barnett Bank of Marion County, N.A. v. Nelson provided legal precedence for the enforceability of loan contracts and the right of banks to foreclose on properties in cases of default.

Benia Gram (b.1990) is an award-winning, interdisciplinary artist based in Los Angeles, California. She is recognized for her multimedia installations, which employ a variety of materials, design elements, and photographs to create diverse experiences and spark dialogue. In many of her works, Gram references personal and collective histories, often reflecting upon the politics of her own Armenian identity. Gram was born in Los Angeles and earned her BA in Fine Arts from the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) in 2013. Her interest in visual arts began at an early age, as she was heavily influenced by the works of her father and grandfather, both of whom were Armenian sculptors. After graduating from UCLA, Gram continued her visual arts education with a fellowship from the Armory Center for the Arts as well as classes in photography, painting, 3D design, and digital media. As an extension to her studies, she then participated in an artist residency at the Banff Centre in Alberta, Canada, where she created a series of digital works inspired by the landscapes of the region. Her work has been featured in a variety of exhibitions and festivals, including the Armenian Pavilion at the 57th Venice Biennale, the Aarhus Arts Festival in Denmark, and the Glasgow International Festival in Scotland. In 2018, she was chosen to participate in the Mine Gallery Residency in Armenia, where she created a site-specific installation in the village of Avala, aimed at healing ancestral trauma. Gram's art has been praised by critics, with her most recent exhibition at the Nevada Museum of Art being described as “emotionally charged” and “a daring exploration of identity, memory, and history.” She has also been the recipient of several awards and grants, most notably from the Los Angeles County Arts Commission, the Creative Arts Agency Foundation in California, and the Pollination Project. Gram's artworks often explore themes such as displacement, loss, and resilience, often tying in her Armenian culture and the beauty of nature. With her creative approach and cross-disciplinary practice, she continues to explore new ways of developing and expressing her work, making her one of the most sought-after artists in her field.

The 53rd Army was a major formation of the Soviet Union's Red Army during World War II. It was created on 17 July 1941 in the Crimea and the Donbass region, located in the southern part of the Soviet Union. During the war, the 53rd Army fought in several major battles and campaigns including the Battle of Smolensk, the Battle of Kursk, and the Battle of Berlin. The 53rd Army initially was composed of four divisions, six artillery regiments, and two separate tank battalions. The Army was under the command of General Konstantin Rokossovsky. He was appointed to command the Army on 10 August 1941, after his predecessor had been removed from command. Rokossovsky quickly displayed his brilliance on the frontlines and was promoted to become a Colonel General while still serving in command of the 53rd Army. The 53rd Army was mainly formed to serve as a reserve force of the Red Army. This proved to be its primary role throughout the war, as it was frequently deployed to break through enemy lines and counter offensive actions taken by German troops. Throughout the war, the 53rd Army participated in several major battles, including the Battle of Smolensk, where it provided crucial support to the Red Army's counter-attack against the German offensive. At the Battle of Kursk, the 53rd Army played a major role in supporting the Soviet advance against the German lines. This support enabled numerous tank and infantry formations to penetrate deep into German occupied territory. At the Battle of Berlin, the 53rd Army again proved its value to the war effort by pushing back German forces in several sectors of the city. After the war, the 53rd Army was disbanded on 16 December 1945, having been awarded numerous honors for its service during the war. The unit's original commanders, such as General Rokossovsky, would go on to serve in other senior command roles within the post-war Soviet military. Today, the 53rd Army holds a special place in Russian military history. Its actions and its commanders serve as examples of the bravery of the Soviet military during the Great Patriotic War. The memory of the 53rd Army remains strong among both veterans of the war, as well as its successors in the modern Russian military.

Legend Tripping is a form of folklore, in which a person, or a group of people visit a location where a legend or myth supposedly exist and take part in a ritual. It is an old phenomenon, and is based on the belief that supernatural entities may exist in certain places. Legend tripping is often associated with activities of a supernatural nature, including ghost hunting, séances, and searching for symbols of the supernatural, such as items associated with lost souls. Legend tripping began in the United States in the late 1800s and early 1900s, and is a popular activity today. Legend tripping might occur in the form of a single individual visiting the location of a haunting, or a group of people gathering at the site of a supposed supernatural event. Participants in legend tripping often look for evidence of a supernatural entity in the form of physical items (e.g. data collected by a psychic), vibrant stories or stories of past or present events, or residual hauntings or ghostly presences. Legend tripping has been identified in many different cultures worldwide. For example, in Japan, legend tripping often involves visiting locations that are either haunted or associated with spirits. According to popular belief, these sites house shadows, or “yurei”, and the spirits of these yurei are believed to be drawn to the site if it is visited by enough people. In Australia, legend tripping often involves visiting Aboriginal sacred sites and taking part in rituals that are believed to bring forth spirits of the dead. Today, legend tripping is a popular form of entertainment which has been spawned by the ubiquity of television shows dedicated to the paranormal and supernatural. Popular television shows often explore haunted locations, supernatural paraphernalia and the stories behind them, creating a demand for individuals and groups to search out such things on their own. This has led to an increase in individuals or groups visiting allegedly haunted sites, although this trend is not exclusive to such locations. Legends tripping is also practiced in non-haunted areas, such as national parks and old cemeteries, which are believed to contain secret or hidden treasures. Legend tripping can be a dangerous and even life-threatening activity, and is not recommended without adult supervision. It is important to remember that there is no scientific evidence that any supernatural being exists, and the risks associated with such activities may outweigh the reward. Always take proper precautions and follow guidance from experienced personnel when engaging in such activities.

HMS Leopard was a 50-gun fourth rate ship of the English Royal Navy launched in 1790. She was built for use as a long-range cruiser and saw service in the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars. She was also used as a transport vessel during the War of 1812. The Leopard was ordered on 27th April 1788 and built by William Barnett at his shipyard in Deptford. She was launched in May 1790 and commissioned in June of the same year. The ship was made from a design by Sir William Rule and was built to a tonnage of 1043 tons. In 1790 the Leopard set sail for the West Indies under the command of Captain Robert Barlow, where it took part in several anti-smuggling operations. After spending a year in the Caribbean the ship sailed back to England. In November 1793 the Leopard sailed under the command of Captain Henry Digby in an expedition against the French naval bases on the French Coast. The Leopard took part in numerous engagements during the expedition, with notable action being the capture of several French vessels. However, the Leopard soon ran out of supplies and was forced to return to England. In 1798, under the command of Captain William Gordon, the Leopard was sent to the Mediterranean to fight the French during the French Revolutionary Wars. During the mission, the Leopard captured numerous French vessels and ferried supplies to the Mediterranean theatres. In 1801, during the Napoleonic Wars, the Leopard participated in the blockade of French ports and also took part in patrols to hunt down French vessels. During this period, the Leopard captured several French vessels, including a 36-gun frigate. In 1806 the Leopard was decommissioned and served for a time as a prison ship, before becoming a hospital ship in 1808. In 1812, during the War of 1812, the Leopard was again recommissioned and served as a transport vessel. In 1814 the Leopard was retired and eventually broken up in May that year. The legacy of the Leopard remains in the form of paintings and engravings depicting the ship engaged in action. A painting by Willian Beechey and an etching by John Rose, both showing the Leopard in battle can be found in the National Maritime Museum in London. Today, there are various memorials to the Leopard, including a memorial plaque in Sheerness and a memorial in Deptford. The original launch book of the Leopard is currently on display in the Greenwich Maritime Museum, as a testament to the proud service of the ship and her crew.

Lunar-A was a Japanese lunar mission launched by the Institute of Space and Astronautical Science (ISAS) in 1994. The project was part of the Japanese Space Exploration Program which included the team at ISAS and the National Space Development Agency of Japan (NASDA). The mission of the program was to study the Moon from Earth-based telescopes and by launching the Lunar-A spacecraft to the lunar surface. The Lunar-A spacecraft was launched on 8 August 1994 by an H-II rocket. The spacecraft had a total launch mass of 622 kg and consisted of two main components. The first component was the main spacecraft bus and the second component was the separate cruise stage. After launch, the lunar-A spacecraft separated from its cruise stage and began its journey to the Moon. The spacecraft was powered by a single SOZ-M-100 liquid apogee engine while the cruise stage used a Monopropellant Rocket Engine. The Lunar-A spacecraft arrived at the Moon seven days after launch and entered into a polar-orbiting trajectory. During the mission, the spacecraft mapped the lunar surface in both visible and near-infrared wavelengths in order to collect detailed topographic data. The mission was also used to study the lunar environment including the radiation environment and the solar wind interaction with the lunar surface. The spacecraft collected data for one week before its primary mission ended. During the mission, the Lunar-A spacecraft also deployed two 80 kg penetrators to the lunar surface. The penetrators were used to study the internal structure of the Moon including its gravity and magnetic fields. On 28 October 1998, Lunar-A reentered the Earth's atmosphere and was destroyed upon impact with the surface. Although the primary mission was completed, the data collected by the mission was used in subsequent missions and continues to be studied by scientists today. The Lunar-A mission was successful and resulted in many scientific discoveries. The mission demonstrated the ability of Japan to successfully launch and operate an interplanetary spacecraft and provided valuable insight into the lunar environment and formation. This mission also laid the foundation for further lunar exploration by Japan and other space agencies.

David Fig (born August 26, 1975) is an American business executive and entrepreneur. He is the Founder and CEO of Fig, a digital entertainment platform focused on the intersection of games, media, sports and technology. Fig is a venture-backed company based in Santa Monica, California, whose growth trajectory has been cited in industry media outlets such as VentureBeat, Fortune Magazine, Los Angeles Times and Wall Street Journal. Prior to Fig, Fig served as the Digital Operations & Strategy Lead for Fox Sports Digital, where he led the teams working to bring digital content and product experiences to Fox Sports fans. Before that, he held media executive roles at 20th Century Fox, Nickelodeon, and NBC Universal, which included developing and launching an award-winning international movie network in India as well as launching Hulu in the UK/Ireland. Early Years Fig grew up in the Pittsburgh suburb of Greensburg, Pennsylvania where he spent a majority of his time outdoors playing sports, fishing and hunting. His first entrepreneurial venture was a lemonade stand where he quickly developed an appetite for success. Fig went on to attend the United States Naval Academy where his studies focused on management and technology. Fig's Career Fig launched his professional career at the U.S. Navy, where he held various positions of increasing responsibility, serving domestically and internati​onally before joining the corporate world. After departing from the Navy, Fig found success in the digital media industry. As a digital executive, Fig tapped into the potential of new businesses and helped transition traditional companies into the digital era leading digital product and content experinces for Fox Sports, Nickelodeon, NBC Universal, and 20th Century Fox. He was part of the team that launched Hulu in the United Kingdom and Ireland and created a unique entertainment experience where Mavel, Sony, Star and Universal’s films and TV shows were made available for the first time. Fig and Fig In October 2018, Fig launched Fig, a digital entertainment platform devoted to giving power to the creators, fans, investors and players in the gaming industry. Fig is a venture-backed company focused on the intersection of games, media, sports and technology. It is the ultimate destination for gaming fans in search of both trending video games and original video game content. Fig has crafted a system where all audience members and industry participants have a profound effect on the successes of Fig in order to create a multifaceted entertainment platform. On the platform, fans are empowered to shape the success by connecting with developers and investing directly in participating games. This unique investment model, called "fan investment" enables fans to purchase a limited-time offering, allowing them to own a portion of the game’s profits and share directly in the game’s success or failure. Awards & Accolades Fig has been the recipient of many awards and accolades throughout his career, including the Platinum Remi award at WorldFest Houston, being named a World Economic Forum 2018 Technology Pioneer, and standing as a finalist for Ernst & Young ‘Entrepreneur of the Year’. Fig’s passion for the gaming industry and business doings has also shown, as he was recently featured as a speaker at the 2016 Collision Conference and chaired the 2018 Games Investor Summit in San Francisco. Additionally, the platform he co-founded, Fig, has been highlighted by publications such as VentureBeat, Fortune Magazine, Los Angeles Times and Wall Street Journal. Conclusion David Fig is an accomplished business executive and entrepreneur who has extensive experience in the digital entertainment industry. He is the Founder and CEO of Fig, a digital entertainment platform which provides unique opportunities to game developers, investors, and players alike. With an inspiring background and numerous awards to his credit, David Fig is leading the way forward in digital entertainment.

"Madness Under the Royal Palms" is a 2015 American drama film directed by Michael Davis and written by Cynthia Lowen. It was released on June 5, 2015, by Regency Enterprises. The film stars Maria Bello, Jeffrey Dean Morgan, and Gia Mantegna. It follows a successful New York couple (Bello and Morgan) who slowly begin to unravel after a tragedy occurs during a weekend retreat in Florida with their friends (Mantegna, Griffin Dunne, and Tom Lipinski). Set in the Florida Keys and Everglades, the film examines the trauma between relationships, the impact of death and loss, and the consequences of making life-altering decisions in a brief moment of time. Madness Under the Royal Palms debuted at the Chicago International Film Festival on October 17, 2015, and played at film festivals such as Palm Springs International Film Festival, Sarasota Film Festival, and the San Diego International Film Festival. It was released on DVD, Blu-Ray, and Digital HD on November 8, 2016, by Image Entertainment. The film received generally positive reviews from critics, praising it for its performances, emotional depth, and visual direction. On review aggregate website Rotten Tomatoes, the film holds an approval rating of 75%, based on 36 reviews, with an average rating of 6.64/10. On Metacritic, the film has a weighted average score of 62 out of 100, based on 14 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews". Los Angeles Times film critic Justin Chang stated: "Any parent can relate to the fear at the heart of 'Madness Under the Royal Palms', a humid, quietly intense drama about an affluent New York couple whose marriage is tested during an ill-fated weekend trip to Florida." In a review for The New York Times, Glenn Kenny wrote: "The performances, especially from Mr. Morgan and Ms. Bello, are the movie’s lifeline, and Mr. Davis directs with a simplicity that pays off." Madness Under the Royal Palms was nominated for Best Feature Film at the 8th Annual Features Houston International Film Festival and was honored with an Outstanding Achievement Award at the Beverly Hills Film Festival.

Gunnar Karlson (November 3 1938 - November 28 2018) was a Norwegian businessman who served as the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the oil and gas company Statoil from 1988 to 2003. He was credited with leading Statoil's transformation into a major international energy company. Karlson was born in Oslo, Norway, and grew up on an island outside Bergen. He began his career in 1963 with the Norwegian oil company Esso, where he worked as an exploration geologist. After a few years, he moved on to A/S Marathon Oil Norway, which later merged with Elf Aquitaine, where he served in various positions, eventually becoming executive vice president. In 1988, he was appointed CEO of Statoil and given the task of transitioning the largely state-owned energy company into a private, commercially-oriented firm. Under Karlson's leadership, Statoil internationalized its operations, opening subsidiaries across Europe and North America, and eventually expanding its presence to countries like India, China and Brazil. Karlson was an advocate of technology and innovation, and he implemented a number of initiatives to maximize Statoil's potential. Under his guidance, the company pioneered advanced reservoir monitoring technologies, as well as seismic imaging and drilling techniques which allowed the company to explore and develop resources in deepwater or hard-to-reach places. Karlson was also a key figure in the development of Norway's petroleum industry, and was an advisor to the Norwegian government on energy issues. During his tenure as Statoil's CEO, Karlson became known for his corporate reforms and strategies, which enabled Statoil to become one of the world's leading oil companies. Karlson retired from Statoil in 2003 and died in November 2018, at the age of 80. He is remembered as one of the leading figures in the international energy sector.

Macclenny, Florida is a city located in Baker County, in the northeastern part of the U.S. state of Florida. It is the county seat of Baker County and has been home to a population of over 6,000 people since its founding in 1823. The city of Macclenny was founded by Scottish immigrant James W. MacClenny. He arrived in North Florida from South Carolina with his wife in 1817 and established what would become the first permanent settlement in the area. He named the settlement Macclenny for himself and his wife. The city was officially chartered in 1883 by the state legislature. Macclenny is home to a variety of interesting attractions, including the Baker County Historical Society. The up-to-date museum documents the early history of the area, showcasing many artifacts, images and stories. There are also a number of beautiful local parks, such as the Catfish Pond Park, boasting an excellent fishing and picnic area, as well as a playground, picnic tables and a pavilion. Macclenny is home to the short-line rail road, Florida Wildwood Railroad and to the popular annual music festival, Magnolia Music Festival. The local economy of Macclenny is largely supported by small businesses, as well as the town's agricultural sector. The city is also home to The Florida State College at Jacksonville and the Council on Aging. These educational facilities provide residents and visitors with ample recreational activities and excellent educational opportunities. Macclenny is an incredibly diverse and vibrant city with plenty to offer anyone looking to visit. With the beautiful parks and a laid-back atmosphere, it's no surprise why many people continue to call Macclenny their home. In the last decade, there has been an influx of young families and professionals moving into the area, looking to take advantage of the quality of life and terrific educational opportunities on offer in Macclenny.

Odeonsplatz is a square located in the old city centre of Munich, Germany. It is located south of the Ludwigstrasse, between the Hofgarten and the National History Museum. The square was named after the Odeon, which was the old concert hall located on the square until it was destroyed during World War II. Odeonsplatz was first built on the former Wittelsbach Palace garden in 1816, and it was quickly becoming one of the most important squares of the city. It was also the centre of public celebrations and military parades, including the celebration of the Bavarian King Ludwig I’s Silver Jubilee in 1844. The Odeon was constructed in the centre of the square between 1826 and 1828 and it was the largest concert hall of its time in Munich. The Odeon was the center of musical life in Munich and its concerts featured the works of many illustrious composers such as Wagner, Strauss, Schumann, and Mozart. During World War II the building was mainly destroyed, leaving only the facade standing. The remains of the Odeon were demolished in 1959 and the square was redesigned in the 1970s. Today, the square is a popular tourist attraction and site of many events. It also houses several important heritage sites, such as the equestrian statue of King Max Joseph and the Bavarian State Chancellery, which was the first building in Munich made with reinforced concrete. Odeonsplatz is also the home of the annual long music and theatre festival known as the IKARUS-Festival. It takes place throughout the summer months and features both classic and modern plays and music events. In addition to music and theatre, the festival includes many other elements such as art exhibitions and special performances. During the festival visitors can experience concerts, opera, theatre, art and fashion shows. Odeonsplatz is one of the most important sites in Munich and offers a wealth of activities and attractions. As such, it is considered by many to be an important part of the city's cultural and artistic heritage.

Sportpaleis is a multipurpose indoor arena located in Antwerp, Belgium. It is regularly used for concerts, family shows, sport events and other activities. The arena was originally opened in 1933, and later renovated in 1989, today has a seating capacity of 18,000. The arena is owned and operated by the N.V. Group Sportpaleis, which runs several entertainment venues and events in the country, including the Ethias Arena and the Lotto Arena. The history of Sportpaleis goes back to 1933 when it was opened as an ice hockey venue, known as U-Rink. During the Second World War, it was damaged by Allied bombing, but was able to be repaired and reopened shortly after the war. In 1962, the arena was renovated and expanded to accommodate up to 10,000 spectators, and became known as the Sportpaleis. In 1989, the arena was renovated once again, and now has a seating capacity of 18,000. The building is split into four levels, with the ground floor devoted to sport, the upper mezzanine views for concerts, the Royal Box for VIP guests, and the corporate suites for the more discerning audience. The arena has hosted a number of highly prestigious events since its opening, such as both the 1987 and 1995 Eurovision Song Contests, 1990 Davis Cup and the 1998 World Ice Hockey Championships. The venue is also regularly used for various sports events, including basketball, volleyball, karate and even sumo wrestling. It is also used for rock, pop and classical music concerts, as well as comedy and other family entertainment shows. In recent years, Sportpaleis has seen an increase in the number of non-traditional events, such as the Michelin Star Chef Test Restaurant Series, the Glow Run and the Ninja Warrior. There are also a number of restaurants located in the arena, which offer a range of cuisine, including Italian, Thai, Mexican and Greek. Sportpaleis is a modern day entertainment hub in the heart of Antwerp and serves as a prime example of the city’s commitment to providing first class entertainment experiences for all. Whether you’re looking for a sporting event, a concert or a family show, Sportpaleis is the perfect venue to visit.

Maria Espinosa is a Spanish politician. She has been Spain's Minister of Foreign Affairs since 2018, serving in the Government of Pedro Sánchez. She was previously the Minister for the Ecological Transition from June 2018 to July 2019 in the same government. Espinosa was born in Madrid on December 2, 1968. She obtained a degree in Law from the Autonomous University of Madrid and pursued postgraduate studies at the Carlos III University of Madrid. Espinosa began her professional career in 1995 as a lawyer for the National Employment Institute and the Department of Employment and Social Policy. From 2003 to 2005, she served as Judicial Secretary at the Superior Court of Arbitration of Madrid. Subsequently, Espinosa took a position as a judge specializing in social policy at the Superior Court of Justice of Madrid in 2010. In the 2015 election, Maria Espinosa was elected to the Spanish Congress as Member of Parliament for Madrid. She was appointed to the post of Secretary of State for Natural Resources and Sustainability at the Ministry for the Ecologic Transition in June 2018. On 5 June 2018, Espinosa was appointed Minister for the Ecological Transition in the Government of Pedro Sánchez. In July 2019, she was appointed Minister of Foreign Affairs in the same government. In addition to her public duties, Espinosa has served as a teaching assistant at the Autonomous University of Madrid and has been a visiting professor at the Universities of Valladolid, Navarra, and Santiago de Compostela. She is also an active contributor to the discussion on environmental policies, gender neutrality at various academic forums. Espinosa's commitment to gender equality and environmental sustainability are fundamental to her policies as Foreign Minister. In 2019, she spearheaded the ‘Woman in Diplomacy’ program, which seeks to increase the presence of women at diplomatic and international agencies, and has also spearheaded Spain's commitment to the Paris Agreement and the European Green Deal. In January 2021, Maria Espinosa was nominated to the post of Director-General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO). She is the first Spanish speaker to hold the post in UNESCO's 75-year history. Espinosa is scheduled to take office on 1 February 2021.

American Idols Live! Tour 2013 was the thirteenth concert tour in North America based on the television series, American Idol. Contested at the conclusion of the twelfth season of American Idol, Candice Glover, Kree Harrison, Angie Miller, Amber Holcomb, and Lazaro Arbos competed in the tour. It began on July 19, 2013, but was canceled in late August 2013, due to weak ticket sales. The tour had show dates in North America and was scheduled to begin on July 19, 2013 in St. Louis, MO, and end on August 31, 2013 in Buffalo, NY. Several of the Idol contestants have solo/group performances, medleys, group sing alongs and special guests, as well as duets with some of the season's quasi-mentors. The first show of the tour featured Daughtry as the special guest, but alums who took part in certain dates were David Cook, Clay Aiken, Adam Lambert, Ruben Studdard, Season 10 winner Scotty McCreery, Season 9 runner-up and Season 11winner Phillip Phillips, and Season 11 runner-up Jessica Sanchez, among others. While on tour, contestants from the 2012 and 2013 seasons of American Idol performed weekly on The Tour Bus radio show produced by SiriusXM radio. This one-hour radio show aired Thursday nights during the tour on Evolve, channel 141 on SiriusXM. The Tour Bus was hosted by the Top 24 semifinalists from the 2013 season. The season twelve Idols received enthusiastic reviews for their performances with The New York Times writing, "The show was laced with solos, duets and group medleys and was a seamless procession of music and memories. It was one of those live events where you felt as if the reality of the competition had been transcended, and something else was going on entirely.” Due to limited ticket sales the tour was canceled in late August 2013 and did not finish out the remaining tour dates. After the cancellation, the seven remaining top 7 Idols held their own show in Ventura, California to complete the American Idols Live! Tour 2013. In total, the American Idols Live! Tour 2013 had 39 shows in 28 cities and was attended by approximately 150,000 fans. It was the last tour to feature the combine

The National Civil War Museum is the only museum in the United States that exclusively focuses on the history and legacy of the American Civil War. The mission statement of the National Civil War Museum is to "preserve, promote, and interpret the history and legacy of the American Civil War for the benefit of present and future generations." Located in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, the National Civil War Museum is a non-profit, 501(c)(3) organization. Founded in 1991, the museum seeks to document the events of the Civil War and its impact on American society. The museum contains over 25,000 artifacts, photographs, documents, and exhibitions that explore the various aspects of the war, such as leadership, politics, tactics, and the home front. The National Civil War Museum has ongoing educational programs, including lectures, book discussions, and workshops. It also offers guided tours of the museum and its exhibits. The museum's permanent exhibitions include "Letters From the Civil War", "Voices of the Civil War", and "From Civil War Soldiers to Civilians". The museum also has temporary exhibitions focusing on specific topics related to the Civil War. In addition to its permanent and temporary exhibitions, the National Civil War Museum also features special events, such as reunions of Civil War veterans, living history lectures, living history camps, and community movie nights. The museum has also produced several award-winning films about the Civil War. The National Civil War Museum is accredited by the American Alliance of Museums and is among the 25 largest history museums in the country. It is supported, in part, by private donations and corporate support, as well as grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities and the Institute of Museum and Library Services. The National Civil War Museum is open year-round, seven days a week. Admission is free for military veterans and members of the armed forces and their families. The museum also offers discounts for seniors, students with valid ID, active reservists, and certain family members. All proceeds from the museum's store, café, and gift shop go to the museum's continued educational programming and preservation of its artifacts.

Rachel is a female given name of Hebrew origin, meaning "lamb." The name is prevalent in many cultures and is heard in the United States, as well as in the United Kingdom, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, and other parts of the world. It is a long-standing name that has held steady in popularity since the 19th century. Rachel is most often associated with the Bible, where it originates from. Rachel was the name of the mother of Joseph and the wife of Jacob, two sons of the biblical patriarch, Isaac. As such, Rachel has symbolic meanings of faith, valor, obedience, and devotion. Among many Christian traditions, Rachel is considered a patron saint and an example of idealized biblical femininity. In popular culture, Rachel is a popular name for television and movie characters. Most notably, a main character on the long-running television series Friends is named Rachel Green, played by Jennifer Aniston. The character is depicted as fashionable, independent, and hardworking. Rachel is also a name connected to literature. The 18th century English author Rachel Hunter is credited with writing books on a variety of topics spanning social issues and feminist causes. Furthermore, Rachel Carson is a prominent 20th century environmentalist whose work helped launch the modern environmental movement. In modern times, Rachel remains a popular name choice in many countries. Parents often select the name Rachel for its biblical ties, its popularity, its simple yet attractive spelling, and its wide variety of available nicknames. These include Rae, Ray, Rach, Rache, and Chelle. Many parents have children with the name with intentions to grow a strong appreciation for the traditional and sentimental value associated with it. The name Rachel is also presented in different spellings such as Rachael, Raquel, and Raechel.

Archelaus was the 4th Century Bishop of Carrhae, a town on the Euphrates River in northern Mesopotamia. He served from 355AD until his death in 373AD. Archelaus is best known for his work on the compilation of the Syrian Canons, or Rules of Church Discipline. His Early Life Little is known about Archelaus' life outside of his involvement in the church. It is believed to have been born in the city of Hierapolis. This is inferred from his writings in which he refers to it as his native town. He received his education from Eustathius of Antioch and became known as "Theophilus of Hierapolis" Writings Archelaus is best known for his work on the compilation of the Syriac Canons. This was a collection of ecclesiastical canons and rules of matrimony, public penance, and absolution. He was using the works of other Fathers and Schismatic authors, which he found in the Patriarchal Library of Antioch. He invoked the help of God and priestly spirit in the compilation. Due to his work on the Canons, Archelaus became recognized throughout the Eastern church as a respected scholar. He was among those consulted during the Synod of Antioch in 363AD regarding the charity famine in Egypt and was also a signatory of three Creeds regarding the Homoousian faith in 367AD. Legacy After Archelaus' death, his works on Syriac Canons would become highly influential in the Eastern liturgies. The 17th Century English clergyman, Richard Jonas, has written a biography on Archelaus, in which he calls him "The Great Bishop of Carrhae". Archelaus' work on the Syriac Canons is still used to teach about the Eastern Christian faith. His writings show the lasting impression he had on the church and how much the Eastern church valued his contributions. A church in modern-day Syria is also named after Archelaus, "Church of Saint Archelaus" which is located in the district of Daraya.

Kwame Boahene (born November 1, 1991) is a Ghanaian professional soccer player who currently plays for Persipura Jayapura in the Liga 1 as a defender. Boahene started his career in the Ghanaian Premier League with All Stars F.C. in 2011. During his time with the club, he made 18 appearances and scored 1 goal. In 2012, he was signed by WAFA, where he made 41 appearances and scored 2 goals in his two-year spell. In 2014, he was signed by AshantiGold and made 40 appearances, scoring 3 goals in the Ghanaian Premier League. The following year, he was signed by the Sudanese Premier League club Al Merreikh. He spent a season with them and earned the chance to expand his career internationally, signing with Indonesian Liga 1 club Persipura Jayapura. He has since become a key player in the team and made a total of 67 appearances, scoring one goal. Boahene has been a regular in the Ghanaian National Team since 2013, appearing in 25 matches and playing an instrumental role in helping the team to qualify for the 2014 African Cup of Nations, where they finished as semi-finalists. Aside from his football career, Boahene is involved in many charitable activities and works with several NGOs. During the COVID-19 pandemic, he provided food and basic needs to over 500 people in Ghana. Boahene has achieved the name and fame of the "Ghanaian Messi" due to the similarities in their play-styles. He is an inspirational figure for many young footballers in Africa.

The 1983 Miller High Life 500 was a NASCAR Winston Cup Series event that took place on July 17, 1983, at Madison International Speedway in Oregon, Wisconsin. The race was won by Tim Richmond, and it was the first win for Richmond's No. 15 Chevrolet. The race was 200 laps and 500 miles long, making it the longest race in the 1983 season. It attracted over 120,000 spectators and was broadcast on ESPN and TSN. The race was marred by a crash on the second lap, involving five cars. The incident resulted in two cars leaving the track, and the third, fourth, and fifth-place cars suffering significant damage. The top 3 drivers at the finish were Tim Richmond, John Andretti, and Bobby Allison. Dave Marcis and Bill Elliott both led laps, but Marcis dropped out with mechanical issues, and Elliott ran out of fuel. Geoff Bodine, Dale Earnhardt, and Harry Gant all finished in the top 10. The 1983 Miller High Life 500 attracted a number of famous drivers to the track. NASCAR Hall of Famers Richard Petty and Benny Parsons both competed in the race, as did Jimmy Hensley and Doug Heveron. The race is remembered as the first win for Tim Richmond and his No. 15 Chevrolet, as well as being the first win for a car sponsored by Miller High Life. It was also the first NASCAR race to be televised on ESPN, the second being the 1983 Firecracker 400. Overall, the 1983 Miller High Life 500 is remembered as an event that showcased the competitiveness of the Winston Cup series and introduced many famous drivers to the racing world. It was one of the most memorable races of 1983 and set a precedent for future NASCAR events.

Walter Edmunds (born October 15, 1960) is an American entrepreneur and investor. He is most recognized as the founder and former CEO of Home Depot, one of the largest home improvement retailers in the United States. Early life and career Edmunds was born in Charlottesville, Virginia and raised in Brooklyn, New York. After attending the State University of New York (SUNY) at Binghamton, he joined the U.S. Air Force where he served as a helicopter pilot and instructor. He then went on to obtain a master's degree from the University of Connecticut. In 1981, Edmunds founded Home Depot, which quickly became one of the leading home- improvement retailers in the United States. He initially mortgaged his home and borrowed money from friends, family and investors to open the first Home Depot store at a time when the home improvement industry was still in its early stages. By the time he stepped down as CEO in 2003, Home Depot had over 900 stores and employed over 250,000 people. After leaving Home Depot, Edmunds focused on his entrepreneurial and investing activities. He is a board director at several companies and venture funds, including the American Enterprise Institute, SeaChange International, Progress Software, and several retail startups. The Edmunds Family Foundation In 2008, Edmunds and his family established The Edmunds Family Foundation, a charitable organization dedicated to providing support to the youth in poor and underprivileged neighborhoods in the United States. The organization provides educational grants and resources to promote financial literacy and entrepreneurship, as well as job training and other educational programs throughout the country. Investment portfolio Edmunds is also an active investor in various high growth companies across a number of industries. He has made investments in a range of ventures, including technology, pharmaceuticals, and renewable energy. He is also a major shareholder in several publicly traded companies, such as Apple Inc., Microsoft Corporation, Amazon.com, Oracle Corporation, and Walmart Inc. Personal life Edmunds is married to Marsha, and the couple has two children, Robert and Marjorie. He lives in Marietta, Georgia, and is an avid golfer, reader and traveler. He is also active in several non-profit organizations and is involved in multiple charitable endeavors.

The Public Sector Pension Investment Board (PSPIB) is an independent, non-profit organization responsible for investing the pooled pension funds of the public-sector plans of Canada. Established in 2000, the board acts as a pension fund manager for Canadian public service and military personnel. At its core, the PSPIB is a long-term investor: it invests the assets of its funds in markets that generate sustainable returns over the long term. This strategy helps it to meet the pension requirements of its clients, while also protecting their capital and mitigating investment risks. The board is guided by a governance framework, including a Statement of Investment Policies and an Investment Plan, both of which have been approved by the PSPA Board of Trustees. These documents set out PSPIB policies and objectives, and provide guidance on the management of the funds. The board works with a number of external advisors to manage its funds, including Mercer, an independent investment consulting firm. The board also employs a team of internal Investment and Risk professionals who are responsible for implementing its investment decisions. The PSPIB invests in a variety of asset classes, including fixed income, listed equities, private markets, inflation-sensitive assets and real assets. It also has the ability to enter into derivative transactions, such as foreign exchange transactions or options. The board takes a holistic approach to portfolio construction which emphasizes diversification, risk management and liquidity, and takes into account the PSPIB’s long-term objectives, relevant market conditions, and current and future cash flows. This long-term, broadly diversified approach is designed to limit volatility and create sustainable returns that serve its clients’ needs. As part of its risk-management process, the PSPIB also has a formal review process in place to oversee itsinvestment decisions. At the end of 2019, the PSPIB held assets of approximately C$117 billion. The board is registered as an Investment Fund Manager in Canada, and its funds are overseen by the Pension Benefits Standards Act, 1985. The PSPIB is chaired by Patrick Elmaleh, and directed by President and CEO Neil Cunningham. The PSPIB is also a signatory of the United Nations-supported Principles for Responsible Investment (PRI), which recognizes the investment responsibility of signatories to advance UN-supported development goals. The PSPIB is also a signatory of the Equator Principles, which promote socially and environmentally responsible borrowing and lending.

Because We Are Girls (abbreviated as BWAG) is a 2019 documentary by Baljit Sangra. It follows the story of the three Dhillon sisters – Jeeti, Kira and Salakshana – as they struggle to come to terms with the sexual abuse they experienced during adolescence. The film premiered at the 2019 Toronto International Film Festival and went on to receive acclaim from critics, as well as awards from various film festivals. The Dhillon sisters grew up in a Punjabi-Canadian family living in Williams Lake, British Columbia. During their early teens, their father's employers both abused the sisters. When one sister confides in the other two, they become determined to face the trauma head-on, and push for the alleged abusers to be held accountable, even though their father and the community fear doing so. The film follows them as they strive to heal and begin to reclaim their voices and identities. Along with spotlighting the sisters’ personal stories, BWAG also provides an in-depth exploration into the obstacles faced by South Asian women in a patriarchal society. It sheds light on the intricacies of gender and power dynamics that are so deeply rooted in South Asian culture. The film covers several topics, including family dynamics and silencing, cultural pressures and expectations, trauma and mental health, South Asian stereotypes, the importance of sisterhood, and how to confront abuse. BWAG has attracted critical acclaim for its portrayal of the lives of young South Asian women. It won the Impact Award for Best Feature Documentary at the Vancouver International Film Festival, the Best Documentary Feature at the Alberta Film and Television Awards, as well as a few similar awards from other film festivals. It also received a 2019 Canadian Screen Award nomination. The film has been praised by critics and viewers alike. Jeannette Catsoulis of The New York Times says, “Because We Are Girls is an affecting testament to a family’s capacity to resist dissembling and emerge righteous.” BWAG is a powerful, moving film that focuses on South Asian sisters healing and growing together, ultimately becoming strong and respected individuals. Despite the horror they faced in their younger years, they triumph bravely as they reclaim their freedom and independence. The film is a testament to South Asian culture, as well as a powerful female story that encourages understanding of a family’s struggles and belief in oneself.

Álvaro Manrique de Zúñiga, 1st Marquess of Villamanrique (1615–1680) was a Spanish nobleman and writer. He was born in Madrid on 5 December 1615 and was the eldest son of Pedro Manrique de Zúñiga, 6th Count of Añover, and Beatriz de Silva. He entered a military career and was made a field marshal in 1657. He governed in the Villamanrique Fief his family was awarded in 1650. During the war against the revolted Netherlands he was sent to their country for diplomatic reasons. In 1662 he was appointed chief commander of an embassy to the Czar of Russia. He was received and granted an audience with Alexis I of Russia at the age of 48. He detailed his experience in his work "Memoirs of the Embassy to the Czar of Moscow" (1673). Upon his return to Spain, he was named captain-general of La Mancha, a title which he held until 1675. In the same year he was created first Marquess of Villamanrique by Charles II of Spain. In 1659 he received a degree of Doctor of Law. He was also a distinguished scholar who wrote works on military science as well as essays on politics and philosophy.
