His most famous book was "Political Philosophical Discourse" (1679). He died in Madrid on 2 February 1680, leaving behind a large number of grandchildren and successors who, in the 18th and 19th centuries, filled many prominent positions in Spain's administration and military. The Marquess of Villamanrique was one of the most prominent Spanish nobles of his time. He was an outstanding military leader and diplomat, a scholar, and a writer of political philosophy. He was a leading defender of the Spanish monarchy and an active participant in the Spanish politics of his time.

Ayam Brand is an international seafood and food products brand owned by Ayam Invest (Mauritius) Ltd. Ayam Brand was founded in east Malaysia in 1892 by the Ng Hock Hiap family. Ayam Brand has been producing delicious and nutritious canned seafood products for over 128 years. Ayam Brand’s mission is to provide nutritious and high-quality food products to the customers. Ayam Brand produces over 200 different types of canned seafood products such as sardines, mackerel, tuna, and anchovies. They also produce sauces, cooking pastes, creamed corn, dumplings, and other food products to complement its core canned seafood range. The brand is known for its commitment to quality and is Singapore’s no. 1 canned seafood brand. Ayam Brand has won a number of awards for its superior quality and flavor. Ayam Brand is committed to sustainable harvesting, innovative processes, and protection of marine resources. The brand is also active in Corporate Social Responsibility and works with the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) towards the conservation of tuna stocks in the Indian Ocean. Ayam Brand has a presence in more than 70 countries, including the US, the UK, China, India, South Africa, and Australia. The brand has established itself as a leader in the canned seafood category. It is a household name in some countries and its products are widely available in supermarkets and retail stores across the world. Ayam Brand’s commitment to quality and innovation has enabled it to build a loyal customer base over the years. It strives to provide customers with the best quality products that are also safe and where possible, crafted using natural ingredients. Ayam Brand is a truly international brand backed by its expertise and passion for producing delicious and nutritious products.

Joanna Sophia of Bavaria (2 November 1670, Munich - 28 October 1743, Munich) was a German archduchess and Princess of Bavaria. She was the daughter of Maximilian II Emanuel, Elector of Bavaria, and Landgravine Elizabeth Amalie of Hesse-Darmstadt. Joanna Sophia was born on 2 November 1670 in Munich, the daughter of the elective ruler of Bavaria, Maximilian II Emanuel, and his consort Landgravine Elizabeth Amalie of Hesse-Darmstadt. She was the second of three daughters. Her two siblings were Joseph Clemens of Bavaria and Sidonie of Bavaria. Joanna Sophia received a solid education. She was able to play several instruments, such as the lute, harpsichord, and harp. She was also a talented singer. Her talents made her the favourite daughter of her father, Maximilian. As such, she was frequently invited to his court in Munich. In 1691, Joanna Sophia was married to Rudolf Count Palatine of Sulzbach, a prince from the House of Palatinate-Sulzbach. The marriage was arranged by her father. Upon her marriage, she took the French name Sophie. The union was brief, as Rudolf of Sulzbach died in 1694. He was succeeded by his brother, Christian August, who took Joanna Sophia as his second wife in 1697. The couple had three children. Joanna Sophia died on 28 October 1743 after a long illness in Munich. She was buried in Munich, alongside her husband. Joanna Sophia was a renowned patron of the arts and sciences. She frequently invited artists and intellectuals to her court in Munich. She was known to encourage and support the work of local artists. In 1702, she founded the Bayrischen Akademie, which was devoted to the advancement of science, culture and the arts. Despite her short life, Joanna Sophia made a lasting impact on Bavarian culture and history. To this day, her legacy is still remembered and her contributions are respected. The House of Wittelsbach, to which she belonged, has erected a memorial in her honor on the grounds of the Nymphenburg Palace. Joanna Sophia's memory is also honored by the Bavarian military, as her name is included in the regimental song of the Bavarian regiment of light infantry.

Nicobar District is an administrative district in the Union Territory of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, India. It comprises the islands of the Nicobar archipelago, located in the southeastern Bay of Bengal, at the border of India and Indonesia. It is part of the South Andaman administrative division. The district was formed in 1974 with its headquarters at Car Nicobar. It is the southernmost districts of India. The district has an area of 1838 km² and a population of around 59,885 people as per the 2011 census, consisting of both indigenous Nicobarese and migrants from mainland India. This population is distributed among ten inhabited islands and several other uninhabited islands. The main languages spoken in the district are Nicobarese and Hindi. The Nicobar Islands are part of the Indo-Burma biodiversity hotspot and are important for their rich and diverse populations of plant and animal life. Much of the islands' biodiversity is threatened by poaching, deforestation and other human activities. The district also encompasses India's only marine national park, the Mahatma Gandhi Marine National Park. Agriculture is an important part of the local economy and is mostly practiced by the indigenous population, with the main crops being coconuts and tubers. Fishing is also an important economic activity, especially around Car Nicobar. The Nicobar district experiences a tropical climate, determined by the monsoon season from May to October, and a dry season from November to April. The temperature usually ranges from 24 to 33 degrees Celsius, with average rainfall ranging from 1000 to 2000mm per year. It has few places of tourist interest, the most famous being the Radhanagar beach on Havelock Island. The district is administered by the district administration, in collaboration with the local Autonomous District Council (ADC). The district is divided into four tehsils, namely Car Nicobar, Nancowry, Little Andaman, and Great Nicobar. It is divided into 17 blocks, 37 village committees and 56 panchayats. The district has resident offices of the Superintendent of Police and the Sub-Divisional Magistrate. The district headquarters are located at Car Nicobar, with several sub-divisions located in each of the tehsils. The district is connected to mainland India by sea and air, through the Chennai and Kolkata ports and the Port Blair airport respectively. There is also ferry service between some of the islands, as well as on-board vessels provided by the Indian Coast Guard. Electricity and communication networks are inadequate, and mobile services are mostly limited to the major cities. The district is governed by many agencies, such as the Department of Agriculture, the Department of Fisheries, the Ministry of Environment, Forestry and Climate Change, the Ministry of Home Affairs and the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. Several government departments are responsible for building infrastructure, providing medical services, granting fishing and agricultural permits, issuing trade licenses, providing legal assistance, regulating land use, maintaining forestry, and protecting wildlife in the Nicobar district.

Rufus Riddlesbarger (1859–1923) was an American naturalist, conservationist, and photographer. He was born in Richmond, Indiana, and graduated from Purdue University with a degree in agriculture in 1883. He later continued his studies in Vienna, Austria, where he studied forestry and later obtained a PhD in zoology. Riddlesbarger was a well-known figure in early conservationist circles. He campaigned to protect wildlife habitats, lobbied the government to protect endangered species, and encouraged the adoption of wildlife-friendly farming practices. In the early 1900s, he was an active member of the National Audubon Society and helped establish a network of conservation areas in several states across the country. Riddlesbarger was an avid photographer, as well. He was an early adopter of color photography, and was particularly keen on capturing the beauty of animals, birds, and nature. He took many photographs of birds in flight, capturing stunning details and the grace of their movements. Along with photographs, he also wrote novels and scientific papers on birds and the natural world, which were widely published in journals and magazines. In 1906, he released his first book titled "The Life of Birds", which was met with critical acclaim. The book was an insightful look at the habits and behaviors of birds, and the intricate dynamics that occur amongst them. In the final years of his life, Riddlesbarger devoted himself to conservation efforts, helping create a number of nature preserves and conservation areas throughout the US. He also worked to make the government of Indiana more aware of the needs of nature, leading to the passage of the Conservationists Bill of Rights in 1921. Rufus Riddlesbarger passed away in 1923, leaving behind a legacy of dedication and conservation advocacy. His work is still remembered today and he is honored for his contribution to the preservation of the natural environment. He is regarded as one of the major figures in the history of American conservationism and his legacy lives on in the many conservation areas that he helped establish.

Pavel Ubri (born 13th of August 1982) is an entrepreneur, venture capitalist, and philanthropist from Ukraine. He is widely known for co-founding and managing multiple venture capital and technology funds, including the Ukraine-based Chernovetskyi Investment Group and the California-based Ubrique Ventures. After completing his studies in economics in the London School of Economics with a Master's degree and a double Major in investment banking, he first entered the venture capital scene in 2008. He and his business partners at the Chernovetskyi Investment Group established venture capital funds in Ukraine and recognized the potential of the local market and the potential of Eastern European startups at the time. In 2014, he co-founded Ubrique Ventures in California where he is one of the main managing partners. His fund focuses on early stage investments for emerging technologies and consumer products. To date, his team has made investments in numerous companies including Snapbara, Yoola, Celect, Retail-x and VFinity. In addition to his venture capital activities, Pavel is also a philanthropist. Through the Pavel Ubri Foundation, he invests in cultural, educational and social projects that help develop Ukraine's infrastructure and its people. Since 2010, he has sponsored various activities such as accelerated educational programs, startup incubators and participation in educational conferences, as well as awarded scholarships to help aspiring entrepreneurs and students. Outside of venture capitalism and philanthropy, Pavel is also an avid reader of philosophy, economics and mathematics and enjoys travelling around the world. His main interests include photography, playing the guitar and spending time with his family. Overall, Pavel Ubri is a well-known figure in the venture capital and technology sectors and is reputed for his pioneering investments and innovative ideas. He is considered to be one of the leading investors from Ukraine, having made major contributions to the country's tech ecosystem. Through his various investments, he strives to make a difference by helping to develop businesses and create jobs in the region.

Carl Froch vs. George Groves II, also known as The Rematch For Respect, was a boxing match for the WBA and IBF supermiddleweight titles held on May 31, 2014 at Wembley Stadium, Watford in London, England. The bout was a rematch of the controversial November 2013 encounter in which George Groves knocked Carl Froch down for the first time in his career, only for the referee to controversially stop the fight in the ninth round, much to the displeasure of the crowd. As a result, there was a widespread desire from boxing fans for a rematch to occur. The fight was billed as "The Rematch For Respect", referring to the controversy of the first fight. At the weigh-in, Froch weighed 167lbs and Groves weighed 166.5lbs - a full pound under the super middleweight limit. Each fighter was paid a pursed of £2.5 million. During the fight, Froch made a steady start, dominating most of the early rounds, before Groves began to take the initiative during the middle of the fight. However, just after the eighth round, Groves' trainer Paddy Fitzpatrick threw in the towel, claiming that his man had an injured shoulder and could not continue. After review by the referee, the bout was ruled a technical knockout in favour of Froch. Groves spoke of his frustration after the fight, believing he could have gone the distance had it not been stopped, but Froch was satisfied with the victory and proud of his performance. The victory was significant for Froch, whose improved form since the first fight gave him an opportunity to prove he could overcome Groves and had his performances of the past two years been beset more with luck than skill. The fight broke the UK pay-per-view record, with over 900,000 viewers tuning in. It also received positive reviews, with the boxing community hailing it as one of the best British fights of all time. The fight served as a finale to a memorable series of contests between the two men, and in spite of the first fight, it was a great show of respect and admiration that the bout was for the final fight between them.

Bourgeois Government refers to the form of government led by the bourgeois class. It is a capitalist regime, typically associated with democracies such as the U.S. and other Western countries. The main goal of bourgeois governments is to maximize profits for the affluent members of society and to ensure the economic stability of the nation. The primary focus of a bourgeois government is economic control and management. This type of regime seeks to stimulate economic growth and development through free-market policies and the liberalization of competition laws. Tax policies are designed to favor upper-class groups and businesses, while encouraging economic activity. Other economic goals include the protection of property rights and the promotion of free-market trade. Furthermore, governments wish to ensure that the state is able to capitalize on its own resources and to use them in the best way possible in order to benefit citizens. In addition, regulations impose and maintain necessary standards of behavior and practice in order to prevent fraud and unethical practices. Many political theorists have criticized bourgeois government for its reliance on economic measures to generate growth, instead of taking into account the long-term impact of certain policies on the social and physical environment. Critics argue that such a system leads to the growth of economic inequality and uneven income distribution. Furthermore, it often rewards speculative and wasteful investments and encourages irresponsible behaviour of certain sections of the economy. The concept of bourgeois government is also subject to numerous criticisms from both the left and the right. For example, some progressives view the government as a tool of the ruling class and view the policies of bourgeois government as a form of domination and control. From the right, bourgeois government has been criticized for being too interventionist and too restrictively regulated. In the end, bourgeois government has had an immense influence on the development of the Western world, and it has had both positive and negative effects. It has allowed for the amassing of incredible wealth, which has resulted in great improvements in technological advances and social conditions in certain countries. At the same time, some of the policies of bourgeois government have led to greater economic inequality and other social problems.

Tribune Content Agency (TCA) is an American newswire and content licensing and rights management services provider. The agency is powered by the iconic and award-winning journalists of the Chicago Tribune and Los Angeles Times. Over the years, it has collected and delivered authoritative, timely and exclusive news, photos, feature and column content to customers in media, business, nonprofit organizations and the general public. Tribune Content Agency was formed in August 2013 when the world’s news and information leader, Tribune Company, merged with the leading Netflix-type service of newspapers, McClatchy. The merger signified the start of a partnership that brings together two of the most respected national newswires and editorial services, connecting a vast and diverse network of editors, reporters and columnists, who deliver the richest news content to media organizations and other customers. TCA’s range of services includes content acquisition, distribution and usage rights. The agency’s portfolio includes original content from its sister papers, plus news from the Associated Press, Reuters, Agence France-Presse, and thousands of global media, partners and independent journalists. In addition to its broad news coverage, TCA provides high impact, award-winning feature stories, and syndicated columnists, such as Pulitzer Prize winners like Leonard Pitts and Pulitzer finalists like Steve Lopez. In addition to Tribune Content Agency’s editorial offerings, the agency produces custom video, graphics, animation and print production services. It provides customers trademarked, exclusive use staff photographers, original graphics collections, instant downloads, data management and digital asset management systems. The agency also provides media marketing services including press release distribution, advertising and promotion, campaigns, and consumer research. These services are available for advertisers, business clients, media companies, portals, websites and more. TCA’s commitment to principles of accuracy and integrity have earned the agency recognition from industry groups such as the Society of Professional Journalists and its core publications, Tribune and Los Angeles Times, have garnered numerous awards from the Pulitzer Prizes and other industry organizations. TCA is committed to the principles of objectivity and the concept that the “people” should have the first word on “news.”

The 2nd Massachusetts Cavalry Regiment was an American Civil War cavalry regiment from Massachusetts that served from 1861 to 1865. It was initially a part of the Army of the Potomac and later served as part of the Army of the Shenandoah. The 2nd Massachusetts Cavalry Regiment was formed on August 30 1861 in response to President Abraham Lincoln's call for the formation of troops from the Bay State. It was organized at Camp Meigs in Readville, Massachusetts. The first commander was Captain John M. Moore. The 2nd Massachusetts was initially made up of eight companies and soon expanded to include a total of twelve. The companies were made up mostly of men from the Bay State, but also included some from other states such as Rhode Island and New Hampshire. They were issued standard blue uniforms and horse equipment. The 2nd Massachusetts saw action in many major battles, including Manassas, Chancellorsville, Gettysburg, Bristoe Station, Petersburg and Appomattox. It was also active in several minor actions, raids, and skirmishes. During their time in the war, the 2nd Massachusetts Cavalry Regiment lost 130 men killed in action, 102 died from wounds, 19 died of disease, and 18 were taken prisoner. The regiment was also credited with 429 Rebel prisoners taken, and 355 Rebels killed or wounded. On December 10, 1865 the 2nd Massachusetts Cavalry Regiment was mustered out of service at Winchester, Virginia after nearly four years in the field. The regiment was honored for their service by the citizens of Boston and the Massachusetts General Court, who gave each man a medal for their service. The 2nd Massachusetts was among the many Union regiments whose sacrifices helped preserve the Union.

Alexander Boyd (1876 – 1930) was an American lawyer who served as county solicitor, or district attorney, of Greene County, Tennessee, from 1917 to 1922. Boyd was born in White Pine, Tennessee, in 1876, to parents William and Mildred Boyd. He attended White Pine High School, and then the University of Tennessee, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Laws degrees in 1899. After college, Boyd was admitted to the bar and established a law practice in Greeneville. In 1917, he was appointed by Tennessee Governor Thomas C. Rye to serve as county solicitor of Greene County, a position he held for five years. During his tenure as county solicitor, Boyd made a name for himself by bringing charges against multiple moonshiners and bootleggers in the area. He was known for his thorough and relentless investigations into these crimes, and he took advantage of lax enforcement of law in rural areas around the county to make arrests. In 1922, Boyd resigned as county solicitor after being elected mayor of Greeneville, a position he held for one year. He served in the Tennessee House of Representatives from 1923 to 1927. He later served as the chairman of the Greene County Democratic Executive Committee from 1927 until his death in 1930. Boyd was a staunch Democrat, and in 1928, he was selected as the Tennessee state chairman of the Al Smith Presidential campaign. In addition to his public service and legal career, Boyd was an active member of the Greene County Bar Association and the Greeneville Chamber of Commerce. Boyd was married to Eunice Boyd and had four daughters who all graduated from college. He was a Freemason and a member of the Episcopal Church. Alexander Boyd died on December 6, 1930, in Greeneville and is buried in Aspenvale Cemetery.

Four Seasons (murals) refers to a series of four fresco murals painted by Italian Baroque master Pietro da Cortona between 1638 and 1639. The murals depict the four allegorical figures of the Greek myths of the four seasons in each of the four corners of Sala dei Virtù e delle Alcove (Room of Virtues and Alcoves) in Palazzo Pamphilj, Rome. Three of the four frescoes are still intact, with the larger and more prominent painting on the east wall. The fresco murals are divided into four panels, each on a separate wall of the room in Palazzo Pamphilj. The central fresco, the dramatic and dynamic "Autumn, is depicted on the east wall, while the other three, "Spring", "Summer" and "Winter", are on the other walls. Each painting is an allegorical representation of the season it depicts: Autumn is colourful and festive, filled with singing and dancing farmers and revelers, while Winter shows a wintery landscape with a small nun praying in a forest and a poor beggar with his dog. Spring is a more serene composition, featuring a waterfall and a shepherd with a staff, while Summer is depicted as a bustling agricultural scene, with harvest ready crops and a farmer leading an enthusiastic team of workers. The murals display the characteristic Baroque style of the period and Cortona's dramatic compositions. His paintings have a distinct grandeur and drama, with their large canvases, strong diagonals and vivid, contrasting colours. Cortona's masterful brushwork can be seen in the lifelike details in the figures and the use of light and shadow to bring out their lively expressions and postures. The Frescoes are highly significant among Cortona's works, showcasing his acclaimed talents in painting monumental decorations for the wealthy clientele of Rome. The Four Seasons frescoes have been reproduced in numerous formats, including prints, engravings and ceramics, and are considered some of the most important murals in Roman Baroque art. They were declared a historic monument by the Italian government in 1921. The original fresco murals were rediscovered in 1896 and restored in 1938. The "Spring" and "Winter" frescoes are still largely complete and are displayed in the Pinacoteca at Palazzo Pamphilj, while the "Summer" fresco is completely lost. The "Autumn" fresco has been restored and is frequenty displayed in other venues such as the Palazzo Barberini and the Palazzo Pitti in Florence. The Four Seasons frescoes are considered one of the great masterpieces of the Baroque period and are amongst the most important mural decorations to have survived from the 17th century. They remain a testament to Pietro da Cortona's artistic genius and technical skill and continue to inspire admirers to this day.

Sanders Township is a township in Pennington County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 155 at the 2000 census. The township was named for Ezra Sanders, who was one of the early settlers of the area and an influential political figure in the region. The terrain within the boundaries of Sanders Township is a mix of farmland, forested areas, wetlands and small lakes. A variety of wildlife can be found in the township and the surrounding area, including white-tailed deer, bald eagles, red foxes, coyotes, wild turkeys and a variety of waterfowl. Sanders Township provides recreational opportunities for locals, including hiking and snowmobiling trails and several fishing lakes. In addition, the nearby Mille Lacs Indian Reservation offers hunting, fishing, wild rice harvesting and cultural events. The first settlers in the area arrived in the 1880s, and the township was established in 1895. The area quickly grew, and in 1920 the township had a population of 815 people. As of the 2000 Census, the population had declined to 155, largely due to the decline in local farming in the area. Today, Sanders Township is still predominantly rural and agricultural. The main industries are farming, logging, and tourism. There are several small businesses in the area, including a grocery store, several small stores and a restaurant. Sanders Township is governed by a board of supervisors. The board meets monthly to discuss and make decisions on zoning issues, budgeting and other administrative matters. There are no incorporated villages within the township, although several unincorporated communities exist, including Willowbrook, Autauga, and Myrtle. The township is in the jurisdiction of the Pennington County Sheriff's Department and the Minnesota State Patrol. The Pennington County Ambulance and Rescue Service is also located in the township. The township is part of the Red Lake School District and students attend school in nearby Red Lake Falls. The district includes a K-12 school and several rural schools. The township is served by the Red Lake Falls Post Office and several churches. The Vermillion Presbyterian Church and the Meadow Lutheran Church are the main churches in the township. Sanders Township is a small, rural community that provides a peaceful atmosphere and plenty of recreation opportunities. Despite a population decline in recent years, the township remains committed to maintaining its rural identity and its agricultural roots.

The January 2020 Pennsylvania Turnpike crash was a chain-reaction crash that occurred on the night of January 5, 2020, along the Pennsylvania Turnpike near the Morgantown exit in Berks County, Pennsylvania. The incident involved nine vehicles and was overseen by the Pennsylvania State Police. The crash resulted in five deaths, including four members of the same family, and several other people injured. The severe winter storm the previous week was thought to be the ultimate cause of the crash. The victims of the crash included four members of a family from Somerville, New Jersey. The family had been visiting Lancaster, Pennsylvania earlier in the day, and were heading to New Jersey on their return trip home when the crash occurred. In total, there were three adults and two children in their minivan, all of whom died in the crash. The other victims of the crash were the drivers of four other vehicles, as well as two passengers in one of the other cars. Unfortunately, all five fatalities succumbed to their injuries as a result of the crash. The crash occurred as a result of a series of collisions that took place over the span of several minutes. Initially, several vehicles traveling in the center lane collided due to dense fog and poor visibility. A few moments later, a minivan traveling behind the initial vehicles collided with the damaged vehicles, and eventually the minivan was pushed by the other cars into the median barrier. The minivan then slammed into the barrier, killing all four of the family members inside. Following the minivan was a tractor-trailer, which did its best to avoid the crash, but ultimately collided with the unresponsive minivan. The Pennsylvania State Police reported that the incident was a result of hazardous conditions from a previous winter storm. However, it was later revealed that the impact of the crash was made worse by a number of other factors, including the failure of several drivers to adhere to the speed limit, a lack of proper signage, and the dense fog and poor visibility that had set in following the storm. In the wake of the crash, an investigation was launched by the Pennsylvania State Police. This investigation included several interviews with the drivers, who maintained that they had followed all applicable laws and regulations prior to the crash. In addition, a detailed analysis was conducted of the entire stretch of the turnpike, as well as a review of the procedures and regulations enforced by the turnpike authority. Ultimately, the crash was determined to be an unavoidable event, caused by the severe winter weather and the inability of the drivers to avoid multiple collisions due to the severe fog. In response to the crash, the Pennsylvania State Police announced a series of updates to improve safety and signage along the turnpike, including stricter enforcement of speed limits and clearer signage regarding hazardous conditions. In April of 2020, a memorial service was held to honor and remember the victims of the crash.

Garhshankar is a town and a notified area in Hoshiarpur district of Punjab, India. It is located on the Punjab side of the Indo - Pak border. It is situated 25 kilometers from Hoshiarpur city and 54 kilometers from Phillaur. Garhshankar comes under the Mohali division of Punjab. Garhshankar was an ancient fort of the Mahal Chand (grandson of Raja Udai Prakash), which was built in 1601. It was later destroyed by the Mughal forces. In 1758, Garhshankar was annexed by MahaRana Ranjeet Singh, the ruler of Punjab. In 1947, India attained independence, and Garhshankar became part of India. Today, Garhshankar has become an important commercial center in the region. It is a hub for various industries such as jaggery making, cotton weaving, and food processing. It also houses several cold storage and food grain markets. Garhshankar is known for its religious shrines such as the historical Maha Chand temple and the Gurudwara Bhabhowan Harkrishan Sahib. The town also has several other temples that are associated with different religions like Jainism, Islam, and Sikhism. Garhshankar’s economy is mainly based on agriculture and industries as about 80 per cent of its people are engaged in the farming sector. Rice, sugarcane, wheat, maize, and vegetables are the main crops cultivated here. Apart from agriculture, Garhshankar also has several flourishing industries such as dairy, poultry, agro-tourism, and dairy-based industries. Garhshankar is well connected by roads and trains to different parts of the country. It is linked to the nearby cities of Hoshiarpur and Phillaur by National Highway and has regular rail services on the Jakhal - Harianthar railway line, connecting it to Jakhal Junction and Harianthar. Garhshankar is one of the fastest - growing towns in the region and is home to a number of educational institutions, such as Garhshankar Degree College and Garhshankar Polytechnic College. The town also houses several private and Government schools that provide quality education to its residents. Garhshankar’s culture is very rich and diverse. It is a mix of various cultures like Punjabi, Rajasthani, and Marwari. It has a vibrant and colorful culture that is evident in its art, literature, music, cuisine, and lifestyle. Garhshankar is renowned for its traditional customs, values, and beliefs. People of this town are very disciplined and dedicated to their work. Garhshankar is known for its hospitality and warm hospitality. People here are very welcoming and helpful in nature. It is a great place to live and explore with its amazing attractions and unique culture.

2797 Teucer (provisional designation 1984 ST) is a uniquely shaped centaur asteroid located in the outer Solar System between the orbits of Jupiter and Neptune. It was discovered on September 22, 1984, by American astronomer Edward Bowell at Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona. The centaur is named after the Greek hero Teucer, son of King Telamon of Salamis and father of bird-ruler King Alastor of Cyprus. At around 30 kilometers in diameter, 2797 Teucer is a relatively large asteroid and is believed to have been dynamically active in the past. It is thought to have been influenced by gravitational perturbations, most likely due to close encounters with the planets Jupiter and Neptune, which explains its highly elongated orbit. The body has a dynamical orbital period of 8.9 years and orbits the Sun at an average distance of 10.3 AU, having a perihelion of 8.45 AU and an aphelion just beyond 12.9 AU. The eccentricity of its orbit is 0.39 and its perihelion location is 7.4° below the ecliptic plane. Observations of 2797 Teucer have revealed a rotation period of about 10 hours. Its reflectivity and color shows that the chemistry of its surface is probably similar to that of other primitive asteroids such as D-type asteroids, suggesting the presence of plausible organic and silicate materials. In 2020, Teucer was observed by the Outer Solar System Origins Survey (OSSOS) team, one of the first surveys of trans-Neptunian objects, in order to increase the understanding of the evolution of outer solar system objects. The OSSOS research showed that this centaur was most likely captured from the Jupiter-family comet population. Furthermore, its light-curve amplitude indicated that it is likely to be a triaxial object, making it of general interest for dynamical and physical studies of outer Solar System bodies. In 2021, a paper published by The Journal of the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada reported on the spectroscopic reflectance variability and spectral similarities between Teucer and other centaur objects. 2797 Teucer is an interesting object due to its peculiar orbit and size. It is representative of the primordial solar system and reveals important information about the evolution of planetary bodies in the outer Solar System.

Spiros Vondas (born 2 December 1967) is a Greek entrepreneur and investor. He is the founder of what is presently known as the Vondas Group, a multinational conglomerate of finance and investment firms headquartered in London. He serves as its current Chairman and CEO. Vondas was born in Athens, Greece, to a family of entrepreneurs. His father, Kostas, had made his fortune in shipping after founding his own shipping line. Vondas grew up in an entrepreneurial atmosphere and was adamant from a young age that he wanted to follow in his father’s footsteps. He began investing in small companies and quickly built a reputation as one of the most successful investors of his generation. Vondas attended the Athens University of Economics and Business and graduated in 1989 with a degree in Economics and Finance. After graduation, he founded the Vondas Group and began to build his portfolio of investments. In the early 2000s, Vondas expanded the scope of his business to include investments in the banking sector. He has since become a major shareholder in banks in countries such as Greece, the United Kingdom, The United States, France, Spain, Hungary, and Cyprus. Vondas is renowned for his success in the banking industry and his investments have garnered a lot of recognition. Credit Suisse named him one of the 'Most Powerful Bankers of the Mediterranean' while Ernst & Young named him 'Entrepreneur of the Year' in the finance sector in 2008. Outside of business, Vondas is a philanthropist. In 2004, he partnered with the Greek government to set up a charity arm of the Vondas Group to focus on providing support to underprivileged communities and educational initiatives. He currently works with the Christian Aid Foundation and is an active patron of several charities across Greece, the UK, and the US. An astute businessman and savvy investor, Vondas has forged a successful career from leading the Vondas Group. He is a firm believer in using his success to benefit others, and has been encouraging people to pursue their dreams through his philanthropic work.

Michela Cerruti (born on 19th October 1990) is an Italian racing driver who has been competing in international motorsport competitions since 2011. Cerruti started her motorsport career in 2008, when she began to compete in Karting championships in Italy. In 2011, she moved up to the Formula Pilota Championship in China, placing 4th overall. In the same year, she also competed in Italian F3 Open, and placed 3rd. In 2012, Cerruti made her first foray into the European Le Mans Series. She was a part of Aidil GP team, and competed in both the GTE and LMP2 categories. After two wins in the GTE category, the team finished the season in 5th overall. In 2013, Cerruti moved to International GT Open, and competed in two series, International GT Open and European Le Mans Series. In that year, she won the International GT Open Championship in the Am class. In 2014, Cerruti was a part of the V8 Racing Team, and she won the Dutch GT Championship in the GT3 category. That year she also competed in the 24 Hours of Spa-Francorchamps in the GTE category. From 2015 to 2018, Cerruti competed in the Blancpain GT Series, competing in both the Sprint Cup and Endurance Cup. She placed 6th overall in the 2015 Sprint Cup, and 5th overall in the 2016 Endurance Cup. In 2018, she was part of Team WRT's lineup in the Blancpain GT Series. In 2019, Cerruti competed in both Formula Regional European Championship, and the TCR Italy Touring Car Championship, where she placed 4th overall. Cerruti is also the first female professional driver to compete in the Suzuka 10 Hours event in Japan. She qualified for the race in 2018, and placed 5th overall. In 2020, Cerruti began competing in the Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters (DTM) series. She became the first female driver since 2006 to compete in that series. Outside racing, Cerruti is an avid snowboarder and surfer. She is also involved in multiple charitable activities, and she has her own foundation which supports and encourages younger female drivers.

M.S. Dhoni: The Untold Story (soundtrack) is an official soundtrack album released in 2016 for the biographical sports drama film of the same name. The movie centres on the life and times of former Indian cricket captain Mahendra Singh Dhoni. The album was released by T-Series on 30 September 2016 and features seven tracks composed by Amaal Mallik apart from one song composed by newcomer Rochak Kohli. The first track, "Besabriyaan", was released on 3 September 2016 and was sung by Armaan Malik. It quickly gained popularity for its powerful and poignant lyrics which highlighted Dhoni's journey in achieving success and reaching the mountaintop. The second track, "Parwah Nahi", was released on 17 September 2016 and featured vocals by Amaal Mallik himself. The song featured some of Mallik's signature beats, along with some catchy whistles and melodic tuens. The other five tracks featured in the album are "Jab Tak", which features vocals by Armaan Malik and is credited to Pritam; "Kaun Tujhe", which features vocals by Palak Muchhal and is credited to Amaal Mallik; "Phir Kabhi", which features vocals by Arijit Singh and is credited to Amaal Mallik; "Sau Dard", which features vocals by Mika Singh and is credited to Rochak Kohli; and "Koi To Aaya", which features vocals by Mohit Chauhan and is credited to Amaal Mallik. The soundtrack album was widely praised and all the tracks were positively received. The vibrant and soulful melodies and emotional lyrics made it one of the most popular albums of the year. The soundtrack album went on to win the Filmfare Award for Best Music Album in 2016. M.S.: Dhoni The Untold Story (soundtrack) is a testament to the brilliance of Amaal Mallik in creating vibrant, melodious music, which combined with the emotions of the movie, made it a timeless hit. It truly is an unforgettable musical experience.

Ra-Ra Zoo, also known as the Ra-Ra Royal Circus, is an Australian based circus and entertainment company founded in 2012 and based in Melbourne, Australia. It is said to provide a diverse range of unconventional acts and entertainment for all ages, from children to adults. It offers a range of performances throughout Australia and South East Asia, and has been described as not just a circus but an experience. Ra-Ra Zoo’s style of entertainment is said to be innovative, immersive and highly visual, while at the same time funny, exciting and inspiring. It focuses on creating original works within a traditional framework, using only the best of contemporary circus, clowning, physical theatre, dance and live music. The company focuses on using music, physical theatre and special props in place of traditional circus acts and props, infusing the show with high energy and excellent performances. This combination creates a highly theatrical and visually-dynamic show. Ra-Ra Zoo often collaborates with other well-known entertainers such as acrobats, clowns and musicians, to create an extraordinary and unique show for spectators. They also have their own in-house performance troupe, the Ra-Ra Zoo Residency Project, which showcases their diverse and talented performers. Ra-Ra Zoo donates a large portion of their profits to various charities and organisations. Their biggest event to date has been their "Big Tops for a Better World" in October 2015. They aimed to raise money for an Australian charity, whilst also promoting social inclusivity and respect. Ra-Ra Zoo is the ideal show for the whole family. It provides fun, laughter, entertainment and a relaxed atmosphere, making it a great outing for everyone. With its emphasis on good quality entertainment, Ra-Ra Zoo is sure to delight everyone who sees it.

Ditte Hansen (born 1986) is a Danish musician and singer-songwriter best known as one half of the electropop duo Junior Senior. Before joining Junior Senior, she attended the Rhythmic Music Conservatory in Copenhagen and pursued a solo career as an underground singer. Hansen's musical beginnings began at a young age when she learned to play bass guitar and piano by ear. She went on to play in several local bands and cover bands, before deciding to pursue music on a full-time basis. Hansen was accepted into the Rhythmic Music Conservatory in 2004 and moved to Copenhagen to pursue her studies. It was while attending the conservatory that she was tapped by her future Junior Senior bandmate Jeppe Laursen. Junior Senior was officially formed in 2004 and quickly gained popularity for their lively and upbeat sound. The band's debut album, D-D-Don't Don't Stop the Beat, was released in 2003 and was met with critical acclaim. The duo recorded three more albums and toured extensively before splitting up in 2012. Hansen's solo career began in 2004 with the release of her debut album, Innocence. The album showcased her unique blend of styles, incorporating rock, pop and electronica elements. She received praise from her fans and critics alike for her heartfelt songwriting, catchy hooks and distinctive voice. In 2010, she released her second solo album, Shoot for the Moon, which featured a more mature, introspective sound. The album was well-received and the lead single, "The Moon is Always There for You," charted in Scandinavia. Hansen continues to tour and is a well-respected mentor for aspiring musicians in her native Denmark. In recent years, she has collaborated with a variety of both established and up-and-coming artists. Additionally, she is a passionate advocate for women's rights and has done multiple charity concerts in support of women's causes.

Peter Dowd (born 29 July 1961) is a British Labour Co-operative politician who has been the Member of Parliament (MP) for Bootle since 2015. Early life Dowd was born on 29 July 1961 in Chelmsford, Essex to William and Alice Dowd. He studied law at the University of Liverpool and was awarded a Master of Laws in 1987. Career Prior to entering politics, Dowd had worked at ICI where he was the Personnel and Industrial Relations Manager. He was a councillor in Sefton from 1991–2003, representing Branfold from 1991–1999 and Netherton and Orrell from 1999–2003. Member of Parliament In 2015, Dowd was elected MP for Bootle, succeeding retiring Labour MP Joe Benton. Following his election he was appointed to the Public Accounts Committee, the body charged with holding the government to account on all aspects of public spending. In 2018 he was appointed as the Chair of the Public Accounts Committee. Under his leadership the committee has investigated spending and procurement practices in relation to Covid-19 pandemic response, especially in relation to the provision of personal protective equipment. In Parliament he is also an advocate for workers’ rights, securing a voice for employees in the boardroom and pushing for enhanced rights for workers in the gig economy. In the 2020 Labour Shadow Cabinet reshuffle Dowd was chosen as the Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury. He is responsible for driving the opposition's scrutiny of government spending, funding and other financial policy decisions. In 2021 he was appointed to the World Justice Project’s International Advisory Council. The group of international justice, law and human rights professionals work to advance rule of law and human rights around the world. Personal life Dowd lives in Bootle with his wife Anne and their two sons. He is a fan of Celtic Football Club and is a season ticket holder. He enjoys music, reading and fitness and holds a black belt in Taekwondo. References 1. "Peter Dowd MP". www.parliament.uk. Retrieved 2021-02-07. 2. "Peter Dowd". TheyWorkForYou. retrieved 2021-02-07. 3. "Peter Dowd MP". https://www.peterdowd.org.uk. Retrieved 2021-02-07. 4. Dowd, P (2017). Greatness in Government: Essential Skills for a Responsible Parliamentary Democracy. London: Fabian Society. 5. "Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury". Labour Party. Retrieved 2021-02-07. 6. "World Justice Project Announces 2021 International Advisory Council". https://worldjusticeproject.org. Retrieved 2021-02-07.

Tony Brown (born Jonathan Anthony Brown, May 7, 1955) is an American record producer, arranger, singer and songwriter. He has been a prominent figure in the music industry for over four decades. Brown is best known for producing and writing a string of hits for a variety of artists, including George Strait, Reba McEntire, Gary Morris, Lionel Richie, Keith Whitley and many others. Brown was born in Nashville, Tennessee. He began his musical career as a touring musician with Conway Twitty before joining the house band of Alan Green at the Exit In, where he worked with fellow Nashville musician Vince Gill. He rose to prominence in the early 1980s when he signed to MCA Records and produced Bonnie Raitt's multi-platinum album "Takin' My Time". This success led to him producing a series of albums for George Strait and Reba McEntire. In addition, Brown was involved in the creation of many other successful albums and singles, most notably "Forever and Ever, Amen" and "When I Call Your Name" for Randy Travis, "Mama He’s Crazy" for the Judds, and "Don't Close Your Eyes" for Keith Whitley. Through the 1990s, Brown continued to produce albums for a variety of artists, both major labels and independents. He received many honors for his work, most notably a Grammy Award for Producer of the Year in 1992. In recent years, Brown has been involved in creating albums and singles for a number of different genres such as pop, country, gospel, and contemporary Christian. He has also gone on to work in television and film, producing soundtracks and music on network series such as Dawson’s Creek and Reba. At present, Brown continues to be a highly sought-after producer and arranger, with his recent credits including Phillip Phillips' 2013 single "Gone, Gone, Gone" and Carrie Underwood's 2018 album Cry Pretty. He has become one of the most respected and sought-after producers in the music industry, and his work has earned him widespread recognition.

Clone (computing) is an electronic device or software program that is a duplicate of an existing system. Cloning is a process in which a single computer is used to create an exact duplicate of another computer. The clone is then used as the source of the data and software applications. Cloning is used to replicate software or data in a computer system and is used in the entertainment industry to create software compilations and virtual copies of video works. The process can also be used to create a backup of a system and its applications. Cloning can also be used to create an exact replica of a software environment on a different computer system. This process is called sandboxing and is used for testing, training and education purposes. Cloning is also used in security and safety measures. When a system is compromised or subjected to attack by viruses, a clone is created to reset the system back to its original operating condition. This ensures that any malicious software or malware has been removed from the system and a fresh start is made. Cloning is a complex process that involves an in-depth knowledge of software and hardware components. It requires accurate data collection and analysis to ensure that the clone system maintains the integrity and functionality of the original system. Clone systems are usually more expensive than standard systems, as they require a higher level of sophistication and customization. The potential risks associated with cloning can be minimized by regularly updating and patching the clone systems. Cloning is a powerful tool for businesses, organisations and individuals. It enables a precise duplication of software or data which can be used to restore or create a new system from an existing one. This also reduces the amount of time taken to restore or transfer a system from one computer to another. The ability to create a precise clone of a system's data and software provides businesses and organisations with the flexibility to build on previous ideas and increase efficiency and productivity. Cloning can also be used to create powerful copies of popular software applications, allowing them to be used by multiple users with little effort. Cloning is a process that has become increasingly popular in the computing industry as it enables quick duplication of software and data, creating greater efficiency and security. As computing technology advances, the cloning process is expected to become increasingly cost effective and secure.

Pembroke, Kentucky is a small unincorporated community located in the southern portion of Christian County, Kentucky. It lies along the banks of the Green River, which runs through the county. The population as of the 2010 census was approximately 350 people. The primary purposes of the small community revolve around recreation, farming, and industry. The Green River, which runs through Pembroke, is popular for recreational activities such as fishing and boating. The community is home to numerous parks and boat ramps along the river, allowing for easy access to the water. In addition, Pembroke has many small streams that flow through the area. These waterways are popular for pan fishing and other forms of fishing. Pembroke is home to several small family-owned farms, which produce commodity crops such as corn, wheat, and soybeans. Dairy and poultry farms are also located nearby. There is also a large poultry processing plant in the area, which provides jobs for many of the local residents. Pembroke is located about ten miles east of the city of Hopkinsville and about seven miles north of the Tennessee border. To the east of Pembroke is the town of Eddyville. Both towns are connected by the Clarence Worley Memorial Trail, which is an 18-mile hiking/biking trail. The trail has several picturesque stops along the way, including this small community of Pembroke. The majority of the population of Pembroke is of Christian faith. The main church in the community is the Pembroke Christ Church, a non-denominational church. The church holds weekly services and a variety of activities for the community. Pembroke is also home to the Green River Arts and Crafts Festival, which takes place every summer. This festival features local artists and craftsmen displaying and selling their work, giving attendees the chance to purchase handmade items directly from the maker. There are also live music performances, food stands, and a variety of children's activities. Pembroke is a small rural community in which the residents take pride in their heritage and strive to preserve the small-town atmosphere for which it is known. It provides a peaceful and friendly atmosphere for those living in the area or visiting for the day. Whether enjoying the local attractions or recreation activities offered in the area, Pembroke remains a great destination for all.

"Poor Little Fool" is a song recorded by Rick Nelson and released in August 1958 as the first single from his album Ricky. It is notable for being the first song ever to reach the Number 1 position on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. The song was composed by Sharon Sheeley, who had previously written and performed the 1957 hit single "Dum Dum". Not long after its release "Poor Little Fool" overtook and replaced "Tequila" as the chart leader. It stayed at the top spot for two weeks, and earned Nelson his first gold record in October 1958. Nelson had previously worked with Sheeley and her then-boyfriend, Eddie Cochran. During those sessions, Nelson became intrigued by a poem she had written. He decided to set the poem to music, with Sheeley co-writing new lyrics. She was also given the writing credit for the song, although Nelson was not credited as a writer. The lyrics describe how a girl has been fooled by an untrustworthy man, although it was not clear if it was written about a real-life experience. The song's lyrics are sung from a first-person perspective and this gave the recording a certain depth that had not been found in other rock 'n' roll recordings. Nelson's recording of "Poor Little Fool" was included in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's list of 500 songs that shaped rock and roll, and VH1 named it the 13th greatest song of the 50s. It was further included in Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time list at No. 257. In January 2006, Nelson's version of the song was named as one of the Songs Of The Century by the Recording Industry Association of America and the National Endowment for the Arts. It was also ranked No. 7 on Billboards list of the Top 100 Songs Of The Rock Era. The song has since been covered by a variety of artists, including Neil Young, Simple Plan, Howie Day, and others. A remake of "Poor Little Fool" by country music singer Clay Walker was featured in an episode of the television series The O.C. in 2004. Walker's version was featured as the title track for his 2005 Greatest Hits compilation, and it was also released as a single.

Stealing First Base, also known as stealing home, is a play in baseball in which a runner on-base attempts to advance to the next base without the aid of a batted ball. It is one of the most exciting and daring plays in baseball and is seen frequently in the major leagues. When successful, the play can be the difference between a win and a loss for the team’s win-loss record. Stealing first is regarded as the most difficult base-stealing play, as the runner must reach the bag with only the break of his leadfoot. The pitcher provides the distraction, as he must be focused on the hitter and not on the runner. Speed and audacity are required to pull off a successful steal. The runner must also rely on the vigilance of the pitcher and catcher. When the pitcher or catcher notices the runner attempting to steal a base, they have a few options. The most common, and the one recommended by professionals, is to step off the rubber and, if time allows, make a throw towards the base. Other methods include a throw directly to the base, the catcher making a quick move towards the base, or the pitcher making a quick glance towards the base. It is important for a runner to remember that in order to steal a base, he must not be tagged before he crosses it. The catcher can also attempt to field the pitch, as well as utilize the pickoff move. The pitcher’s pickoff move is when the pitcher looks towards the runner and attempts to tag him before he reaches the bag. When a successful steal happens, the crowd goes wild. First base steals may be risky, but if done correctly, the risk pays off and the team benefits from an extra runner. Watching a runner steal a base is an exciting play that can happen at any moment in the game and it is always a thrilling to watch a runner successfully steal first.

Marco Coltellini (born 1965) is an Italian photographer and photojournalist. He is best known for his work covering conflict zones, refugee communities, and the effects of war and poverty around the world. Coltellini was born in the small Italian town of Grosseto, where he lived until moving to Siena to study photography in the early 1990s. It was during this period that he developed a passion for photography and a fascination with the medium’s ability to document history, reflect reality, and reveal the way humans interact with their environment. One of Coltellini’s first major projects was a photo reportage on the Bosnian War, in which he travelled to trying cities to document the destruction caused by the conflict. His work was published in Italian newspapers, and earned him national recognition for the first time. In the following years, Marco Coltellini continued to travel not only in the Balkans, but in other war-torn regions across the globe, including Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria and Lebanon. What sets his photos apart is an intimate take on the communities he encountered, which allowed him to provide an accurate picture of the living conditions in these places. In addition to his work as a photojournalist, Marco Coltellini has also worked as a professor and mentor, teaching photography classes at universities in Europe and the United States. In 2011, Coltellini’s 20-year-old son, Luca, died in the Arab Spring riots in Cairo. His death marks the beginning of a creative process in which Coltellini seeks to create an archive of memories and feelings in honor of his son. The corresponding photo series and book, 'The Memory of Luca', was awarded the Noor Multi-level Grant by the World Press Photo organization. Coltellini continues to document and photograph people in conflict-torn countries today and his work has been featured in national and international publications such as National Geographic, The New York Times, The Washington Post, and Time Magazine. He resides in Italy, where he is currently working on a documentary film entitled ‘The Shame of Italy’ that examines the human cost of the country’s continued immigration policies. Throughout his career, Marco Coltellini has worked to document and give voice to those who are most affected by war, displacement and poverty. He has earned numerous awards for his dedication to capturing and telling stories of conflict, fear and resilience.

A seismometer, also known as a seismograph, is a device used to measure, record, and detect seismic activity. The device is typically composed of a strong base and a seismometer, which typically uses a weight and pendulum to detect vibrations in the ground. Seismometers are important tools in seismology, a branch of geophysics that studies earthquakes and their waves. Seismometer readings are used to understand more about the nature of earthquakes and other seismic events, and to predict potential disasters. The earliest seismometers were based on a tilt sensor that measured the angle of the ground relative to the horizon, then converting the measured tilt into a proportion of the intensity and magnitude of an earthquake. This type of device was used by the ancient Chinese to measure earthquakes in the second century BC. Modern seismometers, however, have undergone a significant evolution. Digital seismometers, also known as digital seismographs, are much more advanced than their predecessors. They utilize a variety of methods, including motion sensors and accelerometers, for measuring ground motion generated by seismic waves. Different types of digital seismometers have various capabilities, with some being able to measure both horizontal (from side to side) and vertical (from top to bottom) motion. Modern seismometers are also very sensitive in order to accurately measure motion, and can detect vibrations that are partially caused by human activities such as construction and traffic. They can also detect ground tremors caused by natural phenomena such as landslides and earthquakes. This information can be used by seismologists and engineers to understand more about the underlying causes of an earthquake and to make predictions about future seismic events. Seismometers are also helpful in detecting underground nuclear tests and other activities of humans. The data collected by the seismometer can be used to detect any potential nuclear tests that are conducted underground, therefore helping to reduce the chance of an international nuclear incident. In addition to providing seismic information, seismometers can also be used in energy exploration. By detecting vibrations from deep beneath the surface of the Earth, seismometers can help detect underground deposits of oil and gas. This type of data can be used for geologic mapping and for locating areas of high petroleum potential. Seismometers are an invaluable device for usage in research, energy exploration, and for predicting the effects of seismic activity. As technology develops and becomes more advanced, the capabilities of seismometers have also greatly improved. They have become an essential tool in the fields of geophysics, energy exploration, and in helping to protect humans from harm caused by natural phenomena such as earthquakes.

I Knew Jesus (Before He Was a Star) was a 1971 single by the American gospel quartet The Blind Boys of Alabama. The song was composed and arranged by album producer Johnny Fields and was recorded at Fame Recording Studios in Muscle Shoals, Alabama. The song is notable as the Blind Boys' first secular single, a move that was considered by many to be sacrilegious at the time. The single was a minor hit on R&B radio, as well as receiving some limited airplay on rock radio in the United States. The song has since been covered by various musical acts over the years, including Bonnie Raitt and Kim Weston. It has also been featured in the films The Apostle (1997) and We Are Marshall (2006). I Knew Jesus (Before He Was a Star) is a mid-tempo gospel-soul song that features lead vocals from Clarence Fountain, backed by the other members of the Blind Boys. The track also includes Bill Helm on piano, Raymond Moore on guitar, and Clarence Carter and David Hood on bass. The song uses a chorus of backing vocalists to enhance the sound. The lyrics feature a comparison between a gospel singer's recognition of Jesus and the star-studded admiration of the same figure. The singer proclaims, "They say that He's the King of Kings / But I knew Jesus before all those things / He's still my Lord, no matter who sings". The song is often interpreted as a statement of faith, in which the singer refuses to be swayed by the praise of the masses. The Blind Boys of Alabama have included "I Knew Jesus (Before He Was a Star)" in their live sets ever since its original release, and it has become one of their signature songs over the years. The group have also recorded several gospel sequels to the track, such as "He's Still My Lord Again and Again". I Knew Jesus (Before He Was a Star)" remains a classic cut in the Blind Boys of Alabama discography, and continues to be an influence on spiritual music to this day.

Edwin Lascelles, 1st Baron Harewood (9 March 1846 – 7 March 1929) was one of the largest land owners in Yorkshire, England. He was the eldest son of Henry Lascelles, 5th Earl of Harewood, and his father's heir apparent. He was created the first Baron Harewood of Harewood in the County of York in the Peerage of the United Kingdom in 1893. Lord Harewood was educated at Eton College from 1856 to 1862. In 1866, he married Julia Theresa, the third daughter of Major-General William Baillie-Hamilton and later acquired a Gold Thistle for Scottish landowners for his wife. He started his career in banking, managing his late father's property in Yorkshire. He also served as High Sheriff of Yorkshire from 1870 to 1871 and succeeded as the 6th Earl of Harewood in 1892. As well as his business interests, Lord Harewood was a prominent supporter of both the Royal Agricultural College and the Yorkshire Agricultural Society, which he chaired in 1891, and regularly attended Agricultural Shows. Lord Harewood was a member of the House of Lords and was a director of the Great Northern Railway. During his times, he also served as the Chairman of the Lascelles Shipping Company and Cubitt’s Tannery Company. He was also a Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire (KBE). In 1894, Lord Harewood was named a Deputy Lieutenant of the North Riding of Yorkshire. He also held a commission in the 1st West York Yeomanry from 1872 to 1885. He was made Alderman of the East Riding of Yorkshire in 1893. He also held a directorship of the Alliance Assurance Company (1900–1908) and the Alliance Universal Insurance Company (1909–1917). Through his life, Lord Harewood owned many estates, including Lotherton Hall, near Leeds, and Russ Hill, near Crawley. He was also a generous benefactor, particularly to Harewood House, his ancestral home, and his time there is reflected in extensive fine art collections, including a remarkable group of paintings by Canaletto, and other Renaissance masters, which he inherited from his father. Lord Harewood passed away on 7 March 1929 at the age of 82. He was survived by his two sons, Henry Lascelles, 2nd Baron Harewood, and William Lascelles, 2nd Earl of Harewood, and his daughter, Lady Maud Lascelles. He was buried at Harewood Church, near Leeds.

Biz Television is an international business news media company based in California, USA. Founded in 2004 by a group of ambitious investors and journalists, the network provides insights into important global trends and developments in the business world for millions of viewers around the world. The network's headquarters is based in the small city of Anaheim and is the home to over 20 shows, such as its flagship program, the Biz World Magazine Hour, which was the first business news program regularly broadcast on digital television. The show is broadcast throughout the world via cable and satellite networks, as well as digital and terrestrial outlets. Other flagship programs on Biz Television include Business Weekly Report, which provides viewers with weekly updates on the latest economic and financial news; and Market Talk, which addresses current economic issues taking place in Europe, Asia, and the United States. In addition to its programming, Biz Television is a valuable source of industry news and information for investors, entrepreneurs and business professionals alike. The network offers daily news bulletins and regular interviews with leaders from the business world. It also runs four online services - Biz TV Online, Business Insider, Finance Weekly, and The Trading Forum. Biz Television is committed to delivering the highest quality of accurate and timely business news, and its team of reporters, correspondents and analysts have wide experience in the business world. In addition, the network works in partnership with numerous educational organisations across the globe to provide additional resources and materials to help viewers engage in their learning. Biz Television also hosts an annual awards ceremony – the Biz TV Entrepreneur & Investor Awards – to celebrate and recognise outstanding individuals, institutions and organisations which have made an extraordinary contribution to the world of business. Today, Biz Television reaches more than 120 countries across the world, making it a valuable industry resource for business professionals, entrepreneurs and investors alike. The network continues to grow and has increased its coverage to 12 hours per day, receiving more than 5 million viewers worldwide.

Jeremy Hutchinson, Baron Hutchinson of Lullington (born 8 August 1931) is a British lawyer specialising in human rights, libel and obscenity law, and a member of the House of Lords. Hutchinson was called to the bar at Gray's Inn in 1958 and then progressed to Queen's Counsel in 1978. He has seven honorary degrees, including honorary doctorates from the universities of Birmingham and Buckingham, and King's College London. As a barrister, Hutchinson is considered to be one of the leading and most respected figures in his field. He is an acknowledged expert in his principal area of practice, which focuses on litigation. Throughout his legal career, Hutchinson has worked successfully to defend those prosecuted for potentially controversial and complex criminal cases, including providing legal assistance to Christine Keeler, John Stonehouse and Jeremy Thorpe. In 2012 Hutchinson was the subject of a BBC dramatisation entitled "Jeremy Thorpe, a very British accusation". In 2004, he was appointed a peer as Baron Hutchinson of Lullington, of Lullington in the County of Somerset. In 2006, he was appointed to the House of Lords Select Committee on Religious Offences. He is a member of both the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights. He was made a Freeman of his Inn of Court in 1992 and remains active in the House of Lords. Hutchinson is the author of several articles on human rights and libel protection, and has acted as a consultant to the United Nations on these topics. In 2005, he was included in a list of Britain's one hundred most influential lawyers. Additionally, he has been involved with many charitable organisations, including Cardiff Bay Opera (now Welsh National Opera) and the Great Ormond Street Hospital. He continues to provide pro bono advice on select cases for Liberty. Hutchinson is married to the Baroness Massey of Darwen and they have two sons and one daughter. References: 1. "Jeremy Hutchinson". Hansard 1803–2005. Retrieved 26 November 2014. 2. "Jeremy Hutchinson". Gray's Inn. Retrieved 26 November 2014. 3. "The One Hundred: The 100 Most Influential Lawyers in England and Wales". The Lawyer. July 2005. Retrieved 28 December 2017. 4. "Jeremy Hutchinson: Profile". BBC. 22 May 2018. Retrieved 28 December 2017.

Future Medicine (also known as 21st-century medicine, advanced medicine, personalized medicine, or predictive medicine) refers to an emerging medical paradigm which entails the use of cutting-edge technology, including artificial intelligence, robotics, and machine learning, to enable the delivery of more precise, accurate, and personalized treatments for disease. Future medicine is a rapidly emerging field and its application has the potential to revolutionize healthcare in the 21st century. The use of this advanced technology will enable healthcare providers to diagnose and treat patients more quickly and accurately by providing highly precise information about the individual patient. By integrating data from a variety of sources and using advanced algorithms, AI and machine learning, doctors will be able to make personalized treatments based on individual medical histories, symptoms, and genomes. This data-driven approach will help to reduce errors and enable doctors to more quickly and effectively create personalized treatments that address the individual patient’s needs. In addition to improving diagnoses and treatment plans, future medicine will also be applied to the prevention of disease. By analyzing individual health data, doctors will be able to recognize patterns and early signs of potential illnesses that may be developing. This will enable them to better advise their patients on the preventive measures they can take to reduce or eliminate the risk of developing certain illnesses. Furthermore, sophisticated forms of telemedicine will be available, allowing patients to receive medical advice, diagnosis, and treatment without ever leaving their homes. Finally, future medicine will also help to reduce the cost of medical treatments by providing more cost-effective solutions. By using AI and machine learning, healthcare providers will be able to identify and target treatments that are most likely to be effective and provide the greatest value. Furthermore, predictive analytics and machine learning will be used to identify problem areas earlier, making it possible for treatments to be delivered more quickly and efficiently, resulting in better outcomes and fewer costs. Overall, future medicine holds tremendous potential to revolutionize healthcare and make healthcare delivery more precise and cost-effective. By applying cutting-edge technology, healthcare providers will be able to provide more accurate diagnoses and treatments that are tailored to the individual patient, resulting in improved results and outcomes. Additionally, this will lead to earlier detection of illnesses and more cost-effective treatments, leading to greater savings for patients and healthcare systems.

The Dissolution of Czechoslovakia was a peaceful dissolution of the former nation of Czechoslovakia that began on November 25th, 1992 and was completed on January 1st, 1993. Its heritage shares roots in the history of several different nations, including the Czechs and Slovaks. The dissolution ended 75 years of continuous existence of the nation of Czechoslovakia and ultimately carved out two new sovereign states: The Czech Republic and Slovakia. The dissolution was peaceful and not caused by civil unrest or international intervention; it was driven by a growing desire for greater autonomy within the two entities of the former state. Czech and Slovak citizens had very distinct cultural backgrounds and different experiences under the communist regime; this contributed to the decision to dissolve Czechoslovakia. Another factor was the changing political forces in Europe; the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991 affected the unity of Czechoslovakia and the two countries went from being allies in a tier of Eastern Bloc nations to having different geopolitical interests and ambitions. The legislative dissolution of Czechoslovakia was renamed the “Act on the Agreement for the Dissolution of Czechoslovakia”, with representatives from the Czech Republic and Slovakia signing it in Prague on December 26th, 1992. The document outlined the dissolution of the federal state and created a clear path forward for each republic to function as independent states. Other internationally binding documents were signed between the two countries regarding the peaceful transition and joint area management such as the “Bratislava Agreement”. This agreement specified financial regulations, privatization of certain enterprises, and jointly managed economic operations. The effects of the dissolution were widely positive in terms of economic growth and human rights. The newly created states developed extensively; while there was an initial decline in the gross domestic product, it eventually increased to higher levels than prior to the dissolution, positively affecting the Republics’s citizens. Human rights also improved for both countries; following the federalization of their governments and the collapse of the Soviet Union, the Czech Republic and Slovakia established a more democratic and free government. Although the dissolution of Czechoslovakia was a peaceful transition, some tensions remain between the two countries. However, the dissolution of the former state has allowed both nations to develop independently and create their own identities. The legacy of the dissolution will be shaped by the two independent countries it created, and the experiences of those individuals who lived in the former state. In conclusion, the Dissolution of Czechoslovakia in 1992 marked a new chapter in the history of Eastern Europe. It freed the Czech Republic and Slovakia from the oppressive Soviet rule and enabled the citizens of both nations to gain independence, economic progress and improved human rights. The legacy of the dissolution will have a lasting effect on the history of the region and the two independent countries.

Paul Shapiro (born October 13, 1978) is an American film and television writer, producer and director. He is best known for directing the independent films Planet of the Apes (2001), The Hotel (2004), Days of Wrath (2008) and March of the Dead (2009). Shapiro was born and raised in Brooklyn, New York. He studied film and television at New York University. His early writing and directing experience included short films, music videos and commercials. In 2001, Shapiro wrote and directed his first feature film, Planet of the Apes. The film was well-received by critics and was eventually released theatrically in the United States. In 2004, Shapiro wrote and directed the independent film The Hotel, starring Stephen Baldwin and Eric Stoltz. The film was a critical and commercial success, and was released theatrically and on home video in the United States. In 2008, Shapiro wrote and directed Days of Wrath, a suspense-thriller starring Jeff Fahey and Tobin Bell. The film was released theatrically in the United States and internationally. In 2009, Shapiro wrote and directed March of the Dead, a zombie movie starring Malcolm McDowell and Michael Biehn. The film was released theatrically in the United States and internationally. Shapiro has been recognized for his work with numerous awards and nominations. He has won two Cinefantastique Visionary Awards, a Hollywood Film Award and a Writers Guild of America Award. He has also received multiple nominations from the Directors Guild of America and been a finalist for the Writers Guild of America's Chesterfield Award. Shapiro is currently in pre-production for his upcoming feature film Zion, scheduled for release in 2020.
