The municipality is well known for its wide variety of fruit, vegetables and wine grapes, which are grown in the valley. The surrounding area is also home to a number of wineries, including Cousiño Macul, Concha y Toro, and Casa Silva. Tourists often come to the area to visit these wineries and savor the local cuisine. The municipality is home to a number of historical sites, such as the Observatorio Jotabeche, an astronomical observatory built in 1833. It is one of the oldest structures in the region, and it is still used today by scientists and amateur astronomers alike. Another notable landmark is the San Roque Chapel, built in 1814 as a Greek-style chapel. The municipal market of Jotabeche is an icon in the area and a great place to see local culture. It contains a variety of vendors that sell items such as fruits, vegetables, meats, and local products. It also includes a public library and cultural center. Jotabeche is also known for its local festivals, such as the Fiesta de San Roque, held each September to celebrate the Patron Saint of the municipality. Other festivals in the area include the Fiestas Patrias and Petrohue, two festivals that celebrate Chilean independence and culture. Sports are popular in Jotabeche and the local football team, Jotabeche Huasos, is a member of Chilean Primera Division. The team has enjoyed some success, qualifying for the playoffs every year since 2017. Jotabeche is a popular destination for tourists looking to experience the culture and history of Santiago. Its proximity to Santiago makes it a great day-trip destination and the surrounding area in the vivid Maipo Valley offers plenty of activities, from wine tasting to local markets, that make it an interesting place to visit.

The Count of Lucena is a Spanish aristocratic title bestowed by King Juan Carlos I of Spain to Cayetano Yáñez de la Almedina y Lucena in 1981. The recipient of the title is Don Cayetano Yáñez de la Almedina y Lucena, the first and current Count of Lucena. Don Cayetano Yáñez de la Almedina y Lucena was born in Madrid on April 12, 1948. He is the son of Don Cayetano Yáñez de la Almedina y Vega and Doña Josefina Lucena y Arcocha. He is an attorney at law who specializes in administrative law and is a professor of Human Rights at the University of Cordoba, Spain. Don Cayetano Yáñez de la Almedina y Lucena was the mayor of Argamasilla de Alba (a municipality in the Province of Córdoba, Spain) from 1983 to 1999 and Vice-President of the Province of Córdoba from 1999 to 2004. In 1981, King Juan Carlos I of Spain bestowed the title "Count of Lucena" to Don Cayetano Yáñez de la Almedina y Lucena in recognition of his contributions to civic life and politics in the Province of Córdoba. The title includes the hereditary subordination of the village of Purchena, Spain, and the attachment to it of the towns of Aljucén and Negratín, both in the Province of Granada. As Count of Lucena, Don Cayetano Yáñez de la Almedina y Lucena is a member of the Grand Catalan Council, a body established by King Juan Carlos I of Spain in 1981 as part of the Spanish Monarchy's devolution of powers to the autonomous regions of Spain. In 2009, Don Cayetano Yáñez de la Almedina y Lucena was recognized by the Association of Anthropologist, Economists and Politicians with the "Premio Internacional Amigos de Cervantes," an honorary award given to those persons who have distinguished themselves in the promotion of peace and understanding amongst the peoples of the world. The Count of Lucena, Don Cayetano Yáñez de la Almedina y Lucena is a member of the nobility of Spain and holds an both ancient and modern titles of nobility, such as Count of Lucena, as well as other titles of honour, such as "Grandee of Spain," "Knight of the Order of Isabella the Catholic" and "Grand Master of the Order of the Royal Martyrs of Spain." His official seal shows the arms of the countship, or coat of arms, of Lucena. Don Cayetano Yáñez de la Almedina y Lucena is married to Doña Purificación Palomo Fernández, daughter of Don Luis Palomo Izquierdo and Doña Carolina Fernández Díaz, and has five children. The current Count of Lucena is Don Cayetano Yáñez de la Almedina y Lucena, the first to hold the title.

Ephippiger terrestris, commonly known as the common spotted grasshopper, is a species of insect in the family Acrididae. It is found in France and a number of Mediterranean countries, including Italy, Spain, and Greece. It is recognized as a pest in some parts of Europe and a number of countries have issued import restrictions on agricultural goods linked to the species. Ephippiger terrestris is a medium-sized, moth-like grasshopper. It is typically brown in color with spots on the tegmina and hindwings, although these can range from plain to uniformly colored. The head and legs are usually yellowish-brown, and the antennae are relatively long in comparison with other members of the Acrididae family. Males and females can be distinguished by their wing size and shape; males possess much larger wings than females. The species is sexually dimorphic and exhibits courtship and mating behaviors typical of grasshoppers. The female lays her eggs in the soil during the early autumn within small burrows, typically in warm, dry areas. The eggs remain dormant over the winter months and hatch in the springtime. The larvae undergo five instars before they reach maturity, typically between July and August. Adults typically live for between 3 and 6 months. The diet of E. terrestris consists of a range of grasses and other vegetation, but is strongly dependent on the local ecology of each population and may vary considerably between areas. The species is carnivorous and is known to feed on other small insects, such as aphids and other immature insects. The species is of agricultural importance due to its potential to damage and consume commercially important plants. Control strategies for the species vary based on geographical circumstances and may include biological control strategies such as releasing predatory species or insect parasitoids. Pesticide applications have also been recorded although their effectiveness is debatable. Ephippiger terrestris is considered a species of conservation concern due to its restricted extent of occurrence, small population size, and continuing declines in the quality of its habitat. The species is listed on the IUCN Red List as Near Threatened and is included in Annex IV of the EU Habitats Directive. Conservation efforts should focus on the protection of existing habitat, as well as the creation of new habitats through restoration and management.

Barham is a small village in the district of Huntingdonshire in the East of England. It lies approximately 4 miles southeast of St Neots. It is situated close to the border with Cambridgeshire to the east, and the A1(M) motorway to the north and south. The history of Barham dates back to the Anglo-Saxon period. The name Barham could come from the Old English words "bere" (barley) and "ham" (monastery) or from "bereham" (barley homestead). Barham was mentioned in the Domesday Book of 1086 as a small manor belonging to the Abbey of St Peter at Westminster. It then remained part of that religious estate until the Dissolution of the Monasteries in the 16th century, when it was granted to the Crown. The village lies on a low stream of the River Great Ouse which runs along the eastern edge of Barham. Historically, the village was an important trading centre for the area, but its importance declined in the 19th century as the railway network grew and the area became more industrialized. Barham is home to the Church of St Helen, which dates from the 13th century. Inside the church is the 12th century Barham font, which is a rare example of Romanesque art. The church also houses a vaulted crypt, an organ and a tower, accessible only by a spiral staircase. The old Barham railway station was serviced by the Midland and Great Northern Joint Railway, which ran along an east-west track from St Neots to King's Lynn. The station was closed in 1959 after passenger services were withdrawn from the line in 1959. Barham today is a quiet village, well placed for access to many of the attractions of the Huntingdonshire area. It has one pub, the Barley Mow, which is situated on the A1(M) and offers a warm welcome to visitors. The parish of Barham covers an area of 914 acres (371 hectares) and had a population of919 at the 2011 census. The population remains largely rural, with the majority of people still living in the village itself.

Hartington Hall is a Grade I listed Victorian country house located near Hartington Village in the Peak District National Park, Derbyshire, England. It was built for the Duke of Devonshire in 1842 and remains the activity of the Dukes of Devonshire and their family to this day. The house is situated in the heart of rolling farmland and parkland, surrounded by a large estate of approximately 8,000 acres. The estate is owned and managed by the Devonshire family, who purchased the land in 1719 to build the present estate. Hartington Hall is still the family home of the Duke of Devonshire and his wife, the Dowager Duchess of Devonshire. The house was designed by the architect William Burn and is built in the Tudor Gothic style. The large 3-story building is constructed of grey and blue limestone, with numerous turrets, gables and a large porte-cochère. Inside, the main rooms are decorated with period furniture and artworks. There are also three large reception rooms and a number of bedrooms, as well as a picture gallery, library and a servants wing. The gardens of the Hall are particularly impressive; they were established in the 19th century and laid out according to the English Landscape Movement. The gardens include a maze, a holly tree walk, a pinetum, a Victorian rose garden and a fernery. The Hall is open to the public, who can explore the gardens and part of the house. There are guided tours available and the estate hosts frequent events, including concerts, operas and guided tours of the house. It is also the venue for many weddings, parties and conferences. Hartington Hall is still an integral part of the life of the Devonshire family and their estate. They have taken great care to keep the House in good condition and to ensure that it will continue to be preserved in the future.

Inspirations for James Bond is an exploration of the historical and cultural factors that influence the character of James Bond, codenamed "007" in the popular series of novels and films. First appearing in the 1953 novel Casino Royale, the character of James Bond has become one of the most iconic characters in the culture of the 20th and 21st centuries. This article examines the many inspirations that author Ian Fleming and the many screenwriters, producers, and directors had that helped to shape the character of James Bond and the stories of his remarkable adventures. One major inspiration was the British novelist and Intelligence Bureau agent, William Stephenson. Codename "Intrepid" during World War II, Stephenson had a knack for operating behind enemy lines and performing daring feats to weaken Nazi forces in Europe. Fascinated by the exploits of Stephenson, author Ian Fleming patterned the character of Bond after the talents and feats of Stephenson. Historical accounts of Stephenson had a profound effect on Fleming, who wove those accounts into the fabric of the novel Casino Royale and subsequent James Bond novels. In addition to William Stephenson, popular spy novels of the era were also influential in the construction of the character and styles of James Bond. During the 1950s and 1960s, popular spy novels include authors such as Eric Ambler, Graham Greene, and Len Deighton. The style of the Bond stories shifted from their primarily Cold War espionage origins to embrace sheer adventure stories and outlandish “Bond villain” villains, mirroring the popular trend of thrillers during this era. The success of James Bond in the late 1950s and 1960s also coincided with the worldwide popularity of rock and roll. Virtually all of the Bond film scores contain numerous guitars and drums, with occasional use of brass and strings, to give the Bond films a signature sound of their own. Legends of the rock world, including David Bowie and Paul McCartney, have also been featured in many of the Bond films, while singers such as Shirley Bassey, Nancy Sinatra, and Tom Jones continue to be extremely influential in the continuation of the Bond legacy due to the success of their many theme songs. Inspirations for James Bond have also extended to the action-oriented stunts and gadgets seen in many of the films. Novels such as Jules Verne's Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea provide an obvious influence for the underwater action sequences of The Spy Who Loved Me (1977) and Moonraker (1979). Furthermore, the popularity of science fiction in the mid-to-late 20th century provided endless possibilities for special effects-laden and futuristic adventures like Goldeneye (1995)and Tomorrow Never Dies (1997). Throughout the characters of James Bond’s many adventures, he has become a global phenomenon, and influence from countless creative and cultural sources from the globe have shaped the character and the stories. As these varied inspirations continue to be combined and explored, James Bond will undoubtedly remain as a thrilling, exciting cornerstone of entertainment culture.

The Confederation of Italian Entrepreneurs Worldwide (CIE) is an international, non-governmental organization founded in 1997 that seeks to promote Italian entrepreneurship across the globe. The organization is based in Rome, Italy and is open to Italian entrepreneurs worldwide, regardless of the type, size or scope of their business. The CIE strives to encourage networking and collaboration amongst Italian entrepreneurs based abroad, as well as to support their direct investments in Italy. The organization's aim is to facilitate the growth of Italian businesses and to develop an international network among entrepreneurs, public institutions, and associations of the Italian diaspora. The CIE provides a range of services and support to its members, including hosting workshops and seminars on topics related to international business and Italian regulations and laws. It also offers legal, financial and professional advice, as well as educational programmes to help Italian entrepreneurs become more competitive in the global market. Additionally, it seeks to promote Italian entrepreneurship in foreign countries and to contribute to the development of bilateral economic relations with Italian businesses. In 2008, the CIE launched the Italian Community Awards, an annual event which seeks to recognize and promote the achievements of Italian entrepreneurs and businesses across the globe. The award celebrates those who have made a positive contribution to the international community, and seeks to recognize and promote the achievements of Italian entrepreneurs on a global scale. The CIE regularly joins other organizations, especially non-profit associations, with the aim of collaborating in order to achieve its objectives. The association is a member of the World Association of Major International Organizations (WAMIO), the BRICS Network, and the European Business Conferences Partners. In 2016, the CIE joined the European Commission's “Entrepreneurs for Growth” initiative and became the official representative of the Italian Diaspora in the European Union. Overall, the CIE is a major force in promoting Italian entrepreneurship worldwide, having actively engaged in promoting a wide range of activities that foster mutual growth and cooperation between international business owners.

Prahlada (English: Genuine Devotion) is a 1934 Indian language silent Hindu mythological film directed by Chithralekha and released in the south Indian languages of Telugu and Tamil. It is the first mythological film made in India and is based on the story of Prahalada, as seen in the Hindu holy book Bhagavata Purana. The script of the movie was written by Chithralekha and adapted from the Purana story. The cast of the film includes B. N. Rao, Malathi, Y. V. Rao, K. Venkamma, V. K. Bharati, M. C. Amaravathi, M. V. Subba Rao, E. Rama Rao, and P. S. Mani. The movie focuses on Prahalada, a devotee of Lord Vishnu and son of the demon king Hiranyakashyapu. The movie shows how Prahalada, through his devoted practice of Lord Vishnu, ultimately defeats his father’s devils and saves his people. The movie gained immense popularity when it was released and is seen as one of the most successful mythological movies from the 1930s. Nihal and Chithralekha’s direction of the movie was praised for its ability to blend mythological storytelling with cinematic flair. The depiction of characters and their roles in the movie were also praised for adding a sense of authenticity to the movie. The music for the movie was composed by K. Venkamma, who worked with various regional singers to give it a regional flavor. The melodious soundtrack of the movie was well received by the audiences and remains popular even today. The cinematography of the movie was carried out by R. Rao, and the film was edited by K. A. Muthuswami. Prahlada is seen as an iconic movie of this genre and has been mentioned in various books and articles discussing Hindu mythology and cinema. The success of Prahlada has been attributed to the work of its crew and its ability to portray a timeless story in a modern cinematic manner. The movie was awarded the National Film Award for Best Feature Film at the 3rd National Film Awards in 1955. The popularity of the movie has led to many modern representations of the story of Prahlada, including television serials and movies.

Dr Benjamin Twist is an American medical doctor and scientist, who specialises in the field of molecular biology. He is best known for his research into the genetic basis of certain diseases, and his distinguished teaching of molecular biology. Twist was born in Amarillo, Texas and attended the University of Texas School of Medicine. After graduating in 1983, he moved to San Francisco and completed a fellowship in molecular genetics at the California Institute of Technology. He then worked at the University of California, San Francisco, where he earned his PhD degree in 1989. Twist was hired by the University of Arizona in 1990, where he became professor of molecular biology. He was instrumental in developing the molecular genetics department there, and was highly valued as an instructor and mentor. He remained in his position until his retirement in 2016. Throughout his career, Twist has conducted numerous research studies on the genetic basis of diseases such as cancer, heart disease, and neurologic disorders. His lab has identified new genetic mutations associated with these diseases, and his research has led to greater understanding of the underlying causes of genetic conditions. In 1999, Twist was awarded a prestigious MacArthur Fellows award, in recognition of his research accomplishments. He has been on the editorial board of numerous journals, including the Journal of Molecular Biology and the New England Journal of Medicine. He has also served as an adviser to the National Institutes of Health, the World Health Organization, and the American Medical Association. Twist has authored or co-authored several books and textbooks on molecular biology, and has contributed chapters to numerous textbooks. He has served on numerous committees and government panels and been invited to speak at numerous conferences and seminars throughout his career. In 2006, Twist was one of the founders of the International Institute for Human Genome Research, which promotes collaboration and education in the field of genetics. In recognition of his contributions to the field, the Ben Twist Award for Outstanding Contributions in Molecular Biology has been established in his honor. Dr Benjamin Twist has had an illustrious career in molecular biology and is highly respected throughout the field. His many accomplishments have made him a leader in his field and his research continues to benefit the medical world.

The Linear Park of the Saint-Charles and Berger Rivers is a public green space located in the Canadian city of Montreal. The park is composed of two linear strips of land that runs along both rivers, and the park straddles the Saint-Charles and Berger Rivers for 13.4 kilometers. The Linear Park of the Saint-Charles and Berger Rivers was established in 1972, aiming to provide access for the people of Montreal to the rivers for recreation and sport activities. It covers over 170 hectares of land, and includes 1.5 million trees and bushes, along with picnic and playground areas. The park also includes a wide range of species of birds, including over 300 species of waterfowl. There are also beavers, muskrats, owls, hawks, ospreys and other wildlife in the area. The park also offers facilities that can allow the public to get engaged in recreational activities such as hiking, biking, kayaking, and canoeing. The Linear Park also offers a variety of walking paths that visitors can use to explore the grounds. Visitors are also able to rent kayaks and canoes at designated spots in the park. Montrealers can also enjoy a variety of artistic and cultural events that take place in the park, such as theater nights and outdoor movie screenings. The park is managed and maintained by the Parc Linear of the St. Charles and Berger Rivers, a non-profit organization that is responsible for the upkeep of the park. The Linear Park of the Saint-Charles and Berger Rivers is an important green space for the people of Montreal, offering them access to the rivers, as well as recreational and cultural activities. The park is an integral part of the municipality, and is a great example of the connection between nature and culture.

A Bell for Adano is a novel published in 1944 written by American author John Hersey. The novel tells the story of U.S. Army Major Victor Joppolo, who is sent to the town of Adano, in Sicily, after Italy is liberated from the Nazis. The title of the novel refers to Joppolo’s attempt to restore the town’s bell that was stolen by the Nazis. The novel focuses on the struggles of the local townspeople as they attempt to piece together their lives after the recent events of World War II. They are faced with an influx of American military personnel as they try and restore order to the town. Throughout this process, emotions run high, especially after Joppolo’s decision to assist the citizens in their need for a bell to mark the passing hours. They quickly become triumphant in their pursuit of the bell that had been taken away by the Nazis. At the heart of the novel is Major Joppolo’s struggles to bridge the cultural gap that exists between the townspeople and his American military counterparts. He goes to great lengths to conduct business and show respect for local customs, despite the military’s orders to strictly adhere to standard operating procedures. By the end of the novel, Joppolo finds himself in the unenviable position of attempting to serve the needs of both populations, while struggling to do what’s right and protect the best interests of both groups. The novel was adapted into a 1945 film directed by Henry King, and starred John Hodiak, Gene Tierney and Ernest Borgnine. It is based on John Hersey’s Pulitzer Prize-winning novel and is the first American film to deal directly with the theme of the Italian campaign in World War II. A Bell for Adano remains one of the most critically acclaimed books of the era, and is viewed as a deeply moving story of the human capacity for resilience in the face of great suffering and upheaval. Its themes of lost tradition, identity, and struggle in the aftermath of war continue to resonate deeply to modern audiences.

Party Headquarters is a term used to refer to the physical headquarters of any political party or organization. Political parties in different countries often have different structures of their party headquarters. The headquarters can be used for a variety of activities, such as training staff and volunteers, drafting policies and campaigns, holding meetings and rallies, holding fundraisers, and more. They are typically located in major cities, often near other political organizations. In the United States, many of the major political parties maintain state-level headquarters in each state. These state headquarters often have large staffs and serve as important campaign and election centers for the given party. Additionally, there will often be multiple offices for large metropolitan areas. In addition to these, many states will also have a national-level headquarters, which can coordinate activities and are in charge of running major national campaigns. In other countries, the headquarters of party organizations may vary, depending on the local political situation. In some countries, the headquarters may be centrally located, while in others they may be decentralized. Additionally, some countries may have multiple headquarters for different aspects of the political landscape. The roles of party headquarters can vary greatly depending on the party's structure and goals. On the national level, the headquarters of major political parties are often responsible for approving candidate campaigns and agendas, running campaigns, collecting donations, and organizing and running campaigns at the national level. They also handle communications between campaign staff, voters and the broader public - such as responding to the media, creating press releases, and more. Local-level party headquarters may be responsible for running local campaigns and coordinating with state-level efforts. Additionally, they may collaborate with local organizations to further the party’s cause and attempt to drive voter turnout. Often, local and state headquarters are also responsible for working with political consultants and strategists to develop intelligently crafted messaging for individual regions. In any political party and organization, the headquarters is often considered the center of operations. All levels of the organization communicate with each other and execute their plans through the party headquarters. As such, party headquarters are essential in helping to reach their political goals, and they are essential in the success of any political movement.

The Wessington Springs Saints were a minor league baseball team that represented Wessington Springs, South Dakota, in the Dakota League from 1926 to 1931. The team began play in 1926, and after one season in the Dakota League, they moved to the newly formed Black Hills League in 1927. They competed in the Black Hills League for two seasons before moving back to the Dakota League for the remainder of their existence. The team was originally owned by E. L. Jones, a local building contractor who owned the baseball park in Wessington Springs. He was also the first president of the Black Hills League. He owned the Germania Hotel in Wessington Springs, which served as the team's clubhouse. The team set up shop in Wessington Springs by renaming and renumbering the buildings on Main Street, which was renamed Saints Avenue. The Saints were managed by Loy Petersen during their time in the Black Hills and Dakota Leagues. Petersen was a native of Iowa and had some experience managing minor league teams in the Southern Iowa League. He also managed teams in Harrison and Redfield in South Dakota. The Saints were an unaffiliated minor league team and their roster consisted mostly of college players from the Midwest. They were known for their playing style, with an emphasis on speed and defense. During their time in the Dakota League, the Saints posted a record of 223 wins and 197 losses. Despite their lackluster results on the field, the Saints were very popular in their hometown of Wessington Springs. Attendance at their games was often in the thousands, and the team was featured in the town's newspapers. When the Great Depression hit in 1929, the Saints were hit with a double whammy. Jones, their owner, declared bankruptcy and sold the team. To make matters worse, the Dakota League disbanded the following year, and the Saints were forced to retire. The Wessington Springs Saints may have met an early end, but they still remain an important part of the town's baseball history. The team's legacy lives on in the memories of their fans and in the photos that still hang in the Germania Hotel.

Allied Standards Avionics Architecture Council (ASAAC) is an industry-led organization consisting of member companies dedicated to the development and promotion of standards related to avionics architectures. The organization was established in 2004 by representatives from aircraft manufacturers and suppliers. The goal of ASAAC is to create a consensus and promote interoperability, systems reliability, and shared technical benefits within the avionics industry. ASAAC is an international organization that focuses on the support and implementation of standards in the aviation industry. This includes, but is not limited to, standards related to overall avionic architecture, communications systems, safety systems, and cockpit displays. ASAAC members collaborate to develop, implement, and share best practices information as well as guidance documents and data structures to ensure a consistent approach to avionics architectures. The ASAAC provides guidelines and standards for the avionics industry, but does not act as a regulatory body. However, ASAAC does have a system of self-governance that all members of the organization are expected to follow, including adherence to ethical and professional conduct guidelines. However, each member company is ultimately responsible for ensuring that products and services that adhere to ASAAC standards meet applicable regulatory requirements. ASAAC’s membership is made up of over 100 companies from the aerospace, aviation, and defence communities. These members include major aircraft producers such as Boeing, Airbus, and Gulfstream. In addition, various suppliers such as Rockwell Collins, Thales and Garmin, as well as universities and research institutions, are also represent. Several standards and best practices documents developed by ASAAC are available to the public at large. Each year, ASAAC holds a World Standards-Making Forum in various locations around the world. The purpose of the forum is to provide industry members with the opportunity to share their knowledge, network with suppliers and customers, and stay updated on the latest standards and requirements in the aviation industry. ASAAC plays a significant role in the continuing efforts to maintain a safe and efficient global aviation system. By setting standards for avionics architectures, ASAAC not only ensures safety and reliability, but also helps to promote cost savings and improved efficiency across the entire aviation industry.

Kalki Jayanti is an annual Hindu religious festival, celebrated to commemorate the birth of Kalki, the tenth and final incarnation of Vishnu, who is believed to have arrived in the form of a horse to bring an end to the current Kali Yuga and initiate a new period of peace, austerity, prosperity and Dharma (righteousness). The festival is celebrated mainly in India and Nepal, particularly by Vaishnavites. The exact date of Kalki Jayanti is celebrated annually according to the Hindu lunar calendar. Generally, the festival is celebrated on the twelfth day of the bright fortnight (Shukla Paksha) in the Hindu month of Jyeshtha (May – June). Kalki Jayanti is generally celebrated with great devotion and dedication throughout India and Nepal. On this day, religious functions and puja rituals are carried out in temples and homes, mostly dedicated to Lord Vishnu. Temples are ornamented with fresh flower garlands and lamps are lit in the evening. Special verses dedicated to Kalki are sung. Devotees also observe fast (Upvaas) on this day and take a holy bath in the Ganges River, rivers or lakes. Offerings of flowers and fruits are made to Lord Vishnu before and after chanting mantras and prayers. Prasad (blessed sweets) are served to all who assemble at temples. The celebration of Kalki Jayanti is unique and special with each region having its own way of observing it. In Southern India, especially in the states of Kerala and Tamil Nadu, large processions are organized to celebrate Kalki Jayanti. Special musical performances are arranged in temples of Lord Vishnu and streets, with devotees dressed in traditional colourful attire. In Northern India, mainly in the states of Rajasthan and Haryana, Kalki Jayanti is celebrated with much pomp and grandeur. Devotees take a holy dip in the holy Yamuna River in Mathura and worship Lord Vishnu for success and prosperity. Kalki Jayanti is a festival that inspires people to live a spiritual and peaceful life according to the ideals of Dharma or righteousness. It marks the victory of Good over Evil and signifies hope and faith in Dharma.

Allah jang Palsoe or Palsoe rhymes with Allah is an Islamic hip hop and rap musician based in Accra, Ghana. He is known for his creative lyrics, compelling rhymes and socially conscious message. He has released four studio albums and has toured extensively throughout Ghana, Nigeria and other West African countries. Allah jang Palsoe's passion for music began at a young age, and heavily embedded in hip hop and rap culture. In his early teens, Allah jang Palsoe followed the music industry in Accra, journeying to various places to listen to some of the hottest sounds in town. He befriended other musicians and established a name for himself across the city before deciding to take his music to a professional level. In 2013, Allah jang Palsoe released his debut album 'Grow'. The album was a great success, launching Allah jang Palsoe's profile both in Accra and abroad. The album received radio plays and won him a nomination at the Ghana Music Awards. In 2015, Allah jang Palsoe released his second album, ‘Manifesto’, which went straight to the top of the Ghanian music charts and was praised by critics. The album articulated Palsoe’s viewpoint as an individual, and many of his songs feature incisive social and political commentary. He has continued to perform and record since. His third album 'No Sugar Coating' was released in 2017, and most recently his fourth album, 'Mo Money Mo Better Life' was released in 2019. Both albums further cemented Allah jang Palsoe's status as one of the best and most successful Ghanaian rappers. Allah jang Palsoe has toured extensively throughout West Africa, performing in Nigeria, Ghana, Togo, and more recently Gambia, Sierra Leone, and Senegal. His mission is to bring unity and purpose to his music, through his lyrical voice and with the message of unity and peace. He has received many recognition awards, including The African Storyteller Award at the 2019 All Africa Music Awards. Despite his success, Allah jang Palsoe remains humble, never shying away from the fact that his music is indebted to up-and-coming rappers, especially those who have strong loyal fan bases. As Allah jang Palsoe continues to find ways to touch the lives of his followers and those in the African hip hop scene, the sky is the limit for his career.

Charles Cleveland Nutting (July 8, 1928 - December 21, 2014) was an American artist, designer and sculptor from Los Angeles, California. Nutting was a prominent California modernist who worked in both two and three dimensional media. He produced a variety of works ranging from commerical art to sculpture, with a touch of abstract, Surrealist and Platonic themes. Nutting graduated from the University of Southern California with a degree in sculpture in 1951. He was most fond of abstract expressionism and modernism, which shaped his art. He was a student of renowned sculptor and teacher, Ruth White, who encouraged her students to focus on the creative process, rather than being concerned with the final product. Nutting's career spanned more than six decades, with his works appearing in numerous exhibits across the United States. He is well known in the art world for his series of abstract sculptures, often featuring images of natural forms such as birds and fish. He was commissioned to create sculptures for various cities, parks and public spaces. Additionally, Nutting painted murals for the Santa Barbara Art Museum and private commission projects. Nutting's work was featured in the museum exhibitions at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the Pasadena Museum of Modern Art. He was also featured in the traveling exhibit Sculpture in the Streets, organized by the California Arts Council. He was an active member of the California Art Club and the Los Angeles Municipal Art Commission. He served as president of the Art Division at the Los Angeles Center for Photographic Studies and the Pasadena Art Institute. He was a popular speaker at the Le Salon des Artistes Illuministes in Paris. Nutting served as a juror for numerous exhibitions and awards, including the Otis Art Institute in Los Angeles, and was a key figure in fundraising efforts for the Scripps Industries. Nutting passed away in Los Angeles in 2014. His legacy as a modernist is remembered in his art, which has been highly recognized and collected across the United States. Nutting's works can be found in many permanent collections of art institutions, including the Smithsonian Museum of American Art.

Yang Yongliang (born 1980, Shanghai, China) is an artist whose work is rooted in traditional Chinese landscapes and ink painting, but also interacts with concepts from contemporary practices such as media, technology, and architecture. He has become a leading artist in China and is widely recognized as a respected voice in the global art world. Yang grew up in a traditional Chinese family, and his artistic practice has been shaped by his childhood fascination with traditional landscape painting. He began creating traditional landscape paintings at a very young age and has maintained this technique throughout his career. His works also reference traditional Chinese calligraphy, weaving these traditional themes into more contemporary concepts. Yang uses photography, videography, and large-scale digital prints to create works of art that blend traditional Chinese elements with modern media. His digital prints and installations incorporate elements of traditional Chinese ink painting and calligraphy, merging these forms with modern 3D design and the changes and trends of the city. By combining traditional art forms with the contemporary media, Yang critiques the erasure of Chinese culture and the changes in the urban landscape. He has exhibited widely, including solo exhibitions at the Palazzo Delle Arti in Naples, Italy, Shanghai Modern Art Museum in Shanghai, China, Pace Gallery in Beijing, China, and Chapel Performance Space in Seattle, USA. He has also been exhibited by galleries such as Ben Brown Fine Arts in London, England, and Red Brick Art Museum in Beijing, China. Yang’s work has been recognized by the modern art historical canon, and he has won multiple awards including the 2009 International Art Meeting Prize, the 2009 Shanghai Youth Creation Prize and the 2011 Expo Prize. He is also a professor at the China Academy of Art. Yang’s works have been collected by major institutions, such as the Museum of Modern Art and the Guggenheim Museum in New York, USA; the Louvre in Paris, France; and the Victoria & Albert Museum in London, England. He has also participated in major international events and biennials, including the 2005 Shanghai Biennale and the 2008 Liverpool Biennale. Yang has been described as one of the most influential Chinese artists of his time. Through reinterpreting traditional Chinese art forms and transforming them in modern works of art, his works not only capture the beauty of culture and history, but also reflect on identity and the permanence of global trends.

Saeb N. Jaroudi (born c. 1988) is a Lebanese-Canadian entrepreneur, philanthropist and advocate for girls and women's empowerment in the Middle East. Born and raised in Beirut, Lebanon, Saeb currently resides and works in the Greater Toronto Area. He is the founder and CEO of the Toronto-based company Giv Blocks Inc, and chairman of the N. Jaroudi & S. Nader Charitable Foundation, a foundation dedicated to helping those in need in Lebanon and elsewhere. At a young age, Saeb developed a passion for giving back and empowering individuals through the use of technology. He was involved with a number of local charities, ran a tutoring program for disadvantaged children in Beirut and worked as a volunteer at a number of hospitals. In December 2020, Saeb founded and officially launched Giv Blocks Inc, a social enterprise and technology platform that unlocks the power of digital currency to give back to charities and causes worldwide. Through Giv Blocks Inc, Saeb creates opportunities to donate to various charities and causes from anywhere in the world, removing borders and ensuring that your donation matters no matter where you are. The N. Jaroudi & S. Nader Charitable Foundation, which is chaired by Saeb, was established to provide financial aid and necessary resources to underprivileged individuals and families in Lebanon, Jordan and the surrounding countries. The charity is focused on providing emergency relief and basic necessities such as food and medicine, as well as helping to create employment opportunities in the local communities. In addition to his work with Giv Blocks and the Foundation, Saeb also serves as a counselor to disadvantaged youth. He also is a strong advocate for many charities, particularly those dedicated to the empowerment of girls and women in the Middle East. Saeb's work and passion have been recognized by multiple organizations, most notably the United Nations Foundation which featured him at the 2016 Global Entrepreneurship Summit in Hangzhou, China. In 2018, Saeb was listed on the Forbes 30 Under 30 list for his work in the Technology sector. Saeb is currently working on a number of projects geared towards improving the lives of people in the Middle East. He will continue to pursue his passion for giving back to underprivileged individuals and strive for a safer and more secure future for all.

Meharia is a small village located in the Banasath district of Uttar Pradesh, India. It is situated on the banks of the Ganges River and is home to about five hundred people. The history of Meharia dates back to the medieval period when the land was owned by the local Thakur family. The village has been known for its unique culture and architecture for centuries. The traditional mud-huts with thatched roofs house the villagers who are generally involved in subsistence farming. The village is also known for its natural beauty with several waterfalls and a wide variety of flora and fauna. The village is famous for its vibrant festivals, mainly Basanti Poojan, which is held on the first day of the year according to the Hindu calendar. The village is also home to several educational institutions. The main school is the Government Primary School, which is attended by most of the children from the village. The school has been in existence for more than sixty years and provides basic education for up to class 8. Meharia is also known for its ancient temples, the most prominent being the Meharia Shiv Mandir. It is said to be more than three centuries old and was built in honor of the Hindu God Shiva. The temple has several idols of Hindu gods and goddesses and houses several ancient manuscripts which have been passed down through generations. In recent years, Meharia has also been developing its infrastructure. The roads have been improved, and local businesses such as shops, banks and medical centers have been established. There are also plans to develop a housing complex in the village which will bring in more amenities and resources to the inhabitants. Overall, Meharia is an important landmark in the district of Banasath and is cherished for its unique culture, traditions, natural beauty and history. Despite the development, the villagers of Meharia continue to keep alive their ancient heritage and strive to keep their indigenous culture alive.

Catstye Cam (from the Old English language cæst þe camm, meaning 'jagged peak') is a mountain in the Cumbrian Mountains of England. Located near the Anglo-Scottish border, its summit is approximately 845 m (2,772 ft) above sea level, making it the sixth-highest summit in the county of Cumbria. The mountain stands on its own without any significant height neighbours, allowing for spectacular views in all directions. From its top there are views of Bowfell, the Langdale Pikes, Great Gable and Sca Fell, as well as the Solway Firth and Northumberland National Park. A road leading to the summit is the basis of a challenging and popular drive for recreational 4x4 drivers. As a result, the mountain was declared a Site of Special Scientific Interest in August 2002. The mountain is often climbed from the Startle Tarn valley to the east, where there is a small lake, garden, and parking. It’s possible to follow the stream upwards and take either the east ridge or the south ridge, as both offer reasonably easy access. The south ridge is more popular, as it provides better views over the valley below. The east and south ridge of Catstye Cam are very popular among climbers and hikers alike, providing a challenging climb, with some moderate scrambling and good exposure. The rock on the mountain is mostly sandstone, with some areas of slate and volcanic rock. The mountain can also be accessed from St Sunday Crag, via the ridge path, which runs along Cofa Pike, Nethermost Pike and onwards to Catstye Cam. This route is a bit longer than the direct ascent from the east, but it also offers some of England’s best views. Catstye Cam is an iconic peak in the Cumbrian Mountains, providing fantastic landscapes and stunning views in all directions. Whether you’re looking for a challenge or just want to enjoy breathtaking views, Catstye Cam is the mountain for you!

Samuel Rhoads Fisher (died October 21, 1877) was an American judge, lawyer and politician from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He served as a United States district judge for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania from 1866 to 1877. Early life and education Fisher was born in Philadelphia. He attended the University of Pennsylvania, where he studied law and graduated with an A.B. in 1828. He then attended the Harvard Law School, receiving his L.L.B. in 1831. Career Fisher began his legal career as a lawyer in Philadelphia, focusing primarily on equity law. He also served as a Judge of the Court of Common Pleas of Philadelphia County from 1860 to 1862. In 1866, Fisher was nominated by President Andrew Johnson to the seat on the United States district court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, making him the first district judge from Philadelphia to hold the post. He was confirmed by the United States Senate on May 21, 1866 and held the office until his death in 1877. Fisher was active in Philadelphia's political and legal circles. He was a member of the prominent Quaker family of William Fisher, one of the first settlers of Philadelphia's Germantown area. He was a member of the board of managers of several charitable organizations, and was a trustee of the United States Hospital in the city, better known as Mutter Hospital. Death Fisher died in Philadelphia on October 21, 1877. His funeral was held at the Friends Meeting House in Germantown, and he was buried in the nearby Burial Ground. His papers are held by the Historical Society of Pennsylvania. Fisher was respected by the citizens of Philadelphia and served as an example of exemplary leadership in legal circles. He was remembered for his keen judicial sense, keenness of expression, and soundness of judgement. Legacy Fisher is remembered for his contributions to Philadelphia's legal profession. His name appears on the Fisher Building of the Pennsylvania State Capital Complex in Harrisburg, and is honored with a plaque on the building's wall.

Pugwash, Nova Scotia, is a small village in the Canadian province of Nova Scotia. Located on the Northumberland Shore of the Northumberland Strait, the village is known for its extensive sandy beach, which is frequented by tourists during the summer months. According to the 2016 census, Pugwash has a population of 555. The village was incorporated in 1894, and was founded by the American industrialist, Joseph E. Seeley. The name "Pugwash" comes from the mi'kmaq word, "Pugwesdagun", which translates to "place of eelgrass". This is likely due to the abundant eelgrass beds located along the shores of Pugwash. The village also contains a number of historic buildings, many of which date back to the late 1800s. One of the most notable is the Friends' Meeting House, which is the oldest meeting house of the Religious Society of Friends in Canada and was built in 1817. Pugwash is home to one of the oldest yacht clubs in Canada, the Pugwash Yacht Club, which was established in 1884. The club is located on the Pleasant Point of the Pugwash Harbour, and offers a wide range of activities, such as sailing, rowing and fishing. The Pugwash Harbour is also a popular spot for recreation and sightseeing, offering views of the entire Pugwash area. The village is home to a number of museums, showcasing the local history and culture. Two of the most significant include the Joseph Howe Museum, which celebrates the life of the local patriot and journalist, and the NSLC Heritage Centre, which tells the story of the regions liquor retailers. The village also includes several boutique shops and cafes. Pugwash hosts a yearly pirate-themed festival, the Pugwash Village Pirate Festival, celebrating the village’s connection with the pirates of centuries ago. The festival puts on various performances, workshops, and a large parade throughout the village. This event has become extremely popular among locals and tourists alike and draws large crowds each year. Pugwash is connected to the nearby towns of Amherst and Truro via Highway 6, and is located an hour from the provincial capital of Halifax. It is a popular tourist destination, known for its beautiful beaches, historic sites and relaxed atmosphere.

The London Philharmonic Choir (LPC) is a British choral ensemble, founded in 1932 and based at Cadogan Hall in London. It is one of the country's leading amateur choral ensembles and has an extensive repertoire of music from all genres, including classical, contemporary and popular. Since its inception, the LPC has established a formidable reputation. It regularly performs with renowned orchestras and with some of the world's leading conductors. These include Sir Simon Rattle, Sir Antonio Pappano and Sir Mark Elder, as well as some of the most eminent soloists in the music world. Notable projects include: a performance of Beethoven’s nine symphonies in one day; a massive collaboration of 50 choirs from all over the world, performing Handel’s Messiah at the Royal Albert Hall; and a deeply moving production of Berlioz’s La Damnation de Faust at the South Bank Centre. The majority of the choir's members are London-based amateurs who rehearse with the LPC two evenings a week. Auditions within each section are held periodically, with new members always welcome. In addition, the LPC also offers special sessions in its Singing For Fun classes, where people can come together to learn the basics of singing in a relaxed atmosphere. The LPC is at the forefront of musical education. A wide range of courses, workshops and masterclasses, suitable for all ages and abilities, are available throughout the year. In its mission to promote choral music, the LPC encourages young people to be part of the major performances. It also runs a community choir initiative, dedicated to teaching singing in London’s deprived areas, with a focus on primary schools. Away from the concert hall, the LPC frequently tours nationally and internationally, appearing at major venues around the British Isles, Europe and beyond. Furthermore, it produces an extensive range of recordings. Today, the London Philharmonic Choir stands for excellence in music education and performance, and the building of bridges between the professional and choral worlds. With the depth of its repertoire and its creative spirit, the LPC is a power for good in the choral world.

The D.C. Opportunity Scholarship Program (DCOSP) is an educational voucher program in Washington, D.C., United States, created to give eligible low-income parents the chance to send their children to some of the higher-performing public and private schools in the District. The program was created in 2004 by the U.S. Congress as part of the reauthorization of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act and funds are provided to students annually. The program allocates a certain amount of funds to each eligible student and his or her family. Eligibility is based on financial need using the Free and Reduced-Price Meal program application for eligibility for poverty and the student must reside in the District of Columbia. Furthermore, the student must have been enrolled in either a traditional public school or public charter school in the District of Columbia during the prior school year and attend an eligible school within the District. The program allows eligible students to access private schools by providing funds to cover tuition, books, uniforms, and transportation costs. Through the establishment of a voucher system, the program provides an avenue for families to pursue schools that fulfill the educational needs of their children outside of the public and charter school system. The program is administered by the D.C. Children and Youth Investment Trust Corporation, which is funded by the federal government. The Trust Corporation also acts as an intermediary between the D.C. government and the schools, distributing payments for voucher students to the participating schools. In addition to providing students and their families with the chance to attend new schools, the DCOSP also allows the participating schools to offer new educational options. Through the program, certain private schools can become part of the D.C. public school program, expanding the range of educational choices for D.C. students. Since 2004, the DCOSP has served over 6,000 students from the District of Columbia. The program has seen a largely positive response from both students and families, as they have reported positive experiences in regards to their children’s academic and social growth. Studies have also shown that students who use the voucher program have a higher attendance rate and better test scores than their peers at public schools in the District. Despite the generally positive response to the DCOSP, there has been some opposition to the program. Critics have argued that the program drains resources from public schools, effectively “privatizing” the public school system. Furthermore, they contend that the program unfairly advantages families in the District who have the means to pay for private school tuition. In the face of these criticisms, the D.C. Opportunity Scholarship Program continues to serve its purpose: to give eligible students from low-income families in the District a chance to access quality education in an environment that caters to their individual needs. The program has remained an important part of the District of Columbia’s educational landscape since its implementation in 2004.

Luis Bruschtein (born 1959 in Buenos Aires, Argentina) is an Argentine artist, architect, and urban planner. He is best known for his public art installations, which often incorporate elements of both town planning concepts and visual art. He has been described as a "visionary architect" and one of the most important practitioners of public art in Argentina. Bruschtein attended the Instituto Universitario Nacional del Arte in Buenos Aires, where he obtained a degree in sculpture in 1984. He has since established a career as an artist and architect, working on both big and small-scale projects, in addition to teaching at universities and art schools. He has been the recipient of numerous awards, including being named "Best International Urban Artist" in 2011 at the International Art Basel in Switzerland. Bruschtein's oeuvre is heavily involved with urban public spaces, as he works to engage public art within city structures to create more effective means of communication and interaction. His works often focus on the interactive relationship between people and their environment- taking into consideration multiple senses and aesthetics. He has created many large-scale interactive art installations around the world, extending from Buenos Aires to Europe, Asia and America. One of his best known projects is "Vecinos," a public art project where he created a hybrid between art and planning, transforming a traditional square in Buenos Aires into a vibrant and inclusive community space. He did this by incorporating colorful artworks and sculptural elements- including chairs and benches- which were designed to spark conversation, encourage social gathering, and create a space for community members to share their stories and gatherings. Bruschtein is widely respected for his creative approach to expanding the possibilities of urban planning and public art. His works, many of which are permanent fixtures of both Buenos Aires and other cities around the world, continue to be praised for their innovative use of materials and their ability to bridge the gap between art and planning. Additionally, Bruschtein is an advocate for environmental sustainability and is known to prioritize it his projects, making him a leader in the global public art movement. Finally, Bruschtein's work has been featured in numerous publications and exhibitions, including being included in the first-ever public art biennial in Latin America. Bruschtein's involvement in large-scale urban planning projects and his persistent advocacy for sustainable urban development have placed him as one of the most prominent figures in the realm of contemporary public art.

Stranger in the City, also known as S.I.T.C, is a small non-primary metropolitan area in the southern United States. It is known as a city of contrasts, with a mix of ultra-modern high-rises, quiet suburban towns, and modest family homes. While the city is small and compact, the residents feel a strong sense of belonging and community. Stranger in the City began as a small village more than 150 years ago and has grown into a thriving metropolis. It is filled with bustling energy and a diverse group of people, making it the perfect place to start a business, explore nature trails, or take a break from city living. The infrastructure is well-developed due to the city’s dedication to modernization and progress. With a range of construction projects, businesses and shops, the city has earned its place in the modern world. However, the city still upholds its small-town charm and character. The city has a vibrant nightlife with a wide range of venues offering a mixture of food, drinks, and entertainment. In addition, the city also boasts a range of festivals and live music events. Stranger in the City is home to a range of incredible parks and gardens and diverse culture. Nearby attractions include historical sites, national parks, beaches, and theme parks. It is also home to an array of restaurants, cafes, and boutiques, making it the ideal destination for travelers to explore. The city's economy is largely driven by retail, tourism, and technology, with a concentration on sustainability and innovation. The city is also known for its commitment to culture and art, attracting many creative and performing artists from around the world. The citizens of Stranger in the City enjoy a high quality of living, with highly ranked education and healthcare systems, a well-developed transportation system and a wealth of affordable housing. These features make Strangers in the City a desirable place to live and work. Stranger in the City is a unique and vibrant place, offering many opportunities to live, work, and play. Its diverse culture and energy creates an inviting atmosphere, and continues to attract both business owners and visitors alike.

3850 Peltier is a residential neighborhood located in the city of Santa Clara, California. It was named after Eli Peltier, who was instrumental in developing Santa Clara in the mid-1800s. 3850 Peltier is located between Highway 101 and the city of San Jose, and offers easy access to public transportation and the Santa Clara Convention Center. The neighborhood straddles the borders of Central and South Santa Clara, and features great access to both major arterials like El Camino Real and Public Transit such as the VTA light rail and CalTrain Station. While it offers many popular conveniences, it is also home to several parks and nature preserves, such as Ryder Park and the Great America Wetlands. 3850 Peltier is known for its convenient location and diverse housing. The neighborhood is a mix of single family and condominium homes, as well as upscale townhomes and apartments. Residents of the area are served by excellent public schools, such as Lynbrook High School and Adolfo Camarillo Elementary School, and enjoy a variety of shopping, dining and nightlife options nearby. In 2013, the City of Santa Clara approved the development of a new shopping center for 3850 Peltier. This center, located just off of El Camino Real and Pruneridge Ave, will include a variety of general retail and specialty stores, clothing stores, restaurants and other entertainment options. The development is expected to bring more residents to the neighborhood, as well as creating new jobs in the area. 3850 Peltier is a thriving community with many amenities and activities to offer. It is just a few blocks away from Intel and is home to many local businesses. It provides a convenient, suburban lifestyle in the heart of Silicon Valley. Residents of the neighborhood have access to many recreational activities, such as hiking and biking, and enjoy being part of a vibrant community.

U Škripcu (Serbian Cyrillic: У Шкрипцу, English translation: "In the Cradle") is a Serbian and former Yugoslavian rock band from Belgrade, active from 1976 to 1990. The band experienced its greatest success in the 1980s and is considered to be one of the most popular bands in the former Yugoslavia. The band was formed in Belgrade in 1976. The original lineup featured guitarist, composer, and vocalist Dejan "Škripa" Ivanišević, guitarist Miroslav Cvetković, bass guitarist Milan Mihajlović, and drummer Zoran Radomirović. U Škripcu's initial repertoire consisted mostly of covers of hard rock and heavy metal songs, but with the arrival of composer and lyricist Jovan Jovanović, they began exploring their own sound. U Škripcu released their debut album in 1981, Policajac sa Petlovog Brda (English translation: "Cop From Petlovogbrda"). The album was a huge success, with its title track becoming one of the most popular songs in the former Yugoslavia. Their subsequent releases, Disco-Foni (1982) and Nova generacija (1984), further promoted their recognition. U Škripcu's style was characterized as new wave and progressive rock. Known for its socially conscious lyrics, their songs mostly dealt with themes such as poverty, war, and politics. For this reason, the band often encountered censorship from the authorities, and some of their songs were even banned from airplay. Though U Škripcu achieved mainstream success, the band eventually disbanded in 1990 due to financial issues and personal tensions. Since then, the members of the band have pursued solo careers. In 2011, U Škripcu held a reunion concert at the same venue where the original band played in 1976. The concert was hailed as a success and was followed by several more reunion concerts in the following years. Since their breakup, U Škripcu's music has become a nostalgic phenomenon among fans of the former Yugoslavian music scene. Today, they are seen as innovators in their genre, and their influence can still be heard in many of today's artists.

Marvin Powell (born October 8, 1955) is a former professional American football player. He played offensive tackle in the National Football League (NFL) for the New York Jets from 1977 to 1984, and for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers from 1985 to 1987. Born in Salisbury, North Carolina, Powell attended James Brown High School in Baytown, Texas, where he was an all-state selection in football. He then attended the University of Southern California, where he was a three-year All-American and a two-time All Pac-10 Conference selection. Powell was selected by the Jets in the first round of the 1977 NFL Draft, and subsequently went on to become a four-time Pro Bowl selection as well as being named to three All-Pro teams. He became the first draft pick of the Jets' post-Joe Namath era. As a Jet, he was part of the noted "New York Sack Exchange," with teammate Joe Klecko, and eventually started at left tackle in the team's 1982 season-ending victory over the Miami Dolphins, which clinched a playoff berth for the Jets. In 1985, Powell joined the Tampa Bay Buccaneers for two seasons. Following retirement in 1987, Powell moved to Houston, where he opened a heating and air conditioning business, eventually becoming one of the largest companies of its kind in Texas. Powell was also active in youth football and in 2005, the 110-pound football league in which his son participated in hot weather practices, was named the "Marvin Powell Heat Relief League.” Currently, Powell continues to serve as President of one of Houston's largest heating and air conditioning companies. He, his wife Renee and his three children, Kalynn, Jessie, and Marvin, Jr. each reside in Houston. In March 2007, Powell was inducted into the Texas Sports Hall of Fame. He was inducted into the U.S. Hispanic Sports Hall of Fame in October 2010, and inducted into the USC Athletics Hall of Fame in November 2011.

Reuben Webster Millsaps (1837 - 1921) was an American businessman and philanthropist. Born in Chatham County, North Carolina, he moved with his family to Maryland as a young man. After serving as a wagoner in the Civil War, he moved to Jackson, Mississippi, in 1873. He was an important figure in the development of the city for nearly 50 years, and was one of its largest employers. Millsaps was a self-made man whose ventures included banking, lumber mills, and cotton ginning. He was one of the founders of the Savings and Trust Company of Jackson, served on its board of directors and was president at the time of his death. He also established several lumber mills, including Leaf River Lumber Company, Leaf River Cotton Gins, Rose Ginnery, and Iron Mill of Mississippi. He helped to finance the building of several churches and hospitals in the region, including Hickory Hill Methodist Church, and the MS Baptist Memorial Hospital. He also donated funds to local schools and universities, as well as institutions in Mobile, AL, including Spring Hill College. Furthermore, he and his wife, Marie Magruder (1845–1915), co-founded Millsaps College in 1890. In addition to his financial contribution to Jackson, Millsaps was also a social reformer who sought to improve facilities for African-Americans in the region. He supported the Union soldiers, giving them supplies and protesting for voting rights for newly freed African-Americans. Millsaps was a well respected philanthropist who left a lasting legacy on the Jackson community. In his honor, a park and a nursing facility bear his name, and the local library serves as a fitting tribute to his contributions to the city. He was a leader in business and in civil service, leaving a mark of progress and charity on his adopted city. Millsaps died in 1921 and was buried in Jackson with full military honors.

Catholics vs. Convicts (2016) is an independent American supernatural horror film directed by Serena Kay and starring Shoresh Alaudini, Ah-Rahm Cepero, and Daniel Casten. It follows a group of Catholic high school students who find themselves in a perilous situation after they disobey their teachers and free a possessed convict from a jail cell. The film centers around seven Catholic high school students, desperate to ditch class and have some fun. They decide to break into a jail located in their small town and free an inmate that they believe to be wrongfully imprisoned. After he is freed, they begin to experience supernatural occurrences and discover that the inmate is possessed. The possessed inmate then turns the group against each other and terrorizes them in the form of a demon. As the inmates plot their escape, the demon goes on a killing spree, taking out members of the group one by one. They must come to terms of their sins from former experiences and forgive each other before they can defeat the demon. Catholics vs. Convicts was released on January 1, 2016, to mostly positive reviews from critics. The film holds a rating of 63% on Rotten Tomatoes, with many critics praising its star-studded cast, the level of its thrills, the dark and eerie atmosphere, and its ability to deliver genuine scares. The film was also a mixed success at the box office, grossing $98 million against its budget of $20 million, making it a financial success. Catholics vs. Convicts is an interesting take on the horror trope of teens being menaced by a supernatural menace and its well-rounded characters, memorable performances and surprising final act make it one of the better supernatural horror films of the past decade.

Our Lady of Mercy's Chapel (Clove Valley, New York) is a historic Roman Catholic chapel located in Clove Valley, town of Wawarsing, Ulster County, New York. Built in 1917, the chapel was designed by architect George Conable and constructed by local resident Christopher Greulich. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 2006. Built in the rustic style, the chapel exhibits the characteristics of a vernacular building, with its low frame structure characterizing the rural building tradition. Built of white pine, the chapel is basically a large ell measuring 60 feet by 26 feet with a gable roof. The wooden construction of the chapel is augmented by concrete foundation and bluestone steps. The exterior facade is illuminated by two stained-glass windows of the Sacred Heart of Jesus, while the interior is marked by an altar of concrete blocks, plaster construction and reinforced concrete ceiling. The interior is lined with wooden pews and is further decorated with 24 framed medals of the saints. The chapel serves as an important site for the Roman Catholic families of the region and is used for regular religious services and community events. It is considered a major architectural landmark of the rural Hudson Valley and is frequently visited by locals and tourists alike. The chapel has also been noted for its significance in the history of American Catholic Church residing at a crossroads of Irish/Italian/German and other immigrant Catholic Churches that had recently populated the sparse rural countryside of Clove Valley in the early 19th Century. Today, Our Lady of Mercy's Chapel (Clove Valley, New York) is one of the few churches that remain standing as a reminder of the rich Catholic history of the region. The chapel continues to serve its local community, providing a welcoming place for worship and communal gathering.

Jeff Salmon (born October 18, 1976) is a former professional basketball player from the United States. He most notably played for the Atlanta Hawks and the Minnesota Timberwolves of the National Basketball Association (NBA). Salmon was born in St. Louis, Missouri. He attended high school at John F. Kennedy High School in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, where he was first noticed for his basketball ability and later recruited by Iowa State University which he attended from1994 to 1998. During his college career he received academic honors in his senior year. His basketball career began to take off during his junior and senior year, statistically improving in almost every category each season. Salmon was selected in the second round of the 1998 NBA Draft by the Atlanta Hawks. He played three seasons with the Hawks and showed considerable progress, eventually averaging 8.2 points per game over a one season span. After leaving the Hawks, Salmon moved on to the Minnesota Timberwolves, where his playing time decreased, due to injuries. He retired in 2004 and started his own business in the Atlanta area. Salmon is highly regarded as an upstanding citizen, both on and off the court. He is an active philanthropist in the Atlanta community and currently serves on the board of directors at The Stronghold, a community development center in Decatur, Georgia. Salmon is especially committed to youth and education reform, having established his own "Pros for Education" program, with the objective of helping disadvantaged students. In addition to his philanthropic work, Salmon was invested in the restoration and preservation of the Morehouse College Martin Luther King Jr. Movie Collection. He obtained the collection from a fellow NBA player, reserve Corey Benjamin, and donated the historic memorabilia to Morehouse College for scholars and friends to enjoy. In recent years, Salmon has been a successful business consultant and entrepreneur in Atlanta. He is proudly married and has three children. External Links * Jeff Salmon official business website (http://www.jeffsalmonbiz.com/) * Pros for Education (https://www.p4education.org/) * Morehouse College Martin Luther King Jr. Movie Collection (https://www.morehouse.edu/mlkcollection/)

Nebuchadnezzar II (also known as Nebuchadnezzar the Great; fl. c. 605 BC – c. 562 BC) was one of the most powerful rulers of the Neo-Babylonian Empire (605 BC - 539 BC). He is best known for his construction of the famous Hanging Gardens of Babylon, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. He also succeeded in conquering many of the neighboring kingdoms and imposing Babylonian rule in the conquered lands. Nebuchadnezzar was born around 605 BC, the son of Nabopolassar, a Chaldean rebel who had broken Babylon’s ties with Assyria and declared Babylon a sovereign power. He was a member of the Chaldean dynasty, the last dynasty of the Neo-Babylonian Empire. It is believed that Nebuchadnezzar was born in Babylonia, but his mother’s identity is unknown. Upon his father’s death in 562 BC, Nebuchadnezzar II succeeded as king and immediately set off to conquer lands outside of Babylon. He quickly conquered Syria and Palestine, crushing the Egyptian forces and their leader, Pharaoh Necho II. He also defeated the Neo-Hittite city of Carchemish, the Phoenician city-states of Tyre and Sidon, and the kingdom of Judah. Aside from his military conquests, Nebuchadnezzar is famous for his tremendous building projects and public works. He constructed walls around Babylon and several canals connecting the rivers Tigris and Euphrates. He also erected the famous Hanging Gardens of Babylon, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. The gardens were reportedly built for his wife, Amastis, who was homesick for her native Median countryside. Nebuchadnezzar II is also remembered for strengthening the Babylonian Empire. He reformed the legal, religious and economic institutions of the empire, improving their efficiency and expanding Babylon into an effective bureaucracy. He also ordered the construction of several important monuments, such as the Ishtar Gate and the Marduk ziggurat. Nebuchadnezzar II is a major figure in the Biblical Book of Daniel, in which he is portrayed as a powerful, but ultimately vulnerable ruler. He is also mentioned in Greek and Roman works and is often referenced in modern works as a symbol of imperial power and hubris.

Parallel single-source shortest path algorithm is an algorithm for computing the shortest path from a given source vertex s to all other vertices in a graph. It is an extension of single-source shortest path algorithms for use on parallel computing architectures. The algorithm begins by assigning each vertex an initial distance from the source. The initial distance for the source is 0, and for all other vertices, the distance is infinity. Each vertex is also assigned a predecessor. The predecessor of the source is null, and of all other vertices is the source. The algorithm then iterates until all of the distances have been updated. The basic version of the algorithm, known as the sequential single-source shortest path algorithm (SSSP), operates in a series of iterations known as rounds. During each round, each vertex v computes its new distance dv. The new distance dv is given by the following equation: dv = min{wd, ds + wv} where wd is the distance of the predecessor vertex d to the source, ds is the distance of the vertex s to the source, and wv is the weight associated with the edge connecting vertex d and vertex v. One drawback of the basic SSSP algorithm is that the speed of the computation depends on the size of the graph, since the entire iteration must take place within a single processor. To speed up the process of computing shortest paths in large graphs, various parallel versions of the SSSP algorithm have been developed. One such version is the 'dynamic backtracking' algorithm, which is a combined MPI (Message Passing Interface) and OpenMP approach. This algorithm operates in two phases, a 'reduce' phase and an 'augment' phase. During the reduce phase, the message passing interface is used to communicate the distances of the current vertices in the graph. The augment phase then takes place using OpenMP, to process the newly-received distances. Another parallel version of SSSP is the 'adaptive shortest path' algorithm, which is based on the dynamic programming approach. This algorithm relies on concurrent computations as well as message passing to reduce the time required to compute shortest paths. This algorithm also iterates over a graph, computing the new distances in each iteration. It then uses a set of heuristics to decide which processing cores to utilize, in order to effectively utilize the available resources. Parallel single-source shortest path algorithms provide a way to efficiently and accurately compute the shortest paths in large graphs. They can be used for many applications, such as network routing, transportation optimization, and graph partitioning. As the size and complexity of graphs continues to increase, algorithms such as these will become increasingly important in computing the shortest paths.

Gary Balletto (born July 8, 1975) is an American professional mixed martial arts fighter and trainer from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Balletto started in mixed martial arts in 2001 and has since competed in numerous organizations across the United States. He currently holds the WAKO US Heavyweight Kickboxing title, which he won in 2017. Balletto was inspired by martial arts as a child, when a local karate school opened near his home. With his limited financial resources, he initially could not afford the classes, instead he trained with friends in the street.
