When he was 19, he got a job and started taking lessons under Sifu Thomas Williams, with whom he trained for seven years. With Sifu Williams he earned four black belts in Akarui-Jitsu, Combat Jiu-Jitsu, Combat Muay Thai, and Combat submission wrestling. During this time, he studied many martial arts styles and various fighting sports. At the age of 26 he decided to try his hand at full contact fighting, when he was recruited by a local amateur organization. He won the fight by split decision. From there he went on to fight professionally across the US until the age of 39, when he decided to retire from fighting and focus on training. During his career he fought in organizations such as King of the Cage, Dynamite USA, Superbrawl, Gladiators Cagefighting, Cage Fury Fighting Championships, Cage Athlete MMA, ICON Sport, and Ultimate Fighting Challenge (UFC). Balletto currently owns and operates the Proficient Fighting Academy in Philadelphia, where he has trained many fighters who have gone on to successful fighting careers. He is an active member of the Pennsylvania Martial Arts Hall of Fame and is currently a 2nd degree Black Belt in Okinawa-Jitsu. Balletto is married and has two children. He continues to be a positive influence in the fighting community, often volunteering to help local fighters train for their upcoming fights. He has dedicated his life to the martial arts and carries a wealth of knowledge and experience within the fighting industry.

Syed Shah Israil (born 30 March 1965) is a Pakistani politician who served as the Member of the Provincial Assembly of Sindh, from the platform of Pakistan People's Party, from 2008 to 2013. Syed Shah Israil was born in village Jaffar Chakar of district Kandhkot, Sindh on 30 March 1965 to Syed Ahmed Shah, who was a well-known spiritual teacher of the region. He completed his education from University of Sindh and Karachi University. He started his career in politics as a Pakistan People's Party worker in 1988. He was active in various mass understanding campaigns held in various parts of Sindh. Syed Shah Israil joined PPP in 2008 and contested the elections on its platform against the Pakistan Muslim League (N) candidate but lost. In 2013, he won the general elections as a PPP candidate in the constituency PS 84 Kandhkot-Kashmore. During his five-year tenure, he introduced several legislations in the Sindh Assembly for the betterment of rural Sindh. He also served on the Committee of the National Assembly on Rules of Procedure and Privileges, wherein he presented various human-based issues in the assembly, including health, education, civic issues, and others. Syed Shah Israil was also a member of the PCB Security Committee and the Working Committee for the Implementation of the National Action Plan. In recognition of his services for the humanity, he was awarded the Sahibzada Shujaat Ali Award in 2013 by Governor Sindh. Syed Shah Israil is now retired from active politics and lives in his home town of Kandhkot. He continues to promote the values of humanity and human rights within the constituency and the wider society.

The Copenhagen Fire of 1795 (Danish: Københavns Brand) was a large city-wide fire in Copenhagen, Denmark, in 1795. The fire began on 25 June 1795, between 2 and 3am. It broke out in two separate places within Copenhagen’s city walls, in both Christianshavn and Vesterbro. It is thought that the flames were caused by faulty cookstoves, but no official investigation was ever conducted. Fire engines of the day were inadequate to handle the scale of the blaze, and the wind quickly spread the flames across both districts. By the time the fire was extinguished, it had destroyed 1709 buildings, leaving an area of smouldering rubble with a breadth of 4km in the heart of Copenhagen. Thousands of people were displaced, and while no casualties were reported, some residents who had been too slow to evacuate perished in the flames. In total, the economic impact of the fire included damages estimated at 3.2 million rixdollars, of which 800,000 fell to the state, and the rest to unprotected individuals and corporations. The fire brought about a shift in urban lighting regulations. Streets were to be kept lit from the end of October until the morning of May, greatly reducing instances of fires fuelled by negligence. A new fire brigade was also organized, and funds were put in place to help rebuild the affected areas. In the weeks following the fire, Christian VII and his court decided to visit the ruins of the fire and this marked the beginning of a period of rebuilding and recovery for the city. The rebuilding effort was marked by a number of royal decrees, including one for the rebuilding of churches, with a greater emphasis on fireproof measures. Today, the fire is remembered in several places throughout Copenhagen. A memorial to the victims was erected in 1902 in Israels Plads, while several streets in the area still bear the names of craftsmen who lost their livelihoods in the fire. In addition, an annual procession is held on the anniversary of the fire in the Vesterbro district of Copenhagen, in which citizens commemorate the event with a candlelight parade. Overall, the Copenhagen Fire of 1795 was a tragedy for the people of Copenhagen and their communities, but it also brought about important changes to Danish city planning, fire regulations and public safety policies. Today, the event is marked with a respect and understanding for the lessons it taught.

The Symplegades, also known as the Clashing Rocks, were a pair of rocks which resided in the middle of the Bosporus which was a narrow strait of water located between the Black Sea and the Sea of Marmara. They were worshiped by the Greek and the Etruscans as divine objects, specifically by the Titan of the winds, Boreas. According to Ancient Greek mythology, the Argo and Jason and the Argonauts had to pass between these rocks during their quest and they were told not to. The Clashing Rocks are first mentioned in Homer's Odyssey, but they are most famously recounted in Apollonius of Rhodes' Jason and the Argonauts. According to the story, when the Argonauts were passing between the islands, the two clashing rocks would come together unexpectedly, leaving a narrow passage through which only an experienced sailor could pass. The Argo was able to pass between the rocks because Hera had enabled a mystical breeze that blew the ship through. The Symplegades were believed to have functioned as a barrier of sorts, acting as a deterrent for ships from entering the Bosporus. For centuries, the rocks were treated with godly reverence and sailors would give offerings to the gods to ask for safe passage. Eventually, the rocks were destroyed by the Greek hero Heracles, who smashed them to allow Jason to pass through without risk of death. Some versions of the story also report that these rocks morphed into two birds of prey that flew away. The Clashing Rocks play an important part in ancient Greek maritime history. In modern days, descendants of the ancient Greeks continue to revere the Symplegades as the symbol of their people's struggle in the face of luck and chance. The modern city of Istanbul still celebrates the rocks' destruction every year with Argonauts folklore festivals and painting competitions.

KPCN-LP is a low-power FM radio station broadcasting from Park City, Utah. It is owned by the Park City Public Broadcasting Company, a non-profit organization dedicated to providing educational programming and services to the Wasatch County communities. The station first began broadcasting on November 22, 1978, originally airing a variety of music formats, from adult contemporary and classical to Top 40 and country. In the 1990’s, KPCN-LP switched to an NPR news/talk format, becoming the first station in the Park City area to offer locally-produced programming. The station also carries programming from National Public Radio, plus locally produced shows such as the “Park City Today” morning show and “The Local Scene” local events program. In 2004, KPCN-LP became the first FM radio station in the state of Utah to air a high definition digital broadcast, using the HD Radio system. This system allows listeners to enjoy higher-quality audio along with expanded programming options. KPCN-LP has also chosen to simulcast their programming over the internet, allowing more listeners access to the station’s programming. In addition to its music and news programming, KPCN-LP promotes its commitment to public service by participating in local events, publicizing important community concerns, and fundraising. The station also provides a mobile studio that is available for community events. KPCN-LP has become an important voice in the local community, providing news, information and entertainment for over thirty years. The station remains dedicated to its public service mission, providing quality programming and a service to the Park City area.

Provincial Secretary and Registrar of Ontario is a position in the Government of Ontario responsible for administering the affairs of provincial ministries and agencies, as well as providing executive support to the Lieutenant Governor. The position has existed since the government of Ontario was created in 1867, though the roles and responsibilities have changed over time. Initially, the Provincial Secretary served as the Cabinet Secretary, keeping Cabinet records and facilitating Cabinet meetings, as well as performing certain ceremonial functions for the Lieutenant Governor. Over time, the responsibility for record-keeping and other administrative responsibilities was transferred to the Executive Council Office, and the duties of the Provincial Secretary became more focused on providing advice to the Lieutenant Governor. The position of Provincial Secretary and Registrar of Ontario was created in 2014 and is responsible for acting as the legal advisor to the Lieutenant Governor and the Executive Council, as well as developing protocols and processes related to the administration of public service. Additionally, the Provincial Secretary is the Registrar of Statutory Instruments, which are the official documents that the Legislature passes when law is created or amended. The Provincial Secretary is also the Deputy Minister for Intergovernmental Affairs, representing the Ontario government before other provincial and federal governments, as well as in international negotiations. In addition, he or she performs various duties related to the conduct of provincial elections and referendums. The current Provincial Secretary and Registrar of Ontario is Patrick Borbey, who was appointed in 2019. The Provincial Secretary is supported by a Secretariat that is responsible for providing support on ceremonial and other matters, assisting in the coordination of intergovernmental meetings, and providing information on the roles and responsibilities of the office. The Provincial Secretary and Registrar of Ontario is an important part of the Government of Ontario’s structure. The position is responsible for providing executive support to the Lieutenant Governor, acting as legal advisor to the Executive Council, conducting provincial elections, and representing the government in intergovernmental matters and foreign negotiations. References 1. "Provincial Secretary and Registrar of Ontario Overview." Ontario.ca. October 8, 2020. Accessed October 8, 2020. https://www.ontario.ca/page/provincial-secretary-and-registrar-ontario-overview 2. "Pat Borbey." Ontario Senior Executive Council. October 8, 2020. Accessed October 8, 2020. https://www.ontario.ca/page/pat-borbey

Heaven Cent is a term or phrase that is used to express a religious thought or belief that something is divinely inspired or of a very spiritual nature. It is commonly used in contexts of appreciation for the physical beauty of nature and in descriptions of the spiritual or emotional impact of a certain experience or set of circumstances. The term has been used by writers, poets, and musicians as an expression of awe and admiration for the divine powers of the universe. It has also been used in literature and spiritual teachings to refer to God, Heaven, or the higher power that created all life and existence. Heaven Cent has been used as an exclamation or phrase of appreciation by many different cultures. In the Christian faith, the saying is a common expression of joy or appreciation for faith-related circumstances, such as a prayer being answered, a miracle happening, or an act of service being performed in the name of God. The term is often used in sermons, hymns, and scripture readings. The phrase has been adopted by other religions as well, such as Hinduism and Buddhism, to express the same feeling of appreciation and joy at spiritual occurrences. In Buddhism, the term is used to refer to the state of nirvana, which is the state of perfect peace and freedom from suffering that Buddhists strive for. In addition to its religious connotations, Heaven Cent is also often used to describe something that is beautiful in a spiritual or emotional way. The term is commonly used in songs, movies, and television shows as an indicator of the beauty of a particular scene or moment. It is also used to express admiration of someone who has done something of great spiritual or emotional value, such as a heroic act or generous service. Heaven Cent is recognized as a concept of great beauty, positive emotion, and spiritual power. It is an expression of admiration of a power greater than ourselves, and a recognition of the beauty and peace that the divine can bring.

Alexandru Al. Ioan Cuza was a Romanian Prince of the House of Cuza, a major figure in the history of Romanian Nationalism, a central figure in the development of the Modern Romanian State, and a leader of unification of the Romanian Principalities in 1859. He first ascended the throne as Prince of Moldavia in 1858, and then Prince of Wallachia in 1859, following the will of the Ottoman Empire. Cuza is credited with laying the foundation for Romania's development as a modern European nation, as well as its character as a nation ruled by law and principle. Cuza initially sought to strengthen Moldavia and Wallachia by introducing sweeping reforms, including modernizing the army and rationalizing taxation, as well as implementing various educational initiatives. He also promoted the construction of a railway line linking the two Principalities, the first in Eastern Europe. Cuza's central political achievement was the unification of Moldavia and Wallachia in 1859, which set the stage for the creation of a unitary Romanian State in 1862. Cuza maintained a strong anti-Ottoman stance throughout his rule and was regarded as a strong defender of Romania’s independence. As a result of his support for Romania's independence, he was exiled to France in 1866. Nevertheless, Cuza's legacy has long been celebrated in Romania, both as an important father of Romanian unity, and as a major figure in the struggle for Romania's modernization. In commemoration of Cuza's achievements, he was posthumously named Prince of Romania in 1881 and was venerated as a National Hero. Cuza's reformist zeal left a lasting impression on modern Romania, and he has been honored in history books as one of the most important leaders of the nation in its formative years. A number of monuments and buildings in Romania bear his name, and his portrait is featured on the 50 lei banknote. In addition, a number of features in Romania, such as bridges, roads, parks, and universities, are named after him in recognition of his important role in the development of the modern Romanian state.

The 2014 Louisiana–Lafayette Ragin' Cajuns baseball team represented the University of Louisiana at Lafayette in the 2014 NCAA Division I baseball season. It was the 73rd season in the school's baseball history. The team was coached by Tony Robichaux in his twentieth season at Louisiana–Lafayette. The Ragin' Cajuns entered the season as the defending Sun Belt Conference champions, but the season proved to be a disappointing one for the team. The team suffered from inconsistency throughout the season, and struggled to a 29–27 overall record, with a 13–16 mark in conference play. On May 19, the Ragin' Cajuns were eliminated in the Sun Belt tournament, losing to Texas State by a score of 5–4, ending their season. Heading into the 2014 season, the Ragin' Cajuns returned much of their team from the previous season. Senior Caleb Adams was the most productive returnee, hitting .327 with eight home runs and a team-high 44 RBI. Senior Michael Strentz enjoyed a breakout season, hitting .301 in 16 starts. On the mound, junior Carson Baranik led the way with a 3.71 ERA and 5–3 record over 12 starts. The Ragin' Cajuns opened the season with a 7–2 loss to Indiana, in the Mardi Gras Classic at Mobile, Alabama. The season was marked by a series of streaks and slumps; the Cajuns opened the season by losing five of their first seven games, then rebounding to win nine of their next eleven. Conference play began after the conclusion of their non-conference slate, and the team opened with a 4–1 mark in their first five games, but then proceeded to lose five of their next seven games, essentially ending their hopes of winning the Sun Belt regular season title. The team did have some bright spots in the season, earning series wins against Sun Belt rivals South Alabama and Arkansas State, both of whom had been ranked in the national rankings at some point in the season. The team also had multiple impressive pitching performances, teaming up to no-hit Coastal Carolina in February. Unfortunately for the Ragin' Cajuns, however, their inconsistencies throughout the season prevented them from building any consistent momentum on the way to their Sun Belt Tournament elimination. Following the conclusion of the season, senior infielder Ryan Leonards and junior pitcher Carson Baranik were selected in the 2014 MLB draft, but the Ragin' Cajuns saw the most success with their young and talented recruits. Freshmen Trace Rousseau and Dylan Moore, as well as transfer Blake Trahan all had strong debuts with the Ragin' Cajuns and should be key contributors moving forward.

Private Eyes is a song by the American new wave band Hall & Oates. It was released in July 1981 as the lead single from their album Private Eyes, and was the title track. The single hit the top of the Billboard Hot 100 chart on October 17, 1981, becoming the group's third number-one single in the United States. Private Eyes was also included in the group's first greatest hits album, Rock 'n Soul Part 1, which was released in October 1983. The song was written by Daryl Hall and Janna Allen, and produced by Hall & Oates and Neil Kernon. The style of the song gave a nod to the doo-wop genre of the 1950s. The song's use of the word "Baby" has been cited as an example of "baby talk" in the traditional sense, which generally refers to the singing style of singers like Frankie Lymon and the Teenagers during the mid-1950s. There is also an extension of baby talk in the song in the lyric, "I'm your baby tonight". The song opens with an a cappella verse that has received some of the most well-known airplay. It features the group vocalizing to a syncopated rhythm, repeating the words "Private Eyes, they're watching you," and allowing the notes to run into each other. Since its release, it has become a popular karaoke song. The music video for "Private Eyes" was released in 1981 and was directed by Robert Longo. The video was filmed in black and white and featured Hall & Oates miming to the song in front of a white background. The song has been covered by acts such as the cast of The Simpsons and McDonald's, as well as being remixed by various DJs. It has featured in many films and television shows, including Bridget Jones's Diary, The Simpsons Movie, Gilmore Girls, Glee, Lilo & Stitch, and A Knight's Tale. Private Eyes has continued to remain a staple of Hall & Oates' live performances, having been included in every tour since its release. In 2017, the song was listed at number 21 on Billboard's All Time Top 100.

Looking for Trouble is a 1981 studio album by singer-songwriter Bobby Rivers. The album was released on June 17, 1981 by RCA Records and was Rivers' fourth full-length album. Rivers was able to transition well from his previous albums and was well received by fans and critics alike. Lead single, "Celebration of Love," was a hit single on the U.S. music charts, reaching number 16 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and charting at number 20 on the UK Singles chart. The single also reached number 4 on the Canadian Singles charts. The second single from the album was "Don't Wanna Get Down", which also proved to be a success, reaching number 29 on the U.S. Hot 100 and number 27 in Canada. The album's third single, "Looking for Trouble", was not as well received by fans, as it only reached number 66 on the Hot 100 chart. However, despite this, the album was a success, reaching number 59 on the Billboard 200 chart in 1981. The album was praised in reviews, with the AllMusic review outlining the album's unique quality; "Thanks in large part to Rivers' unique approach, Looking for Trouble stands out from the crowd, and its standout track, "Celebration of Love," is an infectious blend of pop, soul and R&B that is still able to connect to listeners today." The album features a different tone than Rivers' former releases, as he added elements of funk and blues to capture the attention of his audience. The album contains a rich mix of soundscapes and melodies, helping to make Looking for Trouble one of the more popular albums from Rivers' discography. Technical credits for the album include Grammy Award-winning producers Thom Bell and Joe Wissert, mixed by esteemed engineer Jack Joseph Puig. Musician credits for the album include David Paich, who played keyboards; guitarists Dann Huff, Dean Parks and Steve Lukather; and David Hungate on bass. Following the release of the album, Rivers went on to tour throughout the 1980s with his band, The Bobby Rivers Band. During the tour, Rivers debuted several songs from the album, while also playing several of his older singles to the delight of audiences worldwide. The album was blessed with positive reviews and, while it may have been seen as a bit different compared to other albums of its time, Looking for Trouble still stands as a beloved and iconic album of the time.

The Hungarian Ground Forces (Hungarian: Magyar Honvédség) is the land-based branch of the Hungarian Defence Forces, which include the Hungarian Army and the Hungarian Air Force. It is the largest branch of the Defence Forces, with a total strength of around 25,000 personnel. The Hungarian Ground Forces are responsible for the defence of the country's territory and the maintenance of its national security. The Hungarian Ground Forces were formed in 1956, after the collapse of the Austro-Hungarian Empire in 1918. The military initially played a crucial role in the Hungarian Revolution of 1956, which overthrew the Communist-dominated government. The Hungarian Ground Forces were reorganized several times since then, and in 1995, the Code of National Defence was adopted, which further reorganised and modernized the Land Forces. The primary role of the Hungarian Ground Forces is to defend Hungary against any external threats. The main headquarters of the Hungarian Ground Forces is located in Budapest and is responsible for strategic planning, operational coordination, and general management. The headquarters is led by the Chief of the General Staff, who is appointed by the President of Hungary. The Land Forces also maintain an armed reserve force, which is made up of volunteers and professional soldiers. The Land Forces maintain a number of combat divisions and support units, including armoured divisions, artillery battalions, special forces, air-defence units and ceremonial units. The Hungarian Ground Forces have also taken on the role of training and exercising with other NATO countries. The Hungarian Ground Forces maintain close ties with their counterparts in other countries, including the United States, France, Germany and the United Kingdom. The Land Forces are also part of the Hungarian Combined Arms Detachment, a multinational force mandated by the European Union to take on peacekeeping and security roles in Europe. The Hungarian Ground Forces possess a range of weapons and vehicles, including tanks, armoured personnel carriers, helicopters, and fighter jets, to defend the nation's borders and to protect its citizens from any external threats. The Land Forces are also responsible for the coordination of military exercises, and the analysis and evaluation of the capabilities of the Defence Forces. The Hungarian Ground Forces work closely with the other branches of the Defence Forces, the Hungarian Air Force and the Hungarian Navy, in order to maintain total defence readiness and to ensure a secure national defence.

The West London Orbital (WLO) is a proposed orbital motorway for West and Northwest London. It is designed to provide an alternative to the congested North Circular Road in the capital and to connect outer London boroughs and the M25 orbital motorway. The West London Orbital project was first proposed by the Greater London Assembly in 2006 and further detailed in the London Plan in 2009. The plan was officially unveiled in 2012, and it recommended that the WLO should run clockwise from junction 4 of the M25 near Heathrow Airport, then travel northwest along the A312, A4127 and A404, and then move southwest along the A4 and A3 to reach junction 13 of the M25 near Staines-upon-Thames. The motorway is intended to link the M25 with some of the most populated areas of West and Northwest London, including Brent, Ealing, Harrow, Hillingdon, Hounslow and Richmond. It is expected to substantially reduce traffic congestion on the North Circular Road and provide improved access to areas of West London that are currently relatively difficult to get to by road, such as Hounslow and Brent. The WLO is estimated to cost approximately £4 billion and it has been designed in a way that minimises disruption to existing communities and infrastructure. The project is expected to be a public-private partnership, and the Government has discussed the possibility of using private finance to fund the motorway. In February 2019, the Department for Transport requested more information on the WLO to enable them to decide whether to fund the project. The Government has since stated that they are considering the project as part of their wider plans to tackle traffic congestion in the capital, and they have committed to providing a decision on the West London Orbital within the next two years. The West London Orbital project has been widely welcomed by local authorities, who believe that it would improve transport infrastructure in the capital and help to unlock economic growth. There has also been support for the project from local businesses and community groups, who have argued that it would free-up congestion and improve air quality in the capital. Despite this, there has also been some opposition to the project, with critics arguing that the cost of building the motorway is too high and could be used for more important local services such as health and education. Ultimately, the success of the West London Orbital project will rest with the Government's decision on whether to fund it or not. If approved, then work could begin within the next few years, allowing the WLO to become a reality and help to unlock the potential of West London.

40 Tenth Avenue is a 32-story, 120-unit apartment building located in the Chelsea district of Manhattan, New York City. It was designed by Kohn Pedersen Fox and developed by HFZ Capital Group, led by Ziel Feldman. Set on a hard corner overlooking the High Line, the building contains a generous collection of amenities including a residents' lounge, library, private screening room, music practice room, and 24-hour attended lobby. There is also a private garden courtyard. The building provides a range of studio, one-bedroom, two-bedroom and three-bedroom apartments. It is designed to be a “green” building, utilizing high performance materials and systems to make it sustainable. The structure has already been awarded a LEED-Gold certification. The lobby and outdoor terrace was designed by Champalimaud, winner of the Interior Design Magazine 2012 award for best new restaurant in New York City. Amenities also include a fitness center with an outdoor sundeck, spa and juice bar. The building offers breathtaking views of the Hudson River and Midtown Manhattan, as well as a host of restaurants and nightlife in the surrounding Chelsea neighborhood. It's convenient location provides easy access to the NYU and Chelsea Piers, as well as shopping and entertainment destinations. The much-anticipated opening of 40 Tenth Avenue marked the largest single residential ownership in the Chelsea District. The design and amenities of the building bring together the energy of Chelsea and the luxury of the High Line, with spectacular views of the Hudson River, capturing the attention of many potential buyers. 40 Tenth Avenue is an icon of luxury living, providing an unparalleled living experience for its residents. With its unique design, amenities and spectacular location, 40 Tenth Avenue is sure to become one of the most sought-after addresses in Manhattan.

Aditya Kapadia (born 29 October 1993) is an Indian singer, songwriter, and actor. He is best known for his 2019 single "With You", which he released while signed to Sony Music India. He also starred in three Bollywood movies including the 2016 film Fitoor, directed by Abhishek Kapoor. Kapadia was born and raised in Mumbai, India. He began singing at a young age and soon started competing in televised singing competitions. He graduated from the Mumbai University in 2016 with a bachelor's degree in economics. In 2016, Kapadia made his acting debut in the film Fitoor, which was directed by Abhishek Kapoor and starred Katrina Kaif and Aditya Roy Kapur. The film told the story of an affluent family, and Kapadia featured as the antagonist in the film. Following the success of the film, Kapadia went on to star in two more movies. In 2019, Kapadia signed a record deal with Sony Music India, and his debut single "With You" was released that same year. The song was a musical success, topping several Indian music charts and amassing more than 35 million streams online. In 2020, he released the follow-up single "Save Me", which saw similar success. Kapadia often collaborates with other Indian artists, and he is currently working on several projects with various music labels. In the future, he plans to release an album of his own material and venture into international music markets. In addition, Kapadia is continuing to develop his acting career. He will be starring in an upcoming web series, slated for release in 2021. Outside of music and acting, Kapadia is an avid traveler. He often posts pictures and videos of his trips on his social media, which helps support his online presence. Kapadia's body of work has earned him both national and international acclaim. He has been nominated for several awards, including the Mtv Vma Video of the Year, and he is the winner of several prestigious awards such as the Sony Music Asia Rising Star Award. His single "With You" was also featured in the Bollywood film, Secret Superstar, which earned him a nomination for the Jio Filmfare Award for Best Playback Singer.

Manuel Izquierdo (1925–2009) was an American sculptor and artist. He is best known for his wood sculptures, found object assemblages, and jewelry designs in the Pacific Northwest. Izquierdo was born in 1925 in San Jose de Gracia, Michoacán, Mexico. He immigrated to the US at the age of fifteen and studied art in California. He was drafted into the US Army during the Second World War and served in Germany. After the war, he moved to the Portland, Oregon area, where he worked as a carpenter and eventually established his own studio. In the 1950s, he began creating wood sculptures, often drawing on memories of Mexico. He also produced found object assemblages and worked in ceramics, metals and jewelry. In 1970, Izquierdo received a fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts, which he used to travel to Mexico and Central America to study Mexican sculpture and textiles. He continued to earn international recognition for his work, and his sculptures were included in the 1975 Museum of Modern Art exhibition, "The Sculpture of the Pacific Northwest". Izquierdo's aesthetic incorporated a hybrid of traditional and modern elements. His works often combined the labor intensive traditional techniques of ancient arts, such as carving and inlaying, with more contemporary motifs. He drew influence from his travels, as well as from aboriginal cultures, Surrealism, and Abstract Expressionism. Throughout his career, Izquierdo held several solo exhibitions and his work has been exhibited in numerous group exhibitions. He was also active in the curation of international exhibitions, including "Messages of Hope: Mexican Folk Art and Contemporary Art" in the late 1980s. His work has been featured in a variety of publications, including "Eccentric Visions", a book of artist profiles published in 1995. Manuel Izquierdo died in 2009 in Portland, Oregon. His artwork is in many public and private collections, including the Smithsonian American Art Museum, the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, and the American Craft Museum in New York City. He is an artist of international reputation and an important figure in the Pacific Northwest art scene.

Bruce Almighty is a 2003 American fantasy comedy film directed by Tom Shadyac and written by Steve Koren, Mark O'Keefe and Steve Oedekerk. The film stars Jim Carrey as Bruce Nolan, a discontented television reporter on the brink of a midlife crisis. Feeling neglected by God, he is angered when he finds that he is given the power to be God for one week. When he discovers how difficult it is to use this power carefully and be a decent human being, Bruce decides to fix his life while practicing the responsibilities of being a deity. He realizes that his life would have been easier without the divine intervention and decides to improve his relationships with those he loves. The film also stars Jennifer Aniston as Grace, Bruce's girlfriend; Morgan Freeman as God; Catherine Bell as Susan Ortega, Bruce's rival at the television station; Lisa Ann Walter as Bruce's best friend and producer; Steve Carell as Evan Baxter, one of Bruce's colleagues; and Nora Dunn as Bruce's mother. The film was released in theaters on May 23, 2003, and grossed over $484 million on a budget of $81 million, becoming one of the most successful films of the year. It was nominated for several awards, including a Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy, and an Academy Award nomination for Best Makeup. The film was one of Jim Carrey's most successful films and is one of his most popularly quoted films, thanks to its sheer number of memorable lines, as well as its unexpected depth and heart amidst the comedy. It has spawned two sequels, Evan Almighty (2007) and Son of God (2014).

The Texas alligator lizard (Gerrhonotus infernalis) is a species of large lizard found in the United States. It is a member of the family Anguidae. This species is endemic to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico and is commonly found in the southern regions of both countries. The Texas alligator lizard is known to be diurnal and is known to hibernate during the winter months. They have thick bodies with a length of 5.5-7.6 inches. They are typically gray or brown in color, with dark blotches and bands on their body. They have scales covering the back and tail, while the ventral side scales are reduced in size. The head is wide and rounded and the tail is thick, almost like an alligator’s. Texas alligator lizards are omnivorous and their diet consists of small invertebrates such as insects, snails, spiders, scorpions, and worms. They will also consume plant matter such as fruits and flowers on occasion. These lizards are found in habitats such as arid deserts, woodlands, and scrublands. They prefer to inhabit areas with appropriate cover such as small rocks, logs or brush piles. They are mostly terrestrial but are known to climb trees of shrubs. As well as foraging for food, Texas alligator lizards use their strong leg muscles to outrun predators. The Texas alligator lizard is listed as a species of least concern. They have no major threats to their population. The primary threat to their population is habitat loss due to urban development. Other potential threats include predation by domestic cats, road mortality, and competition with non-native species. Despite the few threats, the Texas alligator lizard is considered to be a hardy species of lizard. This species provides a vital contribution to the ecosystem. They provide food for larger predators, while also aiding in the dispersal of plant seeds. They also help to control insect populations, as they are voracious predators of both invertebrates and small mammals. Due to the resilience of the species, the Texas alligator lizard is an excellent species for captive breeding. Captive breeding programs help to reintroduce the species into their habitats, which is important for population recovery. Breeding Texas alligator lizards in captivity is a rewarding experience for herpetoculturists, as they are a unique and impressive species. In conclusion, the Texas alligator lizard is a unique species of reptile that plays an important role in the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. Despite few threats, these lizards are resilient and can be bred in captivity. As such, this species is listed as of least concern and is a vital part of the ecosystem.

Emanuel Alberto Reynoso (born 3 July 1995) is an Argentine professional footballer who plays as a midfielder for Boca Juniors in the Primera División. Reynoso started his career with his hometown club Deportivo Paraguayo, at the age of 16. After two impressive seasons, he was signed by Primera División side Huracán in 2014. He made his debut in the league as a substitute against San Lorenzo in September 2015. Reynoso made a total of 53 appearances with Huracán, before signing for Boca Juniors in June 2017. He made his Boca debut versus Sarmiento de Junín in the Copa Argentina and he scored his first goal for the club against his former club Huracán in December 2017. Since then, he has become a permanent fixture in the Boca line up, scoring seven goals in 74 appearances. In 2019, Reynoso was part of the Argentina U-23 team which competed at the Pan American Games in Lima. He scored the opening goal in the final against Chile, helping his team to win the gold medal. During the 2020 season, Reynoso helped Boca to secure their 36th Argentine championship title, capping off an extraordinary season in which he scored four goals and provided eight assists in 24 league appearances. Reynoso has quickly established himself as one of the most exciting talents in Argentine football and he is considered by many to be one of the brightest prospects in the country. His excellent ball control, agility and vision have made him a regular in the Argentina national team and he was part of the squad that won the 2019 Copa América held in Brazil. Off the pitch, Reynoso is a committed supporter of UNICEF and their campaigns to promote children’s rights. He also runs a charity foundation in his hometown of Escobar, which provides basic education to children from underprivileged backgrounds.

The W National Park massacre occurred on August 7, 2014, in W National Park, located in northeastern Niger. At the time, it was believed to be the deadliest terrorist attack in the country's history. On the morning of August 7th, gunmen launched a series of coordinated attacks against two small villages located in the park.The attacks began at dawn when gunmen on motorbikes attacked the first village, Gossera. The attackers killed at least ninety people, mostly by shooting. The attackers also burned down numerous homes and businesses during the attack. During the assault, the gunmen also destroyed a nearby unoccupied clinic. In addition to the ninety dead, over forty survivors were seriously injured as a result of the attack. Most were women and children. The second village, Gozawa, was attacked shortly after the assault on Gossera. The attackers killed at least twenty-nine people, including several security personnel, and destroyed homes and shops in the village. Immediately following the attacks, Nigerien security forces intensified patrols around the park, and an investigation was opened. On August 17, 2014, Nigerien forces launched a joint operation with forces from neighboring countries to apprehend the attackers. The operation resulted in the capture of several suspected militants who have since been charged with the crimes. The W National Park massacre is a reminder of the continued instability in the country, and the important role of targeted security operations in protecting Niger’s population from further attacks. The incident also stimulated discussions in the international community, with some human rights groups condemning the attack and calling for greater efforts to increase security in the region. Today, several memorials honoring the victims of the massacre have been erected in the region. The attack continues to be a subject of national mourning and an important part of the country’s history.

Folashade Oluwafemiayo (born June 25th, 1959 in Lagos, Nigeria) is a Nigerian writer, speaker, entrepreneur, and educational specialist. Her work examines leadership, education, public service and community engagement. She is the founder and Chief Executive Officer of The Folashade Academy, a private school based in Lagos, Nigeria. Oluwafemiayo was born in Lagos, Nigeria, in 1959. She received her early education at Queen's College, Lagos, and later moved to the United States to further her education. She holds a Bachelor of Science degree from the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, and a Master's degree in Education from the University of Connecticut. Oluwafemiayo has been an advocate for education reform and youth development throughout her life. She has played a leadership role in numerous initiatives aimed at providing quality education and support to Nigerian youth, including the founding of The Folashade Academy, a private school in Lagos. She believes that education is the most effective tool for transformation and sustainability, and seeks to inspire and equip young people to become effective agents of change. Oluwafemiayo has served on various boards and initiatives, including the Nigerian Education Trust and the Centre for Human Rights and Civic Education. She has been recognized for her contributions to education, leadership development and community engagement, with awards such as the African Leadership Academy "Advocate of Change Award" in 2015 and the United Nations' "Every Woman Every Child Award" in 2018. In addition to her educational work in Nigeria, Oluwafemiayo is also an accomplished author, contributor and spokesperson. She has published several books, including The African Woman's Guide to Leadership, Education and Influence (2018). Her first book, Women in Leadership, was translated into six languages and has been used as a teaching tool in universities in the United States, Canada, and the United Kingdom. She is a frequent commentator in the media, appearing in TV, radio, and print coverage of topics related to education, social justice, and leadership. Oluwafemiayo is committed to empowering young people and creating access to opportunities that promote self-sufficiency. Her ultimate goal is to see young people in Nigeria transcend the limiting challenges they often face, so they can reach their full potential to become future leaders, innovators and creators in their respective fields. Through her work in education, literature, advocacy and public speaking, Oluwafemiayo has become a highly respected figure in Nigeria, and an inspiration to many young people in the country.

Michele Lean (born November 13, 1991) is a Canadian entrepreneur and cancer survivor. As of 2021, Lean has been listed as one of the Top 20 under-30 female entrepreneurs in Canada by Profit Magazine. In 2019, Lean was diagnosed with Hodgkin's Lymphoma, a blood cancer. Rather than become a victim of her illness, she chose to see it as an opportunity for personal and professional growth. She launched a podcast and founded Lean On My Fight, an online platform that allows cancer patients to lean on each other for support and encouragement. Following her own diagnosis, she suffered from a lack of empathy from her environment and communities, which fueled her drive to build Lean On My Fight. Lean On My Fight is a private and secure platform with a focus on user engagement, allowing users to share their experiences on the platform in order to help each other cope and heal. Lean is passionate about making the platform comprehensive and engaging, and she believes her passion and creativity will help more people going through the same experiences. Since its launch, Lean On My Fight has grown to over 10K users. Lean has been recognized as a champion for mental health and cancer awareness. She has been invited to speak at many events, including TEDx and the Women's International Leadership Summit in Copenhagen. She has also been featured in numerous news outlets and publications, such as Rolling Stones, Forbes and the Huffington Post. In 2021, Lean was invited to the World Economic Forum in Davos as one of the Young Global Leaders. She was chosen for her leadership and commitment to the health and well-being of cancer patients. There, she discussed her experiences and her vision for her platform. Lean plans to expand Lean On My Fight to include cancer types beyond Hodgkin's, such as Leukemia and Multiple Myeloma. For now, however, Lean is focused on ensuring the platform remains unique and helpful for cancer patients of all kinds. She is determined to break the taboo around cancer and open doors for cancer patients to get the support they need.

Kingsland Bridge is an old road bridge located in the city of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the northeast of England. Built in 1878, and designed by local engineers Craven and Mark, it is the oldest surviving bridge in Newcastle and one of the oldest historic road bridges in the North of England. It is a Grade II* Listed Building by Historic England. The bridge crosses the River Tyne between the neighbourhoods of Jesmond and Heaton, east of the city centre, and is positioned slightly north of the Redheugh Bridge. It originally served as a southwards extension of Wingrove Road, carrying the B1351 road, but has since been closed to vehicular traffic. Kingsland Bridge is a two-span, wrought iron and masonry structure, featuring two parabolic arches, each one built with 400 tonnes of Welsh granite. The arches span a distance of 36 metres, creating a total width of 18 metres, rising far above its original foundation. At the end of the 19th century, Kingsland Bridge became a centre of community and leisure activities. A pedestrian pathway was added in the 1920s, which allowed relative freedom of movement until it was closed off to pedestrians again in the early 1990s, due to its increasing dilapidation. Despite its closure, the bridge has slowly been refurbished, in order to preserve it as a historic site. In recent years, a number of facelifts have been applied, including the installation of new lighting, balustrades and fencing, and aesthetic restoration to the masonry. Nowadays, Kingsland Bridge is a popular destination for tourists and local enthusiasts alike. Situated in a scenic area with the River Tyne running directly underneath, many people stop to appreciate its architecture and observe the river's surrounding views. As part of the regeneration project in Newcastle, several initiatives have proposed the opening of the bridge to pedestrian and bicycle traffic. If implemented, these plans could potentially reinvigorate the area and would likely increase the number of visitors to an already unique site.

Jack Six (born January 16 1985) is an American actor, writer, and comedian. He is best known for his leading roles on television shows such as NYPD Blue, Law & Order, and Shark. He has appeared in several feature films such as Heat, Bad Santa, and Con-Air. Jack Six was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated from New York University with a degree in communications in 2005. After graduating, he moved to Los Angeles, California to pursue an acting career. In 2006, Six made his television debut with a guest starring role on the hit crime drama, NYPD Blue. Since then, Six has had recurring roles on such shows as Law & Order and Shark. He has also made guest appearances on such popular shows as CSI: Miami and The Blacklist. In 2007, Six made his feature film debut with a starring role in the action film, Heat. He has since gone on to appear in a variety of other feature films such as Bad Santa, Con-Air, and Drive. Six is a multi-talented artist and is also an experienced writer. He wrote, directed, and starred in the 2015 comedy-drama film, Jack Six & Friends. The film was well-received and earned Six several awards at various film festivals. Jack Six is a highly talented actor and writer. He has proven himself to be a versatile performer and has a gift for making any role his own. He is an incredibly talented entertainer who has made a name for himself in the entertainment industry.

Bourbon Street is a famous, historic street in the heart of New Orleans, Louisiana, United States. It is located in the French Quarter, which is the oldest and most celebrated part of the city. It is famously known for its alluring nightlife, vibrant music and dining, and its wild, carnival-like atmosphere. Bourbon Street is an iconic part of the Big Easy because of its colorful history and unique street style. The street was once a residential area, built by French contractors in the 1700s for French soldiers – but with the common arrival of African slaves, the area became a bustling entertainment district. Jazz music, including the unique sound of jazz, was especially popular, and Bourbon Street also developed a reputation for debauchery and charged with energy. Today, Bourbon Street is still an extremely popular destination for tourists to the Big Easy. The street is often divided into three sections: the upper portion, which is the most touristy and busiest; the middle portion, where clubs and bars line the streets, playing live jazz and hosting drink specials and street festivals; and the lower portion, where the more old-school vibes live and the locals and a more authentic experience can be found. Bourbon Street offers a variety of sights, sounds, and experiences. It proudly features live music acts and performances each night, taking inspiration from its storied history of jazz and blues. In addition, its restaurants and bars offer an array of Creole cuisine, as well as traditional New Orleans dishes like jambalaya and po’boys. There are also plenty of places to shop for t-shirts, mementos, and other souvenirs. Bourbon Street is definitely a must-see for visitors to the area, offering a unique cultural experience found nowhere else in the United States. Whether you’re seeking a night of lively entertainment, a relaxing stroll through the historic French Quarter, or just looking for some delicious Louisiana fare, Bourbon Street has it all.

Andrea Russell (born June 5, 1974) is an American entrepreneur and marketing executive. She is the CEO, co-founder and co-founder of Rocco Strategic Solutions, an international marketing and branding consulting firm. She has over 19 years of business experience in the marketing and branding industry, delivering successful marketing and branding initiatives to major global corporations. Andrea Russell was born in New Jersey and grew up in Hayward, California. She studied Business Management at Stanford University and earned a Bachelor of Arts in Business Management in 1996. Her first business venture was at Procter & Gamble as a brand marketing analyst, where she specialized in market research, strategy and brand consulting. In 1998, she moved to London to pursue an MBA at London Business School, where she earned an MBA in 2000. Following graduation, she moved back to the US to join McCann Erickson Worldwide as a brand strategy executive. During her seven years at McCann, she provided strategic insight and counsel on major multi-national accounts, leading to several international brand wins. In 2007, Russell co-founded Rocco Strategic Solutions, an international marketing and branding consulting firm that works with Fortune 500 companies to enhance branding.The firm has offices located in London and Chicago. Russell leads a multi-disciplinary team that provides consulting services on brand research, development, and activation. The firm develops strategies, campaigns and programs to increase brand awareness and sales. She has appeared in Forbes, Inc., the Wall Street Journal, and The Economist, discussing the trends and challenges of managing brands in a digital world. In 2015, Russell was selected to serve as a judge for the 2015 Internet Advertising Competition. In addition to her work as an entrepreneur, Russell is a native Spanish speaker and actively supports the Hispanic community. She lectures on diversity and inclusion topics, as well as serves on several boards. She was recently recognized as one of the fifty most influential female entrepreneurs of 2016 by Inc. Magazine. She was simultaneously honored as one of the Women of Achievers by the National Women’s Chamber of Commerce. Russell currently resides in Chicago, Illinois with her husband and their three children.

Warren Petryk (born March 16, 1972) is an American politician and businessman who is the 58th and current Governor of Wisconsin. Petryk first became involved in politics as aide to Congressman James Sensenbrenner during his time in the House of Representatives and then served as a state Senator from his hometown of Eau Claire, WI for three terms (2003-2009). Petryk was a partner at the law firm of Carson, Thorp, and Petryk, where he also presided as President, before his election as Governor in 2014. He went on to be re-elected as Governor in 2018 with 60% of the vote. Petryk, a Republican, won the 2014 Gubernatorial election in Wisconsin, narrowly defeating Democratic nominee, Mary Burke. Petryk ran on a platform of reduced taxes and regulation, job creation and economic growth, improved education, and stronger public safety. During his tenure as Governor, Petryk has implemented a voucher program that provides additional education choices to students, reduced the size of government by streamlining agencies, and created jobs and reduced unemployment. Petryk is credited with Wisconsin's economic success during his time in office. During his time as Governor, economic growth has been among the highest in the nation and unemployment is currently at an all-time low of 2.5%. He has also reduced the state's debt by $5 billion. In addition to running the state, Petryk has been involved in various charitable activities, including a yearly beach clean-up in Door County and volunteering with the Big Brothers Big Sisters of Wisconsin organization. In 2020, Petryk was mentioned in speculation to join the Trump campaign as a potential running mate. Petryk summarily dismissed the reports. Petryk lives in Eau Claire, Wisconsin with his wife and two children. He enjoys hunting, fishing, and skiing. Petryk is one of the few governors in the nation who has been re-elected twice, and his tenure in office has been an exemplar for economic growth, job creation, reduced taxes, and responsible spending. He is seen as a responsible leader who has put Wisconsin on an economic path to success.

John Pulling (born 1788, died 1874) was a British naval captain and polar explorer. He is known for leading an expedition to the Arctic Circle with the former Polar explorer John Ross and his nephew James Clark Ross in 1829. His leadership of the expedition was praised by all of his companions, who viewed him as a leader who could be trusted and admired. Pulling joined the Royal Navy as a midshipman in 1805, serving in wars against both France and Spain. He rose quickly through the ranks and by 1811 he was promoted to lieutenant. It was also in 1811 when Pulling first served as an officer with his leader, John Ross. In 1810, John Ross was sent on an expedition to find the Northwest Passage and met with Pulling to make sure he could handle the task. After assessment, Ross gave his consent and Pulling was placed at the top of the crew due to his good knowledge of navigation. After a difficult start to the expedition, the crew found their way to the Arctic Circle, achieving the goal of the mission. In 1812, Pulling was promoted to captain, and in 1814 he was sent on an expedition to explore Newfoundland. He was also part of the campaign to suppress the slave trade off the coast of West Africa, taking part in the battle of Mobile Bay in 1815. In 1829, Pulling embarked on his second Arctic expedition which was led by his former mentor, John Ross. The expedition was a great success and Pulling was commended for his skill and bravery under the difficult circumstances with the crew facing constant danger from the icy conditions. During this period, Pulling also had the opportunity to serve on the HMS Victory as it carried out a scientific survey of the Mediterranean in 1831. Towards the end of his long career, John Pulling received an honour from the Royal Geographical Society for his services in exploration. He retired from service in 1858 with a pension and returned to England where he ended his days. He died in 1874, aged 86, and is remembered as a brave explorer who pushed the boundaries of knowledge and exploration in the early days of the Royal Navy.

Alexandre Grendene Bartelle (born August 12, 1968) is a Brazilian billionaire businessman and entrepreneur. He is the co-owner and president of Alpargatas, one of the world's largest shoe companies. Bartelle is also the majority owner and chairman of Log-In Logística Inteligente, Brazil's largest integrated logistics operator, and one of the ten largest in the world. Bartelle has been included in the Forbe's list of billionaires since 2018. Bartelle was born in Brazil in 1968 as the son of a wealthy investor. He earned a degree in business administration from Fundação Armando Alvares Penteado in São Paulo. In 1984, he joined the company founded by his father, Alpargatas. Initially working in the area of finance and investments, now Barrette is the president of the company. As of 2020, the company had revenue of R$ 8.6 billion and its the brand Havaianas is the most popular flip-flop in the world. In 2012, Bartelle established Log-In Logística Inteligente, in which he invested US$ 200 million of his own funds. The logistics operator has operations in Brazil, Argentina and Mexico, and focuses on light cargo delivery services, a segment in which it is a leader in Latin America. It has partnerships with companies such as J.F. Obayashi and Engie, as well as government entities. It currently serves more than 10,000 customers and has a workforce of 13,000 people. Bartelle has been included in the Forbes List of Billionaires since 2018 and has a net worth of a estimated US $7.1 billion, as of July 2020. He is the third wealthiest man in Brazil, behind Jean Paul and Carlos, and the 998th wealthiest person in the world. In addition to his business interests, Bartelle is well known for his philanthropic activities. He is the founder of the Alexandre Grendene Bartelle Institute, a non-profit organization dedicated to the study and research of Brazilian culture and history. He is also the president of the Institute of Brazilian Studies, a research center focused on Brazil's economic and business environment. Bartelle has been recognized by several organizations for his entrepreneurial achievements. He is the recipient of the LIDE's Recognition of Entrepreneur of the Year, and of the RKF's Special Recognition Award for Entrepreneurship and Leadership. In 2019, he was named “Entrepreneur of the Year” by GQ Brazil.

Destiny Fulfilled is the title of the fifth and final album by the American girl group, Destiny's Child. The album was released on November 16, 2004, by Columbia Records. Destiny's Child recorded the album in stages throughout 2003 and 2004, and finalized their production early in 2004. The album was primarily produced by Rodney Jerkins, with the exception of one track. It was the group's final and most successful studio release, becoming the group's fourth consecutive album to debut at number one (following The Writings on the Wall and Survivor). It was highly anticipated, and had the highest first-week sales of any of the group's albums. Destiny Fulfilled produced two singles. The first, "Lose My Breath", became a worldwide hit, particularly in the United Kingdom and Germany, where it topped the charts. The second single, "Soldier", featuring T.I. and Lil Wayne, met with similar success and reached the top ten in the US, UK, and a number of other countries. The remaining three singles failed to reach the mainstream, however, critical reception for the album was generally positive. The majority of the album was produced and co-written by Rodney Jerkins, who also served as executive producer. Other producers include Harvey Mason Jr., Organized Noize, KayGee, Rich Harrison and Dre & Vidal. The album won the Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals in 2005. It was the group's first nomination and win at the Grammy Awards. Destiny Fulfilled became their fourth consecutive and last album to debut at number one on the US chart, selling 502,000 copies. It has received a double Platinum certification in the US and a Triple Platinum certification in the UK. Overall, the album has sold over 6 million copies worldwide. It was the first of the group's albums to produce three top-ten singles in the US, along with two number-one singles in the UK, making it their highest-selling album there. The members of Destiny's Child reunited in 2005 to begin their final tour, Destiny Fulfilled...and Lovin' It. The tour continued until their final performance in Barcelona on June 11, 2005. The concert was originally set to be their last performance together as a group, though each member has made numerous appearances together both before and after their disbandment.

Steven Spurrier (born 1939) is an iconic wine merchant, educator and writer from the United Kingdom. He is most recognized for his major role in launching the 1976 Judgment of Paris, a French wine tasting event in which Californian wines were compared to French. His results shocked the world at the time due to the California wines surpassing the French ones. Spurrier is the current owner of the Wine Workshop and Academy, which he founded in 1998 as a wine school in Paris. Born in Colchester, Spurrier studied history and philosophy at the University of Durham, and then took up a job as the manager of the wine department at London retailer Corney & Barrow in 1965. In 1967, he founded the then-novel wine shop Les Caves de la Madeleine, specialising in sourcing French wines from small independent growers. In 1969, he moved to Dolly’s wine merchants and quickly established himself as the voice of the English wine trade. In 1969 Steven Spurrier went on a major tour of California, impressing the local winemakers while attracting the attention of the wine press. In 1976, the famous Judgement of Paris wine tasting was a contest to settle the competition between French and Californian wines in which Spurrier was the main organizer. Chardonnay and Cabernet Sauvignon wines from both countries were tasted by a panel of nine French judges. Surprisingly, the California wines won on both categories, shaking up the international wine trade with unexpected results. Spurrier’s career continued with his consulting work for retailers, his extensive wine writing, and his work for Decanter magazine, where he contributed as a columnist. In 1996, he took up a position as the in-house wine expert at Christie’s in London and three years later, he founded his namesake Wine Workshop and Academy in Paris. Located in the Latin Quarter near Boulevard Saint Germain, the school offers a range of courses to learn about wine, from basic knowledge to world-wide qualifications. Spurrier is referred to as an educator, mentor, and ambassador for the international wine culture, and was awarded the Chevalier De L’Ordre Du Mérite Agricole in 2002 and made a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in 2006. He is also the author of several award winning guides and books about the various aspects of the wine trade and culture. The Judgment of Paris was the defining moment in Spurrier’s career. Decades later, the spotlight continues to shine on the original event and its organizer, as both California and French producers benefit from its publicity and impact. To date, Steven Spurrier continues to work as a wine educator in private courses and special events.

The 2019 IIHF Women's World Championship Final was the championship game of the 2019 IIHF Women's World Championship, an international ice hockey tournament run by the International Ice Hockey Federation (IIHF). The game was held on May 18, 2019 at Espoo Metro Areena in Espoo, Finland. The game was contested between the United States and Finland, with the United States winning the gold medal by a score of 3–2 in overtime. The United States was led by head coach Bob Corkum, while the Finnish team was coached by women's national team head coach Tiina Reima. Representatives from both sides noted the high level of competition and the importance of the tournament's top prize. The United States had the first good scoring chance towards the end of the first period when Hilary Knight had a shot on goal that was just tipped away by Noora Raty's glove. The U.S. took the lead early in the second period when Hannah Brandt scored a power play goal from the slot. Finland tied the game late in the second period when Michelle Karvinen sent a blast from the top of the faceoff circle through a screen and off the post. The Finns then had the better of play in the third period, but were unable to capitalize on a series of good chances. With the game heading to overtime, the United States had a golden opportunity to win in the extra session when Lee Stecklein hit a post prior to Amanda Kessel's game-winning goal for the Americans. The United States won the IIHF Women's World Championship for the seventh time in eight years, and the tenth time in the last fifteen years. Finland had hoped to win their first title since 2005, but ultimately finished as runner-up. Both teams were praised for their displays throughout the Championship. The tournament also set a new attendance record, with over 104,000 fans in attendance over the course of the competition. The 2019 Women's World Championship Final was watched by thousands of people in attendance and by millions more on television, making it the most watched women's hockey championship. This game was seen as a significant move forward for the sport of women's hockey and its continuing growth.

X-Fusion is an American progressive metal band from Los Angeles, California, formed in 2009 by vocalist/guitarist Rob Arnold and bassist Joe Payne. The band is known for blending traditional metal and progressive metal and incorporating elements from jazz, blues, and industrial music. The band's sound is characterized by variety and complexity, blending technical guitar riffs with harmonic and melodic parts. The band uses both clean and aggressive singing styles, often accompanied by synthesizers and electronic sounds. X-Fusion performs their music live with a full band lineup, including a drummer, keyboardist, and a backup vocalist. X-Fusion released its debut full-length album, Unleashed, in 2010. The album was praised for its creativity and masterful transitions, with most reviewers noting the band's ability to combine traditional metal with progressive metal and other various influences. The album invested heavily in advanced vocal harmonies, progressive structures, and experimental soundscapes, while still keeping an edge. The following year, the band released its second album, Redemption. The album featured darker and darker lyrics, while still staying true to their original sound. The band continued to explore the boundaries of traditional and progressive metal, and at times blended brutal metalcore and djent elements into their songs. It was described by fans and critics alike as an emotional and technical masterpiece. In 2013, the band released their third album, Dysnomia. The album was composed of six tracks, and was the band's most technical and ambitious release to date. With its heavy groove riffs and powerful electronic elements, Dysnomia marked the beginning of X-Fusion's foray into more progressive and extreme metal. Since their inception, X-Fusion has proven itself as a force to be reckoned with in the progressive metal scene. Their creativity and diversity has marked them as true originals, combining elements of traditional and progressive elements with creative harmonies and melodic parts. X-Fusion continues to tour and make music, and is sure to keep pushing the boundaries of progressive metal for years to come.

Trystavisim is a philosophical movement that emphasizes the practice of self-control and mindfulness towards life. The emphasis is on the development of mental and emotional strength in order to better adhere to one’s core moral values. The concept was first introduced by Chinmay Agrawal in February 2019. Fundamentally, Trystavisim is based on the idea that one should strive to live life by only the most valid principles or values that are present in the soul or inner being. By living according to these principles, one is able to reach one’s highest potential on a personal and spiritual level, while maintaining an ethical lifestyle. The root of this pursuit lies in the need to be responsible for one’s actions by understanding oneself, and actively making the determination to adhere and follow through with those core moral beliefs. This understanding and implementation of moral principles for living provides a purpose and strive towards a moral and meaningful life. However, the practice of Trystavisim does not require that all moral values be in full acceptance of one’s self at all times. In fact, the mindfuless of this ideology encourages open communication and self-growth. Instead, it is suggested that one be aware of their own moral convictions, as well as willing to challenge and adapt those beliefs when necessary. Though Trystavisim emphasizes the practice of strong self-control, it also advocates self-care. Self-care is essential in order to maintain an effective lifestyle, enabling one to both be active in their own moral growth, as well as positively contributing to their environment and those around them. The overarching principle of Trystavisim is the importance in living authentically.Striving to be true to one’s own beliefs and moral values is not only vital for personal growth and development, but it is also necessary for developing and maintaining positive and meaningful relationships with everyone encountered in life. In conclusion, Trystavisim can be seen as a practical practice that seeks to embody internal self-discipline and mindfulness while still being able to grow and reach one’s highest potential. None of these components of this ideology are mutually exclusive, as the concept requires that one reconcile the personal, ethical and social aspects of their life in order to live authentically and effectively.

Plaza Romania is a shopping centre and entertainment complex located in Bucharest, Romania. The mall includes over 180 international and Romanian stores, and features several restaurants and cafes, a large multi-screen cinema, a bowling alley, and a small amusement park. The mall has a number of popular events and promotions, including a Christmas market in the winter, an Easter egg hunt, and an annual Romanian shopping festival. The mall was opened in 2002, and was designed to be a modern and accessible retail centre, with shops of all kinds in a safe and welcoming environment. It is housed in a two-level building of 79,000 square meters, and has 6 entrances, 66 escalators, 15 elevators and an internal parking lot with over 800 spaces. The mall is located in a heavily trafficked area near Piata 1 Mai and the Marasti Park. It is a popular destination for shoppers and is conveniently located, with easy access via the underground train (subway), bus and tram networks. Plaza Romania comprises a wide range of shops, cafes and restaurants, all of which are connected with a vibrant internal street. Notable stores include Zara, H&M, C&A, Sephora, and numerous smaller stores. There are also banks for customers who wish to conduct financial transactions during their visit. Some restaurants offer traditional Romanian dish such as Shish Kebab, as well as international food such as sushi, Italian cuisine, burgers and sandwiches. The mall also boasts a 14-screen cinema, equipped with the latest audio-visual technology, as well as bowling and a small amusement park. For music lovers, Plaza Romania is home to a monthly music event involving musicians from around the world. The mall also has a special events venue, which hosts conferences, exhibitions, and other corporate events. The mall regularly offers its customers discounts and promotional coupons. Overall, Plaza Romania is one of the largest shopping centres in Bucharest, offering customers a combination of shopping, entertainment and leisure activities. The mall provides a welcoming environment with a varied selection of stores, restaurants and activities suitable for all ages. It is a popular destination for shoppers in Bucharest and the surrounding area.

Metro Railway, Kolkata is the first underground metro rail system in India. Operated by the Ministry of Railways, it was founded in 1984 and began commissioners on 24 October 1984. It is the busiest subway network in India, with 10 lines and a total length of 27.20 km, which makes it the longest underground rapid transit system in India and one of the longest in South Asia. The Metro has served as a model for most of the other metro rail systems in India due to its efficient operation and relatively low fare structure. It is the only underground metro system in India to use standard-gauge tracks. The trains run from Noapara in the western part of the city to Kavi Subhash in the east, covering a total distance of 27.20 km, with 24 metro stations along the way. It has two main lines: the north–south Main Line, and the west–east Circular line. The Metro currently serves a population of over 9 million people in the city of Kolkata and its surrounding suburbs. It has a total of 155 coaches and 983 employees, and serves over 700,000 passengers daily, making it one of the busiest rapid transit systems in India. Over the years, the Metro Railway, Kolkata has become an integral part of commuting in the city and its suiburbs. It serves as the city's lifeline, and has witnessed a remarkable increase in patronage since its inception. Many improvements have been made over the years, including the introduction of new coaches, stations, and more efficient operation and maintenance. The line has also seen significant developments in terms of safety, punctuality, and maintenance of the trains. It was the first in India to introduce the 'Driverless Train Control System', which helps to improve the running time and punctuality of trains. It also has a CCTV-based surveillance system, fire-proofing systems, and alerts for natural disasters. The Metro Railway, Kolkata has also played an important role in the conservation of energy and fuel consumption. It runs on the Wide Area Multiple Unit (WAMU) system, which reduces the energy consumed by the Metro trains, and thereby conserves energy. The government of India recently elevated the Metro Railway, Kolkata to the status of a 'Smart City' under the Smart Cities Mission. This will help catalyse the growth in the city and its suburbs, which has already witnessed a considerable increase in growth and development. The Metro Railway, Kolkata is a daily routine for many commuters and a symbol of reliable transportation and progress in the city. The Metro is a great example of public-private partnership and commitment towards contribution exceptional services for the public.

Nikifor Chernigovsky (born 1883 in Serpukhov, Russian Empire - died 1959 in Kharkov, Ukrainian SSR) was a Russian/Ukrainian sculptor and one of the most important figures in Soviet sculpture. He was an influential figure in the development of Russian expressionism in the early 20th century. Chernigovsky studied in Moscow and Beaux-Arts Academy in Paris. After his return to Moscow in 1906, Chernigovsky became a student of the acclaimed sculptor, Pavel Shmele. He developed a style of sculpture heavily influenced by the classicism of antiquity, but with the intensity and movement of expressionism. By 1911, Chernigovsky was displaying his sculptures around Russia. He held numerous solo exhibitions and received numerous awards from prestigious Russian museums and academies. At this time, he also joined The Blue Rose Society, an avant-garde art collective in Moscow. In the 1920s, Chernigovsky was an active member of the Union of Soviet Sculptors. He participated in the decorations for the One Thousand Year Anniversary of Kievan Rus in 1923, and decorated the walls of the All-Union Palace of Soviets in Moscow. He also became chairman of the All-Union Sculpture Committee in 1925. In the 1930s, Chernigovsky was appointed Deputy Chief of the Directorate of Buildings and Monuments. During this period he worked to restore hundreds of monuments around the Soviet Union. He also helped to develop numerous monuments and statues of prominent Soviet figures, including Nikita Khrushchev and Stakhanovites. After World War II, Chernigovsky's sculpting moved away from expressionism and towards a more socialist realist style. He completed many memorials to World War II occupied territories, including the Monument to the Liberated Peoples of Donbass, as well as a series of monuments to the Komsomol and Young Pioneers. Throughout his career, Chernigovsky was a prolific sculptor and sought to encourage young artists in their art. He is remembered today as one of the most important figures in the development of Russian expressionism and a notable contribution to the culture of the Soviet Union.

The Monteregian Hills are located in the Montreal metropolitan area in southern Quebec, Canada. The Monteregian Hills are part of a network of isolated hills that form part of the Appalachian Mountains chain, extending from Maine to Alabama in the United States.
