The name “Monteregian” is derived from the local populace in the region who commonly referred to the area as “Haut-Montréal” (High Montreal) in the eighteenth century. It was initially used in the nineteenth century to refer to a district within the City of Montreal but gradually came to mean the hilly area surrounding the city. The Monteregian Hills comprise several distinct mountains in the region. These are Mont Royal, Mount Saint-Bruno, Shefford Mountain, Mont Yamaska, Mont Saint-Hilaire, Mont Saint-Grégoire and Mont Rougemont. Each of these mountains rises several hundred feet above the surrounding city, with Mont Royal and Mount Saint-Bruno reaching heights of over 1,000 feet above sea level. These mountains are composed primarily of limestone, shale, sandstone and basalt. They form part of the Notre Dame Mountains and form the western limit of the St. Lawrence Lowlands. The hilly terrain has resulted in the formation of a number of deep valleys and inter-valley ridges throughout the region, giving the hills their characteristic aspect. Apart from providing a picturesque backdrop to the City of Montreal and its surrounding towns, these hills also offer numerous recreational opportunities. Ski-dooing and snowshoeing are popular winter activities on Mont Royal and Mount Saint-Bruno, while summer months bring hiking, climbing and the annual Monteregian Hills Race. The Mont Saint-Hilaire Biosphere Reserve and numerous nature trails, such as the Mount Odanah Trail, provide ample opportunities for nature lovers to explore the natural beauty of the hills. The Monteregian Hills form an important part of the geography of Montreal and its surrounding area. They have become increasingly popular as destination of recreational pursuits in recent years, while providing a much-needed refuge from the hustle and bustle of city life.

Computer America is an American radio talk show based in Dallas, Texas that covers topics in technology. It airs Monday through Friday nights from 8:00-10:00 pm on several radio stations across the United States. The show is hosted by Gurdeep and David Moolten and covers both the personal computer and corporate IT sectors with interviews of company CEOs, software & hardware reviews, and discussion of the latest news in technology. Computer America was founded in 1997 by Gurdeep and David Moolten. The show was initially a local radio show based in Dallas, but due to its popularity and the increasing demand for information on technology, it was soon picked up by national distribution. Computer America places strong emphasis on compatibility. Its presenters and guests have a variety of knowledge and experience, allowing for a comprehensive discussion of different technologies. Topics range from market trends, to new inventions, to software and hardware reviews, to interviews with industry luminaries. Guests of the show have included Larry Ellison of Oracle, Bill Gates of Microsoft, and Mark Cuban of HDNet. Computer America is known for its lack of advertising. It prides itself on reliable yet entertaining information that is not swayed by marketing or advertising tactics. Regular segments of the show include Tech News, Podcast Picks, and Gadget of the Week. The show has also been instrumental in educating business owners and the general public on the complexities of computer security. Computer America focuses on staying informed and up-to-date on the ever-changing technology landscape. In addition to interviews and reviews, the show also organizes competitions and special events with the goal of exposing listeners to new products and software. Reviews of new products are also conducted by experts to provide an unbiased assessment of the so-called new-gen technology. Computer America is considered an established part of the IT industry and is regularly consulted for expert advice. It has been featured in such publications as The Wall Street Journal and CIO Magazine, as well as having been featured as part of the TED speaker series. It also has been recognized with awards from PC Magazine, Radio & Records Magazine, and Microsoft. Computer America has become a ‘voice in the tech industry’ and is cited regularly by national newspapers, magazines, and television news programs. Listeners span multiple generations and are technology veterans, novice users, and the everyday consumer. The show has a devoted following on social media, with lively conversations about topics discussed on the show taking place online.

Saccopharynx lavenbergi is a species of deep sea eel, belonging to the family Saccopharyngidae. This species is found in the tropical and subtropical waters of the Indian and western Pacific oceans, from Sri Lanka to the Philippines, and from southern Japan to the Great Barrier Reef. It is often found near coral reefs, at depths of between 35 and 400 metres. S. lavenbergi has a slender body, with an elongated snout and large eyes. It is silver-gray in colour, and grows to an average length of 7 to 10 cm. It has an upturned mouth and is able to consume items such as jellyfish, squid and small crustaceans. The reproductive biology of S. lavenbergi is poorly known, but it is thought to spawn annually and disperse the eggs into the ocean. Mature adults reach sexual maturity at 4.5 to 5 cm in length. Eggs have been located at depths of 1027 metres. S. lavenbergi is frequently caught as bycatch by various fishing operations, although it has no marketed value. Management measures have been taken to reduce the number of S. lavenbergi caught in fishing nets, such as the use of turtle excluder devices and bycatch mitigation nets. The IUCN has listed S. lavenbergi as Data Deficient, due to inadequate knowledge of the species’ reproductive rate, population trends and threats to its survival. The species is also discussed in the international scientific literature. The research and scholarly studies conducted on S. lavenbergi provide a glimpse into the lives of these deep sea eels.

The White Angel (2007) is a drama film directed by Marco Risi, starring Luca Argentero, Claudio Santamaria, Emanuela Folliero, Caterina Sylos Labini, and William Di Giulio. Produced by Vito Ciccarelli, Andrea Zaccariello and Maurizio Tedesco, the film won the Gauden Trophy for Best Cultural Data Film at the Shanghai International Film Festival in 2008. Set in a small village in Northern Italy, the film follows 15-year-old Ettore (Argentero) who, following his older brother's death, is sent to live with his uncle Ruggero (Santamaria) with the responsibility of running the family's automobile workshop. Struggling with his new identity as the eldest son, Ettore soon discovers he is not alone in his feelings of having lost his parents and brother. Francesca (Folliero), a mysterious woman who moves into the village and begins working at the family's shop, captures Ettore's attention and is the source of much gossip within the tight-knit town. When Ettore learns from Ruggero that Francesca is his father's illegitimate daughter, Ettore's opinion of her and her lifestyle drastically changes. As Francesca soon reveals she needs money to back her ambition of becoming an athlete, Ettore's attraction towards her is rekindled and he commits to helping her achieve her dream and providing her with the funds necessary. Through their relationship, Ettore and Francesca are able to find hope and happiness in their personal challenges and the shared smiles they exchange. The captivating performances by the cast, especially Argentero and Folliero, successfully bring a frequently-told story to life. The White Angel conveys its themes of loss and redemption with a passion that leaves viewers with a lingering feeling of hope and renewal.

Amaury Vassili (born 3 March 1990) is a French tenor and singer. He rose to fame in 2009 after winning the third season of the French show N'oubliez pas les paroles and the sixth season of Stars Academy France. Vassili was born in Herouville-Saint-Clair near Caen, France in 1990. He began music lessons at the age of seven, learning to play guitar and piano. He started by covering English rock bands, such as Led Zeppelin, Red Hot Chili Peppers and AC/DC. Vassili went on to study jazz, reggae, Latino and other musical styles. In March 2009, he appeared on the French series N'oubliez pas les paroles on France 3, where he won the competition. Later that year, in December he was cast in the sixth season of the French show Stars Academy which aired on NRJ 12, and won the competition in April 2010. Vassili began his professional music career in 2011, when he released his first album, Viens chanter, which peaked at No. 5 in France and at No. 6 in Belgium. His second album, Showtime, was released in 2012 and reached No. 4 in France and No. 5 in Belgium. It was certified Platinum in France and Belgium. His third album, Mon Histoire, released in 2013, peaked at No. 1 in France and Belgium, and reached Gold and Platinum certifications respectively. Vassili has toured internationally and performed in countries such as the United States, Canada, Mexico, South Korea, China, Japan and Taiwan. He has collaborated with renowned figures in the music industry, such as Quincy Jones, Wyclef Jean, Anggun and Diane Warren. In 2017, Vassili released his fourth album, Vive, which reached No. 2 in France and No. 3 in Belgium. Notably, it featured singles, "T'es belle," "Una Mano," and "Je T'aimais Je T'aime et Je T'aimerai". Vassili has collaborated with many non-profit organizations, such as UNICEF. He is an advocate for animal welfare and is particularly active in rescuing neglected and abused animals. Vassili continues to pursue his musical career and is respected as a tenor, professional performer, and recording artist.

The Southampton Blitz was the bombing of the English port city of Southampton during World War II by the German Air Force (Luftwaffe). The blitz began on the night of 23 November 1940, and continued for a total of three days and two nights. The attack was part of the Luftwaffe's strategic bombing campaign over Britain, known as the Battle of Britain. This attack was part of a Luftwaffe plan to destroy Britain's war production factories in the major port cities. Southampton was an important strategic target due to its role as a major naval supply base and a centre for aircraft production. In addition, it was an important docking point for the motorized landing craft used in the invasion of Europe. The initial attack on Southampton began with a series of wave raids lasting several hours. German aircraft dropped incendiary bombs, fracturing water mains, and destroying millions of pounds worth of property. On the first day alone, over 800 people were killed and 8,000 properties were destroyed or damaged. In response to the Blitz, the British government established many food ration programs to help the citizens of Southampton cope. On 29 December 1940, the Southampton Blitz Relief Fund was established to compensate those who had lost their homes or businesses. In addition to the monetary contributions from the British government, the citizens of Southampton also launched their own initiatives. The local newspaper, the Southampton Times, ran a campaign for donations. A "Gift week" was held in January 1941, during which local churches and businesses encouraged citizens to donate money and goods to their neighbours affected by the bombing. Despite all the efforts of the British government and citizens of Southampton, the casualties resulting from the Blitz were devastating. 1,655 were killed and 2,935 were seriously injured. Additionally, 150,000 people were left homeless. The last significant raid occurred on the night of 3 May 1941, when the Luftwaffe launched a heavy attack on the city. After that night, there were only smaller scale, sporadic raids on Southampton, the bombings of which resulted in comparatively fewer casualties. The effects of the Southampton Blitz have been long felt by the citizens and remain visible even today in the bombed-out buildings and neighbourhoods. However, it is widely acknowledged that the city's response to the attack, both in terms of their aid programs and the spirit of volunteers who pitched in to help, showed great civic duty and commendable resilience.

Birlinn (Old Norse Byrlind, pronounced [byr-lin]; modern Gaelic Beirlinn) was a type of wooden ship in use in Scotland and Ireland during the Middle Ages, from the Early Middle Ages to the late 17th century. The generic term Birlinn encompassed several different types of vessels, including large cargo ships and smaller boats used for raiding, trade, or transport. The birlinn was designed as a large, multi-masted, open decked vessel with a large square rigged sail and oars for navigation in shallow waters. Its design varied between regions and over time, but it was built with a single, central mast and a square sail, a shallow draught, and was able to navigate in shallow waters due to its clinker-built construction style. By the early 16th century, birlinns were primarily made with four masts and were larger than any other wooden ship in Scotland or Ireland. Due to birlinns being constructed on land, instead of in the water, the offshore winds could be used for sails instead of relying on oars. Consequently, birlinns could travel faster and longer distances than other vessels of their age. The names birlinn and beirlinn were also used to refer to an Irish and Hebridean galley, respectively. This type of vessel was of a slightly different construction, with the central mast often being replaced by two masts and an increased sail capacity. These galley-type birlinns were used for warfare and were likely exchanged between the Gaelic kingdoms of Ireland and Scotland. They were renowned for their speed and manoeuvrability, which allowed them to outrun any other vessel they encountered. The birlinn featured prominently in medieval stories and literature of the period. It was also used in many archaeological excavations, most of which date back to the late 12th and early 13th centuries. For example, a birlinn was recovered in 2010 from Ardnamurchan Bay in Scotland. The vessel, which was likely built between 1150 and 1250, was the oldest ever found and provides valuable information on the design and construction of birlinns during this period. The birlinn has played an important role in the culture of both Scotland and Ireland, and was even used by Robert the Bruce during the Scottish Wars of Independence in the late 13th and early 14th centuries. Today, modern reconstructions are being built of the historic birlinn and can still be found in many parts of the country. Sources https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birlinn https://www.historicenvironment.scot/archives-and-research/publications/publication/?publicationId=205f9d80-7a08-4f82-ab12-a3d600e7b802 http://www.beru.org.uk/birlinns/ https://www.prehistoricwales.org/services/ancient-boats-submarines/the-birlinn-its-ancestry-and-descendants/

Scott Perry (born October 27, 1962) is an American politician for the Republican Party, who serves as the United States Representative for Pennsylvania's 10th congressional district. Early life and career Perry was born in Butler, Pennsylvania, and grew up in the nearby town of Newville. He attended the United States Military Academy, graduating in 1984 with a degree in engineering. Perry was commissioned as a Second Lieutenant in the United States Army and served in Iraq. After his service, he entered private business and eventually settling into his current business endeavors in real estate in Penn Township. Political career Perry first ran for public office in 2006, when he was elected to the Pennsylvania House of Representatives in the 92nd legislative district. In 2012, Perry successfully ran for the United States House of Representatives in Pennsylvania’s 4th congressional district. During his time as representative, he served on the House Armed Services Committee and the House Homeland Security Committee. In 2018, under Pennsylvania’s redistricting, Perry took on a congressional bid in Pennsylvania’s 10th congressional district and was successful. Legislative positions Perry has taken a staunchly conservative stance on a number of issues, including taxes and immigration. He demonstrated strong support for the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, emphasising that “cutting taxes for individuals and businesses alike encourages economic growth and job creation.” Perry is also a strong supporter of US veterans, having planned and supported progressive public policies to benefit the community. He has advocated for increased spending to expedite the claims process, better ensure adequate access to healthcare and even made veterans-specific changes to the Republican Tax Package. On immigration, Perry has been a vocal advocate of Trump’s immigration policies and frequently taken the floor of Congress to express his opposition to any kind of amnesty or pathway to lawful status sought. Personal life Perry and his wife, Colleen, have three children - Scott Jr., Alec, and Annie. Scott and Colleen reside in Carroll Township, York County.

HSC Volcán de Tagoro is a Ro-Ro cargo ferry owned and operated by shipping company Naviera Armas S.A. of Las Palmas, Canary Islands, Spain. The vessel was built in 2009 at Gondán Shipyards in Castropol, Spain and is the largest Ro-Ro cargo ferry in Spain. HSC Volcán de Tagoro has the overall length of 205.50 m (673 ft 7 in), moulded beam of 27.10 m (88 ft 7 in) and maximum navigational draught of 7.00 m (22 ft 11 in). The maximum vehicle carrying capacity of the ferry is estimated at 1,500 lane metres (1,000 cars). Cargo capacity is estimated at 1,680 metres for containers and 250 for rolling goods. There are 6 decks for cargo aboard the ferry and it has a total of 765 berths. The main engines of the Volcán de Tagoro are four Wärtsilä 12V26C, each producing 11.902 kW of power at 500 RPM. Auxiliary engines are three Wärtsilä 12V26 and two Wärtsilä 6L20 generating 1.426 kW each. The total installed power for the propulsion is approximately 75.300 kW, which gives the ferry a maximum speed of up to 21.2 knots. The suspension system on HSC Volcán de Tagorol consists of four main turbines with lengths ranging from 8m-9.8m They have a speed range of 600-1000 r/min, a total power output of 25,000 kW, and a total torque of 750,000 Nm. The turbines are manufactured by RENK based in Germany. Volcán de Tagoro was the first vessel in the Spanish ferry segment to combine modern technology and functionality. It provides speedy travel between the Canary Islands and the mainland, including Madeira and the Balearic Islands. Naviera Armas launched the Volcán de Tagoro in 2009 and has been using this vessel as the primary flagship for their inter-island ferry service since then. The ferry makes weekly trips between Las Palmas, Gran Canaria and Cadiz, plus bi-weekly trips to the port of Barcelona. The ship also sails weekly between Las Palmas and Arrecife, Lanzarote. Additionally, it sails to Tenerife, Palma de Mallorca, Valencia and other mainland destinations. Since its launch, HSC Volcán de Tagoro has made many successful voyages and has become an integral part of Naviera Armas' fleet. The ship has also won awards and accolades for its excellent services, including being declared ‘Best Spanish Ro-Ro Ship’ in 2012 by Lloyds Register of Shipping. The Volcán de Tagoro is one of the largest and most influential vessels in the Spanish ferry-market, and it has been essential in establishing Naviera Armas as the leading ferry company in the Canary Islands.

Maria Ho (born March 6, 1983) is a Taiwanese-American professional poker player and television personality. She is one of the most successful female poker players in the world, having placed third in the 2007 World Series of Poker Main Event and later cashing numerous times in the World Series of Poker and World Poker Tour (WPT). Ho has been involved in poker since age 21, and her popularity has grown in recent years due to her strong results in major televised poker events and her weekly co-hosting spot on the web-based poker show Poker Night Live. Despite her relative youth in the poker world, Ho has quickly become one of the most recognizable faces in the poker world, and has received praise from both her peers and the poker media alike. Ho has done extremely well on the live poker circuit, having cashed in the World Series of Poker (WSOP) 14 times and the World Poker Tour (WPT) 11 times. She first cashed in the 2007 WSOP Main Event, coming in 3rd place and taking home $4,122,764; she was the highest placing female finisher in that event and the highest placing female poker player in a major tournament to date. In 2008, Ho signed on with UB.com and have served as a spokesperson and "lifestyle ambassador" for the site since then. In addition to making numerous television appearances as part of her UB.com endorsement deal, Ho was also featured on the cover of the June 2008 UB.com VIP magazine. Ho’s media duties have extended beyond the poker world, as she has appeared on multiple game shows such as the Price is Right and The Price is Right Million Dollar Spectacular. She has also been featured on the E! Network show Sunset Tan and the Food Network's Chopped. Ho is currently the Tournament Director for the WPT, and regularly travels the world for WPT events. In 2013, she co-founded Feel The Game Entertainment, a company that provides poker and gaming entertainment services. She currently lives in Los Angeles, California and often travels around the U.S. to play in various tournaments. Ho entered the 2013 National Heads-Up Poker Championship and finished in ninth place, becoming the first Female National Heads-Up Poker Champion in history. Currently, Ho has total lifetime live tournament winnings of $5,404,719. She currently has the 2nd highest lifetime winnings of any female poker player, and is the most successful female in tournaments, having had more success in big buy-in poker tournaments than any other female in history.

Breakfast in Bed (Grimm) is an episode of Grimm, an American supernatural drama series on NBC. The episode aired on October 7, 2015, and was written by Thomas Ian Griffith and was directed by Peter Werner. The episode centers around Nick and Hank's investigation into a mysterious sleeping sickness which causes its victims to die in their sleep. Hank and Nick go to the trailer of Penelope’s aunt, where they meet a Wessen suspect and find out about the Heiden Drei, a potion meant to guard people against the sleeping sickness. They also find out that Penelope is afflicted with the disease. After discovering the family heirloom meant to guard against the curse, Nick and Hank search for Monroe and Rosalee, who have the kit to make the antidote. With the help from Adalind and Trubel, they make the antidote and Penelope is saved. Meanwhile, Wu is brought in to investigate multiple discoveries of dead men in their bathtubs with no signs of violence. An old German pen-pal of Wu's is brought in to help solve the mystery of the deaths. In the climax of the episode, Nick and Hank break into the man's home, discovering he is the type of Wesen they were looking for. However, Wu and his pen-pal discover the man is using breakfast in bed as his way of killing his victims. The episode ends with Nick and Hank returning to the precinct, where they find out that Wu's pen-pal has gone missing. Breakfast in Bed (Grimm) proved to be a fan favorite amongst audiences, receiving positive reviews from critics. The episode is widely considered to be one of the strongest episodes from the fifth season of the series. Overall, Breakfast in Bed (Grimm) was a pivotal episode in the fifth season of Grimm, and is held in high regard by fans of the show. The episode’s unique structure, interesting story, and creative twist has helped it remain popular amongst fans for years.

Collins House is a historic home located at Mount Gilead, in Montgomery County, North Carolina. It was built in 1834 and is a two-story, four bay, frame dwelling. It features a T-shaped plan and Swiss-style shallow roof. The house was built for Captain James Collins, a veteran of the War of 1812 and a planter. It is an example of the type of architecture used in a rural area in the early 19th century. The house has Greek Revival details and a two-story portico with six square columns, with each column supporting a round arch. Windows are three-dimensional (also known as "raised") frames. The interior has original woodwork, including chair rails, beaded wainscotting, and doors with unique Greek Revival–style moldings. Collins House was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1974. It is significant as a Rustic Greek Revival–style dwelling with distinctive embellishments, and is reflective of the area's economic and social history. It also serves as a reminder of early 19th century rural domestic architecture. The house was restored extensively in the early 2000s. In 2003, a two-story frame addition was built at the back of the property as part of a renovation project. The renovation was intended to create a bed and breakfast to attract visitors to the Mount Gilead area. The property also includes one outbuilding and a family cemetery, both of which were also older than the house. The outbuilding was constructed around 1820 and added to the National Register in 1999. Collins House is a rural example of the Greek Revival–style of architecture, and is a reminder of the area’s history. The property is still a private residence and the care taken by its owners over the years has kept the house and grounds intact, preserving the unique beauty of the home and maintaining its significance as an important part of local history.

Goodfellas (soundtrack) is the soundrack for the influential crime classic, Goodfellas. Released in 1990, the original motion picture soundtrack for Martin Scorsese’s iconic film featured some of the most memorable music from the period as well as several new recordings by some of the biggest stars of the day. Directed by Martin Scorsese, the classic film follows the life and times of a mobster in the mafia underworld of the 20th century American Northeast. The Goodfellas soundtrack predominantly features rock, jazz and blues recordings by some of the pioneers of the genres. The main title theme “Layla” is the classic, slow blues-tinged rock song initially performed by Derek and the Dominos in 1970. The song was later recorded as an extended acoustic version by Eric Clapton for the soundtrack and contains a classic guitar solo. Behind its slow groove, the song became a background to the life of wiseguy Henry Hill and his journey through the New York mafia. The song earned a Grammy Award for Best Rock Song in 1992. The soundtrack also includes more traditional jazz recordings such as the theme for the character Tommy DeVito (played by Joe Pesci) composed by the big band score of Rascal's “I Got a Woman”. Other selections from the album include songs from Dean Martin, Jimmy Roselli and Bobby Vinton as well as more modern music from The Chiffons, Aretha Franklin and Eric B. & Rakim, which contribute to the mix of eras in the soundtrack. Two previously unreleased tracks on the soundtrack were also written for the film. “Stardust” by Artie Shaw and “The Rainbow And Mrs. Jones” originally featuring Ray Charles and written by Quincy Jones. In addition, Scorsese included one of his own scores written exclusively for the film, this being “Forget It”. Overall, the Goodfellas soundtrack offers a mix of classic and modern recordings that accurately recreate the feel of the classic mobster film. The use of classic tunes as well as original soundtrack pieces, as well as the modern tracks brings a certain melodic poignancy to the film while also illustrating the differences in eras throughout the story. The soundtrack was nominated for an Academy Award in 1991 and was also awarded a Grammy for Best Score Written for a Motion Picture.

Countess Palatine Dorothea of Simmern (1641 - 1702) was a German noblewoman of the Palatine line House of Simmern and wife of Frederick V of the Palatinate, King of Bohemia. she was born on 27 June 1641 in Heidelberg, a territory of the Electoral Palatinate, as the fifth child of Count Johann VII of Simmern and Elisabeth Juliane of Nassau-Dillenburg. After the death of her father in 1673, her brother, Johann VIII, succeeded him in the County of Simmern. In 1680, Dorothea married Frederick V of the Palatinate, the Winter King of Bohemia. Their marriage was arranged by Dorothea's relative, William III of England, in an effort to strengthen his alliance with the House of Wittelsbach, of which the Palatinate line in Bavaria was a part. During their life together, Dorothea and Frederick were renowned in Europe for their hospitality. An example of this hospitality was the offering of refuge to French Huguenots (Protestant refugees) fleeing persecution from Louis XIV of France in the 1680s. The Palatinate Court was considered to have one of the best court orchestras in Europe of that time, and their musical activities were particularly encouraged by Dorothea. Under her patronage, the Palatinate Court witnessed the emergence of many Baroque composers. The couples' political involvement began in 1685 with the uprising of the Protestant Estates in support of Frederick's claim to the throne of Bohemia. However, their efforts were unsuccessful and their forces were ultimately defeated at the Battle of White Mountain. Frederick and Dorothea's involvement in the Protestant uprising caused them to receive severe criticism from the Habsburgs and Pope Innocent XI, especially after it became known that they had plotted to ally with the French and Italian princes. In the face of this pressure, Frederick and Dorothea were forced to flee their homeland for The Hague in the Dutch Republic in 1690. There, Frederick acted as a representative for his son, Charles Louis. At the Hague, the couple's finances spiralled out of control as they descended into poverty. Frederick V died in 1699, and was succeeded by his son Charles Louis. Dorothea, however, remained in the Netherlands until her death in 1702. She was buried in the Protestant Reformed Church in The Hague. Dorothea of Simmern is remembered as a talented and independent woman who defied convention and was an exemplary patron of the arts. She is an important figure in the history of the Palatinate and is immortalised in the names of the Palatinate Dorothea citizens' association and the Dorothea Dorotheenstadt, the former centre of the Palatinate in Berlin.

Alan Menken (born July 22, 1949) is an American composer, songwriter and record producer. He is one of the most successful film and Broadway music writers of all time and is best known for his Academy Award-winning music from films such as The Little Mermaid, Beauty and the Beast, Aladdin, Pocahontas, and Tangled. Raised in New York City, Menken studied piano and composition at New York University and was a lead singer and songwriter for a band called Flying Pickets. He later joined the BMI Lehman Engel Musical Theatre Workshop, where he developed the musicals God bless us everyone and Two by Two. In the 1980s, Menken began working with Disney, composing scores for films such as Beauty and the Beast, The Little Mermaid, and Aladdin. His songs have become standards, including Beauty and the Beast's "Beauty and the Beast", Aladdin's "A Whole New World", and The Little Mermaid's "Under the Sea". Menken won Best Music, Original Song Oscars for all three films. Menken also contributed to Broadway musicals such as Little Shop of Horrors, A Christmas Carol, Sister Act, and Newsies. For these works, he was inducted into the Songwriter's Hall of Fame in 2011. In addition to his stage and film works, Menken has composed for television and released several solo albums, including 1994's The Music of Alan Menken. He also created music for theme parks and video games, wrote the score for the award-winning documentary Waiting for "Superman", and composed the score for the Broadway show Shrek the Musical. As of 2020, Menken has been nominated for 11 Oscars and won 8. In 1997, he was named a Disney Legend. He currently serves on the Board of Directors of the Dramatists Guild of America.

Land-sale overage, also known as residuals or the unearned balance, is the amount of money left over after a land sale has been completed. It is the difference between the original purchase price of the land and the amount actually paid. For example, if a parcel of land was purchased for $100,000 and the total amount paid was only $95,000, the $5,000 difference is the land-sale overage. The concept of land-sale overage is most associated with real estate transactions, but can also be applied to other types of land transactions. For instance, a government may set aside a certain amount of land for public access or conservation purposes in exchange for a lower purchase price. In this case, the land-sale overage is the difference between the original purchase price and the reduced amount. Land-sale overage can be the result of a number of different things. It may be the result of a negotiation between the buyer and the seller, or a government providing incentives or subsidies to reduce the asking price of the land. It may also be due to the tax structure of the local area or the availability of various grants and loans. Whatever the cause, land-sale overage can lead to substantial profits for the landowner. One way landowners may use land-sale overage is to buy additional land nearby. If a landowner is able to purchase land at below market value and then use the overage to purchase nearby land, the landowner can often profit significantly. In some cases, the newly purchased land can be sold for a substantially higher price than was paid for the original parcel. This significant increase in value can result in a significant increase in profits for the landowner. Land-sale overage is a topic that has been studied by economists and other researchers. Studies have shown that in areas where land-sale overage is common, the rate of land use has increased and property values have grown significantly. This is because the additional money from the remaining overage has been invested back into the community, resulting in a greater number of infrastructure projects, improved public services, and increased employment opportunities. In conclusion, land-sale overage is an important concept in real estate transactions. It can result in substantial profits for landowners, increased land use and property values, and improved economic activity in local areas. As a result, it is an important factor to consider when purchasing land or participating in a land-sale transaction.

The Italian Trade Agency is a non-profit organization that acts as the official representation of Italian businesses in the international markets. It is promoted by the Italian Ministries of Economic Development and Foreign Affairs and is part of the Italian Institute for Foreign Trade (ICE), a national agency of the Ministry of Economic Development. The Italian Trade Agency was founded in Rome in 1963 as a result of the reform of the Italian Institute for Foreign Trade. The founding decree defined the Agency’s mission to “promote and support the internationalization processes of Italian companies by providing information and assistance”. The Agency’s main offices are located in Rome while it operates additional branch offices in the major Italian cities, in Italy’s most important export markets, and in representative offices abroad. The Agency’s services are grouped into five main areas of activity: market research, international promotion, direct assistance to companies, training and financing. The Agency has a network of over 4,000 partners across the world and 44 foreign branches, enabling it to provide assistance to Italian businesses of all sizes. It coordinates and sponsors the participation of Italian companies at international trade fairs and organizes initiatives such as business roundtables, expositions, joint ventures and promotion campaigns. The Italian Trade Agency is composed of a Board of Directors, chaired by the Minister of Economic Development, a Statutory Commission also composed of representatives of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, a Managing Director, a Scientific Committee and a general secretariat. The Agency also has an Advisory Council composed of academics, entrepreneurs and representatives of related public organizations and associations, helping to ensure that advice and assistance provided to companies is in line with the latest trends in international markets. The Italian Trade Agency plays an important role in the development of strong economic ties between Italy and countries around the world. Its services and initiatives can help Italian businesses to identify new business opportunities, establish and develop strategic partnerships, innovate and promote their products and services, penetrate international markets and increase their competitiveness.

Outlaw is a term used to refer to an individual who lives in a state of disregard for the law. It can also refer to a person or group of persons who have been excluded from the protection of the law. The term can apply to both criminal activity and to civil disobedience that challenges laws or customs. Throughout history, legislation and common usage has categorized people as outlaws for various reasons, including being declared enemies of the state, disregarding customs, or breaking unjust laws. In the early periods of history, outlaws were viewed as criminals who lived beyond the law and had no legal protection or recourse from their actions. In ancient Mesopotamia and the Middle Eastern nations, the term "outlaw" was sometimes used to refer to a person under sentence of death for certain crimes. Outlaws were believed to have been barred from seeking redress for grievances, or from attending court or gathering for group activities due to their declaration as enemies of the state. In feudal societies, when kings and other rulers wielded total power and control, the concept of outlawry was used as a tool to control the population. Outlaws were declared enemies of the state and were ceremoniously and forcibly removed from their villages and tribes. They were often branded as criminals, robbers, or thieves and were often subjected to cruel punishments as a way to keep the rest of the population in line. In some cases, particularly during the period of the Wild West, outlaws were seen as folk heroes. These individuals often went against the grain of society and gained notoriety for their exceptional skills, fearlessness, and defiance against tyranny. Today, the term outlaw is still used in certain contexts, such as organized crime or for political dissidents, but has generally come to refer to any individual or group who are considered to be outside of, or rebellious against, the laws of society. In popular culture, the term outlaw has come to also refer to those who flout the law or traditional norms for their own personal gain or sense of justice. Outlaws are typically portrayed as rebels or renegades who challenge the status quo and rebel against the norms of society, or uphold their own individual code of morality or justice.

Parsa (also spelled Parso; Sanskrit: पर्सो) is a renowned ancient culture and civilization of the Central Himalayan region, spanning India, Nepal and Tibet. The region is known as "Parso-Nepal", as well as the "Parso Kingdom". Parsa is the land where Soma, the famous drink of the Vedic Aryans, was derived from the wild herb of might which grew abundantly in the area. The region enjoys a rich historical presence, even being mentioned in the Rig Veda of ancient India. Historically, the Parsa region was a vital center of trade between the Ancient Indian, Nepalese and Chinese empires. The Parsa region is inhabited by the Magar, Gurung, and Thakuri people, who have lived in the area for several generations. The modern Parsa people are the descendants of the ancient Parsa people. They speak their own Parso language, which is a dialect of Newar that belongs to the Sino-Tibetan family. It is spoken in the Parsa District of Nepal, as well as in a number of small pockets in North India. The region has been continuously inhabited for thousands of years and has a strong cultural identity and a distinct ethnic identity. There are a number of Hindu religious sites in the Parsa region and numerous historical monuments that serve as evidence to its rich history and ancient culture. The Parsa culture is also known for its distinctive and beautiful art forms, as well as various types of musical instruments from the region. The art pieces and sculptures are typically done in a fusion of the traditional Hindu, Buddhist and Tantric styles, giving them a unique look and feel. The traditional instruments and music of the Parsa culture can be listed out to include a wide array of drums, flutes, harps, and fiddles, each of which have their own regional variations. Additionally, the Parsa culture is known for its unique culinary specialties. The region is especially famous for its Dumplings, Paratha, and the unique Newari Thali Mi. The Parsa region is also home to some of the best herbal medicinal preparations. The Parsa culture is a unique cultural gem of the Himalayan region and should be appreciated for its rich history, complex culture, and unique art forms and music. It should be celebrated and explored to the fullest as it provides an opportunity to better understand the heritage of the Central Himalayan region.

Ivory carved tusk depicting Buddha life stories is a 19th century ivory carving of Southeast Asian origin which depicts the life of the Siddhārtha Gautama, the Buddha. The tusk is made of ivory and has been intricately carved in a cylindrical form. It measures approximately one meter in length and is believed to have originated from either Burma or Thailand. The tusk shows a richly detailed narrative of the Buddha's life and is completely covered in classic Buddhist imagery. It is divided into 12 sequential segments, each carved with intricate detailing intended for educational purposes, to tell the stories of the Buddha. The first segment shows Siddhārtha's father's garden where he was born, and there are also depictions of his mother's dream, as well as his renunciation of luxury and his ascetic lifestyle. The next segment is dedicated to the Temptation by Mara, followed by the incidents that took place before the Enlightenment, His departure from the palace, teaching the four noble truths, debating with Brāhmin philosophers, and the first sermon at Sarnath. The last segment is the death, cremation, and top view of the burning pyre of the ancient Indian sages, which represents the beginning of Buddhism. This culminates in a representation of Bodh Gaya, where Siddhārtha achieved enlightenment, and is carved in incredible detail. The ivory tusk is the product of highly skilled craftsmanship and the refinement of a rare and expensive material. It is a valuable part of Buddhist artwork and provides a unique insight into the teachings of the Buddha. The ivory tusk is currently on display at the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco, California.

Omaha, Arkansas is a small unincorporated community in Washington County, Arkansas. Omaha is located on U.S. Route 71 approximately six miles north of Fayetteville. The community is accessible from Arkansas Highway 45, which intersects with U.S. Route 71 within the town limits. It is part of the Fayetteville–Springdale–Rogers metropolitan area, one of the fastest-growing metropolitan areas in the United States. The town is named after the Omaha Indians, the original inhabitants of the area, and it was one of the earliest settled areas in the region. In 1858, the first post office opened in Omaha. At the time, the community was part of Ozark County, which included parts of present-day Washington, Madison and Franklin counties. According to the 2010 U.S. Census, the population of Omaha is 397. The town has a post office, as well as a volunteer fire department and a Community Church. There are also three schools in town, two public schools and a private school. In addition, Omaha is home to a Baptist church and a Catholic church. Omaha is a small rural community with a tight-knit community of neighbors. There are several small businesses located in the town and nearby, including a convenience store, a hardware store, a cafe and a gas station. The town is known for its rustic beauty, and is a popular area for hunting and other outdoor activities. It is also located close to popular tourist attractions, such as Devil's Den State Park, Beaver Lake and the Ozark National Forest. Overall, Omaha is a quiet and peaceful community in Northwest Arkansas. It is a great place to raise a family, enjoy nature, and experience small-town living.

The 2021 FIBA Women's AmeriCup is the 22nd edition of the FIBA Women's AmeriCup, the international basketball tournament for women in the Americas organized by FIBA. The competition will take place from the 11th to the 20th of June in Puerto Rico. This edition of the tournament is the first being held since the 2017 edition. The tournament will be contested by 10 national teams from the FIBA Americas zone: Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Puerto Rico, Dominican Republic, Mexico, United States and Venezuela. It is the first time that all 10 countries have taken part in the Women's AmeriCup since 2001. The format of the tournament is a round-robin tournament with each team playing the other nine teams once. The top four teams will qualify for the semi-finals and then the winner of the semi-finals will play in the gold medal match. In July 2020, FIBA Americas officially confirmed the host of this tournament, Puerto Rico. This is the second time that the tournament is held in Puerto Rico, the last one being in 1993. The tournament is organized in partnership with the Puerto Rican Basketball Federation (FPB). This edition is highly important for the federation because the last event held in Puerto Rico was the 2017 FIBA U18 Americas Championship. This event has three different levels of awards: MVP, Second Team, and FIBA Americas All Star Team. The 2021 edition of the FIBA Women's AmeriCup is also considered as a qualifying tournament for the 2022 FIBA Women's World Cup, with the top four teams qualifying for the world cup. This tournament is expected to be the most prestigious basketball event of the year in the Americas and it will feature some of the best players in the region. All teams are expected to be very competitive and it will most likely be a very interesting tournament. This event brings the FIBA Americas family together in one place and contributes to the growth of basketball in the continent. This year will be special because after four years the tournament returns to shine, with the best teams in the Americas, who will compete for the title of the champion of the 2021 FIBA Women's AmeriCup.

'Fără cuvinte' (pronounced Farrow Coo-vin-tay) is a Romanian phrase meaning "without words." It is a phrase used to describe a situation that is too complex or overwhelming to put into words. The phrase captures a kind of experience, or emotion, that is too big and too important to be expressed in words. The phrase is often used when speaking of love, pain, or loss. It can also be used to describe how one feels when faced with an obstacle that cannot be overcome, or a feeling of sudden clarity in understanding a situation. In some cases, the phrase may be used to describe a moment of joy or serenity that cannot be put into words. The phrase was popularized in the early 2000s by the Romanian band Fără cuvinte. The band released several songs and albums that featured the phrase in the lyrics and the title. The band's music explored many of the themes associated with the phrase and helped to spread the phrase's popularity. The phrase has grown to have a wide range of uses in Romania, where it is often used to describe a range of emotions, from intense sorrow to tranquil happiness. It is also often used to describe a sudden feeling of understanding, or when a problem cannot be solved. Outside of Romania, the phrase is not as commonly known and has yet to gain widespread recognition. Fără cuvinte has been translated into English variously as "too deep for words," "beyond expression," or simply "without words." While the phrase is likely to remain a specific part of Romanian culture, its meaning and uses are easily transferable to many other cultures as well. The phrase is a reminder that there is often more to experience and feel than can be simply put into words.

Nicky Oppenheimer (born June 8, 1945) is a South African businessman and philanthropist. He is one of the wealthiest people in Africa, and the former chairman of De Beers and its former parent company, the Anglo American Corporation. Oppenheimer was born in Johannesburg, South Africa, to a Jewish family that had a long history in the diamond trade. His father, Sir Ernest Oppenheimer, was a noted business leader who accumulated a large fortune through shrewd ownership of the De Beers diamond company. Nicky Oppenheimer attended Harrow School in London, and later studied philosophy at Oxford University. Oppenheimer began his career in the diamond business shortly after graduating from Oxford in 1967. He became deputy chairman of De Beers in 1984, succeeding his father as chairman in 1998. After two decades at the helm of De Beers, he retired in 2012 and was then appointed deputy chairman of Anglo American. In 2017, he retired from the board of Anglo American and sold his shares to Anglo American. Oppenheimer is a prominent figure in African philanthropy. He established the Oppenheimer Memorial Trust in 2004 to provide educational and medical assistance to communities in Southern Africa. This trust has since grown to include numerous non-profit organizations in areas such as health, education and conservation. He is also the co-founder and chair of The Peace Parks Foundation, which promotes peace, conservation and sustainable development in Africa’s trans-boundary park regions. On top of this, Oppenheimer serves on numerous high-profile boards including the Rockefeller Foundation and the Brookings Institution. Furthermore, he serves as an active patron of the arts in South Africa. In 2012, Oppenheimer was awarded an honorary Doctorate from the University of Cape Town, and in 2016 he was inducted into the International Academy of Business and Public Policy at the University of South Africa. Oppenheimer currently lives in Johannesburg, South Africa with his wife, Debbie Oppenheimer. They have three children. Oppenheimer is regarded as a consummate African statesman and corporate leader. He is an advocate for economic development, peace and stability in Africa, and for the improvement of South African Businesses.

The Rostock-Lichtenhagen riots occurred from 22–24 August 1992 in the Lichtenhagen district of East Germany's Baltic Sea city of Rostock, and were the most serious civil unrest in East Germany since the 1953 East German Uprising. During the event, a mob of right-wing extremists and neo-Nazis attacked a building complex housing asylum seekers and set parts of it on fire. The events sparked widespread public debate and condemnation in Germany, leading to nationwide protests and criticism of the government's handling of the situation. The riots, described as a "pogrom" and "Kristallnacht" by some commentators, were triggered by a dispute between German locals and new immigration. Over the previous months, a wave of xenophobia had risen in the Rostock area, due in part to controversial statements about refugees from local politicians. On the afternoon of 22 August, around 200 people, many of them members of the neo-Nazi scene from other parts of Germany, gathered outside the building complex in the Lompower Ring neighborhood of Lichtenhagen. Many shouted racist epithets aimed at foreigners, and soon began throwing stones and other objects at the building. The police, caught unprepared for the mob, stood by as the building was set on fire and damaged, although some of the officers threw stones at the residents. By the evening, the crowd grew to over 1,000 people, and at times blocked firefighters from putting out the blaze, forcing local firefighters to wait for reinforcements from other parts of the state. As the violence continued, an additional 2,400 police and railway police were deployed to the area. In response to the crowd's actions, some 200 to 300 counter-protestors arrived to try to defend the building from the mob. The violence lasted until around midnight on 24 August, when the police regained control of the area after negotiations. Despite the efforts of the police to stop the rioting, more than 200 people were injured and several buildings and cars were set on fire. As a result of the events, the city of Rostock suffered considerable damage to its public image and relations with its immigrant community. In the aftermath of the riots, the government was criticized by both German and international officials for its failure to prevent the violence, while East German authorities were accused of not providing sufficient security to the asylum seekers. In response, both the local and national government pledged to take action to improve the situation. In 1993, the Bundestag passed a package of asylum-law reforms, including measures to speed up asylum procedures and improve the legal protection of asylum seekers, as a result of the protests. In the years that followed, a number of official efforts to address the underlying issues behind the riots have been initiated, including integration policies and forums for dialog between immigrants and local community members. In August 2012, the 20th anniversary of the riots was marked by a memorial service and conferences to commemorate the events and discuss their legacy.

Daedalus Reef is a natural reef formation located off of the eastern edge of Andros Island in the Bahamas. It is known as one of the best dive sites in the Caribbean. Named after the mythical figure, the reef has lagoons, canyons and a blue hole filled with vibrant coral and an abundance of marine life. The reef is a favorite with divers of all levels since it has plenty of opportunities for exploration. At Daedalus Reef, the average depth is about 60 feet, with walls of over 6,000 feet that drop down to the abyss. The topography of the reef varies from jagged rocks to gently rolling slopes filled with crevices and overhangs. Many of the crevices offer shelter for nurse sharks, moray eels, sea turtles and colorful reef fish. Visitors to the reef can expect to find a wide variety of sea creatures swimming amidst the hard and soft coral formations. Large colonies of glass sponges, sea fans, whips and other cnidarians are common sights. It is also a popular spot for manta ray sightings, as well as dolphin experiences. The water at Daedalus Reef is a crystal clear blue, making it the perfect place to take pictures of the fish, corals, and other aquatic life. The reefs are colorful and vibrant, consisting of a wide range of coral, sea slugs, anemones and other invertebrates. It is also an excellent nursery for juvenile species such as grouper, barracuda and snapper. Daedalus Reef is not just for diving, however. It is also a popular destination for snorkelers, kayakers and boaters, as the area offers calm, sheltered waters and stunning scenery. The best time to visit is usually from June through November, as this is when the water temperatures are most pleasant and visibility is at its highest. Daedalus Reef has long been known as one of the top dive spots in the Caribbean and is sure to provide an unforgettable experience for anyone who visits the area. With so much to explore and discover, it is no wonder why this reef is a favorite among divers and snorkelers alike.

Grown Up is a 2021 American coming-of-age comedy film directed by newcomer Aseem Bajaj. The film stars Sofia Black-D'Elia, Tyler Young, Richa Chadda, Juno Temple, and Omar Sy and follows the story of four young adults coming of age in Los Angeles. The film follows their journey of love, loss, friendship and hardship that ultimately helps them mature into adulthood. The film centers around four college students, Brooke (played by Sofia Black-D'Elia), Ethan (Tyler Young), Madison (Richa Chadda) and Eli (Omar Sy). They spend their days partying, going to clubs and drinking, but when the effects of their irresponsible behavior starts to catch up with them, they make a pact to turn their lives around. The core cast is supported by appearances from Juno Temple, Pantelis Mits Konidi, Brian Dennehy, Bruce Davison and Omar Sy. Fleasing to the group's surprise, they each realize they have more in common than they first thought: forgiveness and understanding, strength and companionship. However, they also quickly understand that changing their lives and behaviors will not be easy. The plot follows the friends’ journey as each confronts the hard choices they have made in life and strives to do the right thing. As they attempt to find balance between their Hollywood ambitions and finding their identities, they begin to understand what it means to be a grown up. Grown Up takes a heartfelt, humorous and ultimately inspiring look at the complications of growing up in the world of instant gratification. It mines the often painful but valuable lessons of independence, responsibility and resilience gained through the highs and lows of this journey. The film had its world premiere at the 2021 Bentonville Film Festival. The film received generally positive reviews from critics, who praised the lead performances and its exploration of growing up. This movie provides a compelling and entertaining journey of self-discovery. Grown Up shows us that growing up is often full of challenges, but ultimately it can be a beautiful thing.

Phacium is a genus of small, single-celled organisms that belong to the Rotosphaeraceae family. These organisms are found in both freshwater and marine environments, and they feed on bacteria and other organic matter. The genus is composed of two species, Phacium marinum and Phacium ventricosum. Phacium marinum is a species of spherical to oval cells that range in size from 3 to 6 microns in diameter. This species is found in marine habitats, particularly neritic and estuarine waters where it is able to attach to other substrates. These cells get their nutrients from a cross-section of bacteria, diatoms and organic material. The cells will often stay in one area if the bacterial substrate is abundant. Phacium ventricosum is a species of irregularly-shaped cells that range from 5 to 10 microns in size. This species is found predominately in fresh water environments where it feeds on a mix of organic matter and bacteria. The cells attach to various substrates in an upright position and will travel within the water using pseudopods. The Phacium genus does not reproduce sexually. Instead, reproduction is asexual through a process called binary fission. This process involves the splitting of the cell wall in the middle, resulting in two identical cells. Phacium has been studied in a variety of research purposes. Scientists have looked at the genus as part of research into the biogeochemical cycling of nutrients within bodies of water, as well as in the study of the effects of environmental stressors on microbial life. Due to their abundance in bodies of water, Phacium is a very important part of the microbial food web, and is essential to the functioning of aquatic ecosystems. In conclusion, Phacium is a genus of single-celled organisms found in both freshwater and marine habitats. There are two species within the genus, which reproduce asexually through the process of binary fission. These organisms play an important role in the microbial food web and the overall health of aquatic ecosystems.

The Battle of Yongsan (1900) was an important battle of the Korean War which took place during the siege of Yongsan, a strategic port city near the southern end of Incheon Harbor on the west coast of Korea. The battle was fought between Japanese Imperial Army forces under the command of General Uyemon (Miyamoto) Masaharu, and Korean forces commanded by Kim Jwa-jin. The siege of Yongsan began on June 6, 1900, when the Japanese forces attacked the city. The Korean forces, under General Kim, had taken a strong defensive position in the city and were able to repel the Japanese attack with relative ease. However, the Japanese forces eventually managed to break through the Korean defenses and take control of the city. The Korean forces then set up a counter attack, launching a series of surprise raids against the Japanese forces in order to gain an advantage. These raids proved to be successful as they managed to regain several positions in the city. The Battle of Yongsan then transformed into a stalemate, with both sides entrenched in positions around the city. This months-long siege of Yongsan ended with a decisive victory for the Korean forces. On August 9, 1900, the Korean forces launched a surprise attack against the Japanese forces and were able to take the city and force the Japanese to retreat. The victory at Yongsan marked an important turning point in the Korean War, showing that the Korean forces were capable of successfully defending their country against foreign invasion. The Battle of Yongsan was significant as it was the first successful defensive battle fought by the Korean forces. Furthermore, it helped establish the Korean forces as a formidable opponent and as a result showed that Korea was capable of defending itself against foreign aggression. The Battle of Yongsan also had an impact on politics, as it raised the question of international intervention in Korea and the legitimacy of Japanese rule in Korea. In addition, the Battle of Yongsan helped to highlight the importance of Korea’s unique cultural and political identity and furthered the move to establish Korea as a unified and independent nation. Following the battle, a peace agreement was signed between the two sides on August 22, 1900. The Treaty of Taft-Katsura resulted in a ceasefire and an official end to the Korean War. The Battle of Yongsan was an important victory which resulted in the establishment of a unified and independent Korea.

Peter Banfield (born June 2, 1980) is an entrepreneur and investor. He is the founder and CEO of MarketWeave, an online market intelligence and analytics platform. Banfield was born and raised in Las Vegas, Nevada. He attended University of Nevada, Las Vegas, where he studied Business Management and Computer Science before transferring to Oregon State University, where he graduated in 2002, with a Bachelor's degree in Business Information Systems. After his studies, Banfield moved to the San Francisco Bay Area and worked in various roles in the software industry, including engineering and product management. In 2007, Banfield founded MarketWeave, a company focused on helping businesses understand their competitive landscape and make more informed decisions. By leveraging its proprietary market intelligence and analytics platform, MarketWeave helps companies keep track of the latest trends and market conditions while also providing a comprehensive look at their competitors. Since launching, MarketWeave has become a trusted data partner for some of the world's leading brands and companies in sectors such as retail, technology, automotive, entertainment and finance. In addition to his role at MarketWeave, Banfield is a sought-after speaker on industry trends and technology. He has been invited to speak at numerous international conferences and events, such as Dreamforce and Shop.org, as well as on television programs and podcasts. Outside of his career, Banfield is a mentor for startups through Silicon Valley-based accelerator, Metamorphosis. He is also an avid traveler, having visited countries across the globe throughout his personal and professional life. Overall, Peter Banfield is a successful entrepreneur and investor who has a passion for technology and innovation. His work at MarketWeave is a testament to his vision, skills, and commitment to helping companies gain a deeper understanding of the ever-changing market landscape.

Berzosertib is an investigational medicine in the class of compounds known as ATR Kinase Inhibitors. Its principal mechanism of action is to inhibit the activity of ATM-dependent protein kinases, which are involved in DNA damage signalling and the responses to such damage. Berzosertib was developed by Array BioPharma and is undergoing clinical trials as a potential treatment for advanced solid tumor cancers such as non-small cell lung cancer and castration-resistant prostate cancer. Berzosertib is a small-molecule, orally administered therapy with impressive activity in several solid tumor indications, including lung and prostate cancer. It has shown to be well-tolerated and has a good absorption profile. It works to inhibit the enzyme ATR kinase from its active conformation, preventing the signal transduction of DNA damage and triggering downstream DNA repair pathways. In this way, it targets major defense mechanisms of cancer cells and promotes cell death. Berzosertib is currently in Phase II trials for several tumor types including non-small cell lung cancer, castration-resistant prostate cancer, bladder cancer, biliary tract cancer and gall bladder cancer. Results from the Phase II clinical trials seem to be promising, showing that the combination of berzosertib and chemotherapy was able to reduce tumor size in advanced non-small cell lung cancer capably while being well-tolerated. In patients with castration-resistant prostate cancer, berzosertib in combination with androgen deprivation therapy appeared to reduce tumor load in a statistically significant manner when compared to patients who were given androgen deprivation therapy alone. Additionally, results suggest a potential benefit of berzosertib over chemotherapy-based treatments. Berzosertib appears to be a promising drug candidate for the treatment of various solid tumor cancers. Its principal mechanism of action targeting ATR kinase has shown to be effective in killing cancer cells, and the drug is well-tolerated. Thus, Berzosertib may have the potential to become the treatment of choice for many advanced solid tumor cancers in the near future. Further clinical trials are needed to evaluate its safety and efficacy beyond the initial phase trials and to determine its utility for other cancer types.

Pamela J. Powers (born 1976) is an American musician and composer known for her work writing and arranging music for film, television, and video games. Powers studied music and composition at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro and has since become one of the most accomplished and in-demand composers in the industry. Powers began her career composing music for short films, and later moved on to larger projects such as television series, feature films, and documentaries. Some of her works include the Emmy-nominated music for the Fox drama series 24, the music for the sci-fi series Dark Angel, and for the psychological horror film The Lady in White. Powers also composed the score for Epic Mickey 2: The Power of Two, released in 2012 and received critical acclaim for her work. In addition to film and television, Powers has composed music for several video games, such as Tron: Evolution and Disney INFINITY. Powers was awarded an MPSE Golden Reel Award in 2013, along with several other accolades, including the Hollywood Music and Media Award in 2017 and the ASCAP Film and Television Music Award in 2018. She is currently composing music for the ABC drama series Scandal, and is also the score supervisor for the video game Onward. In 2019, Powers released her debut album, The Touch of Death, which was well-received by critics. Powers is a self-professed “geek” and loves being surrounded by technology. She is known for incorporating analog, digital, and modern synthesizers into her music, and is always looking for ways to innovate and push the boundaries of her craft. Powers’ work has been described as having a “dark edge and a strong sense of atmosphere” and reviewers have praised her for her ability to capture the emotion of a scene.Although Powers is relatively new to the music industry, her works have already been featured on networks such as FX, ABC, and FOX, and her music has also been featured in commercials and trailers. She is an inspiration to aspiring musicians and composers, and her deep passion for innovation and exploration of new soundscapes has earned her a reputation as an exciting new voice in the industry.

Ekhymosis was a Colombian rock band formed in 1987 by Juanes and Andrés "Special-K" García in Medellín. Their musical style is a mix of rock, Latin rhythms and acoustic ballads, which is characteristic of the "paisa" culture of Colombia. The band made a great deal of impact with their debut album Si Supieras, released in 1992. The record featured the group's greatest hit, the title track "Si Supieras", which is a passionate acoustic rock ballad and remains one of the most influential songs of Colombian rock. The video for the song was also popular, and thrust Ekhymosis into the forefront of the Colombian music scene. The band's follow-up album Dilema, released in 1994, secured their place as one of the best rock bands in Colombia. The album contained hits like "Baja de Peso", "Mientras yo Respire" and "De Pie en el Suelo", and further solidified Ekhymosis' signature style of blending rock, Latin rhythms and acoustic ballads. Due to the somewhat unorthodox structure formed by the need to use a great deal of electricity with the additional complexity of being a Galician-shaped filter, the band had difficulty finding venues in which to perform, especially in Colombia. However, they found popularity in alternative music festivals and produced some incredible concert moments. In 1998, Juanes left the band to pursue a solo career. Ekhymosis continued to work afterwards with the remaining members, but never achieved the same level of popularity. Andres moved to Barcelona and formed a new group, Delta de Ekhymosis, which remained active until 2011. Despite their disbandment, Ekhymosis has remained an influential cult favorite in the alternative music scene in Colombia. Their music has been covered by various bands, including Calle 13, Los Amigos Invisibles, and Ruben Blades. Their influence can also be heard in the music of Latin American alternative musicians including Santana, Juan Luis Guerra, and Manu Chao.

Sophie Moniotte (b. August 5th, 1982) is a Belgian archer and Olympic champion. She is considered one of the best archers of all-time, having medalled in several World Championships and winning gold at the 2012 London Olympics. Moniotte took up archery in 2003, and quickly established herself as one of the top archers in Belgium. In 2008, she won a bronze medal in the individual recurve event at the World Archery Championships held in Antalya, Turkey. This qualified her for the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, where she placed 5th in the same event. In 2010, she medalled again, this time winning a silver medal at the World Championships in Kodaira, Japan. In 2011, Moniotte was part of the Belgian team which won the bronze medal at the European Championships in Bucharest, Romania. The following year, she won the gold medal in the individual recurve event at the 2012 London Olympics. This made her Belgium’s first ever Olympic champion in an archery event, as well as the first Belgian woman to win an individual gold medal in the Summer Olympics. Moniotte has continued to make waves in Olympic-level archery, most recently winning another bronze medal at the 2014 World Championships in Lausanne, Switzerland. She was also part of the Belgian team which won the bronze medal at the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Moniotte has also had success at the European Championships, having won bronze in 2013, gold in 2014, and silver in 2016. In addition to winning major events, she has also placed in numerous other international competitions. Off the course, Moniotte serves as a coach for young archers in her home country. She is also an ambassador for the sport, and is a regular speaker at archery tournaments and other events. Moniotte is widely recognized as one of the best archers in history, her accomplishments cementing her legacy in the sport. She continues to strive to make a difference in archery, and her reputation as a world-class athlete grows with each tournament she enters.

Cienfuegos is a Cuban League baseball club founded in 1922 as one of two teams from the city of Cienfuegos. According to Osvaldo Hernández’s Baseball in Cuba, Cienfuegos were the winners of the 1919 championship, and the team is considered to be one of the oldest and most successful teams in Cuban professional baseball. Cienfuegos were the most successful team in Cuban League history during the period 1934-1952, winning six national championships and three Caribbean Series titles. After the second Cuban team, Industriales, began playing in 1953, Cienfuegos and Industriales began what is widely recognized as the greatest rivalry in Cuban baseball history. Since then the two teams have gone head-to-head over 105 times, with Cienfuegos statistically holding the lead in wins. Aside from their success in the Cuban League, Cienfuegos has been a prominent presence in international competition. The team represented Cuba in the 1981 Intercontinental Cup, taking home a Bronze Medal finish, and sent two members to the 1985 Intercontinental Cup in Italy, as members of the Cuban National Team. Cienfuegos underwent significant changes in the 1990s, starting with the 1996-97 baseball season, when the club left the city of Cienfuegos and moved to Havana, becoming a de facto team of the Industriales. This move was simply the result of the collapse of the Cuban economy, which resulted in a lack of finances for the existing teams in the Cuban League. Today Cienfuegos is a part of the Cuban National Series baseball league, playing as a home team located in the Marianao neighborhood of Havana. The team is still referred to as the "Elefantes de Cienfuegos" (Elephants of Cienfuegos), and they are still amongst the most successful teams in the Cuban League. The team has won two Cuban League championships (1998-99 and 2006-07) and two Caribbean World Series titles (2009 and 2011). Cienfuegos remains one of the most historic teams in Cuban baseball. Despite several decades of up and down periods, the "Elefantes" have always been one of the most successful teams in professional Cuban baseball. Over the years, the club has produced many great players, such as Antonio Muñoz, René Arocha and Orlando Hernández. Thus, Cienfuegos will be remembered as one of the most important teams in Cuban baseball history.

Timo Ochs (born 1982/1983) is a German-born soccer player, who currently plays for FC Gifhorn and has experience in the German Bundesliga and 2. Bundesliga divisions. Born in Wiesbaden, Germany, Ochs began his youth career with German side SV Wehen Wiesbaden, where he emerged as an offensive-minded striker, before joining the Mainz 05 youth setup. After making two appearances with Mainz 05's II squad in the 2. Bundesliga, Ochs was transferred to 1. FC Union Berlin and made 13 total appearances in the 1. Bundesliga during the 2004/2005 season. He then spent the next season with Eintracht Braunschweig of the 2. Bundesliga, notching 1 goal in 21 total appearances. He left German football in 2007 and signed with Montreal Impact of the USL First Division, making 31 appearances and scoring 5 goals during the 2007 season. Ochs then returned to Germany the following season, signing with 3. Liga side Sportfreunde Siegen and making 33 appearances during the 2008/2009 season. After a brief return to Montreal Impact in 2009, he eventually returned to German football, signing with Rot Weiss Ahlen and playing for them for two seasons in the 3. Liga and 2. Bundesliga divisions. Ochs left Rot Weiss Ahlen after the 2012 season and since then has played for Preußen Münster and VfB Lübeck before signing with current team, FC Gifhorn in the fall of 2019. In addition to his club play, Ochs has accumulated vast international experience, playing on numerous teams with the LASK Linz, FC Vaduz, FC Wacker Innsbruck, and VfB Oldenburg. During his career, Ochs has won awards such as the 3. Liga Top Scorer award in the 2008/2009 season and was an All-Stars selection member of the 2007 USL First Division. He has also been described as a "versatile player" who can play several positions at midfield. Since turning professional in 2004, Ochs has earned a reputation for being a consistent contributor for whichever team he is a part of, making at least 20 appearances in each subsequent season since the beginning of his career. He currently resides in the city of Gifhorn.

Spirit of the Boogie is a single by Kool & the Gang released on June 22, 1975. The midtempo funk-pop song was an immediate hit, reaching number four on the US Billboard Hot 100, while also topping the R&B chart. The single was originally featured on the album Spirit of the Boogie (1975). The song's lyrics were composed by Ronald Bell and Kool & the Gang with its music composed by the full band. Its lyrics proclaim the will to "boogie down and have some fun." Early pressings of the single incorrectly listed the songwriter credit as "R. Kyle" instead of "R. Bell". The song was the second major hit single by Kool & the Gang, following the chart-topping "Jungle Boogie". It reached the top ten in various countries worldwide, including the group's native United States and the UK where it peaked at number nine. It was also the group's highest charting song in Australia, where it peaked at number two. The song was also Kool & the Gang's first to feature keyboardist Claydes Smith and also the first of their numerous international smash singles, paving the way for later classics such as "Celebration", "Get Down On It", "Cherish" and "Fresh". The single earned Kool & the Gang their first Grammy nomination, receiving a nod for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals at the 18th Grammy Awards (1975). The song was additionally certified Gold by the RIAA and remains a timeless classic. In 2020, the song was inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame. Kool & the Gang also performed "Spirit of the Boogie" at the 58th Annual Grammy Awards in February 2016 as part of a medley with fellow nominees Nile Rodgers and Pharrell Williams. The song has been covered multiple times, including by Macy Gray and her Backup Band (2001) and Japanese pop singer Chisato Moritaka (2006). It remains one of Kool & the Gang's signature songs and a popular staple of funk, soul and R&B compilations to this day.

Lucien Louis Daniel (July 18, 1846 - February 21, 1917) was a French lawyer, law professor, politician and newspaperman who was an important figure in the French Parliament in the years before World War I. He was a notable person in the forefront of nationalist arguments against German aggression.
