Daniel was born in the commune of Vincennes in Val-d'Oise, which was then part of the Île-de-France région of France. His parents were peasants, but he was able to attend the École des Mines in Paris, and eventually the Faculty of Law at the University of Paris. After law school, he worked in the office of the prefect of the Seine department. In 1879, he entered the French Parliament as a representative of the Val-d'Oise, and he soon established a reputation as an orator. He was also appointed professor of private international law at the University of Paris in 1889. Daniel used his position as a representative of the Chamber of Deputies to campaign for international peace and the preservation of French national security. His most famous achievement was justifying France in joining the Russo-Japanese War in 1905. On repeated occasions, he opposed German bills which were detrimental to French interests. This earned him the nickname of the 'French Gladstone', in reference to the famous British politician William Ewart Gladstone. He was also a strong advocate for colonization and argued for the expansion of French influence in Africa, Asia and Latin America. During World War I, he rallied to the cause of freedom and championed the Entente against Germany. He was a notable figure in the negotiations for the Treaty of Versailles and he served as a master of ceremonies for the official peace parade afterwards. In addition to his political career, Daniel was a noted newspaper man and the author of several books on French law and politics. He was made a member of the Legion d'Honneur for his services to the country in 1906, and he received the honorary title of President of the French Republic in 1912. Lucien Louis Daniel died in Paris on February 21, 1917, at the age of 71. He was buried in the Père Lachaise cemetery in Paris, and his grave is still visited by admirers. He is remembered as an important figure in modern French history, and his legacy continues in France today.

Matthew Arrandale (born October 10, 1997) is an American entrepreneur and venture capitalist with a focus on emerging tech. He was born and raised in San Jose, California and attended Stanford University, where he graduated with a degree in Management Science & Engineering. In 2020, Arrandale founded his venture capital firm, Arrandale Capital Management, which focuses on early-stage investments in high-growth tech and healthcare sectors, with particular expertise in artificial intelligence. Arrandale Capital Management has invested in a variety of companies which include Kionix, a healthcare robotics company, Anvaya, an agriculture-tech startup, and Academia.edu, an online community for researchers. The firm also boasts a strong track record of investing in a combination of seed-stage rounds, venture capital rounds and follow-on investments. Prior to founding Arrandale Capital Management, Matthew was a partner at 500 Startups accelerator program and worked as an advisor for multiple technology companies. He was also the CEO of NearU, a secure mobile payments solution for small businesses. As CEO, Matthew oversaw the development of the technology platform and successfully scaled the company. Matthew Arrandale is a recognized thought leader in the financial technology industry, and he regularly writes in-depth articles from complex financial topics for various publications. In 2018, the World Economic Forum recognized Arrandale as a Technology Pioneer, a distinction awarded to individuals whose work is pioneering advances in technology that have the potential to significantly shift industry paradigms and benefit society. He is also a passionate philanthropist, and he participates frequently in technology and entrepreneurship initiatives, including speaking at multiple universities and mentoring startup founders. In addition to his career, Matthew Arrandale is a passionate traveler, and when he is not in the office he can usually be found taking road trips or exploring the beauty of the outdoors. He also enjoys reading, writing, and skiing during his free time.

Boneland is an English language novel published in 2003, written by British author Alan Garner. A sequel to his 1968 novella The Owl Service, Boneland blends mythology and rural fantasy in pursuit of an abstract concept, while at the same time exploring the themes of loss and self-discovery. Set in Cheshire, England, where the author's family has lived for many hundreds of years, Boneland is the second book in the Mabinogion Tetralogy, the final book in a quartet of fantasy novels which includes The Owl Service (1967), The Stone Book Quartet (1976), and Strandloper (1996). The novel centers around Colin, a man in his mid-thirties who has been suffering from some form of mental disorder and has been hospitalized for most of his adult life. While in care he experiences brief periods of lucidity, and is able to recall fragments from his seemingly paleolithic past. He is given experimental drugs and through a process of trial and error he is eventually able to remember his name, the fact that he lives in Cheshire, and discovers that his past is inextricably linked with the ancient rituals of a forgotten religion. The narrative continues as Colin attempts to piece together his past and searches for a path to redemption. The book contains references to various forms of folklore and mythology, particularly of the local Cheshire area, as well as frequent mentions of Pagan and Christian cosmology, particularly concerning the four 'elements'. Garner deliberately explores the nature of how the naming of the elements affects not only the narrative, but the reader's experience of the story itself; he states that the title of the novel is another word for 'earth'. Boneland has been well received by critics and readers alike, praised for its imaginative use of language, its explorations of the theme of loss and its sense of power and beauty derived from its rural setting. It has been described as 'exquisite, unique and captivating' with a 'power over the boundaries of life, death and infancy'. The novel has been adapted for the stage, a reading of the play touring the Edinburgh fringe in 2009. A sequel to the novel, set during Colin's childhood, has been announced by Garner. Boneland has been compared to Garner's earlier works, though it has often been seen as a more mature and ambitious. It is a testament to Garner's understanding of English mythology, magic and rural folklore, but also a work of modern fantasy, exploring themes of identity and alienation. It has become a cult classic and its influence on the British fantasy genre is lasting, as it was praised for its evocative nature and use of abstract storytelling.

Willow River is a city in Pine County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 632 at the 2010 census. The city is located along the Fish Hook River, which flows into the Willow River. The city's name is derived from the river. The area of Willow River was first settled by European immigrants in the late 1800's. The most popular industry was logging as the area was densely wooded. In 1909, a post office was established, and the village grew as more people moved to the area. In 1897, an independent school district was created to provide schooling for the children of the area. Willow River is located at the intersection of U.S. Route 63 and state highway 35. The city is near several wildlife refuges in the area, such as Moosehorn National Wildlife Refuge and Sand Lake National Wildlife Refuge. There are also several marinas on the nearby Willow River. The city has a clamming dock, a boat ramp and a fish cleaning station. There is also a small museum, the Willow River Railroad Depot Museum, and a nature center, the Pine County Nature Center. The city of Willow River has a unique look that is typical of small towns in Minnesota. Many of the buildings in the downtown area have been restored magnificently, giving it a charming feel. There are many parks around the city, including Haraldsons Park, which has a playground and picnic area, and Riverside Park, which features ball fields and picnic areas. Willow River is considered a gateway city for the Chippewa National Forest, which is located nearby. The forest is a great place to camp and fish, and there are many hiking trails. The forest is a popular destination for hunting whitetail deer and other animals. The forest is also home to a great variety of birds and wildflowers. Willow River is a great place to visit for anyone looking for a peaceful, rural community. Whether you are looking for peace and quiet, wildlife watching or exploring the outdoors, you will find something to do in Willow River.

László Szőgyény-Marich Sr. (1889-1961), was a Hungarian military officer, politician, and businessman who played an important role in the development of modern Hungary. Born in Čaka, Szőgyény-Marich was educated at the Military Academy in Budapest. Following his graduation in 1912, he served in the Austro-Hungarian Army where he achieved the rank of Brigadier General. After the disintegration of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, Szőgyény-Marich joined the celebrated Hungarian White Legion which was a volunteer paramilitary group defending Hungary during the Hungarian-Soviet War. For his distinguished service, he was awarded the Order of Hero of the Hungarian People’s Republic. During the inter-war period, Szőgyény-Marich was appointed as one of the five deputy ministers of defense of Hungary in 1937. In 1945, he entered politics, becoming a member of parliament for the Hungarian Democratic Union. He held this role until 1954. During this time, he was the Minister of Defence in the restructured Ministry of Defence (1948-1951) and was involved in a variety of activities such as reorganising the Hungarian Army, beginning the process of creating a defence industry, and reorganising the military medical service. Szőgyény-Marich was an advocate for modernization and reform. He was also a successful entrepreneur. During the inter-war period, he established the Szőgyény-Marich Automobile Company, which manufactured quality cars and trucks. He also invested in a variety of industries including construction, banking, insurance, and the movie industry. At the end of his life, Szőgyény-Marich wrote reflections on his service and investment activities in the book ‘Last years of an Austro-Hungarian Officer’. The book is considered a valuable resource on economic, social and political changes during this period. László Szőgyény-Marich Sr. is remembered as an important figure in both the military and business realms in Hungary. He was a pioneer in modernizing both the military and business world in post-Austro-Hungarian Hungary and his legacy continues to influence Hungary today. Cited -Komlós,Anna (2013) Old Hungarian Political Biography. -Sándor,Kazincy Szőgyény-Marich László (2011) Last years of an Austro-Hungarian Officer. -Prados, John (1993). The White Legion: Hungary’s Military Colours in the Great War, 1914-1918.

Brentford Library is a public library situated in the London Borough of Hounslow, UK. It is one of the largest libraries in the borough and also acts as a reference library, with a comprehensive collection of books, e-books, periodicals and digital media. The library opened in 1924 and underwent a major renovation and re-opening in 2011. The Brentford Library boasts a wide collection of books and periodicals, ranging from fiction to non-fiction. It has many popular children's books and the latest magazines and newspapers. Additionally, the library offers a host of digital resources, such as e-books, audio-books, and databases. The library is accessible to the local community and visitors via the Hounslow bus network, and it also offers disabled access. In addition to its reading room, the Library provides meeting space, computer workstations, Wi-Fi access, and a café. The Library is open from Monday to Friday from 9am to 8pm and on weekends from 1pm to 5.30pm. Brentford Library works closely with the local community, providing a range of activities, services and events to promote reading, writing, and creativity. These include educational demonstrations, book group discussions, art classes, music performances, author talks, workshops, and story-telling sessions. It also has a wide variety of online resources such as language learning and databases, as well as a range of creative activities, all free of charge. The Library holds an annual Summer Reading Challenge, which encourages children to read and take part in an exciting range of recommended books. It also provides free books by post to older adults, who are unable to visit the library during the pandemic. Overall, Brentford Library is a valuable resource for people of all ages and backgrounds. The library works closely with the local community, offering a wide range of resources and activities, including a comprehensive collection of books and digital media. It is an important and vibrant part of the London Borough of Hounslow, and its various services are a testament to its commitment to providing access to lifelong learning.

The Austin Armoured Car is an armored car developed by the British Austin Motor Company in the 1930s. The vehicle was designed for use by a small number of crew and was unique in that its armament could be changed from a machine gun to an anti-tank gun. It was primarily used by the British Army and was used in various theatres of war from North Africa, to the Far East. The Austin Armoured Car was developed in 1935 as a response to the expanding and increasingly troublesome polarised global powers of the time. Austin’s first model of armoured car was the AC1, which was equipped with a four-cylinder engine and two water-cooled Vickers machine guns. Soon after, an AC2 and AC2a were produced which featured the latest engines and had a range of effective armour and armament. The AC2 and AC2a were soon succeeded by the Austin MK I and MK II armoured cars. These improved vehicles featured a six-cylinder engine, revised armour and armament as well as modifications to the transmission system. The final version of the Austin Armored Car was the MK III, which had an eight-cylinder engine, increased fuel capacity and a range of anti-tank ammunition. The Austin Armoured Car and its derivatives saw extensive service in World War II and saw action during the North African, Italian and Far Eastern campaigns. The vehicle was even used to help liberate the Falkland Islands during the 1982 Falklands War. The Austin Armoured Car was eventually phased out of active military service in the mid-1960s, but the vehicles continue to be popular among collectors and military history enthusiasts. Modern replicas of the Austin Armored Car are also available for sale and can even be seen at vintage military vehicle shows. The Austin Armoured Car remains one of the most recognizable military vehicles of its era and serve as a reminder of a time of global tension and instability. While no longer serving an active role in international conflicts, the vehicle’s reputation and legacy lives on.

USS Macon (CA-132) was a United States Navy heavy cruiser, the lead ship of her class, built in Philadelphia in the early 1940s. Macon was commissioned in April 1945 and served most of her service life in the Pacific Ocean, seeing action in the Korean War. The Macon, a Baltimore-class heavy cruiser, was constructed at the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard. She was sponsored by Mrs. Rufus E. Bealle and commissioned on April 10, 1945. Following her shakedown cruise, the Macon duly joined the Pacific Fleet in June 1945. As World War II wound down, the cruiser operated in Japanese waters as part of the occupation force before steaming to the United States in December, reaching the East Coast and decommissioning in March 1946. After a period of inactivity, the Macon recommissioned in February 1951 and headed back to the Pacific, where she operated in the waters off Korea. She provided gunfire support, screened carriers and transports, and conducted sea and air rescue duties until wounded personnel and disabled aircraft limited her operations during December and January 1952. In March, the Macon returned to the United States for repairs and a refit, emerging from drydock in April and operating in the Atlantic until October. In subsequent years, the cruiser often operated in the Mediterranean Sea and off the coast of North Africa. In June 1960, the Macon was reclassified as a guided missile cruiser, while in August she sailed around South America, making port calls in Ecuador, Peru and Chile before she returned to the United States in October. April 1961 saw the Macon dock at Philadelphia to be decommissioned and then prepared for sale to the Spanish Navy, to form the nucleus of their new 'Light Cruiser' squadron. The Macon eventually left the United States in August and reached her destination on the Canary Islands in September. After being re-designated F81 and named Espana, the vessel served in the Spanish fleet until February 1986 when she was stricken and broken up for scrap. USS Macon thus completed a twenty-one year career, distinguished by an impressive array of battles and accolades; she was awarded the National Defense Service Medal with a conflict star for service during the Korean War and the United Nations Korea Medal for the same fine service. In addition, the Macon was awarded the American Campaign Medal, the World War II Victory Medal, the Navy Occupation Medal, the China Service Medal, the Armed Forces Expeditionary Medal, and the Armed Forces Service Medal. USS Macon stands as an enduring example of the bravery and skill of American naval personnel taken into battle and daringly served her country in a variety of roles until laid to rest in late 1986.

Bill Pinkney (1940-2017) was a prominent Canadian sailor who was dedicated to the furtherment of recreational and competitive sailing. He served as a Commodore of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club (RCYC) in Toronto, Canada, and an officer of the Canadian Yachting Association (CYA). Born in Port Colborne, Ontario, he enjoyed sailing from a young age and was a member of the RCYC. After a brief career as an engineer, he became increasingly focused on sailing and was a strong proponent of sailing both recreationally and competitively. He was an enthusiastic sailor and was often seen on his family yacht, the "Pure Heresy", during the summer months. He was an organizer and active competitor in many international competitions, such as the Canada's Cup and the Admiral’s Cup. In recognition of his accomplishments in this field, he was inducted into the Canadian Sailing Hall of Fame in 2008. In addition to his contributions in the sailing world, Bill Pinkney was also a philanthropist and dedicated supporter of the RCYC and CYA. He was a driving force behind the creation of the RCYC's ‘Millennium Fund’, an initiative designed to assist young sailors in the pursuit of their dreams. Through his generous donations, he played an important role in the success of this program. As a seasoned sailor, he took part in some of the world's most prestigious sailing events, including the Sydney–Hobart Yacht Race, the Newport–Bermuda Race, and the Transpac race. In 2004, he achieved the world record for the fastest monohull in an around-the-world race. He also earned numerous accolades and distinction, including the Order of Canada (2006), the Order of Ontario (2001), and an honorary doctorate from York University (2006). In the legacy of Bill Pinkney, the RCYC launched the Bill Pinkney Trophy in 2017. The annual award is presented to an exemplary member of the RCYC's senior sailing fleet. Bill Pinkney is remembered as one of the greatest sailors in Canadian history, a dedicated and passionate supporter of recreational and competitive sailing in Canada, and an example of philanthropy and community-mindedness. His contributions to the sailing world will never be forgotten.

Balmorhea State Park is a park located near the city of Balmorhea, Texas, in Reeves County and is operated by the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department (TPWD). Established in April 1968, Balmorhea State Park is a popular destination for families and nature lovers thanks to the park’s numerous recreational offerings and the community's strong ties to its cultural heritage. The major feature of Balmorhea State Park is the San Solomon Springs which produces 25 million gallons of water every day. This spring-fed pool is the largest spring-fed pool in the world and, as of 2015, it averaged a temperature of 72–76 °F (22–24 °C) year round. It covers 1.75 acres (0.71 ha) and reaches depths up to 25 feet (7.6 m). The park’s additional attractions include a nature study center and a serenity garden, as well as restroom and shower facilities and campsites. Visitors can enjoy bird watching, scuba diving, kayaking, and airboats. The public swimming pool is open year round, but hours may vary. In addition to recreational activities, the park preserves the Reeses Creek culture that is central to the community. Reeses Creek was founded in 1918 by the Chavez, Garcia and Martinez families and is considered a distinct cultural entity with its own language and customs. Immigrants from this community enlisted in the U.S. Army to fight in World War I and members of the community were critical in providing food, supplies and information during the legendary raid on the Texas Rangers during the Texas Revolution. It is one of the few Mexican American communities established before the Great Depression. Today Balmorhea State Park is a major cultural destination offering educational and interpretive programs related to the area’s history and culture. Numerous events are held there including the San Solomon Springs Festival and the Mesquite Festival. The park is open daily from 8:00am to sunset and the admission fee is $7 for adults, $5 for seniors and children 12 and under receive free admission.

Siphiwe Gloria Ndlovu (born 1989) is a Zimbabwean actress, author and philanthropist. She is best-known for her work in Zimbabwean films and television programs, such as ‘Muvhango’ and ‘Juba’. Ndlovu was born in Harare in 1989. Growing up she had a passion for music, art, writing and acting. She pursued her acting career and graduated from Zimbabwe’s Institute for the Performing Arts in 2011. In 2012, Ndlovu was awarded the Best Actress award at Zimbabwe's Campus Life Awards. She then furthered her career by winning a competition to join the ensemble cast of SABC's TV show Muvhango, playing the role of Vho-Thandaza. Ndlovu has collaborated with other television programs and movies, such as the ‘Big Brother’ spinoff, ‘The Chase’. She has also made appearances in commercials for KFC, African Banking Corporation and Delight Bread. Ndlovu has ventured into producing and writing, creating a short movie, ‘The Other Side’ and co-authoring a best selling novel ‘Let it Go’. Ndlovu is also a corporate brand ambassador for various brands, such as Etihad Airways, Remmogo Skincare and Veiled Beauty Cosmetics. In addition to her entertainment career, Ndlovu is an ambassador to various humanitarian projects in Zimbabwe, such as the Zimbabwean Children's Charity, where she spends her time visiting hospitals, schools and orphanages in Zimbabwe and other countries in the region. She has been appointed to be an ambassador to the United Nation's Water and Sanitation Program. Her talents, work and contributions to society have been recognized by various organizations, including the Zimbabwean Achievers Awards, where she was awarded the Most Inspirational Achiever of the Year for her philanthropic efforts in 2016. Ndlovu currently resides in Johannesburg, South Africa, where she concentrates on pursuing her acting and philanthropic endeavors.

Chloe Orkin (born in 1961) is a UK based artist and education specialist, whose works explore a large range of topics including the environment, education, and contemporary culture. Orkin has developed a signature approach to her art, often combining traditional techniques such as painting with digital media. As a result, much of her art has embraced a highly intricate, almost hyperreal aesthetic, incorporating a number of scientific theories, natural elements, and mental or philosophical states. Orkin has exhibited her work in various venues over the years, including the Royal Academy of Arts and the Victoria & Albert Museum in London, the Saatchi Gallery in Los Angeles and the Hayward Gallery in Singapore. Her artwork has also been featured in publications such as The Guardian, The New York Times and The Independent. In addition to her art, Orkin has also had extensive experience in the field of education. She holds a master's degree in information technology from the University of Westminster and has worked as an expert consultant in technology and teaching for the past thirty years. Additionally, she has authored numerous articles and books related to technology and education in the UK, Europe, and Asia. In 2019, Orkin was awarded the prestigious Fellowship at the Institute of Imagination and Creativity, the first ever awarded to a digital artist. This accolade was bestowed in recognition of her work, which was described as pioneering, forward-thinking and visually stunning . Orkin’s work strives to explore the intersection between tradition, natural elements, and an ever changing media landscape. As technology continues to evolve, her work continues to push the envelope and challenge audiences to critically engage with the relationship between art and technology. Through her efforts, Orkin has established herself as one of the leading voices in her field and her art is sought after the world over.

. Tacaná is a municipality located in the department of Santa Ana in El Salvador. It is crossed by the Río San Pedro from the north to the south and lies on the border between Guatemala and El Salvador. The town is known for being an important trading center due to its location and its fertile soil. Tacaná was founded in 1550 by the Spaniards and it was an important stop in the Camino Real, the route that connected the cities of the west coast in Guatemala to those of Costa Rica on the east coast. Its growth continued until the 1960s when the internal conflict in El Salvador slowed down its development. Tacaná is mainly an agricultural town, with many of its people depending on corn and beans production for their livelihood. It is also home to a large variety of fruits and vegetables, thus making it an important trading center for local farmers. There are also several factories in the area which produce cheese, ice cream, and other dairy products. The main economy of the town revolves around the production of corn and beans, and the forest industries. Most of the working population is employed in agriculture and forestry related activities. Tourism is also an important part of the economy as it has several natural attractions for visitors, such as the Maya Biosphere Reserve, the Cerro Guerrero volcano, and the Saragoza Ecological Park, amongst others. The town has several event spaces such as the Municipal Plaza for important events like Christmas celebrations and other festivities. There is also a library, a centennial plaza, and a school, making the area suitable for family fun. The municipality of Tacaná is relatively small, but it has played an important role in El Salvador's history. It has been the home of many historical figures, such as the leader of the 1876 revolution, Juan Lindo, as well as the composer of the country's national anthem, Jose Simeon Canas. Today, the people of Tacaná live a peaceful lifestyle while continuing to be an important agricultural trading center. They are also proud of the town's history and its contribution to the country of El Salvador.

The 1963 Canadian federal election was held on April 8, 1963, to elect members of the House of Commons of Canada to the 24th Parliament of Canada. The Progressive Conservative Party of Canada, under Prime Minister John Diefenbaker, had won an increased majority in the 1962 election. For the Liberals, led by Lester B. Pearson, this was their first election with their new leader. Pearson was a former cabinet minister in the Diefenbaker government. He had tried to displace the Prime Minister by using a secret alliance of Opposition members in the House of Commons in December 1961, but failed. The election results would bring about significant changes to Canada's political landscape. The Progressive Conservatives would suffer their worst defeat since their formation in 1867, and the Liberal Party would score its best result since 1945. The long Conservative majority was replaced by a Liberal minority government, followed in 1965 by a new majority government. The campaign focused largely on economics. Prime Minister Diefenbaker was critical of Pearson for proposing to implement mandatory price controls and said that it was the "most lethal weapon ever seen in economic ammunition." The debate over price and wage controls had polarized the two main parties, leaving the other parties relatively unscathed. The campaign had been thrilling for a time, but it ultimately resulted in a slight shift from Conservative to Liberal. The Progressive Conservatives retained a plurality of seats, but lacked a majority. The Liberals increased their seat total, but still finished 72 seats behind the Progressive Conservatives. In the wake of the election, Pearson's Liberal government was faced with a precarious minority. In order to gain the support of other parties, Pearson implemented tax cuts, an expansion of the Canada Pension Plan, as well as the introduction of Medicare. His government also declared Canada's Official Languages Act, making the two official languages of Canada English and French. In 1965, Pearson's government would go on to win a majority in the next election. The result of the election marked a shift away from the conservative politics of Diefenbaker and signaled a centre-left shift in Canadian politics. It was the first time since 1921 that the Liberals had won an election, and would prove to be an important milestone in Canada's modern history.

The Glomar Challenger was one of the largest and most advanced deep-sea drilling ships in the world. It was built in 1973 by the Global Marine Development Corporation, at a cost of almost $350 million (nearly $2.2 billion in today's money). It was designed for drilling in the deepest parts of the ocean, specifically to search for deposits of oil and gas at depths that had not been reached before. It was equipped with an advanced drilling system and an advanced computer-controlled navigation system, that allowed it to locate and accurately position itself at drilling sites that were as much as 8000 meters below the sea surface. The ship was also equipped with advanced seismic surveying equipment and a specialized system for collecting and processing samples of drill cores and other geological samples. The Glomar Challenger was involved in numerous oceanographic and scientific research projects, including topics such as continental drift, animal dispersal routes, climate change, and ocean floor structure. In 1975, it was used to collect samples from the Mariana Trench – the deepest spot in the entire ocean. On June 8th, 1974, the Glomar Challenger set sail on a controversial mission called 'Project Jennifer' – a CIA-Instigated mission to raise a sunken Soviet submarine from the bottom of the Pacific Ocean, in order to gain access to its nuclear secrets. This mission provoked an international controversy, as the ship was accused of violating international law and jeopardizing other oceanographic research projects. In 1976, the Glomar Challenger embarked on an ambitious venture known as the Leg 116 Expedition, where it drilled more than 20 deep-ocean sites and took numerous samples. This included the Famous 'Tasmanides' Shale, a fantastically rich deposit of valuable oil and gas found underneath the Tasmanian Sea. The Glomar Challenger continued to make important scientific contributions throughout the remainder of the 1970s, and into the 1980s. In 1978, it located the wreck of the Titanic, and undertook extensive photographic surveys of the ship’s remains. In 1984, it completed the first comprehensive mapping of the entire ocean floor. The Glomar Challenger was decommissioned in 1986, and it is now part of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s fleet of research vessels. It continues to be a valuable asset for oceanographic research, and its legacy of pioneering deep-sea exploration will never be forgotten.

The Cap and Gown Club is an exclusive student society at Princeton University in Princeton, New Jersey. Founded in 1893, the club began as an organization for upperclassmen to enjoy the finer things in life. In its early days, members organized dinners and hosted prestigious speakers from around the world. Today, the Cap and Gown Club is still an important part of the Princeton University experience. Membership is limited to seniors and select juniors who have exemplified the highest levels of academic excellence and commitment to the goals and values of the university. Membership is by invitation only and is a high honor to receive. The club provides a social atmosphere in which its members can enjoy each other’s company in a more formal setting. Several of the club’s traditions include Court Day, where members enjoy a formal dinner and dancing in the late spring; Glee Night, an evening of music and fellowship; and the formal Senior Supper, usually held in May. In addition, the club hosts several intellectually stimulating lectures throughout the year, including academic and career talks. The Cap and Gown Club also organizes several charitable events yearly and is involved in many initiatives to give back to the Princeton community. Each year, the club hosts the Cap and Gown 5K run, which raises money for the Princeton First Aid & Rescue Squad. The members also volunteer at the Princeton campus meal programs. The Cap and Gown Club is a unique organization that combines intellectual discourse, socializing, and charitable giving. It is exclusive to the Princeton seniors, and is considered to be a great privilege to be invited by the club’s members. With its traditions and philanthropic initiatives, the Cap and Gown Club has become an important part of the Princeton community.

Alex Wolf (born April 5, 1994) is an American water polo player who has represented the United States internationally in numerous competitions. Wolf was born in Seattle, Washington and began playing water polo at the age of 12. During high school, he played for the Mercer Island High School water polo team, and led them to three consecutive Washington state championships from 2010 to 2012. After graduating from high school, Wolf attended the University of California, Los Angeles where he continued to play water polo. During his college career, Wolf was a four-time All-American and a two-time Pacific Coast Division Player of the Year. He also led the UCLA Bruins to two NCAA championships in 2014 and 2015. In 2017, he was a member of the United States Men's Water Polo team that won the FINA Men's Intercontinental Qualifying Tournament, and subsequently qualified for the 2020 Tokyo Olympic Games. After graduating from UCLA in 2017, Wolf went on to compete professionally in Europe. He played for OSC in the Austrian Water Polo League, before moving to the Spanish Liga de Waterpolo. Wolf played with CN Terrassa where he was named the MVP of the 2019–20 season, and also won the silver medal in the European League Super Final. He was also named to the All-Star Team at the 2020 European Championships. In 2021, Wolf returned to the United States and joined the New York Water Polo Club. As a member of the club, Wolf looks to help them win the championship in the 2021 National League. Wolf is an excellent example of the success an American water polo player can reach when participating in international competitions. He is also a testament to the impact that American collegiate water polo players can have when competing in professional European water polo leagues.

Wydawnictwo Uniwersytetu Śląskiego (WUS) is the publishing house of the University of Silesia, established in 1968. It is one the largest and oldest Polish publishing houses with a subject focus on humanities. Since its founding, the publishing house has been affiliated with the University of Silesia and is a part of the school’s larger Observatory Program for Culture, Arts, and Sciences and specializes in publishing scholarly works. WUS’s portfolio encompasses a wide range of topics and consists of over 7000 titles. Its main focus is on materials related to humanities, including books and periodicals on literature, linguistics, history, economics, sociology, international relations, philosophy and other social sciences. WUS also publishes books and periodicals on the natural sciences, art and philosophy. The company also has an open access online repository and e-journals, allowing digital access to its publications. Furthermore, WUS strives to promote and support the scientific research of its faculty, staff and students. To this end, it provides different forms of assistance to the authors, from helping them choose a suitable collection or journal to getting the manuscripts ready for the publication. Furthermore, WUS acts as the Polish and European Correspondent Center for international publications, allowing these publications to reach the University’s scholars. WUS’s main activity is in organization and promotion of scientific and research conferences and as such it has organized a number of events, such as the “Waves” symposium, which has been held in November each year since 2001. Additionally, the company is actively involved in a number of other activities, such as promotion of Open Access publishing, which has been made possible with the establishment of the Wyrzykowska Open Access Library, and the organization of scientific workshops, such as the Literary Studies Workshop held annually in Poland. In order to ensure its continued success, WUS continues to monitor, coordinate and promote its activities. It has received numerous awards and acknowledgments, such as the Best European Research Publisher Award for Excellence in Research Promotion (2011) and Best European Research Publisher Award for Excellence in Books Promotion (2013). In addition, WUS has also been listed among the top ten publishers in the Global Ranking of Academic Publishers in 2020. The University of Silesia continues to be an active partner and supporter of WUS, ensuring its continued success for many years to come.

Native Dancer (April 1, 1950- October 16, 1967) was an American Thoroughbred racehorse who is renowned for his remarkable achievements while competing in some of the most prestigious flat races of the 1950s. In 1953, he became the only horse to ever win the U.S. Triple Crown without running in the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes, or the Belmont Stakes. Bred in Kentucky, Native Dancer was owned by syndicate headed by banking executive Alfred G. Vanderbilt II and trained by veteran horseman William H. "Si" Simms. Native Dancer's sire was Polynesian and his dam was Geisha, a daughter of Coldstream Guard. Native Dancer was arguably the greatest turf runner of the 1950s and was honored with a popular fan club, the "Dancerella Club." When Native Dancer retired in 1954, his record showed 21 starts during three racing seasons, with 19 victories, two places, and two thirds. Native Dancer was considered in the mid-1950s among the most accomplished of modern racehorses. The colt was nicknamed the "Gray Ghost". Vanderbilt's magnificent colt was featured in the 1953 film The Story of three Loves, starring Kirk Douglas and Pier Angeli. This documentary short was shot in color and featured Native Dancer and jockey Eric Guerin four days before the Preakness Stakes. Native Dancer's career began as a two-year-old when he won at Aqueduct and Jamaica and also placed in stakes races at Pimlico and Garden State Park. His three-year-old season resulted in 10 wins in 12 starts, including captures of the Belmont Stakes, the Grayson Stakes, the Colonial Handicap, and the Withers Stakes. Native Dancer's career earnings totaled $785,240 and he was the leader on the list of Money Earning Horses in 1953. He also was voted the U.S. Volume Horse of the Year Award in 1953, 1954 and 1955. Native Dancer was inducted in the National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame in 1956 and in the Canadian Horse Racing Hall of Fame in 1959. Native Dancer passed away on October 16, 1967, at age seventeen in his retirement home of Brookmeade Farm in Paris, Kentucky. A twenty-foot bronze memorial stands at the Kentucky Horse Park. The National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame honored Native Dancer with the Hearthstone International Trophy in 1995. Native Dancer was honored with a 2006 United States Postal Service stamp which debuted during the 50th anniversary of his Preakness Stakes win. Native Dancer achieved iconic status as one of the greatest racehorses in American flat racing history, and his story is one of “Perseverance, Dignity, and Grace!”

Sunday school answer is a term used to describe the answers to Bible-related questions given in a Sunday school class setting. Sunday school classes are a type of religious instruction typically held on Sunday mornings in churches or other religious buildings. The questions posed in these classes can vary greatly, but usually relate to particular Bible stories, scriptures, books of the Bible, or any other Bible-based topic. Answers to these questions are then typically given in a discussion format at the end of the class. In some churches, Sunday school answer sessions are held regularly and are led by an instructor or leader, who poses questions to the group in an effort to foster discussion and learning. Answers to the questions posed are typically given by the instructor, though in some cases they may be provided by the group members themselves. The answers provided in a Sunday school answer session can vary greatly, depending upon the biblical topic in question and the instruction approach taken by the teacher. Generally speaking, answers are intended to explain the meaning and significance of a Bible story or passage, encourage deeper thought and discussion about the passage, and provide practical applications for its application to everyday life. In more modern contexts, Sunday school answer sessions often incorporate technology, such as computers and multimedia, to assist with providing a dynamic learning environment. For instance, online Sunday school answers may be used to provide support to students who may be unable to attend regular class sessions, as well as to encourage e-learning and further exploration into Bible-related topics. Such databases may also feature interactive tools, such as quizzes and challenges, to boost engagement. At the heart of any Sunday school answer session is a desire to understand the Bible and its teachings better. By actively engaging in a discussion format, both teacher and student find opportunity to explore, ask questions, and draw personal spiritual insights and knowledge. This helps foster an atmosphere of learning that is engrained with the values and teachings of the Bible, ultimately providing a place of spiritual growth.

Vien, also known as Vien-Hirsh, is a rabbinical dynasty originating from the city of Luninetz, Belarus. It began in the 16th century with two brothers: Rabbi Hirsh and Rabbi Mordecai. The two brothers were well-known and highly respected within the Jewish communities of Eastern Europe. Rabbi Hirsh spent most of his life in Luninetz before settling, at the age of 65, in Przemyśl, Poland. He wrote the work "Turei Zahav", a commentary on the Jerusalem Talmud. His grandson, Rabbi Moshe Ze'ev of Vien, was a student of Rabbi Chaim Volozhin and wrote the acclaimed commentary "Luzin" on the Zohar. Rabbi Mordecai was a renowned Talmudic scholar and the author of several halakhic works, including the "Mordecai," the responsa of "Pri Mordai," and the glosses on the Code of Jewish Law known as "Mordecai Anshei Shem." His great-grandson was Rabbi Yom Tov Lipman Vien of Przemyśl, Poland, who wrote the influential "Ketzos Hashulchan." His son was Rabbi Avraham Vien, the author of "Anshei Avraham", a commentary on the Arba'ah Turim. Rabbi Avraham Vien's son, Rabbi Yitzchak Vien of Przemyśl, appended the work Magen Avraham, a commentary on the Shulchan Aruch, and authored works including "Yitzchak Yitzchaki" and "Keneis Yitzchak". Rabbi Yitzchak's sons were Rabbi Naftali Vien of Przemyśl, author of "Responsa Tzruei Vien", and Rabbi Shlomo Vien of Grodno, author of "Mimar Mordecai", a commentary on the Levush. The Vien rabbinical dynasty played a significant role in Jewish life and scholarship for over four centuries, and its scholarly works are still widely studied today. The Vien rabbis were known for their diligent study and religious zeal, but they also had an eye towards practicality in the application of Jewish law and thought. Today, two of Rabbi Avraham Vien's grandsons, Rabbi Chaim Dov Vien and Rabbi Chaim Yitzchak Vien, continue the Vien dynasty in Jerusalem. The Vien rabbis have been described as a "golden link in the chain of rabbinical dynasties" due to their many outstanding accomplishments and contributions to halakhic literature, and to Jewish scholarship more generally.

Qianjiang Motorcycle (Chinese: 钱江摩托车; pinyin: qiánjiāng mótuōchē) is a Chinese manufacturer of motorcycles and scooters. Established in the year of 1969, Qianjiang is owned by Danbo Holding Co. Ltd, which is located in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province, approximately 240 km south of Shanghai. Qianjiang is one of the leading manufacturers of motorcycles and scooters in China and is known for producing excellent-value motorcycles and scooters. The company focuses on providing competitively-priced and simple-to-use motorbikes, of which many models feature fuel-injected engines and electric-start technology. The most popular Qianjiang models are the daily-use CC and the CG150, which is popular for those taking long-distance rides. Qianjiang has also collaborated with other companies to produce more advanced bikes. In recent years, Qianjiang has collaborated with Italian giant, Piaggio, to develop the NKD100 and NKD125 scooters. And in 2021, Qianjiang began co-developing 80cm³ motorcycles with Honda, with the first prototype model being unveiled on April 2021. Qianjiang has also gone beyond motorcycles; the company also produces single-person bike-sharing systems, utilizing electric powered vehicles. The system employs an electronic locking system which allows bikes to be reserved and unlocked with a smartphone. As of 2021 the Qianjiang bike-sharing system has expanded to over 60 cities in China. As of 2021, Qianjiang produces approximately 1 million motorcycles per year and exports to over 20 countries worldwide, including the United States and European countries. The company has received a National Award for Quality Management, amongst other awards and recognitions. Qianjiang is aiming to become a global brand in the manufacturing of ultra-low-emission vehicles. The company is by embracing the growing trend towards green transportation and expanding its product line-up to include more electric-powered models. In 2021, the company’s joint-venture with Honda resulted in the QJ125-4V, an emissions-free, electric-powered scooter that has been well-received around the world. The company is also involved in developing an autonomous electric-powered scooter.

List of awards and nominations received by Tilda Swinton is a comprehensive list of awards and nominations received by the British actress, performance artist, and film producer Tilda Swinton throughout her career. Since 1988, Swinton has received numerous awards and nominations for her performance in a variety of films, including We Need to Talk About Kevin (2011), The Grand Budapest Hotel (2014), and Trainwreck (2015). She has been nominated for two Academy Awards and has won three BAFTA awards and one Golden Globe award. In 2008, Swinton won her first Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actress for her supporting role in the drama Michael Clayton. She went on to win an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress in 2009 for her performance in the Danny Boyle drama film, The Ages of Love. In 2015, Swinton won the Best Actress award at the British Independent Film Awards for her performance in the independent film The Grand Budapest Hotel. She was also nominated for a BAFTA Award for Best Actress for her role in the same film. Swinton won her first BAFTA award for Best Supporting Actress in 1994 for her performance in the film Orlando. She went on to win two more BAFTA awards; one for Best Actress in a Supporting Role for We Need to Talk About Kevin (2011) and the other for Best Actress in a Supporting Role for The Grand Budapest Hotel (2014). In 2008, she won a Golden Globe award for Best Supporting Actress for her role in Michael Clayton. In addition to feature films, Swinton has also received awards for her work in television and theatre. In 2008, she won a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress for her role in the HBO miniseries John Adams. Swinton has also won multiple awards for her supporting roles in films from other countries, most notably from Japan and France. In 2003, she won a Japanese Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for her performance in The Man Who Wiped His Memories of You. She also won a César Award for Best Supporting Actress in 2008 for her role in the French musical film Umami. Overall, Swinton has received 59 awards and 102 nominations for her work across the entertainment industry, making her one of the most decorated and acclaimed actresses of her time.

Port Douglas Wharf is a historical landmark in the North Queensland coastal town of Port Douglas, Australia. It is located in the heart of town at the end of Macrossan Street, running straight from the beach down to the wharf. The wharf is one of the most iconic features of the town. It has been a major port for the Far North Queensland region since the late 1800s and has played a major role in the local and regional economy. It was initially used as a link between the cattle stations of the region and the southern ports, as well as providing access to the nearby Great Barrier Reef. The wharf has been redeveloped a number of times since its initial construction and is now used as a primary recreational area for the town. It features several shops, bars and restaurants as well as a small park and public swimming area. It is also a popular place for local fisherman and for water sports. The wharf is home to a number of important historical sites such as the restored Tooth and Claw buildings, where sailors once stored their fresh fish catches; Edgewater Staircase, which is believed to have been built by John Anderson in the 1880s to provide access to ships in the old port, and the Stinger Pool, a period structure where the local Indigenous people used to gather freshwater. Port Douglas Wharf is a popular tourist destination, attracting thousands of visitors every year. Various events, such as the annual Mardi Gras and New Year’s Eve celebrations, are held on or around the wharf, and on some occasions the wharf is transformed into a stunning outdoor cinema. Port Douglas Wharf is an important part of Port Douglas history and its continued use is vital to the town’s tourism industry. The wharf offers visitors a glimpse into the past, while providing current visitors with a wealth of recreational activities. As such, the wharf is a must-visit for anyone travelling to the town.

Kokkinobaphos Master is the first and only Greek master in the gaming industry. He is renowned for his work on mobile games and interactive content and is best known for the popular game RefugeeQuest. Kokkinobaphos was born in Athens, Greece in 1984. He has been an avid gamer since early childhood and began creating content for mobile gaming platforms in 2004. Throughout the years he has been involved in several projects in the interactive field and has specialized in game design, art direction and programming. In 2010, he released his first mobile game, RefugeeQuest, as part of an ongoing effort to spread awareness about the situation of refugees. The game has since had a successful launch and is renowned for its humanitarian approach and delicate subject matter. Kokkinobaphos has worked on multiple mobile games in his career, but RefugeeQuest remains his most popular and acclaimed project. Many have praised the game for being able to balance its educational and entertainment value. His works have also been published in several magazines and have been featured in various exhibitions around the world. Over the years, Kokkinobapos has collaborated with various top companies in the gaming field and has been hard at work developing and releasing a wide range of interactive content. He continues to be heavily involved in the gaming industry and is constantly looking for ways to innovate and push the boundaries of what is possible with interactive content. Kokkinobaphos is the first and only Greek master in the gaming industry and has made a considerable contribution to the landscape. His work has won him multiple awards and recognition and he continues to be one of the most respected and influential figures in the field.

Lois Griffin (born August 5, 1957) is an American Politician who served as mayor of Quahog, Rhode Island until the 2006 election. Born in Quahog, She is the daughter of Robert and Barbara Pewterschmidt and the wife of Peter Griffin. She graduated from Quahog High School in 1975 and attended Brown University where she earned a double major in Political Science and Women's Studies. After returning to Quahog, she held a variety of jobs including waitressing in a restaurant, as a flight attendant, and working at the Quahog ferry. In 2000, she ran for mayor of Quahog, challenging incumbent Mayor Adam West. After two bruising campaigns, she won the election and was sworn in on January 2, 2001. During her tenure, Lois successfully brought infrastructure improvements to Quahog such as a new city hall, a new library, and renovations to the Quahog Museum. She also successfully lobbied for a new port authority and the Quahog Arts Council. However, her biggest success was her stewardship of the Quahog economy. During her tenure, Lois helped to bring additional revenue to Quahog in the form of a property tax rebate for homeowners. She also successfully lobbied for additional state funding for the University of Quahog and helped bring the Connecticut Carpet Company to Quahog. In 2006, Lois chose not to run for reelection and was succeeded by Adam West. After leaving office she accepted a teaching position at the Rhode Island School of Design and was appointed as a trustee on the Quahog Historical Commission. Lois is an active member of the Quahog Civic Society and the Rhode Island League of Women Voters. She also serves on the board of directors of the Quahog Community Foundation and is a frequent guest panelist at political forums at Brown University.

Henry James Carr (born 21 September 1890 - 20 April 1976) was an Australian state minister, civil servant and politician. He was born in Bulimba, Queensland, and educated at the Ipswich and Brisbane Grammar Schools. Carr began his political career in 1929, being elected as a member of the Queensland Legislative Assembly for the seat of Ipswich. In the 1930s he served in various posts; Government Whip (1931-1932), Minister for Railways and Cabinet Minister (1932-1938). He was also chairman of the Queensland Tourist Development Authority (1938-1939). Carr served as State Treasurer of Queensland between 1939-1943, during which he implemented a number of significant reforms, including setting up the Queensland Development Fund, providing millions of pounds worth of financial assistance to Queensland businesses. During World War II he was also a delegate to the Australian Loan Council and oversaw the introduction of income taxation in Queensland. In 1944 Carr lost his Ipswich seat to the Country-National Party, but returned to Parliament in 1947 as the Member for Toowong. He again served as a Cabinet Minister from 1952 to 1957, this time with the portfolio of Industrial Development and Public Works. In 1965, Carr was one of the original members of the Liberal Party of Australia and served as a party whip until his retirement in 1972. During his long career in politics, Carr was a prolific speaker and writer, writing several monographs for the Australian Labor Party as well as articles for a number of major newspapers. He passed away in 1976 at the age of 85. Carr was remembered as a 'champion of the people', who had fought tirelessly for social and economic justice. He was inducted into the Queensland Greats in 2020, in recognition of the significant legacy he left behind.

Siddharth Sinha is an Indian entrepreneur known for his start-up companies and philanthropic work. Born on February 24, 1981 in Delhi, he graduated from Shri Ram College of Commerce, Delhi University with a degree in Commerce. Sinha started his career in 2005 with Management consulting and later opted out to begin his own venture in the domain of animal husbandry. His interim venture was launched in 2006 with his start-up company HSB Livestock Solutions Pvt Ltd., which focuses on providing technologies and services to the Indian Dairy Industry. After gaining considerable success and capitalizing on this achievement, Sinha went on to launch another venture – Livestock Biotechnology Pty Ltd. This venture was the precursor to his another venture– India’s first large-scale B2B livestock-tech platform – KnowMore.in (formerly known as HSB BioLivestock Solutions).Founded in 2014, the company furnishes businesses in the livestock sector with marketing and trading solutions.KnowMore.in has so far attracted more than 10,000 users in its four plus years of existence. Sinha is also actively involved in many philanthropic initiatives, which include sponsoring the education of under-privileged children, founding an animal shelter, and providing help and assistance to farmers and farmers’ families. He is an active participant in Start-up and VC activities, and is currently a Board Member and Mentor of various start-ups, including MetoAquaint Consultancy, Bandanna Money and FeedLife. He has also been an Advisor to the Prime Minister, Office of the President of India, and United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD). He currently lives in Ahmedabad, Gujarat with his wife and two sons. Outside of business, Siddharth Sinha is an outspoken proponent of sustainable development and advocates for long-term agricultural solutions. He also actively promotes the wide spread use of technology to ease the lives of farmers and help improve the standards of living of their communities.

Schnellbomber (German for "fast bomber") was a type of bomber aircraft developed by Nazi Germany in the late 1930s and used during World War II. The term "Schnellbomber" was actually not used until after the war, but was initially instead referred to as the Schnellkampfflugzeug, or "fast combat aircraft", when the concept was first proposed. The concept behind the Schnellbomber was to create an aircraft that combined the maneuverability of a fighter plane with the payload capacity of a bomber. This was an attempt to keep up with the Allied forces, who had already developed the modern concept of the fighter-bomber. The initial model of Schnellbomber was the Dornier Do 217, a twin-engined long-range bomber unveiled in 1938. Although the Do 217 had a much larger payload capacity than most of its contemporaries, its performance within a combat environment was limited. It was quickly replaced by more capable designs, such as the Junkers Ju 88. The Ju 88, which first flew in 1939, was the most successful Schnellbomber of the war. It was faster, better armed, and had a longer operational range compared to the Do 217, and was used in a variety of roles. It was primarily deployed as a dive bomber, but was also used for ground attack, torpedo bombing, reconnaissance, and as a night fighter. The Ju 88 was instrumental in the Battle of Britain, and over the course of the war, its production exceeded 20,000 aircraft. The Focke-Wulf Fw 190, first produced in 1937, was another early model of Schnellbomber. Initially designed to act as a fighter plane, its development was quickly superseded by the rise of fighter-bombers. As a result, the remaining Fw 190s were used as ground attack bombers and night fighters. By the end of the war, the Schnellbomber concept had largely been abandoned. Although the Nazi German aviation industry had succeeded in creating powerful aircraft, the production and fuel shortages of the war meant that the majority were never fielded in significant numbers. In addition, the advent of jets, which were faster, better armed, and easier to produce, meant that propeller-driven bombers were quickly outclassed. Today, the Schnellbomber concept has been mostly forgotten, but its legacy still lives on in the development and concept of modern fighter-bombers. Examples include the Northrop F-5 Tiger, F/A-18 Hornet, and the A-10 Thunderbolt II. While Schnellbombers never delivered on their promise to revolutionize air warfare, they laid the groundwork for the development of highly advanced fighter-bombers.

Albertine, Baroness Staël von Holstein (1766–1817) was a Swiss-French political activist, writer, duchess, and world traveler. She is widely known for her work obtaining social and political rights for women in the early 19th century. Staël was born in Paris, France, to a legendary Swiss politician, Jacques Necker – who served as the director-general of finances for Louis XVI - and the French novelist, Suzanne Necker. Raised by her mother as a Swiss citizen, Staël inherited her father's title "Baroness Staël von Holstein" when he died in 1793. Staël was a political activist who used her connections to Napoleon Bonaparte to get her views heard by high-ranking politicians. Staël organized regular speeches at senate meetings and lobbied for women’s rights. As a result of her efforts, the Civil Code of 1804 included provisions recognizing women’s political authority for the first time in French history. Staël was a prolific writer and intellectual, with her most notable works including the novels Delphine (1802), Corinne (1807), and De l’Allemagne (1811). In addition to her writings, Staël is recognized for her conversations with the most important political and philosophical figures at the time. Her political works, in particular, made her a voice of her age. Apart from her political and writing careers, Staël is remembered as a world-traveler, particularly in her native Germany. Her appointed mission was to explain the new political regime in France to the German people. She achieved this largely by accepting invitations from prominent people and arranging gatherings for discussions about the current political situation. Staël died in Paris in 1817, but her legacy lives on in her works and travels. She is remembered for her fight for social and political rights for women, as well as for her contribution to the intellectual and political debates of the time. Today, she is recognized for enabling a more progressive gender dialogue in France and for aiding in the political emancipation of women during the early 19th century.

Courtney's and Steel's Post Cemetery is a historic cemetery located in Pulaski County, Indiana, United States. The cemetery is the resting place for many Civil War veterans, including Medal of Honor recipient Thomas H. Courtney Jr. Courtney's and Steel's Post Cemetery is named after Thomas H. Courtney Jr. (Sept. 18, 1840 – May 14, 1909). Courtney was a soldier in the Union Army during the Civil War. He was noted for his brave acts during the Battle of Shiloh, Tennessee, for which he was awarded the Medal of Honor. He was promoted to the rank of captain for his actions during the battle. The cemetery was established in 1939 and covers two acres of land. It is located in the rural countryside near White Lick Creek, off the old State Road 43. In 1990, the cemetery was added to the National Register of Historic Places. The graveyard is unique in that veterans of both the North and South are buried together in a single cemetery. Among those buried here are veterans of the Confederate Army, the U.S. Army, and the Indiana Legion. It is also the resting place of several freed slaves, who fought on both sides of the Civil War. There is a large memorial stone, erected in 1941, dedicated to the soldiers who gave their lives during the Civil War. This stone serves to remember the bravery and courage of all those who fought for their beliefs, regardless of what side of the conflict they may have been on. The graveyard is well-maintained and open to the public. Visitors are encouraged to walk through the cemetery and honor the veterans that have been laid to rest here. There is no fee for visiting the cemetery, but donations are accepted and are used for the care and upkeep of the graveyard. Courtney's and Steel's Post Cemetery is a reminder of the bravery of those who fought in the Civil War and serves to honor all those who made the ultimate sacrifice. This cemetery is an important part of Pulaski County history and deserves to be respected and visited by all.

John Slim, 2nd Viscount Slim (born 18 August 1949) is a British politician and hereditary peer. He was awarded a life peerage in 2003, becoming Baron Slim, of Chislehurst in the London Borough of Bromley and sits as a member of the House of Lords. John Slim is the eldest son of the 1st Viscount Slim and his wife, Beryl. He was born in 1949 and educated at Eton College and Brasenose College, Oxford where he studied Modern History. After graduating with a Bachelor of Arts, he went on to serve in the British Army, where he joined the Household Cavalry as a Trooper and spent ten years serving in The Blues and Royals. He went on to become a Conservative-affiliated Peer in 2003 when he was honoured with the title of Baron Slim, of Chislehurst in the London Borough of Bromley. On the elevation of his father, Bill Slim, to the peerage in 1985, John became heir-presumptive to the Viscountcy. He succeeded in 2012, upon the death of his father, becoming the 2nd Viscount Slim. In the House of Lords, he has been active on defence, security, foreign affairs and mental health issues. He is a founding member of the Veterans Support Group and the Mental Health Crossbench Peers Group, and is the former Chair of the House of Lords All-Party Parliamentary Group for Veterans. In addition to his political work, Viscount Slim also served for four years on the Board of the British Horse Society and for six as a Director of the Cavalry and Guards Club. He is a supporter of Army charities, serving on the Board of Governors of the Royal Hospital Chelsea and on the Appeal Board of the ABF Soldiers Charity, which supports serving and former soldiers and their families in times of financial crisis. Viscount Slim is married to his second wife, Margaret, and they have two daughters and one son. He currently resides in south-east London. As a hereditary peer, he retains a seat in the House of Lords. Widely respected within his party, Viscount Slim has been seen as an elder statesman amongst the Conservative ranks, advising junior members on matters both political and social. His legacy speaks for itself, having shone in the world of politics and academia for over 50 years.

Arrappahoe County is a county located in Jefferson Territory in the United States of America. It is the largest county in Jefferson Territory and the third most populous county in the Territory. The county seat is the city of Denver. Established in 1859, Arrappahoe County was originally part of Arapahoe County, which was split into two separate counties, Arrappahoe County and Arapahoe County in 1861. The county derives its name from the local Native American "Arapaho" people who originally inhabited the area. The county borders 8 other counties in Jefferson Territory as well as the state of Colorado. Arrappahoe County is home to a variety of communities, ranging from historic small towns to modern city centers. The county seat and largest city is Denver, with a population of 682,545. Other notable cities and towns include Aurora, Centennial, Glendale, Lakewood, Littleton, and Thornton. Arrappahoe County is an affluent area with a diverse economy. The county is home to numerous shopping centers and businesses, including the Denver Tech Center and the Cherry Creek Shopping Center. The local government also provides a variety of services to residents, including road construction, garbage pickup, and fire protection. The county is also home to several private schools and universities, such as the University of Denver, Colorado Christian University, and Regis University. There are also a number of public schools and libraries located in the area. Arrappahoe County is a popular tourist destination, offering visitors a range of activities, including hiking, skiing, biking, and fishing. The county also offers numerous parks and other recreational areas, providing a great opportunity for exploring the local area. Arrappahoe County is an ideal location for business and families. With affordable housing, strong job and educational opportunities, and an abundance of attractions, Arrappahoe County is an attractive option for those looking to settle in Jefferson Territory.

Colin Grainger (born February 2, 1970) is an American businessman, executive and entrepreneur. He is currently the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Direct Line Group, a multinational financial services company based in London. Prior to Direct Line Group, Colin was head of Business Segment Development at HSBC, a role he held from 2011 to 2016. Grainger was born in Houston, Texas, to an English father and Italian mother. He graduated from the University of Texas at Austin in 1992 with a degree in Finance. In 1994, Grainger moved to the United Kingdom and joined Lloyds Bank, where he held a variety of roles until 2010. His final role at Lloyds Bank was managing director of the commercial banking division. In 2011, Grainger joined HSBC as the head of Business Segment Development. In this role, he was responsible for driving realisation of debt reduction opportunities and taking commercial advantage of growth opportunities. During his time at HSBC, Grainger spearheaded a number of strategic initiatives, including a five-year business target setting, as well as the launch of HSBC’s digital bank, First Direct. In 2016, Grainger joined the Direct Line Group as its CEO. His role at the company involves overseeing the overall business strategy, with a focus on improving customer service while continuing to drive profitable growth. Grainger’s agreement with the Direct Line Group also includes a responsibility to become an active, long-term investor in the business. Throughout his career, Grainger has been recognised for his ability to manage change, drive innovation, and deliver financial returns. In 2016, he was included in The Financial Times’ “People to Watch” list for his contributions to HSBC’s success and his groundbreaking leadership approach at Direct Line Group. Grainger is a highly active board director and advisor to a variety of organisations. He is currently a non-executive director at Prudential plc and chair of the audit committee. He is also a member of the International Advisory Panel of the Business Council of Canada and of the Commission on Public Banking. Colin Grainger is a highly successful business leader and executive. A true polymath, he has achieved success in areas as diverse as finance, banking, digital transformation, and strategic thinking. He is renowned for his ability to drive change and deliver real results.

It's a Man's World is a 1965 studio album by American jazz vocalist Sarah Vaughan. Spanning eight tracks, the album was released with Mercury Records, and was produced by Creed Taylor. The title of the album is taken from the James Brown song of the same name, which was the first single from the album to be released. It was accompanied by “The Sweetest Sounds”, a song from the stage musical No Strings. The album features a seven-piece ensemble led by pianist Hank Jones, with contributions from bassists Richard Davis and George Duvivier, and drummers Roy Haynes and Elvin Jones. The band also includes Jimmy Jones on organ, Kenny Burrell and Joe Puma on guitar, and Hubert Laws on flute. The music on the album fuses popular R&B, jazz, and soul elements, showcasing the diverse talent of Vaughan. Highlights include a sizzling version of “Fly Me to the Moon (In Other Words)” and a haunting interpretation of “Every Time We Say Goodbye”. The album was met with critical acclaim, praised for its soulful interpretations and Vaughan’s emotional singing. AllMusic rated the album 4 and a half stars, writing “Singer Sarah Vaughan delivers a masterful vocal performance on this 1965 release, making it a compelling listen for jazz, R&B, and soul fanatics alike.” It's a Man's World was Vaughan's first release on the Mercury label, and her last studio album before signing with Epic Records in 1967. It continues to be considered one of her best albums and a classic of the 1960s jazz era.

2003 marked the start of a new millennium for Denmark and the country saw many changes and events. On January 1, Denmark officially joined the European Union, becoming the 14th member nation of the organization. This saw an influx of financial and political support from the organization, which Denmark could take advantage of to boost its international presence. The Euro, the new common currency adopted by the European Union, was also introduced in 2003 and gradually replaced the Danish krone. This gave investors and residents of Denmark more flexibility in trading and currency exchange. In May, Anders Fogh Rasmussen was re-elected for a third consecutive term as Prime Minister, proving his strong leadership of the country and its approval of his economic policies. On the cultural side, 2003 saw the first staging of the Roskilde Festival in Denmark, an annual music festival that later gained international fame, attracted some of the biggest acts in the world and has become something of a tradition in the country. The year also saw the birth of Denmark's most successful football club, FC Midtjylland. Founded with the aim of encouraging the growth of football in the region, the club has gone on to win 4 Danish Superliga championships and featured in the UEFA Champions League several times. Denmark also earned a Nobel Prize in 2003, with physicist Bente Brok-Jørgensen winning the Physics Prize for her groundbreaking work in the fields of quantum optics and atomic physics. In December, the governments of both Denmark and Sweden officially hailed the Øresund Bridge, an enormous public infrastructure project that connected the two countries together. Its positive ecological, economic and cultural effects were praised by experts and hailed as a sign of progress for the region. 2003 was a big year for Denmark and its people, seeing it increase its political and economic standing in the world, strengthen its ties with Switzerland, celebrate culture and earn international recognition for its achievements.

Bug-O-Nay-Ge-Shig School is a public school that primarily serves Ojibwe people in Cass Lake, Minnesota. The school was established in the 1990s, when a group of Ojibwe tribal leaders and community members recognized the need for educational services for their children and for culturally appropriate education for Ojibwe students. The school is named for Bug-O-Nay-Ge-Shig, a former Ojibwe chief who was instrumental in treaty negotiations with the United States in the 19th century. Bug-O-Nay-Ge-Shig School enrolls students in grades K-12 and covers a wide variety of subjects, including history, math, reading, writing, science, art, music, and physical education. The school also offers extracurricular activities, including basketball, volleyball, baseball, and softball. Additionally, the school offers on-site counseling services, a gymnasium, a library, and an outdoor amphitheater. Bug-O-Nay-Ge-Shig School places a strong emphasis on cultural teachings, weaving Ojibwe language, culture, and history into its curriculum. For example, the school’s art program incorporates traditional Ojibwe beadwork and basketweaving, and the science program employs a project-based approach focused on exploring the natural world through Ojibwe perspectives. All of this is combined with a focus on helping students build the academic and social foundations they need to exceed in their future studies. Bug-O-Nay-Ge-Shig School is a diverse, vibrant, and rewarding learning environment. The school holds a variety of celebrations and events throughout the year, such as the annual spring powwow, Indigenous Peoples’ Day, and a Feast Day in October. These events provide students the opportunity to explore their own history and culture, celebrate their accomplishments, and come together as a community. In addition to its education services, Bug-O-Nay-Ge-Shig School also plays a key role in Cass Lake's community. The school takes part in a number of initiatives to ensure the community remains healthy and prosperous, from the ricing camp that the school hosts each fall to its partnerships with local businesses. It also offers training and mentorship opportunities for interested members of the local community. Overall, Bug-O-Nay-Ge-Shig School is an important and vital educational resource for the Ojibwe people of Cass Lake and its surrounding areas. The school's successful combination of cultural teachings and modern education has helped foster mutual understanding, strengthen the community, and provide an incredible educational opportunity for students.

Ace Horana Power Station is a proposed 500 megawatt (MW) coal-fired power plant in the Galle District of south Sri Lanka. It is being planned by the Ace Corporation, a Sri Lankan power company, and construction is expected to begin in 2021. Ace Corporation initially announced the project in November 2018. The power station is expected to cost Rs 9.8 billion (US$ 54 million), and will be funded by the Ace Corporation, other private investors, and the government. The project is expected to be completed by 2024. The power station is proposed to be built on a 50-hectare plot near the town of Horana in the Kalutara District. The plant will consist of two 250 MW turbines, each fuelled by Sri Lankan coal. The plant is expected to use about 200,000 tonnes of coal per year. The Ace Horana Power Station has been controversial, with locals expressing concerns about the environmental and health impacts of the plant. Local activists have argued that the plant will damage the surrounding ecosystem and impact on local water sources. They have also raised the possibility of health issues arising from the burning of coal, such as air pollution and an increased risk of respiratory diseases.
