In response to these concerns, the Ace Corporation has committed to a number of measures to reduce the environmental impact of the plant, including implementing pollution control measures and minimizing water usage. However, many locals remain unconvinced, and have organized protests against the project. Despite the controversy, the Ace Horana Power Station has been approved by the Sri Lankan government. Construction is set to commence in 2021, and it is hoped that when it is completed the power station will help ensure a reliable electricity supply to the area. The Ace Horana Power Station is part of a larger plan to increase power generation in Sri Lanka and reduce electricity shortages. The government is encouraging other companies to follow suit, and is investing in a number of other coal-fired power stations as part of its plan. Ace Corporation is optimistic about the power station's potential to drive economic development and reduce electricity shortages. However, local residents continue to voice their concerns and uncertainty persists over the impact the power station will have on the local environment.

Neil Lanctot (b. 1975) is an award-winning Canadian music producer and songwriter. His music production and songwriting career began in the early 1990s when he worked as an intern at CBC Radio Canada in Montreal. Lanctot’s music production career has since flourished. He has worked with many of the biggest names in the music industry, including Celine Dion, Sinead O’Connor, and Michael Bolton. He has also worked with international acts such as the band Anastacia, and many music labels including Universal Music Group, Warner Music Group, and Sony Music. In 2009, Lanctot won a Juno Award for “Producer of the Year” for his work on the album “Platinum” by Canadian rock band Three Days Grace. This marked the first time in over ten years that a Canadian producer had been recognized in this category. Lanctot has collaborated on projects with some of Canada’s most recognized figures in the music industry, including Ray Montford, Hawksley Workman, and Jay Ferguson. He has also been praised for his collaborations with independent artists from around the world, such as folk singer-songwriter Jesca Hoop and Americana roots rock duo The Reels. In addition to his work as a producer and songwriter, Lanctot has also served as a judge on the Canadian reality television series “Rock Star: Supernova”. He currently resides in Montreal and is well known for his mentorship role in the music industry, helping young artists develop their creativity. Lanctot has been featured in numerous publications, including The Toronto Star, LA Times, and The Globe and Mail. He has also appeared on several television and radio programs, including CBC Radio-Canada’s “Morningside” program. In 2012, he was awarded the Media Excellence Award from the Academy of Canadian Music. Throughout his career, Lanctot has strived to remain true to his artistic vision, helping to shape the world of Canadian music with every project that he takes on. His dedication to music and willingness to collaborate with other artists has solidified his reputation as one of Canada’s leading music producers and songwriters.

Kohala High School is a public four-year comprehensive secondary school located in the Kohala district of the Big Island of Hawaii, United States. It is operated by the Hawaii Department of Education. Kohala High School, opened in 1895, provides education for all grades 9 through 12. It is the oldest high school in the Hawaiian Islands and one of the oldest in the United States. The school’s mascot is the Cowboys and its colors are maroon and gold. Kohala High School's academic program offers both college-level and Advanced Placement (AP) Courses. The school also offers a wide range of co-curricular activities including sports such as football, basketball, volleyball and tennis along with a variety of student clubs, performing arts and other after-school activities. The school has a rich cultural heritage extending back to its past as a plantation school. One of the school's highlights is its community spirit, which is based upon the experiences of working in the sugarcane fields. Enrollment is approximately 400 students and the school has a staff of approximately 50. The student at Kohala High School come from various backgrounds and nationalities from all over the country, including Latino, Asian and Pacific Islander, Native Hawaiian and American Indian. Kohala High School has an impressive record of achievement in academics and other arenas. In addition to receiving the Hawaii State Department of Education’s recognition for Excellence in Education for the years 1999–2000 through 2006–2007, the school was also the recipient of the Siemens Award for Advanced Placement Achievement in 2002 and 2004. The Kohala High School Marching Band participated in the 2009 Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. Kohala High School sees its mission as one of inspiring its students to reach their individual potential and to become productive citizens. The school strives to create a safe and respectful learning environment while developing academic excellence and the appreciation of the arts and cultures represented in the school's diverse student population.

Ryan Amador is an American singer, songwriter, and producer. Born and raised in the suburbs of the San Francisco Bay Area in California, Ryan’s musical influences began at a young age. Growing up, Ryan enjoyed creating and performing music, especially with his church choir and youth music programs. He eventually attended the Musicians Institute in Los Angeles as a vocal major, and after receiving his certification in The Voice Workshop, he moved to New York City to further develop his musical career. During his stay in New York City, Ryan worked as a freelance singer and songwriter for various studios and artists, producing and arranging a multiple number of songs for various genres. His solo career launched in 2013 with single “This Is The Artifact”, which he released independently to wide acclaim. The single was followed by the EP From the Center, which was self-recorded and produced by Ryan and featured the viral music video "This Is the Artifact". The video was well-received and earned Ryan multiple nominations and awards including Best Music in a Short from How-Farr Media, Music Video Honorable Mention from the Los Angeles Music Video Festival, Top 10 at the VibeOut Music Video Fest, and Best Performance from the Indie Fest USA Film Festival. In 2014, Ryan released his debut album Breathe Life through New York based independent record label Makeout Productions. Breathe Life featured music collaborations with various artists including Team Machines and Mathew James White and was met with critical positive reviews. His sophomore album Divide & Conquer was released in 2015 and follows a rock meets pop sound with the success of the single "Divide & Conquer” which he produced and co-wrote with Nathan X. In 2018, Ryan embarked on a sold out North American tour to promote the single “Definition of Lonely” in promotion of his upcoming EP Young Thoughts produced by Ryan and Grammy Award nominated engineer Owen Biddle. In 2019, Ryan released his third EP, Young Thoughts, and the video for the single “Definition of Lonely” premiered on the front page of Vevo. As of 2021, Ryan is currently in the studio with Team Machines recording his highly anticipated fourth album, and touring throughout the U.S. and Europe. Ryan Amador is a remarkably talented, award-winning singer, songwriter, and producer who is continuing to make waves in the music industry today.

Slavink (also known as fricadel, frikandel, frikkadel or Dutch frikadel) is a Dutch meat product, very similar to a hot dog, which is made from a combination of pig, beef and sometimes poultry meat. It is a pocket-sized meat product served in pairs, usually between buns. It was invented in the early 20th century, probably in the 1920s or 1930s according to some sources, with the aim of providing a cheap alternative to larger, more expensive forms of meat. It quickly rose to become one of the Dutch people's most beloved fast food dishes. The most popular version of Slavink is the single meat version, which is made from beef, pork fat, bread, eggs, onion and spices. This is the most widely available version in supermarkets and snack bars across the Netherlands, however there are many variations available including minced poultry, a fish version as well as vegetarian options. Slavink is usually served with a selection of fryable goods such as French fries, frikadelle (fried meatballs) and rookworst (Dutch smoked sausage). It is usually obtained from supermarkets, snack bars, bratwurst stores and also from fairs and markets. Slavink can be served with a variety of toppings such as curry ketchup, mayonnaise, or most commonly, a combination of both. The dish is very popular in the Netherlands, as well as Belgium and Germany. In recent years, it has also become an increasingly popular part of ex-pat Dutch and Belgium cuisine and is often served in the Netherlands-themed restaurants in the United Kingdom and United States. Although the exact origin of the Slavink is unknown, it is thought to be based on a Dutch meatball recipe that is over a century old. It is believed to be derived from the Dutch word 'slavink', which was an old Dutch term for meatballs. Slavink is an excellent example of how Dutch cuisine has evolved over the years, creating delicious dishes from simple ingredients. It is an iconic Dutch fast food that continues to be enjoyed today, both in the Netherlands and abroad.

The Plaza at Harmon Meadow is a premier shopping, dining, and entertainment destination in the heart of Secaucus, New Jersey. Located adjacent to the Palisades Interstate Parkway, The Plaza at Harmon Meadow features over 85 retailers, including one of the largest AMC theatres in New Jersey and several popular restaurants, such as P.F. Chang's and The Cheesecake Factory. The Plaza at Harmon Meadow opened in mid-1994 with the expansion of Riverside Square, a 500,000-square-foot shopping centre. The addition of The Plaza saw the overall square footage of the mall double and included the construction of a four-story retail structure featuring an enclosed bridge to connect the two halves. The Plaza housing an AMC 16 movie theatre, a bowling alley, comedy club, Starbucks and Barnes & Noble. The Plaza at Harmon Meadow is also home to a wide range of restaurants, including P.F. Chang's, The Cheesecake Factory, and Blue Moon Mexican Café. It offers a selection of fast food kiosks and eat-in options like Roberto’s Italian Restaurant and BurgerShack, while also having multiple specialty stores like Rush Hair Salon, Escapology Escape Room, and AT&T. The Plaza at Harmon Meadow also includes a beauty salon, frozen yogurt shop, and Brooklyn Pizza. The Plaza at Harmon Meadow is part of a larger mixed-use development named Harmon Meadow. This development also houses a 350-room Marriott Hotel & Conference Center and a 200,000 square foot Office Tower. This area is accessible for residents and visitors alike, and is serviced by NJ Transit bus lines, offering an easy and convenient way to get to and from Secaucus. The Plaza at Harmon Meadow is a drawing to visitors from nearby communities as an entertainment destination, and as an example of Mid-Atlantic area development. It represents a major retail hub in Northwest Hudson County, and provides over 14,000 jobs to its surrounding areas. The Plaza at Harmon Meadow is a vibrant destination, with a variety of activities and attractions for all ages. From popular restaurants to nightlife, shopping, and entertainment, it serves as a premier destination for those who call Secaucus and its surrounding areas home.

and should relate to the author. Olivier Bourdeaut (born 1975) is a French author who has written several novels, children's books, and a collection of short stories. Born in the Loire-Atlantique département of western France, he studied literature at the University of Nantes. He subsequently worked as a teacher and editor for a short period of time before embarking on a new career as a freelance author. Bourdeaut's rise to fame began with his 2017 novel En attendant Bojangles (Waiting for Bojangles), which focused on the complex relationship between a musician father and his young son. The book was widely praised by critics and readers alike, and was listed as one of the New York Times 100 Notable Books of the Year. It was later adapted into a French-language feature film. Bourdeaut has since published a further six novels, including Les deux ours (The Two Bears), La voix des sornettes (The Voice of Nonsense), L'arbre sans terre (The Tree Without Soil), Les Déraisons des jours (The Reasons of the Days), Un air de famille (A Family Air) and Petit pays (Small Country). He has also written three children's books. His writing has earned numerous awards, including the prix du Livre Inter in 2018 and the Grand Prix L'Express/GQ du Roman 2020. Bourdeaut has been described as a storyteller who takes on difficult and often taboo topics with "the right balance between respect and humour". In an interview with the Wall Street Journal, he explained that he often combines reality and fiction in his writing, infusing his stories with absurd, whimsical elements. He has published his works in several languages, including English, and has been translated into 15 languages. Olivier Bourdeaut is a celebrated French author whose work continues to earn accolades from readers and critics alike. His unique writing style and ability to capture complicated subject matter in a humorous and respectful manner have earned him numerous awards and accolades, as well as fans from all around the world.

Else Holmelund Minarik (August 24, 1920 – April 12, 2012) was a Danish-American author, best known for her Little Bear series of children’s books. First published in 1957, the Big Little Bear series consists of numerous titles with Minarik’s story and illustrations about Little Bear, a lovable young polar bear who has exciting adventures in the wilderness. She has written more than 60 books for children. Else Holmelund Minarik was born on August 24, 1920, in Denmark, to Holger and Ægidia Holmelund. In 1928, the family emigrated to the United States. They eventually settled in the Bronx, New York, where Minarik attended grade school and Hunter College. After school, she worked as a secretary in a Manhattan bank before trading it in to pursue authorship as a full-time career. Minarik wrote heavily for children. In addition to the Little Bear series, she wrote books about dogs and cats, a series about the Robinson family, stories about familiar childhood characters, the Charlie Smiff series, and books about animals from other parts of the world. She also ghosted Dr. Seuss' first book, To Think That I Saw It On Mulberry Street. With its simple text and sly illustrations, this book Mr. Brown Can Moo! Can You? sold over one million copies in a number of languages. Minarik was a worthy addition to the world of literature for children. She was one of the first authors to combine short gracefully written text with intimate and precise explanation of emotions. Apart from books, she wrote television scripts, wrote essays and magazine articles related to writing and children’s literature. Her other works have been adapted into an animated movie, Little Bear (2001), and animated TV series based on her books. Three of her books have also been adapted into live-action plays. Minarik received numerous awards in her commendable career. The Little Bear books were given the Lewis Carroll's Shelf Award and the Children’s Book Council Award. She received lifetime achievement awards from the American Library Association and the Bank Street College of Education. Minarik married Peter Minarik, a Czech-American artist, in 1947. The couple had two sons, David and Adam, in 1951 and 1956 respectively. She passed away on April 12, 2012. I The children’s literature world will remember Minarik forever for her timeless stories about Little Bear and her many other brilliant and charming works that young readers will always enjoy. To this day, Little Bear books still remain popular among children, giving a modern twist to the classic stories that were penned by Minarik decades ago.

Fourth Fitna, also known as The Revolt of Ibn al-Zubayr, began in 683 CE and ended in 692 CE in the Arabian Peninsula. The conflict resulted from the succession crisis of the Umayyad Dynasty which ruled the Islamic Caliphate at the time. It was the final civil war in a series of three civil wars known as the Fitnas – a time of political and religious turmoil in Islamic history. It was also the most destructive of these wars. The conflict had its roots in a dispute between the Saffarids, who were Shi’i Muslims, and the Umayyads, who were Sunnis. The Saffarids sought to overthrow the Umayyads in order to create a Shi’i Muslim caliphate. To achieve this, they invited the renowned scholar and warlord, Ibn al-Zubayr, to lead their cause. Ibn al-Zubayr was a descendent of Banu Umayya, the clan from which the Umayyads had descended, and was also a descendant of the Islamic prophet Muhammad. Because of his background, he had significant legitimacy to claim the caliphate. In683 CE, Ibn al-Zubayr declared himself caliph and declared war on the Umayyads. He was able to gain the support of the Saffarids, as well as other Shi’i Muslims in the area. The Umayyads responded by sending a large army to confront Ibn al-Zubayr. The Fourth Fitna was devastating; entire cities were destroyed and hundreds of thousands of people were killed. It lasted for nine years and did not end until the Umayyad army was finally able to defeat Ibn al-Zubayr in 692. This marked the end of the Fitnas and the Umayyads continued to rule the Islamic Caliphate until they were overthrown by the Abbasids in 750. The legacy of the Fourth Fitna is one of destruction and death. The conflict revealed bitter rivalries between different Muslim sects and severely weakened the Umayyad Dynasty, ultimately resulting in its demise. It also showed the dominance of tribal affiliations in the politics of the time, which would continue to shape the history of the Middle East for centuries.

Hillman, Minnesota is a small city located in central Minnesota in Todd County. The city was named after Hillman J. Davis, the first mayor and founder of the city. The population is just over 800 people, with most of the town's residents working in agriculture and other industries related to the large agricultural industry, such as food processing and timber. Hillman is located in close proximity to both St. Cloud and Brainerd, giving the city access to a wider range of services, entertainment, and shopping than other small towns in the region. The city also has a small airport, a golf course, and a few restaurants and businesses within the city limits. The city is home to many local events throughout the year, including the Hillman Harvest Days, Hillman Barn Dance, Hillman Centerfest, and the Hillman Dog Derby. These events help bring the community together and create a sense of community pride. Hillman is also home to the Todd County Historical Museum and the Todd County Heritage Center, which have exhibitions telling the history of the region. Information about the area can also be found in the Hillman library and from local businesses. The schools within the city are of great importance to the community. The Hillman Elementary School serves preschoolers through fifth grade, and the Hillman High School serves students in grades nine through twelve. The schools both offer basketball and volleyball teams and have a large number of extracurricular activities and clubs for students. The city of Hillman is an important part of the Todd County economy. Many of the local businesses, such as the Hillman Winery, provide jobs to members of the community, and the city is home to many small and large business owners. Hillman is a great place to live, work, and raise a family. With its proximity to larger cities, a vibrant local business community, and its commitment to providing quality education to its students, Hillman is an excellent example of small-town living.

Lo Fiolairé is a traditional French-Lyonese dish made from rabbit, onions, and white wine. It originated in the region of Lyon, France and is known for its rich, gamey flavor and complex preparation. The dish is believed to have been served since the 16th century, with different names and ingredients depending on the region. The name “Lo Fiolairé” comes from “Li fiolai”, a French root from Old French meaning “making rabbits”. The dish is made with a stew-based preparation of rabbit and other ingredients like onions, garlic, mushrooms, bay leaves, thyme, rosemary, white wine and olive oil. The ingredients are cooked in slow-cooker until all the liquid has evaporated and the rabbit is tender. Alternatively, the rabbit can be cooked on-the-bone, or pan-fried. The vegetables and liquids in the dish are cooked until they have a thick, rich consistency. Lo Fiolairé is usually served with a side of boiled potatoes, or tartiflette and a green salad. It’s often paired with a robust white wine like Beaujolais to compliment the flavor of the game. Over the years the dish has become popular in other regions of France, especially the nearby provinces of Burgundy, Saône-et-Loire and Ain. It is also popular in French-speaking countries in the Caribbean, Canada and Belgium. In addition, the dish has been adapted for non-French cuisines, by adding ingredients like feta cheese and Mediterranean herbs. Today, Lo Fiolairé is still regarded as a classic French dish. It is renowned for its savory flavor, and intricate yet simple traditional preparation. The recipe is often served at festivals and events in the French countryside, where it is served as an homage to traditional French cooking. Lo Fiolairé, a testament of French culinary history and culture, continues to be popular throughout France and the world, providing diners with a delicately-flavored yet robustly-savory experience.

. Pandua (Vidhan Sabha constituency) is one of the 243 assembly constituencies of the West Bengal Legislative Assembly in India. It forms a part of the Hooghly district and is located on the banks of river Bhagirathi and is closer to Kolkata than it is to Howrah. The area of this constituency comes under the Hooghly (Lok Sabha constituency). It is currently represented by Arindam Bhattacharya of the Trinamool Congress (TMC). The constituency can be considered one of the historically significant assembly segments in the state of West Bengal. Pandua has been a center of culture, education and political movements since ancient times and has played an important role in the political and social tussle for supremacy in the region. In 2011, Pandua (Vidhan Sabha constituency) had a total of 2,43,493 registered voters. The election results of 2011 state assembly polls saw Arindam Bhattacharya of the TMC winning the seat with a huge margin of over 10,000 votes ahead of his nearest rival, Chittaranjan Choudhury of the CPI(M). Bhattacharya received 73,205 votes while Choudhury received 62,521 votes. In the 2016 West Bengal Legislative Assembly Elections, Arindam Bhattacharya contested for the seat on behalf of TMC and was re-elected with a massive victory. Bhattacharya received 2,05,551 votes, which was more than the total votes received by all the candidates contesting the elections combined. His victory margin was more than 1,47,000 votes which was the highest in the state during this election. Pandua Vidhan Sabha assembly seat has 7 other resorts affiliated to it. These include Barasat-II, Champdani, Khanakul, Chinsurah, Serampore, Bhabanipur and Tarakeswar. This constituency is surrounded by a number of important towns and cities like Bandel, Behrampore, Chinsurah, Kolkata and Tarakeswar. Pandua is a major commercial center for the surrounding areas and its markets are visited by people from neighboring districts. This constituency will continue to be a key assembly segment in the region and its electorate will play an important role in deciding the future of West Bengal politics.

The 2014–15 UC Santa Barbara Gauchos men's basketball team represented the University of California, Santa Barbara during the 2014–15 NCAA Division I men's basketball season. The Gauchos, led by third year head coach Bob Williams, played their home games at the campus's Thunderdome and were members of the Big West Conference. The Gauchos finished the season 17–15, 8–8 in Big West play to finish in a three-way tie for fourth place. They advanced to the semifinals of the Big West Tournament where they lost to UC Irvine. As a result, they did not receive an invitation to post season play. The Gauchos opened the season at home with a victory over the NAIA-member Biola, followed by a five-point loss to California. In December, UCSB went 2–1 in the annual Ohaha World Vision Invitational Tournament at the Sanford Coyot Arena in Tucson, Arizona. They opened the tournament with a 71–67 loss to UTEP, followed by victories over Northern Arizona (87–69) and Idaho (66–64). The Gauchos closed out their non-conference schedule with an 8–5 record, having played games at many non-power 5 schools, as well as Pac-12 Schools UCLA, USC, and Stanford, who UCSB defeated by 22 at home. UCSB opened Big West play January 8 with a 76–55 win over Cal State Fullerton, and moved to 3–1 with a three-point win at UC Riverside. In their first home conference game, the Gauchos suffered a 46–61 defeat at the hands of Hawaii. The Gauchos struggled at times in conference play, dropping their next three contests, including a double overtime loss to UC Davis, before rebounding with four consecutive wins. They dropped a January 30 road game at UC Davis, then won four straight at home to move to 7–5 in the conference. Behind the play of senior guard Alan Williams (22 points, 18 rebounds, five blocks), UCSB earned a season split with defending Big West champion UC Irvine, winning 69–61 at home on February 12. The Gauchos finished the regular season with a 1–3 stretch, losing at home to UC Riverside and UC Irvine and splitting their final two games against Cal Poly and UC Davis. The Gauchos entered the Big West Tournament as the No. 5-seed and were matched up with UC Irvine, who they defeated in their regular-season finale. UCSB was defeated by the Anteaters, 64–70, and failed to advance to the second round. The 2014–15 season provided a positive outlook for the Gauchos. Senior center Alan Williams tallied a school record 18 double-doubles on the season and was named Big West Player of the Year and Big West Tournament MVP and First Team All Big West. Senior forward Taran Brown also earned First-Team All Big West honors. Head coach Bob Williams was also named Big West Coach of the Year, his first time receiving the award and second in the history of UCSB Basketball.

The Secretary of State for Migration, often referred to as the Minister of Migration, is a Cabinet-level position in some countries' governments, the purpose of which is to manage the country's immigration policy, including overseeing the functions of the immigration or foreign affairs ministries. The position may also involve international agreements and border control. Since the economic and political spheres are closely intertwined with migration, the Minister of Migration may be expected to also handle economic and foreign policy. The Secretary of State for Migration is typically appointed by the head of state, usually with the consent of the legislature, and is usually responsible for a ministry or department of their own. In some countries, the Minister may be granted additional power over related issues such as employment, integration and human rights. The role of the Secretary of State for Migration may vary depending on the country and its specific migration policy. In countries such as the United Kingdom, the United States, and Canada, the Secretary of State for Migration is typically in charge of the ministry responsible for managing the country's immigration and border policies. The Secretary may work closely with other government agencies in order to monitor and control the flow of people entering and exiting the country. The Secretary may be involved in negotiating agreements with foreign countries in order to regulate the flow of foreign nationals and refugees into the country. The Secretary is also responsible for setting and overseeing the rules and regulations governing the immigration process. The Secretary is typically responsible for implementing government programs and initiatives that are related to migration. These may include promoting economic development, assisting refugees and ensuring the welfare of immigrants. The Secretary may also be responsible for providing support to refugee camps and assisting in the process of resettling refugees. The Secretary may also be tasked with promoting policies that support the integration of immigrants into society. The Secretary of State for Migration may also be involved in the decision making surrounding granting asylum seekers the right to stay in the country. They may be responsible for liaising with other departments and organizations to ensure that an asylum seeker’s application is processed first and comprehensively. The General Assembly of the United Nations (UN) has created an annual International Migrants Day held on December 18th to honour the work done by the Secretary of State for Migration. This day recognises the efforts to make migration safe, orderly and regular. The UN calls on governments to implement effective policies that protect the rights of migrants, including their right to be protected from exploitation and violence. Overall, the Secretary of State for Migration plays an important role in managing a country's immigration and border policies. They advise their government on issues such as refugee resettlement and integration. The Secretary of State for Migration works closely with other government ministries to ensure that foreign nationals and refugees are treated fairly and humanely, and have access to the same basic rights and services as citizens of the country.

Benalto is a small hamlet in central Alberta, Canada, located in Red Deer County. It has a population of approximately 1,400 people and is located north of Innisfail, part of the Red Deer metropolitan area. The town was named after Ben Louis McPhail, a contractor who came from Ontario to work during the construction of the railroad from Calgary to Edmonton in 1904. McPhail chose the name because at that time, it was the highest point along the railway line. Benalto has a rural atmosphere and provides convenient access to the nearby cities and larger communities of Red Deer, Rocky Mountain House and Lacombe. The town has maintained its rural lifestyle, but also has access to conveniences and services. Benalto has a library, various churches, a fire hall, and a recreation hall. There are three schools in the area: a K-2, 3-8 and 9-12 school. The surrounding countryside features numerous camping, hiking, and fishing areas, and is home to the historical Evan Young Pioneer Village. Recreational activities may be enjoyed in and around Benalto such as tobogganing, snowshoeing, cross-country skiing, ice skating and much more. Benalto also has a 9-hole golf course for golfers. Every summer, Benalto hosts the Benalto Fair, that features rodeo events and family-focused entertainment. It is organized by volunteer organizations such as the Benalto Agricultural Society and the Benalto Fair Board. Benalto is a picturesque rural area that provides the best of both worlds; convenience and charm. This peaceful hamlet offers a friendly and safe environment making it a great place to be. References - McKercher, Boucher, McPhail (2010). A History of Benalto. Dancing Red Publications. - Benalto Agricultural Society (2012). Benalto Fair. Retrieved from http://www.benaltosociety.ca/events/ - Red Deer County (2013). Benalto. Retrieved from http://www.rdcounty.ca/location/community-profiles/benalto.aspx

Peikarambankottai, also known as Peikarampankottai, is a village panchayat located in the Tiruvarur district of Tamil Nadu, India. It is one of the most densely populated villages in the district. It is situated in the delta region of South India which is known as the Cauvery delta. The village is surrounded by farmlands and rivers. Peikarambankottai has a rich cultural heritage, and has been home to several noted temples and historical monuments. One of the most popular is the Pudukkottai Thiruvaiyaru Temple, which is dedicated to Lord Ranganatha. Another significant temple, the Mannamangalam Varadaraja Perumal Temple, is home to the deity Varadaraja Perumal. These temples, along with several other important religious sites, draw large numbers of devotees year round. The village is connected to some of the major cities of Tamil Nadu by bus. Besides this, there are several ferries that operate from the village to Tiruvarur. The nearest railway station is located at Kodamansur. The main source of income in Peikarambankottai is agriculture. Rice and pulses are the main crops grown here, and are exported to other parts of the country. Other important crops include banana, coconuts, and cashews. There are several industries located in the village as well. These include textile factories, wood-based industries, and others that employ local villagers. Peikarambankottai is also known for its festivals. The popular Pongal festival is celebrated every year with much fervor. Temple chariot processions and religious discourses are organized throughout this festival. On this day, everyone in the village dresses up in their festive best and celebrates with great zeal. The village of Peikarambankottai has a lot to offer its visitors. Tourists can find good accommodation in the village. They can take part in a variety of activities such as visiting temples, engaging in shopping and purchasing souvenirs, engaging in river sports, and sightseeing. Peikarambankottai is an ideal destination to experience a little bit of rural life while still enjoying modern amenities and urban comforts.

Andres Valdez is a Filipino-born American soccer player who recently signed to the Major League Soccer club, Orlando City SC. Valdez was born in Davao, Philippines on January 8, 1991 and moved to Tampa, Florida when he was 14 years old in pursuit of his dream of becoming a professional soccer player. He attended Hillsborough High School, where he was twice named All-Conference honorable mention and became the school's all-time leading scorer. In 2009, he was awarded All-Tampa and All-State selections. During his college years, Valdez attended Polk State College and Hillsborough Community College, where he was the conference player of the year in 2015. He was also named to the NJCAA Southeast All-Region First Team and NCCAA National Player of the Year. After a breakout year, Valdez was recruited by top NCAA Div. 1 programs and ultimately signed with UNC Charlotte. In his three seasons with UNC Charlotte, Valdez started every match, scored 19 goals and had 7 assists for a total of 45 points. Valdez signed his first professional contract with USL Championship, Swope Park Rangers in 2018, where he made 19 appearances. He joined San Antonio FC in 2019, where he scored two goals and had two assists in 15 games. This past January, Valdez signed to Major League Soccer Orlando City SC, where his brother, Josue, also plays. He is the first Filipino-American to sign with the MLS club. Since then, he has made two appearances and scored one goal against Inter Miami CF. Away from the pitch, Valdez is involved with his community in Tampa and Charlotte. He has given back by helping out at soccer clinics and partnering with various organizations that are dedicated to helping underprivileged kids. Valdez continues to make history as a Filipino-American soccer player and hopes to inspire a whole new generation of young athletes with similar backgrounds.

West Haven station is an Amtrak inter-city railroad station in West Haven, Connecticut. The station is served by Amtrak's Northeast Regional and Vermonter lines. West Haven station is located in the city's west shore neighborhood, adjacent to Rhode Island Avenue and Forest Road. It is two blocks west of Interstate 95. The station building has a spacious waiting room, restrooms and self-service kiosks. The station is accessible via the Shore Line East local commuter service and by bus, with Providence-West Haven Express bus service operating between the station and downtown Providence. The station is served by two tracks, both owned and maintained by Metro-North Railroad. The station building, which was reconstructed in 2013, is a one-story wood frame structure built in the French Second Empire style. It has a tall tower and mansard roof with a cupola. The original station was established in 1848 as part of the New York, New Haven & Hartford Railroad. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the station had the highest ridership of any station along the Shore Line Railroad. By the late 20th century, the station had fallen into disrepair, with a deteriorating building, no ADA accessibility and limited off-street parking. In 2013, the station was renovated as part of the Shore Line East expansion project. A $5 million grant from the Federal Transit Administration funded the reconstruction and upgrades to the station. The new station includes a ticket office, public restrooms, improved pedestrian access, and off-street parking for up to 32 cars. West Haven station is one of several stops on Amtrak's Northeast Regional and Vermonter Vece lines. It is also an important point on Shore Line East's regional commuter rail service, providing transit to New Haven and beyond. West Haven station serves as an important transit hub for the city of West Haven and its surrounding communities. The station provides an important conduit for ridership growth in the southern New Haven County region and helps boost economic development in the area.

Frank Budd (born August 9, 1939) is an American former sprinter who equaled the world record in the 100-yard dash, a feat that has yet to be broken, and competed in the 1960 Summer Olympics in Rome. Budd was born in Philadelphia and attended Overbrook High School, where he showed extraordinary speed while playing football and baseball. His track coach, J. Ray Davey, encouraged him to focus his talent on running and competing in track and field. Budd won the Pennsylvania state championships in the 100, 200, and 440 yard dashes during his senior year, and graduated as the fastest high school sprinter in the U.S. Budd attended Villanova University on an athletic scholarship, and continued to break records, becoming the first person to break the 20-second mark in the outdoor 220-yard dash on June 17, 1960. At the 1960 NCAA championships, he set a new world record in the 100-yard dash of 9.2 seconds, then a collegiate best. That same year, he qualified for the U.S. Olympic team, and placed fifth in the 100 meters at the Rome Olympics. After college, Budd began a career in the finance and insurance industry. He continued to participate in sprinting competitions, and in 1965 won the United States National Outdoor Championship in the 100-yard dash with a record time of 9.2 seconds. His achievements earned him a place on the 1980 U.S. Olympic team, as well as induction into the Penn Relays Wall of Fame in 1988 and the Penn Relays Hall of Fame in 1995. In 2015, Budd published his autobiography, No Ghost in My Machine, which recounts his experiences as an Olympic athlete and businessman. He also established the Frank Budd Running Scholarship, awarded to deserving students from Budd's alma mater, Overbrook High School. Today, Budd resides in Limerick, Pennsylvania with his wife Ann, and continues to mentor aspiring runners from his track team, "Frank Budd's Racers." He is also a frequent speaker at local universities and charities, and a strong advocate for physical education in public high schools.

The Australia national soccer team (also referred to as the Socceroos) has competed in five World Cup tournaments and three Asian Cup tournaments since the turn of the century. The Socceroos have had a long and distinguished history, having many great players represent the team in major international events. As such, this article serves as a list of all squads that the Socceroos have fielded in the World Cup and Asian Cup tournaments between the years 2000 and 2020. 2000 UEFA/FIFA World Cup The Socceroos qualified for their first World Cup in 32 years during the June 1999 qualifying campaign. Picked in Group A along with Chile, Indonesia and Sweden, the Socceroos took surprise lead in the qualifying table with four wins out of six, while accumulating 11 points, enough to gain the second-place spot in the standings and the direct qualification ticket to the 2000 UEFA/FIFA World Cup in the Netherlands and Belgium. The final squad for the group stage of the tournament comprised 24 players and was managed by head coach Frank Farina. The names of the players were as follows: Goalkeepers: Zeljko Kalac, Tony Franken, Michael Petkovic Defenders: Craig Moore, Milan Blagojević, Jeremy Charles, Stan Lazaridis, Stephen Laybutt, Tony Vidmar, Shahram Abudato Midfielders: Mark Bresciano, Mark Lee, Craig Foster, Paul Agostino, Tony Popovic, Vince Grella, Paul Okon, Marco Bresciano Forwards: Harry Kewell, Damian Mori, Aurelio Vidmar, Paul Trimboli, David Zdrilic, Stan Galloway 2005 FIFA Confederations Cup The Socceroos had a huge task ahead of them when they qualified for the 2005 FIFA Confederations Cup. Having to face the likes of Germany, Brazil, Mexico, Cameroon and Japan, the team looked good on paper, but were seen as underdogs by the majority of soccer experts. Nevertheless, the squad managed to reach the semi-finals of the tournament, where they were eventually knocked out by Brazil. Australia's final squad for the tournament was as followed: Goalkeepers: Mark Schwarzer, Zeljko Kalac Defenders: Lucas Neill, Ante Milicic, Tony Popovic, Tim Cahill, Brett Emerton, Craig Moore, Stan Lazaridis, Jade North Midfielders: Mark Bresciano, Vince Grella, Marco Bresciano, Josip Skoko, Carl Valeri, Scott Chipperfield Forwards: John Aloisi, John Tambouras, Archie Thompson, Brett Holman, David Carney 2006 FIFA World Cup The Socceroos faced a huge challenge when they had to qualify for the 2006 FIFA World Cup, having to make it through the famously difficult Asian qualifying group. In the end, however, the team achieved their goal with flying colors, finishing second in the group with a perfect nine wins out of nine matches. The final squad for the tournament was as followed: Goalkeepers: Mark Schwarzer, Brad Jones Defenders: Michael Beauchamp, Lucas Neill, Ante Milicic, Tony Popovic, Scott Chipperfield, Craig Moore Midfielders: Tim Cahill, Mark Bresciano, Marco Bresciano, Vince Grella, Josip Skoko, Stan Lazaridis, Brett Emerton, Mark Milligan Forwards: Mark Viduka, Harry Kewell, John Aloisi, Josh Kennedy, John Tambouras, Scott McDonald 2007 Asian Cup The Socceroos campaign for the 2007 Asian Cup was relatively successful, as they reached the final, where they were eventually knocked out by Japan. The squad for the tournament was as follows: Goalkeepers: Ante Covic, Zeljko Kalac Defenders: Brett Emerton, Vitezslav Lavicka, Michael Beauchamp, Lucas Neill, Tony Popovic, Michael Thwaite, Tahj Minniecon Midfielders: Jason Culina, Tim Cahill, Mark Bresciano, Marco Bresciano, Vince Grella, Scott Chipperfield, Josip Skoko, Brett Holman Forwards: Mark Viduka, Harry Kewell, Stan Lazaridis, John Aloisi, Paul Agostino 2015 Asian Cup The Socceroos enjoyed a fantastic Asian Cup campaign in 2015, winning their first-ever title in the tournament. The team went undefeated throughout the tournament, remaining unbeaten in all of their seven matches. The final squad for the tournament was

Montgomery Township is a township in Le Sueur County, Minnesota, United States. As of the 2010 census, the population was 542, making it the smallest township in Le Sueur County. The township was incorporated on April 9, 1858, and named for William E. Montgomery, an early settler of the area. The unincorporated community of Montgomery is located within the township. Montgomery Township is situated on the southeast corner of Le Sueur County and is bordered by Blooming Grove Township to the northeast, Kilkenny Township to the southeast, and Waterville Township to the south. The Minnesota River flows through the township, creating the boundary with Waterville Township. Agriculture is the primary land use in the township, with a majority of the land devoted to crop production. There are some wooded areas, primarily along the Minnesota River and the headwaters of Deep Creek. There are a few businesses located in Montgomery Township. They include a gas station/convenience store, a feed mill, and a sawmill. Montgomery Township is part of the Le Sueur-Henderson Public School District. The township is served by busing to the elementary, middle, and high schools in Henderson and Le Sueur. In addition to agriculture, recreational activities in the township can include fishing in the Minnesota River, boating from the public access in Montgomery, and hunting. Hunting on the township are both waterfowl and deer. Montgomery Township is governed by a three-member township board. The board is responsible for setting policy and for ensuring the operations of the township are within the bounds of the law. The board meets on the second Monday of each month, except for June and December, at the local community center. The Montgomery Township Fire Department, located in the unincorporated community of Montgomery, serves the township with fire protection. The township also contracts with the Le Sueur County Sheriff's Office for law enforcement services.

Alyssa Beckerman (born December 15, 1975) is an American author, public speaker, editor, and filmmaker. Born in Brooklyn, New York to two mental health professionals, Beckerman developed an interest in healthcare and social justice issues at a young age. In her early career, Beckerman worked in television production, first as a production coordinator in New York City, followed by a position at ABC Television serving as the assistant to the senior director. Beckerman left the TV industry in 2006 to pursue a career as a writer. She wrote her first novel, Love in Our Time, in 2007, which was an Amazon best seller and was published in multiple languages. In 2009, she wrote and produced a short film, Homeland, which won several awards, including an Accolade Award in the short film category. She also wrote a children's book in 2011, Buddies Make the Best Friends, which is currently being developed into a stage musical. Beckerman published her first collection of essays in 2016, Perspectives on Life’s Struggles, and has since written two additional books, My Personal Mental Health Journey and Between Courtrooms and Kitchens: A Collection of Travel Essays. In 2016, Beckerman founded a non-profit called H.O.P.E. (Helping Others Persevere and Excel). The organization works to promote mental health and provide access to resources to individuals and families affected by mental health issues. Beckerman speaks publicly on topics surrounding mental health and wellness. She is the host of the podcast, Mental Health Matters and has been featured in multiple publications, including the New York Times, Forbes, and HuffPost. Beckerman lives in New Jersey with her three sons and their pet bulldog.

The 2008 riot in Mongolia began as a protest on June 25, 2008 in the capital city of Ulaanbaatar. This mass protest was sparked by an announcement made by the Mongolian Government to demolish the legal and illegal dwellings and shops located around Sukhbaatar Square. This announcement by the Mongolian Government was to make way for a new commercial and residential project near the city's center. The protest began peacefully, but eventually evolved into a riot. Protesters clashed with the Mongolian police, and some protesters threw stones at the police and set fire to public buses. The rioters then spread to other parts of the city, targeting officials, banks, and symbols of government, including government buildings and the Mongolian Stock Exchange. In response, the Mongolian police used tear gas and water cannons to try and disperse the crowd. The rioting went on until the morning of June 26, when the Mongolian Government declared an emergency, sending 1,000 troops to the capital to help restore order. The riot resulted in over 1,000 arrests and more than 100 injuries among both protesters and police officers. The Mongolian government condemned the riot and labelled it an "attempt to destabilize the country." It was determined that government negligence and inadequate planning of the urban development project sparked the riot and fueled the discontent of citizens. The government set up a commission to investigate the incident, and the Mongolian Parliament eventually passed legislation to provide aid to those impacted by the demolition. In 2009, the Mongolian president offered an apology to those affected by the eviction. The 2008 riot in Mongolia was a major event in the country's history, and it serves as an important reminder of the need to consider public opinion and individual rights when governing a country.

RTHK TV 31, previously known as TVB Comet, is a 24-hour television channel owned and operated by the Hong Kong-based public broadcaster Radio Television Hong Kong (RTHK). It is the first dedicated free-to-air television channel in Hong Kong, launching on 31 December 2021. The channel's slogan is "Insightful and Entertaining". RTHK TV 31 mainly offers terrestrial channels which feature a variety of informational and leisure programs. The channel provides viewers with access to a wide range of local programs, from current affairs to documentaries, to music shows, to dramas. It also provides access to international channels for news, entertainment and educational content. In addition to providing scripted and documentary programs, RTHK TV 31 presents some live programming over the air. It broadcasts legislative and policy consultations, current affairs talk shows, musical shows and other special events. RTHK TV 31 wants to become a common medium for people to share ideas, emotions and experiences. The channel also aim to provide viewers with a unique transmission that they cannot get from other terrestrial or satellite broadcasters. The use of both analogue and digital signals allow this channel to reach many areas with high quality transmission. RTHK TV 31 also strives to become an Advanced Digital Television Satellite (ADTVS) service provider, once this technology is available. With this technology, viewers will be able to watch a range of programs from their TV sets without needing to pay for satellite services. This will bring a higher quality picture, with more interactive features and wider choice of services. RTHK TV 31 also has regular flagship shows like "One Day Special" and "Focus". The former is a special multi-lingual news programme that airs once a week, while the latter is a magazine-style show packed with interviews and documentaries. It is broadcast nightly and is hosted by well-known personalities from the region. RTHK TV 31 is a part of RTHK’s mission to provide quality broadcast media services in Hong Kong. The development of this channel will enable the public broadcaster to expand its audience and bring quality content to its viewers. The channel is aimed to broaden the local broadcasting landscape and bring benefit to all.

. Municipalities of Chiapas are administrative divisions of the Mexican state of Chiapas. The state is divided into 118 municipalities, which are grouped into eight regions. The municipalities consist of boroughs, administrative divisions of a municipality, and have their own municipal government. The municipality of Tuxtla Gutiérrez is the capital and largest city of the state. The largest municipality by area is Venustiano Carranza (6,927km2). The smallest is Cedral with 121.86km2. As of 2015, the population of the state was 5,165,082 inhabitants, distributed among the municipalities as follows: Comitán de Domínguez had the highest population with 378,082 inhabitants, while Cedral had the smallest population at 553 inhabitants. The municipalities of Chiapas are formally divided into boroughs, which are further divided into localities, colonias, ejidos and private properties. The municipalities were first established in the 19th century after the Mexican War of Independence. The municipalities have their own governments, with elected mayors and councillors. Those governments are responsible for public services such as public education, roads, public health, public safety, urbanization, and other local services. The most important economic activities in Chiapas are agriculture, fishing and forestry. Most of the municipalities are based in those activities. Mining is also important in some areas of the state, such as Zinacantán and San Cristóbal de las Casas. These municipalities are important producers of gold, silver, and other minerals. Tourism is also important in many of the municipalities in Chiapas. San Cristóbal de las Casas, Palenque, Comitán and Tuxtla Gutiérrez are the most visited municipalities in the state. These municipalities offer a mix of colonial architecture, natural attractions such as waterfalls and archaeological sites, as well as the gastronomic culture of the local towns. The municipalities of Chiapas offer a rich cultural heritage to all visitors from within Mexico and abroad. Their diverse landscapes, historic sites and vibrant economies offer a unique cultural experience for all.

"The Sound of Missing You" is a single recorded by American singer and songwriter Kelly Clarkson. It was released in the year 2021. The track written and composed by singer-songwriter John Brett, with production and vocal recording by Grammy Award-winning producer Scott Pagano. Clarkson’s vocals were recorded at Blackbird Studio in Nashville, TN. "The Sound of Missing You" receives lyrical inspiration from the yearning desire and longing for a lost lover. The track navigates feelings of nostalgia for a past love as well as its sense of absence. Through the lyrics, Clarkson expresses her own story of a “foreboding heartbreak” and grief of being disconnected from someone from the past. The track incorporates a combination of crisp acoustic guitar and soft synthesizers to achieve a dreamlike, intimate atmosphere. The overall sound reflects a desire for closure and allowing the past to exist in both physical and emotional space. The accompanying music video for "The Sound of Missing You" was released on the same day as the single. Directed by Kirsten Lepore, the video features a surrealist concept that emphasizes the watery sounds and visuals of the track itself. The video follows Clarkson as she moves through various imperfectly composed dreamscapes, as she grieves the absence of a past love and reflects on the mixture of emotions. The track has received universal acclaim. Critics praised the production and clever use of imagery in the visuals to illustrate the track’s themes of past longing and distance. Clarkson’s strong vocal delivery and emotionally charged performance were also praised. The single became a minor chart success, peaking at # 28 on the Billboard Hot 100 and #11 on the Hot Adult Contemporary Songs chart in the US. It was also a minor success on the UK Singles Chart, peaking at #77. "The Sound of Missing You" continues to be a popular song, with many fans praising it for its captivating lyrics, production, and emotional performance by Clarkson. In 2021, it was selected as the lead track off the international deluxe digital edition of Clarkson's compilation, Mixes.

NGC 3175 is an open cluster of stars located in the constellation of Sextans. It was discovered on April 26, 1793 by German astronomer William Herschel. NGC 3175 has an apparent magnitude of 10.8 and its distance from Earth is estimated to be about 12,400 light years. The stars in NGC 3175 are organized into a sparse grouping and are spread over an area of 10 arc minutes in the sky. The stars of the cluster range in spectral type from F through G to M, with the majority being late-type stars. In addition to its open cluster stars, NGC 3175 also contains several Herbig–Haro objects. These are formed when material such as gas and dust travelling away from a young star in jets gets slowed down and compressed by the interstellar medium, forming knots and nebulae. Most of the Herbig–Haro objects that have been detected in NGC 3175 are located near the southern edge of the cluster. Most of the stars in NGC 3175 are young, with a median age estimated to be about 6.8 million years. This indicates that the cluster is a relatively young star-formation region. The estimated total mass of the cluster is about 3000 times that of the Sun, with the brightest stars being about 10th magnitude. NGC 3175 is visible with a relatively small telescope, or even binoculars, in a dark sky. It is best viewed in March and April, and can be found within 5 degrees of the planet Uranus, and just over 6 degrees west of the bright star Spica. Despite its relatively close distance to Earth, and its relatively young age, only a few stars in NGC 3175 have been studied in any detail. In particular, the star HD 86134 has been found to be a red giant, and several others have been identified as binary stars. In addition, some stars in NGC 3175 display evidence of rapid rotation, which may be the result of close flybys of neighbouring stars. Due to its relative youth, NGC 3175 may be of particular interest to those studying star formation. A better understanding of the cluster, in particular its Herbig–Haro objects, may provide new insight into how stars form and interact with their surroundings.

The Ministry of Public Works (Ministerio de Obras Públicas - MOP) is a department of the government of Argentina responsible for setting and implementing public works policy. The MOP is divided into two main departments and two main activities. The two main departments are the Office of Planning and Coordination and the General Direction of Inland Transportation. The Office of Planning and Coordination is responsible for coordinating all federal activities related to public works and for analyzing the needs in the areas of transportation, water and sanitation, land management, energy and communications. The General Direction of Inland Transportation is responsible for developing, designing and constructing roads, highways, bridges and other infrastructure projects. The two main activities of the Ministry of Public Works are the elaboration of projects to be carried out by public or private means and the execution of public works in the various areas. The elaboration of projects includes feasibility studies, technical plans and designs, specifications, estimates and tender documents. The execution of public works includes projects such as the construction of roads, bridges, airports, harbors, dams, irrigation systems, electricity plants, water and sanitation systems and telecommunications networks. The mission of the Ministry of Public Works is to guarantee the development of efficient and cost effective public works projects in order to provide quality infrastructure services and products to the Argentine people. The ministry works in partnership with the other levels of government and private entities to contribute to the national development and to promote the efficient use of resources. The Ministry of Public Works is involved in many projects across the country, including large-scale public works such as the Ruiz de Velasco dam and the Alto Paraná hydroelectric plant in Corrientes Province. Other large-scale projects in progress include the construction of the Paraná-Santa Fe railway line and the expansion of the Santa Fe International Airport. The Ministry of Public Works is supervised by the Secretary of Public works, currently Jorge Triaca. The ministry has offices in all 23 provinces in Argentina. References: https://www.argentina.gob.ar/obras-publicas https://www.businessinsider.com/ministry-of-public-works-argentina-2016-1 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Public_Works_of_Argentina

Faith Newman is an American actress who is best known for her roles as Ben Newman on the popular television series Sam and Cat and as Vicky Duchamp in the Netflix fantasy drama series Warrior Nun. She is one of the youngest stars to be included in the cast of any major series or film. Faith Newman was born on April 28, 2009 in Santa Barbara, California, U.S. to Michael and Elizabeth Newman. She has an older brother Daniel Newman who is a professional basketball player. She began her acting career at the age of 7 appearing in several commercials and feature films. Her first major film role was as Ben Newman in Sam and Cat, a Nickelodeon series that ran from 2013-2014. In 2015, Faith Newman co-starred as Vicky Duchamp in the Netflix fantasy drama series Warrior Nun. Faith Newman has had a special affinity for performing since her earliest years. She attended a prestigious performing arts program in Los Angeles and has performed in numerous plays and musicals. She had the honor of performing with the Off-Broadway cast of Pilobolus and with the Los Angeles based Andrew Sisters. Faith's film and television credits include appearances in the Disney Channel ‘’Camp Rock 2: The Final Jam’’, ‘’Orange is the New Black’’, and ‘’Gortimer Gibbon’s Life on Normal Street’’. In addition to television and film, Faith Newman has cultivated a successful musical career as well. She has performed with various musical acts and released three solo singles. Her single ‘’Never Gonna Leave You’’ reached number 4 on the Billboard Hot 100. 2020 was a very big year for Faith Newman as she starred in the lead role alongside famous actors Jason Segel and Juno Temple in the romantic comedy ‘’Our Friend’’. This was her first feature film in the lead role and she has earned many accolades for her performance. Faith Newman is an inspiring young actress and will surely be a star to look out for in the future.

Olbia Costa Smeralda Airport (IATA: OLB) (former name Olbia-Tempio Airport) is an international airport in Olbia, Sardinia, Italy. It is the main airport in the north-east of the island and the main gateway to the popular beach resort of Costa Smeralda. The airport is operated by GE.S.A.C. (Società di Gestione dell'Aeroporto di Olbia-Costa Smeralda), which also handles traffic for other Sardinian airports such as Alghero Airport and Cagliari Airport. Opened in 1964, the airport is located 5 km (3.1 mi) north-east of Olbia and covers an area of 330 hectares (820 acres). It is connected to the city centre of Olbia and to the nearby town of Golfo Aranci by a taxi and shuttle services. The airport has one runway, 16/34, which is 2,300 metres (7,546 ft) long and paved in asphalt. The arrival hall of the airport has been recently renovated in order to provide passengers with improved services and comfort. It is equipped with multiple shops, restaurants, bars and duty-free outlets. The departure lounge is located on the first floor and is equipped with modern facilities. Furthermore, it provides passengers with car rental services, a parking area and a VIP lounge. In terms of air traffic, the airport boasts direct flights with major Italian destinations such as Rome, Milan, Turin and Florence. Moreover, there are domestic and international flights operating to major European countries such as Germany, Spain, France, Portugal, Belgium and the United Kingdom. In 2020, the airport handled 2.76 million passengers. Furthermore, in the same year it was recorded a total of 8,922 aircraft movements and managed to record a total of 72.608 tons of goods. The airport is served by many airlines, often in partnership with partner airlines. Some of the carriers operating out of Olbia include: Alitalia, Blu-express, Easyjet, Ryanair, Vueling, Wizz Air and Neos. In addition to the regular scheduled flights, the airport also serves seasonal and charter flights which operate during summer. Overall, Olbia Costa Smeralda Airport is a major gateway for passengers wishing to visit the north-east of Sardinia and the beautiful Costa Smeralda. In the future, the airport is plans to expand the existing facilities to provide passengers with a better experience.

The Sisters of the Infant Jesus (S.I.J.) are a Roman Catholic religious congregation of women founded in 1673 in France by Father Pierre Lambert de la Motte. It is a monastic institute of pontifical law, or a Third Order Regular. The institute was founded for the purpose of educating the young and educating the poor. The Sisters of the Infant Jesus have served in a variety of settings, including parochial schools, hospitals, orphanages, colleges, and homes for those with physical and mental disabilities. Today, the worldwide congregation has over 1,500 members in 75 countries. The rule of life adapted by the original founders was composed by Father Lambert and Sister Jeanne de Beuzy, who both dedicated themselves to the service of the poor and young. This Rule prescribed a distinct spirituality which focused on duty and service, the internal life of prayer, self-denial, manual labor, and the union of the life of each sister to that of Our Lord Jesus Christ and His Blessed Mother Mary. The congregation has suffered three suppressions during its history, yet has managed to regain its status as a religious institute. Before his death in 1690, Father Lambert was able to renew this suppression in 1681, with the approval of Pope Innocent XI; he had done the same in 1683 and 1697. The congregation was thus able to continue its work of Christian formation, education, and aid to the poor and needy. The Sisters of the Infant Jesus opened more than 70 foundations in France, Belgium, England, Scotland, India, Mexico, and South America. Their work expanded to include work in diocesan colleges, parishes, hospitals, homes for the aged and handicapped, care for disturbed youth, homes for single mothers and homeless women, and various other forms of outreach. In 1962, the sisters opened their first American foundation in Nebraska, USA. This expanded to include facilities in other states, and today there are over 30 American communities. They work in a variety of capacities in the youth ministry, care for the aged, health care and education, and outreach to serve the needs of those who are poor and vulnerable. The sisters continue to live according to their charisms of the love of God and the love of neighbor and seek to spread this same love to all they serve.

Dadaloğlu is a small village located in the central district of Koltepeli, Turkey. The village is situated at the northeast of Afşar Coast and is mainly inhabited by families of Zoroastrian heritage. The population of Dadaloğlu is approximately 150 people and is one of the few remaining villages of its kind. The origins of Dadaloğlu can be traced back to the 16th century and it is believed to have been founded by a certain Davud Agha Dadaloğlu. This was during the time of great migrations of Zoroastrian and other ethnic groups from the Caucasus and Iran, who were escaping invasions by the Ottoman Empire. The migrants settled on the nearby Afşar Coast, and Dadaloğlu provided protection and security to those who sought refuge there. The villagers of Dadaloğlu are known for their simple way of life and close-knit community. They live in small family houses with few amenities and rely on subsistence farming for their food and income. They grow mostly wheat, barley, and other grains, as well as grapes for wine-making. Their main method of transportation are donkeys and horses. The main language of the inhabitants is Persian, and it is interspersed with Turkish words, creating a unique dialect of the two languages. Despite the language, the people of Dadaloğlu maintain their Zoroastrian faith and beliefs. They celebrate a variety of festivals throughout the year, including the Nowruz (the Persian New Year) and the Masar (the feast for wine-making). The village of Dadaloğlu is best seen during the morning and evening, when the surrounding hills, valleys, and sea provide stunning views. Many locals also take visitors to other nearby villages in the area, to experience traditional trades and crafts such as kite-making, bee-keeping and rug-weaving. The village of Dadaloğlu is a reminder of a forgotten history and an important example of the vibrant Zoroastrian culture and heritage. It is a place where the old world has been preserved and is a remarkable place to visit and experience.

Robin Hood, West Yorkshire is an area of West Yorkshire, England located around 11 miles from Leeds. It is a small village in the city of Wakefield, and is named after the legendary outlaw Robin Hood. History Robin Hood, West Yorkshire is a small village located in the City of Wakefield in West Yorkshire, England. It is believed to have first been settled in the 12th century. In 1851, the population of Robin Hood, West Yorkshire was recorded as 498. By the mid-20th century, the population had increased to 1,261 due to its proximity to Leeds, and it had become a populous village. Points of Interest Robin Hood, West Yorkshire features several notable locations and attractions. It is primarily a residential village with many churches and other ecclesiastical buildings. St Nicholas Parish Church, St Anthony's R C Church, and the Maudsley Congregational Church are three of the most popular sites in the area. In addition, a number of pubs make up the village. The Robin Hood Pub and The Pheasant Inn are both popular spots that serve food and beverages. There is also a select number of shops and businesses located within the village. These range from small convenience stores to larger retail stores. Notable People Several notable people have resided in and around the village of Robin Hood, West Yorkshire. These include writer and poet Peter Benson, and actors Ian McKellen and Bryan Pringle. Education Robin Hood, West Yorkshire is home to a number of educational facilities. The Wakefield City Academy is located in the village, as is the Robin Hood Primary School. Both primary and secondary schools are part of Robin Hood Academy, an independent academy run by Wakefield Council. Conclusion Robin Hood, West Yorkshire is an area of West Yorkshire with a history steeped in legend, and is home to a variety of points of interest, pubs, shops, churches and educational facilities. Several notable people have called the village home, and the village continues to be a popular residential area.

Brannigan, Begin Again is a 1980 British-American action comedy film directed by Douglas Hickox, and starring John Cleese, Richard Mulligan, and Attila the Hun. The film is set in Great Britain and centers on a detective and his investigation into the theft of a valuable jewel. The film focuses on Chief Inspector George Brannigan (John Cleese), a bumbling but competent detective of Scotland Yard, who is assigned the case of tracking down a priceless jewel named The Eye of Pitari. In trying to crack the case, Brannigan soon finds himself embroiled in a far bigger mystery involving the jewel, the shady dealings of the crime boss Attila the Hun, and the activities of mysterious secret societies. The first half of the film follows Brannigan's investigation as he interviews witnesses and follows clues, eventually leading him to a glamorous nightclub owned by Attila the Hun, who has connections to the criminal world. Along the way, Brannigan gains assistance from a mysterious mysterious British secret agent (played by Richard Mulligan) and several members of the criminal underworld. In the second half of the film, Brannigan and his allies go on a mission to retrieve the stolen jewel. The mission, however, is fraught with danger, and as the group are pursued by Attila and his thugs, Brannigan is forced to come up with a daring plan to outwit his adversaries. Once the jewel is retrieved, Brannigan and his team race against time to prevent it from falling into the wrong hands. Ultimately, Brannigan, Begin Again is a fun, lighthearted comedy that offers plenty of witty comedy and slapstick action sequences. The film has attained cult status among fans of John Cleese, and has become somewhat of an icon of British film comedy. In addition, the film has received critical praise for its clever dialogue, pacing, and entertaining visual style.

Colonial Forge High School is a comprehensive public high school located in Stafford, Virginia. It is the only secondary educational facility in the Stafford County Public Schools, which serves grades 9 through 12. Opened in 1998, the school serves the areas of Stafford, Falmouth, Brooke, and Aquia Harbour, as well as parts of southern Prince William County. The student body consists of over 2,000 students in the 2019–20 school year. The mission of Colonial Forge High School is to inspire, challenge, and motivate each student to achieve their highest potential through opportunities to participate in diverse educational experiences. Established values of respect, responsibility, and integrity guide students on their pathway to success. The school offers a variety of coursework and advanced academic programs, including AP classes and college-level classes offered by partnerships with local universities. The school also offers a wide variety of extracurricular activities for students to participate in, including athletics, performing and visual arts, student publications, and community service opportunities. Students also have the opportunity to join over 40 student-run clubs, including FBLA and DECA. Colonial Forge High School has earned recognition from U.S. News & World Report, being ranked #7 in Virginia and #234 in the nation. The school has a college-readiness rating of 47.2, and offers a variety of college-preparatory programs and resources for students to help with their transition to college. The athletic program has also achieved success with their teams consistently winning district championships. Colonial Forge High School has worked to build a strong and committed community through its events and initiatives, from themed spirit Weeks to the school's annual "Grateful" Day. On Grateful Day, students and staff join together to recognize and show appreciation for their School and community. The school’s motto is “Student Achievement is Our Plan” which serves as a reminder to every student and staff member to take all the necessary steps to ensure that all students are receiving the best education possible. This motto, combined with a strong community, has forged a successful school that continues to strive for educational excellence.

Jody Harris (born 1950) is an American musician and songwriter, best known for his significant contributions to the punk and experimental music genres. He is most well-known for being a founding member, guitarist and co-songwriter for the groundbreaking funk-punk trio, The Contortions. Harris was born and raised in a small town in northern California. At age 16, he moved to Los Angeles and soon after, began attending California Institute of the Arts, studying art and design. It was during this period that Harris was bitten by the music bug. He bought his first guitar, began teaching himself how to play, and soon formed the group, The Contortions, with fellow students and future Punk Hall-of-Famers, Richard Hell, Pat Place and Adele Bertei. With Harris as a major contributor to the group’s unique mixture of punk, funk and art-rock, The Contortions developed an immense underground following. The group’s debut album, Buy (1978), is still considered one of the most innovative and influential albums in punk history. Harris also recorded two solo albums during his time with The Contortions: Need for Not (1980), and Escape Artist (1981). Both albums were critically acclaimed and showcased Harris’s talent as a forward-thinking musician and innovative songwriter. After leaving The Contortions in 1982, Harris moved to New York City and became an integral part of the city’s No Wave scene. He joined legendary experimentalists Material and founded the avant-rock collective 8-Eyed Spy. The two groups blended a variety of genres into a wild, mostly instrumental mixture of hard rock, electronic funk and free jazz. In 1985, Harris recorded his third solo album, Big Apple Heartbeat, an unconventional mix of raw industrial percussion and art-punk. Harris’s involvement in the music scene shifted in 1987 when he became a Fulbright Scholar at the Institute of Sonology in the Netherlands. There, he realized the potential of advanced technology and computers to radically manipulate sound. In the late 1980s and early ‘90s, Harris extensively explored the boundaries of electro-acoustic music, computer and video art. Now living in upstate New York, Harris continues his work as a musician, technician, producer and composer. During the 2000s, he returned to more song-based works, creating a large body of solo work that is entirely his own. His current projects include Escapades, an album of intricate, sophisticated and infectious crossover rock. Today, Harris is universally recognized as an instrumental pioneer in the realms of avant-rock, punk and experimental music. He remains an active and respected figure on the music scene, and one of the key musical visionaries of the past four decades.

John Marlay (d. 1790) was a British lawyer and politician who served in Parliament from 1768 to 1790. Born in Yorkshire, England, Marlay studied at Cambridge University before entering into law in London as an attorney-at-law. Marlay was a noted speaker in the House of Commons and was an important figure during the debates leading up to the American Revolution. Marlay served two terms as a Member of Parliament for Droitwich. During his first term, Marlay was an advocate of taxation reform, which was unpopular with British Colonists in the American colonies. He famously argued for more equitable taxation between Britain and its colonies. When the American Revolution began in 1776, Marlay argued in favor of a peaceful settlement and proposed reforms to the Crown's relationship with its American colonies. However, his colleagues disagreed, and he refused to support war. As the war wore on, Marlay proposed several reforms to Parliament that sought to bring attention to the grievances of the colonists in an attempt to avert further violence. In 1782, he introduced the Peace of Conciliation Bill, a legislative resolution to the conflict, which was not accepted. Later that same year, he proposed a compromise to the impasse, but it was not approved by Parliament. Towards the end of his life, Marlay was appointed as the chairman of a committee to investigate the situation in the former colonies. He advocated for a lenient approach to reviving and restoring much of the original American government and the rights of the colonists. Marlay passed away in 1790, but his legacy remains to this day.
