He was an early adopter of the concept of a unified government supporting the rights of its citizens, which he saw as one of the most important qualities of a successful nation. He was an essential figure in the early evolution of British colonial policy and is remembered for his efforts to protect the rights of American colonists.

Adjumani District is located in the West Nile sub-region of Northern Uganda, near the International borders of both South Sudan and the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and is part of the larger Gulu district. It is the second most populous district in West Nile, with a population estimated at 133,319 inhabitants in 2016. The district was initially known as Amidu District but was renamed Adjumani District in 2001. It is divided into eight sub-counties that range from mountains to lowlands, making it one of the most diverse districts in terms of climate and topography. Economically, Adjumani is one of the poorest districts in Uganda. It is classified as a rural district, and despite numerous initiatives over the years, poverty levels remain high. The major sources of income are fishing and small-scale farming, though the latter is limited due to the poor infrastructure in the area. Adjumani is home to a variety of ethnic groups, notably the Kakwa, Lugbara, and Madi. The Kakwa, Lugbara and Madi are among the many language groups found in this district, the others being Acholi, Langipiri, Lope and Boro. Education is another major challenge in the district. Most schools are overcrowded and lack basic facilities, and teachers are often not properly trained. As result, the district is lagging behind in educational standards compared to other districts in Uganda. Adjumani District is known for its dramatic landscapes, as well as its wildlife, which includes the Congo peafowl and the African buffalo. In spite of its many challenges, Adjumani is a great place to explore and appreciate the richness of Northern Uganda’s culture and natural beauty.

List of Great Britain by-elections (1715–1734) are elections to the legislative bodies of Great Britain during the years of 1715 to 1734. During this period, there were a number of general elections for seats in the House of Commons, as well as numerous by-elections. A number of seats were uncontested in various constituencies. 1715 At the general election of 1715, the last elections to the pre-union English and Scottish parliaments, there were four by-elections. In England, Thomas Pitt of Old Sarum, Wiltshire was elected unopposed and William Proby in Northamptonshire. In Scotland, the two by-elections were in Ayrshire (surname unknown) and Forfar Burghs (John Milne). 1722 In 1722, only one by-election took place in England as George Hardinge was elected unopposed in Camelford. 1727 The 1727 election saw four by-elections, with Henry Florence elected unopposed in the City of London, William Leveson Gower in Staffordshire, Robert Bowles in Wiltshire, and John Freke in Bridport. 1734 At the general election in 1734, three by-elections were held. William Dodd was elected unopposed in Abingdon, John Wyndham in Gloucestershire, and Ralph Verney in Buckinghamshire. Conclusion The List of Great Britain by-elections (1715–1734) are a collection of elections held in Great Britain during the years of 1715 to 1734, which include four by-elections during the general election of 1715, one by-election in 1722, four by-elections in 1727, and three by-elections during the 1734 general election. These elections were for seats in the House of Commons and some were uncontested.

White face is an act of painting an individual's face or body with a white substance, intended to create a blank or featureless facial or body expression. It is commonly used in theater, dance, mime, and other performance art genres such as clowning, street performance, and drag performance. Although white face is typically used to express uniformity and to emphasize the performer's eyes, mouth, and other facial features, some people also use white face to make a political or cultural statement. White face is a popular performance art dating back to Ancient Greece and Rome. During these time periods, the white face was used to convey gender roles, with men wearing white make up to appear more masculine and women wearing it to appear more feminine. Some notable figures from the Theatre of Ancient Greece such as Thespis and Aeschylus also used white face as a means to convey expression, as noted in historical accounts such as the writings of Aristophanes. In the 20th century, theater groups such as the Moscow Art Theatre, founded by Konstantin Stanislavski and Viakislav Meyerhold, popularized the usage of white face. The two directors believed that performances were enhanced when the actor was able to convey emotion and expression through subtle shifts in facial expression, gesture, and vocal delivery. Today, white face is commonly used in theatre, dance, mime and other contemporary performance art genres. Professional clowns, street performers, and drag performers may also incorporate white face into their act. White face is usually paired with theatrical makeup in order to express an emotion or message. In many places, white face is discouraged due to its history of being associated with racism and White supremacy. Supporters of cultural appropriation argue that white face is an artistic form used to express emotions or ideas that should not be suppressed. Conversely, opponents of such appropriation argue that performers should not be able to appropriate a culture by using elements that are historically or traditionally associated with a culture they don't belong to. In most contemporary performance art, white face should not be used without permission, either from an audience or the performers themselves. Regardless of views on cultural appropriation, white face is a centuries old form of theatre that still has the potential to make powerful statements and elicit powerful emotions from audiences.

You've Got This is a popular phrase associated with self-empowerment. It is used to illustrate the belief that with a positive attitude, determination and hard work, anything is possible. The phrase "You've Got This" is often used as an inspirational tool to motivate individuals to persevere through difficult times and to challenge themselves to do things that are out of their comfort zone. It is a reminder that with the right attitude and effort, anything can be achieved. The phrase gained popularity in the late 90s and early 2000s when it was commonly seen on bumper stickers. It quickly gained recognition as a positive and motivational message to encourage individuals and build confidence. More recently, it has been used in popular media, television, and film to illustrate a feeling of strength and determination. The phrase has also been applied in a range of cases in education, business, health, and sports. It has been used to illustrate the mindset of individuals going through changes or difficult moments in life. It is often used and printed in motivational posters and posters given to athletes as a reminder of their focus and determination. You've Got This has become known as a powerful statement of self-empowerment, encouraging individuals to continue towards their goals no matter what. It is a reminder to push ourselves, remain focused, and work hard despite the obstacles in front of us. The phrase has become a popular hashtag online as a way for individuals to encourage each other to reach their goals. Popular images using the hashtag display the phrase painted on objects, printed as signs, or written on walls. Even brands have adopted the phrase to promote their products as a way to emphasize the idea of strength and confidence. You've Got This has become an iconic phrase for self-empowerment, and is often used as a way to inspire and motivate others to achieve success and greatness. It is a reminder that anything can be achieved if enough drive and perseverance is put into it.

Nadir Ali Khan (1955-2003) was a Pakistani-American writer, poet, and artist. He was born in the city of Peshawar, Pakistan and later moved to Los Angeles, California. He was best known for his books, The Horizon of Hope and Timeless Shadows, which were semi-autobiographical works exploring the challenges of living in two vastly different cultures. Khan's life's work combined both the spiritual and artistic traditions of his childhood in Pakistan with themes of his adopted American home. His work explored the complexity of contemporary life and the shifting nature of identity. In addition to books and essays, Khan was a passionate painter and film-maker. He was an early advocate of multi-cultural storytelling, using the medium of visual art. His works featured characters from different cultural backgrounds coming together in unexpected ways. Khan began writing in 1979, although it was another four years before The Horizon of Hope was published in 1983. The novel won him acclaim within the literary world and was adapted into a stage play in Los Angeles. Khan went on to write several more books and collaborate on film projects before moving to San Francisco in the mid-1990s. Khan often talked of the difficulty of being an outsider in two cultures. Being in a place but not belonging to it, as he once said. He explored the intricacies of cross-cultural communication in his later writing, striving to build understanding of shared humanity through his art, both visual and literary. Much of his work focused on the struggles of immigrants in both countries and the emotional longing for a sense of home. Khan passed away in 2003 in San Francisco at the age of 47. His legacy continues through his writings, films, and paintings, all of which still inspire and move their audiences. His works have been translated into Spanish and Urdu and exhibited in galleries and universities in the United States and abroad. In 2013, a museum in Karachi, Pakistan was named in his honor, launching a foundation and annual awards program devoted to the preservation of his cultural works.

The 10th century of Muslim history spanned from 900 A.D. to 999 A.D. It saw the rise of numerous Islamic empires and dynasties in the Middle East, North Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. These empires and dynasties made significant contributions to Muslim culture, science and the arts. This timeline outlines some of the major events that occurred during this important century of Muslim history. 900 A.D.: Muslim armies, led by the general Ṭāriq ibn Ziyād, capture the city of Córdoba in present-day Spain. This marks the start of the Islamic rule in the Iberian Peninsula, which would last for several centuries. 902 A.D.: The Fatimid dynasty is established in Tunisia, Algeria and later Egypt. This dynasty would go on to become one of the major Islamic powers of the age and its capital, Cairo, would become a major cultural and intellectual center. 905 A.D.: Al-Shawkani, a famous Muslim jurist, publishes the first volume of his book, Badāʾiʿ al-Sināʿatayn (The Unique Miracle), setting the foundation for Islamic jurisprudence in the 10th century. 905–925 A.D.: The Buyid dynasty, founded by brothers Ahmad and Shirdawy, establishes its rule in present-day Iraq, Iran, Syria and parts of Central Asia. This dynasty is known for its patronage of the sciences, philosophy and art. 923 A.D.: The Ghaznavid empire is established in parts of modern-day Pakistan, India, parts of Central Asia and Iran. This Turkic dynasty is known for its military conquests and patronage of the arts. 945 A.D.: The Ikhshidid dynasty is founded in Egypt and Syria, where it rules until 1200. This dynasty is known for its contributions to art and architecture. 969 A.D.: The Fatimids conquer Egypt and establish their capital in Cairo. This marks a new period of prosperity for the region and the spread of Islam in the region. 981 A.D.: The Ghaznavids conquer Punjab in present-day Pakistan and India. This marks the peak of the empire, which leads to the spread of Islamic culture and learning in the region. 993 A.D.: Al-Firabi, one of the greatest Islamic philosophers of all time, dies in Damascus. His contributions to science and philosophy set the foundations for later works in the fields of logic and philosophy. 999 A.D.: The Fatimid Caliphate reaches its peak of power and influence. This marks the climax of Islamic power in the 10th century. The 10th century is regarded as an important and formative period for Islamic countries and civilizations. It saw the development of several powerful Muslim empires and the spread of Islamic culture and learning throughout the world.

Puelche language, also known as Pehuenche, is an extinct language that was spoken by the Huilliche individuals of southern Chile and Argentina. The language was mainly spoken by individuals living in the northern part of Patagonia on the Chile-Argentina border and had no written form. The Puelche language was first discovered by Spanish and Portuguese loanwordz by Jesuit priest Bernardino Gil y Taboada in 1797 and the language was subsequently studied by Wilhelm von Humboldt. The language is related to the languages of the Chon, Tehuelche, Teushen and Chonan individuals who share a few linguistic commonalities as demonstrated by Georgy Charinov in 1970. In some cases, words from the Puelche language were adopted into Chilean Spanish, such as the word puelche itself which refers to clothes or something from the north. The Puelche language is a polysynthetic language, meaning words are often composed of multiple numerous components. It also makes use of unique systems of voice and mood to indicate the speaker's attitude. Furthermore, Puelche has a large number of particle words which have been used to refer to specific aspects of life and culture such as games, animals, and plants. Though Puelche is now extinct, its influence can be found in the languages of Mapuche and Araucanian. Though the Puelche language number of speakers has decreased significantly since the 19th century, there are still a few speakers in some communities in Northern Chubut and Río Negro, Argentina. There is still a lack of literature and research related to Puelche, which is why it is often referred to as a “lost” language. Puelche has important historical-cultural relevance in the region. It serves as a bridge between the indigenous Huilliche culture and the Mapuche culture, connecting them to the Southern Cone region. Moreover, it is used to gain insight into the cultures, modes of thinking and traditions of the Huilliche, which can inform modern day cultural practices. Further research about Puelche is necessary to accurately document the lives, customs and history of these individuals. Though the language is now extinct, it will continue to live on through the history and legacy of the Huilliche and their descendants. There is still much that can be learned from the study of Puelche, and the language holds an important place in the larger cultural mosaic of Argentina and Chile that cannot be forgotten.

Jannat Ki Talash (English: Search for Heaven) is a 2018 Indian Hindi-language drama film written and directed by Mujeeb Khan, produced by Avnit Bhargava. It stars actors like Kapil Jain, Razia Abbasi, Komal Jain, Shrishti Sharma and Kanchan Gupta in the lead roles. The film revolves around the life of Suhail (Kapil Jain), a police officer tasked with solving a difficult case. He sets out on a mission to find the truth and justice in a forgotten story of his father’s. During his pursuit, he meets some extraordinary people and discovers some extraordinary secrets which lead him to an unimaginable discovery. Jannat Ki Talash was shot in scenic locations of Rajasthan. It earned an opening day gross of INR 32 Lakh and was praised by many film critics. The movie got an A rating from the Central Board of Film Certification (CBFC). The film tells a story of hope, faith, perseverance and self-discovery set against the backdrop of rural India. Beautiful songs, a riveting story and captivating cinematography have helped the film draw audiences at the box office. Jannat Ki Talash received rave reviews for its strong narrative, thoughtful script and creative execution. The film is credited for fostering changes in the way young people look at life and its values. The film was declared a blockbuster hit in India and was praised for its lyrical soundtrack and captivating visuals. The film is a moral drama, with an underlying theme of justice and the values of sacrifice and responsibility. The film has touched millions of people through its beautiful and strong story and is remembered for its strong message of overcoming all odds. Jannat Ki Talash is an emerging cult classic and a reminder of faith and hope when faced with a difficult situation. It has become an incredible cinematic journey that stays with its fans long after the credits roll.

Jamie Driscoll is an English politician and leader of the North of Tyne Combined Authority. He has been the leader of the combined authority since 2018, and has a key role in developing and delivering an ambitious programme to reduce inequality gap and ensure fairness for everyone living in the North of Tyne. Jamie was born in the North East of England, and has lived here all his life. He studied French, Spanish and Italian at the University of Newcastle, later teaching the languages at a local college. Jamie's political career began in 2001 when he was elected as a Labour councillor for North Tyneside. During his time on the council he held many different roles including Cabinet Member for Adult Learning, Cabinet Member for Neighbourhoods and Cabinet Member for Culture. In 2013, Jamie was elected as a Member of Parliament for North Tyneside, where he continued to be a vocal advocate for the region's communities. Jamie pushed for improvements in transport, health and education, and provided a reliable source of support to those in need. In 2018, following a highly successful local election campaign, Jamie was appointed as the leader of the North of Tyne Combined Authority. In this role he is responsible for delivering economic growth and building a better, fairer North East. Jamie works closely with local government, businesses and residents to shape the future of the area. This includes balancing the need to deliver smart and sustainable economic development while tackling the issues of inequality and social exclusion. With his ability to bring people together from all walks of life, Jamie has become an inspiring role model for many in the region. In 2019, he was listed by CNN as one of their nine political heroes for his dedication to creating a brighter future for his constituents. Jamie is married to Juliet and they have two children. He enjoys running, reading, attending political events and playing guitar.

Hugo Matthysen (born 20 October 1971 in Tervuren) is a Belgian musician and former singer of the Belgian music group K's Choice. Matthysen grew up in a musical family. His father Jean-Marie Matthysen was a professional cellist and conductor, while his mother Leen was a singer and vocal coach. At the age of ten, Hugo Matthysen began learning to play the guitar and by age fourteen was writing his own songs. His sister Sarah began singing in choirs with him and they eventually formed the band K's Choice, which rose to international fame in their native Belgium and across Europe. K's Choice achieved their biggest success with the album Almost Happy (1997). Their next album, Cocoon Crash (1999), saw their profile increase even further in Europe. In the United States, one of their most successful songs "Not an Addict" achieved major success. The band's success allowed them to tour the world and perform to sold-out audiences. In 2004, K's Choice decided to go their separate ways and Hugo Matthysen embarked upon a solo career. His debut album, This Is Me (2004) was a mix of pop and acoustic rock and went on to peak at number one on the Belgian charts. He has since released five more albums - The Art of Listening (2007), Until I Find You (2009), Soul of the Earth (2010), Moving (2013), and Let the Sparks Fly (2016). Throughout his career, Matthysen has also performed and collaborated with numerous other artists. In 2012, he teamed up with Belgium's most popular singer and composer, Andreas Pleitgen, to release the album Silver Dream. Matthysen has also composed music for strings and piano and released a string concerto in 2010. He often still performs with his sister Sarah, and they recently reunited the original K's Choice lineup for several live shows. In July 2016, to mark the 20th anniversary of their first album and the reunion of K's Choice, Hugo and Sarah released an acoustic version of their hit song "Not an Addict". The acoustic performance was well-received and reaffirmed their loyal fan base. Hugo and Sarah also released a joint album in 2017, titled Great Stuff. Today, Hugo Matthysen is still performing solo, but is also creating music for film and television. He is a celebrated musician in Belgium and often contributes to charitable causes. He has also received numerous awards, including an Edison Award for Best Pop Artist in 2009.

Sheila Frahm (born 1952) is an American politician and former U.S. Senator from Kansas. She served in both the United States Senate and United States House of Representatives, representing Kansas from 1991 to 1996. Frahm was born in 1952 in Hutchinson, Kansas, the daughter of a Methodist minister and homemaker. She attended Hutchinson Community College, majoring in mathematics and business. She obtained her bachelor's degree in business administration from Wichita State University in 1974. From 1980 to 1984, Frahm served in the Kansas House of Representatives, representing District 24 (Reno and Rice counties) during the 74th and 75th legislative sessions. During her first year, she was appointed to chair the Committee on Higher Education. She then became the first woman Director at the Kansas Department of Employment Security in 1985. In 1990, Frahm was elected to the United States House of Representatives representing the Second Congressional District of Kansas. She served two terms from 1991 to 1995. In January 1995, Frahm was sworn in as the first woman to serve in the U.S. Senate from Kansas when Bob Dole resigned to become the Republican nominee for president. She was appointed by Governor Bill Graves to fill the vacancy and served in the Senate until January of 1996. During her time in the Senate, Frahm was highly focused on making education more accessible and affordable for all Americans. She was a strong supporter of Title IX and the National and Community Service Trust Act. She also played an integral role in passing the Clean Air and Clean Water Acts, and actively advocated on behalf of those who served in the Persian Gulf War. Frahm was a strong voice for economic stimulus in areas of Kansas adversely affected by the closing of a local military base. She supported House passage of the base closure bill and fought to secure over a million additional dollars for the base and to ensure that local projects retained their overall federal funding. Since her time in the Senate, Frahm has worked in both the public and private sector. She is currently the President/CEO of Crossroads Strategies, a public relations and consulting firm based in Kansas. She resides in both Topeka and Leawood, Kansas.

UC San Diego Tritons men's basketball is the men's basketball program at the University of California, San Diego (UC San Diego). They are a member of the Big West Conference in Division I of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA). The team has competed in the NCAA Division II National Championship tournament multiple times and reached the Elite 8 (top 8 teams) in both 2005 and 2006. The current head coach is Eric Olen, who is entering his sixth season at the helm of the Tritons. Olen has lead the team to two conference tournament championships, in 2014 and 2015 respectively, and they finished in the top 3 of the Big West Conference every season under his leadership. In the 2018–19 season, the Tritons finished with an overall record of 19–11, earning a Big West Tournament birth for the fifth time under Olen and the second in as many years. The Triton's home court is the RIMAC Arena. Its capacity is 5,100 for basketball games. The UC San Diego Athletics Program has won the NCAA DII Commissioner's Cup for the California Collegiate Athletic Association five times since their move from DII to DI in 2020. The Tritons had its most successful team in 2005-06, where they went 25-7 and became the fifth team in NCAA basketball history to go undefeated in conference play. They would eventually reach the Elite 8 of the Division II National Championship tournament before losing in the semifinal. The team has produced numerous All-American honorees, including current NBA player Nate Dunn, who was a two-time All-American with UC San Diego. The team also had five All-West Region and five All-California Collegiate Athletic Association selections in the 2020–21 season. The Tritons were able to win the Big West Conference Championship in both 2014 and 2015, making them the only team in Big West history to win back-to-back championships in the modern era. The Tritons have a long and decorated history in collegiate basketball and have enjoyed tremendous success both in the regular season and in postseason tournaments. With their move to Division I in 2020, the team looks to build off a successful past and continue their successful program in the Big West.

Nine Stories Productions is a film and television production company based in Los Angeles, California. Founded in 2013 by Academy Award-nominated film producer Marc Platt and television producers Adam Siegel and Adam Shulman, the company is known for producing award-winning films, television series, and live theater events. The company produces content across a variety of genres, with particular focus on contemporary storytelling. Its works have been recognized with numerous accolades, including Academy Award nominations, Golden Globe and Emmy Award wins, and BAFTA nominations. Their first foray into feature film production was the 2019 drama Beautiful Boy, starring Timothée Chalamet and Steve Carell. The film tells the story of a father trying to cope with his son's addiction and earned two Academy Award nominations for Chalamet and Carell, as well as a Critics' Choice Award for Best Actor in a Drama for Chalamet. In 2020, Nine Stories produced The Trial of the Chicago 7, written and directed by Aaron Sorkin. The film follows the trial of seven activists charged with inciting a riot at the 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago and earned six Academy Award nominations. Nine Stories is currently in production on the untitled David O. Russell project starring Christian Bale, Margot Robbie, and Michael B. Jordan. The film is the company's second collaboration with the director, following their 2020 limited series adaptation of the novel, The Worst Year of My Life Again. Nine Stories also produces theater events to support the release of their work. Notable events include the afterparty for The Trial of the Chicago 7 at the Laemmle Theatres in Los Angeles, and a performance by artist Spencer Ludwig in celebration of the release of Beautiful Boy. In 2020, Nine Stories launched a consultancy division that provides development and production services to content creators, as well as strategic partnerships for feature film, television, and theater projects. Nine Stories has a strong commitment to diversity and women-led stories, and is actively delivering on its mission to help shape the landscape of entertainment by creating bold, ambitious projects.

. How Starbucks Saved My Life is the true story of an anonymous author, an entrepreneur and consultant, who was in a deep depression until the discovery of hope in one of the most unusual of places - a Starbucks. At the lowest point in his life, the man found himself lying in the dirt under a tree with no food for three days, believing he was doomed to spend the remainder of his life as a homeless person. One afternoon, he stumbled upon a Starbucks in a nearby town. Although he was desperately hungry, he gathered enough courage to take a seat inside. After a few moments of rest and reflection, the man was noticed by a barista. The barista asked him how he was doing, and this small act of kindness meant the world to the man. The barista shared stories of hope that the man found inspiring, and he felt a drive to keep going. He left Starbucks feeling joyful, and with hope that one day he would make something of himself. Fast forward fifteen years, and the man is now seen as a successful entrepreneur and consultant working in multiple industries. His success was incredibly unexpected, and a direct result of the stranger's kindness - kindness that he received at Starbucks. Since then, he has returned to Starbucks often, not only to thank the staff, but also to offer words of encouragement to those who may be struggling in life. As highlighted in his story, Starbucks can be a safe place for anyone feeling low and lonely. Although his story is an extreme example of how Starbucks helped regardless of a person’s individual circumstances, there are countless examples of how Starbucks is a place of hope and kindness. They offer free coffee for veterans, support financially disadvantaged communities, create a safe environment for all, and promote sustainability. It is true that everyone’s story of hope and healing is unique. But the story of How Starbucks Saved My Life is an important reminder to never take human kindness and connection for granted. Even in the most severe circumstances, hope and a connection to Starbucks can be life changing.

and include: Godthåbsvej is a main artery in Frederiksberg, an independent municipality in the center of the Danish capital, Copenhagen. It is located in the northeastern part of the city, running from the North Quarter (Nordkvarteret) to the west, and ends at the border to Copenhagen municipality. Godthåbsvej is named after the old Godthåb estate, a manor in the area from the 18th century. It is a busy street, running from north to south, that is lined with both stores, offices, and some of the city's most iconic landmarks: Frederiksberg Town Hall, Frederiksberg Castle, and the Godthåbsvej Synagogue. The street is also a central pedestrian area in the city and it is well connected with its public transportation, as it is located next to the Peter Bangs Vej station. The street is home to many of Frederiksbergs trendy restaurants, bars, cafes and small shops. There is an increasing number of trendy vintage stores and concept stores, which are becoming increasingly popular. Additionally, there are numerous open-air markets, such as that one hosted on the square at the northern end of Godthåbsvej. Furthermore, the street is known for its cultural institutions, such as its historic synagogue, galleries, and churches. Also located on Godthåbsvej is the renowned Frederiksberg Theatre. All throughout the year, this iconic house of culture puts a variety of performances such as film screenings and theatrical plays. Godthåbsvej is also a highly popular destination among pedestrians and cyclists, as it is lined with countless trees and various public parks. Here, locals and tourists alike can stroll through the sweeping green spaces and enjoy the area's lovely scenery. All in all, Godthåbsvej is a prime example of the city's unique and eclectic cultural atmosphere, and a must-stop for anyone visiting the city. With its many cultural institutions, trendy restaurants, and lovely parks, Godthåbsvej stands as one of Frederiksberg's most beloved streets.

Charles Kleiber (February 11, 1932 – June 18, 2013) was a German-American film editor and television director, who was best known for his collaborations with Rainer Werner Fassbinder and Alexander Kluge. Kleiber was born in Berlin, Germany in 1932. He began working as a film editor in the 1950s, and his first major feature was the 1966 television mini-series Man Without a Head. He subsequently worked on several films directed by Fassbinder, including The Marriage of Maria Braun (1978) and Lola (1981). He also edited films by directors such as Alexander Kluge, Dario Argento, and Wim Wenders. Kleiber's collaboration with Fassbinder in The Marriage of Maria Braun earned him the German Film Award (1983) for best editing. He and Fassbinder also won a Special Mention from the Jury at Cannes for the film Lola. Kleiber also directed several television films in the 1980s and 1990s, mostly for German broadcasters. Among these were several Fassbinder adaptations, including Maria Braun: A Scene of German Modernity (1984) and the television version of the 29-hour Berlin Alexanderplatz (1985). His last television film was 1996's Candy Cane Tree. In addition to his feature and television work, Kleiber also directed several music videos and commercials, as well as educational films. Kleiber died in Munich on June 18, 2013. He was 81. References Bernd-Lutz Lange. “Charles Kleiber”, in Mistichelli, PSM & Pittore, Mario (eds.) (2014) International Film Directors. New York: Routledge “Rainier Werner Fassbinder”. International Encyclopedia of Film. Retrieved 22 April 2020 Ritman, Alex (2018). “Charles Kleiber”, Film Encyclopedia. Retrieved 22 April 2020 San Francisco, Gary (2009). German Cinema: A Concise History. Berghahn Books Stromberg, Guzzi (2015). "Death of Charles Kleiber, Film Editor and Director of Rich Hybrids". Film Threat. Retrieved 22 April 2020

Caravan (novel) is a science fiction novel written by British author A. E. van Vogt and published in 1950 by Simon and Schuster. The novel is set in a post-apocalyptic future on Earth where mankind has been reduced to a few hundred thousand survivors. The story follows two groups of survivors who embark on a journey across a radioactive wasteland—the Caravaners—as they search for knowledge, hope and a new home. The novel is set in the distant future, after Earth has been ravaged by nuclear war. An epidemic called the ‘Plague of Madness’ has wiped out all but a few hundred thousand humans who are now scattered across the world. The novel’s protagonists are members of the Van Rijn family, a group of Dutch traders who have come together to form a caravan that is journeying eastward across the radioactive wasteland in search of a new place to call home. Led by their captain, Moses Van Rijn, the caravaners must contend with hordes of animal-like mutants while simultaneously keeping a wary eye out for the mysterious alien race called the Greys, who are known to abduct survivors. Along their journey, the caravaners meet up with a variety of characters, such as the unscrupulous trader named Hardin who promises safety and expertise in exchange for a share of their goods; the scientist Hyland who works to uncover the secrets of the Greys; and the corrupted deviant named Abner, who will either save or doom them all. The novel is an exploration of the effects of humanity’s destruction and features several essential themes, such as the duality of human nature and the notion of survival of the fittest. The story is full of danger, mystery and a hint of allegory, making it an enjoyable read for both fans of the genre and those looking for a fascinating glimpse into a possible future. Though not as renowned as some of Van Vogt’s other works, Caravan is still considered to be a classic example of early science fiction and has been cited as an influence on works such as the Mad Max films. The novel has also been included in a variety of collections, such as the SF Masterworks series, and was adapted into a comic book series in 2014 by Boom! Studios.

The Larklight trilogy is a series of science-fiction novels by British author Philip Reeve. The series consists of three books, Larklight (2006), Starcross (2007), and Mothstorm (2008). All three books were published to moderate success and are praised for their inventive and imaginative plotlines. The series follows Art and Myrtle Mumby, two children of an eccentric scientist who live in an alternate version of Victorian England. The siblings live with their father in a sprawling, dilapidated mansion called Larklight, located on the moon and in wild space. The trilogy follows their adventures as they, with their own eccentricities and cleverness, explore outer space and fight off the villainous forces of alien species such as the spider-like Spirelanders, the murderous Osirans, and the sinister Crawl. The books are lighthearted in tone and intended for readers aged 10 or above. However, the books have been praised for their complexity and their thoughtful and mature themes, such as loyalty, courage, family, and responsibility. The books are often compared to the works of Jules Verne and Jack London, and have elements of Steampunk, Victorian-era humour, fantastical upgrades of everyday technology, and a unique blend of realism and fantasy. In 2006, Larklight was shortlisted for the Nestlé Children's Book Prize and won the 2006 Emirates Airlines Festival of Literature's Best Children's Series Award while Starcross was nominated for the 2008 Nestle Children's Book Prize and the 2008 Golden Duck Award. In May 2017, it was announced that Elton John's Rocket Pictures had optioned the rights to the trilogy and was developing a live-action movie of the series, with Elton John himself serving as executive producer. A potential release date has yet to be announced. The Larklight trilogy is a beloved book series by traditional science-fiction fans and children alike. Reeve's creative and intricate world building and well-developed characters bridge the gap between children and adult literature, making the series a unique gem of the genre.

Ptolemais in Phoenicia (also known as Akko or Accho, from the Hebrew name "Akkō") was an Ancient Hellenistic city-state located in the northern coastal region of the eastern Mediterranean in present-day northern Israel. Ptolemais was founded in the 3rd century BC by Ptolemy I of Egypt. It was originally commissioned as a naval port and trading post between Egypt, Syria, Phoenicia, and the rest of the eastern Mediterranean region. Ptolemy established it as the first city of his Egyptian-Phoenician empire, which he named after himself as "Ptolemais". During its heyday, Ptolemais was a bustling port and commercial center. The city was destroyed by Alexander the Great in 332 BC, but was soon rebuilt by the Ptolemies. It remained an important trading port into the Hellenistic and Roman eras, though it eventually lost much of its significance with the fall of the Ptolemaic dynasty. The city remained largely intact until its destruction by a Crusader army in 1291, after which it lay in ruins until being rediscovered in the 18th century. Over the centuries, it has been occupied in turn by the Mamluks, the Ottoman Empire, the British Empire, the State of Israel and Palestinian militants in the Arab-Israeli War. Today, Ptolemais is a walled city that retains its ancient charm despite the modern changes it has undergone since its founding. It is a popular tourist destination due to its historical sites, including the fortifications, an ancient Maritime museum, and an archaeological excavation site. Most of the original city has been preserved and restored and is open to visitors. It has become a major center of culture, education, and industry in the region, with a major port, an international airport, numerous museums, galleries, and cultural centers, and a thriving economy.

Market City, Haymarket is a shopping centre, located in Sydney, Australia. It is positioned in the heart of Chinatown and is the largest Chinese shopping centre in Australia. It opened in 1988, and is conveniently located nearby the Sydney Entertainment Centre, Paddy’s Market and World Square. Market City is made up of two different levels, with more than 400 specialty stores and food outlets, ranging from electronic items and jewellery, to food and fashion. It is filled with wall-to-wall stores, many of which are Chinese supermarkets and food stalls known for their authenticity. It is one of the few places in Sydney where you can find an array of unique oriental products, such as Chinese herbs and antiques. The centre is marketed as a ‘cultural and exciting shopping experience’ with packages for both locals and overseas visitors. The centre provides shoppers with transportation solutions and valet parking in nearby Capitol Square. It also offers frequent event activities, such as cultural performances, art exhibitions and fashion shows. Market City also provides movie and entertainment solutions, in the form of its Palace Cinema, which is the premier arts theatre in the Haymarket area. Playing current films from the major movie studios, it is the best place for a movie with family or friends. General Manager of Market City, Remy Dang, commented “Since the opening of Market City in 1988, our loyal fans have come to experience the unique shopping and cultural experience that have become synonymous with Market City. We look forward to welcoming ever more friends and customers to our vibrant centre and together continue to bring the downtown cultural experience to greater Sydney.” Market City is open from Monday to Sunday from 9am to 10pm. It is without doubt, a must-visit for locals and tourists seeking a shopping experience that can’t be found anywhere else in Sydney. References 1. http://www.marketcity.com.au/ 2. https://www.timeout.com/sydney/shopping/market-city

Oklahoma State Highway 71 is a north-south highway in the US state of Oklahoma. It travels from US Highway 69 near Iron Post, in McCurtain County, to US Highway 62 near Pawnee, in Pawnee County. It is a major east-west Route in northeastern Oklahoma, and is part of the Indian Nation Turnpike system. The highway begins at a junction with US 69 near Iron Post and travels northwards through rural McCurtain County. As it approaches Idabel, the highway passes through residential areas before intersecting US 259 in the east side of Idabel. From US 259 the highway continues on a northwesterly route through rural parts of McCurtain County, passing several towns and small settlements. In Pawnee County, OK-71 intersects State Highway 18, before reaching its northern terminus at US 62 just east of Pawnee. Overall, OK-71 runs for approximately 95 miles (152.89 km). It serves as an important connection between two major routes, US 59 and US 62, and is an important route for local commuters, freight carriers, and tourists. A nearby section of the road is one of the few places in Oklahoma where the original pre-1920s road still remains, and this section is known as the Old Oregon Trail. OK-71 has been a continuous route since at least 1922 when it was originally designated in the state of Oklahoma. In the mid-1990s the road was improved by resurfacing and was also widened in a few places. The road also underwent several bridge improvements in recent years. OK-71 is clearly marked along its entire route, and provides reliable transportation for residents of the area. The highway also serves as an important link to a number of popular tourist destinations, including the Red Slough Wildlife Management Area, the Ouachita National Forest, and Lake Wister State Park. Overall, Oklahoma State Highway 71 is a key transportation route for the northeastern-most part of the state. It provides an important connection for local commuters and travelers, as well as an important link to several tourist destinations.

Paula Williams Madison (born March 27, 1953) is an institutional and media executive and former broadcast journalist, entrepreneur and philanthropist, who has made significant contributions to the American television and entertainment industry. Madison is a media trailblazer who has held numerous senior executive positions at the NBC and Telemundo divisions of NBCUniversal, the FOX broadcast networks and Los Angeles public television station KCET. She is the former President and CEO of Los Angeles public TV station KCET and the former NBC Vice President of Diversity. During her 8-year tenure IKCET, Madison aspired to deliver inspiring, award-winning TV programming to the citizens of Los Angeles. Prior to her roles at NBC, Madison founded Madison Media Management (MMM) -- the first Black owned TV syndication firm -- which was the first to acquire and distribute the iconic sitcom The Cosby Show. Before creating MMM, she was a Vice President at NBC television news, where she held several executive management positions, transforming the networks news coverage to a wider range of segments. Madison is known for her dedication to the advancement of diversity in the media and entertainment industry. In 2003, she was named one of the most influential women in cable television by Cableworld Magazine for her diversifying efforts at NBC. In 2011, she was appointed by Mrs. Obama on the White House's Advisory Committee for the Arts, becoming the first African American to hold a chair. In addition to her broadcast and entrepreneurial accomplishments, Madison is also an accomplished author, having co-written the memoir Finding Samuel Lowe: China, Jamaica, Harlem with her mother. The book is inspired by her Chinese-Jamaican heritage, which has helped shape her life’s journey. Madison is passionate about giving back to the community. She serves as a trustee of The Paley Center for Media, The California African American Museum and is a member of the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences. In 2019, Madison also established the Paula Madison Foundation to focus on African American art and film, with a vision to bridge cultural divides by creating content that reflects the humanity and history of Black communities. Madison is a Lifetime Fellow of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. She is an inductee of the Broadcasting and Cable Hall of Fame, and a recipient of the Museum of Television and Radio’s Achievement Awards for Diversity.

Wulfsige of Sherborne was an Anglo-Saxon Bishop based in the area of Sherborne, England. He was active during the early part of the 10th century, and is best known for being the first Bishop of Sherborne. Little is known about Wulfsige's life before he was consecrated as bishop at the royal court of King Athelstan. He is said to have been a royal chaplain prior to becoming a bishop. It is likely that Wulfsige was born in the kingdom of Wessex, as he subscribed acts of King Athelstan and King Edmund in the region. As bishop, Wulfsige founded the Cathedral of Sherborne in 909. He also established a monastic community in the area, built a palace and introduced a new system of laws and regulations to govern the area. Under Wulfsige's rule, Sherborne grew to become one of the most important centers of Christianity in Anglo-Saxon England. He was known to have maintained close ties with the Archbishop of Canterbury, and was a supporter of the Carolingian dynasty. He was also a close advisor to King Athelstan, and is believed to have been instrumental in the king's decisions during his reign. By 920, Wulfsige had retired as Bishop of Sherborne, due to ill health. He died soon after and was buried in the area in a tomb that he himself had constructed. He was succeeded by fellow bishop Æthelnoth, who continued his works in Sherborne. Wulfsige of Sherborne is largely known for his establishment of the Cathedral of Sherborne, which is still standing today. His work greatly contributed to the growth of Christianity in the area and helped to shape the later leading role played by Sherborne in English Christian history.

Ranjana script (Nepal Bhasa/NepalBraj: रञ्जन लिपि), is an abugida (alphasyllabary) script used in Nepal to write Nepal Bhasa and Sanskrit. It was the official script of Nepal during the Malla dynasty and remains in use to the present day for writing Nepal Bhasa and Sanskrit. The Ranjana script is believed to have been derived from the Siddham script and Proto-Bengali script. As evident from scattered inscriptions unearthed in Nepal, the script appeared in the 10th century C.E. and quickly replaced several other scripts used in Nepal at the time, such as the Pranava or Sarada script. The script is written from left to right, with horizontal lines extending across the page. Each line has a maximum of five characters and each character consists of either one or two syllables. Upto 22 vowel markers are used to represent the vowels and each consonant is represented by a single syllable. The script uses various ligature styles, such as writing the vowels on top of the characters to represent the consonants. In Nepal, Ranjana is used as a decorative script for religious purposes. It is used for traditional manjusa, a head ornament worn by women, and Newari jewellery. The script is also used for writing in palm-leaves for books, and for generating the Tibetan-style thangkas which are the religious scroll paintings of Nepal. Ranjana is primarily used in the Kathmandu Valley and surrounding areas of Central and Eastern Nepal, as well as other parts of the country. It is not commonly used in the western and mid-western Narayani, Lumbini, and Rapti zones. In recent years, an increased interest in the Ranjana script has led to the revival of the script. As part of this revival, efforts are being made to preserve the script and promote its use. The script was adopted as the official script of Nepal in 2018 and efforts are underway to have it recognized by the United Nations. As of 2019, there are over 25 recognized Ranjana script groups in Nepal, with a significant increase in the number of individuals who can read and write in the script. There are also several online tutorials and apps available to help people learn the script. Ranjana remains an important part of Nepali culture and is still used today to preserve the culture and traditions of Nepal. It is a script steeped in history and is an important part of the cultural heritage of the country.

The Linus Pauling Quartet is an American rock and heavy metal band from Houston, Texas. Formed in 1993, the quartet consists of founding members Jase "The Sandman" Stanley on guitar and vocals, Matthew "Moecker" Hirschhorn on bass and vocals, Chris "T-Bone" Redmun on drums and vocals, and Clay "Triggerfish" Shaley on guitar and vocals. The Linus Pauling Quartet's style spans many genres within the rock and metal spectrum. With influences ranging from classic heavy metal, punk, and stoner rock, the Quartet employs an often industrial sound characterized by relentlessly pounding rhythms, pummeling riffs, cutting solos, and alternately melodic and gruff vocals. The band often makes sly reference to sci-fi, horror and 70s sitcoms in their lyrics. Having released five albums, countless singles, and countless compilation submissions, The Linus Pauling Quartet have remained a rather mysterious entity, having forged a name for themselves largely due to relentless touring and strong independent record sales over the past decade and a half. Though located in Houston, Texas, the band has played extensively throughout the United States, Mexico, and Japan, while also making frequent appearances at South by Southwest and other prestigious music festivals. The band became widely known for their participation in the 2009 Vans Warped Tour, and the subsequent release of the live compilation "Live Freaks Jams", which featured performances recorded during the tour. The band was described by the press as having “shredded their way around the country with a unique blend of ‘70s-era classic rock, punk, and metal.” The group's fifth album "Amps, Axes and Automobiles" was released on Evilegend Records in 2013. Described as a "crunchy and powerful recording that suggests the influence of Blue Oyster Cult, Black Sabbath, Grand Funk and Rush", the album features heavy riffs, driving rhythms, and punk-inspired hooks, further solidifying the Linus Pauling Quartet as one of the most influential American Heavy Metal bands of their generation. The Linus Pauling Quartet continues to make regular appearances around the country and abroad, playing massive clubs and festivals alike, while also developing new material.

Sydney lockout laws, commonly referred to as Sydney's lockout laws, are a set of laws implemented in 2014 in response to alcohol-fuelled violence in the city of Sydney, Australia. The primary purpose of the lockout laws was to reduce the amount of alcohol-fuelled violence in the city by imposing restrictions on venues and the movement of patrons outside of them. The move was seen as a response to a number of high-profile incidents, such as the death of Daniel Christie in 2013 and the brawl between rival fans at a Major League Soccer game in 2008. The laws restrict patrons from entering alcohol-serving venues in the Sydney central business district and Kings Cross after 1:30am and constrain the sale and sale of alcoholic beverages until 3:00am. Venues must also prevent patrons from re-entering after their first entry. Furthermore, evidence of having drunk alcohol elsewhere is not permitted in any of these venues. Since the lockout laws were put in place, levels of alcohol-fuelled violence in the affected areas have decreased dramatically. In the six months after the implementation of the lockouts, violent incidents were reduced by 24%, including a 43% reduction in hospital admissions for serious head-injuries. However, there has been significant backlash from the industry and public due to the restrictions deeming them too restrictive. Opponents of the laws often cite the devastating economic impact on nightclubs and live music venues, as well as freedom of movement, as the main counterarguments to the laws. Businesses have suffered greatly due to the losses in revenue and the nightlife culture in Sydney has been drastically changed, as people now move away from the city centre late at night. The lockout laws continue to face strong opposition and are still in place as of June 2021 despite several attempts to repeal them. The NSW Government has recently announced an inquiry and review of the effects of the laws on the industry and patrons, which will be released later in 2021. Regardless of the inquiry's results, the effects of the Sydney lockout laws continue to be felt beyond the city and act as a reminder of the dangers of alcohol-fuelled violence.

Alec Asher (born February 27, 1992) is an American professional baseball pitcher in the Washington Nationals organization. He has previously played in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Baltimore Orioles and Philadelphia Phillies. Asher was drafted by the Texas Rangers in the 12th round of the 2012 Major League Baseball Draft out of Martin High School. Asher primarily pitched out of the bullpen during his time in the Rangers organization but converted to starting in 2015 with the Myrtle Beach Pelicans, the Rangers AA affiliate. Asher posted a 5–6 record with a 3.88 earned run average (ERA) in 19 starts for the Pelicans. During the 2015–2016 off-season, Asher was sent along with Nick Williams, Jake Thompson, Jorge Alfaro, and Jerad Eickhoff in the trade that sent Cole Hamels to the Rangers. In 2016, Asher posted a 6–14 record with a 5.84 ERA in 26 starts for the Lehigh Valley IronPigs, the Phillies Triple-A affiliate. He made his MLB debut on April 24, 2016, pitching five innings and earning the win over the Los Angeles Dodgers. Asher made 22 starts for the Phillies that year, recording an 0–8 record with a 6.75 ERA. He was released by the Phillies in May of 2017. Asher signed with the Baltimore Orioles in June of 2017, and was assigned to the Norfolk Tides, their Triple-A affiliate. In three starts, he posted 0–2 record with a 9.73 ERA. Asher was then released by the Orioles in July. He returned to the Phillies organization in 2018, making 17 starts for the IronPigs, posting a 5–4 record with a 4.75 ERA. In November 2018, Asher signed a minor league contract with the Washington Nationals. Asher opened the 2019 season with the Harrisburg Senators, the Nationals AA affiliate. He was promoted to the Syracuse Chiefs, the Nationals Triple-A affiliate in April. Asher signed a minor league deal to stay with the Nationals for 2020 before the season was cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Asher is best known for his ability to control the ball, thanks to his deceptive change-up and effective sinker. Over his career, he has also developed a cutter and a curveball. In eight minor league seasons and one MLB season, Asher has pitched in 165 games and posted a 38–56 record with a 4.61 ERA.

Alexander Nisbet (born 1853, Auchtermuchty, Fife, Scotland) was a Scottish businessman and philanthropist. Born to a farming family, Nisbet left school at an early age and through determination, an enterprising spirit, and an excellent business acumen, rose to become one of the most respected and successful businessmen in Scotland. Nisbet's many business ventures included coal mining, property development, livestock farming, and banking. His coal mining business in Torphins, Angus – Torphins Colliery Co. Ltd – was a particularly successful endeavour. Nisbet opened the quarry in 1895, founding the company a year later in 1896. He invested heavily in the company and its success enabled him to expand quickly. In time, the operation had grown to over 1,000 people employed at three quarries, with a further 750 employed to the associated railways. Nisbet's business ventures were not restricted only to coal mining, diversifying into a number of other industries such as, property development, railways and banking. He was a major investor in the Aberdeen Bank of Scotland and helped to establish banks all around Scotland and parts of England. Throughout his life, Alexander Nisbet also possessed a deep commitment to philanthropy. He was very generous in donating to schools, hospitals and churches. In 1913, he donated a substantial amount towards the development of the University of St Andrews. He also made donations towards the founding of the John Gordon Home for Inebriates in Aberlour, where 70 former residents of the East End of Glasgow were cared for and re-trained. Alexander Nisbet died in 1928 aged 75. His son, Robert, succeeded him in business and philanthropy, continuing the Nisbet legacy. In remembrance of his work and generous spirit, a statue of Nisbet stands outside the Torphins town hall. Alexander Nisbet's inspirational and entrepreneurial journey reminds us that with hard work, determination and an enterprising spirit, anything can be achieved. His commitment to philanthropy is a testament to his humanity and his legacy remains a source of inspiration for future generations.

The One with the Embryos is the fourteenth episode of the fourth season of the American television sitcom Friends, which aired on NBC on January 15, 1998. It was written by series creators David Crane and Marta Kauffman, and directed by Kevin S. Bright. The episode focuses on a trivia challenge between Rachel Green (Jennifer Aniston) and Monica Geller (Courteney Cox) to decide who gets a recently acquired apartment. Phoebe Buffay (Lisa Kudrow) and Joey Tribbiani (Matt LeBlanc) act as the "trivia masters" to ask the questions. Rachel and Monica call their respective groups of friends to coach them. Phoebe and Joey, along with Chandler Bing (Matthew Perry) and Ross Geller (David Schwimmer), bet their possessions on the outcome of the challenge. Meanwhile, Chandler and Monica show interest in each other, and Chandler tries to break the news that he and Rachel are no longer together. In the game, Rachel and Monica are asked questions about each other, including items found in the apartment, past in-jokes and memories, and general knowledge. As the game progresses, Rachel and Monica start to reveal hidden secrets and truths that they know about each other. In the end, Rachel wins the apartment. The episode earned 23 million American viewers and was ranked the third most watched show of the week. The episode was well received by fans, who appreciated the nostalgia and references to past events in the fandom. The title is derived from the joke by Joey during the trivia game, about when he and Chandler got stung by a bee, when performing a mating dance to attract women. The “official” name for this dance was the “Embryo Dance”. This episode furthers the first hints of the romantic relationship between Chandler and Monica, which continues for the remainder of the series. It also reinforces the importance of friendship in the series, with Rachel and Monica often competing against each other, but in the end still being best friends. The episode was well received by critics, who noted its nostalgia and humor, and was nominated for the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing for a Comedy Series.

Kokatha is an Indigenous Australian group of the Australian Arrernte people, a group of Aboriginal Australians that live on the traditional lands of the Arrernte people. The Kokatha people are located in the southern part of the Western Arrernte region of South Australia, and their traditional lands lie around Lake Eyre and the Nullarbor Plain in the Northern Territory and South Australia. The Kokatha people are made up of several smaller tribes, including the Wirangu, Yankunytjatjara, Pitjantjatjara and Kadjingaritankalpa. They also share a traditional language, known as Kokatha, as well as a strong cultural and spiritual connection to their lands. Kokatha people are renowned for their traditional knowledge and for their role in the conservation and protection of land and waters. The Kokatha people have an in-depth understanding of, and strong connections with, the environment, wildlife, plants and animals within their traditional territory. The Kokatha people are also involved in many cultural and recreational activities, including music, dance, storytelling, games, hunting and fishing. The music and storytelling of the Kokatha people is well recognised, and includes the creation of unique dot painting designs. The Kokatha people have endured multiple challenges since European arrival and are currently negotiating land claims with the Commonwealth and SA state governments. In 2013, the Kokatha people were officially recognised as Traditional Owners in South Australia, with the help of the Kokatha people, the Kokatha Mula Council. The Kokatha people are also active in the local community, they run and promote programs such as the 'Cultural Connections Program' and the 'Family Nature Connections Program', which aim to bring non-Indigenous people together to discuss and explore the unique culture and nature of the Kokatha people. The Kokatha people are also members of the local Aboriginal Advisory Committee and take part in joint-management of land and water in the traditional country, this includes on-ground projects such as restoring wetlands and re-vegetation initiatives. The Kokatha people and their traditional lands continually face threats from industry, with projects such as fracking, pipeline installation and water extraction highlighting the importance of the traditional custodians of the land and water. The Kokatha people are seeking to protect and preserve their culture, and their traditional lands and waters for future generations. They are working hard to guard their heritage, which includes continuing their connection to the land and water, and honouring the stories of their ancestors.

Clams casino is a dish typically served on the East Coast of the United States, popularized in the early 20th century. It is considered a type of seafood dish made of clams, bacon and bell peppers, sometimes chopped onions and garlic, all cooked in a white wine and butter sauce, typically with breadcrumbs sprinkled on top. The dish originated in a small Italian-American fishing village known as Clamtown that was located in Little Egg Harbor Township in southern New Jersey. It is unknown who created the dish. However, what is known is that it began to become popular during the first half of the twentieth century, especially in Rhode Island and Connecticut, amongst the Italian American population. Gennaro “Jerry” Pellegrino, a restaurateur who was owner of the renowned landmark Clamtown Chowder House which was established in 1906, likely popularized the dish. The dish is typically made with chopped or diced clams, onions, garlic and bacon that have been cooked together in a skillet before being added to the sauce. The sauce includes butter, white wine or occasionally beer, thyme and sometimes Bell peppers. The sauce is finished with a sprinkle of toasted breadcrumbs. Clams casino is generally served as an appetizer, although it may also be served as a main course. Some restaurants may also serve it as a sandwich filling. The dish can be served either hot or cold. The most common way to prepare Clams casino is to bake it in an oven after the stuffing has been prepared. Some restaurants, particularly in Clamtown, may serve it deep-fried. The dish may be accompanied with various side dishes such as mashed potatoes, rice, or salad. Vegetables such as asparagus and broccoli, as well as fruits like oranges, often accompany the dish. Nowadays, Clams casino is available in all parts of the United States and is considered a classic dish. It remains a popular dish among all age groups, as it is flavorful, filling, and easy to make. The popularity of the dish is such that it has given rise to its own food celebration, the Clams Casino Day, which is observed on August 1, each year.

The Truth and Reconciliation Commission Act is a type of legislation used by countries seeking to heal from the wounds of a traumatic past or build a stronger, more inclusive, and just society. This Act seeks to address the lasting impact of past conflicts and human rights violations on societies and individuals. In many cases, Truth and Reconciliation Commission Acts are accompanied by other forms of reparative justice, such as reparations and memorials. Origins The concept of Truth and Reconciliation Commission Acts (TRCAs) originated after the fall of white-ruled South Africa in the early 1990s, when the nation was looking to transition to a new democracy. Although the South African system's main purpose was to step away from the apartheid regime, it also provided an example for how other countries could deal with their own traumatic pasts. The South African individuals involved in the development of this type of legislation sought to create a form of restorative justice which would promote understanding, ensure peace and foster reconciliation between different factions at conflict. In the aftermath of this period, truth and reconciliation commissioners have since been appointed in countries such as Sierra Leone, East Timor, South Africa, Namibia, Peru, Chile, Mali, Austria and Northern Ireland. Process Truth and Reconciliation Commission Acts are usually suited to the particular context in which they are being implemented. For example, the goals and objectives of each commission can vary widely. Furthermore, TRACs can determine the ways in which they will collect information, investigate and fact-find, and deliver findings. Generally speaking, the process of a TRAC includes: * Acknowledging and mapping the patterns of human rights abuses; * Allowing victims access to the process of speaking about their experiences (and/or to receive compensation for their suffering); * Fostering an understanding of how and why abuses or crimes were committed and assessing responsibility for those crimes. In certain cases, this may lead to the recommendations of amnesty, reparation or prosecution; * Providing a means of reconciliation between former enemies; * Contributing to the development of a common history of a country or region; * Recommending means for preventing and responding to future human rights violations and/or conflict. Impact The role of Truth and Reconciliation Commission Acts have been widely debated due to their potential to provide "decisive and successful.[1]The term "success" is generally understood to include the following elements: * A process that is just and "balanced" between victims and perpetrators; * A process that avoids the public spectacle and retribution of traditional trials; * A process that brings perpetrators and victims together to take responsibility and begin a process of reparation; * Creating a national dialogue which can move a society away from retributive justice and toward reconciliation; * The acknowledgment, evidence and documentation of past human rights abuses and violations. Conclusion Truth and Reconciliation Commission Acts seek to promote peace, justice, and reconciliation in a society that has experienced a traumatic past. The impact of such legislation depends on the particular context of each commission, as well as their ability to honor and include the voices, stories, and needs of victims of past abuses.

Protected areas of Libya are areas that are legally protected by the government of the North African country of Libya to conserve the natural environment or certain species of flora and fauna. Libya is a region of vast deserts and coastal areas and their protection is important to the preservation of biodiversity. The first protected area to be established in Libya was the Hamada al Hamra National Park in 1965. It is located within the Gulf of Sidra, off the coast of Libya in the Mediterranean Sea. The park covers a total area of 5,400 km2 and is home to a variety of rare species of flora and fauna, including the endangered Mediterranean Monk Seal. The park is also known for its significant archaeological sites, including remains from the Phoenician and Roman empires. In 2009, UNESCO declared the the Archaeological Site of Cyrene a World Heritage Site. This site boasts numerous ancient temples, colonnaded streets, theatres and baths, public squares and an acropolis. It is a key example of the 'Greek colonies in the Mediterranean region'. In 2016, the government announced an ambitious plan to establish a National Parks and Reserves Authority, with the goal of protecting and managing national parks and reserves. The first project of this program was announced in 2018: Kayet Bay National Park. Covering an area of 4,500 km2, this park will protect the diverse marine and terrestrial ecosystems in the southern coastal area of Libya. Libya's coastal areas are particularly affected by climate change, with rising water levels due to global warming. In order to better protect these fragile ecosystems, several other marine protected areas have been established by the Libyan government, including Ras Thaveyta Coastal Park, Bet Generis and Serte Marine Park, and the Hamada al Hamra Marine Park. In 2018, the government also signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the U.N. Environment Programme and the Global Environment Facility, focused on preserving and developing Libya's protected areas. The Libyan government has taken an important step in recognizing the need to protect its unique environment, habitats, and species; however, more effort needs to be made to ensure that these areas are managed and protected. Despite their best efforts, Libya's protected areas are still under threat from poaching, illegal fishing, development projects and increased pressure from the tourism industry.

1520 (MDXX) was an important year in world history. The year saw a number of significant events, ranging from important political changes to technological advancements. In politics and diplomacy, 1520 marked the year that the Treaty of Tordesillas was formally signed by Portugal and Spain, formalizing the de facto division between the two empires and setting the stage for a period of Iberian dominance in the Atlantic. This year also saw the election of Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor - a position of power that Charles V held for more than 40 years. 1520 was also an important year in the history of the Ottoman Empire. Suleiman the Magnificent captured the city of Belgrade, a significant victory in what would become known as the Ottoman-Hungarian wars. At the same time, the conquest of Algiers by the Ottomans also took place, culminating in an eight-year siege of this Mediterranean port. In the field of science and culture, 1520 saw an important development in navigation: the Amazon River was encountered by European explorers, leading to the development of a number of new trade routes and expeditions across the ocean. This year also saw the invention of the printing press and paper money, which revolutionized the way information was spread and commerce was conducted. On a related note, the Diet of Worms saw Martin Luther take a stand against the Catholic Church, leading to the development of Protestantism which would have major implications in Europe and the New World. In 1520, the Aztec Emperor Moctezuma II was defeated and killed by Hernán Cortés in Tenochtitlan, thus ending a major era in Mesoamerican history and setting the stage for the colonization of Latin America by the Spanish and Portuguese empires. In 1520, the world population was estimated to be around 450 million, a figure which would more than double to one billion by the mid-19th century. Overall, 1520 was an important year in the history of the world. It saw the formalization of two major empires, a technological revolution, the beginnings of the Protestant Reformation, and the conquest of a major civilization. As a result, its influence can still be felt today.

1102 in Ireland was an eventful year full of religious and political struggles. It was the time of the Ua Briain High Kingship and their struggles with the Norman invaders. In January of 1102, Dermott of the Ua Briain dynasty was crowned High King of Ireland. Dermott was the son of the previous High King, Mael Sechnaill, and had been chosen by the leading families of Ireland to take his father’s place as High King over the entire island. Dermott was a strong-willed leader and had a reputation for being a great warrior and negotiator. In May, 1102, several Norman lords, led by Hugh de Leversage, arrived in Ireland to take control of much of the region. These Norman armies were determined to take control of Ireland and impose their own culture and government upon it. Dermott was determined to fight them off and after months of fierce fighting, the Normans were eventually defeated. This was also the time of a power struggle between the Irish Church and the Roman Church. In 1102, the Archbishops of Armagh and Tuam supported the Roman Church and their authority while other Irish ecclesiastic leaders, like the Bishop of Dublin, opposed them. Dermott decided to support the Roman Church which caused great tension amongst the Irish. On the international front in 1102, Dermott was instrumental in negotiating the Treaty of Athelney between the King of Scotland and the Saxon King of England. This was a major diplomatic accomplishment and a testament to Dermott’s strong leadership. Throughout much of 1102, Dermott worked to strengthen the Ua Briain dynasty’s power in Ireland. He was able to forge alliances with the southern Irish lords and was able to bring much of the country under the domination of the Ua Briain. He also worked hard to use his political clout to combat the Normans and to protect the Irish Church from their influence. 1102 was an eventful year in Ireland which saw incredible political and religious upheaval. Dermott of the Ua Briain dynasty was able to successfully lead the Irish people through these struggles and lay the foundation for a period of relative peace and prosperity. Today, his accomplishments are seen as one of the great examples of Irish leadership and resilience.

Mortal Kombat is a series of comic books published by DC Comics based on the popular Mortal Kombat video game series. The first comic series, which ran from April 1995 to August 1996, was written and illustrated by John Tobias, one of the creators of the video game series. The series was then continued with a new story arc under WildStorm Productions, part of DC Comics. The story of the comics is set in the same universe as the video games, however it follows its own continuity and storylines. The first series was originally intended to be a one-off story that was meant to be told in a 4-issue mini-series, but due to the positive reception it received, it was extended to 8-issues. In this story arc, a new tournament was announced in Outworld and the heroes from Earthrealm, the protagonists of the video game series, are invited to participate in it. The WildStorm story arc, titled "Blood & Thunder", began in August 2006 and is currently ongoing. The story takes place some time after the first series and continues with the Mortal Kombat video game storyline. The Earthrealm warriors have to face a new enemy, Shang Tsung and the forces of Outworld. The comics have featured some of the characters from the video game series, such as Liu Kang, Kung Lao, Johnny Cage, Sonya Blade and Raiden, as well as new characters like Ashrah and Taven. The series has also featured guest appearances from characters from other DC comics titles, such as Shazam and Wonder Woman. The comics have been well-received by critics and fans of the Mortal Kombat series, and several stories have been collected in two trade paperback books. The story arcs have also been adapted into an animated feature film, Mortal Kombat: The Journey Begins. overall, it can be said that Mortal Kombat (comics) has been successful at maintaining the lore and tone of the video game series. The series has been praised for its unique art style and for the stories that have been told in it. It is currently ongoing, with several story arcs planned for the future.

D-3 is a video game developed by Taito Corporation and released in 1989. It was released in Japan and then localized in North America, Europe, and Asia by Nintendo. The game was released on the Nintendo Entertainment System and has become a popular cult classic. The game is set in a post-apocalyptic future, where the human race has been wiped out by something known as the D-3 virus. The player takes on the role of Tango, a robotic tank who is traveling through the remains of the former world. As Tango travels, he must battle the virus-infested creatures and discover the source of the virus before it can consume the world. D-3 has been praised for its unique gameplay and its use of difficulty and puzzle-solving elements. The core gameplay consists of a top-down view with the player controlling Tango directly, managing his health and resources to progress through the levels. The game also features the ability to pick up and use various items throughout the levels. The graphics and music of the game have been praised for their time period. The visuals have a gritty and haunting quality to them, and the music has been praised for its unique mix of synthesized and acoustic sounds. The game was commercially successful upon its release, and even to this day, it continues to maintain a strong cult following. It was even re-released on the Wii's virtual console in 2007. Today, it is commonly seen as one of the best NES games and a classic example of the post-apocalyptic genre. Overall, D-3 is a cult classic and an important game in the history of the post-apocalyptic genre.
