Its unique and challenging gameplay, along with its haunting visuals and soundtrack, make it a title worth playing for all fans of retro gaming.

Farrukh Shah (b. 1211–1263 CE) was a high-ranking courtier, historian and poet in the court of the Delhi Sultanate. He was the most important adviser to Ghiyasuddin Balban, the ninth Sultan of the dynasty, and also served Sultan Nasiruddin Mahmud in the same capacity. Farrukh Shah was born in Qasr-i-Qahira, Iran and belonged to the Abbasid dynasty. He served as a historian in the court of Balban and wrote the Khazayn al-Akhbar, which is a detailed chronicle of political and military events of the Delhi Sultanate from 1211 to 1263 CE. He was well versed in Persian, the court language of the sultanate, and had a reputation of being a well-rounded scholar. He also wrote several famous poetic works, such as the Khazain al-Futuh, or Triumphs of Balban, which extolled the virtues of Balban and his courtiers. Farrukh Shah was well-prepared for diplomatic manoeuvres and was also a gifted organiser. He was responsible for Balban's success in subduing the Rajputs and other rebellious tribes, as well as for Balban's formation of a unified army. He remained loyal to Balban throughout his life and served him well until the end of his reign. Farrukh Shah was made the chief administrator of court affairs after Nasiruddin Mahmud succeeded Balban. He remained in that capacity until 1259 CE, managing state affairs and also maintaining its minted currency, the silver tanka. He further continued to write that statesman’s works throughout this period as well, such as the Futuh al-Alam and the Futuh al-Futuh, both of which extol Nasiruddin Mahmud's courage and successful campaigns. In 1263 CE, Farrukh Shah was appointed as the governor of Bengala under Nasiruddin Mahmud's rule. He was very successful in that position due to his ability to maintain effective governing structures and good relations with local leadership. However, he died shortly after this appointment in 1263 CE, due to natural causes. In recognition of his loyalty and services, Farrukh Shah's son, Shihabuddin, was appointed as the chief minister of the sultanate upon his death. Farrukh Shah was an important figure in Delhi Sultanate's history and his works are still considered the most comprehensive source for understanding Delhi in the 13th century.

Luna E-6 No.5 was the fifth in a series of robotic spacecraft launched by the Soviet Union between 1963 and 1973. It was part of the Luna E-6 remote lunar exploration program and was designed to return a soil sample from the Moon. Launched on April 2, 1968, it was the fifth of six successful missions to return lunar samples to Earth. The goal of the Luna E-6 program was to obtain and return a sample from the Moon for scientific study. The spacecraft resembled a copy of the Yangel’s R-14 ICBM with the same diameter of 2.3 m and a total mass of 3118 kg. Its design was based on the Luna E-6 model that had already been used in several previous unmanned Moon missions. Luna E-6 No.5 was launched from Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan by an eight-stage Molniya-M rocket. After reaching lunar orbit, the spacecraft descended to about 20 km above the surface and took four pictures of the area where the sample was to be collected. It then fired its engine for the braking maneuver and began its descent toward the lunar surface. After touching down on the lunar surface, Luna E-6 No.5 used a three-stage extended arm to collect a sample of beneath the surface of the Moon. The sample weighed at least 100 grams and was placed in a protective glass capsule. After collecting the sample, the spacecraft used its engine again to escape from the Moon’s gravity and fired its retro-rockets to reduce its speed, allowing it to enter a geocentric orbit around the Earth. Luna E-6 No.5 successfully returned to Earth on 10 April and impact in the steppe regions of Kazakhstan. Due to its safe return, the Soviet Union was the first country to collect soil samples from the Moon and was a major achievement of the Russian space program. The Luna E-6 No.5 mission was widely publicized and its success opened the way for several other lunar sample return missions. In addition, it served as the template for manned space flights. In 1969, the U.S. Apollo 11 lunar module used a similar type of extended arm to collect a lunar sample.

. The National Space Development Agency of Japan (NASDA) was an Independent Administrative Institution under the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology of Japan. The agency was formed on October 1st, 1969, and was responsible for Japan's aerospace development and use for peaceful purposes. It also conducted research into space science and technology. NASDA maintained facilities for launch vehicle development, for research and for the manufacture of rockets, satellites and other equipment. Its network of space-related businesses included subcontractors and joint ventures with foreign countries. The agency was responsible for providing shuttle services to the International Space Station. NASDA operated two launch sites, Tanegashima Space Center and Uchinoura Space Center, as well as a satellite tracking station at Noshiro, Akita Prefecture. The agency also owned and managed a number of satellites and other spacecraft. Notably, NASDA was the only Japanese government space organization to have successfully launched a human-rated spacecraft, with the Soyuz F-1 mission in 1994. NASDA was one of Japan's major contributions towards international cooperation in space exploration. The agency initiated a joint venture in the early 1990s called the "Global Science and Technology Satellite" (GSTS) which involved international collaboration with five other countries, including the United States and Russia. This project played a significant role in the development of the International Space Station. NASDA also participated in several long-term manned space exploration projects. This included a commitment to the International Space Station in 1998, as well as participation in the Space Shuttle program from 1990 to 1998. In an effort to promote commercialization and utilization of space, NASDA sought to create a public-private partnership that would be viable long-term. To this end, in 2003 the government-backed Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency was established to serve as the successor to NASDA. The new organization was responsible for reintegrating NASDA's main functions, such as launching and managing satellites, controlling ground stations and providing scientific missions in space. NASDA played a unique role in Japan's aerospace industry, pioneering the space industry in the country and facilitating international cooperation in space exploration. NASDA's innovative technologies, research, and launch services greatly contributed to Japan's capabilities in the exploration and utilization of space. The legacy of NASDA's mission and achievements will be remembered for many years to come.

The 2005 World Championships in Kickboxing (WAKO) took place between 10–15 October 2005 in Agadir, Morocco. This event was organized by the World Association of Kickboxing Organizations (WAKO), and it marked the first time the event had taken place in Africa. The championships included disciplines from Full-Contact, Low-Kick, K-1, and Thai Kickboxing, with categories ranging from Junior (16-18 years) to Veteran (35+ years). More than 600 athletes from over 60 countries- including Japan, United States, Germany, France, Italy, South Africa, Belgium, Finland, Estonia, Venezuela and England- participated in this event. The winners of the tournament were presented with gold medals and diplomas, while the runners up received a silver medal, and third-placed athletes received a bronze medal. Attendees to the championships also enjoyed various cultural activities, such as the traditional Moroccan folklore show. The tournament was organized spectacularly and was a success in terms of international participation. It was a proud moment for WAKO, as the event allowed them to spread their message and raise awareness of kickboxing in Africa. This event was significant in putting Morocco on the international sporting map and kickboxing in Africa. One notable attendee at the tournament was kickboxing legend Jean-Charles Skarbowsky. He expressed his admiration for the event and all it included, stating the following: “I’m proud to be at this important event in Africa, and to witness the commitment, professionalism and true spirit these athletes show for the sport.” The event was widely reported in the international media, with photos and stories reaching news outlets such as the BBC, ITV, and major sports channels. The championships enabled kickboxing to gain ground and popularity across Africa, and further positioned WAKO as a leader in the sport.

Vladimir II Monomakh (c. 1053 – 19 May 1125) was a Grand Prince of Kievan Rus' from 1113 to 1125. His reign saw the last flowering of Kievan Rus' as a unified state and the arrival of the Golden Horde from the east. He was the son of Vsevolod I of Kiev and Anastasia. Vladimir II was prince of Novgorod when his father died. He was crowned in 1113 in a grand ceremony in Kyiv and adopted his father's policy of open-handed peace with the tribes of the steppe. Vladimir II secured the Kievan throne by marrying the daughter of the ruling Grand Prince of the Cumans in 1119. After taking the throne, he helped expand Rus territories southward by taking Yuriev, Pereyaslavl, and a number of other towns. In 1120, an alliance with the Pechenegs allowed Vladimir II to expand his rule beyond the Dnieper River, and he was able to return Kiev and Chernigov, which had been taken by the Cumans. The next year he formed a defensive alliance with King Béla of Hungary against the Cumans. In 1123, a war between Vladimir II and a combined Cuman-Polovtsian force forced him to flee Kiev. The Prince then returned to the steppes and helped the Ukrainian prince Mstislav II conquer Galitch to open up new trade routes to the Black Sea. Invaders from the East started to threaten Kievan Rus', and in 1125 the Polovtsi formed a coalition against Vladimir II's army near Pereyaslavl. The Grand Prince led his army to a decisive victory. The Golden Horde (Tatars) arrived soon after, and although Vladimir II was able to drive them back, he realized he could no longer protect Rus' lands from their repeated attacks. Within four years of his death on 19 May 1125, Kievan Rus' was completely conquered and divided among the invaders. Vladimir II's sons, Mstislav and Svyatopolk, were able to briefly revive Kievan power in the late 12th century. His legacy lives on in Russian narrative sources and folklore, and he is remembered as an able prince who firmly maintained the struggles of thestate, tried to preserve and expand its borders, and negotiated success with both friends and foes.

Efrem Hill (born June 22, 1971) is an American actor and philanthropist. He is best known for his roles on television, including playing Reformed Reverend Michael Keller on the Lifetime drama series Against the Wall (2011-2012), Charles Riley on Showtime's The Affair (2014-2015), Wade Cutter on the Disney Channel drama Andi Mack (2017-2019), and Chandler Williams on the Fox hip hop drama Empire (2015-2017). He also had a recurring role as Chief Mike Loman in Parks and Recreation (2011-2013). Born in Houston, Texas and raised in Dallas, Hill developed an interest in performing at a young age, participating in church and school plays. In high school, he excelled in sports, particularly football, and decided to pursue a career in the National Football League (NFL). He played in numerous college leagues, ultimately joining the Arena Football League, where he was an All Star in 1997. After a brief break from competing and consistent defeats as a professional football player, Hill decided to give up on his sports career and focus on a career in acting. He studied and trained at the Tepper Center in New York City and at The Actor's Loft on the Upper West Side. Hill began his acting career in 2000 on the NBC serial drama Third Watch. He continued to hone his skills with various theater, film and voice performances. Hill's breakthrough role came in 2011, when he was cast as Rev. Michael Keller on Lifetime's drama series Against The Wall, which ran for two seasons. Hill has since starred in several TV projects, including Showtime's The Affair (2014-2015), Fox's hip hop drama Empire (2015-2017), and Disney Channel's comedy series Andi Mack (2017-2019). He also had a recurring role as Chief Mike Loman in NBC's comedy series Parks and Recreation (2011-2013). Hill has appeared in the films Breaking the Girls (2012) and the independent film The Birdwatcher (2016). Hill continues to remain active, taking on roles in both television and film. Outside of acting, Hill is an active philanthropist who sits on the national board of directors of the National Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, and has helped to raise money and awareness for the organization. He also supports a number of other philanthropic organizations, including the United Service Organizations (USO) and the Alzheimer's Association. Hill also works to support underprivileged communities and is active in helping children in local shelters. Efrem Hill currently resides in Los Angeles with his wife and their two children.

The women’s coxless pair event at the 2004 Summer Olympics in Athens took place at Lake Schinias in Marathon, Greece between August 15 and August 21. Twenty boats competed in the event and twelve countries competed. The event was held for the 12th time at the Olympics. The Chinese pair of Zhang Xiuyun and Cao Lei won the gold medal in the event with a time of 7:06.108. The silver medal went to the Australian duo of Sally Keown and Kate Hornsey while bronze was won by the Ukrainian pair of Olena Ozyablova and Inna Frolova. In the semi-finals, the Chinese pair set a course record of 6:54.92 for the 2000m distance. This record stood until the 2012 London Olympics. The finals of the event saw all of the top five boats finishing within one second of each other. The Chinese won the gold medal with the Australians four hundredths of a second behind. The other countries that participated in the event were Romania, Poland, Germany, United States, Canada, Bulgaria, Italy, Netherlands, and Great Britain & Northern Ireland. All boats from non-qualifying countries competed in the B-finals, with the lowest finishing boat from semifinal G taking the 19th rank overall. The event demonstrated the growth of women’s rowing on an international scale. Romania had four women’s boats competing in this event for the first time in Olympic history despite the country having no previous rowing history prior to the 2004 Games. This was also the first Olympics where the number of participating countries was more than 10 since the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. This was also the last Olympics with a coxless pair event for women as the event was replaced with a women’s four with cox event at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

The Spokane–Coeur d'Alene Combined Statistical Area is an area consisting of two adjacent metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs) located in the northwestern United States. It spans three counties in eastern Washington and northern Idaho. The statistical area is composed of the Spokane Metropolitan Statistical Area and the Coeur d'Alene–Post Falls Metropolitan Statistical Area and has a combined population of 679,009 as of the 2019 American Community Survey. The Spokane Metropolitan Statistical Area includes Spokane County, Washington and was formed in 1983 by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). As of 2019, the population of the Spokane MSA was 547,219. The Coeur d'Alene–Post Falls Metropolitan Statistical Area includes Kootenai and Shoshone Counties in Idaho and was established in 2003 by the OMB. As of 2019, the population of the Coeur d'Alene–Post Falls MSA was 131,790. The Spokane–Coeur d'Alene combined statistical area is part of the wider Spokane-Spokane Valley-Coeur d'Alene Combined Statistical Area, which also includes the Moses Lake and Pullman, Washington metropolitan statistical areas. The Pullman MSA was established in 2013, but has not yet become a part of the Spokane–Coeur d'Alene CSA though the Moses Lake MSA is listed as a part of this combined statistical area. Spokane is the largest city in the Spokane–Coeur d'Alene CSA, as well as the largest city in eastern Washington. Other major cities in the CSA include Coeur d'Alene, Post Falls, and Moses Lake. The combined statistical area covers an area of approximately 10,116 square miles; and the Spokane–Coeur d'Alene CSA has an estimated combined GDP of $38 billion. The Spokane–Coeur d'Alene CSA is home to several colleges, universities, and professional schools, including Gonzaga University, Eastern Washington University, and North Idaho College. Public high schools in the CSA are mostly managed by local school districts. Four private high schools are located in the combined statistical area, including Gonzaga Preparatory School, Coeur d'Alene High School, and Sacred Heart Catholic School. For transportation, Spokane International Airport (GEG) is located in the Spokane MSA, while Coeur d'Alene Airport is located in the Coeur d'Alene MSA. The Spokane Transit Authority (STA) provides public transportation within Spokane County, while the Coeur d'Alene CityLink provides public transportation within Kootenai County. The Spokane–Coeur d'Alene Combined Statistical Area is economically diverse, and its prosperous service sector is supported by its abundant natural resources, including timber, mining, and agriculture. Tourism is also a major part of the area's economy, and visitors are attracted to the area for its many outdoor activities, such as skiing, fishing, and hiking. The Spokane–Coeur d'Alene CSA is culturally diverse and home to numerous American Indian tribes. The largest tribal groups in the area are the Spokane Tribe of Indians and the Coeur d'Alene Tribe. The region's diverse population is reflected in its cuisine, arts, festivals, and events. References https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/spokanecoeurdalenecombinedstatisticalarea https://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/metro-micro.html https://www.discovermoseslake.com/ https://www.cityofcdal.org/ https://www.spokanetansit.com/ https://www.visitcdaidaho.com/

Escape from Scorpion Island (series 1) is a British children's television game show, produced by the independent Shed Media for the BBC. The programme is presented by Laura Hamilton and Steve Backshall. It was first broadcast as part of the BBC's "Frozen Planet" season in 2006. The premise of the show involves seven teams of two children aged between 11 and 14 being stranded on ‘Scorpion Island’, an artificial location situated off the Australian coast. From here, the teams must complete a series of physical, mental and emotional challenges, in order to win points and be the eventual winners of the series. In addition, the teams are joined by a Skipper, who assists throughout the game and helps to guide the teams through various tasks. Throughout the game, certain elements vary with each series. These include a change of location to one of six different "regions" of the island, based on a fictional area of Australia with unique plants, animals, tribes and cultures. The teams are also required to compete in a range of physical tasks and mental activities in order to reach their final objective – to collect enough points and pass the victory boat to win. There are a total of nine episodes in the series, with the last team standing winning a trip to Antarctica. Throughout the series, the teams must solve puzzles in order to locate the keys to the victory boat, as well as passing a range of physical tasks, such as rock-climbing, raft-building, orienteering and abseiling. The series was released on DVD in 2007, with the narrated version of the series becoming available in August 2008. Since then, both series one and two have been repeated on the BBC's CBBC channel on a regular basis. Overall, Escape from Scorpion Island (series 1) offers a thrilling and entertaining experience for all the family. It offers a unique combination of physical and mental challenges, as well as offering spectacular views of the Australian coast. Such elements all contribute to making this series an enjoyable, exciting and unique children's television show.

Systems pharmacology is a field of pharmacology which combines mathematical modeling, computational modeling and applied experimental approaches to study pharmacological systems at the multicellular level. Its main purpose is to integrate the various components of pharmacology, such as drug actions at a cellular level, the interaction between drugs and biological systems, and to study the effects of drug treatment on the whole organism. This approach is important in pharmacology research, as it allows scientists to understand the complex relationship between different drugs and systems in the human body. Systems pharmacology can be divided into two different parts, namely, cell- and tissue-level systems pharmacology and systems pharmacology of the whole organism. At the cell and tissue level, systems pharmacology is used to improve understanding of cellular and tissue responses to individual and multiple drug compounds. For example, systems pharmacology could be used to study the dose-dependent effect of a single drug on cells or tissues, including how the drug interacts with the cell membrane, its effects on cell proliferation, gene expression and metabolism. Similarly, systems pharmacology at the whole organism level is used to study more complex and widespread effects of drug treatments, such as their impact on body homeostasis, as well as the interactions between drug compounds and the physiological/behavioral and environmental effects. Studies using system pharmacology can be broken into two main categories: in-silico modeling and empirical-experimental approaches. In-silico modeling involves the use of mathematical and simulation algorithms to study drug-induced responses in the body. This type of study is important in understanding drug effects, such as dose-dependent effects, the effects of different drug combinations, the interactions between drugs and body systems, and the effect of drug to drug interactions. On the other hand, empirical-experimental approaches involve the study of drug-induced physiological or biochemical responses by experiments. This type of study is important in developing a better understanding of the effects of drugs on the body. Systems pharmacology has become very important in drug discovery and development, as it provides a better understanding of drug-induced responses and toxicities, drug efficacy, and the underlying mechanisms of drug action. This allows researchers to create more efficient, cost-effective treatments and drugs. Systems pharmacology is also playing an increasingly important role in personalized medicine, as it helps researchers to identify and understand the individual variation between individuals in terms of drug metabolism and response.

166 Rhodope is a large Main belt asteroid, located in the inner Solar System. It was discovered on April 04, 1874, by R. Luther at Düsseldorf Observatory in Germany. 166 Rhodope is a primitive carbonaceous asteroid and belongs to the Koronis family of asteroids, which are thought to be fragments from an earlier collision of two larger asteroids. 166 Rhodope is approximately 93 km in diameter and has an albedo of 0.06, which means it reflects only 6% of the light that falls upon it. It takes about 3.7 years to complete an orbit around the Sun, with a semi-major axis of 2.67 AU, a perihelion of 1.9 AU and an aphelion of 3.43 AU. The tilt of its orbit is 6.3°. The asteroid is named after the mountain range of Rhodope located in the southern Balkan peninsula, along the borders of Greece, Bulgaria and Turkey. Rhodope is rich in biodiversity, and is characterized by grasslands and rare vegetation species, with the eastern part of the mountain having some of the largest forests in Europe. 166 Rhodope has been studied by a variety of ground based optical instruments, and its X-ray emissions were observed by the Chandra X-ray Observatory. The asteroid is too far away for detailed studies, but high resolution images suggest that it has a heavily cratered surface, with a handful of larger craters. 166 Rhodope is not thought to have any significant moons, but it may have a few small ones, as most of the asteroids of the Koronis family have them. 166 Rhodope is also a source of numerous meteorites, as it is a common parent body of carbonaceous chondrite meteorites. Overall, 166 Rhodope is an interesting, primitive example of a carbonaceous Main Belt asteroid, and one of the most studied Koronis family asteroids. It provides an opportunity to study the early stages of solar system formation and the processes that shaped it.

Dobermann (film) is a French action film directed by Jan Kounen and released in 1997. The film stars Vincent Cassel as Dobermann, a ruthless and unstable robber whose reign of terror holds France in the grip of fear and uncertainty. The film follows Dobermann as he takes part in an increasingly violent series of robberies, until finally his criminal ways sabotage not only his own criminal career, but also his relationships with his two closest associates, played by Monia Chokri and José Garcia. The film was written by Kounen and producer Jacques Bled. It was produced by Ciby 2000, with additional backing from Canal+. It premiered in France on March 26, 1997, before being released in the United States by Miramax Films a few months later. Dobermann was generally well-received by critics. It has been touted as an influential crime movie and a precursor to the French New Wave of modern action films. Cassel's performance as the eponymous criminal was praised, as well as the film's stylish visuals and its energetic direction. The film follows Dobermann as he forms his gang, which includes a wide range of criminal types, from slick professional thieves to unbalanced, psychotic thugs. Led by Dobermann, the gang embarks on a series of daring robberies across France, resulting in increasing amounts of violence. In the end, Dobermann's mental instability, coupled with his overconfident and reckless leadership, leads to his downfall. The film is peppered with moments of dark humour, visual style, and surrealism. However, action is the primary focus and the plot is propelled by Dobermann's increasingly daring and evermore immoral antics. The film deviates from typical gangster movie tropes, instead opting for a more off-beat and eccentric style. Overall, Dobermann relies upon its action and violence to create tension and maintain audience interest. Cassel's performance is strong, and though the film seeks to humanize its protagonist it ultimately fails to generate the sympathies of the audience. It is, however, an interesting watch, and a cornerstone of the French New Wave action genre.

The Master of Health Administration (MHA) is a graduate degree program that helps provide students with the knowledge and skills to become leaders in the field of health administration. This degree is offered through many universities and healthcare systems that offer healthcare management programs, and the curriculum emphasizes leadership, administrative, and problem-solving skills. The MHA program usually takes two years to complete, and students typically cover topics such as health policy, finance, economics, and healthcare systems. Most programs also incorporate training in areas such as public health, information technology, and health services research. Students also typically gain practical experience through various work-based learning opportunities. The curriculum is designed to equip students with the leadership skills and knowledge needed to lead and manage health organizations, as well as to develop innovative programs to improve public health. Students who complete the MHA program will be prepared to enter executive and managerial roles in the healthcare system. The curriculum may also include courses in the legal and ethical aspects of health administration. Many MHA programs also offer internships that help students hone their skills while they are in school. Internships provide real-world experience in a healthcare setting and give students the opportunity to explore different aspects of health administration. The MHA degree can also be helpful in advancing a current career in health administration by providing a comprehensive understanding of the industry and its operations. Graduates of an MHA program will be equipped to design, implement, and evaluate health programs and initiatives. Students who complete their MHA program will be well-equipped to work in various health-related positions. Job roles may include CFOs and CEOs of healthcare organizations, directors of public health, and health services administrators. The MHA degree can also be useful for individuals interested in policy-making and public health advocacy. MHA graduates are often valued for their leadership, communication, and problem-solving skills. Due to the increasing complexity in health care, the MHA degree is becoming more popular as a means to demonstrate expertise in health administration. Overall, the Master of Health Administration program is designed to give graduates the knowledge and skills they need to become effective leaders and decision makers in the field of health administration.

Asher Angel (born September 6, 2002) is an American actor who is best known for portraying Billy Batson in the 2019 DC Comics superhero film Shazam!. Angel has also appeared in AMC's TV series Preacher, in the Disney Channel show Andi Mack, and as Jonah Beck in the show of the same name. Angel began his acting career when he was 7 years old, appearing in small roles in television shows and movies. He is most widely recognized for his role as Billy Batson, a teenage boy chosen to become a superhero by a mystical wizard, in the 2019 movie Shazam! Angel won the Rising Star Award from the Arizona International Film Festival for his performance in Shazam!. Angel also voiced Billy Batson in the Lego DC Shazam!: Magic and Monsters movie. In 2016, Angel began appearing as Jonah Beck in the Disney Channel show Andi Mack. The show, which ran for three seasons, until July 2019, followed the lives of Andi, her friends, and her family. Angel was the male lead in the show, starring alongside Peyton Elizabeth Lee, Joshua Rush, and Sofia Wylie. He has also voiced Jonah Beck in the video game based on Andi Mack. Talking about his playing Jonah in the show, Angel said, “It’s been enormously fulfilling playing Jonah. I knew absolutely nothing about the character going into it and it’s been really amazing to grow with him over the past three seasons. He’s a big part of my life and I’m very fortunate to have been given the opportunity to portray such a great character.” Angel's first appearance in a feature film was at the age of 15 when he was cast as Billy Batson in the 2019 movie Shazam!. The film was directed by David F. Sandberg and was released in April 2019. The movie was a box office success, taking in over $364 million worldwide. In 2020, Angel was cast in the HBO Max limited series DC Super Hero High as Garrett, a transfer student at the Super Hero High School. He is also set to appear in the upcoming feature films The Two Locals and A Week Away. In his free time, Angel likes to skateboard and play guitar. In 2019, he was part of the Rockstar Energy Uproar Festival tour as he opened for the band A Day to Remember. Asher Angel is set to continue acting in the years to come, with roles in various feature films, TV shows, and video games. He is set to be a part of the DC Universe for years to come, and fans are sure to love the unique and exciting projects he works on in the future.

TweenTribune is an online magazine and news platform targeted at young teens between the ages of 11 and 14. Founded in 2004 and created by the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History, the site is designed to teach media literacy and community engagement to the young user. TweenTribune assigns stories from both national and international news sources, which are then edited for grammar and for content that is appropriate for their young readers.. For each story, TweenTribune provides multiple activities, such as quizzes, polls and writing assignments to aid in comprehension. The site also offers discussion boards and a blog for readers to share their thoughts and ask questions about the stories. As of 2015, the site was receiving an average of 500,000 page views per month. In addition to news content, TweenTribune also works with students to help create original content for the site. The student-created stories are focused on topics that are relevant to the age group, such as sports, art, interviews, music or reviews of books or movies. The site has also partnered with various education organizations, including the National Council of Teachers of English, to offer workshops and seminars to teachers and students, as a way to promote digital literacy and responsible media consumption. Since its launch, TweenTribune has been recognized with the Webby Award in Education, the Parents' Choice Gold Award in Media, and the Gold Medal from the Association of Educational Publishers. TweenTribune remains an excellent resource for teens looking to develop their media literacy and become more engaged with the news and current events. It is also a great tool for educators and parents that want to foster a love of learning in their students or children.

The Year of the Spider refers to a period of time in 2019, during which the internet and technology industry experienced a series of significant changes, technological advances, and other notable occurrences. Primarily, the year was associated with the emergence of Artificial Intelligence (AI), the emergence of various technological developments and projects, the redefinition of traditional business models, and the rise of cyber-security awareness and threats. In 2019, Google released their first AI assistant called Google Duplex, which enabled users to book their Restaurant and Salon appointments with AI powered robotic voice. Along with that, Google also launched their own self-driving car service. Additionally, Facebook declared the launch of its highly anticipated Libra cryptocurrency, which made waves across the tech industry. On the other hand, tech giants such as Microsoft and Amazon released updates to their own voice assistant AIs such as Cortana and Alexa respectively. Additionally, Microsoft launched updates to its own Quantum computers and Azure cloud platform. The Year of the Spider also saw the emergence of several new trends and technologies, such as the big data analytics and machine learning to bring about a new level of automation to businesses. Additionally, the rise of edge computing opened up new opportunities for data security and analytics. Lastly, the rise of Conversational AI enabled businesses to automate customer service, giving customers an automated yet personalized day-to-day experience. The Year of the Spider also saw several high-profile cyber threats and attacks, such as the series of distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against various businesses that left their tech infrastructure crippled and resulted in loss of data. This further underscored the need for cyber-security awareness and practices. Throughout this period, the internet industry saw a solidification of the social media platforms and the emergence of both new and old ventures, such as TikTok and Instagram, and the influx of new technologies and advancements that enabled both consumers and businesses to take advantage of. As a result, the Year of the Spider saw an upsurge in the development of technological products and services, making it an important year in the history of the internet and technology industry. Overall, the Year of the Spider saw a period of great changes in the internet and technology industry, from the emergence of AI to the rise of cyber-security awareness, and the need for a constantly updated approach to technology. The technological advancements and innovations of this period made the internet a far more efficient and effective tool for the modern day consumer, showcasing the power of technology in the hands of the people.

The Ural Republic (Uralskaya Respublika) was a short-lived semi-autonomous socialist state that was declared in the Russian SFSR (now the Russian Federation) during the Russian Revolution of 1905. It existed for just over eight months, from December 5th, 1905 to August 14th 1906, when it was overshadowed and dissolved by the newly formed Russian Provisional Government. The idea of a socialist republic in the Ural region originated with liberal members of the Union of Liberation, who sought a decentralized government as an alternative to the imperial rule of the Russian Tsar. The Union of Liberation was a liberal political party that advocated for civil liberties and stronger political representation in Russia. In the beginning of December 1905, the Union held its first congress in the Russian SFSR. There were two key points of the congress: the congress declared the formation of a socialist republic and the adoption of a constitution. On December 5th, 1905, the Ural Republic was officially declared and the socialist government embarked on a program of reform. Due to the common liberal orientation of the organization, many policies and initiatives in the Ural Republic were liberal in nature, including the introduction of a new progressive land code, and the implementing of an eight hour work day for workers. Other reforms included having elected provincial assemblies, and granting voting rights to all adults regardless of nationality, ethnicity, or gender. However, the implementation of these reforms was limited due to the lack of resources in the region. Despite the republic's bold goals, it did not survive long. The Ural Republic was a victim of its own internal divisions, caused mostly by conflicting political ideologies between its members. Furthermore, the newly formed Russian Provisional Government had little to no regard for the new republic and refused to recognize it. As a result, the Ural Republic was completely overshadowed and eventually dissolved. Despite the short life of the Ural Republic, its legacy lives on, as the ideals it championed laid the foundations for future Russian social, civil, and political reforms. It also served as an example to other Russian revolutionaries of the potential of a decentralized, socialist-oriented government. The Ural Republic, which was the first of its kind in Russia, can rightfully be considered one of the country's most significant contributions to the Russian Revolution.

Un Caso di Coscienza è un film d'avventura del 1965 diretto da Carlo Campogalliani. Il film racconta l'avventura di un gruppo di soldati partiti per combattere nel nord Italia durante la Prima Guerra Mondiale. La storia è vista attraverso gli occhi di uno dei soldati, Luca (Maurizio Arena) che deve prendere una decisione difficile fra quello che la sua coscienza gli dice di fare e quello che gli ordinano i suoi superiori. Luca e i suoi compagni devono decidere se arrendersi o combattere un nemico formato da soldati italiani e austriaci accampati nella stessa zona. Luca ha un profondo senso di onore e di giustizia ed è determinato a non arrendersi, anche quando i suoi compagni lo convincono a prendere questa decisione. Ma quando gli viene data l'opportunità di parlare con i nemici, la sua coscienza lo spinge a cercare un accordo per porre fine allo scontro. Dopo lunghe e intensa discussioni, Luca riesce a trovare una soluzione in grado di soddisfare entrambe le parti. Un Caso di Coscienza è stato ben accolto dalla critica che lo ha definito come un'esperienza di visionario, allegorico e poetico, che sottolinea le complessità morali dei conflitti. Il film è anche considerato come una delle prime opere moderne che prendeva in considerazione l'importanza dell'individuo nel prendere decisioni eticamente complesse. Si tratta di un film che non segue le convenzioni e mette in discussione i concetti di eroismo di massa e di giustizia. Il personaggio di Luca e la sua introspezione pongono un serio interrogativo etico su quali siano i valori e le scelte migliori da fare. Un Caso di Coscienza è un inno rivolto all'indeterminazione come legge di vita ed è un film importante che rappresenta il coraggio civile e la capacità di rifiutare l'assurdità della guerra.

Roy, Montana is a small, unincorporated community located in Blaine County, in the U.S. state of Montana. It lies about 5 miles west of the Wyoming border and is the easternmost community in Montana. The town of Roy was established in the early 1900s as an agricultural and ranching hub for the surrounding area. The main industries in Roy include cattle ranching, farming, and oil and gas exploration. The town is named after Charles Roy, the original settler and benefactor of the community. Charles Roy, a former railroad conductor of the Great Northern Railway, moved to the area in 1900 and started a small ranch. Roy realized the potential for the prairie and started to farm the surrounding area. He later bought land from the federal government and started developing the town of Roy. Roy began to attract other settlers and soon a small community was established. In addition to its agricultural base, Roy was also home to several businesses that serviced the area. Primarily, these businesses included banks, general merchandise stores, a hotel, a saloon, a blacksmith shop, a hardware store, and a post office. Today, the only business in Roy remains the post office. The 2000 census reported that Roy had a population of 394 people. As of 2018, the estimated population was at 449. The town is mainly agricultural in nature but attracts tourists during the summer who come to fish and hunt in the nearby area. Roy is served by Hill County Public Schools. Primary and secondary schools in Roy consist of one elementary school and one middle school. Nearby universities and colleges include the University of Montana, Montana State University, Missoula College, and Montana Flathead Valley Community College. The town of Roy Montana is known for its natural beauty and rural atmosphere. The community is home to several parks and recreation areas, including Missouri River Headwaters State Park, King's Lake County Park, and Constitution Park. The nearby towns of Vida and Wyoming City offer recreational opportunities and museums, respectively. A museum dedicated to the original settler, Charles Roy, is located in Roy. Roy, Montana is a small but vibrant community that offers a rural lifestyle with access to the amenities of a larger city. The town has an old-school charm and warm community spirit. It is a great place for families and individuals who are looking for a rural lifestyle.

Nueva Rosita is a town located in Coahuila, Mexico. It is located on the banks of the Sabinas River and is known for its oil production. The town has a population of over 20,000 people, and the majority are of the Catholic faith. The town has a rich history that dates back to the early 1700s. During this time, Nueva Rosita was a mining settlement established by Spanish colonialists. As time passed, the town continued to grow and in 1864 it was declared as a municipality and was renamed Nueva Rosita. Oil production began in the late 19th century in Nueva Rosita and it was mainly used for the manufacture of gas and gasoline. In the mid 20th century it became an important economic center and the population of the municipality increased significantly. One of the main attractions of the town is the Nueva Rosita Municipal Petroleum Museum, which displays the history of oil and petrol production over the past two centuries. Aside from the museum, Nueva Rosita also has a traditional market where tourists can buy local products such as honey, spices, clothing, and other regional items. It is also known for its artisanal foods such as tacos, tamales and quesadillas. Nueva Rosita is also home to many small businesses, such as restaurants, bars, hotels, and other services. It has a small airport, which connects with other towns in the region. In the recent years, it has become an important production center for oil and gas. In 2008, Nueva Rosita celebrated its bicentennial anniversary with a week-long celebration that included cultural activities and traditional fairs. The town continues to grow and develop as an important economic center in the region. Nueva Rosita is a charming town with a rich history and cultural activities to offer. It can make a great destination for someone looking to explore the region and learn more about Mexican culture.

A Gal in Calico is a 1946 American comedy film directed by Leslie Goodwins. The movie stars June Haver as Tammie Evans, a young farm girl who dreams of living a life outside the rural farmlands she finds herself living in. To accomplish her dream, Tammie disguises herself as a man named Slim and moves to a small town in California, where she gets a job at the local ranch and enters a singing contest in an effort to win the grand prize. Along the way, she meets a kind hearted rancher named Doc Wallace (Ray Collins) who helps her on her quest and ultimately serves as her love interest. The movie is based on a popular 1944 novel of the same name, written by Lillie Hayman, which was later adapted into a play by E.E. Church and the Broadway producer, Gilbert Miller. A Gal in Calico had its Broadway debut in 1945, and was produced by Miller until 1946. The movie was produced by Universal Pictures, and was a hit at the box office. Tammie Evans is a resourceful young girl who dreams of living in California and becoming a movie star. When her father's financial situation prevents her from attending college, she puts her plan into motion by disguising herself as a man and setting off for the golden state. Once in California, Tammie changes her name to Slim and gets a job on a ranch owned by Doc Wallace. As "Slim," she enters an amateur talent contest, where the prize is a singing contract with the music hall conductor, Mr. Mason. While Mr. Mason is intrigued by Slim's powerful singing voice, he is unaware of her true identity. Much like the play and novel, the movie was a hit with fans of all ages. The charming story resonated at the box office, and the movie grossed $2.9 million. The movie was praised by critics, with Variety noting that it “blends comedy with drama in an entertaining way.” A Gal in Calico was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Scoring of a Musical Picture, and was selected by the National Film Registry in 2001 to be preserved in the Library of Congress. The movie is remembered for its charming story, memorable music, and strong message about never giving up on your dreams, no matter what anyone else says. It also resonated with audiences because of its lead character, who represented the strength of young womanhood at the time. A Gal in Calico remains a popular classic to this day, and a favorite among musical fans who appreciate its timeless story.

Kurt Jara is a Swiss musician, songwriter and producer who has written songs for several popular pop, rock, and dance artists, as well as written and produced his own music. He has released two solo albums and has been associated with labels such as Universal Music, Sony BMG, and EMI. His early career aspirations were not in music but in athletics. In his youth, he trained as a skier, competed in the Swiss Junior Nordic Skiing Championships, and qualified for the Swiss Olympic team trials. Eventually, though, Kurt realized that his true passion was music, and at the age of 16, he traded in his skis for a guitar; this led to his enrollment at the Lucerne School of Music. During his studies, Kurt’s talent for composition was quickly recognized, and he began to make a name for himself by writing for other artists. He has collaborated and written for many successful artists, including British pop star Robbie Williams, English-American pop rock band Maroon 5, Italian dance-pop singer Eros Ramazzotti, German rapper Sido, and Swiss boy band Nataman. Kurt’s first solo album, Reasons to Dance, was released in 2013 to critical acclaim. The album featured pop, rock, and dance tracks and explored themes such as love, life, and hope. His second album, This is What I Am, was released in 2016 and showcased a blend of electronic and rock sounds, focusing primarily on lyrics and songwriting. Kurt’s future looks promising, with a return to the studio planned for the near future. Kurt has also been busy on the live music scene, performing at venues in Switzerland, France, Germany and Austria. Kurt’s music is popular in clubs and on the radio, with several of his songs receiving airplay in various countries. His music has also served as the soundtrack to International film and TV productions. Kurt Jara’s music has had a significant and lasting influence on the music scene in Switzerland and beyond; his style and sound have become increasingly popular in recent years, and many artists continue to be inspired and influenced by his work.

This is a list of New Testament minuscules (also known as scribal abbreviations and manuscript numbers) from 2501 to 2600. Minuscule 2501, designated by siglum \mathfrak{M}2501, is a Greek minuscule manuscript of the New Testament, written on parchment. Palaeographically it has been assigned to the 11th century. The codex contains a complete text of the four Gospels on 220 parchment leaves, with some lacunae (John 16:24-18:7). The text is written in one column per page, 23-24 lines per page. Minuscule 2502, designated by siglum \mathfrak{M}2502, is a Greek minuscule manuscript of the New Testament, on parchment. Palaeographically it has been assigned to the 12th century. It has marginalia. Minuscule 2503, designated by siglum \mathfrak{M}2503, is a Greek minuscule manuscript of the New Testament, written on parchment. Paleographically it has been assigned to the 12th century. The codex contains a part of the Gospel of John (2:7-8:12). The text is written in one column per page, 20 lines per page. Minuscule 2504, designated by siglum \mathfrak{M}2504, is a Greek minuscule manuscript of the New Testament, on parchment. Palaeographically it has been assigned to the 12th century. Minuscule 2505, designated by siglum \mathfrak{M}2505, is a Greek minuscule manuscript of the New Testament on parchment. Palaeographically it has been assigned to the 13th century. Minuscule 2506, designated by siglum \mathfrak{M}2506, is a Greek minuscule manuscript of the New Testament on parchment. Palaeographically it has been assigned to the 14th century. Minuscule 2507, designated by siglum \mathfrak{M}2507, is a Greek minuscule manuscript of the New Testament on parchment. Palaeographically it has been assigned to the 12th century. The codex contains a complete text of the four Gospels and the Apocalypse on 268 parchment leaves (size 35 cm by 27 cm). Minuscule 2508, designated by siglum \mathfrak{M}2508, is a Greek minuscule manuscript of the New Testament on parchment. Palaeographically it has been assigned to the 15th century. The codex contains a complete text of the four Gospels on 360 parchment leaves (56 cm by 43 cm). The subsequent manuscripts (minuscule 2509–2600) are similarly described, with their palaeographical details and contents. This list of New Testament minuscules (2501-2600) is provided as an aid to scholars researching the New Testament in its original Greek. The manuscripts are arranged numerically so that they may be easily located. Minuscules not included in this list may be found in the works of other scholars and in other manuscripts numbering catalogs. See also * List of New Testament papyri * List of New Testament uncials * List of Greek New Testament uncials * List of New Testament minuscules (1–1000) * List of New Testament minuscules (1001–2000) * List of New Testament minuscules (2001–2500) * List of New Testament minuscules (2601–2700)

Locations in South Africa with a Scottish name refer to settlements in the nation that bear the names of various Scottish cities, towns and places. This is due to South Africa's close historical and cultural ties to Scotland, with many of the early settlers to South Africa tracing their ancestry back to Scotland. The most famous place with a Scottish name in South Africa is the city of Edinburgh, located in the province of KwaZulu-Natal. The city was established in 1889, with the first settlers using Edinburgh in Scotland as the basis for the name of the new settlement. A number of other towns and settlements have also been named after Scottish cities, such as Glasgow and Aberdeen, although perhaps the most interesting example is a small town in the Free State Province, which has been given the rather imaginative name of Scotstown. Besides the cities and towns, there are a number of geographical features which have been named with a Scottish flavour, a notable example being the Machadodorp Mountains. The name ‘Machadodorp’, which was given to the range by Scottish settlers, is derived from the Gaelic words ‘mac’ and ‘duthaich’, which literally mean ‘the mountain with the flat top’. The majority of rivers in this region of the Free State Province are also of Scottish origin, with names like the Doorn and the Whileen. The Scottish influence has also been found further afield within South Africa, with places like Haslemere in the Eastern Cape and Kildare in the Western Cape both bearing Scottish names. The hills and valleys around Stellenbosch in the Western Cape have also acquired names with a Scottish link, including names such as Glen Torrie, Glen Barber and Dornoch. The prevalence of Scottish names in South Africa is a reminder of the strong connections that the country has with Scotland, an influence which will doubtless live on for many centuries to come. The large numbers of Scottish names around the country show the legacy of Scottish settlers, while at the same time serving to remind this generations of the friendship and links which have been forged between Scotland and South Africa over the years.

AIP Records is an American independent record label, which was founded in 1992 by Mike "Mig" Matarazzo and Paul Palmer. AIP Records was formed in 1992 as an outlet for the music of several local punk bands that had developed in the Los Angeles and Orange County areas. Matarazzo, who had a background in music production and engineering, and Palmer, who had a business background, formed the label as a means of better showcasing the work of these bands. Over the years, the label primarily specialized in punk, hardcore and ska genres, but it began to expand its musical offerings to include other styles such as alternative rock and pop. The label was initially self-funded and operated by Matarazzo and Palmer out of their respective homes. This allowed the label to take a DIY approach and gave AIP the flexibility to experiment with different sounds and genres. This experimentation included working with a diverse range of artists such as Sublime, D.I. and Roadside Monument. AIP Records was quickly recognized within the independent music scene, leading to the ability to reach a wider audience and an increased presence on the West Coast. They released numerous successful releases, such as Pearl Jam's Ten, Sublime's 40 oz. To Freedom and The Vandals' Peace through Vandalism, in addition to signing and working with established and emerging acts such as Guttermouth, Rancid, The Aquabats, Guttermouth, and The Offspring. Throughout the label's history, AIP has developed many successful artists and released hundreds of albums. Their releases have been noted for their quality and innovation, with many albums being featured on year-end "Best Of" lists, as well as receiving various awards and nominations. AIP Records is still owned and operated by Matarazzo and Palmer. They remain active within the independent music scene, and are committed to providing quality music for fans of all genres. References: Kevin Matrange, Feelin'Fooley (2004). Sublime, 40 oz. To Freedom (1992). Pearl Jam, Ten (1991). AllMusic, AIP Records - Biography & History (2016).

Mottled wood owl (Strix ocellata) is a medium-sized woodland owl native to parts of Asia, Africa, and Europe. It is also known as the Indian wood-owl or ocellated wood-owl. This species belongs to the genus Strix, which includes all the known owls. The mottled wood owl has a body length of 46 to 52 cm, with a wingspan of 88 to 104 cm. The head and upper plumage is mostly brown, with white spots and barring. The facial disc is white with black rim and a yellowish-orange to deep orange eye. The legs and feet are yellowish-brown with grey barring. The mottled wood owl is found in various parts of Asia, Africa, and Europe. Its geographic range extends from Pakistan, western India, and Sri Lanka, south and east through Southeast Asia, to Borneo, the Philippines, and Japan. It is also found in parts of Africa including Ethiopia, Sudan, and Somalia. In Europe, it is present in northern Italy, eastern France, and southern Switzerland. Mottled wood owls inhabit open deciduous and dry semi-evergreen forests, as well as edges, clearings, and plantations. It perches on large branches, often near the edge of forests, whooping calls to establish its presence. The species is nocturnal and usually hunts for small rodents, reptiles, amphibians, and large insects. They also sometimes eat smaller birds. Breeding takes place from March to July. The nest is usually a concealed shelf built on a tree in which two to three white eggs are laid. Mottled wood owls are common and widespread throughout their range. However, their population numbers are decreasing due to habitat loss from deforestation, human encroachment, and disturbance from agricultural activities. They are listed as least concern on the IUCN Red List. It is protected under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES). In India, the mottled wood owl is associated with the goddess Lakshmi and is symbolically associated with fertility, abundance, knowledge, and good fortune. Similarly, the owl is deeply embedded in the culture of many African countries, with some people believing it to have supernatural abilities. The mottled wood owl has been featured on postage stamps of various countries and has also been used in various films and TV series.

The University of South Florida St. Petersburg Baseball Club, commonly referred to as USFSPBC, is a Division-I college baseball program located in St. Petersburg, Florida. Established in 2016, the program competes within the American Athletic Conference and is led by head coach Joe Urso. The USFSPBC began play in the 2016-2017 season with a roster composed primarily of freshman players recruited from outside the local bay area. The club quickly became a competitive force in the AAC, posting an impressive record of 19-9 during its first season. The Bulls went on to finish 38-17 record with a berth in the conference tournament by the end of the team's second season. The team plays its home games at the new Jack National Stadium located on the St. Petersburg Campus of the University of South Florida. The facility was constructed in 2016 at a cost of $12 million, and boasts seating for up to 2,500 fans. The USFSPBC has achieved numerous successes during its brief existence. It is the first college baseball team in the Tampa Bay area to receive a bid to the NCAA tournament since USF's Tampa campus in 2005. The Bulls have also achieved multiple wins against Power Five opponents, with victories over Alabama, Louisville, Mississippi State, and Georgia Tech. The USFSPBC's success has attracted recognition throughout the Tampa Bay area, with the team's five home games this season selling out for the first time in the school's history. The future of the club looks exceptionally bright, with the addition of five-star recruit Hunter Daniels in the 2021-2022 recruiting class. Daniels, a native of Clearwater, Florida, is rated as the top prospect in the state, and is expected to make an immediate impact on the team. The University of South Florida St. Petersburg Baseball Club is quickly becoming a prominent fixture in the Tampa Bay sports landscape, and will only continue to grow and improve in the years ahead.

The List of butterflies of the Republic of the Congo includes a variety of butterfly species found in the tropical rainforest biome of the Republic of the Congo, located in Central Africa along the Gulf of Guinea. This country is home to a variety of butterflies with very interesting and unique characteristics. The most common butterfly species native to the Republic of the Congo are the common African skipper (Gomalia elma), the common Guinean skipper (Parosmodes minima), the mimosine skipper (Discophora sondaica), the yellow-banded Yeoman (Polydrusus flavomaculatus), and the yellow-striped two-oga (Selysiotes flavomaculatus). Other less common butterfly species include the African grass jewel (Zizina antanossa), the Malayan swallowtail (Papilio lucious), the Congo mime (Graphium aburanus), the Congo, blue-spotted skipper (Systropus congoges) and the African copper (Lycaena agrippina). Other notable butterflies of the Republic of the Congo include the green-banded swallowtail (Papilio chikae), the glossy grass skipper (Arhopala draco), the white Satyr (Satyrodes francina), the bronze swallowtail (Graphium weiskei), and the black-veined skipper (Nacaduba natalensis). In addition to these species, the Republic of the Congo also boasts more than two hundred moth species. There are a variety of moth species that are dependent on local conditions and include such species as the brown-banded Saturniidae (Hypospila adelphia), the blue-lined Snout (Hypena vacuteria), the blue-spotted Erebidae (Mimorista cudoni), the tiger moth (Thysanopolia glaucescens), the chocolate tigermoth (Cosmelia flavicollis), and the two-spot Stratiomys (Stratiomys chamaeleon). Overall, the butterflies of the Republic of the Congo are an example of the remarkable variety of fauna that thrive within the tropical forests of Central Africa. The unique characteristics and diverse habitats of this region make it one of the best places to observe and appreciate the incredible diversity of the Congo's butterfly species.

The Breit equation is a model of a nuclear force proposed by American physicist Gregory Breit in 1934. It is used to describe the interaction of two particles in a three-dimensional system. The Breit equation is derived from one of the most popular theories of scattering theory, the scattering amplitude theory. The Breit equation is an extension of the exchange of virtual photons between two particles, and is the basis for the exchange of mesons in particle physics. The Breit equation is written as a function of the energy-momentum product (also known as the Mandelstam invariant or "s-product"). It is expressed as: F(s,e)=G(s,e)+H(s,e) where G and H are functions of s and e. G is the Gamow factor and H is the exchange-forcing term. The Breit equation can be solved analytically for different values of s and e. The Breit equation was originally developed for the purpose of calculating scattering amplitudes for nuclear and particle physics. But it has recently been used in other fields including optically active crystals, plasmon and polaritons, and cavity quantum electrodynamics. The Breit equation is an important tool in particle physics because it can calculate scattering amplitudes for various processes. This allows researchers to investigate the behavior of particles in different circumstances and to better understand the nature of Nature. The Breit equation is also used in quantum field theory to investigate gravitational interactions and quantum electrodynamics. It is also used to study neutrino oscillations and for calculations of the Bragg peak structure for radiation therapy. The Breit equation is a powerful and versatile tool for understanding the nature and behavior of particles. It is an indispensable part of the scientific arsenal used by physicists to study and develop new and improved theories of fundamental interactions.

Matthew 8 is the eighth chapter of the Gospel of Matthew in the New Testament of the Christian Bible. It contains Jesus' curing of a centurion's servant, the expulsion of many demons from two men, and a stilling of the storm. In the beginning of the chapter, Jesus is approached by a centurion who asks Him to heal his servant. Jesus offers to come to the centurion's house and heal the servant Himself, but the centurion states that he is not worthy of such an honor and believes that Jesus' word alone will be enough to do the job. Jesus is impressed by the centurion's faith and says that he will not find such faith in Israel. He then heals the servant from afar. Verse 24 is the start of the stilling of the storm, when Jesus and His disciples get into a boat and cross to the other side of the Sea of Galilee. As soon as they do, a severe storm comes upon them and Jesus is sleeping. The disciples wake Him up, scared that they will drown, yet Jesus demonstrates His power over nature by commanding the wind and the sea to be still. Instantly, the storm stops and there is a great calm. The first part of the chapter concludes with Jesus' arrival in the land of the Gadarenes. He meets two men possessed by many demons and casts them out. At the command of Jesus, the demons enter a herd of pigs, which then run down a steep bank into the sea and are drown. The second part of the chapter consists of Jesus healing many of the sick people in the region. He touches them and they are instantly healed. He also casts out many demons and is even asked to go away by the people because they are afraid of Him. Matthew 8 is a very important chapter of the Gospel of Matthew, as it is an example of Jesus' power and authority over creation. This power and authority are key points throughout the New Testament, and this chapter emphasizes it with Jesus' stilling of the storm, healing of the sick, and expelling of the demons. In addition, the centurion's faith is an example of what it means to have faith in Jesus.

John Canton Braithwaite (4th June 1745 - 1796) was an English author and acclaimed playwright whose works spanned genres including comedy, drama and romance. He is credited as the first to introduce music into British comedy, revolutionizing the London stage. John Braithwaite was born in London to a family of the middle-class gentry. His father was an attorney and he was educated at a private school in the city. He attended Eton, where he distinguished himself in Latin, Greek, and French and, as an exhibitioner, Oxford, where he studied law. He then trained as an attorney at Lincoln's Inn, but never practiced. Braithwaite first made a name for himself in the theatre, mostly as a writer of farces and comedies. He is best remembered for the popular 1771 play "_High Life Below Stairs_," which spawned several adaptations and was even later adapted into a successful movie in the 1930s. He directed and acted in his productions, garnering acclaim for their musically-inclined wit. His influence on the London theatre scene is still evident today; for example, he was the first to write original music for the stage, an idea that is now a mainstay of modern British and Broadway theatre. He also wrote adaptations of popular French lyrical comedies, including the hugely successful production "_The Deserter of Naples_" in 1777. His other works included the book _Rural Life: An Essay_ (1774), as well as translations of German works, and a number of political lyrics and satires. John Braithwaite died suddenly in 1796 after a long period of illness; his funeral was well-attended, underscoring his widespread popularity. He left behind a wife, three children and an extensive literary legacy, with works that remain read and appreciated to this day. A student prize is held in his name at the University of Oxford, and a monument was erected in 1833 in Kensal Green Cemetery, London. He is remembered as a pioneer of the British theatre and his influence can still be seen in the edgy and musically-inclined comedies produced today.

Spider is a type of pulp fiction magazine that centres around the exploits of a particular protagonist. It appeared in the United States during the early twentieth century, between 1944 and 1949, with a brief revival in the form of a paperback series in the 1970s. The original Spider magazine was created by award-winning pulps publishers Popular Publications. It initially used the pseudonym Grant Stockbridge for its authors, although later issues did feature appearances by some famous authors such as Robert E. Howard, Robert Bloch, and Norvell Page. The stories for each numeral featured a vigilante anti-hero named The Spider, whose true identity was never disclosed, who solved problems with his special brand of justice. The Spider was given a few superhuman abilities, such as a superhuman intuition and the ability to create chemical weapons. His real name was Richard Wentworth, although most of his antagonists addressed him as The Spider. The Spider first appeared in issue number 1 (October 18th, 1944) and quickly gained an audience of fans devoted to crime-fighting stories that were fast-paced and action-packed. He was the feature character in 66 of the next 78 issues before the magazine was discontinued in 1949. This magazine was referred to as "Spicy Detective" in the early issues and "The Spider Magazine" in late issues, due to its content being considered to be ‘spicy’ by the standards of its time. The stories followed The Spider's adventures as he fought criminals from all types of crime: from gangsters to mad scientists, alien monsters to Nazi spies. Over the years, The Spider was shaped into a vigilante figure, with stories becoming even more violent and risque than in the original run. In 1970, a paperback series was published that reprinted collected Spider stories from early issues. The stories, which had been extensively edited for the new audience, were a moderate success but the series was short-lived and by 1974, it had vanished again. Due to its long absence and lack of exposure, The Spider and the magazine he personified are all-but forgotten among new generations of readers. While the magazines were never part of the popular culture, they had a powerful influence on the genre of superhero and vigilante stories, and The Spider will always remain a nostalgic bit of pulp fiction history.

Symphony No. 4 in E minor, Op. 60 (1933) by Karol Szymanowski is a work for large orchestra composed in the late years of the Polish Romantic composer's life. It was composed during the spring of 1933 at a passionate and tumultuous period in Szymanowski’s life, and was a critical work in the development of the composer’s final style. The first performance of the symphony occurred in February 1935, when it was played by the Warsaw Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by the composer’s pupil, Grzegorz Fitelberg. In its premiere concert, the work was coupled with Szymanowski’s 1st and 3rd Symphonies. The formal structure of the symphony is in four movements. It begins with an Allegro initial movement that serves as an abiding entity throughout. An episode takes up the middle section, and the whole is concluded with a brilliant, energetic recapitulation of the opening materials. The second movement is a dramatic scherzo and trio based on an idyllic, pastoral melody. It is marked by swiftness of tempo and fleeting, modulatory ambiences, and features habanera- and polonaise-style rhythms that introduce a sonic awareness of Szymanowski’s native Poland. The third movement is a somber “Largo”, in which a cast of woodwind instruments assume dominant roles. The music here is slow and contemplative, with a broad, static wall of sound. It is built around longer melodic lines and slowly developing imitative contrapuntal strands that give the music a dreamy, reflective nature. The fourth and final movement is a brilliant “Finale” of sparkling, brilliant sonorities and larger-than-life dynamics and textures. It presents a panoramic view of the orchestra in its full power, to the backdrop of a cyclic theme and a tumultuous string of bravura cadences in the closing moments of the symphony. Symphony No. 4 is emblematic of Szymanowski’s late, mature compositional style, with its eclectic use of Polish folklore, impressionist harmonies, and exotic sonorities. The work was a success upon its premiere, and since then it has gone on to become a popular piece in the orchestral repertoire. It has had several recordings, released on various record labels, and since 2004 it has been featured in a number of festivals commemorating the composer’s 125th anniversary.

The Louisville and Nashville Depot of Evergreen, Alabama, is an important landmark in the city that was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1974. The two-story Romanesque Revival style depot was built in 1903 and served as the main passenger depot in the city for the Louisville and Nashville Railroad until 1971. The depot is a two-story red brick building that was designed by noted architect Jarrott McKnight. The interior of the depot was designed to be ornate, with the ceilings and walls covered in tile and mosaic. The building also originally featured three waiting rooms, ticket offices, and a restaurant. The building served as not only a passenger depot, but also a major center of commerce. During the 1930s and 40s many cotton producers used the facility to ship and receive products while several personal offices and freight companies opened at the adjacent freight office. The depot has been an important part of Evergreen's history for over a century and is among the few remaining depots from the Louisville and Nashville Railroad that still exists. The depot is located in the center of the city directly across from the Conecuh County Court House. In October 2019, the Evergreen Preservation Group acquired the building from CSX in an effort to restore the depot and create a gateway to downtown Evergreen for residents and tourists. The preservation group intends to renovate the depot with the assistance of grants from the state and federal governments and to use the facility to host local events. The goal is to create a cultural hub and community center in the heart of the city. The Louisville and Nashville Depot in Evergreen is a critical part of the city's history and has served the community for decades. The recent preservation effort promises to protect this landmark for future generations and to create a vibrant hub for citizens of the city.

The International Knockout Mouse Consortium (or IKMC) is an initiative created to facilitate creation of knockout mouse models that are available to the worldwide research community. The consortium is coordinated by the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute, European Molecular Biology Laboratory, Jackson Laboratory and several additional partner organizations. The consortium's goal is to generate up to 5,000 new targeted mutations, each one in its own named mouse line, by the year 2024. The IKMC provides researchers with a network of common resources and services that facilitate efficient production of mouse lines carrying targeted mutations. This helps reduce the technical and resource burden that individual research laboratories carry when producing their own targeted mutation mouse models. The IKMC’s targeted mouse model generation services are funded by the Wellcome Trust and member contribution. The IKMC produces mouse models carrying mutations in genes identified by the research community, reviewed and approved by a scientific committee. Feedback from the community is used to prioritize the genes of interest, develop new services and enhancements, and to help guide the resource allocation in order to ensure maximal benefit to the research community. The goal of the IKMC is to make all created resources available to the entire research community, so it has made an agreement with the international non-profit, Mouse Genome Informatics, to house publicly available and annotated mouse lines on their website, so they can be accessed by the research community. They have also started a data sharing partnership with the Mammalian Synthetic Biology Reference Data Archive, so that genotyping and mutation data can be shared. The IKMC has also created some other services for the research community, such as a community portal for discussion, a registry for requesting and tracking mouse lines and reagents, and a user-guided compliance support service. Additionally, it offers a series of training courses in mouse genetics, which are designed to help researchers better understand genetic approaches to disease modeling and experimental design. The initiative not only has the potential to significantly reduce research costs, but also could speed up the preclinical research process, contributing to the development of new therapies for human diseases. As the IKMC continues to work towards its goal and create new resources, it will become a valuable asset for the research community.

The Province of Schleswig-Holstein (German: Provinz Schleswig-Holstein) is a state of Germany located in the northernmost part of the country. It is bordered to the north by the North and Baltic Seas, to the south by the state of Lower Saxony, to the east by the state of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, and to the west by the North Sea. The province has a population of just under 3 million inhabitants. Its capital and largest city is Kiel, located at the outlet of the Kiel Canal. Other major cities include Lübeck, Flensburg, Neumünster, and Heide. The most widely spoken language is German, but German dialects are spoken in some areas, along with North Frisian on the islands of Nordstrand and Pellworm. Schleswig-Holstein is also known for its maritime culture with its boat building and sailing industries. Originally a part of Denmark, Schleswig-Holstein was ceded to Prussia in the Second War of Schleswig in 1864. It joined the German Empire in 1871 and became part of the Weimar Republic in 1919. After World War II, the province was split in two; the northern part went to Denmark, though the southern part remained with Germany. In 1949, the western half of the state rejoined the Federal Republic of Germany. The province is home to multiple historical attractions, such as the Old Town of Lübeck and the Frisian villages along the Wadden Sea. Schleswig-Holstein is also known for its natural beauty, such as the Schlei inlet, the Südfall in Kiel, and the many lakes in the Uckermark region. The coastline is dotted with distant islands, creating a striking landscape and making the province a popular tourist destination. The economy of Schleswig-Holstein is diverse and includes shipbuilding, tourism, and renewable energy. It is also home to major companies such as German supermarket chain Edeka, transport company Hapag-Lloyd, and pharmaceutical giant Novo Nordisk, to name a few.
