Schleswig-Holstein is known as the "Land of the Two Seas" for its unique dual coastlines. The province is rich in history and culture, and continues to play a pivotal role in the politics and economy of northern Germany.

Golyam Rezen (Bulgarian: Голям Резен) is a small town in southeastern Bulgaria located in the Haskovo Province. It is situated on the banks of the Arda River, about 20 km from the provincial capital of Haskovo. The town is known for its picturesque surroundings and its rich cultural heritage. Golyam Rezen has a population of 4,882 as of 2019. The main industries are agriculture, construction and trade. The town has seven schools, a high school, a library and a post office. The town's patron saint is St John the Baptist. The area has a long history, having been inhabited since ancient times. Archaeological finds date back to the first century CE, when the area was part of the Roman Province of Thracia. In the Middle Ages, the town was part of the Second Bulgarian Empire and the Bulgarian churches in the region date back to this period. Throughout its history, the population of the town has been mainly Bulgarian. Golyam Rezen is known for its abundance of flora and fauna, especially in the areas surrounding the Arda River. The Arda is home to brown trout, grey mullet and other fish, as well as a wide variety of birds, including kingfishers, hoopoes and cormorants. The forests near the town are also home to deer, wild boar and a variety of other animals and plants. The region is also home to many cultural and historical sites, including churches and archaeological sites. The church of St John the Baptist, which dates back to the 11th century CE, is a popular tourist attraction due to its well-preserved frescoes. The nearby village of Sarmodik is the site of a 4th century CE Roman fortress, and several other Roman sites, such as a bridge and ramparts, can also be seen. Golyam Rezen is a popular tourist destination due to its rich cultural heritage and abundance of flora and fauna. The town is also known for its traditional festivals and craft fairs, where local craftsmen display their handiwork. Visitors to the town can also take part in traditional Bulgarian customs, such as the ritual of the Easter resurrection, and taste the local cuisine.

Back to Life is a 1913 American silent short drama film directed by Alfred E. Green and produced by Mack Sennett. The plot of the film follows a father as he struggles to get his son, who was sent to prison, out and back on the right path. The film stars Mabel Normand, Charles Avery, and Minta Durfee, and features cameos by Harry Gribbon and Bobby Moyer. The plot focuses on a couple, George and Betty, with a son, Jack. When Jack falls onto a life of crime, the couple has to do whatever they can to help their son back on the right path. In order to post Jack's bail, the couple is forced to sell their own home. They are successful in getting him out on bail and pledge to never allow this to happen again. Jack is overwhelmed with guilt and regret and begins to pay for his crime by becoming a philanthropist and donating money to charities. He is eventually accepted back into society and his family is proud of his progress. The film was commercially and critically successful, and was praised for its "eloquently expressive and convincingly portrayed" characters. The film was released in the United States on October 14, 1913. A copy of the film was restored and submitted for copyright registration in the USA on October 5, 2006. The film is now widely available on home video. Back to Life is included in the Mack Sennett Collection held by the Academy Film Archive. The Archive describes the film as follows, "Alfred Green's muddled story of repentance carries a strong moral message as parents drive their son back to the straight and narrow with clever psychological tactics." Back to Life is recognized as an important early silent drama. The film's plot and characters prove its importance in the history of film, and its still relevant messages of redemption and personal responsibility resonate with audiences today.

Fluid kinematics is the study of how fluids of any type – including combustible gases, liquids and slurries – move in a variety of ways. This branch of mathematics covers an array of complex dynamics, such as turbulence, viscosity and drag force. It has applications in many scientific realms, including physics, engineering, aeronautics and climatology. In natural phenomena, fluids typically move in one of two forms – laminar or turbulent. They are designated as such depending on their velocity, or the rate of their movement. Laminar flows occur when the velocity of the fluid is steady and the individual molecules follow well-defined paths. Turbulent flows, by comparison, involve chaotic and unpredictable movements that are characterized by vortices and eddies. When it comes to modeling how fluids move, the principles of fluid kinematics combine both laminar and turbulent mechanisms. Depending on the scope of the study, a wide range of formulas may be employed to calculate the fluid's velocity, acceleration and momentum. The principles of fluid kinematics also enable researchers to understand how changes in a fluid's kinetic energy affects sound production and heat transfer. One of the most important aspects of fluid kinematics is the behavior of fluids that are experiencing a drag force. This force occurs when an object is moving through a fluid and must overcome the resistance of the molecules around it. As this resistance increases, the object's speed decreases. The behavior of fluids in such settings is analyzed extensively in the field of fluid dynamics, which is closely related to fluid kinematics. In addition to fluid dynamics, fluid kinematics has practical advances in many fields. It is employed in medical fields, such as physiology and biophysics, to understand the behavior of blood flow and other body fluids in living organisms. It also has applications in engineering and aeronautics, where it is used to model fluid flow patterns in machines, such as aircraft and wind turbines, and streamline their performance. In conclusion, fluid kinematics is an important branch of mathematics that allows for the analysis of complex motion in fluids. It is used across many scientific disciplines, from physics to engineering and biomedical science, to predict and manipulate the behavior of liquids and gases.

Business casual is an ambiguously defined Western dress code, commonly accepted in large corporations, universities, and government offices. The term business casual originated in the United States in the late 1980s/early 1990s when many companies encouraged their employees to dress more casually, attempting to move away from the “stuffy” and rigid formal wear expected before. Generally speaking, business casual is considered to be more formal than typical casual clothes, but still allows the wearer to maintain a level of comfort. The definition of business casual varies with context and geographic location, but when deciding what to wear, it is important to be aware that many organizations will still enforce dress codes and safety requirements to ensure a professional appearance. Common items that are worn in a business casual environment include collared shirts, khaki trousers, sweaters and cardigans, dressy skirts, dressy shorts, dressy underwear, slacks, and well-polished dress shoes. Business casual does not include ripped jeans, shorts, sandals, T-shirts, hoodies, sweatpants, or other casual attire. Business casual attire has become increasingly popular for those in professions with a higher standard of dress. It is also common to find business casual attire in the banking, financial, legal and real estate industries. Ambiguity in the definition of business casual has resulted in a wide range of interpretations and has caused many people to dress inappropriately in the workplace. Irrespective of the exact definition of business casual, it is important to remember that personality and smartness are still important, and any out of the ordinary clothing will likely stand out and be noticed. Different industries may require different levels of dress depending on their environment. For example, the financial or banking sector might require a more tailored or professional look, such as a three-piece suit and tie. On the other hand, a technology company could abide by a more relaxed dressing code, allowing for jeans, polos, but still excluding athletic wear. As such, it is important to research the particular dress code requirements for each industry and workplace to ensure that one is dressed appropriately. When in doubt, it is best to err on the side of caution and dress more formally. Overall, the evolution of business casual has provided employees with more comfortable and attractive options than traditional business attire, and this has in turn made it easier for employers to hire and retain talent. With the continued evolution of the modern workforce, it is important for each individual and their managers to identify what dress code fits their particular needs.

Paul Maas (1880 - 1987) was a Dutch botanist and professor at Utrecht University. He was an internationally renowned specialist in grasses and sedges and made major contributions to plant geology, plant physiology, and plant taxonomy. Maas studied biology and medicine at Utrecht and Leiden universities, later continuing his studies in Paris and Brussels. In 1908, he completed his doctoral thesis, On the Anatomy and Systematics of Poaceae. Following this, he spent time in Java and Suriname to research tropical grasses and their habitats. During World War I, Maas served as a reserve officer in the 5th Infantry Regiment in Zwolle, where he studied soil textures and the spread of vegetation. In 1917, Maas was appointed professor at Utrecht and 18 years later, made professor of vegetation science and botany. During his time at Utrecht, Maas led several expeditions to study the distribution of plants and developed a technique for drying and measuring plants. Much of his research focused on reeds and sedges, of which he wrote five monographs. Maas is also known for his landmark work in vegetation science, Flora Neerlandica. This book detailed the vegetation and grasses of the Netherlands, describing the biodiversity of both natural and cultivated environments. Maas’s work was widely recognised, and over his career, he received many awards and honours in botany, including the most prestigious award of the Dutch Botanical Society in 1956. In addition to his research, Maas was an active member of several professional organisations, primarily the Dutch Botanical Society. Maas is considered one of the most important botanists of the twentieth century, having made significant contributions to plant ecology, systematics, and taxonomy. His work remains highly relevant for the study of plants today and is regarded as foundational for the fields of morphology and vegetation science. Despite his international fame, Maas was also remembered for his generosity and sense of community, donating his time to engage with local organisations and student societies to share his knowledge and enthusiasm for botany. Maas died in 1987, at the age of 107, leaving behind a legacy of extensive research and publications.

The Francis D. Williams House is a historic two-story timber frame home in the historic district of Pinopolis, South Carolina. Built in 1839, it was the residence of Francis D. Williams, a prominent local plantation owner and politician. The Williams House, as it is commonly known, is a two-story weatherboarded wood frame I-house with a central hall and two rooms on each side. It was originally constructed by Samuel Cheesborough, one of the first settlers of what would later become Pinopolis. The house has a central gable roof and a pair of low-pitched Doric-style front porches. The roof is constructed of "shingles and is topped with a central cupola adorned with finials and a mahogany weather vane. In 1895, Francis D. Williams and his wife, Millie, moved from the house following Williams’ successful bid for the South Carolina House of Representatives. The house then became the residence of A.M. Keller, and in 1911, it was purchased by the Pinopolis Express newspaper. The newspaper used the house and its grounds as its office and printing shop until 1945. In 1985, the house and grounds were listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It is one of the most well-preserved early 19th century houses in South Carolina, and its historical significance lies in its association with Williams, his family and his values. The house underwent renovations in the late 20th century, including a modern kitchen and updated bathrooms, but the original architectural elements remain intact. The house has since become a local landmark. In 2006, it was the subject of the South Carolina Historical Association Annual Tours, a series of lectures and guided tours examining the state's most notable structures. Today, the home is privately owned and maintained, and is available for limited guided tours. It stands as a testament to South Carolina's early architectural past, and its significance to the cultural history of Pinopolis and the surrounding area. It remains as a symbol of the region's development, as well as the success and influence of its former owner, Francis D. Williams.

Padilla, Bolivia is a small town in the Bolivian countryside located in the Department of Santa Cruz. It lies 56km from Santa Cruz de la Sierra, the department's capital. Originally founded by the Spanish Empire in 1576, the town has a population of just over 3,000 people. Padilla has a semi-arid climate with high temperatures during the summer months (November-March). Its main form of employment is through agriculture, growing potatoes, manioc, and maize. The area also has a number of beef cattle farms. The economy of Padilla is mainly sustained by tourism. Tourists come to visit the town’s colonial architecture, as well as the surrounding nature reserves. These reserves boast an array of animals and plants, from the endangered giant armadillo to a variety of orchids. Padilla is a culturally diverse town with a mix of Spanish, German, Italian, and indigenous Bolivian traditions. An important event in the town is the Mysicu Festival, which celebrates traditional music and mysticism. The municipality of Padilla is also invested in the preservation of its local areas. One example is the protection and rehabilitation of Rio Caraparí, the local river. In 1964 it was treated by the Padilla public with the support of local authorities and was declared part of the environmental heritage in 2002 by the Santa Cruz government. Padilla is considered to be a traditional contrast to the large and noisy city of Santa Cruz. Its tranquil atmosphere is the ideal place for those looking to escape the hustle and bustle of the Bolivian city life. Overall, Padilla is a rural town full of culture and nature. It is the perfect spot for those looking to experience Bolivian heritage while taking in the area's natural beauty.

Yukio Iketani (池谷 幸雄, Iketani Yukio) is a fictional character in the manga and anime series, Initial D. He is the best friend of Takumi Fujiwara, the protagonist and main character of the series. Yukio is a long time friend of Takumi and member of the Akina Speed Stars. He is the designated driver and leader of the team, taking charge for the most part and overseeing their meetings and races. He is often the one Takumi confides in when it comes to his racing skills and it's clear throughout the series that the two of them have a strong bond. Unlike Takumi, Yukio was not an experienced driver. He struggled with his technique, often unable to perform the same feats as Takumi and other more experienced drivers. Yukio was often frustrated by this, and while he kept his cool and kept encouraging his friend, it took a while before Yukio himself was able to perform the same feats as Takumi. Yukio is the owner of an AE86, a car that Takumi eventually took over when Yukio was forced to sell it due to mounting repair costs. It was Yukio who taught Takumi driving techniques, like the clutch kick and Scandinavian flick, and even confessed to Takumi that he lost the mountain race due to an internal conflict in his mind because he had been teaching Takumi the skills that he himself could not master. Throughout the series, Yukio remains supportive of his best friend and willing to give him advice no matter what. He is often one of the few characters in the series who is willing to stay and have a beer with Takumi, even when it seems like all has been lost. At the conclusion of the fourth and final stage of the series, Yukio and Takumi are seen together, reflecting on their time racing together. Together with the rest of the Akina Speed Stars, Yukio and Takumi escape to the mountains for one last hurrah to celebrate all that they accomplished together. Throughout the series, Yukio is the one constant that Takumi can rely on. Although he has his flaws, Yukio's friendship and willingness to help provide a moral backbone to the series that helps Takumi keep going, no matter how tough things get.

The Lansdowne Club is a private members' club in London, England. Established in 1865, it is considered one of the most prestigious private members' clubs in the world. The Club's mission is "to encourage social intercourse, literature, and the sciences, according to the principles of benign charity". The Club's original home, in a townhouse in Berkeley Square, was bought in 1865 by Arthur Balfour, 1st Earl of Balfour, Lord Arran, and Lord Robert Cecil. The Club later moved to a larger premises in 1883 at 9 Hereford Road, London. The present building, at 9 Fitzmaurice Place in London's Mayfair, was purchased in 1893, and is an impressive five-story mansion with a striking red-brick facade. The building was designed by architect Charles Harrison Townsend, who also designed the nearby Hyde Park Corner tube station, and is considered an excellent example of his work. The Club's facilities are extensive, and include two dining rooms, the Lawrence Room and the Peter Room, as well as a smoking room and library. Many notable figures have been members of the Lansdowne Club, including the Duke of Wellington, Rudyard Kipling, George Bernard Shaw, Bertrand Russell, King Edward VII, and Winston Churchill. The Club is considered among the most exclusive private members' clubs in London. Membership is by invitation only and is limited. Candidates must be recommended to the Club by at least two members and be able to pay an annual subscription fee. Members of the Club benefit from the wide range of social, cultural and sporting events organized by the Club and its committees, from lectures and dinners to charity fundraising events and sporting competitions. The Club also boasts a collection of almost 2,000 works of art. Much of the art collection is displayed throughout the Club's premises and includes works by renowned artists such as Monet, Canaletto and Rembrandt. The Lansdowne Club remains one of the most coveted private members' clubs in London. Its combination of historic charm and modern facilities, combined with its exclusivity, makes it an ideal venue for networking, entertaining and leisure.

Clientitis is a term to describe a type of corporate behavior in which a company devotes an inordinate amount of energy to the demands of their current clients. This behavior typically leads to an overemphasis on existing customers at the expense of other important priorities such as market research, product innovation and diversification. The term is specifically used to describe a situation in which current customer’s needs become the primary focus of the business. At times, this can lead to a certain type of myopic tunnel vision where the company’s existing customers become a dictating force. Companies that fall into this pattern of behavior often redefine themselves to meet the specific needs of clients who have become dominant users of the product or service. The patterns of behavior inherent in clientitis present challenges to the sustainability of a company’s growth. Companies that come to prioritize the whims of their customers run the risk of alienating potential future clientele, or failing to see the importance of emerging market segments. This loyalty to existing customers can also divert resources away from vital activities such as research and development, or marketing of new services and products. The symptoms of clientitis can manifest in various ways, including: maximizing current customer retention for short-term gains, committing extensive resources to address the requests of large customers, and running promotions and introductory offers specifically tailored to existing customers. The effects of clientitis may not be visible until after long periods of time, which makes it difficult overcome once entrenched in the corporate culture. Historically, large-scale companies have been the most vulnerable to clientitis due to their size and tendency to attach certain management processes to particular accounts. Smaller companies have typically been able to outmaneuver the symptoms of clientitis by changing their strategies quickly, responding to customer requests quicker than larger competitors. Overall, it is important for corporations to recognize the consequences of clientitis and ensure that it does not take precedence over more crucial business activities. Companies must make it a priority to properly balance their current customer needs with their long-term business objectives. Doing so will enable them to improve their relationship with existing customers, while also preparing them to better capitalize on new market segments.

Evergreen Cemetery is a Historic cemetery located in Boston, Massachusetts. Established in 1805, it is one of the oldest cemeteries in the city. It is located in the West Roxbury neighborhood of Boston at 690 Canterbury Street. Evergreen Cemetery is listed on the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP). The cemetery includes a variety of sites, including bird walks, stone walls, and historic monuments. It covers almost 75 acres of land, with some sections also accessible by roads and paths. Evergreen Cemetery features a landscape of rolling hills, ponds, woods, and gardens. It is home to a variety of natural habitats, including wetlands, meadows, and a wildflower meadow. It is managed by the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation and is open to the public from dawn to dusk every day of the year. Evergreen Cemetery holds many graves of Civil War veterans, Revolutionary War heroes, and other well-known figures from the colonial period. Over 20,000 people are buried in the cemetery, including poet Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, writers Julia Ward Howe and Paul Revere, and former US President John Quincy Adams. Other notable burials include actor Alan Hale Sr., and labor leader William Green. The cemetery holds a number of monuments and memorials. In the front of the cemetery is a granite archway with the inscription, “To the Memory of Our Nation's Defenders”. The dedication ceremony took place in 1927, and was attended by veterans from the Spanish-American War. Other monuments at the cemetery include memorials to the Civil War and World War I, a granite obelisk dedicated to the soldiers of the Spanish-American War, and monuments to the Rev. Jonas Clarke and his two sons, who are buried in the cemetery. Evergreen Cemetery is also home to a range of wildlife. It is a managed wildlife refuge and a member of the Audubon Society. Visitors can observe a variety of birds and other wildlife, and the cemetery is also home to a number of rare plant species. In 2018, the Evergreen Cemetery Preservation Corporation was established to protect and restore the cemetery. The non-profit organization is dedicated to the preservation, maintenance, and improvement of the cemetery. Its mission is to ensure the legacy of Evergreen Cemetery and its important place in Boston's history is preserved for future generations.

Takashi Aoyagi (born 12 June 1966 in Tokyo, Japan) is a professional animator, animation director, and a toy designer. He is best known for his work in two most famous animated television series: Dragon Ball and Neon Genesis Evangelion. He is also the creator of the popular Kamen Rider Ex-Aid toys. Aoyagi studied visual design at Tokyo Zokei University and the University of Tokyo, while serving as a freelance designer for various television networks. He started his professional career as an animator and animation director in the early 1990s. His most notable works include all monsters featured in the "Dragon Ball" anime series, in addition to some of the mecha and robot designs. From 1995 to 1998, Aoyagi worked as the animation director of "Neon Genesis Evangelion". He created the mecha designs for the series, including the concept designs for the EVA series. The huge success of "Evangelion" solidified Aoyagi's status as one of the most esteemed animators in the industry. Aoyagi began creating toy designs in 2000. He worked on some of Bandai's most iconic toy lines, including the Kamen Rider Ex-Aid figures which were released in Japan in 2017. His transforming robot figures immediately become popular among fans due to the highly detailed articulation and wide range of accessories. In 2018, Aoyagi set up his own company- Aoyagi Design Studio- to focus solely on his toy designs. He aims to bring back the organic, organic-transformable figures to the toy market. His goal is to create a figure that combines the organic feeling of animatronics and the smooth-operating transformations for which "Kamen Rider" toys are known. Aoyagi also continues to work in the anime industry. He has served as the animation director for "Fruits Basket Another" (2020) and is currently involved in other projects. Though his career is relatively young, Takashi Aoyagi has already risen to become one of the most influential figures in the anime and toy industries. He is recognized for his creativity, innovation and dedication to bringing the best possible quality of design to both his animation and toy projects.

Saltwater Heroes is a non-profit organization located in the Outer Banks of North Carolina. Founded in 2013, the organization's mission is to save marine life through education, conservation, and research. Saltwater Heroes works to create a new generation of ocean stewards by connecting people with the ocean and connecting marine life in need with the help it needs. Saltwater Heroes works to educate and inform people about marine issues and enlist their support to help protect our ocean and marine life. Through special events, workshops, programs and exhibitions, the organization reaches out to the public to build awareness and appreciation for our natural underwater environment and its inhabitants. The organization is committed to marine conservation through its sea turtle conservation project, seabird research, and recreational fishing advocacy. The organization works with local and international partners to improve the conditions of the ocean and marine life through hands-on conservation projects. In addition to its conservation efforts, Saltwater Heroes also actively works with local communities to help foster stewards of the sea. Through educational initiatives and activities, the organization helps children and adults develop a deep respect for our oceans, its inhabitants, and the integral role it plays in our environment. Saltwater Heroes actively engages in scientific research and also partners with other non-profits and government agencies. The organization seeks to empower its supporters with their voice so they can help protect marine life and promote sustainable ocean practices. Saltwater Heroes advocates for ocean-friendly legislation and actions to protect vulnerable species, habitats and ecosystems. The organization is committed to the highest standards of scientific integrity and strives to create a network of environmentalists, researchers and activists in order to work towards creating a healthy ocean-scape. Saltwater Heroes works with a variety of partners, including scientists, local communities, schools and universities, businesses, government agencies and concerned citizens in order to achieve its mission. The organization is focused on creating long-term solutions to the threats to our ocean's wildlife and habitats by bringing a greater sense of awareness and appreciation for the ocean's resources.

Simon de Brantingham (active early 16th century) was an English knight who served in the armies of Henry VIII, and developed a military system that allowed him to successfully keep a large body of troops equipped and supplied. In 1513 he was appointed captain of the King's Troop of 12,000 men-at-arms, the largest mounted force ever assembled in the history of England. De Brantingham began his career in military service in the retinue of Thomas Grey, 2nd Marquess of Dorset, and held a number of temporary positions in the various armies of the time. In 1507 he was one of 1,000 men-at-arms who attended the wedding of Henry VIII and Catherine of Aragon at Greenwich. He was part of the entourage, when Henry and an army of 50,000 invaded France in 1513, and was made captain of the King's Troop, the vanguard of the army. De Brantingham developed an innovative system for the equipping and supply of the 12,000 men. Every six men were assigned a wagon and provisions for month's service. De Brantingham divided the army into a number of companies and brigades which were assigned to march along the roads for a specified number of days and make camp at night. He also developed a system of accountability for material losses and ensured that all of the men were paid and provided with proper care and provisions. At the Battle of the Spurs on 16 August 1513, de Brantingham's troops formed part of the vanguard and was praised by the King for his effective supply and troop management. He was knighted later that year and continued to serve in France until 1514. Following his time in France, de Brantingham served on various military campaigns with Henry VIII, ranging from Scotland to France. He was also involved in building and equipping fortresses along the English coast in preparation for a possible invasion by the French. In March 1515, de Brantingham was sent on a diplomatic mission to Spain to negotiate a possible alliance between the two countries. This mission was unsuccessful and in 1517 de Brantingham was arrested on suspicion of treason and sent to the Tower of London. He was pardoned shortly afterwards and went on to serve in military campaigns during the 1520s, but his career ended in 1531 when he was formally discharged from military service. No record of his subsequent career exists, but he likely returned to his family estate in Hampshire. He died sometime before 1567, as his will was proved in that year. Simon de Brantingham's career was remarkable for its length of service and its innovation. His supply system ensured that the armies of the time could move with efficiency and that the troops were properly supplied and paid. He was a highly respected leader who was awarded a knighthood for his service, a testament to both his skill and his dedication to duty.

BiTrektual is a new software solution developed to help improve customer service and collaboration. It integrates customer service, sales, operations, and customer data to provide a single comprehensive view of customer relationships. The story of BiTrektual began in 2019 with two computer scientists from the United States. The idea for the software was born out of a need to provide better customer service to organizations of all sizes. When companies use outdated technologies, they struggle to meet customer expectations. The BiTrek team set out to create a solution that offered an easy-to-use store front, large library of useful customer support features, and customer data management capabilities to provide organizations with the tools they needed to deliver excellent customer service. BiTrektual is the result of that effort. It's a cloud-based customer relationship management (CRM) and customer service platform that can be deployed in minutes with a few simple steps. The platform brings all of an organizations customer interactions, sales, and operations into one place to foster collaboration. Organisations can also create tailored experiences and interactions for their customers with the help of custom workflows and automated processes. BiTrektual delivers a customer service experience that can adapt to the unique needs of customers. It also offers data-driven insights that enable organisations to better understand customer behavior, drive upsell opportunities, and identify key areas for improvement. The software platform is easy to set up, integrate, and manage. It has a customizable user interface designed to be used by non-technical personnel. It also has an easy-to-use dashboard, analytical powers and reporting capabilities to assist in decision making and operations. BiTrektual will help organizations stay competitive and deliver the kind of customer service experience that will keep customers coming back. This software will give organizations the ability to quickly identify and address customer needs, tailor customer service for each individual, and measure the efficiency of customer interactions. Overall, BiTrektual is said to provide an improved customer experience, increase customer satisfaction, and foster team collaboration.

România TV is a Romanian free-to-air television channel, owned by the Romanian government and operated by Societatea Românǎ de Televiziune (SRTV). The TV station was launched in 1994 and has become one of the most widely watched television channels in Romania. România TV offers news, lifestyle and entertainment programming, as well as documentaries, sports, drama and children’s shows. It is the home of several popular Romanian shows such as Românii au talent and Vocea României, and regularly hosts interviews with prominent personalities and political figures. The channel broadcasts 24 hours a day, seven days a week. As well as being broadcast on terrestrial television, România TV is also available on cable, satellite and digital terrestrial platforms including Orange, UPC, Telekom and DigiTV. In addition, the channel is streaming live online on its own website and via its YouTube channel. România TV is part of the wider SRTV media group, which also consists of satellite channels Prima TV, Antena 3 and Antena Stars, and provides news stories to Antena Info. It has been the exclusive broadcaster of the Eurovision Song Contest in Romania since 1995 and also serves as the Romanian broadcaster for the FIFA World Cup and the Olympic Games. România TV’s longtime editor-in-chief was Bogdan Olteanu, who was appointed in 2002 and held the position until his death in 2016. In 2021, the channel’s editor-in-chief became Radu Banu. Throughout its history, the channel has been known for its independent reporting and objectivity in its news coverage. In its 6+ year history, România TV has often had different owners and managers, who have all contributed to its growth in audience share and breadth of programming. In 2015, România TV was acquired by SRTV, who have overseen an expansion of the channel’s original schedule, adding new shows and content. Today, România TV is one of the most widely watched television networks in Romania, with an average weekly reach of 26.1%. It is particularly popular among those aged 18 to young adults aged 25, accounting for 24.2% of viewers in this demographic.

Page Fence Giants was a professional black baseball team which existed from 1894 to 1905, based in Adrian, Michigan. The team was organized in 1894 by Nelson Page, a former Adrian resident who owned a number store there. The team was composed largely of former semi-pro players from the area, and was named after the company Page owned, the Page Fence Company. Their games were held in a park near the corner of North Main and Broadway streets. It had a seating capacity of two thousand and was surrounded by white picket fence, earning the team its namesake. Professional teams from the eastern United States would travel to Adrian to face the Page Fence Giants, who were well-known for their style of play during the games. The team enjoyed success and was financially successful, every game selling out and every season profitable. The Giants also made regional and national tours, playing against teams like the New York Cuban Giants, the Chicago Unions and the Cuban X Giants. The team’s star players included pitcher William Binga, outfielder Robert "Reggie" Williams and catcher William "Dizzy" Dismukes. Binga played from 1894 to 1895, Williams from 1895 to 1898, and Dismukes from 1903 to 1905. The squad also featured Hoss Radbourne, a pitcher who would go on to be inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame. The Giants' success led to a scandal in which the team was accused of being involved in a betting scandal and receiving payment from gamblers to throw the Championship Game in 1902. This ended the team's stay in Adrian. After the Giants disbanded in 1905, the Page Fence Company reorganized and became the Page Fence Company Athletic Club, which played amateur baseball and other sports until 1920. Today, The Adrian Historical Society recognizes the Page Fence Giants as a pivotal part of Michigan's baseball history. Teams like the Page Fence Giants paved the way for black Major League talent and formed the foundation of the "Negro Leagues". One of their original players, William Dismukes, is included in the Michigan Baseball Hall of Fame. The legacy of the Page Fence Giants continues to inspire current players and draw attention to a unique time in Adrian, Michigan's history.

Emma Chambers (born 24 December 1965, Doncaster, West Yorkshire, England) is a British actress, best known for the roles of Alice Tinker in the BBC sitcom The Vicar of Dibley, and Honey Thacker in the romantic comedy film Notting Hill. Chambers began her acting career in the late 1980s with small television roles and performances in theatre. Her breakthrough role came in 1994, when she was cast as Alice Tinker in the popular BBC sitcom The Vicar of Dibley, opposite Dawn French. During her time on the show, Chambers was nominated for the British Comedy Award for Best TV Comedy Actress in 1996 and 1997. In 1999, Chambers starred opposite Hugh Grant and Julia Roberts in the romantic comedy Notting Hill, as Hugh Grant's exasperated older sister and romantic confidante, Honey Thacker. Chambers' performance was critically acclaimed and she was nominated for an ALFS Award for Best Supporting Actress in a British Film. Chambers has appeared in numerous television and film roles, including in the drama series Bremner, Bird and Fortune, the film Stuart Little, and the mystery series Jane Wymark's Midsomer Murders. Her other television credits include roles in Absolutely Fabulous, Florence Nightingale and Jonathan Creek. In addition to her acting roles, Chambers has published two books: Wild West Ham: A Guide to Keeping Chickens and Ducks in Your Garden was released in 2010 and Growing Your Own Vegetables was released in 2011. In 2016, Chambers retired from acting to focus on her writing career and on her hobbies, including chicken keeping and vegetable gardening. Chambers is a self-styled 'soubrette', which is a French term for the secondary comic role, usually a giddy girl or flirtatious young woman. She received the nickname 'Gorgon of Grinning' from BBC Radio 4 presenter John Humphrys due to her distinctive and infectious laughter.

¿Qué le pasa a mi familia? (English: What is Happening to My Family?) is a Mexican telenovela produced by José Alberto Castro for Televisa. It was based on the 1994 telenovela written by the Venezuelan writer Humberto "Kiko" Olivieri, which was adapted in more than 30 countries. The series premiered on Las Estrellas on October 20, 2014 and aired its last episode on May 24, 2015. The series stars Silvia Navarro, César Évora, Erick Elias, Margarita Magaña, Malillany Marín, Laura Zapata, Federico Ayos and Juan Ferrara. Featuring the special participations of David Zepeda and Eugenio Siller. The story of ¿Qué le pasa a mi familia? revolves around two sisters, the youngest and the eldest, who have chosen two different paths to follow in their lives. Raquel has chosen to live the fast-paced rich life, with its glamour and fine living, while Yessica opts for the simpler life in which to focus on her marriage and religious beliefs. The series begins as Raquel returns to Mexico after a period of exile in Europe following her involvement in a scandal of her past. Her return stirs up the deep secrets of a past that the family had kept in silence. As the story progresses, the audience discovers the secrets that surround each of the characters, and the consequences they have brought to the family. The series received positive reviews. Eugenio Siller received praise for his Romeo and Juliet inspired love story with Silvia Navarro. On June 17, 2015, a new installment called ¿Qué le pasa a mi familia? ¡De Nuevo en Acción! was released as a web series, in which the cast reinterpreted their roles from the first season with comical plots. The first episode premiered on YouTube on June 21, 2015. ¿Qué le pasa a mi familia? proved to be a critical and ratings success, becoming the highest rated telenovela of 2014. As a result, it won an Astrolatino award for Best Telenovela of the Year. It has also been nominated for different awards including Premios TVyNovelas and a Kids' Choice Mexico Award. The series was released on DVD region 1 by Sony Pictures Home Entertainment.

Kentucky Gold is a white bourbon whiskey created and bottled under the umbrella of Maker's Mark. It is a limited-release spirit available in select states throughout the United States, including Kentucky, Indiana, Illinois, Ohio and Tennessee. History The whiskey was first made available in March 2018, after Maker's Mark announced the release of the special edition spirit at an event at the distillery in Loretto, Kentucky. Master Distiller Greg Davis described the process of making the whiskey, which follows a different path than the distillery’s traditional whiskey. Davis said the process begins with a mash of locally sourced corn and malted barley, with a special variation of Maker’s Mark yeast. The whiskey is then distilled in a copper pot still using a mash bill of 70 percent corn. After it is distilled, the spirit is barrel-aged for a minimum of 10 years in a variety of new and used Maker’s Mark barrels. Kentucky Gold whiskey is intended to be a celebration of Maker’s Mark’s commitment to small-batch distilling and a subtle nod to the brand’s long tradition of producing high-quality spirits from grain to bottle. The whiskey is meant to be enjoyed neat or on the rocks, and it is non-chill filtered. Distribution Kentucky Gold is a limited-edition spirit and is available in select states throughout the United States, including Kentucky, Indiana, Illinois, Ohio and Tennessee. There is no set release date, and bottles may appear sporadically throughout the United States. Maker’s Mark also recommends contacting local retailers or bourbon enthusiasts online to inquire about its availability. Reviews reviewers praised Kentucky Gold for its smooth, oaky flavor with “sweet apricot,” “soft spice,” and “floral notes.” Others noted the whiskey’s balance of dry, nutty notes from the longer aging process. Its age and unique spirit profile make it desirable for those who want an aged bourbon in a non-chill filtered whiskey. Conclusion With its unique production process and a flavor profile featuring sweet apricot and floral notes, Kentucky Gold is a limited-edition addition to the Maker’s Mark portfolio. Crafted from grain to bottle, each hand-bottled bottle is a celebration of Kentucky and Maker’s Mark’s commitment to small-batch distilling.

Soluble transferrin receptor (sTfR) is a glycoprotein expressed on the surface of erythroid precursors and is related to the human protein transferrin receptor. It acts as an iron-uptake receptor to the cell surface and is used as a marker of erythropoiesis in medical diagnosis. The sTfR gene is located on chromosome 3p25.1-25.2 and has four exons. The full length mRNA contains 1585 nucleotides, which can produce a protein of 353 amino acids with a molecular weight of 39.477 kDa. sTfR shares structural homology with several other cellular receptors including scavenger receptor, major histocompatibility complex class II receptors, cell adhesion molecules and desialylated transferrin receptor. sTfR is primarily expressed in erythroid precursors, though low expression has been detected in hepatocytes, myeloid defined precursors, thymocytes and monocytes. sTfR plays an important role in erythropoiesis by facilitating iron uptake into developing erythrocytes and ensuring the proper development of adequate erythroid precursors. On the cellular surface, sTfR exists in two forms: a membrane-bound form and a soluble form. The soluble form is generated by shedding of membrane-bound sTfR by the action of metalloproteases. The importance of soluble sTfR has been established in recent years since it is more specific and more reliable as a marker of erythropoiesis, due to its independence from changes in erythroid precursors. The level of sTfR in the body can be measured in the serum or plasma of a patient. In healthy individuals, sTfR levels are low, usually between 0.4-1.25 mg/L. However, in cases of anemia, sTfR levels can be significantly higher or lower depending on the underlying cause. In conditions such as iron deficiency anemia, sTfR is generally found to be higher than normal, while in other conditions such as thalassemia, sTfR is usually found to be lower than normal. In addition, soluble transferrin receptor has been used in diagnosis of certain diseases such as sickle cell anemia, hemoglobinopathies, and in monitoring response to therapy in thalassemia patients. The use of sTfR as a biomarker is particularly useful in diagnosing deficiencies and in assessing the severity of anemia. Overall, sTfR is an important biomarker that helps medical specialists in the diagnosis and monitoring of various anemias, as well as the response to treatment. References: 1. Mahmood, S. and Ahmad, Z. (2009). Soluble transferrin receptor: an indicator of erythropoiesis. Trends in Hematology, 8 (3), 59-66. 2. Maniou, E., Wilson, A. and Marsden, H. (2003). Role of the soluble transferrin receptor in iron homeostasis. Blood Cells, Molecules and Diseases, 30 (3), 284-297. 3. Silva, A., Engström, L. and Mori, M. (2017). Soluble Transferrin Receptor: an Emerging Biomarker in Diagnosing Anemia and Other Iron-Related Disorders. International Journal of Molecular Sciences, 18 (7), 1560.

Alain Gautier (born November 23, 1942) is a French yachtsman and navigator. Gautier began sailing at an early age with his father and grandfather in the waters off the Atlantic Coast of France. He first competed in racing in 1963. Between 1966 and 1974, Gautier was part of Bernard Tapie's sailing team. In the 1950s, Gautier competed in the crew of the French sailing yacht Norge, gaining his first experience in offshore racing. He has since participated in numerous international sailing competitions, including the Admiral's Cup, the Bermuda Race, and the RORC Race on several occasions. In 1976, Gautier was part of the French challenge of the America's Cup and was navigator aboard the French yacht France. He then went on to become a professional navigator and coach, giving him an opportunity to share the knowledge and experience he had gained over the years. In 1979, Gautier won the OSTAR single-handed transatlantic race aboard Quest for Atlantic. In 1982, Gautier again sailed in the ORC race, this time aboard Recherche. He was part of a team that won the race from Plymouth, England to La Rochelle, France. Gautier has also been part of the French sailing team in the Open Class of the America's Cup between 1989 and 1991, and the International America's Cup Class between 1992 and 2001. In 1994, Gautier competed in the International 15-metre class aboard the Ofcet. He participated in the IMS European Championships 1994, earning the team a third place finish. Gautier returned to the America's Cup in 2001, as part of the French sailboat Abracadabra in the Louis Vuitton Cup. Today, Gautier continues to be an active contributor to the sailing world, having served as an advisor to the organisation of the Vendee Globe since its inception in 1989, and often offering his expertise to sailing youth teams in France. He resides in La Rochelle.

Michiko Kakutani (born February 4, 1955) is an American literary critic, essayist, and a best-selling author. She was the chief book critic of The New York Times from September 1983 to 2017 and the recipient of a Pulitzer Prize for distinguished criticism. Born in Tokyo, Japan, to Japanese parents, Kakutani moved to the United States when she was 18, to attend Yale University. She received her Bachelor of Arts degree in 1976. She also studied at Harvard University's School of Criticism and Theory. Kakutani’s earliest professional writing was for Japanese and American magazines and newspapers. She was a staff writer at the New York Times from 1980 and was promoted to chief book critic two years later. As Chief book critic, she wrote about an array of topics, from famous and controversial novels to lesser-known independent works. She wrote reviews for literary works of all lengths and genres, from memoirs to detective fiction. In addition to her work at the Times, Kakutani has written extensively for other publications, including the New York Review of Books and the NewYorker. Her articles have also appeared in The Atlantic, The Washington Post, Slate and the Los Angeles Times. Kakutani is the author of two books. ‘The Death of Truth: Notes on Falsehood in the Age of Trump’ was released in 2018 and deals with the politicization of facts and ‘Truthiness: How the Right Has Manipulated The Media, Misled the Public, and Corrupted Politics’ was released in 2009. In 2006, she was awarded a Pulitzer Prize for Criticism. Kakutani has also been awarded multiple honorary degrees, such as those from Kenyon College and St. John’s University. She has been a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences since 2013 and was presented with the National Book Critics Circle’s Ivan Sandrof Lifetime Achievement Award in 2017. In addition to her roles as critic, essayist, and author, she also lectures regularly on postmodernism and the impact of technology on books and modern culture. Michiko Kakutani is an essential part of the literary world, both in the United States and beyond. Her unique perspective, combined with her passionate writing style, has led to rewarding and resonating criticism.

Channel stuffing is a type of inventory fraud associated with the marketing and sales practices of a business. In channel stuffing, companies force their distributors to take multiple shipments of goods that they cannot immediately sell or use. The aim of channel stuffing is to artificially inflate sales and profits of a particular period and deceive investors, creditors and shareholders. It is a form of financial statement manipulation done by companies in an effort to enhance their financial performance. The result of channel stuffing is an increase in the quantity of goods reported on the income statement as sales, but which actually do not move into the marketplace. The effect of this can be wide-ranging, including overstated sales results, inventory imbalances, strained relationships with customers and partners, and ultimately, it may lead to incorrect financial results and a possible SEC filing violation. Channel stuffing is a form of fraud because it undermines the integrity of a company's financial results by creating misrepresentations in the firm's financial reporting. It involves the mis-allocation of goods as they pass through a supply chain, which, if not managed properly, can result in inflated inventory levels, unhealthy customer relations and an incorrect view of sales. Channel stuffing is thought to occur when 1) a company has an incentive to recognize additional sales or revenues; 2) a company has access to delivery channels for the goods, or; 3) when a company needs to turn around its financial fortunes in the short-term. Companies indulge in channel stuffing in an attempt to artificially boost their sales and profits. Businesses can employ this technique by shipping more goods than necessary to distribution centers, selling goods to customers at a discount to move more inventory, and allowing retailers to return more stock than usual. This form of manipulation makes financial statements inaccurate as it is based on transactions that are not properly reflecting the actual conditions of the market and the supply and demand of goods. Channel stuffing is considered a serious form of corporate fraud and carries penalties under the law. It can lead to indictment or significant fines, or both. For example, in 2020, the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) charged an executive and two companies of channel stuffing (among other things) and ordered them to pay over US $9 million in fines and disgorgements. In conclusion, channel stuffing is a manipulative practice meant to artificially increase a company's sales and income by moving goods improperly or to customers that do not intend to buy. It undermines the integrity of financial statements and is subject to criminal and/or civil penalties. Investors should carefully monitor signals that a company may be channel stuffing, such as significantly increasing inventory and cash sales.

Hebert High School is a public high school located in the city of Borger, Texas. It is part of the Borger Independent School District and serves 9-12 graders. The school's mascot is the Hebert Hawk and the colors are purple and gold. The school was established in the fall of 1971 and is named for the late educator W.D. Hebert. Hebert High School is proud of its academic and extracurricular achievements. The school is proud of its academic programs, including AP and IB courses, and its extracurricular activities, such as marching band, student council, and competitive sports. The extracurricular program also includes a variety of clubs and organizations such as National Honor Society and Spanish Club, as well as its own student-run newspaper, The Hawk. Hebert High School offers a variety of clubs and organizations such as Friends of the Arts, National Honor Society, National Technical Honor Society, StuCo, Design and Drawing, Spanish Club, Student Council, Ski Club, Anime Club and much more. In addition, the school has a rich tradition of athletic programs, hosting teams in football, basketball, swimming, soccer, baseball, softball, golf, track and field, volleyball, wrestling, and cross country. The athletic teams have enjoyed great success over the years, with the Hebert Hawks Football Team winning the 4A UIL State Football Championship in 2004. Hebert High School has strived to create an atmosphere of excellence and achievement. The principal, Mr. Paul Ruiz, is a strong advocate for providing a nurturing and safe learning environment for all Hebert Students. A variety of programs are available to support and encourage student learning, including the Hebert Honors Program, an internationally recognized education program that focuses on student achievement. Hebert High School offers a well-rounded educational experience and an extensive array of opportunities to learn and grow. The school provides students with a positive and supportive environment that encourages success both inside and outside the classroom. Hebert High School is a great place for students to discover their talents and reach their goals.

Henry Braham was an American film cinematographer and director. Braham started his career on the sets of television shows in the early 2000s, eventually moving on to become a director of photography and cinematographer. He is most well known for his work in the fantasy film The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005), family adventure film Night at the Museum (2006), and science fiction epic Jupiter Ascending (2015). Braham was responsible for the stunning visuals and visuals effects in those movies, which helped propel them to box office success. In 2016, Braham was awarded the American Society of Cinematographers Award for Outstanding Achievement in Cinematography for his work on Jupiter Ascending. He was also nominated for the International Cinematographers Guild Outstanding Achievement in Cinematography award for Jupiter Ascending as well. Braham also earned acclaim for his work on other films, including the romantic fantasy romantic sequel A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004), the action adventure Snow White and the Huntsman (2012), the post-apocalyptic science fiction film Mad Max: Fury Road (2015), and the supernatural horror thriller It (2017). Braham is also an accomplished director. His feature film directing debut, 3 Days to Kill (2014), was a box office hit. He has also directed music videos, including the Nicki Minaj song "Anaconda" (2014). In 2014, Braham was honored with the International Cinematographers Guild Founders Award for his achievements in the film industry. In 2019, Braham was honored with the Hollywood Foreign Press Association Award of Excellence. Braham works in various genres, ranging from fantasy to action to horror to comedy. As a cinematographer, he is well-respected for his imaginative visual storytelling and creative use of lighting and camera techniques. Whether behind the camera or directing, Braham has developed a reputation in Hollywood for technical excellence and aesthetic artistry. As of 2020, Braham has continued shooting television shows. He has also been working on several upcoming feature film projects, demonstrating his continued passion for the art of filmmaking.

Richard Vesey Hamilton (born June 7, 1951) is an English theatre director and writer. He was Artistic Director of the National Theatre in London for twenty years from 1997–2017, where he was the theatre's longest-serving director. Born in Bradford-on-Avon in Wiltshire, Hamilton attended King Edward's School, Witley and Downing College, Cambridge, where he studied English literature. After graduating, he spent time in repertory theatre at the Little Theatre in Leicester and also worked as a stage manager at the Haymarket Theatre, Leicester. From 1976–1978 he was a Junior Associate Director at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, before becoming a freelance director. As a freelance director, Hamilton was appointed Associate Director of the Nottingham Playhouse (1981–1984), Senior Associate Director at the Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester (1984–1988) and Artistic Director of the Riverside Studios (1989–1993). Hamilton has also directed in the West End with plays such as Hobson's Choice (1992) and The Master Builder (1993). In 1997, he was appointed Artistic Director of the National Theatre in London, a post he held until 2017. As Artistic Director, Hamilton spearheaded a policy of balanced programming, with half of the programming of the three theatres devoted to classical drama, a quarter to new writing and a quarter to new adaptations and revivals of classic plays. During his 20-year tenure, the National Theatre won numerous awards, and opened The Shed – a venue for experimental productions. As well as his work at the National Theatre, Hamilton has a long-standing relationship with the Almeida Theatre, London, where he has directed plays such as Arthur Miller's The Crucible (2003) and Tom Stoppard's Arcadia (2004). Hamilton has also written several plays, including A Hero of Our Time (2000) and The Little Prince (2002). He has been an Associate Director at the Royal Shakespeare Company and also an Associate of Kneehigh Theatre Company. In 2009 he was made a Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature. In 2017, Hamilton received the Japan Art Association's Praemium Imperiale prize, one of the world's highest honours in the arts, in the category of theatre/film. In the same year, he was awarded the Queen's Medal for Music.

Communes of Mayotte are a set of nineteen administrative divisions the French overseas department of Mayotte. They are located in the Comoros archipelago in the Indian Ocean, about halfway between northern Madagascar and northern Mozambique. Mayotte is divided into two communes - Mamoudzou and Dzaoudzi - and seventeen cantons. Its population is estimated at 263,000, making it one of the most densely populated regions in the world. Most of the population live in these two communes, with Mamoudzou being the largest and most populous. Mayotte was initially part of the French colony of Madagascar before becoming a separate overseas department in 2011. Mamoudzou is the capital and main city of Mayotte, with an area of 33 km2 and a population of approximately 90,700. It is known for its coconut palm plantations, Parc de la-Gwiaziz landscape and bright coral reefs. It is also home to the Augustin Machine Gate, the main gateway into Mayotte's mainland, as well as the Place de la Republique, the Place du Marche and the Tour de Fatima de Mamoudzou landmarks. Aside from Mamoudzou, there are eighteen cantons, all governed by elected mayors. The cantons are Bandrele, Boueni, Chiconi, Chirongui, Dembeni, Kani-Kéli, Koungou, Mtsamboro, M'Tsangamouji, Ouangani, Pamandzi, Sada, Tsingoni, Bandraboua, Tsararano, M′ Tsangamouji, Acoua, and Mayotte. The cantons are further divided into municipalities, each municipality consisting of several villages. Communes serve to organize the local public administration and are in charge of public services such as schooling, public health, police, sanitation, and town planning. The prefect is in charge of several communes and exercises the powers of the state in the communes, ensuring that the laws of the state and regulations of the communes are obeyed. The prefect is also charged with maintaining public order in Mayotte. The people of Mayotte elect representatives to a local assembly to make decisions concerning matters related to the communes. This representation is critical in ensuring that the local community is heard and able to take advantage of its right to self-government and that their collective contributions to Mayotte are accounted for in plans for the future. The communes of Mayotte form an integral part of the island's social fabric and serve as the key to a strong socio-economic future for the people of Mayotte. They are essential in setting the direction for development and progress in Mayotte and provide an important connection between the state and its citizens.

"I Can Dream About You" is a song written and performed by American singer-songwriter Dan Hartman and originally released in 1984. The song was featured in the film Streets of Fire as as the closing theme and was featured on the film's soundtrack album. The song slowed down the tempo and added a saxophone solo, whereas the original was a faster, uptempo dance track. The form of the song is a ballad. The track peaked at number six on the Billboard Hot 100 in the United States, back in 1984. It also charted in the United Kingdom at number forty four. The lyrics of the song tell the story of a man, dreaming of a woman he is attracted to and remembering the happiness they once shared together. It’s been said that the song was written about Karen Lawrence, Dan’s friend and keyboardist for the Edgar Winter Group. The lyrics breathe heartache as the singer dreams about all the things he wishes he could do with his former, departed love: “When I'm feeling down, Blue and lonely Picture your smile, and I can dream about you When I'm in a crowd, I'm so alone Picture your face, and I can dream about you” The song was covered by 3T featuring Michael Jackson in 1995. Meanwhile, a remix of the song was released in 2011 by German DJ and producer David May. The remix peaked at number twenty seven on the German Singles Chart. Furthermore, the song was used in the 2017 Super Bowl ad for Buick. In 2019, the song was featured during a scene in the fifth episode of the second season of the FX series, "Pose". Although "I Can Dream About You" was not a major hit in the United Kingdom, it continues to be a staple on classic, gold and dance radio station and is considered a true classic of the 1980s.

Conor Gillaspie (born July 16, 1988) is an American professional baseball third baseman who is currently a free agent. He made his Major League Baseball (MLB) debut in 2012 with the San Francisco Giants, and also played for the Chicago White Sox and San Diego Padres. Gillaspie attended Wichita State University, where he played college baseball for the Shockers from 2007-08. Gillaspie was drafted by the San Francisco Giants in the first round (37th overall) of the 2008 Major League Baseball draft. In 2009, he was named a California League All-Star. Gillaspie made his major league debut in 2012. During that season, he hit .277/.305/.422 with five home runs in 76 games for the Giants. In 2014, he hit .282/.344/.399 with 11 home runs in 137 games. On October 28, 2014, the Giants won their third World Series Championship in five years. During the series versus the Kansas City Royals, Gillaspie hit the game-winning home run in the ninth inning of Game 3, which put the Giants ahead in the series. It was his only hit of the series. On June 12, 2016, the Giants traded Gillaspie to the Chicago White Sox for pitcher Jeff Soptic. On November 5, 2017, the White Sox released Gillaspie. On March 5, 2018, Gillaspie signed a minor league contract with the San Diego Padres. He played in twelve games for the Padres Triple-A team, the El Paso Chihuahuas, and in one game for the major league club before being released on April 8. On June 18, 2019, Gillaspie signed a minor-league deal with the St. Louis Cardinals. On July 24, 2019, Gillaspie was released. Gillaspie is married to Lauren Gillaspie. They have two children. He is a Christian.

Wesley Jobello (born 28 July 1993) is an English football player who plays as a defensive midfielder for Yokohama F Mount Sports Club of the Japanese J2 League. He started his professional career at non-league side Eastbourne Borough where he made 20 appearances before joining Irish side Cork City in 2011. At Cork, Jobello spent three years making 59 appearances and scoring 4 goals. In 2014 Jobello signed for Spanish side Alcorcon where he made a total of 111 appearances and scored 7 goals. In 2016 he signed for Sodgoire of the French lower divisions where he made 21 league appearances. He signed for Yokohama F Mount Sports Club in Japan in 2018. Jobello is known for his tough tackling as well as his passing ability. He has established himself as a key player at Yokohama and has made a total of 79 appearances and scored 3 goals. He has also represented England at the semi-professional level. Jobello has developed into a fine defensive midfielder and is a reliable presence in the Yokohama team. He is an important figure in the team and has regularly represented the club in the media. Jobello has become a fan favourite at Yokohama and is often seen as an integral part of the team's success. Jobello's height of 1.78m (5'10") means that he is often compared to the likes of fellow midfielders Xabi Alonso and Paul Pogba. Jobello is regarded as a hard-working midfielder who is capable of playing both attacking and defensive roles. He is also often praised for his excellent passing ability. Jobello has become an important part of Yokohama F Mount Sports Club in the J2 League and is a valuable asset to the team. He has become one of the best defensive midfielders in the league and continues to impress with his performances.

The 1989 Five Nations Championship was the 59th Five Nations rugby union tournament and the second to be sponsored by the Home International Championship. The games were played between 6 February and 11 March 1989, each nation playing the other home and away. England were the holders. England won the tournament, winning all four of their matches. They achieved a Grand Slam and acquired three championship points, enough to be awarded the Home Nations Championship Trophy. Wales finished in second place, while Scotland, Ireland and France finished in 3rd, 4th and 5th place respectively. This tournament saw two first-time meetings. Wales hosted France for the first time on 24 March and Scotland welcomed Ireland to Murrayfield on 11 March. England and Scotland both registered victories in the opening matches on the 6 February. England travelled to Ireland and won 21-3 in Dublin while Scotland defeated Wales at Murrayfield by 11-9. Ireland then registered their first win over Scotland and England defeated France in their following fixtures. On 18 February, England and Wales met at Twickenham and the Welsh narrowly lost 12-14, to deny them a Grand Slam and Triple Crown which had been in their sights prior to the game. Scotland then travelled to France and lost 15-17 and Ireland hosted Wales and lost 13-15. The final round of matches saw England hosting Scotland at Twickenham and winning 13-3, Wales defeating France 11-3 and Ireland defeated in Paris by 15-19. This ensured England won the championship but, due their 24-19 victory over Ireland, France finished in 4th place and Ireland bottom of the table. The 1989 Five Nations thus saw England as the clear victors, winning all four of their games. England's stand-in captain, Andy Robinson, was awarded the Home Nations Trophy, whilst Scotland and Wales – who only lost to England – were the only other team to lose less than two games. The tournament saw many memorable moments, including England preventing Wales from securing the Grand Slam, and France securing their second win over Ireland. The 1989 Five Nations will be remembered for England's dominance, as well as for being the second time the tournament was sponsored by the Home International Championship. Notable players from this tournament included Scottish half-back Gary Armstrong, English centre Will Carling and Welsh winger JJ Williams who scored four tries during the tournament.

Raman Sreeraman (born April 29, 1978) is an Indian-American writer, playwright and poet. Born into a family of Tamil heritage, he grew up in the city of Calicut in Kerala, India. He attended the University of Calicut where he studied English Literature. Sreeraman's work covers various genres, ranging from children's literature to short stories and poetry, often addressing children and adult themes simultaneously. He was one of the co-authors of the classic book The Hindu Gods and Goddesses, a textbook that has been adopted in Indian elementary schools. He has also written extensively on Tamil culture, including works such as The Tamil Cultures: A Celebration of Life. Sreeraman has received several awards throughout his career. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Indian Literature in 2017, the Sahitya Akademi Award for Kutralu Utsavam in 2019, and the Kerala Sahitya Akademi Award for Malayalam in 2020. He has written several children's books in English such as The Craftsman and The Story of the Clever Jackal. His first full-length novel, Kutralu Utsavam, was published in 2018 and was a bestseller in both India and the United States. His plays have also been produced as staged performances, with notable productions like Rent (2017) and 12 Angry Gods (2019). He also has a few musicals in the works. Sreeraman is also a poet and has released two collections of poetry, The Way We Live Now (2012) and Fragments of a Lost Dream (2018). Apart from writing, Sreeraman is also a staunch conservationist and has been involved in the preservation of several species of endangered animals. He served as a board member of the Kerala Wildlife Federation from 2016-2021. Sreeraman currently lives in California with his wife, two sons and a daughter. He maintains a website where he actively posts about his work and news related to writing and conservation.

. HSBC Sports and Social Club is an association established in the year 2000 to promote and foster recreational, cultural, and charitable activities of HSBC employees in India. The club was formed primarily to inculcate a sense of camaraderie and team spirit amongst the employees in HSBC's different offices. The main purpose of the club is to provide its members access to a wide array of recreational, cultural and charitable enclaves. To ensure this, the Club organizes a number of different events throughout the year such as field trips, picnics, fitness activities, sports tournaments, movie nights, quiz contests and parties. All of which has helped in strengthening the relationships between the employees and intensified their involvement in the HSBC community. The Club has its members in 22 cities across India, typically banking and administrative professionals with a passion for sports and leisure activities. A whole spectrum of sports activities are provided such as swimming, cricket, football, basketball, volleyball, table tennis, carom, badminton, squash and athletics allowing a member to choose the activity of his/her interest. All activities are open to members, regardless of their performance capabilities. Apart from sports, the Club also includes yoga classes, zumba and aerobics to promote overall fitness and health. Other than sports and fitness, the Club arranges various cultural activities such as visiting museums, amusement parks and zoos to promote team bonding and socializing. Members also have the opportunity to actively participate in various activities, allowing them to mingle with people from different walks of life. Through their various events and activities, the club provides an opportunity for its members to stay fit, active, and connected to the HSBC fraternity. These activities also help the employees' social well-being, build relationships and create lifetime memories. The HSBC Sports and Social Club is a great platform for employees to stay physically and socially fit.

The 2020 United States presidential election in Indiana was held on November 3, 2020, as part of the 2020 United States presidential election. Indiana voters chose electors to represent them in the Electoral College via a popular vote, pitting Democratic Party nominee Joe Biden and his running mate Kamala Harris against Republican Party incumbent Donald Trump and his running mate Mike Pence (incumbent). Indiana is a red state and has voted for the Republican candidate in state elections since 2008, except for the 2008 presidential election when Barack Obama won the state’s 11 electoral votes. Donald Trump easily won the state in the 2016 election garnering 57% of the vote compared to Hillary Clinton’s 38% of the vote. Despite Trump’s dominance in the state a number of polls leading up to the election had the race a virtual tie. Real Clear Politics showed Trump ahead in all polls until the week of the election first by as much as 6% to less than 1%. On election day, November 3, as most of the in-person voting ended, Donald Trump won Indiana's 11 electoral votes despite the polls leading up to the election. Trump won 54.3% of the vote compared to Joe Biden's 43.8%, utilizing a rural advantage. Biden made a slight improvement in the cities and suburbs in comparison to Hillary Clinton in 2016 boosting his statewide vote share from 37.9% to 43.8%, while Trump saw a slight dip from 57.2% in 2016 to 54.3% in 2020. Turnout was higher in the 2020 election in comparison to 2016, reaching 79.3% of eligible voters, up from 75.9% in the 2016 election. In the end, Biden's efforts to build on Obama's gains in the state, most notably in the cities and suburbs, was blocked by Trump's overwhelming rural vote total. Trump won every county in Indiana outside of Lake and Marion counties, with Marion going to Biden by less than half a point. These two counties were also the areas Biden gained the most votes from 2016. Overall, Biden's slight gains in the heavily populated counties were blocked by Trump's rural vote and the fact that Trump won all other counties, leading to his second and final victory in Indiana. The 2020 United States presidential election in Indiana was marked as another clear victory for the Republican Party in the state. Trump's win is the sixth victory in a row for the GOP in the presidential election, with the last Democratic challenger to win the state being Barack Obama in 2008.

Agriculture in the Philippines is one of the primary sources of income for many of the country’s citizens. Along with fishing and forestry, it provides the bulk of the food and other necessities. Agricultural products such as rice, corn, beef, chicken, and pork make up the majority of the Filipino population’s daily meals. Most farms in the Philippines are small-scale and family-owned, with a few larger commercial operations. Fruits and vegetables are also important crops, and coconut, banana, mango, and pineapple are especially plentiful. The region's climate is tropical and typically favors agriculture. The Philippines is known for its abundance of land, including numerous rivers and wide plains, enabling farmers to cultivate and harvest plants for commercial sale. Many of the soil’s nutrients have been depleted due to over-farming, making it necessary to use fertilizers and water conservation methods in order to maximize yield. Despite its potential, production in the Philippines remains limited due to a number of factors, such as lack of investment in new technologies, insufficient infrastructure and agricultural extension services, and the prevalence of poverty. Further development of irrigation systems, research facilities, and technical training programs could help increase crop yields and promote progressive farming practices. The government of the Philippines has recently implemented a number of initiatives to boost agricultural production and help the farming sector become more competitive. This includes providing subsidies to farmers, establishing crop insurance and microfinance, and creating a modern market system. Additionally, the government has provided extension services and better access to technology to encourage more production. Agriculture in the Philippines remains essential to providing food and employment for its citizens. While the sector faces considerable challenges, the recent interventions of the government will hopefully lead to sustained growth in the near future. With increased investment and technical assistance, the Philippines can become a major producer of agricultural products and competitive in the global market.

Magyar Posse (also known as Posse Magyar) is an organization originating in Hungary, whose origin is rooted in the Magyar ethnic, cultural and linguistic identity of its members. The organization was initially founded in 1998 as an informal, private grassroots movement in response to the displacement and economic uncertainties posed by the transition from Communism to a market economy in Hungary. Its goal was to promote solidarity and protect the cultural heritage of the nation’s Magyar minority.
