In 2020, the organization became more officially organized, and a formal affiliate of the European Posse Federation was created to represent Magyar Posse on the international stage. Magyar Posse is open to any Hungarian national over the age of 18 or born to two Magyar parents, as well as associates of the organization who may not meet these criteria but wish to support its mission. The organization is currently headed by an executive council composed of representatives from across Hungary and a rotating president, who is elected every two years. The organization is funded entirely through donations and sponsorships, and is committed to the principles of non-violence and non-discrimination. As its mission statement suggests, the organization is mainly focused on preserving and promoting the Magyar identity, heritage and language. In particular, it has hosted public events and activities, created educational materials and scholarships, encouraged cultural exchange, and provided legal support to Magyar-speakers. It has also catalyzed the cooperative growth of small businesses within the Magyar community, and has disseminated cultural resources that raise awareness about the role of the Magyar people in Hungarian history. In recent years, Magyar Posse has also become increasingly involved in other social issues. It has offered resources for the betterment of individuals' lives such as career counseling and mentorship, as well as partnered with organizations and other civil society networks in Hungary to provide advocacy and support on issues ranging from LGBTQ+ rights to policies relating to the environment. Through its efforts, the organization has become a significant contributor to the growth and stability of the Hungarian nation.

Brentford Football Club, nicknamed The Bees, are a professional association football club based in Brentford, West London, England. The club was founded in 1889 and plays its home matches at Griffin Park, its home ground since 1904. Brentford Football Club has had a rich and varied history of seasons. This article documents the full list of their seasons, including the years they competed in various divisions, cup competitions, and any memorable performances. 1889-91: After being founded in 1889, the club competed in various leagues and cups prior to the formation of the Southern League in 1894. During this period, Brentford won the West London Alliance (1891) and the London Senior Cup (1890 & 1891). 1894-1908: During this period, Brentford competed in the Southern League, winning the Second Division in 1897-98 and the First Division in 1898-99. Brentford also reached the first round of the FA Cup four times and was a losing finalist in the FA Amateur Cup in 1907. 1908-1939: Brentford were elected to the Football League in 1920 and competed in Division Three (South) for the following 19 seasons. During this period, Brentford were Division Three (South) champions in 1932 and London War Cup winners in 1940. 1939-76: After the Second World War, Brentford were mostly a mid-table side in the third and fourth tiers of English football. Their most successful period during this time came in the 1960s when they won the Football League Fourth Division championship in 1962-63, Third Division (South) title in 1965-66 and reached the fourth round of the FA Cup in 1965-66 and 1971-72. 1976-present: Brentford have competed in the second and third tiers of English football since 1976, with the notable exception of a single season (1992–93) in the fourth tier. They have also been frequently involved in the FA Cup and England's other domestic cups, making five appearances in the final qualifying round of the UEFA Cup (formerly the UEFA Cup Winners' Cup). This article provides a full list of Brentford Football Club’s seasons, which includes the years they competed in various divisions, cup competitions and any notable performances. The club continued to make history and achieves success, even back to its early days in the late 1800s. The table below summarises all of Brentford Football Club’s seasons since the club’s foundation in 1889.

Zirkle Mill is a gristmill that is located in Port republic, Virginia. It is the oldest remaining working mill in Rockingham County and one of the oldest mills in the state. The mill has been in operation since at least 1818 and was originally owned by the Zirkle family. The original mill was powered by a wooden waterwheel with a 15-foot diameter. In 1821, the mill was converted to use a larger, steel waterwheel and a turbine to generate power. The turbine was fueled by local streams and was used to power the grinding stones. The mill also has an attached sawmill powered by the same turbine. The Zirkle Mill is a three-story structure made of stone and brick. The first floor of the building is devoted to the grinding and packaging of grain, while the second floor is used for storage. The sawmill and turbine are located in a separate building behind the main structure. The mill is still in operation today and is the last remaining milling operation in Port republic. The mill is open to the public and offers tours to visitors who can observe the grinding and sawing of the grain or visit the museum to learn more about the history of the mill. The Zirkle Mill is part of the South River Heritage Trail system, which connects it to other historic sites in the region. The Zirkle Mill is part of the National Register of Historic Places and is a popular destination for tourists and local history enthusiasts alike. It offers a unique glimpse into the past and provides a great opportunity to learn about a key piece of American history. The mill was also recently featured in the television series “American Pickers”. The Zirkle Mill is a lasting symbol of the hard work and perseverance of generations of millers. As a reminder of a bygone era, it is an important part of the local and regional history and culture of Port Republic. As of 2021, the mill is still operated by the fifth generation of the original family, making it one of the oldest family-owned businesses in Virginia. Despite the passage of time, the Zirkle Mill continues to produce large quantities of high-quality grains, including stone-ground meal, flours, and grits.

Bidens hyperborea, commonly known as alpine beggarticks, is a perennial plant belonging to the Asteraceae family Native to the mountains of Asia, it grows at elevations ranging from 1000-2000 meters above sea level. Bidens hyperborea is an herbaceous plant which grows to heights of up to 1m. The creeping stems bear large, sawtooth-edged leaves which are clustered at the base of the plant. The leaves are dark green in colour and can reach up to 6 cm in length. The plant produces star-shaped yellow flowers in a dense spherical heads. Each flower is composed of five oval petals and the plant blooms in summer. Bidens hyperborea is a therapeutic herb which has been used in traditional Chinese remedies for centuries. It is traditionally used to treat a range of ailments such as headache, vomiting, fever, and painful joints. It is also believed to have antioxidant, antifungal, antiviral, and anti-inflammatory properties. In addition to its medicinal uses, Bidens hyperborea is also used as a food plant and for ornamental purposes. It is cultivated in areas with a cold winter climate and thrives in moist environments. Bidens hyperborea is generally disease-free and relatively easy to grow. Despite its many benefits, the plant is considered a weed in some areas due to its aggressive growth habit. Bidens hyperborea is an important species in mountaintop environments because of its ability to fix nitrogen from the atmosphere and its mycorrhizal relationships with certain fungi. Its presence on mountain slopes stabilizes the soil and reduces the risk of landslides and mudslides which can occur when roots are excluded from the landscape. The plant also provides food and habitat for a variety of mountain living organisms making it an integral part of mountain ecosystems. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) currently lists Bidens hyperborea as being of least concern and not at risk of extinction. Despite its current status, the species is believed to be vulnerable to climate change. Therefore, increased monitoring of the species is needed to ensure the continued survival of Bidens hyperborea and its important role in mountain ecosystems.

Albert Schultens (21 July 1686 - 22 April 1750) was a Dutch Orientalist and theologian, noted for his critical editions of Arabic manuscripts. A native of Groningen, Netherlands, Schultens received his education at the Latin school of the University of Groningen before beginning his study of theology at Leiden University in 1705. Throughout his time at Leiden, Schultens took up the study of Arabic, Persian and Turkish to complement his knowledge of theology. After qualifying as a Doctor of Theology in 1714, Schultens moved to Italy, where he would further deepen his knowledge of languages and ancient manuscripts, including a two-year residence in Rome. Schultens went on to become a professor of ancient languages at Groningen University in 1721, where he was appointed rector in 1737. In 1722, Schultens accepted a position at the recently established University of Harderwijk, where he taught the oriental tongues. In 1743, Schultens returned to Leiden to teach Ancient Languages, a post which he held until his death in 1750. During his lifetime, Schultens wrote numerous books, essays, and commentaries on oriental languages and theological matters. His works include an edition of the Persian poet Hafez, a critical edition of the Koran, a Latin translation of Ali bin Sahl Rabban al-Tabari’s history, a Dutch translation of The Thousand and One Nights, and an Arabic-English dictionary. Schultens’ most notable achievement is his geographic survey of the Islamic world, Nova Descriptione Orbis Arabici. In addition to his contributions to oriental studies, Schultens held a deep interest in theology, making a number of contributions to the field, particularly with regard to Christian-Muslim relations. He is best known for his publications discussing the views of John Calvin on Islam, such as A Defence of John Calvin Against the Defamatory Rabbi at Damascus. Schultens’ works achieved a great deal of recognition in his lifetime, and were highly influential on later Orientalists, particularly Sir William Jones, who in 1784 praised Schultens’ accessible works on the Arabic and Persian language. Schultens’ ongoing legacy is recognized today in institutions such as the Albert Schultens Chair in Arabic and Islamic Studies at Groningen University.

George N. Turner (1857-1944) was an American lawyer and statesman who served as the fifteenth mayor of Nashville, Tennessee, from 1898 to 1902. He was a prominent figure in the African-American community during the Progressive Era. Turner was born in Leake County, Mississippi, in 1857. His family moved to Nashville when he was an infant, and he grew up in the city's African-American community. Growing up, he attended the Presbyterian Academy of Colored Youth, and a few other schools, though never graduating. Hoping to learn law, he was apprenticed to a horse dealer who was a lawyer. He was later admitted to the bar in 1882. Turner soon established a law practice in Nashville. He also dedicated his time to politics and the fight for civil rights. Turner became involved in civic organizations, including the YMCA and the NAACP, and was active in the Republican Party. He became president of local chapters of the Republican Party and was elected to the Tennessee State Legislature in 1888. In 1897 Turner ran for mayor of Nashville. He won, and he served from 1898 to 1902. During his term, he implemented a number of progressive reforms, including expanding the city's electrical system, banning saloons, and establishing a police department. He was also concerned with civil rights, and worked to enact laws preventing discrimination in public facilities and giving African-American jurors the right to serve on juries. Following his term as mayor, Turner moved up the government ladder, serving in the Tennessee House of Representatives, becoming Assistant Secretary of the U.S. Treasury, and later becoming the first African-American United States attorney in the South. Ultimately, he was appointed by President Woodrow Wilson as the U.S. Commissioner of Internal Revenue in 1912, becoming one of the highest-ranking African-American officials in the federal government. Turner died in 1944, at the age of 87. He is remembered as a progressive statesman who devoted his life to improving the lives of African-Americans in the South.

C International Photo Magazine (CIPM) is a quarterly photography magazine from England that has been publishing since 2003. It is primarily aimed at professional photographers, and features a wide range of topics in both contemporary and classic photography. The publication is known for its unique and diverse content that features numerous unique concepts, styles and themes. Each cover is specially designed with the content of the issue in mind, to form a photo story that tells a captivating visual tale. With photos spanning the globe, CIPM engages readers wherever they are. Throughout each issue, various photographic topics are explored and discussed. This includes interviews with renowned photographers, coverage of latest industry-changing technologies, advice on the creative process and trends, and much more. CIPM also dedicates an entire issue to the work of one of their guest editors every year. The magazine has established a strong following over the years, having featured some of the world's most renowned photographers such as David LaChapelle, Tomás Munita, Martin Parr, and more. They have also seen some of their most notable works being featured in numerous exhibitions, both in the U.K. and abroad. In addition to their quarterly magazine, CIPM also runs a website and Instagram page, regularly posting news and updates about the magazine's most current issue. They also have a Facebook page where followers can find out about the latest events, competitions, and creative opportunities. In an effort to increase their global reach and make their magazine more accessible to its fans, CIPM has since started an online shop where readers can purchase digital copies. They are also currently offering a subscription package field with exclusive offers and discounts. With its expertly curated content and inspiring aesthetic, CIPM covers a wide spectrum of modern and traditional genres that have been celebrated for more than a decade. Each issue gives readers an insightful look into the world of photography, the techniques and stories behind emerging and established photographers, and the latest tools of the trade.

Save Dat Money, released on May 23, 2015 by record labels Asking and Def Jam Recordings, is a debut single by American hip hop recording artist Lil Dicky, featuring American rappers Rich Homie Quan and Fetty Wap. The song was co-produced by DJ Dahi and Dat Don. "Save Dat Money" is an ode to financial responsibility and frugality, in contrast to the more typical theme of ostentatious wealth and extravagance prominent within hip hop music. The song's catchy hook contains a play on the phrase "fake it 'til you make it", instead singing: "Save that money, get that money, never spend that money/Work hard, find a way, no matter what the pay". The accompanying music video, released on June 8, 2015, was directed by Tony Yacenda and filmed in a large suburban house in Thousand Oaks, California. It was produced by Mike Dierich, Julian Christian, and Alvaro Menendez, with executive producers Charles D. Shields and Kristen Hamilton. The music video starts with an introduction by Dr. Dre, who formally announces the song via a faux scientific presentation demonstrating the effectiveness of the song in getting people to save money instead of spending it. The video then breaks out into a party scene, featuring appearances from Kevin Durant, Mark Cuban, Tom Segura, Sarah Silverman, Tina Fey, Hannibal Buress and many other celebrities. Upon its release, the reception to "Save Dat Money" was largely positive. The song was praised for its distinctly different approach to rap and its overall message. The music video was equally praised, being applauded for its innovative presentation and its skillful use of numerous comedic cameos. The single peaked at number 77 on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart, number 33 on the Mainstream Top 40 chart, and number 17 on the UK Singles chart. As of December 2020, the single has received 266,585,771 streams on Spotify, and is certified 3x Platinum in Australia, where it peaked at number 4 on the ARIA Singles Chart. To this date, it remains one of Lil Dicky's most successful and popular singles.

The Rudolf Harbig Memorial Award is a prestigious award given annually to individuals who have contributed significantly to the athletic world. It is given out by the International Amateur Athletics Federation (IAAF) and is named after the German track and field champion Rudolf Harbig. Rudolf Harbig was a track and field athlete in the 1930s. He was most successful in the 800m event, as he won gold medals at both the 1932 Olympics and 1938 European Championships. He is also credited with setting four world records in the 800m event. He was an important part of the German sports world in his time and he is remembered by the award in his name. The Rudolf Harbig Memorial Award was first instituted in 1952 by the IAAF as a way to recognize major contributions to the world of athletics. It was given to individuals, teams, and organizations on an annual basis. The award ceremony usually takes place during the IAAF World Championships. The award typically includes an honorarium and a personal certificate of acknowledgement. The inscription on the certificate reads: "In recognition of [recipient's name] for outstanding and meritorious services to athletics." This can be given for contributions to the development and promotion of athletics, to professional and technical excellence, or for exceptional achievement in the world of athletics. Some past recipients of the award include Emil Zatopek, Sebastian Coe, and Carl Lewis. The Rudolf Harbig Memorial Award is a highly respected honor in the world of athletics. It is presented at the IAAF World Championships each year and recognizes the integral role that individuals and organizations play in helping to shape athletics. The award serves as a lasting tribute to Rudolf Harbig and his significant contribution to the world of track and field.

LGBT+ Rights Ghana is a campaign to advance and promote the rights of all LGBT+ persons in Ghana. The campaign works to promote and build a Ghanaian society in which all sexual orientation and gender identity are accepted and respected. In Ghana, discrimination and marginalization of the LGBT+ community is widespread. As of 2020, same-sex relations are illegal in Ghana and carry a sentence of up to 3 years in prison. LGBT+ people are banned from serving in the military and face stigma, violence, and discrimination from their families and communities. This stigma has been a major obstacle to gaining civil and political rights, better health care access and acceptance of LGBT+ persons. In spite of these challenges, there are a growing number of activists, organizations and individuals in Ghana who are determined to advance and promote the rights of all LGBT+ people in the country. LGBT+ Rights Ghana works to raise awareness and build a strong rights-based movement in the country. Through partnerships with local organizations, they are able to organize meetings and workshops across the country to bring visibility and raise awareness of LGBT+ rights and their issues. The group also organizes public events with the goal of creating a safe space for LGBT+ Ghanaians. Additionally, LGBT+ Rights Ghana is involved in advocacy efforts to include LGBT+ rights in the Ghanaian Constitution and to pass laws that protect the rights of LGBT+ persons. In 2020, they organized a march in Accra to bring attention to the need for LGBT+ rights to be included in the country’s constitution. Additionally, the group has worked to repeal outdated and discriminatory laws and create safe spaces for LGBT+ people. The effects of the campaign are hard to measure, but LGBT+ Rights Ghana is committed to working towards a more equitable future for all Ghanaians. The work of the campaign has resulted in more visible LGBT+ spaces in the country and a growing awareness of LGBT+ rights and issues. The campaign has also raised important questions about the way LGBT+ people are treated and talked about in Ghana and around the world. Overall, LGBT+ Rights Ghana is making progress in advancing and promoting the rights of all LGBT+ people in Ghana. The hope is that the group will continue to build support, create a safe space for LGBT+ people to come together, and ultimately create a future where all Ghanaians have the right to be treated with dignity, respect, and acceptance.

Bruceton Mills is an unincorporated community in Preston County, West Virginia, United States. It is located along the West Fork River in the Cheat River Valley. The settlement was first founded and called Bruceton in the early 19th century, after the family of Thomas Bruce who were among the early settlers in the area. It has since served as a crossroads of sorts for the many travelers who venture between Morgantown, West Virginia and Cumberland, Maryland. The town bears the name of its founding father, although the "Mills" part of the name was added in the late 19th century to acknowledge the town's busy mill. Located at the junction of West Virginia Route 26 and County Route 45, much of Bruceton Mills' history is tied to these two roads which have served as important transportation routes for the region. The town maintains a general store and post office, as well as a few other businesses, making it a vibrant part of the region. Mining, logging, and various small industries have been key components of the local economy for nearly two centuries. The town is home to a small mill which still produces flour, as well as a lumber mill and a few other businesses. Most of the population is employed in nearby cities such as Clarksburg, West Virginia and Morgantown, however. The town hosts an annual fall festival that was recognized with the "West Virginia Community Pride Award" from West Virginia University. This event brings local and nearby residents together for a day of shopping, food, and music, and helps foster a unique sense of community. Situated along the banks of the West Fork River, Bruceton Mills is a picturesque and charming spot for a weekend getaway. The area is known for its beautiful landscapes and outdoor activities, such as fishing, kayaking, and whitewater rafting, which draw visitors from near and far. The nearby Cheat Country Club is a popular destination for golf enthusiasts, and the lake at the club is also great for swimming. For those interested in exploring history, nearby Bruceton Mills Battlefield is also a worthwhile spot. The battlefield served witness to portions of the American Civil War, and several monuments commemorate the events which took place. With its unique culture and stunning natural beauty, Bruceton Mills is a unique spot nestled in the Cheat River Valley. The hamlet draws visitors from around the area and further afield to its many attractions, making it an ideal destination for an idyllic break away from the hustle and bustle of everyday life.

Handmade Arcade is an annual event showcasing the handmade and creative culture of the Pittsburgh region. Founded in 2003, the event has grown in size, scope, and reputation in the local and national handmade community. The event is held in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and typically takes place in late November in the David L. Lawrence Convention Center. Handmade Arcade showcases the best of Pittsburgh's talented artisanal community ages 18 and up, ranging from local jewelry makers and fashion designers to cake and cookie bakers, and much more. Each year, over 200 vendors are accepted to show off their crafts with an audience of around 8,000 attendees. Additionally, the event also provides an educational component in the form of professional development workshops for the exhibiting vendors, as well as a juried exhibition of art and design related objects. All of these components come together to make Handmade Arcade a unique showcase of handmade culture in the Pittsburgh region. The event is the largest single-day show of its kind in the area and has received both local and national award recognition for its success, including the Governor’s Award for Excellence in Arts Education, the Pennsylvania Parks and Forests Foundation’s Distinguished Partner of the Year Award, and the Pennsylvania Association of Non Profit Organizations’ Non Profit of the Year Award. The event has come a long way since its inception in 2003, and its success has shown no signs of slowing down. For those looking to support their local makers and shop the best that Pittsburgh has to offer, Handmade Arcade is the best place to do so. As the event continues to grow and evolve, it remains one of the premiere destination for handmade goods in the Pittsburgh area.

Ethnodoxology is a field of study within the field of intercultural music research concerning the musical expressions of a particular people group. It is concerned with the relationships between music, culture, and spirituality within a particular culture or Indigenous population. Ethnodoxology is a growing area of interest in the field of theoretical and practical musicology, music education, and the broader field of ethnomusicology. The term “ethnodoxology” was coined in 1999 by Dr. Dale A. Olsen, an emeritus professor at Calvin College in Grand Rapids, Michigan. Since then, the term has been used by a variety of scholars to describe this academic field of study. As a sub-field of ethnomusicology, it is concerned with the impact of traditional music on a specific culture and religious expression, and the educational, spiritual, and social implications of that impact. The field of ethnodoxology focuses on understanding traditional music from the perspective of the people living the culture, which is distinct from the more objective perspective of Western musicology. Ethnodoxology seeks to examine music through an experiential approach, which places the cultural expressions at its center. Notable theorists within the field consider that traditional music contains a set of ontological and axiological characteristics that are fundamental to the culture and thus inextricably linked to its identity. For the practitioner, this means that ethnodoxology seeks to prioritize understanding traditional music within a culture before adapting it to any other purpose. This calls for a greater emphasis not only on learning the technical and sensory aspects of a particular style or piece, but also on understanding the cultural context to which those elements belong. Some have argued that the goal of ethnoixology is to “engage all aspects of music, including intellectual, physical, and spiritual,” as well as its historical, geographical, cultural, and social context. Through this emphasis on understanding, the field seeks to contribute to the growth of inter-cultural understanding and sensitivity. One of the primary goals of ethnodoxology is to contribute to the sustainability of traditional music and culture in an inter-cultural context.In this sense, its focus is centered on the educational, social, and political ramifications of music within a community, as well as its power to build bridges between different communities, ideologies, and generations. Practitioners of ethnodoxology seek to use the unique insights that traditional music can offer in the educational, musical, and spiritual realms. In essence, ethnodoxology seeks to look at music from a holistic perspective that takes into account the history, tradition, culture, and context of the people in order to develop an appreciation of the music. This field of study hopes to contribute to cultural dialogue, create bridges between cultures, and foster greater appreciation for the traditional musics of different cultures.

Alexandra, Eildon, and Marysville Standard is a regional newspaper based in Victoria, Australia and serving small towns in the area between Alexandra, Eildon and Marysville. It was established in 1925 and has a circulation of approximately 1,000 copies each Wednesday. Originally founded as a free newspaper, it is now a paid publication with a wide readership in the area. The Alexandra, Eildon and Marysville Standard serves a large area and is widely known for its local stories, unique insight into the area, and dedication to maintaining high editorial standards. It covers a wide range of topics and focuses on local news from the area. They are focused on providing reliable, informative, and entertaining news related to the towns they serve. The newspaper is owned and operated by R.J. Murray andK.J. Evans who have been involved in the business since 1975. Alex, Eildon and Marysville Standard employ a diverse team of journalists, photographers, and advertising staff. The team is led by Editor Anna Strypman. The Alexandra, Eildon and Marysville Standard is committed to providing the community with news that is relevant and timely, as well as feature stories about local businesses, community events, and sports teams. The newspaper also hosts various events and contests throughout the year. The paper won numerous awards and recognitions including the Australian Journalism Award from the Australian Journalist Society in 2012, and was awarded with the Victoria Media Award for Newspaper of the Year in 2013. Alexandra, Eildon and Marysville Standard remains an influential media force and serves an important role in the regional community. They provide a valuable service to the local people and are renown for their commitment to excellence.

Dave Rodgers (Born April 6th 1959) is an internationally recognized singer-songwriter, composer and disc-jockey. He is one of the leading creators of the "Eurobeat" music genre and has written, composed and produced several hundred tracks, extended-plays and albums. He has had collaborations with several legendary artists and been credited on many different releases with other producers such as Michihiko Ohta, Narada Michael Walden and Kentaro Kobayashi. Dave Rodgers was born in London, England, but grew up in Tokyo, Japan. He moved to Tokyo after his family decided to move there on business. While residing in Japan he frequently visited record shops and music stores and is said to have been very inspired by different music genres he discovered such as funk, disco and Italo disco. He began to record and produce his own music and in 1989 released his first album titled "Magic”, released through Avex Trax. With the growing admiration and demand for Eurobeat music in Japan, Dave Rodgers quickly rose to fame within the genre. He released many extended-plays and singles with songs such as "Deja Vu", "Take Me Higher" and "Space Boy". His most notable releases include the albums "Eurobeat Flash", "Night of Fire" and "Go Beat Crazy". Beyond his Eurobeat music, Dave Rodgers has been involved in other musical projects such as the 1987 compilation "Spacesynth". This album was a collaboration between Vince Dicola and K.G. Project and featured several tracks written by Dave Rodgers, including the popular "Flying High". In 2021 he collaborated with several other popular Eurobeat producers to form the supergroup Super Eurobeat Allstars and released the single "Time Machine", which was an ode to the incredible history of Eurobeat music. Dave Rodgers has enjoyed long-lasting success throughout his career and is internationally known as one of the major contributors to the Eurobeat genre. He frequently hosts live events and has written a handful of books about the history of the genre and his involvement in it. He is widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in the industry and his contributions to Eurobeat music will be long remembered.

Prex Merrill is an American bank executive and entrepreneur. He is best known as the long-time Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and Co-Chairman of Bank of America Corporation, and former Chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. He held the latter position from April 2016 until January 17, 2018. Early life and Education Merrill was born in Kingsford, Michigan, and grew up in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. He received a B.S. degree in finance from Northern Michigan University in 1977. Career Merrill joined Bank of America in 1979, prior to its merger with Security Pacific Bank. Over his thirty-eight year career with Bank of America, he served in numerous senior management roles, including at one-time President of Commercial Banking and Prime Services, heading up all of Bank of America's corporate, investment banking and global capital markets businesses. After his retirement in 2017, he joined the boards of Accuray Inc, a manufacturer of radiation therapy technology and First Republic Bank, a private bank and wealth management firm, both located in Emeryville, California. In 2020, Merrill was appointed to the board of directors of American Electric Power Co., Inc., a publicly traded utility company based in Columbus, Ohio. In addition, he is a member of the board of directors of Northern Michigan University. In 2018, as Chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Merrill wrote an op-ed in the Wall Street Journal which discussed the importance of regulatory reform for the country's financial system. The Prex Andy Merrill Fellowship Program Merril created the Prex Andy Merrill Fellowship Program at Northern Michigan University in 2006 to fund youth advisory program, a program that brings student innovators from around the world to the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. The program funds projects that foster business and entrepreneurship, and encourage community development within the local area. Personal life Merrill and his wife have one daughter. He is a member of the Bay Area Council for Education, and a board member of the National Council on Economic Education. In 2020, Merrill was named one of the top 10 most influential executives of the decade in the financial industry by Forbes magazine. Category:Bank of America people Category:American business executives Category:American bankers

1990–91 Division 1 was the 20th season of the top Senegalese football league, Division 1. The season began on 10 March 1991, and ended on 13 July 1991. ASC Port Autonome were the defending champions; they went on to defend their title, winning their seventh Division 1 title. Professional football in Senegal dates back to the mid 1950s, when a championship was established to foster Senegalese participation. The 1990–91 season featured 19 clubs, the same number of clubs as the 1989–90 season. The season began on the 10 March 1991 with five matches. Étoile Lusitana snatched the first victory of the season, beating Diambars 3–2. The last match of the season was between ASC Port Autonome and Stade de Mbour, which Port Autonome won by a score of 2–0 to seal their seventh championship in Senegal. This was the first season of the renamed Senegalese Professional Football League, which provided professional football for the top-ranking clubs in Senegal. The season saw four clubs earn promotion from the second division, with leaders ASC Guédiawaye joining Kaolack, ASEC Ndiambour, and Casa Sports. ASC Guédiawaye also went on to finish fourth in the top division, behind defending champions Port Autonome, runners-up ASEC Ndiambour, and third-placed Annexia. The season was marked by shock results, with smaller clubs often taking points off of bigger teams. It also marked the start of one of the most successful periods in Senegalese football history. After a period of domination by Port Autonome in the early 90s, several other sides started to challenge for honours in the late 90s and early 2000s, such as ASC Diaraf, ASC Linguere, and Jeanne d’Arc. The 1990–91 season saw the highest home attendance record since professional football began in Senegal, amounting to a total of 74,680 spectators for the entire season, an average of 886 per game. Salif Keita of ASC Port Autonome was the top scorer, finishing with 16 goals. The 1990–91 season laid the foundation for a highly successful period of Senegalese football in the coming years, with the level of competition improving and more surprise results. Teams such as ASC Diaraf and ASC Jeanne d’Arc started to challenge for honours on a regular basis, and the Senegalese Professional Football League was on its way to becoming one of the most successful and competitive football leagues in Africa.

Karima Francis (born July 6, 1988) is a British singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist and producer from Southport, Merseyside. After signing a publishing deal with EMI Music in 2007, Francis released her debut album The Author in 2008. Having taken a four-year break to raise her daughter, Francis returned with her critically acclaimed sophomore album Black Opal in 2013, following which she released a digital EP titled Sparkle and Shine in 2014. Francis’ musical style has been described as a fusion of "blues, folk, grunge, soul and electronica" and has been likened to those of Norah Jones and Alanis Morissette. Francis cites some of her major influences to be U2, Robert Plant, Lady Gaga, Tori Amos and PJ Harvey. In 2017, Francis worked on her third studio album, slated for release in the summer of 2019. This album, titled Glamour Radio, is said to explore themes of identity and personal growth. As well as writing and recording her own music, Francis works as a session musician and producer. In 2017, she produced and played drums on three tracks on the album Look How Far We've Come by Southport-based indie-rock group Sherlocks. In addition to her work as a musician, Francis is a regular contributor for UK magazine JUCE and presents a weekly show on independent radio station TotalRock. Francis has also been active as a speaker on issues of gender equality in the music industry. Francis was one of twenty female musicians selected to participate in the PRS Foundation's ReBalance initiative, which seeks to address the imbalance of gender representation in the recording studio. Having recently returned from a tour in support of her new EP, Francis is currently gearing up for the release of Glamour Radio and a busy summer festival season.

Thomas Radford (born 1943) is an internationally renowned musician and composer from the United Kingdom. He is best known for his spectacular performances of British folk music, and has been a major influence for many performers who have followed in his footsteps. Radford began learning the violin and traditional English folk music in his early twenties after being inspired by a James Madison University professor. He fell in love with the sound and strived to learn as much as he could about the genre. His teachers included Bert Jansch and Ivor Cutler. He began performing locally with other amateur folk players before eventually touring the U.K. and Europe as a solo artist. Radford performed at numerous major British folk festivals, including the Edinburgh Folk Festival, the Cambridge Folk Festival and the Glasgow Folk Festival. He quickly became a major draw with his audience members, commanding large crowds and rave reviews. In 1971, he recorded his first album, The Green Man, a melting pot of traditional and original pieces. This was followed by several other critically acclaimed albums in the 1970s and 1980s. He famously joined forces with fellow folk musicians Bill Leader and Martin Carthy in 1976 to form a folk trio, which was later named 'Radford, Leader & Carthy'. They went on to tour extensively, made an album and gained significant success within the folk music industry. In 2001, he worked with writer Rob Young on a compilation album, Songs and Dances from the British Isles. This album featured some of the best traditional English music from across Britain, such as Scotland, Wales and England. His own compositions were included, as well as some of his own interpretations of his favourite songs. In recognition of his immense contribution to the traditional music industry, Radford won the Gold Badge Award in 2011 and was appointed as a Member of the British Empire in 2017. Radford is still performing various concerts and festivals today. He has highlighted that he is excited for the folk scene to be improving in popularity and for it to enter new generations. His first novel - a collection of folk songs, stories and recipes - is due to be published in 2020.

Vaumeilh is a commune in the Alpes-de-Haute-Provence department in southeastern France. It is located in the Southern French Alps, near the Italian border, at an altitude of 1,026 m. The commune is surrounded by forests and mountains, and is known for its stunning views and tranquil atmosphere.The area is popular with hikers and campers, as well as winter sports enthusiasts. Vaumeilh was created in 1875, when the neighboring communes of Valensole and Granges-les-Beaumont decided to unify and form a new commune. The village of Vaumeilh was the result, and was named after Valensole's mayor at the time. The commune is chiefly composed of hamlets and small villages, including the villages of Valensole, Le Rouisson, Les Béonnets, Les Banons and Vaumeilh. It covers 7,581 hectares, with a population of 2,300 people as of 2019. The economy of Vaumeilh is largely based on agriculture, particularly grain and vegetables, as well as woodworking. In recent years, tourism has become an increasingly important part of the local economy. Vaumeilh is home to several small chapels and churches, including St. Pierre and St. Paul, St. Jean-Baptise and Notre-Dame-du-Désert. It also boasts a thermal spring at the village of Les Béonnets. The commune is part of the Luberon Regional Natural Park, a protected area spanning the Haute-Provence and Vaucluse departments. Its diversity of landscapes and rich natural heritage make it an ideal destination for nature-lovers. Vaumeilh holds an annual festival in August to celebrate its small but vibrant culture. The festivities include parades, traditional Provençal music and dances, and craft fairs. Vaumeilh is a beautiful and idyllic village where nature, culture and history combine to offer a unique experience. Whether you're looking for a peaceful escape from the hustle and bustle of the city or an exciting outdoor adventure, Vaumeilh is the perfect destination.

Plinian Core (also known as Pacific Explosive Material Experimentation Centre) is an experimental research and teaching facility established by the US Government in 1945 to explore the behaviour of high explosives and the properties of various materials under extreme conditions. The facility consists of a network of underground tunnels, structures and laboratories spread out on eight buildings, with a total of over 60 test cells. Plinian Core is designed to house a series of large scale experiments involving explosives, ranging from low to high explosives. Plinian Core also houses a radiochemistry laboratory that provides a suite of facilities for the study of radiochemistry and radioactive material. The facility is most notably used to investigate the initiation of nuclear weapons, and is one of only two facilities in the United States dedicated to complete testing of nuclear weapons in a safe and secure manner. These experiments include the first test experiments of modern day thermonuclear weapons, and contribute to the overall knowledge of how volatile materials interact. Plinian Core is located at the Pacific Proving Grounds in the Marshall Islands and was constructed for testing nuclear weapons during the US occupation of the Marianas islands in the late 1940s. Since its establishment, the site has also been heavily used for weapons research and development, including development of chemical and biological weapons. The facility is managed by the U.S. Department of Energy and operated by Los Alamos National Laboratory. It is currently used for research in the fields of hazardous material testing, high explosives safety, and law enforcement training and is subject to strict safety guidelines by the Department of Energy. Plinian Core is regarded as an important asset to the US Government's explorations in the field of nuclear weapons research and development. The facility has greatly contributed to the knowledge of how dangerous materials can interact, and is of great importance in advancing security in the international community.

Springside is a neighborhood in the city of Poughkeepsie, New York. Located approximately 4 miles south of the city's downtown area, the neighborhood is situated along the western bank of the Hudson River. The community is considered to be part of a larger group of neighborhoods making up the city's “Southside”. The neighborhood was first established as early as the mid-1800s when the Poughkeepsie Eagle Steamboat Line created stops along the riverbanks. A single neighborhood road in the area, known as Springside Avenue, is one of the last remaining traces of the original steamboat stops, and is listed in the National Register of Historic Places. Eventually Springside was home to several factories, including the Dutchess Lace Mills in 1865, which closed in 1945. Today, the Springside neighborhood is home to a largely diverse population of both families and local business owners. Residents enjoy convenient access to local stores, restaurants, and recreational areas including the waterfront walkway where one may take in breathtaking views of the Hudson River. Other attractions in the area include Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site, Four Brothers Double Drive-In and Mid-Hudson Children’s Museum. In recent years, Springside has experienced an influx of businesses and developers investing in the area to improve the quality of life and the value of homes in the area. The neighborhood has seen the construction of dozens of new homes and businesses, while keeping the same charm and history that has made it a primary residential choice in the city. Those looking to move to the Springside area should be aware of the water and sewage services provided by the Poughkeepsie City Water and Sewer Department, and any associated costs. Additionally, due to its proximity to the Hudson River, additional home and flood insurance may be required. Springside is a charming community that offers plenty for its residents. From local stores and recreation to the breathtaking views of the Hudson River, those moving to the area can be sure to find a unique and vibrant experience here.

Palasip Qaqqaa (also known as "mixed boiled meats" in English) is a traditional Inuit dish typically served on special occasions in the Circum-Arctic region. The dish consists of various meats, including caribou, seal, beluga and Arctic char, boiled in a mixture of water, salt and spices. The cuts of meat are arranged in the pot of water and cooked until the desired level of tenderness is achieved. Palasip Qaqqaa is typically served with special homemade bread called "Qajaq" and often accompanied by a variety of jams and fruit. The dish has been an important part of Inuit culture and tradition for centuries, and served, at times, as an important source of sustenance and nutrition in difficult years of food scarcity, when game and fish were scarce. Today, Palasip Qaqqaa is an integral part of many travel experiences in the Arctic, where hunters, fishermen and travelers often enjoy the dish when crossing the region. Many Inuit families still serve the dish for special occasions, usually for weddings and holidays. Furthermore, the dish is served in many restaurants across Canada and Alaska and provides a great opportunity for experiencing authentic Inuit cuisine. Due to its versatile nature and rich history, Palasip Qaqqaa is often used as an example of food sharing and traditional Inuit hospitality. It serves as a reminder of the hospitality and resilience of the Inuit people, who have managed to survive and thrive despite difficult environmental conditions and scarce resources. Palasip Qaqqaa is a unique example of cultural synchronism between Arctic cultures and a reminder of the importance of traditional knowledge and practices among Inuit communities. This dish is still very much alive within the Circum-Arctic region, representing a significant part of Inuit culture, history and identity.

The Vanishing Man is a 2003 mystery thriller novel written by Robert Goddard. It is the sixth installment of the Parker Pyne series and follows Parker Pyne, a retired civil servant who now acts as a private detective. The novel opens with an introduction to Herbert Maxford, a small-town optician who is terrified of thunderstorms. When a mysterious man claiming to be his brother asks Herbert to keep hold of a large sum of money for him, Herbert obliges. When he reneges on his promise, the mysterious man begins to haunt him. The police are unable to help him, so Herbert contacts Parker Pyne for assistance. Pyne begins an investigation and soon discovers that likely the mysterious man Herbert has been dealing with is a master of disguise. Pyne's investigation reveals that the man may be connected to any one of several crimes that took place years ago. However, before Pyne can prove his theory, the man disappears. Herbert is left terrified of thunderstorms and Pyne is forced to journey to a variety of countries in order to track down his quarry. Pyne eventually finds the man and learns the truth about the affair. The novel is notable for its clever mystery and twists, with both characters and plot devices being cleverly constructed. The novel holds a particular appeal for those who enjoy detective stories, however its strong characterization is what makes it truly stand out. The Vanishing Man is one of the best installments of the Parker Pyne series. It is a clever and engaging story that will keep readers guessing right until the end. With clever characters, mystery and engaging atmosphere, this novel is a must-read for all lovers of detective fiction.

Hocuspocus is a 1953 American drama-comedy film produced by 20th Century Fox, directed by Jules White, and starring Charles Ruggles. The screenplay was written by Charles Ruggles and Robert E. Kent. Hocuspocus is the story of Aaron Kiefer (Charles Ruggles), a prosperous carpenter who dreams of one day owning a house in the country. His dreams become reality when he finds an enchanted house up for sale for a nominal sum. However, when a group of mischievous witches move in next-door, Aaron discovers that he has inherited more than he bargained for. The witches, played by Lorna Gray, Cora Witherspoon, and Louise Beavers, cause chaos and upheaval for Aaron, his family, and the entire town. From sticky spells that make everything dangerously wet, to enchanting music that lures people to the witches' house and secrets that expose Aaron's hidden talents, the hapless householders face one magical problem after another. As the situation intensifies, Aaron is eventually forced to bargain with the witches and make a deal in order to save his family and return peace to the community. In the end, Aaron's resourcefulness and good-natured attitude win out and he is able to resolve the issue in a peaceful and mutually beneficial way. Hocuspocus is a classic example of early family films, and its themes of friendship and understanding endure to this day. As well as providing entertainment, the film teaches young viewers about the importance of kindness and compassion towards others, regardless of their differences. Hocuspocus received mostly positive reviews from critics, who praised the performances from Charles Ruggles and the female witch trio. It is still regarded as a significant work of its era, and is remembered fondly by generations of fans today.

Douglas James Saunders (born January 25, 1960) is a Canadian author, journalist, and media advisor. He is best known for his books Arrival City: The Final Migration and Its Transformations, The Myth of the Muslim Tide: Do Immigrants Threaten the West?, and Maximum Canada: Why 35 Million Canadians Are Not Enough. Born in Ottawa, Ontario, Saunders grew up on Montreal’s South Shore and studied at Queen’s University in Kingston, Ontario. He completed a B.A. in Economics and Political Science in 1983 and went on to receive an M.A. in International Relations from the University of Toronto in 1988. Saunders began his journalistic career in the late 1980s, when he was a reporter for the Financial Times in Paris and London. He then worked for the Globe and Mail for 12 years, first as a foreign correspondent in Europe and the Middle East, and then as an editor and columnist. In 2001, Saunders left the Globe and Mail to write Arrival City, a critically acclaimed examination of the worldwide urbanization of rural populations, especially in developing countries. The book was published in hardcover in Canada in 2010, and in paperback in the United Kingdom and United States in 2011. The book has since been translated into 10 languages and published in more than 20 countries. In 2012, Saunders wrote The Myth of the Muslim Tide, a criticism of arguments used to justify anti-immigration laws and policies in western countries. His latest book Maximum Canada was published in 2019 and takes a look at what it would mean to double the current population of Canada. Saunders is a frequent contributor to various media outlets, including the Wall Street Journal and The New York Times. He was also a consultant for the United Nations, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. He is currently a senior advisor to Canada’s Department of Global Affairs and is on the editorial board of the Toronto Star. Saunders has been awarded numerous prizes, including the 2017 Donner Prize for Public Policy Writing and the 2016 Freedom of Expression Award from PEN Canada. He was also listed in 2013 among the 35 most influential Canadians by The Huddle.

The Seoul Korea Temple (Korean: 대한민국 서울 템플) is a temple of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS Church) located in Seoul, South Korea. It is the second temple of the LDS Church to be built in South Korea, the first being the Korea Busan Mission Temple in Busan. The Seoul Korea Temple was announced on October 6, 2002, by the LDS Church. Construction was completed and the temple was dedicated on August 20, 2011, by LDS Church president Thomas S. Monson. The temple has a total floor area of 45,830 square feet (4,259.7 m2). The temple has become an important religious center in the South Korean capital. It is located in the Gangnam district of Seoul, and features six spires, symbolizing the six directions of the compass and light emanating from heaven. The temple grounds are beautifully kept, with manicured lawns, lush flowers and a pond, helping to create a serene atmosphere. Inside, visitors find a beautiful circular baptistry, important to members of the LDS Church as baptism is a key part of their faith. The Celestial Room, used for meditation and sermons, is decorated with a crystal chandelier to simulate the diversity of the lunar sky. The temple also features a permanent art gallery, which displays several pieces from South Korean history, as well as paintings from members of the LDS Church. Visitors to the temple are welcome during public tours throughout the week. LDS Church members wear modest clothing while in the temple and later receive a signature "temple recommend" card that allows them to perform religious ordinances and take part in special ceremonies. The Seoul Korea Temple has been featured in several South Korean films, including The Grand Journey and Kingdom on the Wind. It has also become a major tourist attraction in the Gangnam district and is part of a larger group of temples in the area. Church members come from all over the world to visit the temple and gain a deeper understanding of their faith. References: -LDS Church Announces Seoul Temple, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, Newsroom, October 6, 2002. -Seoul Korea Temple - LDS Church Temples, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, ChurchofJesusChrist.org. -Seoul Korea Temple - South Korea, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, ChurchofJesusChrist.org. -The Grand Journey, IMDb.com. -Kingdom on the Wind, IMDb.com.

Kero Kero Chime is an online collectible card platform developed by the online technology company Simon Solutions Ltd. and marketed by Tokyo-based publisher Shogakukan. The game was released in Japan on April 1, 2011, and in English in the United States on June 15, 2011. The game is free to play, but users can pay real money to buy virtual cards. Kero Kero Chime is an online digital card battling game, somewhat similar to collectible card games like Magic: The Gathering. The game uses a "fantasy battle" system that allows players to create their own avatar and face artificial opponents in card battles. Players can build a deck of cards to represent their virtual avatar and then use it to challenge opponents. Each card has unique abilities that can be used to defeat enemies. The game also has various levels with increasing difficulty based on a ranking system. Gameplay in Kero Kero Chime revolves around a battle system that allows players to confront their opponents with card decks. At the start of a battle, players draw cards from their deck to set up their virtual avatar's formation. During a fight, players can use various abilities provided by the cards in their deck. These abilities can be used to defeat opponents or gain advantages in battle. Kero Kero Chime also has a variety of features designed to help players enhance their decks and experience. These come in the form of incentives, such as special mission rewards and tournament rewards. The game also offers "raid events" that allow players to challenge large dungeons filled with giant monsters and powerful enemies. Defeating these monsters unlocks special rewards that can be used to further enhance a player's deck. The game has been well-received by gamers and critics alike, with many praising its unique gameplay and high-quality art. Kero Kero Chime has developed a dedicated fanbase and loyal players. It was one of the most popular free-to-play games on the Japanese market in 2011 and continues to be popular today. The game is currently available for PC, iOS and Android devices. Kero Kero Chime is an enjoyable and strategic game that has been well-received by gamers and critics alike. Its unique gameplay and high-quality art make it an engaging experience for gamers of all ages. With its many rewards and strategic gameplay, Kero Kero Chime makes for an enjoyable experience for both casual gamers and hardcore card-battling fans.

Julie Lescaut is a French television police drama series created by José Zysman, produced by Else Edelman and broadcast on TF1 from 1992 to 2002. The series stars Virginie Ledoyen as Commissioner Julie Lescaut, a police officer from the Brigade Criminelle (Criminal Investigation Division) of the French National Police. The series follows Commissioner Lescaut, an independent and strong female police officer, as she investigates and solves a variety of serious crimes (involving terrorism, organised crime, serial killers, drug traffickers, etc.). Despite being a police commissioner, Lescaut often works on cases undercover and is unafraid to take risks in order to catch the criminals. Throughout her investigations Lescaut relies on her team (Hauser and Geistlinger) and her lover (Alexandre), although the task force changes and evolves during the course of the show's run. As well as investigating cases, Lescaut is often confronted with personal drama and professional dilemmas. In particular, her estranged relationship with her daughter Nathalie (played by Virginie Ledoyen in her younger years) provides an ongoing plot line throughout the series. The series was popular in France, running for 10 series from 1992-2002 and gaining numerous awards. It was also a success in other countries such as Spain, Belgium, Canada and a number of other countries in Europe. The series spawned a film (Julie Lescaut: Le Secret) in 2005 as well as a spin-off series, Julie Lescaut - Division Homicides, which ran for four series between 2003-2007. In 2008, TF1 revived the franchise with Julie Lescaut: L'Héroïne, starring Nathalie Ségur-Cabanac as Lescaut's daughter, who had taken her mother's place as a police officer. The series ran for 4 seasons and was popular in France, selling to over 20 countries worldwide. This is the third version of the franchise, after the original and Julie Lescaut: Division Homicides. Lescaut is a multi-faceted female character, strong and independent, willing to work undercover and take risks to catch the criminals and solve serious crime. She is an iconic character in France and abroad, a symbol of female police force and of justice.

WDRB (sometimes referred to as WDRB-TV or WDRB 41) is a full-service television station in Louisville, Kentucky, broadcasting a local newscast, weather updates, and sports programs on digital channel 41 (UHF frequency 22) for the Louisville, Kentucky and Southern Indiana area. The station is affiliated with The WB Television Network and is owned by Block Communications, a telecommunications holding company located in Cincinnati, Ohio. WDRB first went on the air on August 15, 2001. Prior to being acquired by Block Communications, WDRB operated as an affiliate of the United Paramount Network from 2003 to 2006. Since August 1, 2006, WDRB has broadcast its digital signal on Channel 41, providing a 6-megawatt signal over a 35-mile coverage area. It also transmits through cable and satellite providers in the Louisville area. WDRB features 24 hour programming including syndicated programming such as True Crime Files and CSI, network news and entertainment programming including The Ellen DeGeneres Show, and local news, weather and sports. The station covers local, national and international news and has a wide variety of sports programming including University of Louisville, Louisville Bats, Louisville City FC, and other local high school, college and professional sports. The news and sports departments have been honored with Emmy Award nominations. WDRB airs the Fox network's primetime programming, and is the only television station in the Louisville DMA (Designated Market Area) to have gained the rights to air most of the NFL Sunday Ticket package from DirecTV in fall 2010, though WDRB does not air the Sunday Ticket games–they are simply offered via DirecTV to viewers in the Louisville DMA. In July 2013, WDRB and WHAS-TV launched The NOW Louisville, which provides live traffic, weather, news and other up-to-the-minute media updates framed within 30 minute intervals airing twice daily. Along with WDRB, WHAS-TV (ABC) and WAVE-TV (NBC) form the largest network of news teams in Kentucky and Southern Indiana. WDRB also offers streaming live newscasts on the internet on both the web and mobile platforms. In July 2017, WDRB was acquired by Block Communications, a media and communications holdings company, as part of its $105 million purchase of Ohio television stations, which included Louisville-based WDRB-TV. Block Communications also owns The Blade, a daily newspaper in Toledo, Ohio and the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. WDRB is known for its commitment to local programming, for its access to the Kentucky Derby and the Kentucky Oaks, and for its extensive coverage of sports in Louisville.

Jack Brownschidle (born March 12th, 1966) is an American businessman, investor, and philanthropist. He currently serves as the CEO and owner of Brownschidle Enterprises, a privately held investment company that owns a portfolio of diverse companies in several industries such as technology, healthcare, media, consumer products, real estate, and more. Brownschidle was born in Texas and raised by his single father, who taught him the fundamentals of investing. After graduating from college, he started managing money for some of his family members and quickly developed a shrewd eye for making lucrative investments. From there, his career in investing rapidly expanded, and he quickly became a highly respected businessman. In the late 1990s, Brownschidle started his career in philanthropy. He founded the Brownschidle Foundation, a nonprofit organization dedicated to providing opportunities for children and young adults in the developing world to reach their full potential through education and innovation. The foundation has donated millions of dollars to humanitarian aid in countries such as Ethiopia, Sudan, and Haiti. Brownschidle's professional portfolio extends beyond just business investments. As an active member of the arts community, he has served on the board of several major art organizations and galleries across the nation, and donated generously to major institutions such as the Art Institute of Chicago and the Dallas Museum of Art. In recent years, Brownschidle has become increasingly interested in politics, leading to his decision to run for public office. He ran for the United States Senate in the 2018 election, though he eventually lost the race. This didn't stop him from promoting his views, however, as he is still a vocal figure in debates about progressive policy and immigration reform. Overall, Brownschidle is one of the most visible and successful businessmen and philanthropists in the United States. His investments and philanthropy have earned him a reputation as a brilliant and generous investor and leader, and his work as a political activist has demonstrated his commitment to making the world a better place for the future.

Canım Hoca Mehmed Pasha (c. 1550-1620) was an Ottoman statesman and military commander who made a significant contribution to consolidating the Ottoman Empire in the late 16th century. He was heavily involved in Ottoman-Safavid conflicts of the period and was a key figure in the Battle of Chaldiran (1514-1517), the Ottoman victory over the Safavid forces of Shah Ismail I of Persia. Canım Hoca Mehmed Pasha was born in 1550 in Yenice, a village near Edremit in the Sanjak of Saruhan in the Ottoman Empire. His father was a deputy of the Sanjak of Saruhan and his mother was a member of a powerful tribal family. Little is known of his early life, but in 1582 he was appointed Governor (Sanjakbey) of Chios, the largest of the Dodecanese Islands in the Aegean Sea. In 1588, during the Ottoman-Safavid War (1577-1590), Canım Hoca Mehmed Pasha was named General of the Ottoman navy following the death of the previous General, Kusa-Chelebi. During this period, the Ottoman navy was used to blockade seaports of the Safavids and to launch raids into Persian territory. Under his command, Ottoman forces were able to gain control of the islands of Lemnos, Chios and Crete by 1591. In 1595 Canım Hoca Mehmed Pasha took part in the Battle of Chaldiran, a decisive Ottoman victory over the Safavid forces of Shah Ismail I of Persia which secured the Ottoman Empire’s control over much of the Middle East. During the battle he took command of the left wing of the Ottoman army and was praised for his courage in the face of a numerically superior Safavid force. Canım Hoca Mehmed Pasha continued to rise in the ranks of the Ottoman military and by 1604 he had been appointed Grand Vizier, the highest position in the Ottoman Empire at that time. He focused on consolidating the power of the Ottoman Empire and his reign marked the beginning of an era of stability in the region. Canım Hoca Mehmed Pasha was well respected for his administrative abilities and for his military skills, particularly his naval tactics. He died in 1620 in Istanbul, where a bridge and a street still bear his name today. He is remembered for his role in the consolidation of Ottoman power and was an influential figure in the history of the Ottoman Empire.

The City of Nedlands is a local government area in the western coastal suburbs of Perth, the capital city of Western Australia. It is named after Sir Frederick Nedders, an early settler and local entrepreneur. The City is bordered by the Swan River to the south, Melville to the east and Suburban Perth to the north. The City covers an area of 22 square kilometres and at the 2016 Census, had a population of 24,758. Nedlands was officially founded in 1898 upon being granted Local Government status, making it one of the oldest cities in Perth. The city is known for its affluent suburban atmosphere, with many historic buildings, as well as its universities, schools, parks and other leisure activities. The city is home to the University of Western Australia, which is situated on the banks of the Swan River. The university is an important research and education centre, and its main campus houses many world-class lecture theatre, library, and sporting, art and cultural facilities. It is also host to the annual international movie, television and music festival, Perth UWA Film Festival. Nedlands is home to several parks and reserves, including Lake Monger which is situated on the banks of the Swan River, and Nedlands Foreshore Park on the banks of the Deravell River. Additionally, the city is home to the much-loved King’s Park Botanical Gardens, the City’s largest park spanning over 400 hectares. It hosts a range of walking and cycling trails, as well as a number of events including the iconic Festival of Perth, which is held every December. Nedlands also has plenty of shopping, dining and entertainment options to offer its residents. The high-end Claremont Quarter Shopping Centre and Subion Shopping Centre are both within the City limits. The vibrant nightlife is answered for by the popular cafe and restaurant enclaves in the local area, notably the “Café Strip” on Hampden Road. Overall, Nedlands is an affluent, well-developed City, with plenty to keep its residents and visitors occupied. Its parks, universities, shopping and restaurant precincts, as well as its many leisure activities, make it an ideal place to live and visit.

SAFA Programme (Supporting Achievers of Future Aspirations) is a comprehensive government sponsored scheme launched by the Hon. Prime Minister of India Narendra Modi in August 2019. The program strives to provide holistic support to deserving individuals and families from weaker sections of the society through mentors supported by technology. This initiative is aimed at uplifting people from deprived backgrounds, enabling them to secure better education, employment opportunities and overall development of their lives. The main objective of the program is to provide support to the economically weak families so as to ensure the overall development of their children. The beneficiaries are provided access to quality education, vocational training and human resource development activities. The scheme also focuses on improving the health, nutrition and hygiene of the beneficiaries and their families. The scheme is implemented through different public and private agencies. The agencies involved in implementing the SAFA programme are the Ministry of Human Resource Development (MHRD), the Ministry of Women and Child Development (MWCD), the Department of Rural Development (DRD) and the Department of Minority Welfare (DMW). The programme provides a mentor for each beneficiary family. The mentor acts as a guide and advises the family members on different aspects of education, employment and other developmental initiatives. The mentor also follows up with the family on their progress. In order to benefit from the program the individuals and families must meet certain eligibility criteria. The criteria include annual income of less than Rs. 2 lakhs, possession of fewer than 3 acres of land, absence of an earning member in the family, female-headed family, and belonging to a Scheduled Caste/Scheduled Tribe. The program has been designed to cover all aspects of development. It provides guidance for academic excellence, access to quality training opportunities, digital literacy, schemes of loan and social support. The program positively impacts the lives of thousands of beneficiaries and their families. It is a step towards creating an equitable and secure future for those who are economically deprived. The successful implementation of the SAFA programme has been well acknowledged by the government and various communities.

G9 is the fourth studio album released by South Korean boy group BTS on May 18th, 2018. It is the fourth installment of their acclaimed "Love Yourself" series and contains eleven tracks, all produced by "Hitman" Bang. The album was promoted through the short film "Fake Love / Airplane pt.2" which was released in several countries including the United States, United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, Mexico and Latin America. It is the first album from the group to be released in the United Kingdom, making them the first K-Pop group to make this achievement. The lead single of the album is titled "Fake Love" which is a dark pop/trap song composed by Bang, Supreme Boi and RM. Musically, the song is characterized as a future bass, funk-pop and trap-pop track. The song achieved both critical and commercial acclaim, peaking at the number one spot of both the Billboard Hot 100 and Mainstream Top 40 charts, making BTS the first K-Pop group to achieve this feat. The album contains ten tracks and is comprised of various genres such as hip-hop, EDM, ballad and rock. Many of the album's songs such as "The Truth Untold", "134340", "Paradise", "Love Maze" and "Magic Shop" received positive reviews from critics, praising the group for their ability to blend genres and create a unique sound. Commercially, the album was a great success, peaking at number one on the Gaon Album and Billboard 200 charts, as well as 4 other countries and the iTunes albums charts for 65 countries. It also received multiple awards and became the first K-Pop album to receive a Gold Certification from the Recording Industry Association of America, making BTS the first Korean artist to receive this accolade. Overall, G9 is considered a great success for BTS and helped solidify their status as one of the most popular acts in K-pop, not just domestically but also internationally. The album was a commercial success, critically acclaimed and, most of all, an artistic triumph for the members of BTS.

La Roche-en-Ardenne Castle is a medieval castle located in the town of La Roche-en-Ardenne, in the Province of Luxembourg, Belgium. The castle is one of the most renowned and beautiful castles in the country, characterized by its typically medieval towers and walls. The exact date on which La Roche-en-Ardenne Castle was first built is unknown, though some sources estimate it to the 9th century, during Carolingian Empire rule. At first, it served as an initiative of local counts who depended on the town’s strategic position near the rivers Ourthe and Lomme. In the 11th century, the castle was seized by the count of Luxembourg and later, it passed on to the earls of Bouillon. In the 15th century, the castle was severely damaged during the Burgundian Wars, and during the 16th century, it was rebuilt. However, it was once again destroyed in 1677, when Louis XIV of France sent an army to take over the castle. It was then reconstructed yet again, this time in a more modern appearance, with a tower and two massive bastions. Another restoration was made in the 20th century. Today, the castle remains a beautiful attraction and is open for tours year round. Visitors can explore the castle and visit the old armory and chapel, built in the 13th century. Additional facilities such as a hotel, restaurant and shop are also available for visitors. The castle also hosts a number of cultural events throughout the year, including music festivals, plays, and other social gatherings. La Roche-en-Ardenne Castle is a beloved tourist spot, and is widely admired for its grandeur and history. It remains a reminder of the turbulent past of Belgium, and a testament to its perseverance and strength.

The Gold Souq (Arabic: سوق الذهب‎) is a market located in the Al Ras area of Deira, Dubai, United Arab Emirates. It serves as one of the main trading hubs for gold jewelry in the Middle East, and is a major tourist attraction. The souq is renowned for its wide array of gold jewelry, from 22-karat to 24-karat of various sizes and styles. A large portion of the gold is sourced from the local gold markets in Dubai, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. Gold merchants from Iran, India, Pakistan and Russia also stock their shops in the souq. In addition to gold, the souq is also home to a variety of jewelry stores offering precious stones, pearls, diamonds and other gems. Other businesses in the souq specialise in watches, fragrances and women’s clothing. The souq is easily accessible via the Dubai Metro’s Al Ras station. It is located between Al Ras and Al Rigga stations on the Red Line, four stops away from the Dubai International Financial Centre and six stops away from the Dubai Mall. Pedestrian access is available via the bridge connecting Al Ras Station with Fish Roundabout. The souq has grown significantly in the past twenty years, and its area has now expanded to cover around 3 million square meters. The souq attracts both local and international shoppers who come to look for unique pieces of jewelry and quality craftsmanship unique to the region. The souq is open from morning until late at night, and as with most souqs in the country, bargaining is expected. Prices of gold jewelry are also subject to fluctuations in the world gold market. For up-to-date pricing information, visitors are advised to check the prices at local jewelry shops in the area.

The Canandaigua Street Railroad was a former streetcar system that operated in the city of Canandaigua, New York between 1895 and 1929. It served to provide transportation to the suburbs and to the city center. The first streetcar of the Canandaigua Street Railroad was built in 1895, after plans to build the streetcar system were approved by the City Council in 1894. The system was initially built as a horse-drawn line and was the first such system in Ontario County. However, the line was soon converted to electric streetcars in 1902. The route of the Canandaigua Street Railroad ran from a station located at the corner of Main Street and Brighton Avenue in the city center and then down West Avenue, South Avenue, and East Avenue before terminating at the Canandaigua junction station. This route intermediate stops in the neighborhoods of South Avenue, West Avenue, and East Avenue. In the early days of the streetcar system, fares were very low, costing only five cents for a ride. This contributed to the popularity of the system and it quickly became one of the most important means of transportation in the town.In its later years of operation, the company also operated a fleet of buses which ran on a superseded streetcar route.
