The service provided by the Canandaigua Street Railroad was quickly becoming more and more obsolete with the development of the automobile and the rise of alternative public transportation. By the end of the 1920s, the system was struggling to stay in operation and it eventually ceased operations in 1929. Today, the former streetcar line is no longer visible; however, some of the original tracks can still be seen in the historic neighborhoods of West Avenue, South Avenue, and East Avenue. The Canandaigua Street Railroad was an important part of the town's history. It provided a reliable and affordable means of transportation to the citizens of Canandaigua, enabling them to move around the town more freely and conveniently. Although it is no longer in operation, its legacy can still be seen around the town.

"I Know Who Holds Tomorrow" is a beloved hymn with words and music composed by Ira Stanphill. Written in 1950, the hymn has become a staple in Christian faith over the years, having been performed and recorded by country and gospel musicians alike. The title of the hymn is derived from a line in the chorus, “I don’t know about tomorrow, I just live from day to day, but I know who holds tomorrow and I know He will show the way.” This and the subsequent lines in the chorus emphasize the sentiment of trust in God’s plan and faith in His future guidance. The lyrical content of the song vividly portrays the hope and comfort of the believer in the midst of a chaotic and unpredictable world. The first verse starts by painting a picture of a troubled, weary soul who is seeking solace and help from the Lord. The following two verses serve to reiterate the assurance of trusting in God and leaning on His promises through prayer, providing an uplifting reminder of divine guidance. The popularity of “I Know Who Holds Tomorrow” has made it a staple Christian hymn. It has been covered and performed by numerous musicians, including Alison Krauss, Bill Monroe, and Elvis Presley. Alison Krauss’s cover of the hymn was even featured in the 2014 movie, Heaven is for Real. The global revelation of this song has caused it to touch the lives of many people across different religions, generations, and creeds, making it an indelible part of modern Christian culture. With its timeless message of unwavering faith and strength in the midst of suffering, “I Know Who Holds Tomorrow” is sure to inspire many more souls for many years to come.

Parr, St Helens is an area of St Helens, Merseyside, England. Located in the northwest of St Helens, it is bordered by the wide expanse of Carr Mill Dam, to the south and part of the Mersey Valley Regional Park. The area in general is made up of smallto-medium sized post-war housing estates and terraces of houses, a large park and the environs of the dam, consisting of small fields and woods. Parr has a well-maintained and popular walkway that loops around the lake and in turn has its own railway station, which serves the nearby locations of Edge Hill and Rainford. The Parr area contains the A57 St Helens Linkway, which stretches from the area in the direction of the neighbouring towns of Huyton, Prescot, and Rainhill. The wider St Helens area was once well connected by passenger rail, however, today only two lines of the old railway network remain operational, the Kirkby Line and the St Helens Loop Line. The Fiddlers Ferry power station is located nearby, situated to the east of Parr which can be seen for miles around. The power station was opened in 1972 and is one of the largest coal-fired power stations in Britain, capable of powering up to 2.3million households. Parr is largely residential and therefore lacks many amenities of its own, however, the neighbouring towns of St Helens, Rainford and Whiston have a number of supermarkets, convenience stores, pubs and restaurants. Parr is served by St Helens North railway station, which causes the area to have easy access to the neighbouring locations of Huyton, Kirkby, Rainford and Rainhill. Parr is an area of high residential density with most households containing either a family or a single occupant. It has been suggested that the area is suffering from deprivation judged by the wide range of income it generates and the housing quality within the area.

Mantis is a genus of the family mantidae containing over 2,400 species of large predatory insects. Mantis belong to a large group of insects within the order Mantodea, typically characterized by a specialized head, legs adapted for gripping prey, segmented body, and remarkable praying behavior. The suborder Mantodea is comprised of many different genera and species, with Mantidae - the mantis family - counting for approximately 80% of all mantodean species. Mantises are widespread and can be found in temperate and tropical habitats around the world. Most species of mantis have a three-stage lifecycle, consisting of egg, nymph and adult stages. Females typically have a mottled brown coloration while males are usually lighter colored with longer and more active wings. During mating, the male typically performs a "dance" to entice the female, and the male will often perform acrobatics including somersaults to evade the female's grasp. Mantoideans exhibit a variety of behaviors, including the fascinating praying behavior in which they raise their front legs to appear as if they are in prayer. Their front legs are extremely sensitive and are used to detect nearby prey such as small flies, crickets and other small invertebrates. Thesis are both beneficial and pest species, as they generally feed on other insects. They have been introduced to many areas as a form of natural pest control, and are sometimes used in displays in gardens and zoos. Some species, such as the African Mantis, have become an invasive species in many parts of the world. In addition to its use as a form of pest control, Mantis are also popular as hobbyists. They are generally easy to keep and make an interesting addition to an insect collection. There are even specialized websites devoted to the keeping of mantids and many species of mantis have been bred in captivity. The most commonly available species of mantis are the Chinese Mantis and the European Mantis. They are popular due to their large size, attractive colors, and ease of care. Mantis can make a great addition to any insect enthusiast’s collection and provide a fascinating view into the world of hunting insects. They are a great way to learn about their behavior while also helping provide natural pest control.

Outland (Spear of Destiny album) is the fourth studio album by British post-punk group Spear of Destiny, released in October 1985 by 10 Records. Based on a concept by vocalist and songwriter Kirk Brandon, the album was recorded in six weeks in the summer of 1985 and produced by Steve Hillage. Outland is considered one of Spear of Destiny's most successful albums, garnering critical praise and commercial success. It reached number 13 in the United Kingdom Albums Chart, the most successful chart position of the band's career. Outland yielded two successful singles: "The Wheel" and "Never Take Me Alive". Writing Honest Tune magazine, Leanne Harding described Outland as "the most classic example of SOD’s expression of optimism buried beneath gritty realism." The album opened with the radio-friendly "The Wheel", a song initially intended to be included on the previous album, One Eyed Jacks. The lyrics to "The Wheel" were written by Brandon and Lawrence O'Neill, and was accompanied by a promotional film released in 1985. The follow-up single to "The Wheel" was the heavy rock single "Never Take Me Alive." Written solely by Brandon, "Never Take Me Alive" draws its lyrics from a darker period in Brandon's life, the struggle with the corporate music machine and his alcoholism. Outland continued with a range of cohesive and cuttingly lyrics themes, such as the environment ("Message From the Bunker"), religion ("Love On the Danger Line"), war ("In the Cold Wind We Smile") and reality ("The Hacker"). A live version of the single "The Wheel" was included as a bonus track at the end of Outland, recorded at The Riviera in Chicago. Outland is considered Spear of Destiny's most successful and best album. Since its release, the album has been regarded as one of the best 1980s post-punk albums. The album was remastered in 2020 and included as part of a limited edition box set.

Primate experiments at Columbia University are a form of animal testing done by team at the college's College of Physicians and Surgeons. These tests involve the captive use of monkeys, and many other non-human primates, to study elucidate, and observe the behavior of the animals and its use in the fields of psychology and neuroscience. The experiments have been conducted since the late 1940s and they have provided valuable insights into the behavior of primates and their evolution, as well as the evolution of species as a whole. In recent years, due to public concern and the effort of animal protection campaigners and laboratory animal advocacy, there has been increased focus and scrutiny on animal use in medical research and by Columbia University specifically. The majority of the primate experiments at Columbia University are aimed at understanding how different drugs affect the behavior of primates and their potential use in treating humans. Many studies involve using mouth-swabbing or intravenous injections of various drugs, including hallucinogenic drugs and other psychotropic drugs, to observe how primates react to the effects of these drugs. Other more traditional experiments focus on studying the physical effects of drugs on the animals, such as the possible effects of pain killers or cancer-causing agents, or studying the effects of radiation on the primates. Columbia's primate research center has had difficulty in recent years due to funding issues and difficulty in hiring knowledgeable staff to conduct the experiments. Despite this, the university has committed itself to continue the experiments, citing the importance of the research that it produces. The results of Columbia's experiments have been credited in almost all areas of basic science, including the development of new drugs, psychological theories, neuroscience, and cognitive models. In addition to the important research done at Columbia University, the university is also highly dedicated to the humane treatment of its study animals. The research center staff is comprised of veterinarians and qualified animal technicians who are trained to identify and provide the best possible environment for the animals. Also, in order to minimize the impact of the experiments on the animals, the number of individuals used in each experiment is kept to a minimum. Despite the importance of the research conducted by Columbia University and its commitment to animal welfare, the school has been the target of animal rights activism in recent years. This opposition has been met with a variety of responses from the university and some of its teachers and research staff, including an open debate on the issue of animal testing and a commitment to minimize harm to the animals through proper practices. Overall, the primate experiments conducted at Columbia University continue to provide new and valuable insights into the fields of psychology, neuroscience, and animal behavior. Despite opposition from certain groups, the school and its staff remain committed to conducting the experiments in a safe, humane, and ethical manner.

A hollow fiber bioreactor (HFB) is a type of bioreactor primarily used in biopharmaceutical and biotechnology industries. It is a system that facilitates the large-scale production of microbial or cell cultures. The primary components of a HFB are hollow fiber membranes that are used to create a sterile environment to grow the culture. The membranes act as a barrier to the outside environment, allowing for efficient filtration of impurities out of the culture. They also help to maintain a favorable environment for efficient growth of the culture. A HFB consists of a cylindrical container divided into two chambers; the exterior and interior chambers. During operation, the exterior chamber is filled with growth medium, and the interior chamber is filled with culture. A pump circulates the medium and culture between the two chambers. Nutrients are constantly added to the growth medium and the cell culture is provided with oxygen for efficient growth. Once the cells are cultured, they can be harvested and used for further applications. The advantage of a HFB is that the waste product of the cells can be removed easily, making it useful in large-scale production. Additionally, a HFB can achieve large-scale production by increasing the population density of the cell culture on the membrane. While most of the HFBs are single layered, some bioreactors combine various layers of hollow fibers. This type of bioreactor is known as a ‘deceptively complex’ system and is used for more specialized processes such as genomic sequencing or gene expression studies. The various layers of fibers provide for precise control over the cell culture environment and allow for different rates of production. Hollow fiber bioreactors are widely used in the biopharmaceutical and biotechnology industries due to their high speed of production, their low energy consumption, and their ability to achieve a high concentration of cells in the culture. The highly efficient filtration provided by the use of hollow fiber membranes, as well as the possibility of precise control over the environment, makes the HFB ideal for various industrial applications.

Chaim Gross (1904-1991) was a renowned Austrian-American sculptor and painter best known for his realist figurative works. He was born to a Hassidic family in the city of Wolmirt in the former Austro-Hungarian Empire. Gross studied at the Vienna Academy of Fine Art and the National Academy of Design in New York, USA. In 1925, he immigrated to the United States and settled in New York where he established a studio for carving and sculpture. He would take his craft to a higher level at the Parsons School of Design, where he taught for more than fifty years. He was instrumental in introducing direct carving and abstraction to American sculpture. His work in modern figurative sculpture is highly reputable, and it has influenced many of his contemporaries and younger artists. Gross specialized in wood, stone, and bronze sculptures. He used a traditional European technique of direct carving and abstention. His woodcarvings often depicted Biblical stories. His stone sculptures portrayed a humanistic vision of Jewish folk art, with his bronze works featuring a blend of emotion, whimsy, and symbolism. Gross was a founding member of the Sculptors Guild in 1937, and he was the President of the National Academy of Design in 1955-56. He was also a member of the National Institute of Arts and Letters and was awarded the International Sculpture Center’s Lifetime Achievement Award. Gross held exhibitions in New York galleries as well as at prominent museums both nationally and abroad, such as the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Corcoran Gallery of Art, the sculptors guild and the National Academy Galleries. Among his most renowned works are Biblical reliefs, the bronze sculpture, “The Visionary,” and a ceramic sculpture. “Conversation Piece,” a painting by Gross, is featured in the White House’s art collection. Gross received major recognition for his works, including awards from the National Institute of Arts and Letters and the National Academy of Design. He also received a board of regent’s citation from the Smithsonian Institution. Gross passed away in 1991 at the age of 87, leaving behind a legacy of creativity and a large body of work.

Fuka Kakimoto is a Japanese competitive figure skater. She is the 2018-2019 Grand Prix Final bronze medalist and a two-time Japanese national champion. In 2020, she qualified to the World Figure Skating Championships. Kakimoto began skating as a child in 2003, and began competing as a junior skater in 2013. In her debut season, she placed 6th in the Japan Novice Championships. She continued to have success in the junior ranks, placing 7th in the 2014-2015 Japan Junior Figure Skating Championships. Kakimoto debuted in the senior ranks in the 2015-2016 season, winning the Japan Junior Figure Skating Championships silver medal and placing 8th in the Japan Figure Skating Championships. She steadily improved, placing 5th and 6th at competitions in the Japanese Nationals and Grand Prix of Figure Skating in the following two seasons, respectively. Kakimoto had her breakthrough season in the 2018-2019 season, winning the bronze medal at the Grand Prix of Figure Skating Final and being crowned the Japanese national champion. The historic result secured her an invitation to the 2019 World Figure Skating Championships, where she placed 8th. In 2020, Kakimoto performed well during the 2020-2021 figure skating season, topping the scoreboard at the Grand Prix of Figure Skating in October and becoming a two-time Japanese National Champion. She went on to finish in 6th place at the 2021 World Figure Skating Championships, becoming the first Japanese female skater to medal in the Grand Prix Final and place in the top six of the Worlds in the same season. Kakimoto has achieved all of these accomplishments amidst adversity, having to undergo ACL surgery in 2020. She is considered one of Japan's top female skaters and is an inspiration for aspiring skaters and athletes of all levels.

Bitch, Don’t Let Me Die! is an anthem of resilience, resistance and solidarity that was created in response to the call for Black Lives Matter and other racial justice movements around the United States. The song, written and performed by Rahbi and featured artist JohnBoy, was released on July 4, 2020 in the wake of national protests and outcry of racial injustice sparked by the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Yalonda Johnson-Gutierrez, also known as Rahbi, reported that the emotional and passionate song was created as a cry out for help and support for those who were hurting in response to the ongoing crisis surrounding police brutality and systemic racism across America. The song was created in collaboration between Atlanta-based artist Rahbi and American hip hop recording artist and storyteller, JohnBoy. The lyrics of the song provide a candid look into the escalating urgency of the Black Lives Matter movement and its intent to uplift Black and Brown individuals in the United States. JohnBoy and Rahbi’s song blends R&B, hip-hop and soul elements, creating a powerful and moving musical accompaniment to the strength and resilience of justice-seeking protestors in the nation’s streets. The two artists sought to use their platform to spread a message of unity, love and inclusivity by staying true to their craft and delivering honest soundscapes. The song has since had support from press outlets such as NBC’s The Grio and The Shadow League, which praised the tune for its “message-driven lyrics and strong emphasis on positivity.” Since its release, the song has gained over 70,000 streams and millions of impressions as it continues to spread throughout streaming platforms. As JohnBoy and Rahbi continue to spread their message of love, justice and solidarity, their mission will ring louder than ever in their anthem, "Bitch, Don’t Let Me Die!"

R. Thyagarajan (1945-present) is an Indian film director, writer, and producer who has worked in the Tamil film industry. He has directed more than fifty movies and has also produced more than fifteen movies in his career over the last four decades. He has also penned the story, screenplay, and dialogues for most of the movies he has directed. His early career began with the hugely successful 1975 movie Rotti, which catapulted him to the top ranks of Tamil directors. Also known as Thiyagarajab, R. Thyagarajan was born in 1945 in the former kingdom of Pudukkottai in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu. He began his film career in 1973 as a dialogue and story writer for the Tamil movie Pudhiya Bharatham. This was followed by writing and producing the blockbuster, Rotti in 1975. The movie was so successful that it helped launch R. Thyagarajan as one of Tamil cinema’s’ most successful directors. He is most known for his comedy and action films, most notably Thozhilali (1984), Thanga Gopuram (1985), Deva (1995), and Kizhaku Seemayile (1996). He has collaborated with many renowned writers, actors, and directors throughout his career such as A. R. Rahman, Ilaiyaraaja, and Prabhu Deva. R. Thyagarajan has had considerable success working in the Tamil film industry and is credited with introducing several new actors and technicians to the industry. He also founded his own production house, SRV (Srushti Enterprises), in 1990. Three of his productions, Gandharvam (1993), Seeman (1997), and Villu (2009) were remade in other languages. He has also won multiple awards throughout his career, including the Cinema Express Award for Best Director (Thillaanaa Mohanambal, 1968) and the Filmfare Award for Best Director – Tamil (Deva, 1995). Throughout his career, R. Thyagarajan has steadily redefined Tamil cinema with his distinctive style and campy vision. He is remembered fondly by fans and critics alike as an iconic and influential figure in the Tamil film industry.

Geylang Bahru MRT station is a Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) station in central Singapore, located at the intersection of Geylang Bahru Road and Upper Paya Lebar Road, along the Downtown Line. Geylang Bahru MRT station is an underground station, serving between the residential areas of Bendemeer, Kallang Bahru and Redhill. The station was opened in 2017. The Geylang Bahru MRT station is the eastern terminus of the Downtown Line 3 (DTL3). It links commuters from the western area of Singapore to other parts of the city, including Toa Payoh and the Central Business District (CBD). As the eastern terminus, the Geylang Bahru MRT station serves as an important interchange station for commuters travelling on DTL3. The station provides commuters with a wide range of amenities and facilities, including escalators, lifts, tactile paving, ample seating and lighting, as well as wayfinding signs. There are also ticket vending machines, open conditions and barrier-free access at the station. Retail outlets, food facilities, and ATMs are located around the station, providing convenience to commuters. The area around the Geylang Bahru MRT station is home to a variety of shopping, food and entertainment venues, such as Kallang Leisure Park, City Square Mall, Kallang Wave Mall and other nearby shopping malls. It is also situated near several parks, such as Geylang Park and Boon Keng Park, as well as numerous places of worship, including a mosque and a church. The Geylang Bahru MRT station is served by the Downtown Line 3 and the Eastern Region Line of the Singapore MRT network. The station is a 5-minute walk from the nearest bus interchange, which provides access to destinations all over Singapore. On-site parking is available for passengers travelling to and from the station. Geylang Bahru MRT station is part of the DTL 3 extension, which seeks to improve connectivity along the existing rail network. The station is also part of the Government’s plans to create a more integrated transport network, by improving connectivity and accessibility to other public transport nodes. The station is expected to benefit approximately 58,000 households in the area, providing accessibility to amenities and other destinations. The station is one of the most used in the network and is considered a key transport hub in Singapore. Geylang Bahru MRT station is a significant part of Singapore’s transport infrastructure, providing convenient access to a range of locations, as well as providing commuters with an easy and convenient way to travel around the city.

The GNU Compiler Collection (GCC) is a set of programming compilers mainly developed to support various programming languages on Unix-like operating systems. It is a free, open-source compiler collection available under the GNU General Public License (GPL). GCC is used to compile C, C++, Objective-C, Fortran, Ada, Go, and D programming languages. GCC was originally written for the Unix-like operating system, but it can currently be used on a range of other platforms including many embedded systems. Its purpose is to provide a fully functional, free compiler suite that can be used for developing both kernel and user-space software applications. GCC was first released in 1987 by Richard Stallman's Free Software Foundation. Initially, it was developed as part of the GNU project, with the objective of creating a completely free operating system. However, its application has surpassed initial expectations, and it is now the default compiler on many Unix and Unix-like systems. In addition to C, C++ and Fortran compilers, GCC also contains additional languages such as Objective-C, Ada, Go, and D. It also contains libraries for other languages, such as C++ Standard Template Library, and has ports for several architectures. As of 2021, GCC is considered to be the most used C and C++ compiler for many reasons, including its reliability, portability, and support for multiple processors. The compiler suite also provides optimizations which can improve the execution speed of code written in C, C++, Fortran, and other supported languages. GCC has a modular approach making it easy to modify or extend its functionality. This includes independently developed third-party packages like OpenMP, which can provide support for shared memory multiprocessors and other advanced features. GCC is considered to be instrumental in the advancement of free software and the open source movement, providing an essential toolset for the development of many widely used Linux distributions, such as Ubuntu, Fedora, and Red Hat Enterprise Linux. Developers of the GNU project are likely to continue to maintain and enhance the functionality of GCC as more programming languages are invented. The GNU Compiler Collection is an essential tool for Unix-based development, and it is recognized as a major contribution to the open source software movement. Its robust set of compilers, libraries, and optimization engines make it a valuable choice for a variety of applications. The fact that GCC is open-source and free make it the preferred choice for many developers.

The 2008 City of Ipswich 400 (also known as the 2008 Ipswich City of 400) was held on 28-29 June 2008 at Queensland Raceway near Ipswich in Queensland, Australia. It was the sixth and penultimate round of the 2008 V8 Supercar Championship Series. The weekend saw the fourteenth round for the Fujitsu V8 Supercars, which was run over two days, the first being a 350km race and the second a 200km race. In the qualifying for Race 9, Mark Winterbottom claimed his third pole position of the year with a 1:10.2818. He was followed by Craig Lowndes, Rick Kelly, Will Davison and David Reynolds. Race 9 went ahead under clear skies, but with tricky conditions, which saw Winterbottom fall backwards in the field. It was ultimately won by Steven Johnson, who held off Jamie Whincup, who finished just 0.1780 off the pace. James Courtney, watching on with championship contender Rick Kelly, completed the podium. Race 10 was a much tighter affair, with Craig Lowndes winning an incredibly close finish. He held off Triple 8 Racing teammate Jamie Whincup by only 0.0567, while Fabian Coulthard rounded out the podium in third place. The weekend ended with Craig Lowndes only three points off championship leader Rick Kelly, but Winterbottom graduating from 5th to 3rd in the points standings. The City of Ipswich 400 was the penultimate round of the 2008 V8 Supercars Championship Series and served as an exciting prelude to the season finale at Phillip Island.

Don't Be Tardy is an American reality television show that premiered on Bravo on April 26, 2012. The series is a spin-off of The Real Housewives of Atlanta, starring Kim Zolciak and family. Originally titled "Don't Be Tardy for the Party," the series was first announced in April 2012, with the series premiering on Bravo in April 2012. Don't Be Tardy follows the daily exploits of Kim and her husband Kroy Biermann, an NFL free agent, and their blended family of six children. The first season focuses heavily on Kim's wedding and the planning of her dream home in Roswell, Georgia, as Kim has to juggle motherhood, her business endeavors, and her personal life. Subsequent seasons of Don't Be Tardy continue to explore Kim's life, and the lives of her family, as the family moves into their new house and works to keep their family life in balance. In season three, the Biermann family moves into a new home, living in both Roswell and Atlanta. The season chronicles their move and transition into the new home, family life, and Kim's business ventures. In season four, Kim's daughter, Brielle Biermann, begins to make her transition as a celebrity and Kim focuses on expanding her business ventures into new lifestyle brand. In season five, Kim and Kroy take a big step and buy a second home in Atlanta. In addition, Ariana and Brielle both experience major life changes as they move away from their parents' home and become independent women. Season six will premiere on April 23, 2019. Since its premiere, Don't Be Tardy has received mostly positive reviews from critics. It has also been praised for presenting an honest take on parenting and family that viewers can relate to. Don't Be Tardy has become one of Bravo's most popular and successful realities shows, with many viewers tuning in to follow the Biermanns' lives. The show has also spawned two spin-off series, Don't Be Tardy After Show, which aired on hayu, and Kim Zolciak: Don't Be Tardy, which aired on Bravo. Despite this success, Don't Be Tardy was canceled after season six.

Glenn R. Conrad is an American historian, biographer, and author of several books about people and places in the American South. He was born in White Castle, Louisiana and grew up in nearby Opelousas. He is a graduate of the University of Southwestern Louisiana and earned his PhD in History from Tulane University in 1976. Conrad has written and edited numerous books about the people and history of Louisiana, and the American South generally. While his published works include numerous books about well-known figures—including Sam Houston, E. D. Hirsch, Huey P. Long, and others—he is best known for his multivolume books about two other important historical figures: Robert Moore Conrad and P W. Carleton Conway. He is the author of the Robert Moore Conrad: A Southern Louisiana Biography, which won various awards including Louisiana Endowment for the Humanities Book of the Year in 1985. He also edited volumes two and three of that series, and two volumes concerning P W. Carleton Conway, who was an early advocate of land ownership and a leader in the establishment of the Orleans Parish Education Board in 1882. Other work of Conrad's include In Defense of the Republic: Robert Moore Conrad, White Knight of the Confederacy, an extensive look at the life and works of Robert Moore Conrad, and The Architecture of the French Quarter, which explores the French cultural influences on 19th century buildings in New Orleans. Conrad has gained recognition as a respected historian and biographer and has been honored by numerous organizations, including the Louisian Historical Association, the American Association for State and Local History, and the Smithsonian Institute. In 2002, he received an honorary doctorate from White Castle High School and the Grand Coteau town council. Conrad is an active member of the National Council for Public History, the History Department of the University of Southwestern Louisiana, and the Claude Laval Center at Tulane University. He has lectured at numerous institutions and conventions and remains deeply invested in the history of the American South.

Hispanics and Latinos in New York comprise a large and diverse demographic that has grown considerably since the late 20th century. As of 2018, 29.6% of New York State's population identified as Hispanic or Latino. This includes individuals of various ancestries, including Mexican, Puerto Rican, Dominican, and Cuban. Moreover, New York City itself is home to 2.1 million Hispanic or Latino residents, making up 28.6% of its population. The Hispanic population has had a significant presence in New York since at least the mid-19th century. This includes long-established communities of Sephardic Jews in the Lower East Side and various immigrants from what is today Latin America. Through the 20th century, the Hispanic population in New York grew appreciably, as many newcomers arrived from Latin America in search of work. This was especially true after the 1965 Hart-Celler Immigration Act. Since then, the Hispanic population in New York has seen tremendous growth, particularly in places like The Bronx, where 48.5% of the population is Hispanic or Latino. Of the Hispanics and Latinos living in New York, most are of Mexican, Puerto Rican, Dominican, and Cuban ancestries. Mexican-American communities are mostly concentrated in areas like Long Island, The Bronx, and Westchester County. Meanwhile, Puerto Ricans, the largest Hispanic demographic, mostly reside in New York City. As a whole, the Hispanic and Latino population is young, with a median age of 28.3 years old, lower than the state's average. Hispanics and Latinos in New York have had a significant influence on the state's culture and economy. Many of the state's large businesses, especially in the retail and hospitality industries, rely heavily on Hispanic or Latino labor. Moreover, Hispanic-American and Latino-American entrepreneurs have had a significant impact on the state's business landscape, especially in the food and fashion sectors. The Hispanic and Latino population in New York has experienced some challenges. Despite contributions that have shaped the culture and economy of the state, Hispanics and Latinos in New York continue to face pressing issues, such as poverty and lack of access to health care and education. As such, organizations in New York, such as the New York Immigration Coalition, are advocating for greater inclusion and resources for the Hispanic and Latino population. References - American Fact Finder. (2018). Hispanic or Latino. Retrieved from https://factfinder.census.gov/faces/nav/jsf/pages/community_facts.xhtml - City Data. (2021). New York: Percentage of Hispanics. Retrieved from https://www.city-data.com/states/New-York-Demographics.html - New York Immigration Coalition. (n.d.). About Us. Retrieved from https://www.nyic.org/about-us/

Morris Swadesh (1909–1967) was a noted linguist, lexicologist, and anthropologist, who is best remembered for his theoretical and methodological contributions to the field of linguistics. He is widely recognized as the founder of glottochronology, a technique used to estimate the age of related languages. He is also well known for his development of basic word lists used to compare languages and track language divergence. Swadesh was born in the United States, in the now defunct town of Schoenmaker in Wisconsin. He completed his undergraduate studies at the University of Wisconsin, Madison in 1933, and completed his PhD in linguistics from the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia in 1939. He was first appointed to the Institute for the Study of Man in 1940, where he eventually became the director of research. Swadesh's work pushed forward the field of historical linguistics. He developed the Swadesh List, or the 200 Basic Word List, as a method to compare related languages. Swadesh proposed that languages which shared more words were closer related and had diverged more recently. He also developed the glottochronology method, which allowed linguists to estimate the age of related languages by comparing the percentage of word retention over time. Swadesh also studied dialects and movements of American Indian peoples, particularly in the Great Plains areas. He studied the linguistic aspects of a number of American Indian tribes, gathering significant amounts of information on their languages, which provided an important contribution to Native American language studies. He also published important works on Proto-Iroquoian and Proto-Algonquian, as well as a number of other Algonquian and Iroquoian languages. Swadesh was a prolific writer, publishing a number of monographs and articles on a variety of theses in Native American language studies. He wrote on topics ranging from studies on Indian languages, specifically those from the Great Plains, to methods for the analysis of basic vocabulary and language divergence. He was also involved in formulating a number of language and lexicological studies for the International Institute of Comparative Linguistics. Awards and honors Swadesh received in recognition of his work include Fellow of the Royal Society of Canada, Fellow of the Linguistic Society of America, honorary degrees from the University of Zurich, and Corresponding Member of the Institute National des Sciences et des Arts in Paris. Throughout his life, Swadesh was respected not only for the quality of his work but also for his approachability and sociability. He was well liked by his students and colleagues alike, and was believed to have served as a mentor and an inspiration to them. He died in 1967 of an aneurysm. In his honor, the Morris Swadesh Award for Achievement in Native American Linguistics was established in 1998. The award is funded by the Endangered Language Fund and is sponsored by the University of Pennsylvania, where Swadesh had been a professor and researcher. Swadesh's importance to the fields of linguistics and lexicology remain widely relevant and celebrated to this day. His contribution to the study of language remains a testament to one of the greatest minds in the field.

James Hodge Codding (October 18, 1869 - April 16, 1960) was an American minister who was ordained in the Presbyterian Church in 1892 and the most renowned Melanesian missionary. He was born in Verona, New York, and graduated from Hobart College in 1891. After traveling and teaching in the Melanesian Archipelago, he became superintendent and director of the London Missionary Society's South Seas evangelistic enterprise in 1902. He is credited with establishing the foundation for one of the largest and most successful missions in that region. Codding was sent to the South Seas by the London Missionary Society in 1895, where he spent the rest of his life working to bring the Gospel to the heathen over an immense range of islands known as Melanesia. During the span of his ministry in the region he planted over 160 churches and ordained 430 native pastors. He recorded more than one thousand names on his family register. The custom of head-hunting, common among the islanders at the time of Codding's arrival, was replaced by Christian worship services during his time there. He also popularized the phrase "sons of Solomon", which became the nickname of the islanders. In recognition of his missionary spirit, Codding was awarded an honorary doctorate in divinity by the University of Edinburgh in 1926 and the Order of the British Empire in 1928. In addition to his Christian message, Codding was a great social reformer and wrote numerous books and articles on Melanesian society. He wrote largely of his trials and tribulations as a missionary and his experiences in the "island world" as a form of cultural documentation. His works include: "Things Seen in the South Seas" and "Light in the Islands". Codding returned to California shortly before his death and is interred in the Forest Lawn Cemetery in Glendale. He had been a lifelong friend of the Roosevelt family, who attended his funeral. After his death, his widow, Ethel, hired a sculptor to create a bronze statue of Codding in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park. Codding is remembered today for his pioneering work in the South Seas. He helped to bring the Gospel to the regions of the Pacific islands, establishing educational and medical facilities, building churches and helping to reform island culture. His impact on the region can still be seen today in the islanders’ reverence for Christianity and the deep religious faith they practice. Codding will always be remembered as a great missionary, whose life and work left an indelible mark in the islands he visited.

Albert Burditt (1865–1940) was an American businessman and the founder of Burditt Corporation, an early industrial company which was a major supplier of rubber products for the U.S. Government in the early 20th century. Albert was born in 1865 in Pennsylvania. He received his early education in his native state and from an early age, he demonstrated an aptitude for business. At the age of sixteen, he began working as an apprentice in a small rubber factory, which eventually gave him the experience needed to start his own rubber manufacturing business. By 1888, Albert had established the Burditt Corporation, which specialized in the production of rubber products for government and commercial clients. At first, Burditt's Corporation focused mostly on the production of rubber balls and rubber tires, and this was an integral part of their success. By 1912, Burditt had extended their business to include the manufacture of piping, springs, gaskets, and similar rubber parts. Not only did the company become an important part of the industrial sector in the United States, but it made a great contribution to the war effort in World War I. In addition to the production of rubber and related parts, Burditt also began to provide consulting services to government clients. By then, Burditt had become one of the country's most respected firms in its field. Albert Burditt was a hands-on operator who ran the Burditt business until his death in 1940. He ran a tight ship and insisted on only the very highest standards in production and service. He was dogged in adherence to his principles and often clashed with governmental and other agencies, but he always stayed focused on the production and delivery of quality products. In 1956, Burditt Corporation was acquired by a larger industrial conglomerate, but the company still exists as a shadow of its former self. Nonetheless, Albert Burditt's legacy lives on in the contributions Burditt Corporation made during his tenure as the founder and first CEO. He was a true pioneer in the American industrial sector and a driving force during the early years of growth of the rubber industry. He set a high bar for quality and standards, and these remain hallmarks of the Burditt Corporation today.

Robert Rolle (died 1660) was the leading English lawyer of his day. He was born in Devon, the son of an lawyer, and was educated at Exeter University. He practiced law in the courts of common pleas, the star chamber and King's Bench, and worked with many of the lawyers of his day, including William Noy and Sir Orlando Bridgeman. His legal career was highly successful as he debated and argued on a variety of cases in the most significant court of his time. He appeared in many of the leading cases, including the Somersett case, which granted freedom to a particular slave affirming his rights to life, liberty, and possession of property. At the time, England was governed by the monarchy of King Charles I, who had the deciding power and influence in the court proceedings. Prosecutors of the time had absolute power to make a case against a defendant and would often arbitrarily refuse to accept a plea or settlement from a defendant. Rolle was seen by many as a good role model for a fair-minded lawyer and challenged the prosecution's arbitrary decisions in court. As his influence spread, King Charles appointed him as counsel to the navy, a position he held until his death in 1660. Although Rolle was criticized for his legal decisions, he stood out in his network of friends and colleagues. He was known to be supportive of civil liberties and never lost sight of the equality he found in natural law. He was very highly respected by the English legal system and stands out as a significant figure in the development of English law. Rolle's work continues to influence the development of English law. Numerous books and articles have been written in his honour, and various foundations and trusts have been set up in his name. In the end, Robert Rolle was a respected lawyer, a proponent of justice, and a leader in the advancement of English law. He will forever be remembered for his contribution to the development of a fair and legal system in England.

The Guitar Experience Festival is an annual event that celebrates the world of the guitar. It is a three-day gathering held in a major metropolitan city that attracts guitarists of all skill levels and genres. The event includes a variety of performances that showcase the incredible talents of those playing the guitar. Concerts, improvisational jams, and live guitar battle competitions are all featured in the festival. Attendees can also learn tips and tricks from some of the most talented professionals in the industry during the numerous master classes and workshops. The Guitar Experience Festival also features a comprehensive collection of gear. Attendees can test out new guitars and accessories from leading brands in sound, as well as learn about the latest technology from industry insiders. The Guitar Experience Festival is the perfect space to mingle and connect with other guitar enthusiasts. There are open stages set up around the venue for spontaneous jams and performances. In addition, attendees can participate in networking sessions for producers and songwriters, or just enjoy grabbing a beer and relaxing with like-minded people. The event’s founder and director, Luke Walsh, began the festival in 2007 with the intention of creating a safe, informative and fun atmosphere where guitarists of every skill level can come together and appreciate the amazing sounds of the instrument. The Guitar Experience Festival is a unique celebration of all things related to the guitar. It's a one-of-a-kind event that has become a major draw for both local and international guitarists. For three days each year, dedicated guitarists and music lovers can experience some of the best the instrument has to offer.

Moran, Texas is an unincorporated community located in Hill County, Texas, United States. The population was recorded as a mere 25 inhabitants at the 2010 census, making it one of the smallest settlements in the state. History Moran, Texas was established in 1873 and named after Moran Smith, who once owned the land where the community stands today. The town soon began to flourish due to its abundance of coal and its location along the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad. Many businesses, including three churches, were built in the area, and in 1904 the town had an estimated population of 172. The town began to decline during the 1950s, and by the 2000s the population had dwindled to 25 residents. Today Despite its small population, Moran, Texas continues to be a popular destination for tourists who come to see its historic buildings and beautiful natural landscape. Visitors can take part in activities such as hunting, fishing, and canoeing. The town is also home to the Moran United Methodist Church, which was built in 1894 and is still in operation today. Moran, Texas is also home to the Frank B. Curtis Elementary School, which serves students from pre-kindergarten up to 8th grade. The school offers a variety of educational programs and resources to help students reach their goals. Conclusion Moran, Texas is a small unincorporated community in Hill County, Texas that may be small in population but big in spirit. Despite its small size, the community offers plenty of activities for visitors and plenty of resources for its students. As such, it is well worth a visit for those who are looking for a quaint, historic, and peaceful place to visit.

Yabba Dabba Doo! is an iconic catchphrase which originated in the American animated television series The Flintstones, the first major primetime animated series on television. It is typically used as a celebration of good times and was most famously uttered by the show’s main protagonist Fred Flintstone when excited. In addition to its use in The Flintstones, the phrase has become a popular cultural reference, with multiple uses in popular media and merchandise. The Flintstones aired for six seasons on ABC from 1960 to 1966, and was created by Hanna-Barbera Productions. Released in the same era as The Simpsons, it is believed to have greatly contributed to the success of primetime animation in the United States. The Flintstones centered around the Stone Age adventures of the titular family, who lived in the fictional town of Bedrock. and were comprised of Fred Flintstone, the breadwinner and husband, Wilma Flintstone, his wife, Pebbles Flintstone, their young daughter and Dino, their pet dinosaur. The catchphrase “Yabba Dabba Doo!” was introduced into the show in 1962 by Fred’s character as a way to express joy and excitement, and was said in reaction to moments like a successful golf swing or a beneficial spin in a game of chance. As the series progressed, the phrase began to take on a life of its own, appearing in promotional materials and other pieces of media outside of the show, such as statues and buttons. In addition to becoming a cultural icon in its own right, the saying has made appearances in various movies and television programs over the years. It was most recently used in an episode of the TV show Futurama, as well as an episode of The Simpsons. It has also been featured in songs and video games, such as in an update to the classic game Worms in which a character exclaims “Yabba Dabba Doo!” after victory. As well as its appearance in pop culture, the phrase has also been used to name various clothing brands, toys and other products. In 2010, a popular online clothing store, Yabba Dabba Doo!, was opened in the United Kingdom, and has since expanded to several countries over the years. The phrase has also been used in advertising campaigns and as the name of a beer brand produced by the American brewing company, Anheuser-Busch. In conclusion, “Yabba Dabba Doo!” has become an iconic phrase which has been embraced by the general public as a lighthearted way to show enthusiasm or happiness. Despite its humble origins in the 1960’s, the phrase has been adopted by modern cultures and is now used in various pieces of media, products, and advertisements.

The 1984 Buffalo Bills season was the franchise's 25th season in the National Football League and the 15th under head coach Kay Stephenson. The Bills had a 7-9 record and failed to make the playoffs for the fourth consecutive season. Their 7-4 record through 11 games was their best since 1976, and had them in playoff contention entering December. However, 3 losses in their final 4 games, including a 15-13 loss to the Green Bay Packers in the season finale left the team at 7-9 and one game out of the playoffs. The offense was led by quarterback Joe Ferguson who threw for a career-high 3,043 yards, 22 touchdowns and 17 interceptions. He was backed up by rookies Matt Kofler and Mark Stevens, who shared duties playing backup. The team's leading rusher was Larry Mason who carried the ball 234 times for 705 yards and 5 touchdowns. Top receiving targets for Ferguson were Elbert "Ickey" Woods with 43 receptions for 449 yards and 8 touchdowns, and rookie wide receiver Ernest Givins who caught 41 passes for 545 yards and 6 touchdowns while earning Pro Bowl honors. On defense, the Bills ranked 12th in the league, allowing 339.2 yards of total offense per game, while recording 33 sacks and 27 interceptions. Second-year defensive end Bruce Smith was named to the Pro Bowl, leading the team with 14 sacks and earning Defensive Rookie of the Year in 1983. The Bills also returned both kickers from the 1983 season, punter Chris Mohr and kicker Scott Norwood. Norwood made 16 field goals and 21 extra points for 69 total points. The Bills opened the season on September 3, 1984 with a win at the New York Jets, 10-7. This was their first win versus the Jets since the 1980 season. They would later lose to the Jets in the season finale, 15-13. Other highlights of the season included a 34-3 home victory against the St. Louis Cardinals, and a 17-13 victory over the Chicago Bears, which was the Bills' first win against the Bears since 1975. The Bills finished the 1984 season 7-9, a improvement over their 4-12 finish the year before. The team failed to make the playoffs, finishing one game behind the 8-8 Miami Dolphins who earned the last Wild Card spot. Despite their promising mid-season record, the Bills went winless in their final 4 games, ending their season on a sour note. Despite the disappointing finish, the Bills showed promise as they began to form the nucleus of what would be one of the most successful teams in the late 80's and early 90's. The 1984 season marks the end of the Kay Stephenson era, as he was replaced by Hank Bullough in 1985, and with him came a new era for the Buffalo Bills.

Demon Gaze is a dungeon crawler role-playing video game developed by Kadokawa Games, and published by Bandai Namco Entertainment for the PlayStation Vita and Microsoft Windows. The game is a spin-off of the original Demon Gaze series, released for the PlayStation 2 in Japan. Demon Gaze was released on PlayStation Vita in Japan on January 24th, 2013. The game was then released in North America on April 22nd, 2014, and Europe on May 30th, 2014. The game was then released on Windows PC on November 26th, 2015. The game is viewed in a top-down, 2.5D perspective. The player controls a strong, young man named Oz and his 6 allies as they travel through dungeons to fight monsters and gain experience. During the dungeon, players can use skills and items to battle enemies. Players can also customize their characters by purchasing items and equipment. In addition, the game revolves around a “D-Pact” system, which allows players to summon powerful demons to aid them in battle. These demons can be leveled-up to become stronger, while they can also be used to gain access to special abilities. Another system in the game revolves around using a Demon Leveler, which allows players to improve their abilities. Upon completing a dungeon, players can save their progress and receive bonuses based on their performance. Reception of the game was generally positive, with critics praising the game’s dungeon crawling elements as well as the overall art direction and character design. However, some critics found issues with the game’s enemy design, complaints about the D-Pact system, and long loading times. Despite its criticisms, Demon Gaze was considered to be both an entertaining and entertaining game to be enjoyable by those familiar with dungeon crawlers. In following updates, the game was later released in Europe on May 30th, 2014, as well as Windows PC on November 26th, 2015, with both versions re-balancing the tools and improving gameplay. A sequel to the game, Demon Gaze II, was released for the PlayStation Vita in 2016, and brought a more story orientated adventure with it.

First Dates is a British fly-on-the-wall documentary television series that first aired on Channel 4 on 17 June 2013 in the United Kingdom. The premise of the show was that couples went on a first date, and the viewers were given a revealing insight into the different attitudes, thoughts and behaviours of the prospective couples. The aim of the show was to discover whether each couple had a genuine connection during their date or if they were just not compatible. As of 2021, the show is in its eighth series. The show is created and produced by Twenty Twenty, a British production company founded by Martin Scott and Clare Bennett. First Dates is presented by comedian Paddy McGuinness and ex-model and actress Sarah-Jane Crawford; both were included in the show’s sixteenth series. Regular commentators on the series include relationship guru (and celebrity matchmaker) Nadia Essex, neuroscientist and human behaviour professor Emma Kenny, and psychologist Dr. Dawn Harper. The show's restaurant is located in Finchley, North London. It is a dedicated, purpose-built restaurant complex which includes a themed bar, a garden and a Love Lift to transport dates to the restaurant. It was reported by the Evening Standard in 2014 that the restaurant has served over 60,000 meals during the show's first series. The show's format provides a platform to explore various themes within the dating process. For instance, romantic chemistry, opportunities to discover more about each person, preconceptions, confidence, attitudes towards love and relationships, as well as any potential difficulties or surprises. In addition, there are regular features such as success stories, embarrassing stories, tips from celebrity daters, and fashion tips from stylist and make-up artist Alex Babsky. The series has been generally well received by critics. The Guardian praised the format for its "rousing mixture of warmth, humour and poignancy", while Radio Times dubbed it "Saturday night televisual pleasure". Viewers have also been impressed, with First Dates gaining a dedicated fanbase on social media and even becoming a trending topic on Twitter during its airing. Though its chaotic and often unpredictable format may make it feel more like an entertainment show than a serious social experiment, First Dates certainly has value in its realistic portrayal of the dating experience. It has opened viewers’ eyes to the various dynamics involved in the process of looking for love and possibly gaining a deeper understanding of why people do what they do when it comes to romance.

Pig City is a large commercial and financial center located in Zhangjiang Town, Shanghai, China. It is one of the largest high-tech zones in the country, and is home to numerous multinational corporations. The city was developed in the 2000s and is now a major hub for technology, e-commerce and finance. It is the home to several of China's largest and most successful tech companies, such as Huawei, Tencent, and Alibaba. Several of the world's biggest internet companies, such as Yahoo and Google, also have offices in Pig City. The area is well connected to other parts of the city, and is served by two metro lines. There are two airports nearby, Pudong International Airport and Hongqiao International Airport, which are both accessible from Pig City stations. Pig City is renowned for its excellent infrastructure, including fast broadband internet connection, which makes it attractive to companies looking to set up operations in the city. It is a business centre for multinationals, start-ups and venture capitalists, and is a crucial area for China's economy. In addition to its modern infrastructure, Pig City is also home to an array of attractions. There are shopping malls, cinemas, theatres, museums, and galleries. It is one of the most popular tourist destinations in China and is a frequent stopover on Shanghai city tours. Pig City is an important hub for China's tech industry, and its importance is set to grow in the coming years. It is a great place to visit, and provides a glimpse into the future of tech and business in China.

Daycroft School, founded in 1924, is an independent, coeducational, progressive elementary school in Greenwich, Connecticut. With a student-teacher ratio of 7 to 1, the Daycroft School is dedicated to providing a personalized learning experience to its students. Through a combination of educational methodology, developmentally appropriate education, individualized instruction and experiential learning, the school prepares children ages 3 through 12 for the challenges of the 21st century. Daycroft School is based on the principles of progressive education and strives to achieving the highest standards of academic excellence while developing the complete child – emotionally, socially and cognitively. Through experiential learning, small class sizes, personalized attention from teachers and staff, the school creates an environment to foster intellectual curiosity and creativity. The curriculum is broad and flexible, allowing students to explore their own interests within the framework of a core curriculum that is based on the principles of experiential learning, individualized instruction and a holistic approach to academics. Projects, field trips and innovated team building activities are all part of the Daycroft School experience. The Daycroft School also aims to develop leadership skills, community awareness and responsibility. The school's commitment to service learning ensures the children understand the importance of community and environmental responsibility, while demonstrating active involvement in their local and global communities. The Daycroft School also has an extensive alumni network, with many success stories. Many Daycroft alumni have gone on to study at the most selective universities, engage in successful careers and become leaders in their communities. In an effort to share its philosophy and mission, Daycroft School regularly hosts conferences and seminars for local schools, social service organizations and universities. Through these visits and conferences, Daycroft hopes to share its teaching methods and progressive educational philosophy with wider audiences. The Daycroft School continues to offer a personalized, high quality and progressive education to its students. The school's mission is “to assist each child to become the best that he or she can be, to inculcate in each child the joy of learning and the habit of lifelong learning, and to develop the whole person in his most productive and creative individual way.”

Dave Gumpert (born June 19, 1947) is an American businessman and entrepreneur. He is the founder and president of Gibsons International Sales Group, a company he founded in 1978. He is also the author of two books, Raise Your Prices and Put Your Profits in Your Pocket (McGraw-Hill, 2012) and Put Your Profits in Your Pocket and Take Control of Your Business (Career Press 2019). Gumpert grew up in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. After graduating from the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee in 1969, he served as an officer in the Army's Psychological Operations Branch in Vietnam. He then went on to start his business in exports, initially dealing in scrap metal. After numerous business mergers and acquisitions, Gumpert founded Gibsons International and assumed the role of president and chief executive officer. Gumpert's various business experiences are the foundation for his books, both of which received praise from leaders like Ken Blanchard, New York Times best-selling author and co-author of The One Minute Manager. Raise your Prices and Put Your Profits in Your Pocket is a book tailored to entrepreneurs, small business owners and marketing professionals teaching them how to maximize profits by raising prices. In Gumpert's view, pricing requires a mindset switch from “sales,” to “profits.” He also sees pricing as a tool, not a numbers game. Put Your Profits In Your Pocket and Take Control of Your Business is a book based on Gumpert's idea that strategies are needed in order to profit-proof a business. He shares the importance of creating "long-term win/win partnership" with customers, suppliers, employees and other stakeholders. The book was written with the goal of helping business owners take control of their businesses and grow. In addition to his books, Gumpert has written articles for The Journal of Business Strategy, a publication of The Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals. He has also published many articles in the national media like The Wall Street Journal, Inc. Magazine and Entrepreneur Magazine. Gumpert believes in giving back to the community, and actively promotes several charitable organizations, including DonorsChoose.org, Wounded Warrior Project, and The Diller Teen Tikkun Olam Awards. In 2006, Gumpert was honored with the Eagle Award for entrepreneurs by the Wisconsin/Illinois Minority Business Enterprise Council, as well as The prestigious Wisconsin Entrepreneur Of The Year Award (SBDC Network) from the Wisconsin Department of Commerce. Gumpert currently resides in Minneapolis, Minnesota and continues to be involved in the business world. He has become a speaker for various entrepreneurial events and organizations and can be found on the internet speaking about his books and business strategies. External Links Gibsons International Sales Group (www.gibsonsgrouptx.com) Dave Gumpert speaking engagements (https://www.gumpert.org/speaking-engagements) Raise Your Prices and Put Your Profits in Your Pocket (https://www.amazon.com/Raise-YOUR-PRICES-Profits-Pocket/dp/0071780738/) Put Your Profits In Your Pocket and Take Control of Your Business (https://careerpress.com/products/put-your-profits-in-your-pocket-and-take-control-of-your-business)

Karachi is the largest city in Pakistan and one of the most populous cities in the world. With a rich history spanning centuries, Karachi has been the economic capital of Pakistan since independence from the British in 1947. The roots of Karachi go back to the ancient city of Kolachi, located on the coast of the Arabian Sea in Sindh province. Kolachi is said to have been founded in 1729 when various Balochi, Pashtun, and Omani settlers first made the land their home. The city remained in relative obscurity until the British colonization of India in 1839, when it was developed and modernized by the British and became the principal trading port of British India. In 1901, the old city of Kolachi was incorporated into the larger Municipality of Karachi, which was established by the British. This marked the beginning of large-scale urbanization of the city, with the creation of grand public parks, modern architecture, and public institutions. From this point, Karachi began to grow rapidly, becoming the center of politics, industry, and commerce in the newly formed nation of Pakistan after the partition of British India in 1947. During the 1940s and '50s, Karachi witnessed one of its most prosperous periods under the rule of its first mayor, Seth Harchandrai Vishandas. He implemented various long-term economic and social development projects such as reorganizing Banarasi Bazaar, building new parks, and introducing a number of factories in the city. This helped Karachi to enter an era of spectacular economic and population growth. Karachi has experienced a wide range of political upheavals over the years, from sectarian riots in the 1980s to a decades-long military operation by the Pakistani army against Taliban insurgents, which was initiated in 2014. Despite the many challenges, the economic and social progress of the city continues and is being further embellished by the initiatives of the current mayor, Wasim Akhtar. In recent decades, Karachi has emerged as one of the most important cities in South Asia, serving as the commercial and financial hub of Pakistan. As of 2019, Karachi is the second-most populous city in the world, with an estimated 20 million people. It is also a major transport and industrial center with a large international seaport and a modern international airport. The city continues to embark on a journey of development, encompassing many public and private projects with the aim of achieving an even better standard of living for its inhabitants. The future of Karachi undoubtedly looks bright.

Dieter Lehnhoff (b. April 4, 1940) is a German engineer and inventor best known for his cutting edge technology and innovation in the electrical industry. He studied electrical engineering and industrial technology at Technical University of Munich, graduating in 1964. After graduation, he joined Larsen & Toubro Siemens India, where he was involved in project led by Dr. Adolf Goetzberger to develop large scale solar power generation systems. During his time there, he was awarded a PhD in Electrical Engineering from TUM. In the early 1970s, Dieter returned to Germany and joined HUAWEI Technologies, where he led the company's development of industrial automation. During this time, he developed the concept of programmable logic controllers (PLC) and invented an integrated switchgear system for factories. This resulted in HUAWEI Technologies receiving an award from the German government for their contribution to innovation in the electrical industry. In 1982, Dieter founded his own engineering firm DELattronics, which specialized in electrical engineering and simulation. At DELattronics, he pioneered energy efficient and precision control technology, producing highly innovative products and services. His company’s clients included industrial and engineering companies, energy providers, and education institutions. After several successful years, DELattronics was taken over by Siemens in 1999, and Dieter became Senior Vice President of the company’s automation division. During his time there, he contributed to research and development of new energy efficiency technologies. In 2004, he received the Siemens Innovators Award for his groundbreaking technologies. Following his retirement in 2010, he became an advisor to Siemens on energy efficiency. Apart from his engineering achievements, Dieter has also been involved in teaching and academic research. He taught electrical engineering at Germany's Applied University of Mannheim for 20 years and has written several books and academic papers on electrical engineering. He has won numerous awards and accolades for his engineering achievements, including the German National Champion of Technology in 1974 and the Grand Prize of Merit from the Economic Senate of Germany. Dieter also holds 20 patent registrations for his inventions. In 2010, Dieter founded his own company Lehnhoff Technologies, which produces automation and control solutions for industry, energy and research sectors. To date, his company has successfully produced products that are cost effective, energy efficient and technologically advanced.

Ruth Feldman (b. 1960) is an Israeli psychologist and professor of comparative human development and social policy at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. She is a world-renowned leader in the fields of biological and psychosocial determinants of human behavior, especially in the context of early-life adversity. Feldman was born in Israel and educated in the United States, where she earned her bachelor’s degree in psychology and sociology at the University of Missouri-Columbia in 1984 and her doctoral degree at the University of Wisconsin-Madison in 1989. She then returned to Israel and joined the Hebrew University in 1990, where she is currently a professor in the Department of Psychology and chairman of the Graduate Program in Comparative Human Development and Social Policy. Feldman has researched and written extensively on the biological and psychosocial determinants of behavior, especially in the context of early-life adversity. She has applied her research to a variety of contexts, including child development and parent-child relationships, adolescent mental health, and the development of social policy. Her research has shed light on the long-term effects of child abuse and neglect and their implications for addressing social problems. Feldman is the recipient of many awards, including the Emil A. Frankel Award from the National Institutes of Health, the Israel Psychological Association Prize for Outstanding Professional Achievement, and the Israel Women’s Studies Award. She is a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and the Academy of Behavioral Science. She has served as editor-in-chief of Development and Psychopathology and as associate editor of Child Development. Feldman has consulted for numerous organizations, including the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and—from 2005 to 2008—the World Bank Group. She also served on the World Health Organization's Scientific and Technical Advisory Group on Social Risk Factors. Her work has been featured in numerous publications and journals, including Nature, Science, The New York Times, and The Washington Post. Feldman is a co-founder of the ALUT Mental Health Foundation, which focuses on the mental health needs of the Israeli Special Needs population. She is also the co-founder and co-director of the Parent Developmental Research Program at Bar-Ilan University in Israel.

The Bank of Springfield Center is a three-story office building located in downtown Springfield, Illinois. Built in 1968 and originally named the S&L Building, it was renamed the Bank of Springfield Center in 2008 after its current owner, Bank of Springfield. The Bank of Springfield Center is the tallest building in Springfield, rising to a height of 175 feet (53 m). It is the only building in Springfield to exceed 100 feet (30 m) in height. The building has three floors, with the top two stories featuring office space while the ground floor is used for retail and restaurant space. The facade of the Bank of Springfield Center is notable for its large glass windows and sleek, modern design. The building was designed by architect Henry Chapman, who took inspiration from the International Style school of architecture. The Bank of Springfield Center is home to offices of several financial and legal firms, as well as other businesses. It is also the home of the American Bar Association's Springfield headquarters and the Simmons Law Group. The building also houses the offices of local and state governmental institutions, such as the Sangamon County Clerk and the Illinois Department of Labor. The Bank of Springfield Center is easily accessible by car and public transportation. It is located near the downtown loop of the Capital Area Mass Transit District (CAMTD), and is served by five bus routes at the adjacent intersection of Adams and Fifth streets. The building is also a short walk from the Amtrak station located in the Fifth Street Station building. The Bank of Springfield Center is a prominent landmark of Springfield's downtown business district, and a reminder of the city's commercial hub status. Its unique design and historic location attract locals and tourists alike. In recent years, the building has been featured in several motion pictures, including "The Chicago 7" and "The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford". In 2020, Bank of Springfield received a ten-year tax abatement from the City of Springfield in recognition of its commitment to the local community. This abatement will help ensure the long-term viability of the Bank of Springfield Center and enable ongoing investment in the building's upkeep and management. Overall, the Bank of Springfield Center is an important part of the Springfield Cityscape. Its modern design and vibrant presence have helped to redefine its downtown district. In addition, its various offices, retail stores, and bustling hospitality have enriched the local economy. While its origins may be modest, the Bank of Springfield Center stands tall as a testament to Springfield's growth and prosperity.

Amolops archotaphus is a species of frog in the Ranidae family of frogs. It is endemic to the Sichuan Basin, China. It is known commonly as the Archotaphetic Frog. The adult males of this species range from 31-49mm in snout-vent length. The species is distinguished from the European frogs of its genus by its small size and its color. The body of the frogs is dorsal surface is brownish-black in colour and their ventral surface is whitish. They have a greyish canthal stripe and there are black patches behind the eyes. The legs are pale brown or pink with darker spots. Amolops archotaphus is found in the Sichuan Province of China near streams, ponds, paddy fields, and gardens with vegetation. The species is generally found in grasslands, but is also known from higher elevations. The breeding sites of Amolops archotaphus are the shallow streams and ponds that are found in the Sichuan Basin. The frogs often lay their eggs among vegetation and the eggs click when touched. When the eggs hatch, the tadpoles emerge in mid-summer and take around two weeks to transform into froglets. The diet of Amolops archotaphus consists of a variety of small insects and arthropods including crickets, ants, and spiders. The species has also been observed to feed on other small vertebrates such as fish and small frogs. Amolops archotaphus is listed as a Near Threatened species on the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species and is also listed in CITES Appendix II. The primary threats to the species is habitat destruction due to agricultural activities and development. Pollution is also known to be a common threat to the species. In order to protect the species, the Chinese government has taken several steps, such as establishing local Govt. nature reserves to protect the species and its habitat. In addition, public awareness campaigns have been launched to educate the locals regarding conservation of the species.

Ranger, Texas is a city located in Eastland County in the U.S. state of Texas. As of the 2010 census, the city had a population of 2,468, down from 2,814 at the 2000 census. The city was named after the Texas Ranger Division, which was formed in 1874 to protect settlers against Native American raids. The city grew primarily as a bus stop in the early 1900s. The city incorporated in 1930. In 1912, the town of Ranger was incorporated when a post office was opened in the city. Ranger College was founded in the city in 1965. It is a two year college and member of the Texas Junior College System, with campuses in Brownwood, Stephenville, and other cities throughout the region. Military veterans returned from World War II and Korea and the college was founded to help those veterans earn their degrees. The city has six city parks: the C. L. Hutchins Park, the Deer Park, the J.B.S. Street Park, the Melvin Vause Park, the Ranger City Park, and the State Street Park. Spivey Lake is located in the southside of Ranger. The lake is seven-and-a-half acres large and offers a variety of outdoor activities, such as fishing, swimming, and boating. The city is home to two museums, the Jack Hatfield Music Museum, which is dedicated to the life and music of legendary country singer Jack Hatfield, and the Coleman Memorial Park and Museum, which features artifacts from the early days of Pioneero County and its development. Events in the city include the annual Ranger Heritage Days, which is a day of celebration, parades, and entertainment, with the festival occurring on the first Saturday in October. Other events include the Ranger Blue Comet Annual Support Run and the Eastland County Fair. Ranger is home to three schools, the Ranger Independent School District (RISD), Ranger College, and the Texas Christian Academy. RISD is the largest employer in Ranger, with over 1,000 people working for the school district at various levels.
