Ranger is the site of the memorial to James Browning, the last surviving member of the Rangers' Battle of Palo Duro Canyon and one of only two members of the Central Column to survive the attack.

M. D. Antani (born 1984) is an Indian actor, film producer and entrepreneur. He is best known for his work in feature films such as Multiple and 7 Hours to Go. Antani is also the founder of a production house in Mumba and has produced several short films and documentaries. Antani graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in Economics from University of Mumbai in 2007. In the same year, he started his own production company called Big Planet Films. He has worked on various projects including documentary films, creating original content for various web-series and television commercials. In 2015, Antani made his debut as an actor with the movie Multiple starring Govinda, Aditi Rao Hyderi, and Shruti Haasan. His second movie Seven Hours to Go was released in 2016 and was one of the highest grossing Bollywood films of that year. He followed this up with movies such as Kick, Boss and Happy Jorney. Antani is an active member of the Bharatiya Janata Party, having served as its entertainment industry spokesperson for the 2013 General Elections. He was also the part of the team behind the BJP's campaign to win the 2014 Lok Sabha elections. In 2016, Antani joined Harsh Goenka's chairmanship of Rsys Technologies. Antani is also an avid traveller and has traveled to many countries in Europe and the United States. He enjoys reading books and is an admirer of Mahatma Gandhi and Mahatma Phule. In 2017, he was honored with the "Outstanding Young Entrepreneur" award by the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FICCI). Antani has been actively involved in philanthropic work, having started his own NGO - Antani Social Foundation. Him and his production house is also known for producing short films and videos that promote social messages such as gender equality and environmental conservation. He has also been a prominent part of various cleanliness drives in Mumbai to spread awareness about the importance of waste management. He currently resides in Mumbai with his wife and two children.

Mark Kilstofte (born 1945) is an American sculptor and artist known for his figurative bronzes and large-scale public commissions. He is widely regarded as one of the preeminent representational sculptors in the United States. Born in Michigan, Kilstofte apprenticed with a European trained sculptor before studying at The School of the Art Institute of Chicago and the Art Students League of New York with instructor Dudley Talcott. Kilstofte's elegant bronze works are collected and displayed around the world. His works have been featured in the National Sculpture Society's Annual Exhibition at the National Academy of New York, the American Academy of Arts and Letters, the DuPont Pavilion in Florida, and the Palm Beach Civic Center the Aronson Galleries in New York City, Sandzen Museum, and many other public and corporate locations. Inspired by the Renaissance masters, Kilstofte’s works can be found across the globe, such as his sculpture of Saint Christopher displayed at the Graceland Memorial Chapel in Memphis, the Holocaust Memorial in Montevideo, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Spokane and his architectural sculptures for the River Bank State Park in New York City. Kilstofte has also served as a long time professor and director of the sculpture department at the State University of New York at New Paltz from 1979 to 2009. He continues to work from his custom-designed studio in the Hudson Valley of New York state and has remained active in teaching, lecturing, and sculpting. He is the 2009 recipient of the Henry Hering Achievement Award, the most prestigious honor given by the National Sculpture Society. Kilstofte's art is part of prestigious collections private, corporate, and public such as Elizabeth Arden, Astra Zeneca, Warner Music Group, the Butler Institute of American Art, and many more. His work is represented by Viridian Gallery in New York City, USA. Kilstofte remains a major contributor to the field of three-dimensional art and continues to inspire new generations of sculptors.

Nepal–Spain relations refers to the bilateral relations between Nepal and Spain. Relations between the two countries have been mainly warm and friendly. History Spain had some indirect involvement in the history of Nepal in the 18th century, when diplomats from the court of Nepal's ruling Shah dynasty were dispatched first to St. Petersburg, then to Madrid, to infom the Spanish government about Nepal's presence and to seek Spanish recognition of the Shah rule (as opposed to the monarchy's traditional tributary relationship to China). In the modern times, formal diplomatic relations between Nepal and Spain were established on May 16, 1964. Since then, exchanges in various fields have taken place on a regular scale. In June 1996, King Birendra of Nepal made a state visit to Spain at the invitation of then King Juan Carlos. During this visit, a joint communique was issued expressing commitment to the strengthening of sound friendly and cooperative bilateral relations between the two countries. Diplomatic mission Nepal and Spain enjoyed full diplomatic relations since the establishment of Embassy of Nepal in Madrid in 1982, which is currently headed by Hon. Rabindra Nath Shrestha as the Ambassador of Nepal. On the other hand, Spain established its embassy in Kathmandu in 2004 and the Spanish Ambassador to Nepal is currently Hon. Juan Francisco Amador Carranza. Cooperation In 2011, Spanish government provided technical assistance for the infrastructure development of projects such as airports and bridges in Nepal. Germany, United Kingdom and Spain have undertaken 1 Eco-Development project in the Annapurna Conservation Area in western Nepal. The Spanish Government is also coordinating particularly with the AECID-funded projects in Nepal to improve their economic and social development. The two countries have also established an effective mechanism of cooperation in the field of science and technology. A Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) was signed between the Ministry of Science, Technology and Research of Nepal and Spanish Agency for International Cooperation and Development (AECID) in 2062 for cooperation in the field of science and technology. In April 2013, Embassy of Spain in Nepal and the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology, Ministry of Science, Technology and Environment of Nepal jointly launched the Spanish-Nepal Climate Change Project to support the development of adaptation strategies and climate models for Nepal. Cultural exchange The two countries engage in significant cultural exchanges. In 1976, Federation of Nepalese Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FNCCI) and its Spanish counterpart signed an agreement for establishing and promoting friendship, understanding and cooperation between the two Chambers. In December 2003, a Nepalese-Spanish Chamber of Commerce and Industry was established in Nepal and currently undertake activities such as organizing exchange programs, organizing joint venture activities, and offering study grants to Spanish students in Nepal. The Embassy of Spain in Nepal and Spanish Agency for International Development and Cooperation (AECID) launched the 2009-2012 Spanish-Nepal Cultural Exchange Program to foster exchange in the field of massmedia, arts, education and sciences. In April, 2012, Embassy of Spain in Kathmandu hosted a function to celebrate the II Nepal-Spain Cultural Week. Cultural programs such as musical soirees, art exhibitions and festivals were organized by visiting delegations from Spain. The event is being held annually. See also * Foreign relations of Nepal * Foreign relations of Spain * Spain–Asia relations * Spain–India relations Category:Nepal–Spain relations Category:Bilateral relations of Spain

John Franklin Enders (1897-1985) was an esteemed American scientist and Nobel Prize laureate who made lasting contributions to the fields of chemistry, virology, immunology, and biochemistry. Born in West Hartford, Connecticut in 1897, Enders had a long and distinguished career in his fields of expertise, achieving important breakthroughs in both the chemistry and virology-related fields of science. While attending Yale University, Enders fell in love with chemistry and decided to pursue it as a full-time career. After graduating in 1918 he went on to the Harvard University where he received his Ph.D in Chemistry in 1924. In his Ph.D dissertation, Enders laid the groundwork for research into the structure of proteins which he later developed while working in the department of physical chemistry at Harvard. In addition to his work in chemistry, Enders became a pioneer in the field of virology. His most famous achievement was the development of the so-called "Enders-Edmonston-Litzman Boston Vaccine” for measles. Enders's work led to a Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine shared with Thomas H. Weller and Frederick Robbins in 1954 for "discovering and isolating the active virus strains that cause measles, mumps, and chicken pox." Enders also made valuable contributions to the field of immunology, particularly through the development of the MIT Vacuoles Test, an early form of the modern ELISA test. This test was used to diagnose multiple sclerosis and other diseases. Throughout his career, Enders was involved in various research projects both directly and indirectly. He was a founding member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, as well as a member of the National Academy of Sciences, the American Philosophical Society, and the American Academy of Physicians. Upon his death in 1985, John Franklin Enders left an indelible mark on the scientific world for which he was revered.

She Used to Be Mine is a song by American recording artist Sara Bareilles from her fifth studio album, What’s Inside: Songs from Waitress. Written and produced by Bareilles, it was released as a single in the United States on October 6, 2015, after teasing the song on Twitter a few days prior. Moreover, it became the theme song of the stage musical based on the 2007 film Waitress, for which Bareilles wrote all of the songs. The song is an emotional ballad, in which Bareilles reflects on her memories, regrets, and life with mixed feelings. She also describes the "monsters" and "demons" that reside within her trying to take over her life, and make it unrecognizable. She Used to Be Mine expresses feelings of sorrow and regret, and its lyrics focus on how someone becomes a “shadow of their former self” and how they are “losing control” of the situation and the “dreams they had before.” The music video for She Used to Be Mine was released October 26, 2015, and features Bareilles performing the song on a black and white stage. As she sings, glitching special effects are used to illustrate her emotional turmoil. The video has since amassed over 39 million views on YouTube as of October 2019. Reception of the single has been generally positive. Allmusic described it as a “heartfelt” song and praised its “intensely personal lyrics” and “catchy melody.” Rolling Stone similarly called it “a somber ballad” and noted that the lyrics were “filled with vulnerability.” Entertainment Weekly also praised the song’s “yearning” and “emotionally charged” vocals. At the 2016 Tony Awards, She Used to Be Mine was highlighted by lead actress Jessie Mueller, who won Best Performance by an Actress in a Leading Role in a Musical. Mueller and Bareilles performed a duet of the song, as a tribute to the musical Waitress. The song was also included on the 2017 Waitress (Deluxe) compilation album. In addition, She Used to Be Mine became a popular karaoke song. Its mellow sound, combined with its relatable and heart-warming lyrics, made it ideal for singing with friends and family. The song has also been covered by a number of artists, including Adele, Taylor Swift, and Florida Georgia Line.

Fat Man and Little Boy are two supporting characters featured in the animated television sitcom The Simpsons. They appear as recurring characters in the show and are voiced by the show's creator, Matt Groening. The characters first appeared in the episode "Treehouse of Horror II" from season 3 of the show. In this episode, Fat Man and Little Boy were two atomic bomb technicians, who were assigned with the task of transporting the bombs Little Boy and Fat Man for the Manhattan Project. However, the two scientists were not aware of the destructive power of the bombs and instead played a game of catch with them in Springfield while Homer Simpson was unable to stop them. In the end, the bombs exploded and caused massive destruction in the town, as well as creating a nuclear fallout cloud over it. In subsequent episodes, Fat Man and Little Boy retain their roles as scientists who transport dangerous objects of unknown power. However, their appearances vary widely, depending on the situation. In the episodes "Homer the Smithers" and "Trash of the Titans", they are shown as janitors working in Springfield Nuclear Power Plant, while in the episode "Weekend at Burnsie's" they are shown as customers in a store, buying an electric guitar. In addition to their roles in the show, Fat Man and Little Boy have become popular icons of The Simpsons, becoming frequent references in popular culture and parodies of the show. They have been featured in a number of merchandise as well, such as action figures, trading cards and T-shirts. There are even fan websites devoted to them and their catchphrase, "Ohhh! Atomic Power!" has become widely known. Overall, Fat Man and Little Boy remain beloved characters of The Simpsons, gaining a great deal of recognition and respect from fans of the show. Their appearances and personalities have solidified their status as popular figures of the show and have added to its overall appeal.

Lund v Boissoin is a court case in Alberta, Canada, that resulted in a ruling regarding the limits of free speech in relation to issues of homosexuality. It was centred around a complaint filed by University of Alberta student Tracy Lund against Stephen Boissoin, a fundamentalist Christian pastor, who wrote a letter containing anti-gay views which was published in the Red Deer Advocate in 2002. The complaint alleged that Boissoin had violated Alberta’s then Human Rights, Citizenship and Multiculturalism Act by publishing the letter in the newspaper. The Canadian Constitution Foundation, a group representing conservative values, supported Boissoin's case. In June 2003, the Alberta Human Rights Commission upheld the complaint, finding that Boissoin’s letter was discriminatory on the basis of sexual orientation and made its ruling by stating that Boissoin was to cease publishing in newspapers, acknowledge his mistake in a full-page advertisement, pay Lund C$5,000 in costs and C$5,000 as compensation for injury to her dignity, feelings and self-respect. The Court of Queen's Bench of Alberta heard arguments regarding the case in March 2008 and rendered its decision two months later. The court held that portions of the Human Rights Commission’s ruling were in error and that the Commission “crossed the line and ignored some basic tenets of Charter protection of expressive activity in writing and publishing the remedy it imposed.”. In the following November, the Alberta Court of Appeal upheld the Court of Queen's Bench decision. As a result of Lund v Boissoin, it had been argued by some that Alberta's human rights legislation is unconstitutional and has violated democratic values concerning the right to free speech. However, in the ruling from higher court, it was concluded that free speech shouldn't be absolute under any situation and should be subject to restrictions. The ruling was perceived by some to have supported or affirmed the right of individuals to express their religious beliefs while protecting the rights of individuals from the harm caused by such beliefs. Since the ruling, this case has become a significant example of the struggle for religious freedom and the limitations of free speech in Canada. It serves as an example of how Canadians are attempting to balance their rights with respect to free speech and with respect to public expression of their religious beliefs. The ruling in this case also touched on how the Canadian concept of fundamental freedoms is being applied to its citizens. The court suggested that governments should be careful when imposing limits on speech, arguing that citizens should be allowed to express ideas and beliefs that may be considered disagreeable or offensive, as long they do not lead to harm. This decision could have implications for Canadian law going forward regarding how Canadians are allowed to express their personal religious beliefs and opinions.

Kevola Observatory is an astronomical observatory located in northern Europe, near the town of Kevola in Finland. It is operated by the Kevola Astronomical Society, and is used for research and public education in astronomy. The observatory was constructed in 1990, with the help of donations from the local population. It is equipped with top-of-the-line telescopes, including a 24-inch Newtonian reflector and a 10-inch Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope. It also has various smaller instruments for various purposes. The Kevola Astronomical Society regularly organizes various educational activities for the public. These include star-gazing days, lectures and demonstrations, as well as hands-on activities such as building model telescopes, learning about the science behind the observation of the night sky, and much more. The observatory is also home to an advanced research lab, housing several computers and various software programs for data analysis and visualization. This is used by amateur astronomers and professional astronomers alike who come to the observatory to study the night sky in greater detail, including taking CCD images of various celestial objects. The observatory is open to the public, and visitors can enjoy a tour of the facility, as well as look through different types of telescopes and view the night sky through them. A programme of educational lectures is also held at the facility on certain days, with topics ranging from astrophotography, to solar astronomy, cosmology and more. Kevola Observatory also hosts numerous outreach events throughout the year, including public viewings of the sky through various types of telescopes, and various other educational activities for all ages. In addition, the observatory has been the site of many successful deep sky imaging campaigns and the results of these have been featured in various science magazines and books. Kevola Observatory is an attractive facility for both amateur astronomy enthusiasts and professional astronomers alike, due to its modern equipment, regular public outreach events and educational activities, and a commitment to astronomy research. It is a valuable asset to the local community, and to the world of astronomy.

Prasophyllum mimulum, commonly known as the small Prasophylum, is a species of orchid native to Australia. It is a terrestrial herb, growing up to 10 cm in height, with several leaves and a single, white flower. The flower has a noticeable mid-lobe, two lateral lobes, a dorsal sepal and two lateral petals. It is found in wet and dry sclerophyll forests, and is distributed throughout south-eastern Australia, from Victoria and New South Wales to Tasmania. The species epithet mimulum is derived from Latin, meaning "small resemblance". The flowers of Prasophyllum mimulum are easily recognised due to their small size. Prasophyllum mimulum is an obligate outcrosser and requires cross-pollination for successful seed-set. Pollination is carried out by a variety of bees, including large carpenter bees and small flower-visiting bees. As the flowers open, the lower labellum curls down to a horizontal position, providing a platform for the pollinator resting. The species is listed as "Vulnerable" under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. It is threatened by a number of factors, including the alteration of fire regimes and the impact of invasive weeds and feral animals. However, its presence across much of south-eastern Australia may indicate that it is resilient to some extent. The species is likely to experience increased pressure from climate change and urban development. Some populations have become fragmented, reducing the number of pollinators, as well as genetic flow between populations. It is likely to need targeted conservation management and monitoring to ensure population resilience in the future. Prasophyllum mimulum is an attractive species and is popular amongst orchid enthusiasts. It can be propagated vegetatively from clumps or from seed and is easy to maintain in cultivation. It does best in well-draining, acidic soil, with plenty of air-flow and in partial shade. (Word count: 268)

John Anthony West (1932 - 2018) was an American author and Egyptologist best known for his seminal works on ancient Egypt and its civilization. He is best known for introducing a radical revision in conventional Egyptology, most prominently the suggestion that the Great Sphinx of Giza may in fact be thousands of years older than previously thought. West was born in 1932 in Mineola, New York and earned a B.A. in Fine Arts from Columbia University. He went on to pursue graduate studies at the University of Geneva and Oxford University, but chose not to receive a degree. He then crafted a career as a poet, screenwriter, journalist, and painter. West's interest in Egyptology was first piqued during a childhood visit to the Middle East with his father. Over the years this interest grew, and ultimately formed the basis of his writing and research. In 1979, West presented "The Case for the Great Sphinx", a documentary that argued the sphinx might in fact be thousands of years older than the traditional dates assigned by Egyptologists. This presented a radical departure from the traditional understanding of the sphinx, and attracted the attention of Robert Bauval, whose Orion Correlation Theory West drew on to support his conclusions. In the late 1980s, West organized two exploratory visits to the pyramid complex of Giza. During these visits, West and his team of experts uncovered evidence that further supported his findings. The theory of West and his colleagues also drew the attention of some of the world's leading Egyptologists. While some of the findings of West and his team were further explored by Egyptologists, others were dismissed. Nonetheless, his work is still considered groundbreaking and significantly influenced many later studies on ancient Egypt. West continued to write, eventually authoring several books on the subject of Egyptology. His last book, 'Serpent in the Sky', was published in 1993, and explores an alternative explanation for the origin of civilization. West died in 2018 at the age of 85, leaving behind a legacy of groundbreaking work in Egyptology. His work has inspired others to push the boundaries of conventional Egyptology, introducing new theories and revising the traditional understanding of this ancient civilization.

Cranbrook is an Anglican Church hymn tune composed by William Henry Monk in 1861. It is best known for its use with the lyrics of "Fairest Lord Jesus", one of the most beloved Christian hymns with both Catholic and Protestant roots. The tune was named after Cranbrook, a town in Kent, England. The hymn was first published in Monk's book Hymns Ancient and Modern, which was released in 1861. The original version is scored for SATB choir, and while Monk wrote two accompaniment options - organ and harmonium - the organ version is generally preferred due to its fuller sound. The organ version was first featured in the 1861 edition of the English Hymnal. "Fairest Lord Jesus" is one of the oldest surviving Christian hymns, having been sung in German as early as the 13th century. The English lyrics were first published in 1752, and a number of tunes have been written for it, many more recently than Cranbrook, such as Mark Hayes' "Lorraine". Though Cranbrook is now most widely associated with "Fairest Lord Jesus", it was originally written for the hymn "Tell Out, My Soul". The lyrics of this hymn have also been revised over time, first by Robert Robinson who contributed the first three verses in 1776. Regarding its popularity, Cranbrook remains one of the most widely used hymn tunes in churches around the world. It has been featured in many hymn books, including the Trinity Hymnal, the 1940 Methodist Hymnal, and the Contemporary Christian Music Project. In addition, Cranbrook is often used as a processional and recessional hymn at Christian weddings. It has also been featured on recordings by a number of contemporary Christian artists, including Josh Groban, Amy Grant, and Chris Tomlin. Cranbrook remains one of the most beloved Christian hymns of all time. Its simple melody and timeless lyrics still touch hearts and evoke deep emotions over one hundred and fifty years since its original composition.

Herbert Henry Woollard (30 October 1885 – 9 May 1942) was a British illustrator and war artist. He is best remembered for his depictions of conflict during the First World War, which have been viewed by millions. Early life Woollard was born in the village of Harrow Weald, London, and educated locally at Harrow Weald Primary School and Harrow High School (now Parmiter's School). In 1896, he studied at Chiswick Technical School before attending the Royal College of Art from 1902-06. Career When Woollard completed his studies at the Royal College of Art in 1906, he began a successful career as a commercial illustrator, mainly for newspapers, magazines and books. He was commissioned to produce a series of Illustrations for magazines, such as The Sketch, The Graphic and The Illustrated London News, and to illustrate titles by authors such as Charles Dickens and Arthur Conan Doyle. He also worked as a magazine and advertising artist. In 1911, he was invited by the British Government to paint a series of official war pictures during the Italo-Turkish War, which were exhibited in 1920. World War I For much of World War I, Woollard served as a staff artist of the British War Office. During his service, he produced hundreds of sketches and paintings, some of which were exhibited in a successful touring exhibition. He was one of the first official war artists to paint the Western Front, and his work often focused on the men of the front line and the harrowing conditions they endured. Woollard's work was widely praised by his contemporaries, including Gilbert Evans who proclaimed that "no one will ever forget the terrible war pictures of H.H. Woollard." Later life After the war, Woollard returned to his former profession as a commercial illustrator, producing work for a variety of newspapers and magazines. He also accepted a teaching position at the Royal College of Art in 1920 and remained at the college until his death in May 1942. Legacy Woollard's work has remained popular and is highly regarded. His depictions of the First World War remain some of the most vivid and powerful war art in the world. His wartime efforts were so appreciated that he was awarded the Order of the British Empire in 1918. His works can be found in the Imperial War Museum and the National Museums in London and Liverpool.

Gun laws in Georgia are among the more permissive in the United States and have become increasingly so since the late 1960s. Georgia does not require a permit to openly carry a firearm, and constitutional carry, which allows for the concealed carry of a firearm without a permit, is legal in most areas of the state. However, carrying a concealed firearm in certain areas, such as schools and government buildings, is still prohibited. History The laws surrounding firearms in Georgia have evolved over the years. Until 1967, it was illegal to carry a firearm in public without a permit from the state. This changed in 1967 when a new statute allowed citizens to openly carry firearms without a permit. In Florida v. J.L. (2000), the Supreme Court of the United States ruled that law enforcement could not search a person suspected of carrying a firearm without first establishing reasonable suspicion of criminal activity. This ruling provided additional protection for Georgia gun owners and largely removed restrictions on firearm possession and usage. Concealed Carry In 2014, Georgia passed a law that allows citizens to carry a concealed firearm without a permit. This is referred to as constitutional carry. This law does not apply in some areas including restaurants that serve alcohol, government buildings, and places of worship. As of 2019, there are still restrictions on the carrying of firearms on college campuses, although a bill has been proposed to allow it. Stand-Your-Ground Georgia is a Stand-Your-Ground state where citizens may use deadly force to defend themselves or their property in certain circumstances. For a stand-your-ground defense to be successful, the person claiming self-defense must be in a place they have a right to be and they must not have provoked the assault or be involved in criminal activity. Open Carry Open carry is legal in Georgia without any kind of permit or license. While it is not illegal to openly carry a firearm, it is recommended to carry a permit with you in order to avoid any potential confusion with law enforcement. Municipal Laws While there are no statewide restrictions on the possession of firearms, some municipalities have passed their own laws establishing additional restrictions. For example, in the City of Atlanta it is illegal to carry a firearm, either openly or concealed, without the proper permit. It is important to check with local laws before carrying a firearm in Georgia. Conclusion Overall, the gun laws in Georgia are among the more lenient in the United States. Citizens are allowed to openly carry firearms without a permit, and concealed carry can be done with a permit or through constitutional carry. There are still some restrictions on concealed carry in certain areas, as well as local laws that can affect firearm possession and usage.

Gregory M. Erickson (born April 8, 1956 in Springfield, Illinois) is an American paleontologist and evolutionary biologist. He is Professor of Biological Science at Florida State University, and the current President of the Society of Vertebrate Paleontology (2019–2021). Erickson is best known for his research on the growth and development of dinosaurs and other vertebrate animals. He has published numerous articles on the topics of dinosaur growth, dinosaur metabolism, dinosaur biomechanics, and dinosaur extinction. He is also known for his work on dinosaur-like birds, and the evolutionary history of modern-day mammals. Erickson earned his undergraduate degree in biological sciences from Michigan State University in 1981. He completed his Masters degree in 1984, at the University of California, Santa Cruz, and his Ph.D. in 1990, from the University of California, Berkeley, where he studied under the mentorship of renowned paleontologist Kevin Padian. Erickson’s research has been supported by grants from the National Science Foundation, the National Geographic Society, and other organizations. His work has been featured in National Geographic magazine, Natural History magazine, Nature, Science, and other popular science publications. He has also served as a reviewer for academic journals such as the Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology and The Anatomical Record. Erickson is an outspoken believer in the importance of science education. He often speaks publicly on the topics of science and outreach, particularly in public forums and schools. He has served as a speaker at conferences, lectures, and other science education events, and as an editorial board member for the journal PaleoEducation. Erickson's research has greatly contributed to the field of vertebrate paleontology. He has published numerous books and scientific papers on the topics of dinosaur growth, dinosaurs and birds, and the evolution of mammals. He is a member of the Society of Vertebrate Paleontology, and has served in various executive committees for the organization. In addition to his academic accomplishments, Erickson is an avid outdoorsman and an enthusiastic photographer. He enjoys spending time in the outdoors and often incorporates his photographs into his academic lectures.

Sebastián Arce (born 1983) is an Argentinian DJ, producer and sound engineer. His career in the electronic music industry began in 1999, making him a pioneer in the Latin American music scene. Arce studied musical production, engineering and composition at the National Institute of Popular Music. After his studies, he co-founded Planasound, a professional recording and mixing studio in Mar del Plata, Argentina. During this time he also began crafting his own house music sound. In 2008, he released his debut EP, Sublime Drop, on Esperanza Records. The following year, he produced an album, Wurks 4 Daze, with Jazzanova and Charles Webster. Since then, Arce has gone on to produce collaborations with a number of world-renowned producers and DJs, including Alexkid, David Israel, and Losoul. He has released a number of original creations and remixes on labels such as Get Physical Music, Innervisions, Lost My Dog and Mähtrasher. He is also the A&R of Plaza Records. Arce has gained international recognition for his sets, performing around the globe at various gatherings and events, such as the Panorama Bar and the Sunday Club in Germany, Social Club and Showcase in France, and Fabric in the UK. Additionally, he has been part of a number of well-known festivals, having appeared at the renowned Sónar Festival and the Tomorrowland Festival in Belgium. In 2012, he was named Best DJ Artist by Beatport. Today, Arce lives in Buenos Aires and is an innovator in electronic music in Latin America. He continues to produce and perform worldwide, bringing his unique sound to audiences around the world.

The Detroit Mercy Titans are the men's and women's sports teams representing the University of Detroit Mercy in Detroit, Michigan. The university is a member of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) and competes in the Horizon League. The athletic department fields 18 varsity teams: 8 men's and 10 women's teams. The men's teams are basketball, cross-country, golf, lacrosse, soccer, tennis, and indoor and outdoor track and field. The women's sports consist of basketball, cross-country, golf, lacrosse, rowing, soccer, tennis, indoor and outdoor track and field, and softball. The Detroit Mercy Titans have won several Horizon League championships over the years, most recently the 2018 Men's Basketball Championship. The men's basketball team has also made several NCAA Tournament appearances, including one Sweet 16 appearance. The Titans compete in a variety of other sports as well, such as swimming and diving, volleyball, and water polo. Detroit Mercy also offers club and intramural sports options for students. The Titan logo includes a stylized "T" with a crown above it, and the university mascot is the Titan King. The school colors are blue and gold. The Titan Athletic Department is responsible for creating a positive and safe experience for all student athletes. They also promote integrity, respect, and teamwork. The department is supported by the university's Board of Trustees and the Athletic Director. The department has also established several committees focused on academics, diversity, and fundraising. The Titan Athletic Department strives to create a culture of excellence and success for Detroit Mercy student athletes. They recognize the importance of academic success and strive to foster an environment where student athletes can excel. They also encourage community involvement and pride in the Detroit Mercy community.

Mark French (born February 4, 1982) is a Canadian former professional ice hockey player. Born in Scarborough, Ontario, French attended the University of Alaska Anchorage, where he played four seasons (2000–2004) of NCAA Division I hockey with the Seawolves. He was the team’s leading scorer in 2003–04, with 19 goals and 25 assists for 44 points in 27 games. He was named to the CCHA All-Conference third team for his breakout campaign. French was signed as a free agent by the Washington Capitals in 2004. He then split the 2004-05 season between the Capitals’ AHL affiliate, the Hershey Bears, and its ECHL affiliate, the South Carolina Stingrays. He finished the season in South Carolina, where he recorded 7 goals and 33 assists in the regular season and 5 points in 11 playoff games. In 2005–06, French returned to the Bears and recorded 8 goals and 15 assists in a full AHL season. French’s solid play earned him a call up to the Caps, joining Washington for five games and notching his first NHL goal during the stretch. He stayed with the Capitals for the entire 2006–07 season, posting 2 goals and 5 assists in 44 games. French was traded to the Pittsburgh Penguins before the 2007–08 season, but he didn’t appear in any NHL games with the team. He split the season between the AHL's Wilkes-Barre/Scranton Penguins and their ECHL affiliate, the Wheeling Nailers. He spent the 2008–09 season back with the Hershey Bears on an AHL-only deal, and that summer French signed with German team Hamburg Freezers, playing three seasons in the Deutsche Eishockey Liga (DEL). Since 2012, French has continued to ply his trade in the DEL, and in 2014–15 he served as an assistant coach and player for the Schwenninger Wild Wings. French announced his retirement at the end of that season. Following his retirement, French became a scout for the Edmonton Oilers in August 2016. He currently lives in Edmonton with his wife, Kristin, and their two children. French represented Canada twice at the World Junior Championships, in 2001 and 2002. Overall, French enjoyed a 12-year professional career and spent parts of four seasons in the NHL.

The Battle of Reims, fought on 13–14 March 1814, was an important engagement of the Napoleonic Wars. It was an Allied victory that effectively ended any hope of the French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte remaining atop the French throne. The battle pitted the garrisons at Reims and their surroundings under the command of Jean-Jacques Ambert against a superior force of 22,000 men and sixty-four guns of the Sixth Coalition commanded by Prince Blücher. The fighting took place in and around the city of Reims, located in modern-day France. The Sixth Coalition consisted of troops from Prussia, Austria, Württemberg, Bavaria, and Russia, while the French forces numbered around 17,000 men and forty guns. Blücher deployed his troops in a modified formation that created a defensive circle around the city, intending to hold fast to the superior firepower of their artillery. On the other hand, the French used a concentration of men and guns, hoping to break through the Allied lines. The battle began on the morning of 13 March with an attack by the French forces against the Allies’ northern flank. The attack was repelled, but the Allies' defensive circle was breached in the east, allowing the French to advance into the city. Despite a desperate counter-attack, the French managed to maintain their momentum and fought their way further into Reims. After a night of desperate fighting, and no further gains for the French, Blücher ordered a retreat. The retreat was executed and the French, exhausted from the previous days fighting, were unable to stop it. The Battle of Reims ended in an Allied victory. Approximately 11,000 French troops were taken prisoner, along with forty guns. Additionally, numerous ammunition and provisions were captured by the Allies. On the other side, Allied losses totaled around 5,400 men, including two generals and thirty guns. The Battle of Reims was a decisive victory for the Sixth Coalition and marked a turning point in the Napoleonic Wars. Afterward, Napoleon's hold on Europe began to unravel and the Allies began their advance into France. The fall of Reims was the first step in the Allies' march to an eventual victory at the Battle of Waterloo.

The 1973 Wirral Metropolitan Borough Council election took place on 3 May 1973 to elect members of Wirral Metropolitan Borough Council in Merseyside, England. This election was held on the same day as other local elections. The Labour Party won most seats, gaining five from the Conservatives. While Labour increased their majority on the council, overall the Conservatives gained more seats than Labour from the previous election and actually gained two more councillors than Labour, having 16 councillors to Labour's 14. The Liberal Party also gained one councillor. The electoral wards used for the 1973 election were the same as those decided in a 1968 boundary review. All wards were single-member. As a result of the election, the composition of the council was: * Labour: 14 * Conservative: 16 * Independent: 1 The election was the first in Wirral since the creation of the Metropolitan Borough in April 1974. Previously, members served on Birkenhead Borough Council (established 1877), Wallasey Borough Council (1900) and Hoylake Urban District Council (1889). Turnout in the election was over 48%. The results of the 1973 election had the potential to shake-up council leadership, as the Labour majority could controversially be repealed. The first mayor of Wirral was Alderman David Goldie, who was elected at the council's inaugural meeting following the election. After the election, a Conservative-Liberal Democrat coalition government was formed. The proposal was forged by Bruce Ishikawa, the newly elected Conservative councillor for the Heswall ward. Despite the council's previous majority under Labour, the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats came into power citing the need for greater cooperation between the groups. At the council's inaugural meeting Labour abstained from voting on the arrangement, with Labour councillor Mary Dunn expressing the party's disappointment that there was no real joint government between the two parties. The coalition government lasted until the 1977 local election, where Labour regained the majority on the council. The Conservative-Liberal Democrat coalition was dubbed the "Mission Impossible" government due to its unorthodox ruling of a Labour-majority council. Category:Wirral Leaks Category:1973 English local elections Category:1970s in Merseyside Category:20th century in Merseyside Category: May 1973 events in the United Kingdom

Clay Schexnayder (born 1989) is an American basketball coach, currently the head coach for the Tulane men's basketball team. He previously served as an assistant coach with the LSU Tigers men's basketball team from 2013 to 2021. A native of Plano, Texas, Schexnayder attended Jesuit High School in Dallas, Texas and was a four-year letter winner in basketball. He was a two-time offensive team MVP (2003 and 2006) and a four-time scholar-athlete All-District selection. Following his high school career, he attended Weatherford College, where he was a freshman All-American while helping lead the Bulldogs to the school's first 20-win season in school history. He then transferred to Texas A&M University, where he served as a team captain and played in 90 total games in his two-year career. Following his playing career, Schexnayder served as the director of basketball operations at Galveston Community College. He then moved on to McNeese State University, where he served for two years as an assistant coach. In 2013, Schexnayder was hired by LSU as an assistant coach and was part of head coach Johnny Jones' staff for eight seasons, where he helped the Tigers make it to the NCAA Tournament three times during his tenure. In June 2021, Schexnayder was named the head coach for the Tulane men's basketball program. He succeeds Mike Dunleavy Sr., who had been fired that same month. With the hiring, he becomes the 13th head coach in program history. Schexnayder is married to his wife Jessica, and they have a son, Austin.

List of rural localities in Udmurtia is a comprehensive list of all rural localities in the Republic of Udmurtia, a federal subject of the Russian Federation. Udmurtia is located in the north-west corner of the Volga Federal District. The region covers approximately 43,600 square kilometers and has a population of 1.73 million people as of 2019. Udmurtia is divided into 24 districts, 5 town districts and 1 city district, and a total of 540 rural localities, including settlements, villages, aul (hamlets) and others. The Alnashsky Rural Okrug, located in the north-western part of the republic, contains 25 rural localities, the largest of which is the village of Nizhny Sinyachik. In the centre is the Ivanovo-Vozrozhdenny Rural Okrug with 28 rural localities, the largest of which is the village of Sapoka. The Balezinsky Rural Okrug, located in the south-eastern corner of Udmurtia, contains the most localities with 51, the largest of which is the village of Novaya Petrovka. The following table provides a list of the 540 rural localities in Udmurtia, organized by administrative level and district (including the city district). The list includes the type of locality, name, population and coordinates data, except for the independently administered cities, which are included in their own respective districts. In most cases, the localities on this list are classified as “rural” according to the 2010 official Russian definition of rural settlemants, which includes settlements of various sizes, but excludes independent cities and towns. This definition of rural settlements is applied to all regions of the Russian Federation, including Udmurtia. Udmurtia is home to a wide variety of cultural and natural attractions and the region serves as an important gateway to the Middle and Deep Volga Region. It is also a major producer of oil and gas, has a thriving agricultural sector, and is home to many quaint villages and rural districts. The localities listed here are only a small part of the vast number of interesting destinations, activities, and attractions in the Republic of Udmurtia. References: • National Population Census of the Russian Federation (2019), Federal State Statistics Service • Official website of Udmurtia • Kuvayev, A. V., Chetverikov, A. V., & Akhmetov, E. I. (2018). Geographical Dictionary of Udmurtia. Moscow: Research and Publishing Center "Znanie. Active Citizenship". • Article 64 of the Russian Federation Law on “State Regulation of the Rural Zone of the Russian Federation”, 2018 • Official website of the Volga Federal District

Overton Loyd (born January 6, 1942) is an American professional basketball player. Loyd was born in Quinton, Alabama and attended John T. Park High School in Birmingham, Alabama. After high school, he chose to stay in Alabama and attended the University of Alabama where he became a star player on their basketball team. During his college career he was an All-SEC Second Team selection and was named to the ABCA and USBWA All-American Second Teams. He was also a Final Four participant in 1965. After graduating, Loyd was selected in the 1967 NBA Draft by the San Francisco Warriors, with whom he played the 1967-68 season. During that season, he averaged 7.5 points in 45 games and became the first African-American to play in a Warriors uniform. He then played the 1968-69 season in Canada with the Vancouver Nighthawks of the Eastern Professional Basketball League. In 1969, Loyd was one of the original members of the American Basketball Association (ABA), after signing as a free agent with the Miami Floridians. His time in Miami was short-lived, and he was traded to the Kentucky Colonels in 1970. With Kentucky, he became part of the infamous ABA-style play, leading to their victory in the 1975 ABA Championship. During his time in Kentucky, Loyd continuously maintained a starting role and was known for his aggressive play. Later in his career, he joined the Los Angeles Lakers in 1976 and stayed with them for two seasons until his retirement in 1978. After his retirement from the NBA, Loyd coached basketball at the high school, college and NBA summer league levels. He is currently living in Birmingham, Alabama and works as a real estate broker. Loyd has been inducted into the Alabama Sports Hall of Fame and the Kentucky Colonels Hall of Fame in recognition of his success in professional basketball. He was also recognized in the 2013 film "Free Throw: The Legend of Overton Loyd" which tells the story of his life.

David Menhennet is an Australian entrepreneur, author, and speaker in the fields of business, technology and hospitality. He is the founder of the TBS Group, a hospitality and business training organization. He is especially renowned for his innovation and expertise in developing training solutions for small business and hospitality industry. Menhennet attended the University of New South Wales, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree, followed by post-graduate studies and qualifications in business, advertising, and marketing. In 1987 Menhennet founded the TBS Group– he saw a need in the hospitality industry for providing clients and partners with better training solutions. He aimed to provide customers with skills and knowledge needed to improve operational efficiency and customer service. TBS Group evolved to become an industry leader in hospitality and business training solutions. It offers a full range of consulting and training services, including performance improvement, risk management, compliance and accreditation, mentoring and facilitation, and franchise system audit and development. Menhennet has written two best-selling business and hospitality books, “The Wiseman’s Guide to Thriving in the Hospitality Industry” and “Negotiating with Giants: The Key to Business Negotiations”. He is also well known for his lectures and seminars in many countries, for which he has won numerous awards. Menhennet's philosophy is centered on the belief that people need to be nurtured by their work environment, treated with respect and valued for their contribution, and should be able to realize their dreams and aspirations in achieving financial freedom and lifestyle choices. Through his work and writing, Menhennet has strived to provide solutions which enable businesses to utilize their human resources and propel corporate culture to its highest potential. Menhennet's passion for the hospitality industry is evident in the relationships he has formed in the industry and the motivation he has provided for young professionals to join the ranks of innovative and successful hospitality entrepreneurs. Through his work he has shaped the industry to be more responsive to the changing needs of the market, focusing on digital marketing, customer experience and sustainability. In 2014 Menhennet proudly became a Fellow of the Australian Institute of Management and retired in 2018 to continue writing, lecturing and providing guidance to small business owners.

Hindol State was a princely state in India, located in what is now Odisha, located in the south-western part of the Bengal Presidency. It was founded in 1789 by Raja Narayan Singh, the eldest son of the last zamindar of Balugaon. Hindol State had an area of 1708 square km and was divided into 8 tehsils. The population as of 1931 was 203,383 with 79.2 inhabitants per square km. The rulers of Hindol State belonged to the Gajapati dynasty of Rajputs, claiming descent from the famous emperor of Orissa, Mukunda Dev. The capital of the state was inhabited by the ruling family and the Rajputs (Thakis). During its existence, it was administered by Hindol Agency which was a sub-division of the Bengal and Bihar Agency which was part of the Eastern States Agency. The state was annexed to Bengal in 1847 by the British. Under British rule, the state had a number of prominent institutions, such as the Rajkumar College, Hindol government High School, and several other schools and colleges. The Rajkumar College was established in 1849 and was the only institution of higher education in the state. It was known as the "Bhagavatha College" in the royal times and has since been renowned for its high standards of education. It has produced several notable alumni, including S.Sivabhaktan, Sriguru Das, and B.Devakaran. During its existence, Hindol state had also been partially integrated into India. The Legislative Council of the state had been abolished after the declaration of independence in 1947, and the state was fully absorbed into the province of Orissa in 1951 following the reorganization of Indian states. Despite its brief existence, Hindol state had left a lasting impression on the culture and history of Orissa. The inhabitants still revere its rulers as legendary figures. Its various monuments, such as the Rajkumar College and the Thakis' Palace, still stand as reminders of its past glory.

System Development Corporation (SDC) is a business and technology services provider that provides information systems, technical consulting, software engineering, project engineering, and much more. Founded in 1956, the company provides services to businesses of all sizes in the United States and worldwide. SDC provides a wide range of services to its clients, from consulting to custom software development, with the goal of helping organizations improve their operations and slash their costs. SDC's service offerings include: business process analysis, program management and integration, systems design, and development, operations support, network and database engineering, systems administration, IT security, access management and training. The company also provides a wide range of services in support of enterprise applications, such as Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP). The company is further divided into four divisions: Consulting Services, Business Applications, Web Services, and Technology Solutions. Consulting Services provides financial consulting services for companies’ accounting and tax needs, as well as business process reengineering. The Business Applications division offers software development and integration, enterprise application integration and management, and database maintenance and development. Web Services covers server and network management, web applications, and e-commerce solutions. Technology Solutions focuses on systems design and implementation, performance engineering, and network monitoring. SDC has built a reputation for quality and reliability, winning awards for its work such as “The World’s Best Employee Retention Strategy” from the CIO Magazine, The Microsoft Corporation Partner of the Year Award, The Internet World “GoMarketing” Award, The Transaction Processing Council 2007 Award, and many more. The organization is known for its commitment to ethical standards and community involvement. Due to its reputation, SDC has earned the trust of many prominent organizations. Its past clients include The Department of Justice, NASA, The Centers for Disease Control and prevention, The Pentagon, and The Department of Defense. In an ever-evolving world, SDC continues to remain on the cutting-edge of business and technology and to take a leading role in helping organizations deliver superior customer service through their IT initiatives. Through its vast array of services, and impressive list of clients, it is no surprise SDC has become one of the world’s top providers of business and technology services.

Richard D. Todd (19401-2001) was an American mathematician, computer scientist, and professor at Carnegie Mellon University. He was best known for pioneering research in logic programming and programming language design, with significant contributions to the development of Prolog, predicate calculus, and the programming language PROLOG. Todd was born in Dallas, Texas in 1940. He received his B.A. in mathematics from the University of Texas at Austin in 1961, and his M.S. and PhD degrees in mathematics from Harvard University in 1962 and 1965 respectively. He then became a professor of Mathematics at Carnegie Mellon University and was there until 2001, when he retired. He was also a visiting professor at the University of Pittsburgh and Ohio University. Todd's research interests were in the areas of program synthesis, programming language design, and in the application of logic to computing. He developed the theories of predicate calculus and programming language PROLOG, or programming in logic. He worked with French professor Alain Colmerauer to develop the programming language Prolog, which was published in the 1970s. He also worked on the development of the programming language 2Lisp and the automated logic prover Otter. He collaborated extensively with other researchers in the areas of logic and programming, most notably Noam Chomsky, with whom he coauthored a book, Programming in Prolog, in 1979. Throughout his career, Todd was recognized for his contribution to the field of programming, receiving numerous awards and recognitions, including the ACM Turing Award, the highest honor in computer science. He was a fellow of the American Mathematical Society and of both the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers and the Association for Computing Machinery. He was also the chairman of the Computer Science Department at Carnegie Mellon University and a member of the National Academy of Sciences. Todd passed away in 2001, at the age of 61, but left behind a legacy of research and innovation that continues to influence programming language design today. He was remembered by many as a creative and visionary thinker and as a passionate teacher, who always strived to make difficult topics accessible to students and colleagues alike.

Pawnee Chief is a term for the leaders of the American Indian Pawnee people. The Pawnee Chief worked as the primary cultural and political leader of the Pawnee Nation. The Pawnee are a Native American tribe who lived primarily in what is now Nebraska, Kansas and Oklahoma. The Pawnee have a long history of leadership and authority, traced back to the mid-14th century. The Pawnee were actively trading with Europeans throughout the late 17th and early 18th centuries, at which time the chiefs held nearly all the political power within their society. The Pawnee Chief had several duties and responsibilities. They served as the spiritual leaders of their people, as well as the political leaders. Chiefs were responsible for managing relationships with other tribes and nations and negotiating treaties. Chiefs also maintained law and order within their community and were responsible for seeing to the livelihood of their people, which included food supply, hunting and agriculture. The Pawnee Chief also had a large role in the spiritual and religious aspects of the culture. They were responsible for mediating disputes between individuals and factions and for organizing festive gatherings and spiritual rituals. Chiefs also conducted ceremonies such as the Sun Dance and performed healing rituals for the sick and wounded. The Pawnee Chief was typically the eldest and most respected male in the tribe, often selected by both the elders and the younger members of the tribe based on his ability to lead. The Chief was traditionally respected and obeyed by all members of the tribe. The Pawnee Chief held strong support from within his people and was respected as a great leader and protector. He was respected for his ability to lead and guide his tribe through difficult times and for his willingness to put the tribe's needs before his own. The role of the Pawnee Chief during the 19th century was especially important as the tribe tried to survive the challenges and hardships of life on the Plains. The Chief was the voice and the heart of the Pawnee Nation and was responsible for the wellbeing of his tribe.

. Jiří Wolker (18 February 1896 – 28 December 1924) was a Czech poet, journalist, playwright and revolutionary. He was one of the leading figures of the Czech avant-garde in the early 20th century, and one of the most influential Czech poets of the interwar period. Wolker was born into a Jewish middle-class family in the small town of Sedlčany. As a student in Prague, he became involved in revolutionary activities; he was imprisoned for a year for his involvement in the The Workers’ Sport International and the Young Czech Social-Democrats. This experience shaped his social and political views, which he expressed through his writing. Writing became his passion, and he wrote hundreds of poems, plays, and essays over the course of his short life. Wolker's best-known works include his poem "The Ballad of Young Heřman", which tells of a man who gives up his life in a fight against gendarmes to save his friend, and "Thoughts on Life and Death". He also wrote many plays, including The Provincial Robbers and The Knife Maker. His poetry was notable for its rhythmic, passionate expression of love, loss, and struggle. He was deeply influenced by the Czech folklore of his youth and by romanticism, but his works also echoed the disillusionment of the avant-garde; his themes were often dark and macabre. Though he achieved fame during his lifetime, he died in poverty in 1924 at the age of 28, having been struck by a deadly form of tuberculosis. His death, both tragic and untimely, caused a great shock in the Czech Literary community. Today, he is remembered as an inspiration to writers and poets, and as one of the most original figures of the Czech avant-garde. His writings continue to be influential in the Czech Republic, and in 2010 he was commemorated with an exhibition in Prague.

J. B. Nethercutt was an American automotive entrepreneur who co-founded Merle Norman Cosmetics and later established The Nethercutt Collection in Sylmar, California. He is widely credited with being the driving force behind the proliferation of the automobile in the United States. Born in Raleigh, North Carolina in 1895, Nethercutt was the son of a wealthy furniture manufacturer. At the age of fourteen he moved to California with his family and became an apprentice at a shoe factory. After his apprenticeship, he worked for the Hines Shoe Company in Los Angeles, where he developed a passion for cars and everything to do with the automobile industry. In 1925, Nethercutt and his childhood friend, Merle Nethercutt Norman, founded their first business; Merle Norman Cosmetics. This business rapidly became a nationwide success and would become one of the most recognized and successful cosmetic businesses in the world. In the late 1950s, Nethercutt decided to start collecting cars. As his collection soon became too large to house, he purchased a building which would become The Nethercutt Collection, the first publicly funded automobile museum. This museum became a unique collection of 19th and early 20th century automobiles, and is one of the largest and most respected private collections of its kind. Nethercutt was a dedicated philanthropist and declared his intention to donate the entire collection to an educational institution in the future. In 1988, after his death, it was announced that the Nethercutt Collection and Foundation would merge with the Smithsonian Institution, ensuring the preservation and accessibility of the museum for future generations. Nethercutt not only preserved the history of the automobile, but also made sure that the industry would continue to thrive and develop. He is remembered for his foresight and dedication to the automotive industry, and his contributions to the cultural and economic growth of Los Angeles.

Sigrid de Lima (born 17 August 1979) is a Brazilian chef, entrepreneur, philanthropist and television personality based in Miami, USA. She is best known as the creator/presenter of 'Sigrid de Lima's World Flavours', a long-running multi-award winning television cooking show which has been broadcast in over 80 countries. Born in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Sigrid grew up surrounded by food, learning to cook traditional Brazilian dishes from an early age. She developed a strong interest in cookery and, with support from her family, she trained at a prestigious Swiss gastronomy school. After developing her culinary skills, Sigrid began her professional career as a personal chef in Europe. She quickly gained a reputation for her knowledge of international cuisine and received invitations to appear on television cookery shows and with high-profile personalities, such as Madonna. In 2009, Sigrid moved to Miami and maintained her profile as a personal chef. She also began a new project, writing and presenting Sigrid de Lima’s World Flavours. This 13-part series was aired in the USA, Latin America and the Caribbean, and received numerous awards, including the International Emmy Award for Best Culinary Program. In addition to her work on Sigrid de Lima’s World Flavours, Sigrid has written several books, including ‘Eating Around the Globe’, and has secured partnerships with high-end fashion labels such as Giorgio Armani and Hugo Boss. Since 2014, Sigrid has been actively involved in several charities, raising money for food related projects, education for young girls in Africa and social welfare works in South America. Sigrid is an inspirational figure for many young people around the world and continues to lead projects that are focused on providing access to food and education for people in challenging circumstances.

Turning the other cheek is one of the most recognized and important teachings of Christianity and as such has been quoted by many prominent figures and theologians throughout history. It is a concept full of complex spiritual implications, and exemplifies one of the most powerful and fundamental Christian values. The phrase first appears in the New Testament of the Bible in a passage from the Sermon on the Mount, which is attributed to the words of Jesus. It reads: "You have heard that it was said, An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth. But I tell you, Do not resist an evil person. If someone strikes you on the right cheek, turn to him the other also." (NIV, Matthew 5:38-39) The phrase "turning the other cheek" has been interpreted in many ways over the years. Broadly speaking, it refers to the idea of "forgiveness" in the face of hurt, injustice, and oppression. It suggests we should not retaliate when faced with evil and injustice, but instead, we should find it in our hearts to show compassion and understanding. Turning the other cheek is seen as a much more meaningful and effective response than a violent reaction which can only lead to more hurt and violence. By responding without violence, Christians can take a moral stand and exemplify their faith while standing up to evil. In the modern world, the concept of turning the other cheek has become the standard for compassionate and responsible behavior, and is a crucial part of living a meaningful and peaceful life. Martin Luther King Jr., a leader in the civil rights movement, often spoke of the importance of turning the other cheek, where he stated "We must love our white brothers, no matter what they do to us. We must make them know that we love them. Jesus still cries out across the centuries, 'Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, pray for them that despitefully use you'." Turning the other cheek is more than just an example of kindness and compassion, it is an example of strength and courage that stands in the face of evil and oppression. It reminds us that we can reclaim our power and self-esteem, and prevent future hurt, by responding peacefully and thoughtfully in the face of danger or mistreatment. It helps us to look beyond our own needs and see the needs of others, and act in the best interest of all. In summary, turning the other cheek is one of the most significant teachings in Christianity, where it carries the powerful message to rise above injustice and to not allow hurt and violence beget more hurt and violence. It is an example of responding with compassion, and of reclaiming our power by responding peacefully and thoughtfully in the face of evil.

Raja (2019 film) is an Indian Tamil language fantasy drama starring K. G. Venkatesh. Written and directed by M.V.Muthu, Raja is a tale about fulfilling dreams through hard work and determination. Plot Raja (K.G. Venkatesh) is an ordinary middle-class man, who works hard to provide for his family. After a tragedy in which his son falls off a bridge and becomes paralyzed, Raja and his family believes that their dreams are shattered. His wife is supportive and helps him stand up in this time of struggle. Raja is determined to fulfill his son's dreams and begins to work towards that goal. He meets a mysterious old man named Parvathi (M.V.Muthu) who tells him a secret. He tells Raja that he must travel to Tirumala and complete seven day prayer to get his son back to health. Raja embarks on a difficult and dangerous journey to Tirumala, amidst several obstacles and fights against social evils. After completing all seven days of prayer, the miracle happens and his son is finally cured. Raja's family is filled with joy and joy fills the hearts of the villagers. Cast K. G. Venkatesh as Raja M.V.Muthu as Parvathi P.V.K. Prasad as Raju N.V.M. Muthu as Selvi Vasu Samaroo as Udhay G.S. Lakshminarayanan as Gowtham Sathish Babu as Singam R. Rama as Jaya Production Raja is directed by M.V.Muthu, who has previously directed films like Vallinam and Onnu Rendu. It was shot over a period of five months in villages around Thiruvannamalai, Tamil Nadu. Cinematography was done by N. Thirumaran and editing by S. Pradeep. The film was produced by P.V.K. Prasad and distributed by Shakthi Chitra Films.. Soundtrack The soundtrack of the film is composed by S. S. Rajendhar and lyrics written by Pulavar Hameed. Release The film was released on 6 June 2019 to Generally Positive Reviews. The film was praised by the critics for its excellent cinematography, characterization and the pleasing performance of the lead actors. The film was successfully run for about 50 days in Tamil Nadu and other south Indian cities. However, due to its low budget and limited release, it failed to have success in the box office. Awards Raja won the Best Feature Film (Tamil) at the 66th National Film Awards in 2019. The jury praised the film for its “simple story that showcased the values and sorrows of ordinary people with natural surroundings”. External links Raja (2019 film) on IMDb (https://www.imdb.com/title/tt10315362/)

Harry Hiestand (born May 14, 1957 in Toledo, Ohio) is an American football coach. He is currently the offensive line coach for the Chicago Bears of the National Football League (NFL). Hiestand began his college coaching career at Carroll College of the NAIA in 1983, and also served as head coach from 1985-1987. In 1988, he joined the University of Illinois staff as the offensive line coach, and remained there until 2005. He achieved national prominence with the success of Big Ten Conference champions Illinois teams in 2001 and 2002. He was a key factor in the development of elite NFL players such as center Peter Kinder (Buffalo Bills) and guard Ryan Lilja (Indianapolis Colts). He is regarded as one of the premier offensive line coaches in the nation. After leaving Illinois in 2005, he joined the staff of the University of Tennessee as the offensive line coach, where he maintained his stellar coaching resume. He was responsible for the development of offensive linemen who went on to successful NFL careers, such as Jack and Eric Cook, Alex Walls and David Ligon. In 2010, Hiestand joined the staff of the Notre Dame Fighting Irish under head coach Brian Kelly, and he was instrumental in the development of offensive linemen Zack Martin and Ronnie Stanley. Both were drafted in the first round of the NFL Draft in their respective years. The success of the Fighting Irish offensive line in 2012 earned Hiestand the distinction of being named the Football Writers Association of America Offensive Line Coach of the Year. In 2018, Hiestand joined the coaching staff of the Chicago Bears, replacing previous offensive line coach John Fox. Under his tutelage, the offensive line unit has improved significantly. He is responsible for the individual improvement of Bears offensive lineman James Daniels and Charles Leno, Jr. In 2019, Hiestand was recognized as Pro Football Focus’ Offensive Line Coach of the Year. Hiestand is widely considered one of the best offensive line coaches in the NFL today and is credited with the development of multiple Pro Bowlers. He is known for his demanding yet positive demeanour, emphasizing technique and fundamentals in the pursuit of success.

Used to Love is a song by Dutch DJ and producer Martin Garrix and Australian singer-songwriter Dean Lewis. Released on November 30, 2019, the track is the fourth single from Garrix's upcoming fourth studio album. The track starts out with Dean Lewis' soulful and melancholic vocals, followed by a lush and dance-like production by Martin Garrix. The two artists blend electronic and acoustic elements, which result in an emotion-charged song. The track is a melancholy yet upbeat electronica, exploring themes of emotional pain and break-up. Lewis shares his emotional trauma through his angelic vocals and speaks of a relationship that had gone wrong. Garrix accentuates and emphasizes the lyrics of Lewis' verses with a catchy chorus and a powerful blend of EDM and rock influences. The song has an inspirational tone of resilience, recognizing that breakups are uncomfortable but you must be strong, because life will continue to move on. The single was released for streaming and digital purchases on November 30, 2019. The accompanying music video was premiered on Martin Garrix's official YouTube channel on December 7, 2019. It was directed by Emil Nava and takes an experimental route with a unique narrative. The video follows the duo in an action-packed car chase, showcasing close-up shots of Garrix as he is racing on the highway. It received acclaim from music video critics and was described as a “distinct visual experience” by Billboard. The track performed well on the music charts, reaching number one in the UK Dance Chart and number three on the US Dance/Mix Show Airplay chart. It also peaked at number nine on the UK Singles Chart and number twenty-four in Australia. The single was also Grammy-nominated in the 2021 lineup, where it was in the running for "Best Dance Recording". Garrix and Lewis were two artists whose styles had already been well known before their collaboration, so Used to Love served as a reminder of their potential to make an inspiring and successful single together. The track is well-received by fans and critics alike and continues to be a fan favorite.

Myself World Tour is the debut album by American singer-songwriter, Tori Simms. Released on March 27th 2020, the album is a departure from her previous musical styles, which were heavily influenced by alternative and indie rock genres. Myself World Tour is a collection of twelve pop-influenced songs, drawing on sounds from synth-pop and R&B. Simms wrote and produced the entire album, and for the first time included several features from other notable artists such as Khalid and H.E.R. The lead single from the album, "My Way", was released in February 2020. The song quickly gained mainstream radio play, peaking at number ten on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart. The song's themes of self-discovery and rediscovery are a prominent component of the album, and are prevalent in the other single releases; "Floating" and "Change". Upon its release, Myself World tour was widely praised by critics. The album scored an 86 on Metacritic, indicating "universal acclaim" among publications. Myself World Tour was commercially well received, debuting at number four on the US Billboard 200 chart. In total, the album has produced three top-ten hits, noteworthy for Simms's previous lack of mainstream radio recognition. The success of the album catapulted it to win the 2021 Grammy awards for Best Pop Vocal Album, and a nomination for Album of the Year. The album also received platinum certification from the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA). In the summer of 2020, Simms launched her first world tour in support of the album. She primarily visited North American venues, selling out several shows. After being postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the remaining leg of the tour was rescheduled for October 2021, with a few extra dates around Europe and the United Kingdom. To promote the tour, Simms partnered with other companies to launch giveaways and exclusive merchandise. Some of these promotions included the chance to fly to meet Simms at the beginning of the tour, or to win VIP tickets to shows with backstage access. With Myself World Tour, Tori Simms has solidified her status as an international pop sensation. The album has been released to critical and commercial success, and the pending tour is one of the most anticipated events of the year. The album has received global recognition for its universal themes and production quality, and is set to stay as a defining in the genre of pop music.

Robert Auth (born 1949) is an American businessman, philanthropist, and political activist. He is the Chairman of Maxus Financial Limited, a Los Angeles-based financial services company and the founder of the Auth Foundation, an organization dedicated to advancing public policy solutions that impact poverty and public health. Prior to founding Maxus Financial in 1999, Auth served as the Executive Director of Goldman Sachs International, where he managed a group of specialists in structured finance, loan syndications, retail and institutional asset management, and private interests. During his tenure, Auth was responsible for the origination and execution of transactions related to the development and capitalization of emerging markets. Auth is best known for his advocacy for greater access to financial services to the economically marginalized. His long-standing commitment to promoting financial literacy and financial inclusion started during his tenure at Goldman Sachs serving emerging markets with various philanthropic commitments and partnerships. Auth is a co-author of the book, Investing for Impact: Mobilizing Private Capital to Public Good and the Art of Financial Structuring (2018), a comprehensive book for investors and finance professionals looking to deploy their resources to meet societal needs. Auth also wrote Start-Up Financing: A Guide for Entrepreneurs, Investors, and Investment Bankers, which provides a practical guide to secure start-up capital. He serves on the boards of several organizations dedicated to poverty alleviation, microfinance and public health including the Grameen Foundation, The Social and Human Capital Collaborative, Mimslyn Inn, and Chilton College. In 2016, Business Insider listed Auth as one of the most influential people in finance as part of its FinTech 50 list. Auth is a passionate advocate for children's rights. He established the Auth Foundation in 2011 as a means to empower underserved communities and to help improve access to financial services and health care to those living in poverty.
