Over the years, the Auth Foundation has funded scholarships, microfinance initiatives, and economic development projects with a special focus on helping emerging markets achieve sustainability and enhancing health care systems in impoverished regions. In 2019, Auth was honored with the Los Angeles Business Journal's Service to the Community Award for his philanthropic and community service work. He was recently named "Social Impact Entrepreneur of the Year" at the 2019 African Financial Services Awards.

Karla Jessen Williamson (born April 16, 1969) is a Greenlandic social scientist, diplomat, and politician. She earned her Ph.D. in Social Anthropology from the University of Copenhagen in 2000. Williamson has been responsible for international and research policy for the Government of Greenland. She also served as Greenland's Ambassador to the Arctic Council from 2015 to 2019 and Greenland's Ambassador to the United States from 2015 to 2019. She is currently the Vice-Chair of the Arctic Council's Senior Arctic Officials. Williamson has had a long career in public service and research in the Arctic. From 2006-2011 she was a member of the Greenlandic Inatsisartut and was the Minister for Education, Culture, Church and Foreign Affairs. In this role she had specific responsibility for Greenland’s emergence as a recognized nation, and responsibility for its foreign policy and international relations. She also worked in the private sector as Vice-President of the Assat Corporation, a Greenlandic private holding company, from 2003-2005. Williamson has been an outspoken advocate on the need for greater engagement of the Arctic, including in addressing climate change and promoting sustainable development in the Arctic. She has served in numerous capacities on Arctic Council Committees, including as the Chair of the Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programme (AMAP), and as a member of the Sustainable Development Working Group. In addition, Williamson served on the Permanent Participants Council, a body which provides advice on the Arctic Council's activities. Williamson has also been involved in various non-governmental activities, such as the Arctic Imperative Summit and the Arctic Energy Summit. Most recently, she is a member of the International Arctic Science Committee, an organization that provides scientific advice about the Arctic to various national and international bodies. In recognition of her contributions to the Arctic, Williamson has been made a Member of the Order of the Dannebrog in 2018, and a Knight of the Order of the Polar Star in 2019. Throughout her career, Williamson has sought to promote the interests of Greenland, and the interests of the Arctic as a whole. Her work is an example of the importance of interdisciplinary research, collaboration, and action in addressing the challenges of a changing Arctic.

Amigo is a 2010 Philippine drama film directed by John Sayles and written by Sayles and one of his frequent collaborators, Glenn Datuin. The film stars Joel Torre as Rafael "Amigo" Dacanay, a local mayor caught in the middle of a Philippine-American insurgency at the turn of the twentieth century. The film begins in 1900, with a group of American soldiers led by Major Monroe (Garret Dillahunt) arriving in a small village in the Philippines in an effort to quell the insurgency. Rafael "Amigo" Dacanay (Joel Torre) is the mayor of the village, a former Spanish soldier who has worked hard to keep the peace in the area. His efforts are complicated by the presence of local guerillas fighting for Philippine independence, and he is soon caught in a conflict between what he perceives to be his responsibility to his community and his loyalty to the American forces. Throughout the film Amigo is forced to grapple with the consequences of making seemingly impossible choices. He must decide whether to stand up for his constituents or to help the Americans with their mission. He also faces pressure from within his community surrounding his leadership, as his fellow villagers often express discontent with his decisions. In a symbolic attempt to bridge the gap between himself and his people, Amigo walks a tightrope that stretches above the village, as if to demonstrate his own vulnerability in a situation beyond his control. The film received considerable critical acclaim, with particular praise coming for Sayles' direction and Torre's performance. It was nominated for Best Feature Film at the 2010 Asian Pacific Screen Awards, and was an official selection at the 2010 Toronto International Film Festival. Its complex portrayal of Philippine-American tensions offers an interesting and thought-provoking perspective on a period in history that is often misunderstood or overlooked.

Tamnyaskey is an urban neighborhood located in the eastern part of Baltimore, Maryland. It is sometimes referred to as an "inner-city" community, due to its high concentrations of minority populations and its nearness to the city center. It is bordered by North Avenue to the North, North Charles Street to the East, West North Avenue to the South, and East North Avenue to the West. As of 2020, the population of Tamnyaskey is estimated at 4,792 people, making it one of the largest and most populous neighborhoods in Baltimore. The origin of the name of the community, Tamnyaskey, is not known. It is believed to have been derived from the name of an early resident or family, or from the area's close proximity to the Valley Railroad and Key Bridge. Tamnyaskey is a predominantly low-income community and crime rates are high with more than 1,000 violent and property crimes reported annually. However, recently there has been a downward trend in crime rates with the support of local outreach programs such as the Community Mediation Program, the Boys and Girls Clubs, and the Vacant House Initiative. These efforts have resulted in fewer reports of assaults, robberies, and burglaries. Residents of Tamnyaskey are overwhelmingly African American with some Hispanic and white minorities. In addition to its population, the area is known for its unique culture and distinct architecture. The neighborhood contains a mixture of different architectural styles including Victorian, Colonial, and Georgian homes. Tamnyaskey is served by public transportation that includes the Maryland Transit Administration (MTA) bus system, MARC train service, light rail, and subway. There are several schools within the neighborhood, including Booker T. Washington Middle School and Brehms Lane Elementary School. The Herbert A. Beall Center for Community Education, which offers educational and recreational programming for children, is located nearby. The residents of Tamnyaskey are involved in various community organizations and initiatives, such as the Tamnyaskey Community Association, which works to promote neighborliness and aid in community development. The group hosts an annual festival to celebrate local traditions and community spirit. Tamnyaskey may be known as an urban inner-city community, but it is a vibrant and diverse neighborhood with a rich history and tradition. With its commitment to public safety, educational services, and community outreach, Tamnyaskey is a neighborhood on its way up.

The AAA Fusión Championship is a professional wrestling championship recognized by the Mexican professional wrestling promotion, AAA. It was created on August 5, 2017 by AAA's then-head booker, Antonio Peña. The championship is defended only in singles matches, and is subject to the very strict AAA Fusión ruleset, which governs all specialty matches contested as part of AAA's Fusión television series. The AAA Fusión Championship has been recompeted four times: the original champion, Psycho Clown, was later succeeded by Daga on November 11, 2018, and then by Pagano on January 15, 2020, who lost the title to Pentagón Jr. in March 2020. The current champion is Black Taurus, who won the belt on December 4, 2020. To date, Psycho Clown is the longest-reigning champion, with a combined reign length of 343 days over two championships, in the first and fourth iterations of the title. Pentagón Jr.'s reign is the second-longest reign by length, lasting 300 days for his single reign. Pagano holds the unique distinction of being the only champion to win the title in three consecutive years. The championship is defended exclusively at AAA Fusión television taping, held sporadically throughout the year. To win the championship, a wrestler must pin the championship. Disqualifications and countouts do not result in a title change. As of April 2021, 11 different wrestlers have held the title for a total of 14 reigns. The championship is contested under the unique AAA Fusión ruleset, which is applied to all specialty matches on AAA Fusión programming. The ruleset, which is extremely restrictive and not often seen in other professional wrestling promotions around the world, forbids all forms of leverage pins, as well as various other forms of attack and submission. The American professional wrestling promotion, Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide, has established the AAA Fusión Championship as an important element in their Fusión television series. As such, champions are typically taken seriously and given bigger pushes on television than other wrestlers. Since its inception, the championship has been defended in various countries including Mexico, Canada, and the United States. The AAA Fusión Championship stands as one of the most respected titles in all of AAA and is often seen as a major opportunity for any placed contender. As of April 2021, the championship is currently held by Black Taurus.

Liu Kai (劉開; courtesy name Dijing (帝景)) (1022–1088) was a jinshi (禁史) and general in the Song dynasty of China. Liu was born to a prominent family in Eyang (Yixing), Jiangsu. He had an older brother, Liu Tingen (劉廷根), who was a member of the Forum. At the age of 24, Liu passed the Imperial examinations and was appointed as a provincial official in Wangdu Prefecture (望都縣) in modern Hebei. In 1054, Liu was appointed as governor of Hedong (河東), a strategic port and military base in modern Shandong. During this tenure, he was faced with the complexity of Qiang nomads, who often crossed the borders and raided border regions. In 1064, Liu was appointed as a commander in the imperial army and led a detachment of troops to fight against the Tanguts of the Western Xia. Liu then played a decisive role in the Battle of Chengdu, which was a crucial battle in the war. During the battle, the Song army successfully routed the Tangut forces, routing them from their capital, Zhuozhou (涿州). In 1068, Liu was appointed to lead a naval attack on the Jurchens of the Jin dynasty, a hostile northern neighbour. He led the successful attack on the strategic ports located in the mouth of the Yalu River (烏爾流河). Despite inflicting heavy casualties, Liu's forces were eventually forced to retreat due to the superiority of the Jin forces. In 1086, Liu was appointed to lead troops against the Wuyue kingdom of Shao (韶); he eventually routed the kingdom and the Song forces went on to occupy its capital. Liu was a patriot and a brilliant strategist. He dedicated his entire life to defending his country and was highly appreciated by the Emperor Song Huizong, who granted him a posthumous title as Grand General Wangbei Hou (望北侯). Liu is remembered to this day as an outstanding military leader and an embodiment of patriotism. He is still honored with massive statues and memorial shrines in his native city of Yixing, Jiangsu. In the present day, Liu Kai has become a popular cultural icon; inspiring movies, television shows, novels, games, and songs about his exploits. His story is used to teach lessons of patriotism and courage in Chinese classrooms. From the long history of China, Liu Kai continues to stand out as an influential and prestigious figure, revered and remembered to this day.

The National Science Museum (Thailand), or NSTM, is a Thai institution dedicated to a mission of inspiring, educating and connecting people to science and technology. The museum, located in Pathum Thani province, was established in 2015 and has since become a leading science information and exhibition venue in Thailand. The museum manages an extensive array of collections, displays, activities and services which are designed to entertain, educate and engage both adults and children. Its areas of focus include physical sciences and technology, science history and culture, life sciences and chemistry. The National Science Museum strives to share the understanding that science, technology and innovation are integral parts of everyday life. It does so through its numerous permanent and special exhibitions, including interactive displays that cover topics such as robotics, transportation, photography and space exploration. In addition to its exhibitions, the museum hosts public programmes, including seminars, lectures and science education workshops for students. It also contributes to the development of science instruction in Thai schools and provides educators with professional guidance. The NSTM is also active in research and publications. From 2015 to 2016, the museum carried out numerous research projects on various topics, in collaboration with various universities and research institutions. It has since published two books and several technical reports, including “Scientific Reports of Thailand: 2016”. In 2017, the museum established the “NSTM School of Science and Technology”, a programme that seeks to nurture and inspire talented young scientists in Thailand. The school provides opportunities such as academic and laboratory internships, research mentorships and scholarships. The National Science Museum has gained significant support from both the public and private sectors. It is also an approved location for field trips for students from participating schools in Thailand. The National Science Museum is currently undergoing renovations and expansion, with plans to become a nationwide educational center for students, researchers, and the public. In addition, the museum is building partnerships with international institutions and organizations, in order to foster and strengthen global collaboration in the sciences.

An organoiodine compound is a chemical compound composed of organic compound and iodine. These compounds are commonly used in synthetic organic chemistry, particularly in the production of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals and synthetic dyes. Organoiodine compounds are often used as reagents and catalysts due to their unique reactivity and stability. Organoiodine compounds can be further divided into two categories, iolynating agents and iodinating agents. Iolynating agents are compounds that are capable of adding iodine to an existing carbon-carbon bond. These compounds can also be referred to as iodoalkene precursors. Iodinating agents are compounds that produce organoiodine compounds by the addition of iodine to an existing carbon-carbon bond. Organoiodine compounds can be synthesized in a variety of ways depending on the application. One popular method of synthesis is through iodine-catalyzed add-on reactions. These reactions take place when an iodinating agent, such as iodobenzene, reacts with a carbon-hydrogen bond in order to form an organoiodine compound. Other methods of synthesis include the use of iodine-stabilized ylides, iodine thiolates, 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds and organoiodinium salts. Organoiodine compounds are known to be toxic and should be handled with care. Exposure to organoiodine compounds can result in irritation of the eyes, skin, and mucous membranes. In addition, prolonged exposure to certain organoiodine compounds has been known to cause thyroid gland damage, as well as, neurological and reproductive damage. Organoiodine compounds have a wide range of applications. Organoiodine compounds are widely used in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and synthetic dyes. In addition, they can also be used as reagents and catalysts in a variety of organic reactions. Lastly, organoiodine compounds can be used to produce highly water-soluble iodine species, which are utilized in biological and DNA labeling. Overall, organoiodine compounds are an important class of compounds that are used in many applications. They are known to be toxic and should be handled with care. It is important to be aware of the potential health risks of exposure. With proper handling, organoiodine compounds can be used safely and effectively.

The 1993 Western Australian state election was the worst electoral defeat for the Labor Party since its victory in 1911, and the best result it had ever achieved for the Liberal-National coalition. The election was held on Saturday, 6 February 1993 and was for all 58 seats in the Legislative Assembly. The incumbent Labor government, led by Carmen Lawrence, had been in power since 1989. The state had become embroiled in two very public health scandals, and Lawrence was seen as lacking the strong leadership needed to get the state out of them. The government also found itself in a precarious financial position, with its deficit expected to balloon to $3.3 billion by the end of 1993. At the election, the Liberal and National parties, led by Richard Court, campaigned on the promise of an economic reform agenda. They also supported the privatization of public organizations, a move that had been partly reversed in recent years. The Liberal and National parties won a landslide victory, winning 39 of the 58 seats on a primary vote of 55.7%. This was an increase of 17 seats over their performance at the 1989 election. Labor's primary vote fell from 43.8% to 34.3%, and the party won just 19 seats. The Australian Democrats, who had won one seat in 1989, failed to win any in 1993. The Liberal-National Coalition was sworn in as the new government on 7 March 1993. Richard Court was elected as the first Liberal premier of Western Australia since 1983. The landslide victory marked the beginning of an unprecedented period of economic reform for the state. The state Labor Party was led by two different leaders in the months following the election. Geoff Gallop replaced Lawrence as leader in June 1994, and in February 1996, Jim McGinty was elected state leader. The government was particularly focused on improving the state's economy, providing incentives to business and eliminating bureaucracy. The Liberal-National Coalition remained in power at the 1996, 2001 and 2005 elections. Yet the 1993 election ultimately marked a dramatic shift in the state's politics, with the new Coalition government introducing dramatic and far-reaching reforms to the state's economy.

Harrison Musgrave (born April 24th, 1989) is a professional baseball pitcher for the Colorado Rockies. Musgrave was drafted in the 13th round of the 2011 MLB draft by the Rockies out of West Virginia University. Musgrave made his major league debut for the Rockies on May 30th, 2017 against the Philadelphia Phillies, pitching 5 innings, giving up 3 earned runs, striking out 4 batters and getting the no-decision. Musgrave has split his time between the Majors and Triple-A since his 2017 debut. In 2018, while pitching for the Isotopes (Triple-A), he was selected to represent the Rockies in the Triple-A All Star Game. His 2019 season was cut short due to injury and he underwent corrective surgery on his throwing elbow to repair nerve damage. Before playing two season in the Majors, Musgrave spent most of his career in the minor leagues and in Independent leagues, playing for teams such as the Ogden Raptors and the Long Island Ducks. Musgrave is known for throwing a sinker, four-seam fastball, slider, and a rarely used cutter. He uses the sinker and fastball heavily, usually accompanied by a slider to the opposite batter, who he believes can hit the slider better than the sinker. Off the field, Harrison Musgrave is an avid outdoorsman and loves to hunt and fish. He is a Pennsylvania native, and credits much of his success to growing up with a strong work ethic instilled in him by his parents. He's an active advocate for pet adoption and donates much of his time to local animal rescue organizations.

An air-gap flash is a form of solid state storage device which has a wide array of uses in computing, especially in embedded systems. It is a form of flash storage, but with a key difference in design. Unlike a traditional flash drive, which is attached directly to the circuit board via a USB port or other form of connection, the air-gap flash is designed to be 'air-gapped.' This means that the storage media is installed without being directly connected to any computer boards, instead the device receives power solely by a battery or other external means. An air-gap flash has the advantages of higher read/write speeds and greater durability than traditional flash drives. It also offers increased data safety and improved performance in hazardous or mission critical environments. Because it is air gapped, an air-gap flash also has the ability to resist physical tampering and electrical interference from outside sources. Air-gap flash is found in a variety of applications in both home and business computing settings. It is especially suited to industrial settings, where physical tampering or electromagnetic interference from other pieces of equipment can be fatal to the workings of the system. In addition to the obvious technological benefits, the device can also provide cost benefits over traditional storage solutions, due to its increased durability and reliability. Air-gap flash is usually divided into two distinct form factors. The first type is a form factor referred to as a 'self-powered' design, which is housed in its own casing and supplied with its own power. This type is used in traffic lights, medical pieces of equipment and military settings. The second type is called ' externally-powered', and supports a much wider range of applications. This type has the ability to be powered by other pieces of equipment, allowing for greater flexibility. The main drawback of an air-gap flash is the cost of installation, as the device requires installation in a case or on a circuit board, which can be expensive for larger applications. Additionally, the lack of direct connection to the circuit board increases the possibility of data loss due to disk damage. Despite these drawbacks air-gap flash is becoming increasingly popular due to its durability, performance and data safety benefits.

The Orangeback fairy-wrasse (Cirrhilabrus aurantidorsalis), is a species of fish in the Labridae family. It is native to the Indo-Pacific region, ranging from East Africa to the Marquesan Islands and the East Indies. This species grows to a maximum length of around 9.5 cm. As their common name implies, Orangeback fairy-wrasse have a distinctive bright orange dorsal fin, with red or yellow scales providing a beautiful contrast. These distinctive scales, located in the front and lateral portions of the fish, are what makes this species so attractive and sought after by aquarists. The remainder of the body is primarily violet with yellow face and blue eyes. Orangeback fairy-wrasse are found near reefs, primarily in shallower waters where they feed on a variety of benthic organisms and small fish. These fish are social and often form small schools that find forage together. They can be territorial and will establish small domains within a reef, but are typically peaceful with their own species. Orangeback fairy-wrasse are an easy species to keep in the home aquarium. These fish prefer tanks with plenty of live rock, caves, and plenty of open space to swim. They can be kept singly or in small groups and should always be provided with plenty of cover. The ideal water temperature for this species is between 76-78°F. When Orangeback fairy-wrasse are kept in pairs or even small groups in the aquarium, they may form strong bonds. Captive specimens will often form fascinating courtship displays and color changes. When housed with conspecifics, these wrasses are most active and exhibit their most exciting behaviors. It is important to note that individuals from this species may sometimes become aggressive towards other fish, especially if they are of the same species. Orangeback fairy-wrasse are an excellent choice for aquariums of all sizes, from nano aquariums to larger aquariums. They are a beautiful addition to any tank and will provide hours of fun and fascination. With proper care and attention, these fish can live up to 10-15 years in captivity.

Gorillas on the Mast is an American musical ensemble formed in 2011 by siblings Isaac, Robert, and Talise Fisher and their friends Alex Gorant and Chris Anderson. The group was formed in New Orleans and grew to a rotating cast of seven to nine members. The bands unique eclectic sound of modern folk, gypsy jazz, calypso, klezmer, and other folk-infused music, combines multiple genres and styles with acoustic string instruments to create a truly original, unforgettable sound. The band’s 2008 release, Bonehorse, earned them a nomination for Southwestern Regional Jazz Improvisation Band of the Year honors. Their follow-up album Boff, released in 2010, was met with even more critical acclaim. Backed by Contemporary Artist David Lanier on the upright bass, Gorillas on the Mast is often compared to classic gypsy punks Gogol Bordello and Firewater. Gorillas on the Mast has built an impressive career touring alongside acts including Railroad Earth, Greensky Bluegrass, Rebirth Brass Band, and Kool and the Gang. They have also appeared at festivals such as New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival, LOCKN Festival, Summer Camp Festival, Founders Fest and others. The group has received rave reviews from music critics and performed at popular music venues throughout the US. The group’s latest album, A Sailors Repose, was released in 2019. The record has a looser feel than its predecessors, as the more free-form improvisation takes center-stage. A Sailors Repose has since been applauded by fans and critics alike as the Gorillas on the Mast’s most polished effort to date. Gorillas on the Mast have become one of the heaviest-hitting American musical groups of the last decade. The groups genre-bending sound and live stage shows have continuously caught the eye of the music industry, solidifying their place as one of the top folk acts of the decade.

Walt Disney Cartoon Classics was an umbrella title for cartoon compilation videos of Walt Disney cartoon shorts released digitally and on VHS cassettes. The compilations were released between 1984 and 1991. The first compilation in the Walt Disney Cartoon Classics series was The Collection of Classic Disney Shorts, Volume 1, released on VHS in 1984. It featured six classic Disney shorts from the 1930s: Three Little Pigs (1933), The Tortoise and the Hare (1935), The Country Cousin (1936), The Practical Pig (1939), The Ugly Duckling (1939), and The Reluctant Dragon (1941). The second volume of the Disney Cartoon Classics was released in 1985, followed by twelve more volumes released over the next five years. The compilations featured Disney shorts from the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s including the Academy Award-winning short “Lamplighter” (1945), “Grand Canyonscape” (1938), “Pluto’s Dream House” (1940), “Mickey Down Under” (1948), and “Toot, Whistle, Plunk and Boom” (1953). During the series' run, the Walt Disney Cartoon Classics were released on three different formats: VHS cassettes, laserdiscs, and digital downloads (DVD and digital download). Some volumes became quite rare and sought-after due to their limited edition printing. In 1991, the Walt Disney Cartoon Classics series was discontinued due to the emerging home video market and the rising demand for the company's entire library of feature films. With the introduction of full-length feature films on VHS and laserdiscs, the demand for cartoon compilations was gradually supplanted. Today, some volumes of the Walt Disney Cartoon Classics continue to be available through online streaming services such as Amazon Video and iTunes. Meanwhile, other volumes have become collector’s items and are highly sought after by fans of Disney’s classic cartoon shorts. The Walt Disney Cartoon Classics series is a unique cultural artifact, introducing generations of viewers to some of the greatest animated shorts in film history. It is also a cherished memory for many, who may have grown up watching the cartoons that could be found in these compilations. With each volume, viewers had the opportunity to delight in the charm and wit of these beloved Disney classics.

The Mizoram–Manipur–Kachin rain forests are a tropical moist broadleaf forest ecoregion of Southeast Asia. The ecoregion includes the montane rain forests of Mizoram and Manipur States of India, and Sagaing Region, south Kachin, and northern Chin States in Myanmar. These forests cover an area of 25,811 square kilometers (9,983 square miles). The climate is monsoonal, with high humidity and rainfall. Temperatures range from 16–26 °C (61–79 °F), and mean annual rainfall ranges from 1,800–2,400 mm (70–94 in). The ecoregion's flora includes species such as trees of the Fagaceae (especially Bombax ceiba) and Lauraceae (Gomphandra arborea and Machilus odoratissima) families, as well as evergreen trees such as Castanopsis tribuloides, Holigarna arnottiana, Microglossa lomatophylla, and Quercus spp. Lianas, palms and bamboos are also prevalent. The fauna is comprised of a variety of species including mammals, birds, reptiles and amphibians. Mammals such as Asiatic black bears (Ursus thibetanus) and gaurs (Bos gaurus) inhabit the forests of Mizoram and Manipur, while species such as red pandas (Ailurus fulgens), Himalayan tahrs (Hemitragus jemlahicus), and serow (Capricornis sumatraensis) inhabit the forests of Kachin. The endangered pig-tailed macaque (Macaca nemestrina) is also found in the ecoregion. Bird species found in the Mizoram–Manipur–Kachin rain forests include the endangered white-shouldered ibis (Pseudibis davisoni) and Blyth's tragopan (Tragopan blythii). Reptiles such as the krait (Bungarus caeruleus) and the king cobra (Ophiophagus hannah) are also found in the ecoregion. Threats to the biodiversity of the Mizoram–Manipur–Kachin rain forests include habitat destruction and fragmentation due to logging, road construction, and conversion for agricultural and development activities. Illegal wildlife trade, over-exploitation of forest resources, and development of tourist resorts also pose threats for the ecoregion’s ecology. To conserve this ecologically important ecoregion, the state governments of Mizoram and Manipur have established the Murlen National Park, Blue Mountain National Park and Paimafra Wild Animals Sanctuary in India while the Hkakabo Razi National Park and the government of Myanmar are protecting the Kachin area with a proposed 1,352 km² conservation zone. In 1993, the forests of Mizoram, Manipur, and Kachin were collectively added to the list of World Heritage Sites. Conservation efforts in these protected areas are being undertaken by the local communities, governments, and non-governmental organisations, in order to protect this fragile ecoregion and its ecosystems. The Mizoram–Manipur–Kachin rain forests contain a rich array of species and represent a unique combination of biodiversity and natural beauty. Thus, it remains one of the most important areas in Southeast Asia for conservation and research.

The 1922 Lithuanian parliamentary election was the first election held in the newly independent Lithuania as part of the First Seimas. It was held on February 23, 1922 and was contested by 153 candidates from 21 electoral lists. The election was considered to be largely fair and democratic and was seen as a symbolic start to Lithuania's new-found independence. The election was called following the new Lithuanian National Council's decree of December 21st, 1921, which called for the nation to create a Seimas (Parliament) with a 151-member legislative body. Candidates could run singly or on lists and had to have a minimum of 500 supporters to qualify. All citizens of Lithuania had voting rights, irrespective of their class, religion, or gender. This election saw a large increase in the participation of women, with the number of female candidates increasing from just one in 1920 to 47 in the 1922 election. The women's list, called Žaliūkės (Little Greens), was created in response to fears of a return to pre-war conditions and won five seats. This made it the third-largest list in the election and the first women's party to gain representation in Lithuania's Seimas. The election itself was contested primarily between two main lists: the conservative Peasant Union and the Lithuanian Social Democratic Party. The Peasant Union won the most seats (49), while the Social Democrats took 38 seats. The Lithuanian Christian Democrats, led by Augustinas Voldemaras, won 25 seats, while the Polish Christian Democrats and Žaliūkės won 5 seats each. The newly elected Seimas convened for the first time on May 17, 1922, however, the Lithuanian Christian Democratic Union soon dissolved due to disagreements about the country's rural- urban balance of power. Later in the same year, the Peasant Union dissolved as well due to disagreements about agrarian reform. The Social Democrats and Žaliūkės fared better, with the former becoming the largest parliamentary group and the latter being a significant player in politics until the 1930s. The 1922 Lithuanian parliamentary election was a major victory for democracy in Lithuania. It was the first time that the newly independent state had held a free and fair election, and it opened the door for future elections, which became more democratic as time went on. It was a major milestone in Lithuania's newfound independence, and has helped Lithuania become the democratic nation it is today.

Coyote Valley is a small unincorporated community located in Santa Clara County, California. Located about 9 miles south of downtown San Jose, and about 5 miles east of the city of Morgan Hill, it is essentially a rural hamlet composed of scattered ranches, small farms, and homesteads. It covers an area of 14.6 square miles, with an elevation of 715 feet (218 meters). Coyote Valley is known for its small-town feel, with a population of just over 1,000 people, mostly concentrated in the hamlet of Coyote, which lies south of Coyote Creek and east of Little Llagas Creek. The area has long been rural and agricultural in nature, with a rich history in cattle ranching and farming, but in recent years has experienced some residential development, largely due to its proximity to the Bay Area. As a result, Coyote Valley has become an increasingly popular destination for those seeking a rural lifestyle, while being close enough to enjoy the nearby attractions, amenities, and job opportunities of the larger cities in the Bay Area. In addition to the diverse variety of attractions in the area, Coyote Valley is home to a number of native plants and animals, including coyotes, bobcats, mountain lions, pigs, and white tailed deer. Additionally, two of the region’s rarest native plants, the Santa Clara Valley dudleya and the Santa Clara Valley brodiaea, are known to inhabit the area. Coyote Valley also contains a few small businesses, typically locally owned and operated, including a post office, a wood shop, and a feed store. Additionally, a local winery, Sonnet Wine Cellar, offers tastings in the area, and a farmers’ market is held in nearby Morgan Hill on select weekends. Despite the fact that it is an unincorporated area, Coyote Valley has a community association, which works to preserve the rural feel of the area and to protect its agricultural and ranching heritage. In 2007, the community was recognized by the US Department of Agriculture as a ‘Century Community’, which is a designation given to rural communities that have been continuously occupied and farmed since at least the 1880s. Coyote Valley provides a unique and appealing combination of rural charm and proximity to nearby cities. With its strong sense of community and tradition, along with its natural beauty and wildlife, it is a popular destination for those looking to get away from the hustle and bustle of city life, while still offering the opportunities of larger cities.

Jones-Brown-Smith, often abbreviated as JBS, is an advisory firm headquartered in London, England. Founded in 2015, JBS provides a comprehensive range of advice and tailored solutions in the areas of corporate finance, mergers and acquisitions, and capital raising for clients in the United Kingdom and Europe. JBS is managed by a partner team led by its three founders - Jim Jones, David Brown, and Scott Smith. All three have worked in the corporate finance industry for over 20 years. They have wide-ranging experience in the UK and European markets and have managed and completed a broad range of transactions. Their collective knowledge and deep understanding of the regional markets and sector-specific regulations make JBS a sought-after provider of professional advice for both inbound and outbound transactions. JBS focuses on delivering long-term sustainable results to its clients and continues to build an enviable portfolio of transactions that include public and private mergers and acquisitions, management buyouts and equity placements, debt financings, and equity investments. Boasting a high-caliber team and a large, varied client base, JBS has quickly become a reliable and respected name in the corporate finance industry. The firm's successful track record is the result of their commitment to providing tailored corporate finance solutions that are clients centered, and its partners utilization of their extensive connections in the industry. JBS's services also include due diligence, concept development, strategic advice, and financial restructuring. Furthermore, the team is committed to offering the highest quality of advice to its clients in order to maximize value and return on investment. Since its inception, JBS has continued to grow and diversify its expertise by recruiting talented professionals and developing innovative solutions for its clients. The firm boasts strong relationships with many large private equity firms, including Blackstone, KKR, and TPG. JBS is a leader in the corporate finance sector, providing top-notch solutions to clients from different industries. The firm's continuous growth and success are a testament to its commitment to the highest standards of integrity and excellence.

I Am Not an Easy Man is a 2018 French comedy film that follows a chauvinistic man who finds himself in a female-centered world. The film was directed by Eléonore Pourriat, written by Eléonore Pourriat and Mathieu Oullion with the film stars Vincent Elbaz and Françoise Fabian. The film centers around Damien, a chauvinistic man who is utterly oblivious to any form of gender equality or feminist values in society. One day, he wakes up after being hit by a car to find that the roles of men and women in society have been reversed. Men are put in a subordinate role while women rule the world and its politics. Damien finds himself in a world where women are powerful and men are treated as objects, which shapes his views and attitudes towards women. Throughout the movie Damien experiences numerous cases of sexual harassment from a male client and is constantly degraded by his female superior. Damien is initially unaccepting of the new society in which he is a part of. However, this all changes when he meets Alex, a female acquaintance from before the role switch. She and her best-friend show him a different perspective from the world he had been living in and give him positive views on women in society. With the help of them and his female superior at work, Damien soon starts to embrace the women-dominated world and learns to understand the values of feminism. I Am Not an Easy Man was released on April 4, 2018 in France, where it was generally well-received by both critics and audiences. It was praised for its humorous plot and the powerful message it sent to men in today's society. It was also selected to compete for the Golden Lion award at the 75th Venice International Film Festival. Overall, I Am Not an Easy Man is a comedic and thought-provoking film that sends a powerful message about gender roles and feminism in modern society. It sheds light on how chauvinistic men can learn to accept and appreciate powerful female leaders and understand their importance to society.

Upper Saxony (German: Ober Sachsen) is the regions of Germany located on the northern edge of the country bordering eastern Netherlands, including the cities of Erfurt and Dresden. Upper Saxony comprises several historical states including the Principality of Reuss, the Duchy of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach, the Duchy of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha and the State of Thuringia. The region also includes the northern part of Saxony-Anhalt, the eastern part of Saxony-Anhalt and a small portion of the Franconian region of Bavaria. Upper Saxony was established in 1945 as part of the Allied powers occupation of Germany following the end of World War II. The term is derived from the traditional name of the historical area of Upper Saxony and the Federal State of Saxony. Lower Saxony, which is located to the west, is the region that the origins of the name are based from. The dominant landscape of Upper Saxony is shaped by rivers, low rock formations and plateaus. It includes several nature reserves, including Unesco World Heritage Site Thuringian Forest, mountain ranges of the Rhön, Ore, Franconian, Thuringian and low mountain ranges as well as parts of the Elsterberg. The economy of Upper Saxony is primarily based on its services sector and its manufacturing and industrial output is among the highest in the country. It is an important economic center and one of the five German economic regions. In 2015 the region grossed a total of €93 billion in gross domestic product and accounted for 10.7% of Germany's total economy. Automotive, electrical engineering and mechanical engineering are the main industries in the region. Upper Saxony is home to a number of institutions of higher education, including the University of Erfurt, the University of Applied Sciences in Erfurt, and the Dresden University of Technology. Culture in the region is rooted in the traditions of the Saxons of Prussia, as well as a range of other cultural influences. Throughout the region, festivals and concerts to celebrate traditional music, theater and film take place throughout the year. The region is also home to the Theater Erfurt, a renowned concert hall, as well as several world-famous historic attractions. Given its proximity to the Netherlands and Central Europe, Upper Saxony is a popular destination for tourists. Dresden, one of the most visited cities in Germany, is a center for culture and art and is known for its monuments from the time of the Saxon kings. The city also boasts many historic sites, museums and churches, alongside a lively nightlife and excellent shopping. Overall, Upper Saxony is an economically prosperous area as well as a vibrant center for transportation, industry and culture. With several nature reserves and significant cultural and historical attractions, there is something for everyone.

A lithium ion manganese oxide battery is a type of rechargeable battery that relies on lithium-ion technology as the main energy storage medium. These batteries use manganese oxide as the active material, a combination of cobalt, nickel, and other metals to form a cathode, and a graphite-based anode. The result is a lighter, more powerful battery with superior cycling performance compared to other commonly used battery cells. Lithium ion manganese oxide batteries have a longer cycle life than other lithium-ion cells due to the lower potential of the cathode structure compared to other materials. It has good capacity and good low temperature performance. Also, manganese oxide chemistry is capable of providing higher power discharge rates compared to other lithium-ion chemistries. Due to the high energy density and excellent cycle life, these batteries are used in a wide range of applications such as satellite communications, medical electronics, electric vehicles, and consumer electronics. They are used in electric bikes, hybrid vehicles and electric scooters. Alongside their long life cycle, these batteries can provide high power with a low environmental impact and low maintenance costs. Their low cost and reliable performance has seen the lithium ion manganese oxide batteries become increasingly popular for small mobile consumer devices and grid storage applications. The improved efficiency of lithium ion manganese oxide batteries has enabled the development of next-generation battery electric vehicle technology. For example, power banks, transport electrolyte batteries, power supplies, and electric vehicle battery packs are being developed with these batteries. These batteries have some disadvantages, such as a slightly lower voltage compared to other lithium-ion cells, which can lead to power capacity issues depending on the application. However, due to their low cost and improved cycling capabilities, these batteries continue to be popular and have become the go-to choice for many applications. Despite the issues, lithium ion manganese oxide batteries are considered to be one of the most reliable and cost effective, safety conscious batteries available in the market. Their ability to produce high power with a long cycle life, makes them an ideal choice for many applications.

Adult/Child is a concept in psychosocial development to describe the relationship between adult and child and how this interaction affects the development and wellbeing of the child. It focuses on how adults interact and respond to the social, emotional, and physical needs of the child. The nature of the relationship between adults and children is strongly shaped by the beliefs and values of the adults, as well as their attitudes towards the child. It is typically seen as a power dynamic in which the adult is in charge and has the ultimate responsibility for caring for the child. Therefore, an effective adult/child relationship is one that is respectful, supportive and nurturing, and enables the child to develop to their fullest potential. Some of the factors that influence an adult/child relationship include the emotional health of the adults, their level of psychological maturity, their experience with children and the amount of time they have to commit to caring for the child. Additionally, individual beliefs and values, attitudes to discipline and behaviour, and the availability of resources such as time, money and emotional support also shapes the relationship. The nature of the adult/child relationship is also shaped by cultural values and norms, which can vary considerably across different societies and international borders. While, in some cultures, adults may place a high value on instilling discipline and controlling the behaviour of children, in other cultures adults may take a more relaxed, open-minded approach and focus on developing and nurturing social and emotional relationships. The quality of the adult/child relationship has a significant impact on the outcome of the child's growth and development. A child who is exposed to positive adult/child relationships will often be more secure, happy and confident, and will be better equipped to cope with life’s challenges. Similarly, a child exposed to negative adult/child interactions, such as abuse, neglect or emotional neglect, is likely to experience long-term and often severe emotional and social issues. Therefore, fostering a positive relationship between adults and children is of vital importance for the wellbeing of the child. This should include providing a safe and secure environment in which the child can explore, learn and grow, developing a warm and nurturing relationship with the child, and offering consistent discipline and guidance. These are all essential elements for the long-term wellbeing of the child, and crucial for the successful development of their social and emotional skills.

Plants vs. Zombies is a tower defense and strategy video game developed and originally published by PopCap Games for Windows and Mac OS X systems in 2009. Players assume the role of a homeowner in the game, tasked with using a variety of different plants to repel hordes of zombies from "invading" their home. The idea is to help the homeowner build an arsenal of different plants and then utilize these plants to protect their house from the relentless zombie siege. The game is relatively simple in concept: the player is presented with a grid of squares, representing the homeowner's garden, upon which they can place various plants to thwart the zombie attacks. Each plant has its own special power, and the player must utilize the available plants in an attempt to fend off the zombie attacks. The player must also make strategic decisions in order to outsmart their opponents and survive the waves of zombies. The game also features other elements, which add a certain level of chaos and fun to the proceedings. The zombies themselves come in various shapes and sizes, and have their own special abilities, making them quite difficult to eliminate, as the player may need to use specific plants to take out certain enemies. There are also a few mini-games interspersed throughout the game as well, which can offer the player a breather from the main action in between waves. The graphics of the game are quite cartoonish and cheerful, helping to keep the game lighthearted and enjoyable. The sound effects are also of a high-quality and are particularly good at environmental atmospherics, such as the sound of birds chirping in the background. The music of the game is just as good, and fitting to the action taking place in each wave. There have been several versions of the game released since it first debuted in 2009, including a spin-off game, as well as mobile versions for iOS and Android devices. Plants vs. Zombies has been critically acclaimed since its launch, and is cited as one of the top tower defense games of all time. Thanks to its easy learning curve, engaging gameplay and polished presentation, Plants vs. Zombies is still highly regarded today, and is sure to delight gamers for many more years to come.

Massimiliano Rosolino (born 27 July 1976) is an Italian Olympic medal-winning swimmer and three-time world champion who competed in the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney. Born in Naples, Italy, Rosolino initially studied economics but switched to philosophy; he later took up swimming and went on to become one of Italy's leading swimmers. Rosolino began competing nationally in 1992 and by 1996 he was competing in the European Championships, winning his first gold medal in the 400m individual medley. In 1999 he set his first world record in the 200m individual medley and won the gold medal at the 1999 European Swimming Championships. At the 2000 Summer Olympics, Rosolino won the gold medal in the 200m individual medley, breaking his own world record in the process. At the 2001 World Aquatics Championships in Fukuoka, he won two golds (200m and 400m individual medleys) and a silver medal. In 2002 he earned a bronze medal at the European Championships in Berlin. Rosolino received a bronze medal in the 200m freestyle at the 2004 Summer Olympics in Athens, claiming fourth place in the 400m freestyle. He is the current world record holder in the 200m freestyle, set in 2002 in Riccione. He holds two Olympic medals and three World Championship golds as well as numerous national titles. Outside of competitive swimming, Rosolino has been involved in a number of other projects. He has written a book entitled "Swimming with Power: The Pros and Cons of High-Performance Training" and serves as an ambassador for the Italian Swimming Federation. He has also acted in films and on television, featuring in the Italian series "Il confronto" and the feature film "Amore 14". He studied philosophy at State University of Milan and is currently a part-time lecturer in swimming technique at the University of Milan. Rosolino is the father of four children and is also an avid car enthusiast. He is an active member of the swimwear brand Arena Italia. Rosolino currently serves as the Vice President of Italian Swimming Federation. He is seen as one of the most decorated Italian swimmers of all time and is widely recognized as a great motivating force in Italian sports. In 2014 he was inducted into the International Swimming Hall of Fame.

Silje is a female name of Scandinavian origin. The meaning of Silje is "calm and peaceful". The name is derived from a combination of the Old Norse elements for "light" and "peace". Silje is a popular name throughout the Nordic countries, including Norway, Sweden, and Denmark. It is especially popular in Norway, where it was the seventeenth most popular name for girls in 2016. The popularity of this name has been increasing in recent years, as it has been given to many prominent Norwegian cultural figures. Silje is a versatile name, as it can be spelled in both its Norse and anglicized forms. The former spelling is the traditional official form, while Silje is the anglicized version that is more commonly used. The name has traditionally been used as an independent given name, but it has also been used as a short form of longer names with the same root such as SiljeMaria or Siljestina. Silje has also been used to create nicknames. Silja and Sili are popular variations. People with the name Silje include: * Silje Nergaard, a Norwegian singer-songwriter * Silje Norendal, a Norwegian snowboarder * Silje Fjellanger, a Norwegian football defender * Silje Wergeland, a Norwegian fashion model * Silje Solberg, a Norwegian ice hockey player The Swedish DJ Alan Walker has a song titled "Silje's Song". Silje has also been used in literature. In Norwegian author Knut Hamsun's novel Growth of the Soil, the two female protagonists are named Silje and Helga. The elements of Silje's meaning make it a perfect name for a baby girl, since it implies a girl of serenity, light and peace. It is the perfect name for a baby who will grow up living a life surrounded by love and happiness.

François Cacault (October 25, 1837 – June 7, 1916) was a French academic, writer and poet. He was a member of the French Academy and the Académie française. Cacault was born in Bordeaux and was educated at the schools at Saint-Aure and at the lyceé in La Rochelle. He moved to Paris in 1859 and studied law and literature. During this period, he also wrote for several reviews, including Revue des Deux Mondes and Revue Belge. After his studies, he was appointed to the Academy by the French Government in 1867. Cacault was well-known for his writings on various topics, including the French Revolution and the connections between the French and British empires. He also composed a long series of works on philosophy, history, and literature, including Essai sur le Bonheur (1886), Histoire des Évêques de Nantes (1886), and Etudes sur les Temps Modernes (1902). Cacault was a prominent figure during the Belle Époque and was close to the French nobility. He was a frequent guest of the Imperial family, and the Empress Eugénie, who granted him the Legion of Honour, appointed him to the Institute of France in 1872. Cacault published several editions of works by Voltaire, including Oeuvres Completes (1875) with André Chélu. He also wrote a number of articles for prominent reviews, as well as for periodicals such as the Journal des Débats and La Démocratie Pacifique. Cacault was highly celebrated during his lifetime and was awarded numerous honours, including being made a Grand Officier de la Légion d’Honneur in 1879 and an Officer de l'Institut de France in 1888. He died in Bordeaux in 1916.

Gabibbo (Italian pronunciation: [ɡaˈbibo]) is an Italian character created by Pippo Baudo. The character was created in 1991, and it has appeared in various shows and films, mostly in Italy. Gabibbo is a red-haired puppet with a funny, upturned nose. He wears yellow and red striped garments, a Captain's hat, and carries a sword with a blue handle. He speaks in a thick Neapolitan dialect and jokes about his lack of a sexual organ. Gabibbo has appeared in television programs such as Festival di Sanremo, which is a music festival held annually in Italy. He has also been featured in comic books and commercials. The original Gabibbo show was called "Gabibbo Show" and aired from 1991 to 1994. The show featured sketches, cartoons, and music. Gabibbo was often accompanied by a companion, Lolita (voiced by Marisa Laurito). Together, Gabibbo and Lolita entered into adventures that dealt with current events and popular culture topics. Gabibbo appeared in the film "Falsomiele" (1993), "Torno Sabato" (2000), and "L'Uomo del proiettile d'oro" (2005). He has also been featured in popular Italian music videos. The video for the song "Gimme Five" (2003), which stars Gabibbo as a rocker, has over 175 million views. In October 2015, Pippo Baudo was accused of plagiarizing the character of Gabibbo, which sparked a debate in Italy. Baudo denied having stolen the character and stated that it was his own creation. The issue was later settled out of court, with the parties signing a confidential agreement. Gabibbo is an iconic Italian character, and is recognized around the world. His characteristic physical features, personality, and voice have made him a beloved figure in Italy.

The Wells-Ogunquit Community School District (WOCSD) is a regional school district located in the state of Maine. It is composed of the towns of Wells and Ogunquit and serves as the sole educational offering for these two communities. It was formed in 1968, and its first superintendent, R. Kenneth Simonton, was appointed in 1969. WOCSD is one of approximately 160 districts in the Maine state school system, and it serves the educational needs of almost 3,000 students. The district has two elementary schools, two middle schools, one high school and two alternative education settings. The Wells-Ogunquit Community High School offers comprehensive curriculum including Advanced Placement (AP) courses and a wide range of college level courses. In addition, the district provides a variety of extracurricular activities including varsity and junior varsity sports, music and theatrical performances, and a variety of community service opportunities. The district prides itself on being dedicated to its students' well-being, learning and development. It maintains a focus on developing lifelong habits of learning, problem solving and inquiry, while encouraging the development of strong character, leadership and personal responsibility. The district is committed to assisting each student on their educational journey, providing academic, social and emotional support. It's goals include helping develop each student's academic and social skills, promoting healthy relationships between peers, staff and homeroom families, and emphasizing the importance of personal responsibility. The WOCSD receives approximately $22 million annually in state and local funding. About 14 percent of its funding is federal and Title I money is used to support its nine schools. The district also has a number of private sector, local and state grants that support programs such as a new behavioral evaluation system and school safety initiatives. The Wells-Ogunquit Community School District is committed to providing a quality education to its students and investing in the future of the community. Its staff strives to create a positive learning environment and work with families to ensure students meet their potential.

Jake Bilardi (June 25, 1996 - March 18, 2015) was an Australian teenager who was born in Melbourne, Australia. Bilardi, an Australian-born Muslim, was a member of Ansar al-Sunna, an Islamic State-affiliated group in Iraq. Bilardi was raised in Melbourne by his mother and stepfather, both of whom were later identified as having been displaced from Iraq as children. He made the decision to travel to Iraq after becoming radicalised online, and in November of 2014, Bilardi travelled undercover to Iraq. Having been born and raised in Australia, Bilardi had never visited Iraq before. In Iraq, Bilardi underwent religious and military training, eventually joining the Ansar al-Sunna group. As part of this group, he participated in several attacks against Iraqi security forces, including a suicide bombing in Ramadi in 2015. Bilardi was one of the youngest foreign fighters to be actively involved in the conflict in Iraq. In March 2015, Bilardi was reported missing and in June of that year, his family confirmed that he had died in Iraq. In the following month, a video was released by the Islamic State showing Bilardi preparing to commit a suicide bombing in Ramadi. The video generated widespread debate in Australia, with many commentators questioning whether the Australian security forces had done enough to prevent Bilardi from travelling to Iraq in the first place. Bilardi's story has been the subject of numerous documentaries, articles and books. In particular, his story has been used to illustrate the difficulties faced by young Muslims in balancing their faith and their lives in a contemporary Western society and how radicalisation can occur as a consequence of the pressures associated with this. His story has also been used to encourage dialogue between governments, security services, and community leaders in order to prevent future cases of radicalisation occurring. Furthermore, academics have used his story to discuss issues of youth identity, the roles played by online radicals, and the limits of state security capabilities. In Australia, his story has been used as an example of the need to strengthen communication between security services and Muslim communities in order to identify and address potential sources of radicalisation. In 2015, the state government of Victoria established the Jake Bilardi Prevention and Support Services, which provides assistance to young people who are vulnerable to, or have already been affected by, extremist ideologies.

Annette van Dyck-Hemming (born July 8, 1976) is a Dutch businesswoman, entrepreneur, philanthropist and venture capitalist. She has served as a managing partner of Amsterdam-based hedge fund, Dyck-Hemming Capital, since its inception in 2002. She is an active philanthropist, having founded and funded the Women’s Venture Capital Initiative (WVCA), a mentor-mentee program that provides advice and funding to female-led businesses in the Netherlands, as well as the Van Dyck-Hemming Foundation, an Amsterdam-based non-profit for the advancement of education, science and the arts. Annette van Dyck-Hemming was born in Amsterdam in 1976. She attended the University of Amsterdam, where she earned a BA in Business and Economics in 2000. After graduating, she joined the Dutch bank ING and began her career in the banking, finance and venture capital industry. In 2002, she and her father co-founded Dyck-Hemming Capital, a hedge fund focused on venture capital opportunities primarily in Europe. At Dyck-Hemming Capital, Annette has been the managing partner since its inception. During her tenure, the company has become one of the most successful venture capital firms in the country, with investments in several innovative companies and organizations, including Uber and Airbnb. She also has a seat on the board of several organizations, including The Women's Venture Capital Initiative (WVCA) and The Dutch Venture Coalition (DVC). In 2015, Annette launched the Women’s Venture Capital Initiative (WVCA), an Amsterdam-based non-profit organization with the mission to empower women-backed businesses with the skills, coaching, and funding to succeed. The WVCA has now become a global movement, with hundreds of mentees from around the world signing up for the program. Furthermore, Annette founded the Van Dyck-Hemming Foundation, a charity dedicated to the advancement of education, science, and the arts in Amsterdam. The foundation’s philanthropic activities include offering scholarships to students, providing grants to innovative start-up businesses, and supporting artistic and cultural initiatives. Annette lives in Amsterdam with her husband and two children. She enjoys traveling and playing sports, especially golf and tennis. Annette van Dyck-Hemming is an accomplished businesswoman and philanthropist who has used her success to open opportunities and create opportunities for others. Through her foundation and venture capital initiatives, Annette has encouraged female-led businesses and promoted innovation in the Netherlands.

Nevadaplano is a small unincorporated community located in southwest Texas in the United States. It is located in Presidio County and is part of the Big Bend region of the state. The population is estimated at about 450 people. The community is situated at an elevation of 1,248 feet (380 m) above sea level. The community was founded in the late 19th century and was named for the Nevada-Colorado river that runs through the area. The community was originally a farming and ranching center, but over time became the gateway to Big Bend Country due to its proximity to Big Bend National Park. The Nevadaplano area is known for its natural beauty and outdoor recreational opportunities. The area boasts numerous hiking trails and biking trails. The state park of Big Bend National Park is nearby, as are Devils River State Natural Area and Elephant Mountain Wildlife Management Area. Tourists often drive in from Austin, El Paso, and other parts of Texas to explore the area’s many outdoor activities, especially in the summer months. Nevadaplano is also known for its signature cuisine. The community’s restaurants serve up traditional Mexican dishes, as well as traditional American fare. Visitors will also find a variety of Tex-Mex dishes on the menu. The area is served by several primary roads, including Interstate 10, US Route 90, and State Highway 111. Locally operated businesses offer employment opportunities and general services to the residents of Nevadaplano and the surrounding areas. The local school district operates several schools, including Nevadaplano Elementary School, Nevadaplano High School, and Nevadaplano Junior High School. The local library, Carnegie Public Library, is located in nearby Marfa. Although Nevadaplano is a small community, its proximity to Big Bend National Park and its stunning surrounding landscape makes it a great destination for travelers and outdoor enthusiasts alike. References https://nevadaplanotx.com/ https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/hln41 https://www.caprockcanyons.com/visitor-guide/locations/nevadaplano/ https://www.bigbendnationalpark.com/visit/things-to-do/accommodations/45-nevadaplano-tx

The National Philatelic Society (NPS) is an organization dedicated to fostering an appreciation of the hobby of stamp collecting. Founded in 1915, it is the oldest philatelic organization in the United States. The Society seeks to promote the worldwide growth of the hobby by inspiring interest and appreciation in collecting, speaking to philatelists, offering support to various philatelic activities, and maintaining an online library of philatelic materials. The NPS also aids stamp collectors, particularly beginners, with educational activities and publications, while offering resources to experienced philatelists. The NPS sponsors exhibition, shows, auctions and sales, and publishes a monthly magazine, which includes news and articles about philately. Additionally, it hosts an annual meeting and symposium each year, bringing together philatelists for presentations and lectures. The NPS also has an extensive library of philatelic books and magazines, as well as an extensive selection of collector items for sale. It offers a variety of benifits to members, including discounts on stamp shows, auctions and sales, as well as access to special member-only auctions. The Society is currently led by an Executive committee, which is comprised of a President, four Vice Presidents, and a Treasurer. All of these officers are elected by the members of the NPS, and serve staggered two-year terms. The National Philatelic Society is a member of the American Philatelic Society and the Philatelic Society of America. It is also affiliated with many smaller specialty societies and organizations dedicated to the hobby. The NPS is open to all those who are interested in stamp collecting and the Society encourages anyone who wishes to join to be an active member. Membership fees are inexpensive, and members of the Society who join before the end of the year will receive a certificate and pin as well as printed versions of the NPS magazines.

The Turkish Cypriots (Turkish: Kıbrıs Türkleri) are an ethnic group originating from the island nation of Cyprus, who are predominantly Muslim and of Turkish ethnicity. Although the majority of the population of Cyprus is Greek-speaking, the Turkish Cypriots constitute a significant minority on the island, forming roughly 18% of its population. The Turkish Cypriots are native to Cyprus and have strong cultural ties to Turkey, with around half the population having emigrated from the mainland in the wake of the Turkish invasion of Cyprus in 1974. Most Turkish Cypriots live in the part of the island which is under the control of the internationally unrecognized Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, while a significant number also reside in mainland Turkey and other countries such as the United Kingdom (where the largest diaspora population resides). The Turkish Cypriots have had a turbulent history of displacement and conflict, having been caught in the middle of tensions between Greek and Turkish Cypriots dating back to Ottoman Empire rule of the island. During the 1960s, tensions between the two ethnic Cypriot communities on the island climaxed in inter-communal violence, eventually leading to the Turkish invasion of Cyprus in 1974. This saw the displacement of many Turkish Cypriots from the island, with a significant proportion of them relocating to mainland Turkey and other countries. The Turkish Cypriots have maintained a distinct cultural identity since their displacement and continue to speak their native languages of Turkish, Cypriot Turkish and Cypriot Greek. They are predominantly Muslim, with Sunni Islam being the most widely practised religion within the community. This is in contrast to the Greek Cypriot majority which largely follows Eastern Orthodoxy. The economy of Northern Cyprus, where the majority of the Turkish Cypriot community resides, is largely dependent on aid from Turkey due to its disputed status. This has led to a large influx of foreign capital and investment, leading to an improvement in the financial position of many Turkish Cypriots. Turkish Cypriots have also started to move back to the southern side of the island as a result of the understanding between Turkish and Greek Cypriot leaders, with the first bus crossing the Green Line in April 2003. The Turkish Cypriots remain subject to political and social tension due to their disputed status on the island and their minority status in the Republic of Cyprus. They continue to work closely with the Turkish government and together they actively seek to improve the situation of the Turkish Cypriot people, both at home and abroad.

Himmatsinhji M. K (18 October 1936 - 18 April 2019) was an Indian entrepreneur, philanthropist and Member of Parliament, who is most remembered for beingheralded as a pioneer in the Indian industrial revolution. Himmatsinhji founded, YPS International, traditionally known as a construction business, and went on launching the now renowned Kinetic Corporate clothingline and the Software Technology Parks of India (STPI). During his lifetime, Himmatsinhji played a pivotal role in leading several initiatives, setting up a medical college, promoting environmental development, and levelling the educational gender-gap. Himmatsinhji was born in Kotsuva, Gujarat, India, to Motibhai and Bhanumati Chandramal Rajgor. He was introduced to the business world at an early age and worked as an apprentice to his grandfather. His aspirations to become an entrepreneur led him to complete his Bachelor’s degree in Economics and accept a job in Gujarat. He started his own business in the construction industry at just 24 years old and quickly grew YPS into a leading infrastructure and hospitality business. Thanks to the success of the YPS International, Himmatsinhji was able to enter into the real estate development business. He established several business conglomerate, such as the Kinetic Corporate clothing line and the Software Technology Parks of India (STPI). Throughout his business career, Himmatsinhji was widely recognized for his humanitarian efforts, donating land for medical colleges, funding parks, and financing educational initiatives toelevate the economic standing of women. He was also a vocal environmental activist and donating funds to various environmental clean-up campaigns in his native Gujarat. In 2009, he was appointed in the Rajya Sabha, the Upper House of India’s Parliament by Prime Minister Manmohan Singh. He served on the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Railway and was also a member of the Consultative Committee in National Security. Himmatsinhji died on the 18 April 2019, in Porbandar, Gujarat at the age of 82. He was lauded for his achievements as an entrepreneur and philanthropist. His legacy continues to live on in the several establishments that bear his name. Himmatsinhji M. K. was an advocate for economic development and an irreplaceable leader in theindustrial revolution of India. His incredible business acumen, philanthropic initiatives, and political legacy make up the centrepiece of this influential Indian entrepreneur.

The 2011 Elite League speedway season was the 16th to take place since the first airing of the Speedway Elite League in 1995. 2011 was the last season of the Elite League as the total of ten teams were reduced down to just five for the 2012 season. Opening the season on 8 April, Swindon Robins defeated their rivals Wolverhampton Wolves 50–45 to begin their campaign, while Coventry Bees drew 46–46 at home with Peterborough Panthers. A week later, the Eastbourne Eagles dispatched the Belle Vue Aces 50–42 at Arlington Stadium in the first of the ‘Academy League’ fixtures. After the first round of fixtures, the Wolves led the standings with 7 points, followed by the Robins, Eagles and Panthers on 6 points, with Coventry bringing up the rear of the table. Wolverhampton Wolves maintained their lead throughout the early part of the season, with Swindon and Eastbourne equally matched in second and third place respectively. After 13 rounds of fixtures, the teams faced the first split of the season with early frontrunners Wolverhampton finishing top of the overall standings. Swindon and Eastbourne finished the regular season tied for second place, with a number of young riders making their debut in what was to be the final season of the Elite League. Leicester Lions and Belle Vue finished third and fourth respectively, with Plymouth Devils ending the season in fifth and Coventry Bees finishing bottom of the table. The play-offs saw the four highest placed teams all make the semi-finals, with reigning champions Swindon Robins defeating the Eastbourne Eagles in the first leg, before Wolverhampton Wolves prevailed against Leicester in the second. Swindon and Wolverhampton met in the Grand Final at the prestigious Monmore Green Stadium, with the Robins narrowly defeating the Wolves to be crowned Champions of the Elite League. The 2011 Elite League saw some of the best racing in the history of the league, with a record crowd of over 7,000 racing fans being in attendance for the Grand Final at Monmore Green. With the league set to expand to 12 teams for the 2012 season, the 2011 elite League proved to be an exciting and memorable season for all involved.

Edward Ruthazer (born May 6th, 1964) is a Canadian businessman and professor who is best known for his contributions to the fields of finance and economics, and for being one of Canada’s most successful entrepreneurs. Ruthazer was born and raised in Montreal, Quebec. He attended secondary school at the Montreal Boys High School, where he developed a passion for finance. He then attended McGill University, where he attained degrees in economics and business administration. It was during his university education that he began to develop an interest in using his knowledge of finance and economics in the business world. In the early years of his career, Ruthazer held financial management and corporate finance positions at several major companies, including Johnson & Johnson, Petrom Canada, and Imperial Oil. Ruthazer was eventually promoted to the position of Senior Vice President of Finance at Imperial Oil, where he managed the company's investments, credit activities, and corporate finances. In 1989, Ruthazer founded his own firm, Ruthazer Capital Markets Ltd. (RCM). RCM is a full service investment bank that specializes in mergers and acquisitions and corporate finance. Through RCM, Ruthazer was involved in some of Canada’s largest and most successful transactions. Since its establishment, RCM has advised on numerous transactions including the purchase of Hudson's Bay Company by Lord Jacob Rothschild, the sale of Ogilvie & Co. to Cara Foods and the IPO of Magellan Aerospace. In addition to his work with RCM, Ruthazer is an Adjunct Professor at McGill University. In this role, he has taught courses in finance and economics at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. He is also a passionate philanthropist and is the vice-chair of the Canadian Friends of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. Ruthazer is considered by many to be one of the leading finance and economics experts in Canada. His expertise and success in the corporate world has not gone unrecognized: he has been the recipient of numerous awards and honors, including being inducted into the Order of Canada in 2000 and the Hall of Fame of Canadian Professional Executives in 2006. In addition, he was awarded an Honorary Doctorate from McGill University in 2008.

Orenburzhye (Russian: Оренбуржье) is a historical and geographical region located in the southern part of Russia, on the border between Russia and Kazakhstan. It is part of the Ural Federal district, and is composed of three oblasts: Orenburg, Samara and Saratov. Geographically, the region is located in the southern part of the Ural Mountains and their foothills, between the Siberia and Kazakh Steppe. Despite its large size, it has a sparsely populated and relatively flat terrain. The region's main rivers are the Ural and the Don, which are both important navigable waterways. The economy of Orenburzhye is mainly based on agriculture and food processing. Potatoes, onions, grain and livestock are the main agricultural products. The industrial sector accounts for 16% of the region's GDP and is mainly focused on the production of ferrous metals, minerals and chemicals. Orenburzhye is also important for its fishing and forestry industries.
