Orenburzhye has a significant cultural importance for Russia, as it was the birthplace for some of the country’s most acclaimed writers, poets, musicians and filmmakers, such as Ivan Turgenev, Fyodor Dostoevsky and Sergei Eisenstein. The region is also known for its unique traditional music and cuisine. Popular dishes include "Oladyi" (fried pancakes) and "Pelmeni" (ravioli). Orenburzhye has many places of interest for tourists, including historical monuments, natural parks and wildlife sanctuaries, such as the Orenburg Nature Reserve. The capital city of the region, Orenburg, is known for its historical churches and cathedrals, as well as its many parks and museums. In recent years, Orenburzhye has seen an influx of international tourists, who come to visit the region’s many attractions, relax in its warm climate and sample its rich local culture.

Erith dockyard, located in Erith, Kent, was a major 19th-century shipbuilding centre and later, an engineering works of notable importance to naval and commercial marine customers on the River Thames. The dockyard was established in 1854 as the Great Millwall Dock Co. by JohnCay, Robert Nisbet and Philip Smith. The company started off life building brigantines and barques at their shipyard on the riverbank for the East India Company, and for other general trading companies. By 1861 the yard had a good reputation and the beginnings of a commercial marine supply network had been put into place. Before long, Erith shipyard had achieved a great reputation among its maritime customers, becoming the go-to shipbuilder for the construction and repair of a variety of ships including cargo vessels, fishing trawlers, lifeboats and warships. During the First World War, Erith dockyard played a major role in producing composite vessels, which were fitted with tank-like turrets to be used in assaulting enemy trenches. In 1926, the big demand for warships led to Erith merging with the River Engineering Co. and becoming known officially as the Erith and River Engineering Co. Ltd. The Erith dockyard was at its peak during the Second World War and by the end of the conflict had become known as the Erith Works, specialising in the manufacture of destroyer parts and cruiser parts. After the war the works shifted its focus to producing civilian vessels, including passenger and cargo ships for the Merchant Navy, as well as commercial trawlers, yachts and pleasure boats. The Erith dockyard closed its doors in 1975, and the site was gradually rehabilitated and redeveloped in the late-20th century. Today, the site of the former dockyard is occupied by a modern apartment block, a new housing development and a shopping centre. The heritage of the dockyard is remembered by the local community. There are plaques around Erith, which commemorate the proud dockyard history, including the fact that the Erith works built 19 destroyers during the Second World War, two of which were the first all-British destroyers in history. There is also a heritage board in the shopping centre. The history of the Erith dockyard is a fascinating reminder of the important role this small shipyard once played in the industrial and commercial life of the British people. This forgotten dockyard will never be forgotten, and will remain an important part of this country's rich maritime heritage.

Stephen Little (born March 3, 1976) is an American artist and arts educator. He is best known for his large-scale mural paintings depicting colorful geometric abstractions and vibrant images of wildlife and the natural environment, which have been installed in cities around the world. Born in Santa Rosa, California, Little grew up in Santa Cruz during the 1990s and early 2000s before moving to Oakland in 2010. He grew up surrounded by nature, playing outdoors and experiencing the natural environment of the West Coast. After earning a degree in art from California State University in Chico, Little began to pursue a career in the art world. His creative career began in 2007, with his first commissioned public mural appearing in Marin County, California. Since then, his work has been featured in various art exhibitions and has been installed in numerous high profile locations, including the California Academy of Science in San Francisco, the National Museum of Wildlife in Washington D.C., and The Contemporary Austin in Texas, among others. Little's work is strongly inspired by nature, with a focus on connecting viewers to the natural environment through bright colors, geometric forms, and vibrant imagery depicting wildlife and landscapes. Many of his works feature abstract landscapes and animals, often inspired by memories of his time spent outdoors as a child. In addition to his public murals, Little has taught art in many settings, ranging from elementary schools to university level art programs. He has given lectures, demonstrations, and artist talks at numerous institutions, including the University of California, Berkeley, University of the Pacific, and Stanford University. He has also been an artist-in-residence and staff artist in various locations throughout California. In addition to his painting, Little has also collaborated with several companies to create footwear designs, textile artwork, and clothing designs. His works have been featured in various publications, such as the Los Angeles Times, Juxtapoz Magazine, and the New York Times. Outside of the arts, Little has spent time working to support the environment, participating in various conservation projects. Stephen Little's artwork is regularly exhibited worldwide and continues to attract attention with its bright colors and nature-inspired imagery. His works can be found in numerous public and private collections around the world.

Ratt (EP) is an EP by the American hard rock band Ratt. It was released in 1984 through Atlantic Records. The EP featured the Top 40 hits, "Round and Round" and "Wanted Man". Both of these songs were included on the album Out of the Cellar. Ratt was founded in San Diego, California in 1982 by vocalist Stephen Pearcy, guitarists Robbin Crosby and Warren DeMartini, bassist Juan Croucier and drummer Bobby Blotzer. This line-up recorded the EP, along with a second version of "Round and Round". The success of "Round and Round" prompted Geffen Records to give the band a five-album record deal. The EP was a commercial success, reaching #20 on the US Billboard Top 100 charts, selling more than one million copies, and being certified Gold. The EP opened with "Round and Round", a hard rock song that combined a "bone-shaking" guitar riff with lyrics about a girl that Pearcy had written about. It is considered one of the band's signature songs, and gained success after being included on the eponymous debut album. The flipside of the single, "Wanted Man", was another hard rock song, with lyrics about an outlaw on the run from the law. The single eventually peaked at #12 on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart. The second version of "Round and Round" featured on the EP was a live acoustic version of the song. The live acoustic performance was recorded in London during a 1984 tour. The EP is often viewed as a breakthrough for the band, and is a testament to their early classic rock sound. It is considered a classic in the genre, and is still popular today among fans of classic hard rock and metal.

Claude Thornhill (August 10, 1908 – July 1, 1965) was an American pianist, arranger, composer, and bandleader. Thornhill was born in Terre Haute, Indiana. His father was a professional violinist who had led his own dance band since 1931, allowing the young Claude to absorb music from a very early age. Thornhill attended Indiana State University for two years, where he received classical training in composition and a degree in music theory. In his early career, Thornhill performed jazz music at several small clubs in the Midwest before receiving a job touring as a pianist for a vaudeville show. He later served as an arranger and accompanist for a number of famous bands, such as the Casa Loma Orchestra and the Ted Weems Orchestra. It was while working with Weems that Thornhill wrote his first hit song, “Harlem Nocturne”, which later became a jazz standard. In 1940, Thornhill formed his own orchestra and quickly earned a reputation as a progressive bandleader. He was among the first to arrange jazz music for a larger orchestra — including French horns and a full string section to complement the standard brass, woodwind, and rhythm sections — and he was always willing to experiment with fresh new sounds. Thornhill signed with Columbia Records in 1941 and released a number of critically acclaimed albums throughout the 1940s. His first big hit was the song “Snowfall”, which charted at #1 on Billboard’s chart of the nation’s most popular songs for two weeks in 1943. Thornhill's unique sound caught the attention of many jazz fans, and he became one of the first big swing bandleaders to draw a sizable crowd of African-American listeners. His colleague, trumpeter Miles Davis, noted that Thornhill was “the first genuine jazz composer and musician who had the nerve to write for a black audience". In the 1950s and 1960s, Thornhill toured and recorded extensively until health problems forced him to retire in 1965, the year of his death. His influence continued to be felt long after, inspiring later generations of jazz musicians and composers. He was inducted into the Big Band and Jazz Hall of Fame in 1989.

Joe Grey is an American entrepreneur, investor, engineer and philanthropist. He is most widely known for founding and leading Gray Wolf Exploration LLC, an energy exploration and development company. Joe Grey was born in Houston, Texas on June 15, 1980. He began studying engineering at the University of Texas at Austin, but soon transferred to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) where he earned his bachelor's degree in Mechanical Engineering. After earning his degree, Grey worked as a research and development engineer at Schlumberger, a major oil services and technology firm. In 2007, Grey founded Gray Wolf Exploration. Under his leadership, the company became a leader in deposits exploration and exploitation. The company soon acquired a number of strategic assets, including a significant stake in the natural gas reserves of the Gulf of Mexico and onshore shale projects, leading to significant growth in the firm's operations. In less than a decade, Grey had built Gray Wolf Exploration into a major player in the energy industry, eventually merging the company with another oil and gas firm and selling it to Chevron for a reported sum of more than $225 million in 2017. Following the sale of Gray Wolf Exploration, Grey retired from active business and invested his money in philanthropic projects. Since then, he has devoted much of his time and resources to various charitable causes. He is considered an effective, generous philanthropist with a focus on improving education and alleviating poverty. Grey has also recently become involved in environmental causes, investing in sustainable energy initiatives and developing strategies to reduce carbon emissions. Apart from philanthropy, Joe Grey also writes books on entrepreneurship and investing and lectures at universities around the world. Having started his own business from almost nothing and grown it into a major success story, he is regarded as a highly sought-after mentor and advisor in the world of venture capital. Overall, Joe Grey is a successful entrepreneur, investor and philanthropist with a reputation as a quietly effective and generous contributor to charitable causes. His success, determination and ever increasing influence in the worlds of venture capital and philanthropy have earned him the admiration of many and he is quickly becoming a symbol of success and a model of leadership and philanthropy in the world of business.

Sonwar Bagh is a garden located in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir, in the city of Srinagar. It is one of the oldest gardens in the state and was once one of the major attractions for tourists visiting the city. The garden was originally built in the 17th century by Mughal Emperor Jahangir. It is said that Jahangir enjoyed visiting this place during the summers and liked its lush greenery. The garden is often compared to Shalimar Bagh, another famous Mughal Garden in Srinagar. Sonwar Bagh spreads over an area of 20 acres, near the banks of the Jhelum river. The scenic landscape of the garden includes terraces lined with flowering shrubs and trees, as well as a large fish pond at its centre. Some of the trees found here are banyan, chinar, cypress, willow, and mulberry. The architectural ruins at Sonwar Bagh are a reminder of its days as a Mughal garden. The ruins of a gateway, a fountain, serais, and terraces can be seen in the garden. There is also an old bridge built by the Mughals, which is now in ruins. Sonwar Bagh is also known for its archaeological importance as evidence of ancient settlements have been found here. These ruins are from the ancient Hindu and Buddhist temples, as well as Pyramidal stone mounds. There are also sculptures of female figures dating back to 10th century AD. The garden is a popular spot among tourists, offering an opportunity to enjoy its scenic beauty and archaeological treasure. Visitors can take a leisurely stroll around the garden or relax by the fish pond while enjoying the view of the old ruins. Sonwar Bagh has been refurbished in recent times and is now an important tourist attraction in Srinagar. With its lush greenery and ancient ruins, it is seen as a piece of paradise not only for tourists, but also for the locals who often flock here in search of peace and relaxation.

Elkhart station is an Amtrak passenger train station located in Elkhart, Indiana. It serves both long-distance and local trains, such as the Capitol Limited, Lake Shore Limited, and Pennsylvanian. It also serves the South Shore Line commuter rail line, which is owned and operated by the Northern Indiana Commuter Transportation District. The station has two tracks and is located near downtown Elkhart, with a nearby connection to Route 20. The Elkhart station building was built in 1881 and was possibly the oldest remaining wooden train station in the United States when it was replaced in 2009. The new building officially opened on February 27, 2009 and was designed in a contemporary style to match the local industrial and transportation history. The station has a waiting room, restrooms, a dispatching room, and small concession area. Access to the station is provided by shuttle service from downtown Elkhart and from Indiana University South Bend. The station offers many amenities for passengers including a baggage service, ticket vending machines, and a lost and found area. The station provides local and long-distance bus services and has regularly scheduled bus departures for locations in Michigan, Ohio, and Pennsylvania. The station also offers a number of other features, including free short-term and long-term parking, bicycle racks, an ATM, and vending machines. Elkhart station is a popular destination for railway and bus passengers due to its convenient location and services. The station also serves as an integral part of the economy and community of Elkhart, providing important transportation and travel services to areas far and wide.

Netball in Africa is a popular female sport that is growing in popularity across the continent. The African continent has a long tradition of competing in netball, with the earliest known matches being played in South Africa in the early 1900s. It has since grown steadily in popularity, particularly in countries such as Malawi, Mozambique and Botswana. In addition to the established leagues found across the continent, girls and women from Africa have also come together to take part in prestigious youth and international tournaments such as the 2015 Netball World Youth Cup Africa tournament held in Uganda, and the 2016 African Netball Championship which was held in Zimbabwe. Netball is not only an exciting and fast-paced team sport, but it also provides potential lessons and values to participants. As such, it has helped to encourage empowerment and inclusivity among many of the young women who take part in it. This has been particularly true in countries with lower education quality, as the game provides an opportunity for girls to participate in activities and build new skills, while having fun at the same time. Netball in Africa has the potential to become even more popular in the coming years; encouraged by the increasing number of African International Netball Federation and International Netball Federation sanctioned events, and with more countries, such as Uganda and Zambia strengthening their developing netball programs. With this, the continent will hopefully be able to further strengthen and expand the popularity of the game and enable more young women to participate in it. Despite the positive development of netball across Africa, there are still many challenges that need to be overcome in order to ensure the continued growth of the sport. First and foremost, is the lack of funding, resources and infrastructure which has meant that many of the local and international tournaments have been cancelled due to insufficient numbers of players or an inadequate playing area. Furthermore, there have also been reports of high levels of gender discrimination and inequality in certain African countries, directed specifically towards netball events, which can further compound the difficulties of organizing and running events as well as maintaining regular training and competition fixtures. Indeed, despite the growing popularity of netball in Africa, much more still needs to be done to ensure that the game is able to fully realize its potential. Increased levels of support and investment in the game are necessary in order to help to continue the development of the sport, and ensure that the African continent can become a formidable competitive force in international netball.

Ron Schueler (born July 25, 1951 in Chicago, Illinois) is an American sports executive and former Major League Baseball (MLB) pitcher. He is currently an executive at Harris Blitzer Sports & Entertainment, where he is the Senior Vice President & General Manager of the Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association (NBA). Schueler attended Creighton University and was drafted in the 17th round of the 1972 MLB draft by the Baltimore Orioles. He pitched for four seasons in the minor leagues before making his MLB debut in 1975. Schueler was part of the starting rotation for the Orioles pitching staff in 1976, where he went 8-16 with a 4.91 ERA in 33 games. After briefly playing with the Cleveland Indians and Chicago White Sox in 1977 and 1978, Schueler retired and joined the White Sox as their scouting director in 1979. Schueler moved into the general manager role with the White Sox in 1990, a position he held until 2000. As General Manager, Schueler earned several accolades, including MLB Executive of the Year in 1995 and AL Executive of the Year in 2000. During his tenure, Schueler built two of the strongest and most successful teams in White Sox history, winning a division title in 2000 and making a World Series appearance in 1993. From 2000 until 2014, Schueler held executive positions with Major League Baseball's New York Mets and Oakland Athletics, as well as Minor League Baseball's Sacramento River Cats. In 2015, Schueler joined Harris Blitzer Sports & Entertainment, where he currently serves as Senior Vice President & General Manager of the Philadelphia 76ers. Throughout his career, Schueler has been a respected presence in the MLB, having built numerous successful teams. He remains active in baseball and mentoring young executives, and is a frequent guest speaker at the Baseball Commissioner’s Symposium.

The Word on the Street (WOTS) is a national Canadian non-profit charitable organization dedicated to promoting literacy, reading and writing both locally and nationally. WOTS hosts one of Canada’s largest book and magazine festivals, The Word On The Street (WOTStreets) festival, which takes place in cities across the country each year on the last Sunday of September. The festival features hundreds of exhibitors and vendors of new, used and antiquarian books, magazine, newspapers and other materials, as well as a variety of special events and activities. The festival seeks to bring together authors and readers both from, and beyond the Canadian literary world, featuring some of Canada’s leading authors, poets and journalists. Booths hosted by literary organizations, publishers, magazines, festivals and other book-related enterprises are also a mainstay of the WOTStreets festival. The primary purpose of the festival is to promote and celebrate books, reading and writing. WOTS produces a host of events throughout the year, including book launches, workshops and other events across Canada, in order to support their cause of literacy and a love of reading. One of WOTStreets more unique events is the "Word Play" game show and the "Great Canadian Poetry" slam. The Word Play game show has teams of local authors compete against each other to answer literary themed questions and guess the name of books from clues alone. The Great Canadian Poetry Slam is also very popular and features live performances by Canadian poets. Other activities such as Authors’ Corner, Magazines Canada Showcase and WOTS stage, featuring a number of eminent Canadian authors and plenty of reading-related discussion and debate are just some of the activities at the event. The Word on the Street Festival has been taking place since 1987 and has grown from a handful of participating vendors to one of Canada’s largest literary events, with more than 160,000 people attending each year. This event has become an important part of Toronto’s culture and has been a cornerstone of the city’s literary and cultural life. The Word On The Street Festival provides a wonderful opportunity to celebrate books, creativity, ideas and reading in Canada. It's a great event for the whole family, offering something for everyone with unique, exciting and inspiring literary programming.

Schizopygopsis is a genus of cyprinid fish that are native to Central and East Asia, from Bhutan and Nepal to the Amur Basin in eastern Russia and northern China. The genus contains over twenty species, most of which inhabit upland rivers and streams with cool to cold water environments. Some species may also enter waters around lakes and the edges of wetlands. The majority of Schizopygopsis species are medium-sized, with adults growing up to 25 cm (9.8 in) in length. They can be identified by their streamlined and laterally compressed bodies, featuring large eyes, powerful jaws and teeth, as well as muscular dorsal and caudal fins. Whilst adults of the species display a gray-brown coloration dorsally, most species also exhibit a distinct color pattern on the sides and belly, often with patterns of blue, green and red. The diet of Schizopygopsis consists mainly of aquatic insects such as midge larvae, crustaceans, and the larvae and eggs of other fish. In turn, the adults and juveniles of Schizopygopsis are consumed by a variety of predators, such as herons and hawks, as well as other fish. Schizopygopsis species may also occasionally enter into spawning migrations. For example, the Schizothorax richardsonii may migrate up to 40 km (25 miles) from their year-round habitats in isolated rivers to reach the tributaries of large lakes. When spawning, adults of this species may form dense aggregations. Upon hatching, larvae of most species drift downstream until they reach nursery habitats of shallower, warmer waters. Like many species of cyprinids, Schizopygopsis species are an important food source for local populations and are widely fished. Thus, there is intense pressure on these species, particularly in areas where capture limits are not regulated. As Schwizopygopsis inhabit relatively narrow ranges, they are susceptible to habitat changes that can affect their limited populations and also increase the risks of overfishing. Therefore, it is widely recommended that management plans be established to conserve these populations. Management plans should include provisions for setting appropriate catch limits and protecting their habitats from both chemical and physical disturbance. Furthermore, research should be conducted to better understand the ecology of these species and the effects of various environmental changes.

Future Worlds is a term referring to an imagined world in the future. This concept has been explored extensively in literature, films, television, video games, and other forms of media. The vision of future worlds typically centers on technological and socio-economic advances that have drastically changed the way people live, work, and play. Whether depicting a utopian paradise of advancement or a dystopian wasteland of destruction, all versions of the future promise a glimpse into the potential that lies in store for humanity. If not for the constant refinement and evolution of technology, many of the imagined futures presented in books, movies, and video games would not be possible. Examples of future worlds presented in media are plentiful. In literature, Aldous Huxley's Brave New World or George Orwell's 1984 explore the potential of societies vastly different from our own. In film, Joss Whedon's Serenity, Christopher Nolan's Inception, and James Cameron’s Avatar offer fascinating visions of the future. Television series such as Star Trek, Babylon 5, and Battlestar Galactica are also noteworthy in this regard. Video games are perhaps the medium most closely associated with the concept of future worlds. Examples such as Bioshock, Half-Life 2, and Mass Effect all feature visually stunning environments where the player experiences life outside of our reality. In each of these, the player is tasked with wandering through unknown and highly advanced environments full of unique challenges. Future worlds in media are often used to explore the potential consequences of humanity’s behavior over time. By leaving familiar surroundings and entering a world not yet realized, readers, viewers, and players can see firsthand the potential options available to society and its future inhabitants. In this way, future worlds can be seen as a kind of warning against the dangers of unchecked progress and ambition. Although always highly speculative, future worlds have become an integral part of the human experience in the modern age. By immersing oneself in an unknown reality that promises to be greater than anything which has come before, we can gain a glimpse of how our current actions and decisions may shape the future of our species.

. NDUFAF5 is a mitochondrial outer membrane protein found in humans and other animals. It is a member of the NADH-ubiquinone oxidoreductase family of proteins and is integral to the mitochondrial electron transport chain and function as part of the electron transfer system within the inner mitochondrial membrane. The protein is encoded by the NDUFAF5 gene and is thought to play an important role in mitochondrial energy production. The NDUFAF5 gene, located on the short arm of chromosome 12, consists of four exons, and encodes an outer-membrane protein of the same name. This gene has been linked to a mutation in the human NDUFAF5 gene associated with Leigh Syndrome. Leigh Syndrome is a severe neurological disorder which is caused by a defect in mitochondrial respiratory chain function. NDUFAF5 is a member of the NADH-ubiquinone Oxidoreductase family and, like all members of this family, it is a component of the electron transfer system within the inner mitochondrial membrane. This protein is involved in the transfer of electrons from NADH to the ubiquinone pool, and therefore plays an important role in energy production within the mitochondria. Functionally, NDUFAF5 has been shown to have an essential role in the assembly of the respiratory complex I. Specifically, it acts as a scaffold protein which binds the iron-sulfur clusters of the complex to the membrane at the interface. As such, NDUFAF5 is thought to be important for the efficient assembly of complex I and for its proper functioning. In addition to the role that NDUFAF5 plays in the assembly of complex I, it has been suggested to play a regulatory role in this evolutionary ancient enzymatic pathway. Specifically, it has been proposed that the interaction of NDUFAF5 with complex I is partially regulated by post-translational modification of NDUFAF5, suggesting that it may play a role in controlling the levels of complex I assembly and its activity. Overall, NDUFAF5 is an important mitochondrial membrane protein involved in electron transport, energy production and complex I assembly. Furthermore, the mutation of this gene has been suggested to result in Leigh Syndrome, highlighting the importance of NDUFAF5 in the healthy functioning of cells and organisms.

Brandubh of Tynagh is an early 8th century Irish game discovered in 1953 by Helen Roe and recorded by archaeologists in Ptolemy Dean's National Museum of Ireland excavations in county Galway. It is the oldest known board game in Europe. It is believed to have been played by the Celts. Brandubh consists of a board in the shape of a shield composed of 6 dots looking like points on the circular shield. There are also 5 pieces consisting of two black pieces that represent warriors and three white pieces that serve as the king and his counselors. The game has all the elements of a chess-like strategy game. The object of the game is to capture the king while protecting one's own king. To play the game, the pieces are placed on the board according to the positions of the dots which represent the cities of the players. The pieces are then moved according to a unique set of simple instructions requiring movements on the playing board. The pieces are moved until one side is victorious. The warrior piece, called the "brandubh," has the ability to move in any direction, jump over opponents or occupied squares, and capture any piece it lands on. Brandubh is still played in some parts of Ireland as a local custom. The game has been studied and interpreted as symbolic of conflict in the region in the 8th century, with the king and warriors representing powerful noble families fighting for land and resources. The discovery of Brandubh reveals the emergence of more sophisticated board games in Celtic society at the time. The board of Brandubh was found during excavation at the Irish site of Tynagh. The pieces were carefully labeled and are believed to have been made of bone. The discovery of Brandubh gave birth to a whole host of new interpretations of Irish Celtic board games. In fact, the game is so important to Irish culture that the Irish government once issued a commemorative coin bearing its depiction. The game of Brandubh of Tynagh is invaluable to Irish board game history and is a living testament to the culture of the Celts that lived there. It has grown in popularity over the years and is now celebrated by both Irish and international audiences.

Doherty Amplifier is an RF power amplifier that is designed to improve the efficiency of RF power amplifiers. The Doherty Amplifier is a variation on the traditional Class-AB power amplifier design. It is named after Stuart Doherty, who developed the technique in 1936. The Doherty amplifier is characterized by two amplifier stages. The first is a high-efficiency Class-A amplifier, known as the carrier or drive amplifier. This amplifier is used to provide the bulk of the power output at low power levels. The second is a low-efficiency Class-B amplifier, known as the peak amplifier, which is used to provide additional power at saturation or peak power levels. The Doherty amplifier works by operating the carrier amplifier at a lower power level than the peak amplifier. This allows the peak amplifier to be more efficient since it is only used to gain the additional power needed at peak power levels. By using this technique, the overall amplifier efficiency can be increased significantly when compared to a single Class-AB amplifier. The Doherty Amplifier can be used in a variety of applications, including broadcast radio and television transmission systems, mobile communications systems, as well as other RF and microwave systems. The advantages of Doherty amplifiers over traditional Class-AB amplifiers include higher efficiency, better power control, and improved linearity. In broadcast applications, Doherty Amplifiers have been used for many years to improve the overall efficiency of RF transmitters. They are preferred over most other types of amplifiers due to their unique design and ability to efficiently provide power at both low and peak power levels. Doherty amplifiers are also used in commercial and industrial radio communication systems and domestic applications, such as Wi-Fi systems. The advantages to using them in these applications are increased efficiency, improved linearity and better thermal stability. The Doherty Amplifier is an important component in RF communications and is becoming increasingly important in other industries as the need for higher efficiency amplifiers increases. As technology continues to improve, it is likely that this technique will be used even more widely in the future.

Ashwin Kumar Lakshmikanthan (born 15th May 1990) is a prominent Indian fantasy sports player. He is most well-known for becoming the first Indian to win the International Fantasy Football Championship held in January 2019 in London. Lakshmikanthan was born in Chennai, Tamil Nadu. He began playing fantasy sports in 2010, and has since established himself as one of the best fantasy football players in the world. He won his first major tournament in 2016, taking first place at the UEFA Fantasy League Series in Budapest. In 2017, he placed in the top 10 in the official Fantasy Premier League and was a finalist in the European Fantasy Pro League. In 2018, Lakshmikanthan achieved a significant milestone when he became the first Indian to qualify for the International Fantasy Football Championship. He went on to win the tournament, defeating over 640 players from around the world and winning a cash prize of US $75,000. The victory made him a celebrity among the fantasy sports community and earned him sponsorships from MTN, Dream11, and Adda52. Following his major victory, Lakshmikanthan has continued to compete in several major tournaments and leagues. His successes include a third-place finish in the 2018 World Cup Fantasy League, a second-place finish in the 2019 Grand Prix Ligue 1 League, and a fourth-place finish in the 2019 Champions League. Apart from playing fantasy football, Lakshmikanthan is also a highly acclaimed content creator and influencer. He regularly posts his own analysis and tips on his YouTube channel, where he has over 75,000 subscribers. He also hosts an FM radio show showcasing the best fantasy sports talents from India and other countries. In 2019, he was featured in a documentary short film produced by the BBC, showcasing his journey from being an unknown amateur player to one of the most recognizable names in fantasy sports. Lakshmikanthan is also an avid supporter of sustainable and ethical gaming. He is an ambassador for several initiatives promoting responsible gaming and works with industry stakeholders and authorities to promote education around fantasy sports and regulation. Throughout his career, Lakshmikanthan has won multiple awards and recognitions, including the 2020 Cashless Gaming Award and the 2017 Fantasy Footballer of the Year Award. He currently holds the rank of Champion Fantasy Footballer in the International Fantasy Football Federation and is widely considered one of the most promising talents in the fantasy sports world.

Oldřich Nejedlý (born June 10, 1867 - November 9, 1951) was a Czech sculptor, illustrator, painter, and architect. He is best known for his sculptures, with the greatest concentration of his work in Prague and the Czechoslovakian region. Nejedlý was born in Hrochův Týnec, Bohemia. He began his work in the late 19th century, and trained as a sculptor in Vienna in 1889-90. He then studied at the Prague Academy of Arts in 1894, and finally taught at the same academy from 1913 to 1932. Nejedlý's sculptures often depict young and muscular women, which reflects his unabashedly naturalistic approach to the sculpting process. Many of his sculptures can be found in national parks and museums throughout the Czech Republic, including the botanic gardens of Brno and Terezín. His statue of St. Procopius, for instance, stands in the small church of Záhorská Ves. In addition to his sculptures, Nejedlý took up painting and illustrations. His illustrated books, such as The Life of St. Procopius, remain popular even today. He also wrote several essays on art and aesthetics, including 'Art in Relation to Nature' and 'The Use of Color in Art'. In the 1920s, Nejedlý launched a successful career as an architect. Among his works are the National Memorial in Prague, the National Active Poor Refuge, and the National Women's University. His picturesque house in the woods of Slavkov, called Villa Hvezda, is considered to be his greatest architectural feat. Oldřich Nejedlý died on November 9, 1951 in Prague. He remains one of the most prominent sculptors, painters, and architects of the 20th century from the Czech Republic. His legacy comprises of numerous sculptures, paintings, illustrations, and buildings, all distinctive in their own unique way.

The Acer Aspire One is a subcompact netbook computer manufactured by Acer Inc. released in July 2008. The Aspire One focused on portability, with models featuring Intel Atom processors and 7-inch to 10.1-inch LED-lit displays. The Aspire One was initially popular due to its low price, with versions drenched in various colors offering aesthetic appeal. The Acer Aspire One features Intel Atom processors which are energy efficient. This allows for longer battery life than mainstream CPUs and helps to keep prices low. The laptop can be purchased with either a 8.9-inch, 10.1-inch or 11.6-inch display. The 8.9 and 10.1-inch displays are LED-lit, while the 11.6-inch displays offer HD display. In terms of storage, the Aspire One offers a range of hard drive options. Most models featuring traditional hard drives, although some models incorporate an SSD (solid state drive). These SSDs offer faster read and write speeds but lack large capacity sizes. As such, they are better suited to netbooks with limited requirement for storage. The Aspire One ran the Windows XP Home Edition operating system, although some customizable configurations offer different operating systems. A range of connectivity ports helps the user to connect a range of peripherals, including USB, VGA and FireWire. The Aspire One also features an integrated webcam, integrated Wi-Fi and Ethernet, optional 3G, as well as optional Bluetooth. Most models feature a 3-cell battery, although some configurations feature 6-cell batteries allowing for up to 8 hours of battery life. This makes the Aspire One particularly suited for those needing an ultraportable device when travelling. In general, the Acer Aspire One is a cheap, light and versatile laptop for those needing an ultraportable computer. It is an ideal fit for those on the move or with limited storage needs. Although equipped with mediocre specs, the Aspire One has managed to stand the test of time, with newer models still in production today.

Charles Ray Hatcher (1919–2005) was an American entrepreneur and philanthropist who, through his various business ventures over the course of his long life, made great contributions to the communities of Georgia and Alabama in which he lived. Hatcher was born in Marshallville, Georgia, in 1919. He was the youngest child of nine siblings and attended school in his hometown. After serving in World War II and the Korean War, he attended the Georgia Institute of Technology and earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Industrial Engineering. After completing his education, Hatcher began his career in engineering. He was employed at the Martin Marietta Griffiss Air Force Base in Rome, Georgia, and he went on to become a manufacturing executive at the Fiberite Corporation in Brimingham, Alabama. He later served as a Vice President at the American Can Company in Parkway, Georgia. Throughout his business career, Hatcher was passionate about giving back to the communities he called home. In 1967, he founded and served as president of the Monitor Group, Inc., a printing and lithography company based in Birmingham. His company was known for outstanding service and quality workmanship, particularly in the production of product labeling. In 1991, Hatcher established the Charles R. Hatcher Foundation, a non-profit organization which provides support to numerous sciences, education, and health care organizations. The foundation has provided many scholarships for students in Alabama, Georgia and Tennessee. Additionally, the foundation has funded research in the fields of medical science and biotechnology. Hatcher was also a passionate supporter of music and the performing arts. His foundation established a theatre program for children at the Alabama Shakespeare Festival and also provided generous funding for the symphony orchestras in Birmingham and East Point, Georgia. Though he was a successful businessman and philanthropist, Hatcher never forgot his humble roots. He was known for his generosity to his community and his genuine desire to help others. At the time of his death in 2005, he had touched thousands of lives through his philanthropy, inspiring countless people to strive for greatness.

Packet switching is a data communication method which breaks information into packets that are then sent over a channel shared by multiple types of communication. This allows multiple messages to be sent at the same time over shared communication lines while limiting the amount of interference each message experiences. Packets, also known as datagrams, are typically identified by their source and/or destination addresses, along with format and control information. Packet switching can support multiple communication protocols, including Ethernet, asynchronous transfer mode, token ring, and X.25. Packet switching was first developed in the 1960s, but was improved throughout the 1970s and 1980s. During this time, the technology moved from mainframe computing to distributed systems and was widely used in digital networks. Packet switching is often combined with other technologies such as frame relay, X.25, and asynchronous transfer mode (ATM). Today, packet switching is still commonly used, particularly in the internet. Packet switching is advantageous over traditional circuit switching in several ways. It makes much more efficient use of bandwidth and resources, as the data being sent is broken into smaller chunks and only the necessary portion of a link will be used to send the data. Packet switching also allows for dynamic traffic routing, as packets can be sent through different channels to their intended destinations. This mode of communication can also support error detection and correction by re-sending packets if errors are detected. There are also potential drawbacks to packet switching. As multiple communication paths can be used for transmission, the amount of time for a message to reach its destination can vary. Additionally, collisions can occur, when the same link is used to transmit two or more packets at the same time. Finally, as packets are routed independently of each other, there is potential for packets to get out of order. Overall, packet switching is an effective method of communication for digital networks, and is widely used in the internet. By breaking data into smaller portions, packet switching allows for efficient communication which can support multiple protocols and dynamic traffic routing. While there are potential drawbacks, packet switching is still an important component of modern digital networks. References: [1] https://searchnetworking.techtarget.com/definition/packet-switching [2] https://www.codesandciphers.org.uk/documents/packets/packet.HTM [3] https://www.networksolutionsme.com/networks/packet-switching/

The 1520s in music saw a flourishing of polyphony, part songs and motets during the Renaissance period. The decade was a time of experimentation, with composers experimenting with different polyphonic structures, textures and rhythms. During this period, polyphony became increasingly complex, culminating in the works of Thomas Tallis and William Byrd. The range of genres during this period was vast, ranging from sacred music to secular songs. Composers of the 1520s wrote a variety of different sacred pieces, including motets, Mass settings and hymns. These works focus on the spiritual aspects of music and often include intricate melodies and harmonies, as well as harmonies written in the contrapuntal style. The most famous composers of sacred music during this decade include Josquin Desprez, Thomas Tallis and William Byrd. In the field of secular music, the 1520s saw the rise of the Netherlandic-French School and the English Madrigal. This new genre of music was characterized by its lively melodies, contrasting between homophonic and polyphonic structure, and its ability to create vivid scenes and moods. Popular composers of madrigals during this period include Thomas Morley, John Wilbye, and Thomas Weelkes. In addition to these two genres, music during the 1520s was also influenced by popular forms such as the estampie, basse danse and passepied. These popular dance forms, often accompanied by instruments like the lute, commonly appear in music manuscripts from this decade. The influence of the Renaissance period was pervasive throughout Europe, and the 1520s saw a wide variety of regional styles emerge. Composers from Italy such as Palestrina, Gombert and Marenzio incorporated imitative counterpoint into their compositions. In Germany and Austria, the influence of the Reformation lead to the emergence of a distinct chorale style, characterized by its strict contrapuntal settings and German sacred texts. In the New World, the 1520s are particularly noteworthy for the rise of the Mexican chanson. This genre, which has its roots in Spanish folk songs, developed into a distinct style featuring vocal parts and texts written in Spanish and Nahuatl. Popular composers of Mexican chansons include Diego Enciso and Juan López de Flandes. Overall, the 1520s were a pivotal period in musical history. This decade saw the emergence of many different musical styles, forms and genres, and the emergence of composers who would reshape the musical landscape of Europe and the world.

Friedrich Horschelt (born 1849 in Berlin; died March 7, 1938 in Berlin) was a famed German dancer, choreographer, and theater director. He began his performing career in Germany in 1870 but moved to the United States shortly after. In the U.S., Horschelt quickly became renowned, performing with the Carl Rosa Grand Opera Company, as well as several stock companies as a dance soloist and choreographer. He is credited with choreographing "The Black Flag", the first coon song performed on an American stage. He was an important figure in the development of modern dance in the United States, and wrote the first dancing manual written in English. In 1879, he co-founded the National College of Dancing, the first public education school in the United States devoted to teaching dance, located in New York City. He was the school’s principal until 1885, when he returned to Europe and founded the Old Viennese State Opera Ballet School. The school made a tremendous impact in the world of ballet in Germany and modern dance in Austria. Horschelt was named professor of dancing at the Dresden State Theatre in 1877. He was appointed professor of ballet at the Imperial Ballet in Vienna in 1906 and later, director of the Imperial Ballet in 1911. His research helped initiate an important reform period in German and Austrian ballet. In 1895, he wrote "Treatise on Pageantry in Schools and Colleges", an important work for physical educators and dancers. His most respected work, "The Art of Ballet," was published in 1927. It was immediately recognized as one of the best and most comprehensive works on the theory, history, and technique of ballet. One of the most acclaimed dancers of his time, Horschelt was widely recognized by both German and American audiences. He received numerous awards during his career, including the Order of the Iron Cross, Prussian Civil Orders, the Order of Merit and honorary weapons, the Doctor of Letters, and was inducted into the United States's National Dance Hall of Fame. By the time of his death in 1938, Horschelt had performed more than 200 concerts and ballets around the world. He is considered one of the most influential dancers and educators of his time, and his works continue to form a historical and instructional basis for modern-day dancing.

Sergei Shmatko (born 20 April 1958) is a Russian statesman and former minister of energy from 2009 to 2012. He has held various government positions since 1992 and is a member of United Russia. Early life Shmatko was born on 20 April 1958 in Moscow, where he graduated from a secondary specialized industrial college in 1978. In 1985 he graduated from the Moscow Institute of Electronic Engineering with a specialty in automation and methodical management of technological processes. Career In the early 1990s Shmatko was a major at the Leningrad Military Commandant's Institute. From 1992 to 1995 he was the head of the Moscow Police Department. From 1995 to 2000 he worked as an adviser to the head of the Interior Ministry. In 2000 he became the First Deputy Minister of the Interior. He served in this office until 2002 and then became advisor to the Ministry of Economic Development and Trade. In 2006 Shmatko was appointed Deputy Minister of Energy of the Russian Federation. Three years later he was appointed Minister of Energy in the government of Prime Minister Vladimir Putin. He served in this office until 16 May 2012. In October 2019, Shmatko has been appointed as the Head of the Federal Agency for State Property Management. Political views Shmatko is a member of United Russia, Russia’s dominant political party. His views are primarily pro-Putin and he advocates for greater economic and political unity between European and Russian countries. He has called for energy security in the world and stated that nuclear energy should not be disregarded as an energy source. Awards and honours In 2009 Shmatko was presented with the Order of Friendship, an award bestowed upon individuals who have "made a great contribution to strengthening friendship and cooperation between nations". He also holds a number of honorary titles and awards, including the Order for Services to the Homeland, 1st class, and the Order of Honour. Personal life Shmatko is married and has a son.

The Navy Special Action Regiment (SANAR) is a special operations force of the Colombian Navy created in 1974. The ring, ratified in July of the same year, is an elite security, intelligence and action unit, trained and prepared to efficiently complete the most complex and difficult tasks the Navy may have. The members of the regiment come mostly from the Naval Infantry and the Naval Cavalry, as well as being selected from other divisions, due to their special characteristics and physical and psychological conditions requested. The duration of the training process ranges from one and a half to three years, with activities such as Sea, Air and Jungle Infantry, Swimming, Survival, Intelligence, Free Fall, etc. The mission of the Navy Special Action Regiment is to protect the sovereignty of the Republic of Colombia in the Caribbean Sea and in all the territorial waters of the pacific, eliminate rebellion and terrorism, apply the sanctioned laws of sea and air, and protect the national coasts, islands and maritime and fluvial commerce in accordance with the government of Colombia. The unit is made up of various specialized branches such as the 1st Naval Infantry Parachute Battalion, the 2nd Naval Infantry Air Assault Battalion, the 1st Naval Cavalry Anti-Terrorism Battalion, the 2nd Naval Cavalry Maintenance, Communications and Logistics Battalion, the 3rd Naval Infantry Amphibious Battalion and the 4th Naval Infantry Intelligence Battalion, among other highly specialized branches. The SANAR is equipped with the most advanced systems and weapons; all its members are highly qualified professionals and have the security and defense of the territory as their main mission. Consequently, the Navy Special Action Regiment is the principal element of the National Plan of Maritime Security. The SANAR has developed special operations inside and outside the country, participating in the fight between the Government of Colombia and the rebels, supporting other nations in the fight against drug trafficking, performing search and rescue actions, providing humanitarian aid and providing training in intelligence and special action topics. The members of the Navy Special Action Regiment are the most highly trained and qualified in the country, and the unit's operations offer a high level of efficiency and reliability. They guarantee the sovereignty of the country and comply with their mission to protect the Nation from any aggression that violates Its sovereign rights.

Jin-go-lo-ba is a traditional West African rhythm and song game. It is thought to have originated in Cameroon and been passed on to various West African countries. It is commonly played among the Mandinka, Ewe and Ga people of Ghana, and other tribes in Guinea and Nigeria. The name Jin-go-lo-ba is derived from the phrase “to exchange messages of love,” which is indicative of the game's purpose, to engage players in a musical exchange or “dialogue.” In a typical game, two people take turns singing, clapping, and imitating each other's movements. The exchange between the two participants is interactive, with the two competing to make their movements the most creative and challenging, leading one participant to attempt more intricate moves than the other. No instruments are used during Jin-go-lo-ba. The players keep time with their hands and feet, and the game often relies on improvisation and audience participation. Players can also choose to add words, facial expressions, and variations in their movements and rhythms. Jin-go-lo-ba is usually played at weddings, festivals, or other celebrations. It is a form of entertainment, a means of expression, and a collective experience. Sometimes, two or three people join together to form a jin-go-lo-ba trio. The game has been adapted over the years and is increasingly used in contemporary performance contexts. It is also used in West African dance classes and drumming circles, as the musical and rhythmic structure of the game is ideal for exploring musical ideas and establishing a groove. Jin-go-lo-ba is now gaining popularity all over the world, as artists incorporate it into their own live performances and recordings. Now, with the rising interest in West African music and culture, Jin-go-lo-ba is gaining appreciation from around the world. Jin-go-lo-ba is an important part of traditional West African culture, and is sure to remain relevant for years to come. The game is proof that even with the development of western musical genres and instruments, it is still possible to have musical conversations with just the use of body movement and voices.

Armenian needlelace is a type of fine needlework, also known as kshot or kshord, developed in Armenia in the 19th century. It is characterized by geometrically arranged white or off-white cotton threads worked into an intricate, symmetrical pattern of multiple layers. The process of making Armenian needlelace is much like that of other forms of needlework—needles and thread, not embroidery floss—but the outcome is a very distinctive, strong three-dimensional design. The basic element of the needlelace are the stitches which are made in a regular pattern to make up the ground or foundation of the design, typically with one layer of stitching having multiple layers of stitching added to it. The stitches used in Armenian needlelace include poke, round, and buttonhole, as well as 'satyn' (double running) and 'ojakheer.' It takes a great deal of skill and dedication to the craft to create a finished piece. The intricate patterns used in the craft of needlelacing make it unique and highly sought after. Patterns are repeated multiple times and even the most experienced craftsperson could not replicate a pattern by memory. Consequently, an Armenian needlelacer would traditionally document their work in a pattern book with written or drawn diagrams of the pattern. Armenian needlelace is highly valued and has a long history, tracing back to ancient times when it was used to embellish clothing and furnishings. It was used to decorate clothes and buildings, from churches to palaces, and the craftsman had to be highly skilled to achieve the intricate patterns. Armenian needlelace is a valued skill, not only for its beauty, but for its symbolism. During certain folklore traditions, young women gathered to sew together items of needlelace and would make toasts with the resulting piece. The toasts would serve to bless the young women and wish them success. The needlelace pieces were then blessed at church and hung in homes, believed to bring protection and health to the family. In modern times, Armenian needlelace is still a respected craft and continues to be used by skilled practitioners to decorate clothing, furnishings, even as a stand-alone piece. Its uniqueness and craftsmanship are what make it so special, and a testament to the generations of craftspeople who used the medium to create something that stands the test of time.

Tracy Jordan (born 1964) is an American actor, comedian, and musician. He is best known for his role as Tracy Jordan on the television sitcom 30 Rock which aired from 2006-2013. Jordan was born in Wisconsin, though he spent most of his childhood in Chicago. He began his career as an amateur stand-up comedian in 1990, eventually supporting himself as a cab driver while performing at comedy clubs around Chicago. His big break came in 1999, when he was cast in the cult comedy sitcom The Tracy Jordan Show. The show ran for four seasons, though its ratings steadily decreased throughout its run. Jordan earned two Emmy nominations during the show's run for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series. In 2006, Jordan was cast as Tracy Jordan on the sitcom 30 Rock. His portrayal of the flamboyant and often outrageous character earned him two Emmy and three Golden Globe Award nominations. Jordan also starred in a recurring role on the NBC series Law & Order: Criminal Intent as Detective Charles Collins from 2008 to 2011. Additionally, he has had guest roles on Saturday Night Live, The Office, and Parks and Recreation. In 2006, Jordan released his debut rap album Busta Rhymes Is My Daddy. The album was met with lukewarm reviews, but it did not deter Jordan from continuing his music career. In 2007, he released his follow-up album Twisted Brain Cells, to better reception. Outside of acting and music, Jordan is a philanthropist. He has worked with causes related to hunger and poverty, animal rights, and disability rights. He also supported President Barack Obama during his 2008 presidential campaign. He was named the Human Rights Campaign's National Coming Out Project Honorary Ambassador in 2012. Jordan lives in Los Angeles with his wife, Angie Jordan, and their three children.

The European Association for Digital Humanities (EADH) is a non-governmental and non-profit organization that seeks to promote digital humanities research, networking and cooperation on an international and interdisciplinary level. Founded in 2012 by a group of scholars passionate about the use of digital technologies to advance humanities knowledge, the EADH seeks to bring digital humanities to the forefront of humanities research and teaching in Europe and beyond. The EADH works to inform, represent and connect members to the worldwide digital humanities community and to advocate for the production and use of digital technologies for humanities research. The EADH works closely with other organizations and networks, such as the Alliance of Digital Humanities Organizations (ADHO), the Association of European Research Libraries (LIBER), and the Consortium of European Social Science Data Archives (CESSDA). In addition, the EADH has developed a number of initiatives, such as establishing and hosting the annual European Summer University in Digital Humanities as well as promoting initiatives to make educational and research material in the Humanities freely available. The EADH is an active and diverse body comprised of researchers, teachers, institutions, publishers, archivists and research data centres. It administers a number of key initiatives and events, such as biennial conferences, sessions at other major international conferences, workshops, and webinars. Furthermore, the EADH has launched a number of publications, including in-depth research reports and newsletters that aim to share knowledge, promote teaching, and advocate for digital humanities. In its attempt to encourage career development and providing collaboration opportunities, the EADH also manages a number of grant programs, such as the Early Career Grant, the JISC Cloud Computing Call, and the Established Career Grant. In addition, the EADH is an official partner to the Digital Humanities Awards, through which it recognizes outstanding achievements and abilities in the field of digital humanities. The EADH is a scholarly environment for innovation, collaboration, and experimentation and serves as a bridge for dialogue between academics, libraries, IT professionals, science and technology funders, cultural heritage institutions, and research data centres. Thus, the EADH brings together European Digital Humanities experts and institutions in order to develop the field and explore future challenges in Digital Humanities research, teaching, and technology.

Tolitoli Regency covers an area of 1,705.46 km^2 in Central Sulawesi, Indonesia. It has a population of about 300,000 people, mainly Malay and the indigenous Buton tribes. The capital of Tolitoli Regency is Tolitoli Town, located on the eastern coastline of the regency. The economy of Tolitoli Regency is mainly agricultural, with corn being the main crop. Other crops produced here include rice, cassava, coconut, and sugarcane. Fishing is the other main economic activity in this region, with pelagic fish being the most common catch. Tolitoli Regency borders the following regencies: North Buton Regency to the west, South Buton Regency to the southwest, Morowali Regency to the south and southeast, Donggala Regency to the east, and Banggai Regency to the north. The regency is also bordered by the Jawano Strait to the east and the Minahasa Gulf to the north. The town of Tolitoli itself was once the capital of Central Sulawesi, and, in the 17th century, was the epicenter of the Buton Kingdom - one of the island's major seafaring trading powers. The town is renowned for its local culture and art, including the famous Makasar, Bugis and Butonese-influenced lontara script during colonial and contemporary times. Tolitoli Regency is home to a variety of wildlife, including the Tarsier, a small primate native to the area. The regency is also home to the rare pygmy manta ray, as well as a number of deep sea shark species. Birdwatchers will be able to view Tolitoli's numerous native bird species, such as the Sulawesi hornbill. Tolitoli is known throughout the region for its vibrant night markets, which offer a variety of local produce and handicrafts. The markets are set up nightly in the town's main square, and it is common to see large crowds enjoying the atmosphere. Tolitoli Regency is not without its share of challenges. The regency is impacted by both regional and global climate change, with increased flooding occurring due to rising sea levels. The local population also faces health issues due to sanitation and a lack of access to clean water. Despite these challenges, Tolitoli is a vibrant region of Central Sulawesi and an important destination for travelers and locals alike. Its wide array of cultural and natural attractions, combined with a unique Malay-Butonese cultural identity, makes Tolitoli Regency a place worth visiting.

Mario Frittoli (born December 25, 1962) is an Italian film and television producer, writer, and director known for his wide-ranging projects. He is best known for producing the films Dear Father (1995), The Consequences of Love (2004), and Red Light (2017). Frittoli was born in Massa, Italy, and grew up in Genoa, Italy. After studying Communication Arts at the Art Institute of Liguria, he entered the world of film and TV production in 1984. During his career he has worked in different industry-related positions, including Director in Secondary and Representative of Production Companies, General Distributor and International Distributor. He began his career in film and television as a producer at Cinecittà. His first two films, Dear Father and The Consequences of Love, were both met with critical acclaim. In 1996, Frittoli won the Italian Film Academy Award for best screenplay for Dear Father. In 2002, Frittoli left Cinecittà and opened his own production company. Since then, he has collaborated with numerous TV production companies, not only in Italy but also abroad (e.g. Spain, UK, USA, France, Germany). Frittoli has produced multiple films, series and documentaries since 2004. He has also directed several films and documentaries. His most acclaimed film, The Consequences of Love, earned seven Academy awards, including Best Film. Frittoli's latest projects include television series such as "Tales of the New World" and the film Red Light, which premiered at the 2017 Venice Film Festival. The same year, he received an Academy Prize for his contribution to cinema. Frittoli is an active member of the European Parliament and is an active campaigner for human rights and environmental protection. He is an outspoken critic of Italy's economic crisis, and regularly speaks out about the effects it has on the culture, economy and politics. In addition to his work in television and film, Frittoli is a prolific writer. He has written a series of novels, the most recent of which, Let's Talk About Love, was released in 2016. He is also an avid traveler and speaks various languages, including English, Spanish, French, and German.

Paul Billerbeck (born December 5, 1897 in Wiesbaden, Germany, died December 10, 1988 in Wiesbaden) was a German theologian and New Testament scholar. He was a professor emeritus at Tübingen University. Billerbeck studied at the universities of Marburg, Giessen, and Göttingen and attained his doctorate in 1924 at the University of Göttingen. In 1932 he obtained his habilitation at the University of Tübingen. He was made a professor at the University of Tübingen in 1935. His research mostly focused on the New Testament, though he also wrote on ancient history and archaeology. He did research on the Greek language, parables of Jesus, and explored Christian ethics using the insights of New Testament theology. He wrote extensively on the Synoptic Gospels, focusing on historical and textual criticism, theological themes, and cultural context. He also wrote on the life of Jesus and the events of the Resurrection. One of his works is an analysis of the development of the Easter narrative. In 1944 and 1945, Billerbeck participated as an editor of the NTSBS series, as well as an editor of the German theological journal Neutestamentliche Zeitschrift. With the help of fellow editor Hermann Strack, he was able to keep the journal going despite the demands of the Nazis on his time, despite being prohibited by the Nazis from publishing because he was Jewish. Billerbeck died in 1988 at age 91. His body was buried in the Wiesbaden Jewish Cemetery. He was best known for his five-volume commentary on the Synoptic Gospels, Das Kirchengeöcht des Neuen Testaments (The Church History of the New Testament). His work is considered a cornerstone of modern New Testament scholarship. Billerbeck's work has been praised for its insightfulness and depth and for his ability to reconcile scholarship with devotion. He brought the knowledge of an historian and the faith of a theologian to his work, making it the standard for interpretation. His expertise on ancient history and his profound theological analysis are seen to this day as the essential frameworks for interpreting the Bible.

Philabundance is an American nonprofit organization based in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania that was founded in 1984. It works to alleviate hunger and malnutrition in the Philadelphia area by reducing food waste and acquiring food to distribute to those in need in the community. Founded by Susan Frost, Randall Freed, and Rick Langan, Philabundance helps more than 90,000 people each week receive meals. Philabundance helps to significantly reduce hunger in the Philadelphia area by providing both food assistance programs and nutrition programs. These programs include the Community Food Distribution program, the KidsBites program, and the Mobile Food Pantry. Philabundance acquires and distributes food through two methods. The first is through donations from individuals, events, and business partners; the second is through its own food sourcing, meaning that Philabundance acquires some of the food it distributes directly from supermarkets and farms. Through these two methods, Philabundance is able to provide food to many different parts of the community, including low-income families, children, and the elderly. In addition to food assistance, Philabundance also provides nutrition and education programs. The KidsBites program is a healthy diet education program for children from preschool to 8th grade and the Mobile Food Pantry program provides fresh fruits, vegetables and other nutritious foods to vulnerable communities in the area. Philabundance also aims to reduce food waste through its "Rescuing Leftover Cuisine" program, in which it connects restaurants, caterers, and other food-service providers with nearby shelters and churches to ensure that excess food is not sent to landfills. Philabundance’s efforts to combat hunger and poverty have earned it numerous awards and recognition including being named Nonprofit of the Year in 2018. It has also been recognized by the Pennsylvania Nonprofit Association and Pennsylvania State Senate. Philabundance’s success is largely due to its dedicated staff, volunteers, and supporters who strive to make sure no one in the Philadelphia area ever goes hungry. Philabundance is dedicated to making sure no one in the Philadelphia area ever goes hungry and its food assistance, nutrition, and education programs have allowed it to make a big impact in the fight against hunger and malnutrition. Philabundance is dedicated to continuing its fight to end hunger and malnutrition in the Philly area and its commitment to reducing food waste has allowed it to have an even bigger impact and help even more people in the community.

Malik Ek is an Indian singer, songwriter, producer and actor from Kochi, Kerala. He has recorded songs in numerous languages, including Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam, Hindi, Kannada and English. Malik Ek was born and raised in Kochi, Kerala, India. He began singing at the age of 5, and moved to Chennai at the age of 8 to pursue his music career. He received his initial training in carnatic music from B.N.S.Rajam at the Weavers School, Chennai. He then went on to study Western music under S.A.Ragu in Chennai. Malik Ek is known for his wide vocal range, which he has showcased in his numerous singles and albums. His first single, 'Kannan', was released in 2008, and became an instant hit in South India. He has since released several successful singles and albums, some of which have topped the Billboard Indian music charts. Malik Ek has collaborated with several popular artists, such as Sunitha Upadrasta, Shankar Mahadevan, Benny Dayal and Vijay Prakash. He has composed for several Tamil and Telugu films, and is the playback singer for AR Rahman's 'Yaaro Yaaro'. He has also performed live at several venues around the world, including Carnegie Hall in New York City. In addition to his music career, Malik Ek has also acted in various films and television shows. He made his debut in 2010, in the television show Kanda Naal Mudhal, which was directed by K. Balachander. He has since gone on to appear in several films, such as Kadamban, Chitram, Vrundavanam and Karmayodha. Malik Ek is known for his philanthropic work, and he has established two foundations in Kochi and Chennai named after him, which work to help underprivileged children. He also founded his own record label, Jagadamba Records, and launched his own jewelry brand, Maharaja Jewels. As of 2021, Malik Ek is one of the most popular singers in India, with a huge fan base around the world. His work has earned him numerous awards and accolades, including three South Indian Filmfare Awards, two Tamil Nadu State Film Awards, and the National Film Award for Best Music Direction. Malik Ek continues to write, produce and perform music, and is committed to giving back to the community. He is an inspiration to many aspiring singers and musicians, and is seen as a leader in the Indian music industry.

Angelo di Pietro (born 1962) is an Italian entrepreneur and business mogul. He made his fortune through extensive involvement in the real estate, construction, asset management, banking, and commercial brokerage industries. Born in the small town of Giugliano in Campania, Italy, Angelo followed his father’s footsteps and entered the construction industry. His first project was a building in Rome, and after this success, he moved on to larger projects. Angelo quickly rose to the top of his profession, developing complex business strategies that allowed him to invest in lucrative opportunities around the world, such as the European Union, the United States, and the Middle East. The combination of his business acumen and drive to succeed has made Angelo a highly successful businessman. He has earned a reputation as one of the most respected entrepreneurs in the Italian business world. Furthermore, Angelo is a strong proponent of corporate social responsibility. His corporate philosophy focuses on “building a better world” and seeks to actively contribute to making Italy a better place. He has established a number of charitable organizations to help make this a reality. Angelo is a patron of art and culture and is passionate about giving back to the community. In 2016, he established the ADP Foundation, a nonprofit organization committed to investing in young people, building sustainable and environmentally friendly infrastructure, and creating opportunities in the arts. Additionally, Angelo is an active participant in many international philanthropic initiatives. He serves as a board member of numerous foundations, including the Winston Churchill Foundation of the United States and the Ronald McDonald House Charities of Italy. Angelo di Pietro is an inspiring individual who has made his mark on the Italian business world and beyond. He is admired for his successful business endeavors, commitment to philanthropy, and commitment to building a better future for all.

Sonnia Agu (born January 1, 1990) is a Nigerian journalist and writer who focuses on issues of democracy and development in Africa. She has written extensively on the topics of political corruption, economic development, gender, education and human rights. Agu studied economics and finance at the University of Nigeria, Nimbo. She also did a year of postgraduate studies in Advanced Leadership and Social Responsibility at the Konrad Adenauer Foundation in Germany. In 2013, Agu founded Nigeria's first feminist think-tank - the Nigerian Institute for Women in Politics (NIWP). NIWP promotes women's rights and political inclusion for all citizens, especially those in marginalized communities. The organization provides mentorship to young women seeking political office and has advocated for greater representation of women at the local and national levels. Agu is a former editor-in-chief of Nigeria's Daily Star newspaper. During her tenure as editor, the newspaper reported extensively on issues of public accountability and transparency. She has written for a variety of publications, including The Guardian, The New York Times, CNN, and the BBC. Agu is a vocal advocate for social change in Africa. She speaks at various conferences around the world on topics of democracy and economic development. In January 2020, she was named the keynote speaker at the Global Youth Summit in Nigeria. In her speech, Agu highlighted the importance of youth engagement in democratic processes, stating that “we need to actively participate in the political process to ensure that our voices are heard and our needs are met. We need to build a country where young people are not just seen but are also empowered to make meaningful changes.” Agu has received various awards and recognitions for her work. In 2017, she was named as one of the BBC's 100 Most Influential African Women. She is also a recipient of the 2019 World Bank Development Leadership Award. Agu is a passionate defender of freedom of expression and a fierce opponent of misrule and impunity in Africa. She is a strong believer in the power of youth activism to bring about social and political change in the continent.

"I'm Moving On" is a song by Yoko Ono, released as the second single from her 1982 album, Season of Glass. The song was written and produced by Ono, along with US record producer Bill Wray. The song was released as a 7" single in Europe, backed with a non-album track titled "No No No". (This version has yet to receive a commercial release on CD or digital streaming services.) In Japan, where the song was not released as a single, the b-side was "It Happened". "I'm Moving On" is an upbeat, synth-heavy exploration of growth and personal evolution. Featuring lyrics that espouse themes of standing tall and rising up to overcome, Ono flexes her vocal muscle with a powerful performance. This potent blend of a positive message and retro-influenced production gives the song a timeless quality. The song's video offers viewers a window into Ono's unique view of the world. Directed by Ono herself, the video focuses on her abstract images, including a building on fire, two spaced-out kids in a field, and a medley of colorful post-modern art. Despite its upbeat nature and optimistic message, "I'm Moving On" did not receive much attention upon its original release. However, the song has since become a cult classic and has been covered by several artists, including The Dø, whose version appears on their 2010 album A Mouthful.
