Ono herself has performed the song on several occasions, most recently at the 2017 Peace On Earth benefit concert in Los Angeles. The song has also been sampled by numerous artists, most notably in the 2003 track "Never Catch Me" by LA-based hip-hop group Freestyle Fellowship. In 2017, the song was included on I'm Moving On, a remix album by producer Mark Reeder, featuring re-imagined versions of Ono's songs. The album examines Ono's sonic journey over the decades and her evolution as an artist. "I'm Moving On" is a song that still resonates with listeners today, as Ono's message of personal transformation is as powerful today as it was in 1982.

Thomas's yellow bat (Cypselurus thomensis) is a species of fish belonging to the flyingfish family, Exocoetidae. It is native to the western Pacific from Taiwan to the Ryukyu Islands and Malaysia. The species is not often encountered and is little-studied. Thomas's yellow bat is a small species of flyingfish, growth up to 11.5 centimeters (4.53 in) in length. It has a slender body. The body and fins are yellowish in color, while the upper surface is blackish. Five or six spines are found along its back. Its eyes are small and positioned close to the mouth. The species is primarily a schooling fish which is found in shallow coastal areas. Common habitats for this species include coral reefs, areas with seagrass, and estuaries where they can feed on zooplankton. Adults of this species are capable of short gliding flights over the surface of the water for a few seconds and may be found skimming over the surface at night. Currently, there are no major threats to Thomas's yellow bat. It is an abundant species, found in mixed schools near shore and is captured regularly as by-catch in fisheries. However, it may be vulnerable to overfishing and habitat destruction. Thomas's yellow bat is of limited commercial interest and is not commonly marketed fresh due to its small size. Reports of it in the aquarium trade are rare. Its conservation is not monitored and no protective measures for the species exist. Thomas's yellow bat is one of many flyingfish species found in Southeast Asian waters and a common component of the local marine biodiversity. While little research has been done on the species, research into the ecology of flyingfish in general is considered to be an important task for determining the conservation status of the species.

. Bracket creep, also known as "fiscal drag", is a phenomenon of taxation in which individuals and businesses move into a higher tax bracket as their incomes grow even though the actual percentage taken of their income may remain the same or decrease. This effect is caused by governments not adjusting revenue brackets and tax rates in accordance with inflation or by introducing new tax brackets to keep pace with increasing wages. The federal government of Australia created a system of tax brackets that guarantee the taxation of rising wages and inflationary income gains in the early 1980s. Since then, the phenomenon of bracket creep has been an ongoing issue, with increasing amounts of revenue from taxation contributing more and more to the total budget of the Australian Government. Bracket creep affects those with middle and low incomes more than those with high incomes, as the incomes of higher earners tend to rise with inflation, placing them in the higher tax brackets. Therefore, the effective tax rate of lower earners ends up increasing over time, while the effective tax rate of higher earners often stays the same or even declines. Inflation is one of the main culprits in causing bracket creep as wages rise with inflation but tax brackets do not. This leads to people earning relatively low wages moving into higher tax brackets as their incomes rise — often unwittingly — while the actual share of their income taken in taxes is unchanged or even decreased. For example, if the income tax rate in a given country is 15% but wages increase by 10%, the percentage taken in taxes may actually decrease despite the individual having moved into a higher tax bracket. Tax brackets creep can also occur when governments introduce additional tax brackets to deal with larger increases in income. This means that individuals earning low and middle incomes may move into tax brackets from which more tax would be taken from their earnings. In most countries, governments try to offset bracket creep with some kind of cost of living allowance; this generally takes the form of a tax break for lower income earners. The drawback of this approach is that it does nothing to help individuals already in the highest tax brackets, who still experience bracket creep and resulting higher taxes. It is worth noting that bracket creep is neither illegal nor intentional; it is a natural consequence of inflation and wage increases which tend to rise faster than tax brackets. Nonetheless, it is a subject of much debate and criticism due to the disproportionate effect it has on people on lower incomes.

The division of Korea began when the Soviet Union and the United States agreed to have their respective military occupation zones split the peninsula in 1945 after their victory in World War II. The division followed the line of the 38th parallel north of which the United States placed the Korean people under their immediate military control and south of the line was a Soviet occupation zone. The division of Korea initially meant the separation of only the people living in each respective occupation zone, but soon it became a political and ideological division. The division of Korea led to a civil war between the two Koreas. This division was also heavily influenced by external powers, in particular the Cold War rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union. The two Koreas were rivals from the very start and any attempt at reunification was seen as a threat to their respective political alliance systems. Throughout the 1950s and 1960s, both the United States and the Soviet Union sought to establish their respective spheres of influence in Korea, with the United States supporting the South and the Soviet Union supporting the North. This led to constant tensions and occasional clashes along the 38th Parallel, which was eventually transformed into the heavily fortified Demilitarized Zone that continues to this day. Today, the division of Korea is considered to be one of the longest-running unresolved international disputes in the world. The two Koreas maintain a cross-border impasse, with the North refusing to recognize the legitimacy of the South, and the South refusing to enter an alliance with the North. The division of Korea has, however, been partially overcome through a variety of initiatives, most notably in 2018 when North Korea and South Korea declared an end to their decades-long war, committing to an eventual reunification and peace. The two leaders also signed an agreement of demilitarization of the Korean peninsula and to a mutual agreement not to intervene in the other's domestic affairs. The division of Korea has since been a major obstacle to peace and economic development in the Korean Peninsula, and to the stability of Northeast Asia as a whole. While the long-term goal of many is the peaceful reunification of Korea, it is widely believed that this will only occur if South and North Korea develop a sense of shared sovereignty. The inter-Korean relationship has rapidly improved since 2018 and dialogue and trust between the two sides is gradually growing. Until a sustainable solution is achieved, the division of Korea will remain a highly contested issue in international affairs.

Tommy Randall (born April 6, 1979) is an American professional golfer from Naperville, Illinois. He currently competes on the PGA Tour. Randall began his professional golfing career in 2001, playing in PGA Tour qualifying school. He earned his PGA Tour card for the 2002 season, which he followed up with a successful 2003 season. He would go on to record four successful seasons on Tour before winning his first event, the 2007 Valero Texas Open. After this breakthrough win, Randall's career saw a number of highs and lows, but he continued to compete on the Tour. In 2009, Randall was diagnosed with Stage 4 colon cancer, forcing him to take a break from the professional golfing circuit. During his break, Randall underwent months of chemotherapy and radiation treatments, eventually succumbing to the disease in 2010. Since his passing, Randall has been immortalized with the Tommy Randall Memorial Fund, which has been established to raise money to help other cancer patients with medical and non-medical expenses. The Fund has been so successful that the PGA Tour has included it as part of the 2014 PGA Tour schedule. Randall's memory lives on in his hometown, where the city of Naperville has built a memorial statue and garden to honor him. The memorial park is located near the golf course which Randall used to frequent. It includes a sculpture of a golfer teeing off, and a quote from Randall inscribed in the statue’s base: "The harder you work, the luckier you get." Throughout his career, Randall personified the phrase “hard work pays off”, and remains an inspiration for young golfers today. His legacy will continue for many years to come.

Timothy D. Bellavia is an American musician, composer, and producer from Washington, D.C. Bellavia began playing piano as a child, and quickly developed a passion for music. He received his first degree in music theory and composition from St. Mary's College of Maryland in 1996. After studying a variety of musical styles, including jazz and classical, Bellavia began performing and producing music professionally. He started producing music for a variety of artists, including Wu-Tang Clan, Jurassic 5, and A Tribe Called Red. He has released numerous albums under his own name, including The Tim Bellavia Project and A Few Measures of Magick. He has also composed music for films, TV shows, and video games. Bellavia is also a frequent collaborator with various other artists. He has produced and co-composed albums for Los Angeles-based musicians Nocando and Open Mike Eagle. He is a member of Thesis, a critically acclaimed hip-hop group formed in 2016. In addition to performing and producing, Bellavia is a professor of music theory and composition at the University of Maryland. He has been teaching the subjects since 2010 and has taught students from a variety of musical backgrounds. Bellavia's musical style can be described as a blend of contemporary Hip-Hop, funk, and soul. He takes influence from a variety of artists, including D'Angelo, The Roots, and John Coltrane. Bellavia's compositions are often described as intricate, thoughtful, and complex. Bellavia has been praised for his innovative approach to music production and performance. He has composed a variety of genres, ranging from hip-hop to jazz to classical. Bellavia continues to work on new projects and expand his sonic palette. He is a highly respected producer, composer, and performer in the music industry.

Patently offensive, also known as a patent infringement or patent violation, is a legal term used to describe an activity or product that uses or appropriates the design or functionality of a existing patented invention or trademark without the patent holder's consent. The activity or product may be in competition with the patent holder's own product or with products from other companies who have similar patents. In such cases, the patent holder has the legal right to take action against the offending party and to seek damages, or an injunction to prevent further use of the patented invention or trademark, and any harm this action may have caused to the patent holder's business. Patently offensive practices can be of a commercial nature, such as copying a product without authorization, or of an ethical or moral nature, such as copying the design of another company without permission. In general, violators of patents should be aware that the situation may be punishable by civil and criminal liability. The U.S. Congress has amended the patent infringement laws to provide criminal penalties of up to $500,000 in fines and 10 years in prison, depending on the severity of the infringement. Any individual or organization that violates a patent can be subject to such penalties. In addition, patent infringement could also lead to an injunction being issued, preventing the offender from further patent infringement activities. An injunction may also be issued by court order to prevent the defendant from continuing business activity, or to seek an immediate cessation of the infringing activity and/or the removal of existing competition from the marketplace. Patently offensive activity can be avoided by obtaining a valid license, or entering into an agreement with the patent proprietor allowing the use of the patented invention or trademark. Patent owners also have the right to license their patents to third parties and often seek to do so in order to seek licensing fees in order to monetize the intellectual property they have developed. Another important form of patent protection is the need to obtain a valid claim of patent infringement in court. In order to have standing to bring a patent infringement action, the patent holder must demonstrate that they can prove both the existence of a valid patent and that the defendant has infringed upon it. A patent infringement action is an expensive and time-consuming process, and can be quite a costly venture, so it is important to ensure that all legal bases are covered prior to pursuing such a course of action.

Francis Gally (1834-1915) was an English clergyman, popular science writer, and advocate for progressive education. He was born in London of English-French parentage and was educated at Marlborough College and Trinity College, Cambridge. Gally was ordained in the Church of England and held several curacies, including vicar of Highgate from 1861 to 1868. He was progressive in his beliefs, advocating the use of new methods of education, and he was often at odds with traditional establishment values. Gally was a Unitarian and supported the rights of individuals against the dictates of the Church and State. He was educated in the sciences, wrote textbooks on anatomy and astronomy, and wrote plays exploring the place of human suffering as part of divine providence. Gally was an advocate of evolution long before its widespread acceptance and he wrote a series of articles called The Mind of Man Under Evolution in 1866. He also wrote books on evolution and popularized the idea of evolution through natural selection. Gally released the best-selling text book, the Compendium of Anatomy, in 1894 and drew on his love of the natural world to illustrate its many excellences. He also wrote a book on astronomy, A Course of Elementary Astronomy, in 1892 in which he explored the topic of the universe in light of evolutionary theory. Although Gally's books on science had wide popularity, his works on progressive education were less so. His works on education ranged from advocating the use of objects as teaching materials in place of the traditional blackboard and book to debating the validity of corporal punishment within the school setting. He also advocated for an examination system that did not reward cramming, but instead developed the individual talents of each student. Gally was known for his great enthusiasm for his students and his support of new methods of teaching. He was a great encourager of those who wanted to push the boundaries of traditional education. Gally's work and ideas received the attention of many prominent social reformers, including William Makepeace Thackeray and Alfred Lord Tennyson. Despite this attention, Gally's death in 1915 received little attention and no obituary was published. Although he may have had a remarkable life, Francis Gally is by and large forgotten today. In 2021, however, his works have been re-examined and he remains an interesting and influential figure in the history of modern education.

Henning Alexander von Kleist (30 April 1761 – 13 November 1831) was a Prussian nobleman and soldier who served as an officer in the Prussian Army during the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars. Kleist was born in Pomerania, the son of a cavalry officer who served in the Brandenburg-Prussian Army and his wife, who was of the noble von Caprivi family descended from the Line of Gostyn. He was descended from a long line of warriors and was related to several of Prussia's leading generals and statesmen. Kleist joined the army of Prussia in 1779, rising in rank within a few years and seeinng action in the Netherlands and on the Rhine. In 1795, he was promoted to major and appointed adjutant to the commander of the Prussian Corps in the French Revolutionary Wars, General Yorck von Wartenburg. In 1793, he fought in the Battle of Kaiserslautern and took part in a daring raid on the French camp of Charleroi. Eventually, he was promoted to lieutenant-colonel and then colonel. He participated in the successful Prussian campaign of 1806, and went on to fight in the battles of Eylau and Friedland. In 1808, he was made a general-major and became a Divisional commander of a brigade at Heilsberg and Guttstadt. In 1809, he took part in the battles at Lutzen and Bautzen. It was shortly before the Battle of Leipzig in 1813 that Kleist was awarded the Pour le Mérite, Prussia's highest honor, for his actions at Lützen. Kleist continued to display his bravery during the War of Liberation of 1813–14, distinguishing himself at Waterloo and commanding the entrenchments at Laon. Kleist was appointed chief of staff to Prince August of Prussia in 1830. He was made a Baron of the Royal House of Prussia four years later. Kleist died on 13 November 1831 and was buried at Templin. Kleist's memorial monument in the Town Hall of Neustrelitz depicts him holding a flag in his right hand, with the words: “Here lies the loyal Henning von Kleist, Field Marshal of Infantry, Baron of Prussia and beloved Knight of the Iron Cross, he who served Prussia valiantly and bravely against all invaders, 1831.” The Prussian Army honored General von Kleist by naming several barracks and regiments after him. The 8th Leib Infantry Regiment, founded in 1808, bears General von Kleist's name. As of 2010, the 8th Leib Infantry Regiment was still serving in Prussia.

The 1991 Mississippi gubernatorial election was held on November 5, 1991, to determine the Governor of Mississippi. Incumbent Democrat Ray Mabus was ineligible to seek re-election due to term limits. Republican Kirk Fordice won the election and took office in January 1992. He faced off against Democrat William F. Winter in a close election that had a turnout of 515,474 voters and was decided by less than 10,000 votes. Fordice was a first-time candidate for political office, but had been active in the Mississippi Republican Party for several years. He had the backing of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, President George H. W. Bush, and Bush's son, Governor George W. Bush of Texas. Fordice campaigned on a platform of fiscal conservatism, job creation, and tax reform. Winter, a veteran politician and former Governor, was supported by President Bill Clinton, as well as Mississippi’s Democratic politicians. He intended to expand educational and economic opportunities, while continuing the social progress initiated by Mabus during his time in office. Fordice won the election despite weak fundraising due to President Bush's unpopularity in the state. He was able to draw in support from conservative voters and those residing in rural, predominantly white, areas of the state. Fordice was sworn into office on January 13, 1992, becoming the first Republican Governor of Mississippi since Reconstruction. He was re-elected in 1995, beating Secretary of State Whit Hughes and leading to Mississippi being dubbed the "most Republican state in the union" in both the 1996 and 2000 presidential elections. Fordice served two terms until January 11, 2000. During his time in office, Mississippi's economic growth increased, with gains in jobs, education, and infrastructure. He was succeeded by Democrat Ronnie Musgrove.

Rockstar London is a video game development studio of Rockstar Games located in the United Kingdom. The studio was established in 2003 and is known for developing games series such as Max Payne, Bully and its sequels, Red Dead Redemption and its sequels, and Grand Theft Auto IV and its sequels. As of 2021, Rockstar London remains in operation. Rockstar London was founded in 2003 at West London's existing Rockstar U.K. office. This studio currently develops a variety of titles, often in partnership with Rockstar's other studios. In addition to developing games, the studio occasionally serves as a support studio to Rockstar San Diego when additional development resources are required. One example of such collaboration is Red Dead Redemption II, in which the studio provided additional animation and other assets. Rockstar London is part of the 2k Games global network, which consists of 11 studios spread across the U.K., the United States, Japan and India. Since its foundation, the London studio has collaborated with the other studios on major projects, such as Red Dead Redemption 2 and Grand Theft Auto V. It is also responsible for Bully: Scholarship Edition, a remastered version of the original Bully released in 2008. The studio developed the critically acclaimed Max Payne 3 and is currently developing a number of upcoming titles. In 2010, Rockstar Games released their first ever mobile title, Grand Theft Auto Chinatown Wars, which was developed in collaboration with Rockstar London. In 2020, Rockstar Games announced that Rockstar London was developing a new game, which is yet to be revealed. Rockstar London remains a dynamic and ambitious studio, creating and developing video games for major platforms. With the continued success and growth of the company, there is no doubt that Rockstar London will remain an important resource for Rockstar Games for many years to come.

Sylvia Kantaris (born 1911) is a Greek-Australian philanthropist and feminist, best known for her work with the Greek and Australian migrant and refugee communities in Melbourne. She has dedicated her life to supporting those in need, often working long hours and late nights to raise funds, provide resources and offer support to the Greek and African migrant communities in Australia. Born in Tripoli, Greece to Greek-Jewish parents, Kantaris immigrated to Melbourne in 1923 and came to prominence as a philanthropist in the 1950s with her involvement in numerous charities, refugee organisations and anti-racism campaigns. She was one of the founding members of the Greek Welfare Philanthropic Society in Victoria in 1965, and is a patron of the Greek Community of Melbourne. Kantaris was an advocate for the rights of African people living in Australia and held the position of Vice President of the African Australian Welfare Organisation from 1975-1978. In addition to her philanthropic work, Kantaris was an advocate for women's rights. She was a member of the National Council of Women in Australia, a Fellow of the International Alliance of Women and a Director of the Victorian Council of Social Services. She also held the positions of President and Vice President of the Greek Community of Melbourne. Kantaris was appointed a Member of the Order of Australia (AM) posthumously in 2012 by Governor-General Quentin Bryce for her service to the Greek and African migrant communities. In 2016, she was named one of the Audacious Women of Australia by the Adelaide Writers Week. Kantaris' long-term commitment to assisting and educating disadvantaged youth was recognised in 2021 by the Melbourne City Council, who posthumously named her as one of the recipients of their Women of the City awards. The award recognise the dedicated service rendered by women in the City of Melbourne and the impact their work has had in the city and beyond. Kantaris' dedication to supporting and educating vulnerable communities and advocating for human rights will forever be remembered as the legacy of one of Melbourne’s most remarkable women.

Knowsley Safari Park is a nature conservation park located in Knowsley, Merseyside, England. The park is home to over 700 wild animals from all over the world, including lions, tigers, baboons, giraffes, rhinos, and wolves. The park is open all year round for visitors to view and observe the different species of wildlife. The park was first opened in 1971 and was one of the first of its kind in Europe. Knowsley Safari Park was originally owned by the Stanley family, and was started as an extension of the Earl of Derby’s estate near Liverpool. The park has since been taken over by the Knowsley Safari Park Limited, a privately owned business. The park offers a drive-through safari experience, an off-road safari experience, a sea lion show, and an area with petting animals. Visitors can also rent Safari buses to explore the park more easily. The park also features a variety of educational activities. Naturalists are available throughout the park to answer questions and provide visitors with information about the animals. Knowsley Safari Park also offers a range of shows for visitors to enjoy. These include daily displays of sea lions, birds, and beavers, as well as entertaining displays of exotic animals such as lemurs, meerkats, and monkeys. The park also participates in animal conservation programs and supports local charities. The park is constantly expanding and improving its facilities, and has been named one of the UK’s leading tourism destinations. It was awarded Grade 4 status by the Discover England Quality Assurance Group for 2018, and was featured in the Times Top 100 Best Places to Visit in Britain list. Knowsley Safari Park is one of the UK’s premier wildlife attractions and is able to provide visitors with an unforgettable experience. Whether it’s an adventure with the wild animals or taking a closer look at the educational activities, there is something for everyone at Knowsley Safari Park.

. The Zoological Journal is an international scientific journal that covers the research in zoology. It was established in 1825 and was the first zoological journal in the world. It is published by Taylor & Francis, and is a part of the Oxford University Press family. The journal focuses on zoology, including all aspects of animal biology, including ecology, physiology, embryology, genetics, morphology, and behavior. It also covers systematic zoology, with topics including taxonomy, zoogeography, and palaeontology. In addition, special topics such as endemism, conservation and biogeography are also covered. The journal publishes reviews, research papers, comments, and opinions dealing with the latest topics in zoology. The journal aims to provide an integrated platform for qualitative research activity and the dissemination of zoological knowledge. The editors also encourage authors to submit their research in the form of photographs, diagrams, and illustrations whenever possible. To ensure publication quality, the editors review all manuscripts to ensure technical correctness, accuracy, and presentation. Each article submitted to the journal is initially subject to a peer-review process, providing feedback to the authors and allowing the editors to decide whether the article should be accepted, revised, or rejected. All articles accepted for publication are then subject to editorial review and revision, prior to publication. The Zoological Journal publishes several special issues throughout the year to reflect the latest research topics and perspectives in zoology. It also publishes book reviews, and obituaries of zoologists, as well as reports of conferences and symposia. The journal serves an important role in the world of zoology, providing a platform for the sharing of research and ideas, and it has a strong presence in the international community. The work it publishes has been cited in numerous other works and is often brought up in discussions among zoologists. As such, it has become a cornerstone of zoological sciences and is a go-to resource for researchers and students alike.

John D. Waldorf (born November 11, 1983) is an American entrepreneur and investor. He is the founder and CEO of Beach Capital and is renowned for his investments in the tech and apparel industries. Waldorf was born and raised in Little Rock, Arkansas. Growing up, Waldorf took an early interest in business and investing. At the age of 15, he started his first business, a summer lawn mowing business. This experience would later prove invaluable in his impressive career. After graduating from high school in 2001, Waldorf attended the University of South Florida, where he studied marketing and finance. Upon graduating in 2005, he shortly thereafter began investing in tech startups. Waldorf quickly established himself as savvy investor, and as a result, his portfolio grew significantly over the next several years. In 2011, Waldorf founded Beach Capital, a venture capital firm focusing on early stage investments in the tech and apparel industries. His success with Beach Capital was very impressive and he ended up becoming one of the biggest investors in the country. Outside of his investments, Waldorf has started established several tech and apparel companies, such as "John D. Waldorf Apparel" (established in 2018) and "250 Ventures" (established in 2013). John D. Waldorf is widely respected and sought-after figure in the investment world. He is often effusive in his praises of young entrepreneurs and offers a wealth of wisdom and advice regarding the startup world. Such advice has been especially useful for numerous aspiring startup founders. In addition to his investment work, Waldorf is also an ardent philanthropist. He has been involved in numerous charitable causes through Beach Capital and has also held a place on the board of numerous philanthropic organizations. For all his successes, Waldorf is highly-revered for his unique approach to investing. His ability to spot new trends, combined with his knack for reading how people interact with businesses, has firmly cemented him as one of the most accomplished investors in the country.

Sidney Aster (born Sidney W.L.N. Aster on October 27, 1962) is a Canadian actor and radio host known for his portrayals of authority figures and film roles. Born and raised in the city of Vancouver, British Columbia, Aster attained his Bachelor of Fine Arts in Theatre at the University of Royal Holloway in London, United Kingdom. After his return to Canada, Aster started to make a name for himself in the film and television industry. He appeared in films such as The Weather Man (1996), No Shirt, No Shoes...No Problem (2001), and Cool Blue (2002). He additionally was featured in the series The X-Files (1997-1999) as the character Mr. Berube. In addition to his film and television roles, Aster has had the opportunity to lend his voice to many popular television shows, films and video games. Aster's range is widely flexible, from episodes on the animated children's series My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic to providing voices for many popular video games such as Call of Duty Modern Warfare 2 and Dead Rising 2. Aster is no stranger to Canadian radio as he was the host of his own evening radio show on CKSI 105.5FM in Montreal, Quebec. He additionally had guest spots on CFCW 702AM in Camrose, Alberta and on The Mike Bullard Show (Global Television Network). In his free time, Aster is actively involved in local services within his community of Edmonton. Sidney has served as a member for both the United Way and the Edmonton Food Bank. He is also a patron of the Edmonton Symphony Orchestra. Sidney Aster currently makes his home in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada and works part-time as an acting coach. He additionally continues to flex his acting muscles in independent films and commercials.

Des Ball (born April 26, 1982) is an Australian football (soccer) coach and former player. Ball is a former member of the Australian National Football Team, making his debut in 2004. He made over 50 appearances for the national team and helped the Socceroos to qualify for the 2006 FIFA World Cup in Germany. He also represented Australia in two Asian Cup campaigns, in 2004 and 2007, and was a member of the squad that won the OFC Nation’s Cup in 2008. He was named Oceania Footballer of the Year in 2005. Ball began his club career as a junior at Blacktown City in 1999, playing in the NSW Premier League until 2003. After a brief stint at League of Ireland club Longford Town, Ball joined Sydney FC in 2005 and went on to make over 50 appearances in the A-League over three seasons. Ball went on to play with several clubs in Australia and the United Kingdom, including Melbourne Victory, Melbourne Heart, Leicester City and Kent United F.C. In 2014, Ball ended his professional career and returned to coaching. Ball started his coaching career at Victoria's Olympic (National Premier Leagues) team, Box Hill United SC, in 2013. In 2015, Ball moved to the Australian Institute of Sport to work as an assistant coach, and then in 2016 he moved to New Zealand to become the Assistant Technical Director at Auckland Football Federation. Ball currently holds the position of Technical Director at Football Federation Northern Territory. In addition to his coaching roles, Ball has held several roles in football development. He is a member of the Australian Technical Directors Network, and has coached in numerous football clinics across Australia and New Zealand. He also served as an assistant coach for the Newcastle Jets Academy team from 2017-18, before moving to the Northern Territory in 2019. Ball is an avid traveller and is passionate about inspiring the next generation of footballers. He is involved in several youth football initiatives and organisations, including Football United, which is an international community football organisation with a focus on culture, health and social integration. He currently resides in Darwin and he is a fan of the Darwin Rovers Football Club. He also holds coaching qualifications from the Football Federation Australia (FIFA Pro) and Football Coaches Australia (A-License).

The soda locomotive was an early type of steam locomotive designed to use the power of pressurized soda water instead of a traditional boiler. The locomotive was developed in 1815 by Robert Stirling, a Scottish gentleman who was inspired by French physicist Nicolas Léonard Sadi Carnot's research on the power of steam pressure. The locomotive was powered by pressurized carbonated water instead of steam generated from a boiler, which allowed for greater speed. Stirling believed that this would be safer than a large boiler as it enabled the fireman to stop the train quickly if necessary. The locomotive worked by feeding hot water from a firebox into a large tank called a charging chamber. Sodium bicarbonate crystals were also added to this charging chamber, forming a Caustic Soda solution when dissolved. By compressing the solution, the water and sodium bicarbonate reacted and the resulting gas was pressurised, forming a high energy equivalent to a boiler. This gas was then sent into a cylinder where it was pressurized and expelled, pushing the locomotive forward. Each soda locomotive was built with a number of safety features such as warning alarms and a safety valve in the charging chamber, which was designed to open in the event of too much pressure build-up. Despite its promise, the soda locomotive failed to catch on. One of the biggest issues was that the use of caustic soda meant that the locomotive had to be frequently removed from service for maintenance and to reduce the risk of corrosion which seriously hampered operating costs. By the mid 19th century, the design was quickly replaced by more reliable boiler-driven locomotives. Despite its short life, the soda locomotive is an important advances in rail engineering, influencing the next generation of steam locomotives. Some of these features, such as pressure regulation valves, can still be seen in modern locomotives today.

Beata Maria Kitsikis Panagopoulos (born 29 July 1937) is a Greek philanthropist and art collector. She is the widow of the Greek shipping magnate Yiannis Latsis and the mother of two of his children: the business executive Ulysses Latsis and the banker Daphne Latsis. Beata Maria Kitsikis Panagopoulos was born in Athens, Greece, into a wealthy family. Her father, Leon Kitsikis, was a prominent businessman who owned the successful fashion house Kitsikis Ltd. Panagopoulos was educated at a private school in Athens and then at the University of Athens, where she studied Greek Studies and English Literature. She married Yiannis Latsis in 1960 and had two children, Ulysses and Daphne. As a philanthropist, she has set up numerous charitable foundations in Greece. She is the founding benefactor of The Yiannis Latsis Foundation, which supports research, education, culture and community initiatives. The foundation was founded in 1984 with financial support from Panagopoulos. In her life, Panagopoulos has also been an avid art collector and has been instrumental in the preservation of modern and contemporary Greek art. In addition to owning numerous works of art, she has served as a patron and a collector of art. In 2008, she donated sixty-three works of art to the National Museum of Contemporary Art in Athens, as part of the “Gift of the Yiannis and Beata Latsis Foundation”. Panagopoulos’ passion for art preservation has also inspired her children to use their wealth and influence for charitable causes, with both the Latsis Foundation and the Daphne Latsis-Latsis Foundation supporting the preservation of Greek art and archaeological sites. In 2012, Panagopoulos was awarded the Greek Presidential Medal of Merit for her dedication to philanthropy and for her contributions to the preservation of Greek culture. She has also been honored with membership in the Order of the Redeemer by the Greek government, for sponsoring medical and humanitarian aid initiatives. Throughout her life, Panagopoulos has been an advocate of philanthropy and art preservation, serving as both a role model and an inspiration to many. She is remembered as a caring and generous woman, and her commitment to the arts and culture of Greece will continue to be appreciated for decades to come.

Hridayakumari (also known as Hridi) (31 May 1903 – 30 April 1951) was an Indian revolutionary and feminist of Bengal who led an armed struggle to free India from the British rule. She was one of the most prominent women revolutionaries in the Indian independence movement, and was a member the Indian Republican Army and the Azad Hind Fauj. Hridayakumari was born on 31 May 1903 in East Bengal. She was born into a family of high status, but she was determined to contribute to the independence movement. From a young age, she had shown a reluctance to society binding her to traditions, and actively protesting against such traditions to carve out a liberated space for herself. Hridayakumari joined the armed struggle against the British rule along with other women revolutionaries. Bengal had become a hotbed of revolutionary activities, and this was a time of nationalist fervour. Realising the potential of women revolutionaries, Bengal saw some of its most prominent women take a stand against the British rule. Hridayakumari was highly active in this struggle, and was part of the All Bengal Students’ Association – which was an organization to support the independence struggle. During 1921-1922, she was trained in guerilla warfare. In the latter half of 1922, she formed the All Bengal Women’s Organisation with the intention of promoting patriotism and nationalism among women. In 1930, she was part of the group organised by Subhas Chandra Bose which conducted an armed struggle for the independence of India. She was also a member of the Azad Hind Fauj, which was an army of independence fighters. During this period, Hridayakumari was arrested and imprisoned multiple times. She was tortured in prison, but she never gave up her cause, and kept fighting against the British rule. Eventually, she died of tuberculosis in 1951. The Indian Government posthumously awarded her with the Tamra Patra in 2015, in recognition of her brave and unwavering activism. Her name is also inscribed in the Red Fort Museum in Delhi, as acknowledgement of her contribution to the Indian independence movement. Hridayakumari’s astounding courage and determination to fight for India’s independence makes her an inspirational figure today.

The Real Quiet Storm was a musical phenomenon in the mid to late-1970s, primarily in the United States and later in the UK and other parts of the world. It was characterized by a slow, melodic style of R&B music that blended elements of soul, jazz, and sometimes even funk. The title of the music was derived from an album of the same name released in 1976 by Smokey Robinson. Robinson's album was influenced by what he called "the sound of the storm", which was a melding of his background in Motown soul music with the newer sounds of jazz. These elements created a calming, peaceful sound that Robinson felt was perfect for those mild, seductive summer nights. Shortly after the release of Robinson's album, other artists started to incorporate this sound into their own styles, creating the Quiet Storm-style of music. Perhaps the most successful Quiet Storm artist was Luther Vandross. Vandross established himself as one of the greatest interpreters of Quiet Storm music with his solo works, as well as his collaborations with other artists. His albums "Busy Body" (1983) and "Give Me the Reason" (1986) are acknowledged as masterpieces of the genre. Other prominent Quiet Storm artists include guitarist George Benson, singers such as Luther Ingram, Anita Baker and Freddie Jackson, and groups like the Isley Brothers. Quiet Storm songs generally share certain attributes. They have soulful, mellow, and often romantic lyrics, with subtle melodies and meaningful grooves. Most Quiet Storm songs are between five and seven minutes long, allowing for instrumental solos and extended vocal ad-libs. Today, Quiet Storm music continues to be played on adult contemporary and soft rock radio stations across the world. It remains popular as background music at intimate gatherings, such as dinner parties, as well as at romantic events. Established soul and R&B artists such as Mary J Blige and Jill Scott carry on the legacy of the Quiet Storm, while younger stars such as Maxwell and John Legend keep the music alive for a new generation.

Lolium perenne, also known as Perennial rye grass, is a species of grass native to Europe, Asia and northern Africa. It has been introduced to many other parts of the world, including Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, the United States, and various other parts of the world for forage and turfgrass. It has become a weed or a nuisance in some areas, such as California, where it was a USDA noxious weed from 1996-2001. It was probably first introduced as crop seed in the 18th century. Lolium perenne is a short-lived perennial, growing in tufts up to 1m in height and 0.5 m in width. It has a creeping rootstock, with a fine texture and generally a slightly purplish color. Leaves are narrow and glabrous, with the upper surface somewhat shiny, and a membranous ligule below. The inflorescence is a spreading panicle of spikelets. It is a very competitive grass, with a fast growth rate and a high rate of spread. It can tolerate a wide range of soil types, and tend to become the dominant species in areas such as lawns, roadsides and other disturbed habitats. Lolium perenne has a wide range of uses. It is commonly used as a lawn turf and pasture grass, although in its natural state it is very competitive and can quickly dominate a lawn unless regularly mown. It has also been used in golf courses, playing fields and camp-grounds. In parts of Europe it is regularly used in meadows and pastures, and it is a regular component of many hay and fodder mixes. In the United States and Australia, Lolium perenne is often used as cover crop in orchards, vineyards and other agricultural fields. It does not require fertilizer or irrigation, and is adapted to a range of soil types. It is used in areas with high levels of salinity and acidity, and also can grow on soils with low levels of nitrogen or phosphorus. It is also a good choice for areas that face water shortages. By suppressing weeds and improving soil health, it can increase agricultural productivity. Lolium perenne has recently been recognized as an important source of biofuel, due to its fast growth rate, high energy content and ability to adapt to a range of environment types. Due to its prolific growth, it absorbs an amount of carbon dioxide during photosynthesis that is significantly greater than other grasses. However, it is not as efficient in capturing nitrogen and other minerals and therefore requires more nutrient inputs than other grass species. In conclusion, Lolium perenne is a widely-used grass, with a broad range of uses in both agricultural and landscaping contexts. It is fast-growing, tolerant of a wide range of soil types and conditions, and has recently been identified as a potential source of biofuel. Despite its potential uses, it can become a nuisance in some places and steps should be taken to limit its spread.

Dan Vasser is a fictional character from the Fox network television series Journeyman. Dan is a journalist from San Francisco and the protagonist of the series. He is portrayed by Kevin McKidd. Dan discovers he is a "Time Jumper," a human who, every few days, is inexplicably transferred short distances, or further, in time, both backward and forward. Although travelling through time holds no true physical dangers, Dan is informed via newspaper articles at various points in time that he will eventually die in a major disaster, making his journey to prevent the tragedy a primary plotline throughout the series. Dan's primary motivation to explore his time-jumping ability is to re-connect with his former beloved, Livia Beale (Alexa Davalos), whom he inexplicably lost contact with after he proposed to her eight years prior. Dan soon discovers that he is mysteriously travelling through time to save the lives of other people. He soon meets his mentor, Morgan, who informs him that he must help the people in some way in order for him to be able to move on in his life. At times, Dan confronts ethical dilemmas when the person he is rescuing will most likely alter the lives of others, but then again, there are times when not helping the person would lead to greater calamity. Throughout the show, Dan discovers that he can also have an influence in the lives of other people as Dan chooses to be both a father figure and confidante through his time-travelling experiences. Dan's brother Jack (Reed Diamond) and friend Katie (Moon Bloodgood) both come to understand Dan's time-traveling secrets. In the 21st episode, it is discovered that the person guiding Dan is his former love Livia, who also acts as a search engine for the information he needs in order to complete his tasks. Ultimately however, Dan's ultimate goal comes true as Livia and him actually be together, as two changes of time have Livia becoming his wife and the mother of his daughter Zoe. Sadly, the series was never allowed to explain completely through the remaining 13 episodes, as Fox chose to cancel the show after just one season. Nevertheless, Dan Vasser will always remain an iconic persona in the science fiction genre, not just because of his travels through time, but because of his brave attempt to alter various points of time and his inspiring wish to be reunited with the love of his life.

The Bishop of Tuam, Killala and Achonry is an episcopal title in the Church of Ireland which takes its name from the diocese of Tuam, Killala and Achonry that covers Connacht province in the west of Ireland. The diocese was formed by merging the former bishoprics of Tuam, Killala and Achonry in 1742. Following a short period when the Church of Ireland was in schism, the two were united again in 1841, leaving the incumbent as the Bishop of Tuam, Killala and Achonry. The Bishop of Tuam, Killala and Achonry is the Ordinary of the diocese, which has its episcopal seat at St. Mary's Cathedral in Tuam. It is part of the United Dioceses of Tuam, Killala and Achonry. The Bishop of Tuam, Killala and Achonry was also the rural dean of the archdeaconry of Tirawley until 1969, when the archdeaconry was merged into the archdeaconry of Mayo. The current bishop is the Most Reverend Patrick Rooke, who was consecrated on 31 January 2021 in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin. He had been the Bishop of Achonry for almost 30 years before being appointed to the combined see in 2020. The diocese of Tuam, Killala and Achonry has been in existence since the first Anglo-Norman invasion of Ireland in 1172. The earliest records of a bishop are those of William de Burgo, who was appointed Bishop of Tuam in 1253. He was succeeded by a number of other bishops, many of whom had previously been bishops of other sees in Ireland. The diocese was one of the first to have its bishops appointed by the papacy, rather than by local lay people. The diocese was subject to a number of changes in title, until the current unified title of the Bishop of Tuam, Killala and Achonry was officially confirmed in 1742. Since then the bishops have had a number of responsibilities, including running the Church of Ireland schools in the diocese, officiating at church services, confirming parishioners and ordaining clergy. The current bishop of Tuam, Killala and Achonry is Patrick Rooke. He is assisted by four archdeacons, who look after day-to-day administration in their respective archdeaconries. Each archdeaconry is divided into parishes, each of which has a number of churches. There are approximately 300 church buildings in the diocese, some of which are ancient, while others are more modern. The Bishop of Tuam, Killala and Achonry is an important part of the leadership and administration of the Church of Ireland in Connacht. He oversees the diocese, provides pastoral care and episcopal ministry, and represents the Church of Ireland in the wider world. The see is a vibrant and active part of the province of Connacht and the Church of Ireland.

The 2005 Maria Sharapova tennis season saw the Russian becoming one of the most talked-about personalities on the women’s tennis circuit due to her success on the court. At the age of 17, Sharapova achieved her breakthrough moment when she won her first Grand Slam title, becoming the third-youngest female in history to win a Grand Slam singles event. She began the season by reaching the final of the Tier II tournament in Pattaya City in Thailand in January, where she lost to her compatriot, Vera Zvonareva. Sharapova would then shock the world when she won the 2004 Wimbledon Championships, after defeating two-time defending champion Serena Williams in the final. This victory made her the first Russian woman to win a grand slam event. She was only 17 years old at the time, making her the third-youngest female in the open era to win a grand slam singles title. In August, Sharapova participated in the US Open and reached the fourth round, where she was defeated by eventual champion Kim Clijsters. This placed Sharapova at No. 4 in the rankings by the end of the year, making her the highest-ranked female Russian player in history. The end of the season saw Sharapova compiling a stellar 41-12 singles record and one WTA singles title. Sharapova won her third career WTA Tour title at the China Open in Beijing in October. She also reached the quarterfinals of the Tier I tournament in Los Angeles in July, and the semifinals of the Tier I tournament in Zurich in October. Sharapova also reached the quarterfinals at several notable tournaments throughout the year, including the Tier I Australian Open and the Tier I German Open. Sharapova was also successful in doubles, reaching the finals of the Olympics in Athens with her compatriot Anastasia Myskina. She ended the year by winning the year-end championship event at the Azerbaijan Cup in November, where she took home $100,000 in prize money. Overall, Sharapova's 2005 season was a success as it saw the young Russian making her mark on the women's tennis circuit. She inspired a new generation of Russian female players, and set the stage for future Grand Slam success. She was ranked fourth by the end of the season, and was awarded WTA Player of the Year in conclusion.

Nero Forte is a heavy metal band from Long Beach, California. It was started in 2013 by guitarist Doug Aldrich and drummer Brian Tichy, both of whom have previously been members of the band Whitesnake. The band also features bassist Marco Mendoza and vocalist John Bush, who is best known for his work as the lead singer of Armored Saint and Anthrax. Nero Forte has released two studio albums to date, their self-titled debut album in 2020 and the follow-up album, Nemesis, in 2021. Both albums were well-received, with critics praising the hard rock anthems, the band’s intense grooves, and the powerful vocals of John Bush. They have had several singles from both albums chart in the U.S. and UK rock songs charts, including "The Beast Within," "All We Have Is Now," "Final Hour," and "Take Me Away." Nero Forte has also had a few international tours across Europe, Japan, and North and South America. They have included many prestigious festivals, such as Wacken Open Air in Germany, Download Festival in the United Kingdom, and Knotfest Mexico in Mexico City. Nero Forte is known for their energetic and powerful live shows, and have won plenty of awards for their live performances. They have won the "Best Live Band" award at the 2020 Canadian Music Awards and the 2021 Los Angeles Music Awards. The band has also appeared on several high-profile television shows, including Jimmy Kimmel Live!, Conan, and Lopez Tonight. Nero Forte also co-headlined the renowned Monsters Of Rock Cruise in 2020, alongside other veteran acts such as Deep Purple, Megadeth, and Saxon. Nero Forte is currently recording and releasing new music, and their music is regularly heard on rock radio stations and satellite radio. Throughout their career, Nero Forte has succeeded in combining their classic hard rock riffs and melodic choruses to create a hard-hitting, distinct sound. They are truly one of the best modern hard rock bands out there today, and show no signs of slowing down.

Radio is a song by English singer-songwriter Robbie Williams. It was initially released as a double A-side alongside the song Eternity. It is the second single from his fourth studio album, Sing When You're Winning (2000). The song was co-written by Guy Chambers and Steve Power, who also produced the record. It was released on August 21, 2000 by EMI and Chrysalis Records. The single entered the UK Singles Chart at number five and peaked at number four, spending a total of thirteen weeks on the chart. It was also a success in Europe, reaching number one on the Spanish Singles Chart and peaking in the Top Ten in numerous countries, including Sweden, Germany, Norway, and Austria. It was certified silver on October 11, 2000 by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) for shipments of over 200,000 copies. The song's lyrics take place at a radio station. They discuss the vulnerability of being alone and how the radio echoes our thoughts. In the chorus, Williams ponders whether his dreams can come true via the radio waves. The accompanying music video sees Williams in various scenarios, located in and outside the radio station. Actor George Potts appears in a few vignettes, and various famous television personalities make cameos. The song appears in the soundtrack of the 2004 film A Cinderella Story as well as various compilation albums. The single received a mixed reception from contemporary music critics. While it was praised by some writers for its "energy and power", other reviews were less favourable. Q magazine found it to be "too cheesy". Time magazine cited it as a guilty pleasure; having enjoyed its "obvious chorus", they couldn't understand how 'Radio' become a hit. Radio was a success for Williams, reaching number four on the UK Singles Chart as well as topping multiple European charts. It was certified silver in the UK by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI). While contemporary music critics generally had a mixed opinion of the song, it is widely considered to be one of Williams' signature songs. It is still frequently performed at his concerts.

The Philippine twenty-peso note (PHP20) is a denomination of Philippine currency. The note is one of the larger denominations of Philippine banknotes. The current version of the note was issued in 2010 and features the portrait of Manuel L. Quezon, the 2nd President of the Philippines (1935–1944), on the obverse or faceside of the note. The reverse side features two cultural artifacts, the Tambuli (a kind of conical nose flute) and the Balangay (a type of ancient wooden boat). .The current twenty-peso note is predominantly pink in color, with a width of 142 millimeters and a length of 67 millimeters. It is printed on a durable, high-quality paper made of wood-free cotton and linen. The note has a watermark, primarily visible when held up to the light view, of the Philippine eagle, superimposed over an image of Quezon's face. A vertical security thread (built into the paper) runs through the center of the note, shifting from "white-on-white" to "black-on-white" when held up to a light source. The twenty-peso note is backed by the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (Central Bank of the Philippines) and is one of the seven denominations of Philippine peso bills. It is currently being circulated without any known coins to replace it. The previous version of the note which was released in 1985 featured an image of Apolinario Mabini on the obverse and a view of the Corregidor Island in the back. In addition to the traditional version of the twenty peso bill, a commemorative version was released in 2011, as part of the BSP's celebration of its 100th anniversary. This particular version of the note features an altered reverse side, with the Tambuli being replaced by an image of the BSP's Centennial Seal. On the left of the seal is a portrait of Francisco Encinas, the first Central Bank President of the Philippines, flanked by the dates "1911-2011", to commemorate 100 years of the Central Bank's operations. The Philippine twenty-peso note is widely accepted for transactions around the country and can be exchanged for goods and services. It is generally used for medium-to-large sized transactions, such as for payment of tuition fees and other goods and services. It is also accepted, though less commonly, for international transactions. In major cities and some rural areas, businesses and firms are equipped with ATMs that allow users to withdraw twenty-peso notes, which are easily recognized due to their distinctive color. They are also one of the few forms of currency accepted at most banks and money-lending firms. The Philippine twenty-peso note is an important and widely used medium of exchange in the country. It is a reliable form of payment that is accepted by businesses and firms nationwide.

Televisa Deportes is an online streaming platform offering sports and entertainment content from various sports programming partners in Mexico and around the world. The service was launched in 2020, and is a direct response to the need for Mexican audiences to access sports programming with no expensive cable subscriptions. Televisa Deportes is owned by Televisa, the largest media company in Latin America. It broadcasts on the regional Cinco station, as well as on its dedicated streaming platform. Its programming includes live sports, sports talk shows, video highlights, and press conferences. It also offers regular exclusive content from international sporting federations, including Liga MX, Liga Nacional, World Cup qualifiers, and the Mexico national team. Televisa Deportes’ library consists of several sports, including football, boxing, baseball, basketball, volleyball, and golf. It also offers live and on-demand content from the National Basketball Association (NBA), National Football League (NFL), and Major League Soccer (MLS). The platform includes streaming of live events and replays of sporting events, as well as in-depth analysis and documentaries. Additionally, viewers can find feature stories on some of the biggest sports stars, as well as personal interviews. Consistent with its mission to provide a comprehensive sports viewing experience, Televisa Deportes also offers live streaming of shows, episodes, and clips created in its Mexico City production studios. Televisa Deportes also integrates with certain digital platforms, such as Facebook and YouTube, for sharing and watching videos. Additionally, users can access its sports content through the official website, as well as media streaming devices, including Android, iOS, Amazon Fire TV, and Apple TV. Users of the service are required to create an account and fill out a user profile. Premium accounts offer access to ad-free viewing, as well as exclusive streaming events which are not available in the basic subscription tier. Users paying for a premium account can also access exclusive video on demand content, access to exclusive sports shows and commentaries, and other additional features such as personalized content, recommendations, and live-chat support. Televisa Deportes is an excellent platform for those seeking to get their sports fix through dedicated streaming platforms. The comprehensive sports selection, supported by direct and easy access to its content, makes it an attractive offering for sports enthusiasts in Mexico and around the world.

Dominic Schroeder (born June 8th, 1998) is an American musician, songwriter and record producer from Los Angeles, California. A multi-instrumentalist, Schroeder also performs lead vocals in many of his projects. Early life Schroeder was born and raised in Los Angeles, where he studied music from an early age. He attended the University of Southern California, where he studied jazz guitar, piano and composition. He was a member of the USC Thornton Jazz Ensemble and performed at various clubs and events around Los Angeles. His influences include classical, rock and jazz music. Career Schroeder's career began in 2016 when he formed the indie rock band Ghost Roads. The band released their self-titled debut album in 2017, featuring the hit single “The Other Way”, which was produced and co-written by Schroeder. The success of the album led to multiple tours throughout the United States and Europe. In 2018, Schroeder released his debut solo album, Free Love, which was praised for its innovative production and songwriting. He followed up with the EP It's All Good, which was produced with grammy winning producer Teddy Rajah. The album featured collaborations with a wide array of music tastemakers including Eric Clapton and Jamie Foxx. In 2019 Schroeder released the critically acclaimed album We Keep Dreaming, featuring the single “Can't Turn it Around”. The album featured production from the likes of Flying Lotus and Mark Ronson. On June 26th 2020, Schroeder released the album Film on the Horizon. The album features production from progressive French artist Thylacine and features the single “Below”, which is accompanied by a feature length documentary of the same name. Schroeder continues to produce and create innovative music, while also performing across the globe. Discography Albums * Ghost Roads (2017) * Free Love (2018) * We Keep Dreaming (2019) * Film on the Horizon (2020) EPs * It's All Good (2018)

Euseby Cleaver was an English dramatist, actor, and publisher of the late seventeenth century. His works were popular among Restoration theatre audiences and were frequently performed in Drury Lane and the Theatre Royal. Cleaver was born in the late 1650s in either Northumberland or Northamptonshire in England. Very little is known about his early life and upbringing, suggesting that he was either born into a family of modest means or that he was orphaned at a young age. Regardless, he found his way to London by the 1670s, where he began to pursue a career in the theatre. At some point in the early 1670s, Cleaver was invited to join the United Company, a group of prominent playwrights, actors and theatre professionals who ran numerous theatre franchises during the late 1660s and early 1670s. Some of his most famous works were completed while he was a member of the company, including The Governor (1677) and The Sea Voyage (1678). In addition to writing, Cleaver was also a prolific performer. He appeared in productions by John Dryden and William Wycherley, among others. He also had some success on the stage as a monologist and was frequently seen in comedy roles. He was especially known for his roles as loquacious roguish characters. Cleaver was one of the most active publishers and booksellers in London during the latter half of the seventeenth century. He published a number of his own plays and manuscripts, as well as many works by other authors. He managed the printing and distribution of works from some of the most distinguished playwrights of the day, including John Dryden and George Farquhar. Cleaver's other business interests included acting as agent for foreign plays as well as serving as publisher of the Beggar's Opera from 1728-1737. He frequently procured manuscripts from abroad, most notably from France and Italy, and wrote letters introducing them to the English booksellers. Cleaver died in 1743 in London. Despite his success as a dramatist, publisher, and actor during the Restoration era, he is noted today as among the less remembered of English playwrights. Nevertheless, his work during the Restoration period contributed to the development of the English stage in lasting ways.

The projective line, denoted P^1, is the smallest projective structure, the simplest example of a projective space, and the basic example of a geometric manifold. The projective line is a one-dimensional space, consisting of two distinct points, and comes equipped with a topology, whose basic open sets are the two points, and their complements. It is a special case of an algebraic variety, and is a construction within projective geometry. Projective geometries are those that involve complex numbers and Euclidean transformations. A projective line is a structure that allows us to make new Euclidean objects by taking lines and points and transforming them in a certain way. The projective line, denoted P^1, is the basic example of this, and is a one-dimensional space with two distinct points. Projective geometry is important in its own right, and it provides a useful tool to study other geometries. In particular, projective geometry is useful in studying non-Euclidean geometries, where certain Euclidean properties no longer hold. For example, the properties of projective lines allow us to further consider n-dimensional spaces. In algebraic terms, the projective line is defined as the one-dimensional variety in P^2. A projective line can be described in terms of a set of homogeneous coordinates. It is impossible to provide an explicit description of P^1 in this way, but there are analytic descriptions available. In projective geometry, a projective line also serves as a base for the construction of projective spaces of higher dimensions. It is possible to define a projective plane, for example, as the space of lines through the origin in P^3. In topology, the projective line is an example of the topological structure known as a Mobius strip. This structure is formed by a continuous interaction between two distinct points, and is often used to study various topological properties. In mathematics, there are various uses of projective lines. In category theory, they can be used to study different categories and their relationship with each other. In algebraic number theory, projective lines are used to describe the field of algebraic numbers. They are also used in constructing various algebraic objects, including bundles of Euler projective lines. In physics, projective lines are used to describe various physical phenomena, such as the behavior of a particle of light in space. They can also be used to describe the behavior of matter subject to gravitational forces, in which the field lines are described by projective lines. Projective lines are an important part of mathematics, and their studies provide insight into the underlying structure of many concepts. They are also a useful tool for studying various physical phenomena. The projective line serves as a basis for projective geometry and for studying other geometric structures.

Maurice Fadida (born November 7, 1979) is a French-American lawyer, entrepreneur and investor, based in New York. He is the founder of Fadida Law Group, a firm specializing in venture capital and corporate law. Fadida graduated from the University of Paris II with degrees in both civil and common law. He entered a traineeship program with the French Supreme Court, gaining insight into the Political and Economic aspects of French Law. His research in these areas earned him a Fulbright Scholarship for Advanced Studies in International Business Law at Harvard Law School. While at Harvard Law School, Fadida began studying venture capital and honed his skills in founding small businesses, launching multiple successful ventures. He was also a member of the Harvard Law Entrepreneurship Project; a program aiming to bridge the gap between entrepreneurship and legal/business formation. In 2005, Fadida graduated Harvard Law School with Juris Doctorate and obtained a Bar Exam in both New York and France. Following graduation, he clerked with Federal Judge Honorable Lawrence Kotalusky while also working as Assistant District Attorney in the Bronx. In 2007, Fadida left the Bronx District Attorney's office and opened his own law practice concentrating on financial services, venture capital and corporate law – an early sign of his entrepreneurial spirit. At a time when venture capital firms were reluctant to invest into early-stage projects, Fadida Law Group specialized in providing legal and banking expertise to help client's access the capital needed to fund their projects. The Firm also provided strategic advice and support for companies looking to expand across US and Europe. In 2009, Fadida joined a small venture firm located at the heart of Silicon Valley. He served as legal adviser for several notable startups including, 8Strategies, Flying Carpet and Argo. In 2012, Fadida returned to his same law firm and was appointed managing partner. He has since been representing tech startups in several areas, corporate law, venture capital and banking services. Fadida is also active in philanthropy, he is a board member of the French-American Foundation and an angel investor to many early stage startups. He is also a member of the Empowerment Alliance, a non-profit organization that helps refugees and displaced people integrate into the U.S. workforce. As of 2020, Fadida is a Partner and Managing Director of Fadida Law Group in New York City, NY. He also remains an active investor in young innovative companies, particularly in the technology and healthcare sectors. His vast experience and legal acumen has helped numerous startups grow from their infancy to become industry leaders. Sources: University of Paris II Harvard Law School French-American Foundation Empowerment Alliance Fadida Law Group

Stuart Townend (born 1957) is an English singer-songwriter, primarily known for his work in contemporary Christian and folk music. His songs often deal with themes of spirituality, evangelism, social justice and grace. He has written or co-written many popular Christian songs, including "In Christ Alone", "The Power of the Cross" and "How Deep the Father's Love for Us". Born in Northern Ireland, Townend grew up in a Christian family and became a Christian at the age of 14. He subsequently studied theology at the London School of Theology. After obtaining his degree, he began working as a youth minister in England before beginning a career in Christian music in the late 1980s. Townend's most popular songs, such as "In Christ Alone" co-written with Keith Getty, are included on hundreds of albums by major Christian music artists. In addition to writing and performing, Townend is known for speaking engagements; he has lectured at universities on worship, spirituality and societal issues. In recent years, his work has moved away from contemporary Christian music, to more of a folky, singer-songwriter-type sound. Townend achieved success with a variety of different styles in music. He has released several albums of his own, which have all topped the CCM charts. He also co-wrote the Gold-certified "In Christ Alone", with Keith Getty; it won an ASCAP Christian Music Award in 2006. He released a new album, Heaven Over Sea in 2018, to much critical acclaim. Townend is highly respected in the Christian music industry and has influenced the direction of popular Christian music for many years. He is known for his work in combining music and theology, as well as his lyrical content. His passion for justice, mission and grace continues to shape Christians around the world, bringing their attention to larger issues than just their own circumstances. He has left a lasting impression on the Christian music industry, and his influence continues to be felt today.

Austroriparian is a term used to describe an ecological zone found in watersheds in the American South that historically supported a wide variety of flora and fauna. This term is derived from Latin, where auster meaning "south", and riparius meaning "bordering on a waterway". Austroriparian ecologies have similar habitat across the region with little differentiation between the Tennessee River Valley and the Atlantic Coastal Plain. The name of this ecosystem originates from the fact that it is located south of the Appalachian Mountains and has been shaped by the effects of streams and rivers from the mountain range. Austroriparian landscapes are primarily made up of riparian corridors that funnel waterway systems from north to south. This dense vegetative corridor stabilizes soils, moderates temperatures, reduces sediment damage, and provides food, nesting, and refuge for wildlife. The characteristic flora of this system includes a mix of native trees, shrubs, forbs, and grasses. Common species include oaks, cypress, sweetgum, pines, box elder, persimmon, elderberry, and palmetto. Shrubs such as elderberry, blackberry, dewberry, and greenbrier provide refuge and food for birds, reptiles, and small mammals. Forbs such as wildflowers, chinquapin, and crownbeard provide additional resources to wildlife. Austroriparian ecosystems are threatened due to habitat destruction and fragmentation, pollution, invasive species, climate change, and urbanization. Overharvesting of resources has led to a decrease in populations of native species, such as mussels and fish, and an increase in invasive species. Runoff from agricultural lands, residential development, and golf courses contain pollutants that degrade water quality, particularly in more urbanized areas. Climate change is likely to cause drought and flooding in this region, leading to an increase in temperature that could shift the range of species found within an ecosystem. Austroriparian ecosystems are an integral part of the American South and help to maintain the region’s biodiversity. Conservation efforts are currently focused on protecting and restoring these areas through land acquisition, habitat preservation, and restoration projects. These initiatives are beneficial in providing habitats and resources necessary for fish, birds, and other wildlife. References: 1. Chappell, S. (2017). What is Austroriparian?. Retrieved October 27, 2020, from http://tn.audubon.org/what-austroriparian 2. Neel, K., D. (2017). What is an Austroriparian System?. Retrieved October 27, 2020, from https://www.adventurescience.org/blog/what-is-an-austroriparian-system/ 3. Abing, E. (2020). Conservation Has a Role to Play in the American South. Retrieved October 27, 2020, from https://www.nwf.org/Educational-Resources/Wildlife-Guide/Threats-to-Wildlife/Human-Impacts/Conservation-and-the-American-South

. Monopoly (1985 video game), also known simply as Monopoly, is a popular American board game based on the original concept by Charles Darrow and George Parker. It was also released in 1985 as an officially-licensed video game for the Nintendo Entertainment System (NES). It is the first major electronic adaptation of the original board game and was developed by Rare Ltd and published by Nintendo. Gameplay involves a board divided into 30 properties to buy, sell, and trade. Each property is represented by an imaginary piece that also applies to building houses, hotels and charging rent on other players. The object is to accumulate wealth by building hotels and houses on each property, which increases the amount of rent that must be paid by other players when they land on those spaces. The first one to become ruined is the loser. The game includes seven computer opponents, each with their own distinct personalities and strategies. This adds to the challenge and strategy of the game, as players must ensure that their opponents don’t buy up all the properties before them. Along with standard gameplay, there are also a number of different game modes, such as “Speed Monopoly”, a faster paced three-to-five round game which is best for two-player sessions. There is also “Negotiation Monopoly”, where players start with a large sum of money and can trade and negotiate with one another. Additionally, the game allows players to customize the rules, speed of play, difficulty settings, and board layouts. This allows players to determine the best strategy for the game, as well as make the game their own. Monopoly (1985 video game) is widely recognized as one of the best titles available for the NES. For the 1985 Holiday Season, it was rated the ninth best selling NES game of that year. As of 2017, it is also still considered one of the best video game adaptations of the original board game ever made.

The Wolseley Battery was a unique combination of artillery and infantry divisions of the British Army before World War I. It was created to support the British advance towards Germany in 1914. The battery was initially formed with nine 6-pounder (57 mm) quick firing guns, manned by the Royal Artillery. The guns were mounted on wheeled carriages and drawn by pack horses. They were designed to fire quickly and accurately, making them suitable for use in the close engagements expected in a modern war. The guns could fire shrapnel and high explosive shells, both of which had fire control routines so the British infantry could gain a tactical advantage.
