Alongside the Royal Artillery gunners, the Wolseley Battery was supported by a detachment of Riflemen from the King's Royal Rifle Corps, who carried out reconnaissance and other supporting roles such as providing covering fire in case the guns came under attack. In addition, the Battery was equipped with machine guns, mortars and signalling equipment. The machine guns were used as light weaponry, and the mortar was included to provide quick and accurate support during engagements. The signalling equipment was essential for communication between the Battery and the forward line. The Battery was originally commanded by Major G. A. Browne who became the highest ranking artillery officer in the Royal Artillery. He was later replaced by Major F. M. P. White, with Lieutenant G. C. Symes acting as second-in-command. The Battery quickly gained a reputation for their accuracy and swiftness, so much so that by October 1914 it was attached to the British Expeditionary Force (BEF). It was under the command of the 1st Division of the BEF, where it participated in the first engagements of World War One in Belgium. During this time, the Battery gained recognition and respect from both sides of the war, as they were able to quickly and accurately engage enemy targets, often with devastating results. After the War, the Battery was decommissioned and disbanded, with the guns and personnel re-assigned to other artillery units. However, the name ‘Wolseley Battery’ continues to be associated with Britain’s artillery and infantry divisions, even to this day. The legacy of the Wolseley Battery continues to this day, with a museum dedicated to the Battery’s service in France located in Redhill, Surrey. The museum holds a variety of artefacts and memorabilia from the War, and is open to the public daily. The Battery’s role in shaping the British Army’s tactics, equipment and leadership as it entered the twentieth century has been accurately depicted in the museum. The Battery’s actions and successes during the First World War have been recognised by the Royal Artillery and by the British Army as a whole. The Battery’s name is continued on various honours and awards, including the awarding of the King’s Medal in 1918 and a memorial erected in the Royal Artillery Park in London in 1921. In 2006, the Battery was included in the Queen’s Birthday Honours list. The Wolseley Battery’s legacy is seen as a strong one, representing Britain’s ability to rapidly develop effective field artillery during the First World War. Its use of advanced tactics, weapons and personnel has been remembered as a turning point in the development of British military strategy. The Battery’s story stands as a testament to the capability and skill of the British forces.

Leasburg is a small rural unincorporated community located in Caswell County, North Carolina. It was developed in the 1770s and is noted for its historical preservation. The town is situated on the northern side of the Uwharrie River, near Anderson Creek. Leasburg was officially founded by William and Mary Lea in 1772, and they were the first recorded settlers in the area. The town was likely named after the family. During its early years, Leasburg served as an important crossing point along major trade routes that went through the area. Leasburg has long served as a popular area for farming and agricultural activity. In recent years, its location on the Uwharrie River has made it popular among visitors looking to enjoy recreational activities such as fishing and camping. The small town has been able to maintain much of its historical charm, and is home to a number of preserved buildings and structures, many of which date back to the original settlers. Notable structures include the Leasburg Plantation, the Stevens-Chapman House, a one-room schoolhouse, and an abandoned railroad line. The community was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1972. Leasburg is also home to a number of small businesses, including restaurants, a feed store, and a sporting goods store. The community also boasts its own library, elementary school, and post office. Today, Leasburg remains a small but vibrant community. Its historical preservation and rural hospitality have been preserved, and it remains a popular destination for visitors looking to experience the culture and history of the area.

Yael Dowker (born November 27, 1977) is a Canadian actor, director, and producer who is best known for her roles in theatre, television and film. After earning her BFA in Theatre Performance at Dalhousie University in 2000, Dowker went on to join the National Theatre School of Canada's Professional Actor Training Program. Following this, she worked as a guest artist and member of several theatre companies in Halifax, Toronto and Winnipeg, including Theatre Calgary, Prairie Theatre Exchange and Cahoots Theatre Projects.​ On the big screen, Dowker has appeared in the films Away From Her (2006), Hairspray (2007), and The Stone Angel (2007). She has also made television appearances in Canada's Flight Before Christmas (2008). In 2010, Dowker worked on the independent film Not My Last Waltz and was awarded the Best Actor at the Canadian Filmmakers' Festival for her work in it. In 2011, Dowker wrote, directed and produced her first feature film Redemption: For Robbing the Dead, which was awarded best script by the 2013 Edmonton Female Eye Film Festival. She was named one of the Ten Up and Coming Actors from the Northwest Territories by The Aisle Seat Magazine in 2012. Dowker has been a part of many Canadian Shakespeare productions and has been commissioned by LungA School in Seyðisfjörður, Iceland. She also guest-starred in two episodes of Fox's Terra Nova in 2011, and was featured in an episode of NCIS in 2012. Dowker is currently living in Toronto and working in theatre, film and television. She is a board member at the Breastfeedin’ Mamas’ Collective and an ambassador of the Canadian Film Centre's CFC WOMEN: Reel Leaders Program. In her spare time, Dowker is an avid runner, yogi, and music enthusiast. She often travels to remote areas to practice yoga, connect with nature and to explore different cultures.

Crossing Lines is a crime fiction television series that is produced by French-German channel organisation Telfrance and focuses on the International Criminal Court in The Hague. The series follows the adventures of a transnational police unit, referred to as the "International Organised Crime Task Force". It is the first ever police procedural drama to focus on an international team. The team consists of a mix of law enforcement agents from around the world who come together to tackle organised crime across Europe. The series follows the cases they solve, their interactions and the drama of their personal lives. The first season was filmed in and around Lausanne and Geneva in Switzerland while the second season was filmed in Munich and Amsterdam in Germany. The series stars Donald Sutherland as former FBI Agent Carl Hickman, whom the series follows as he leads the team. The other team members include British investigator Louis Daniel (Marc Lavoine), French Inspector Eva Vittoria (Eva Lutz), American Detective Charlie Ballard (Sebastian Roché) and German ex-policemanCaroline Petersen (Gabriella Wright). Among the criminals featured in the series are the Corsican mafia, Serbian mafia, and Russian mob. The team has to confront various gangs, terrorists, and politicians in order to bring an end to the criminal activity across Europe. The series has received generally positive reviews from critics and viewers. Season one received an average rating of 8/10 from TV Positive. The second season also received a positive reception, with Kyrie Magdalene of Paste Magazine noting the show's 'gripping action, complex cases and engaging characters.' Crossing Lines is a series that has been successful in engaging viewers with its gripping and suspenseful crime stories, as well as its international take on the policing of the underworld. With two successful series under its belt, it's likely that Crossings Lines will continue to entertain, excite and enthrall viewers for a long time to come.

Anthony Winchester (born 26 April 1971, Los Angeles, California) is an American actor, best known for his roles in shows such as The Vampire Diaries, Supernatural and Bones. Early life Winchester was born to parents who were both involved in the entertainment industry. His mother worked as a stage and voice-over actress and his father was a stuntman and actor. He credits his parents for inspiring him to pursue an acting career. Acting career Winchester started off on stage, performing in several plays and musicals during high school. After graduating from the University of California, Berkeley, he moved to Los Angeles and embarked on a professional acting career. His breakout role was in the MTV series Undressed. He has since appeared in numerous television shows, including The Supernatural, Bones, and The Vampire Diaries. He has also had recurring roles in Two and a Half Men, Castle and Nez Parker P.I. In 2014, Winchester co-starred in the psychological horror film The Village. Other film credits include Hero, Dream On and Freefallin'. He also starred in the 2014 Western The Posse alongside Sam Shepard and Kris Kristofferson. More recently, Winchester appeared in the 2019 post-apocalyptic zombie comedy The Dead Don't Die. Other work Aside from acting, Winchester runs a professional surf and video camera business called Badwater Productions, with partner and wife, Kathleen. Winchester has had some success as a producer as well. He co-produced the movie Dream On, which won an Audience Choice Award at the Moondance Film Festival in 2005. Personal life Winchester lives with his wife, Kathleen, in Los Angeles, California. The couple sometimes works together, running their professional surf and video camera company, Badwater Productions. They have two children, a daughter, Kayden, and a son, Noah. Anthony said that he starting surfing 15-years ago and still enjoys surfing in his free time. He supports and advocates for worthwhile causes in his spare time. He also volunteers and donates to local charities. Filmography * The Dead Don't Die (2019) * The Posse (2014) * The Village (2014) * Bones (2007-2008) * The Vampire Diaries (2010-2012) * Two and a Half Men (2006) * Hero (2006) * Undressed (2000-2001) * Dream On (2005) * Freefallin' (2004)

Nasi lengko is a classic Javanese dish, traditionally served at ceremonies, such as weddings and circumcisions. It is also a popular breakfast food. The dish references the traditional staple Indonesian food, nasi, meaning "rice," and lengko, which refers to the topping and side dishes. Nasi lengko is usually served accompanied with fried shallots and peanuts, fresh vegetables, and a variety of sambals and condiments. The preparation of nasi lengko is complex and requires the use of highly specialized techniques. Start by boiling white jasmine rice with a pinch of salt. Once the rice is cooked, spread it out to cool and set aside. Meanwhile, prepare the topping and side dishes. For example, a typical nasi lengko dish can include boiled potatoes, hard-boiled eggs, ketoprak (a popular Indonesian dish made with bean sprouts, tofu, and fried shallots), and tahu bacem (a sweet and sour combination of spiced fried tofu, tempeh, and potato). To assemble a plate of nasi lengko, place some of the cooked rice in the center of a plate and arrange the toppings and side dishes around it. Then, spoon some of the condiments and sambals over the rice and toppings. The variety of sambals and condiments can also vary from region to region. Some popular sauces and condiments to include with nasi lengko are sambal kacang, kecap manis, and bumbu balado. Nasi lengko is also a popular street food in many parts of Indonesia. Vendors often offer nasi lengko as a cheap meal option, and the toppings can vary based on the availability of ingredients. The dish is popular due to its convenience and affordability. In addition to its food value, nasi lengko is also culturally significant. The dish is served during traditional ceremonies or gatherings, such as weddings and circumcisions, and has become an important symbol of Indonesian culture and heritage. The social aspect of the dish is also a common feature, as it is often served communally, encouraging guests to interact and enjoy the traditional dishes. Nasi lengko is a traditional Indonesian dish that has been served for centuries. As a tasty, nutritious, and affordable meal, it is a favorite among locals and tourists alike. The dish has also come to symbolize the cultural identity and heritage of the Indonesian people. References 1. https://www.thespruceeats.com/indonesian-nasi-lengko-recipe-3217657 2. https://www.indonesia.travel/en/post/indonesian-cuisine-nasi-lengko 3. https://www.idntimes.com/eat/culinary/angelica-ains-15d5b/ini-bumbu-nasi-lengko-yang-kelihatan-lebih-sedap-dari-sembarang-1 4. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasi_lengko

The Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Single-Camera Picture Editing for a Comedy Series is an Emmy Award given annually to the individual or team of picture editors responsible for the editing of a single-camera comedy series. The award has been awarded annually since 2000 and is presented by the Television Academy at the Creative Arts Emmy Awards ceremony. The award is specifically for picture editors. It is one of the many awards that honors those in the field of post-production. Picture editors must be the primary editors of a series and the editing must be done with a single-camera, as opposed to being a multi-camera sitcom edited in a live broadcast format. In 2018, the award went to Debra Light and Jack Neary, the editors of the HBO series Silicon Valley. Light had previously won the award in 2007 for her work on the NBC comedy 30 Rock. The other 2018 nominees included an editor from Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt, an editor from Master of None, and three editors from Veep. The Primetime Emmy Award has been awarded to several prominent comedy series. Shows such as Curb Your Enthusiasm, Modern Family, and Veep have all earned the award multiple times throughout the years. In 2017 and 2018, both Veep and Modern Family were nominated for the award but were beaten out by Atlanta and Silicon Valley respectively. The Emmys for single-camera picture editing for a comedy series has become a respected award in the post-production field. It recognizes the technical skills of the individuals responsible for transforming the scripts and performances of a television series into an enjoyable and engaging experience for viewers. It serves to remind the public of the significant contributions of the editing teams that work behind the scenes on their favorite shows.

Steve Susskind (1945 - June 2000) was an American folk singer, songwriter and performer who is often credited as one of the driving forces of the 1960s folk music revival. He rose to prominence during the time when the U.S. was involved in the Vietnam War and a decade of anti-establishment social movements. He was one of the first to tour throughout the country, introducing a new style of electric folk music to a generation desperate to rebel against traditionalism. Born in Brooklyn, New York City in 1945, Susskind grew up listening to traditional Hebrew music. By the time he was fourteen, he was playing banjo in a children’s theatre company and started to gain notoriety in the folk music scene. At the age of twenty-one, he opened an all-night cafe so he could perform his songs on a larger scale. In the mid-1960s, he released two influential albums that propelled him to national fame and acclaim. Susskind was a pioneer in introducing electric folk music to a mass audience. He taught artists like Ramblin’ Jack Elliot and Steve Goodman how to electrically accompany their acoustic guitar and vocal work. This allowed him and other musicians to bring their music to venues such as religious institutions and schools, places that many of the rock and roll genre could not access. In 1967, Susskind founded one of the most influential folk music labels, Fumble Records. In 1969, he and his wife moved to California and established a folk music publishing company and a production house. His talent as an artist was matched by his business savvy. Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, Steve recorded several critically acclaimed albums and played extensively throughout California, the Western US and Europe. He often traveled to Los Angeles to perform on folk radio shows and even performed at the White House during the Carter administration. In June 2000, Steve Susskind passed away while in the midst of recording a new album and writing his memoir, "Notes from a Troubadour". He is remembered for his contributions to the folk music scene, which heavily influenced the music of the 1960s by popularizing the electric folk style.

Emil Schram (1865 – 1932) was a Polish-born Swiss banker and financial executive. He was the founder of Emil Schram and Co., a banking and financial services firm in Zurich. Schram immigrated to Switzerland from Warsaw in the late 19th century. He quickly rose to prominence in Zurich's banking and financial circles, founding his own firm in 1890. He was a pioneer in the development of modern banking practices in Switzerland, such as issuing loans to businesses, providing foreign exchange services and assisting with stock market speculation. A successful investor and financier, Schram's most notable investments include the merger of various Swiss companies in 1911 to form Nestlé, a leader in the global food and beverage industry, and the purchase of Helvetia, a major Swiss insurance company, in 1912. Throughout his career, Schram was known for his philanthropic efforts. He was an ardent supporter of the arts, and he donated a sizeable portion of his wealth to various causes, including education and medicine. He also provided grants to students and supported the construction of hospitals and other medical facilities. Schram was also an advocate for economic liberalization in Switzerland. He strongly opposed the country's stringent import tariffs, and he exerted a considerable influence in the banking industry, convincing various Swiss banks to increase investments in foreign countries. Emil Schram died in Basel in 1932. His influence on the banking and financial world in Switzerland has become a legacy of his lasting impact. He is widely remembered as a man of integrity, a successful financier, and a generous philanthropist.

Bath Simple (often referred to as Bath Sim) is a lifestyle brand that specializes in the design and production of bath products. Founded in 2008, the brand is based in New York City and focused on creating innovative, high-quality products for the home and body. The company was founded by two entrepreneurs, Ramy and Jay, who were inspired by the need for truly unique and quality bath products, and the realization that most of the products already in the marketplace were either too generic or too expensive. Since its beginning, Bath Simple has focused on creating innovative, high-quality, simple yet luxurious bath and body products at a great value. Bath Simple's product line has grown over the years to include a wide variety of items, ranging from bath soaps and shampoos, to natural lotions, body washes, and balms. They also offer a selection of unique and luxurious items such as candles, body oils, and even skin care products. In addition, the company also produces accessories such as bath mats and towels, to make the bathroom a more inviting space. One of the main appeals of Bath Simple is its commitment to using natural ingredients for their products. For instance, all of their soaps, shampoos, and body washes are made from natural plant oils and essential oils, making them gentle and naturally scented. Their lotions and balms are also free of parabens, sulfates, and synthetic fragrances, and instead use natural plant-based oils to nourish and moisturize skin. The company also takes pride in the fact that all of their products are made and assembled in small batches, to ensure that they are truly of the highest quality. In addition, they use recycled and/or reusable packaging whenever possible in order to help reduce their environmental impact. Bath Simple has become a go-to brand for anyone looking to provide their home with luxurious and quality home care products. With its commitment to quality, natural ingredients, and environmentally conscious production, Bath Simple is a brand that stands for the best in home care.

School uniforms in South Korea refers to the standardized dress code that is enforced by the Korean Ministry of Education for the purpose of maintaining social order and discipline in the nation's public and private educational system. School uniforms are mandated from elementary school to high school, and although private schools have a certain level of autonomy to deviate from necessary requirements, they must still maintain regulations outlined by the Ministry of Education. Despite being a commonly accepted requirement, there are debates regarding the actual purpose and effectiveness of school uniforms in South Korea. Proponents of school uniforms assert that it acts as a form of collaboration between school and family; it reflects the mentalitity of the Korean government to follow rules and regulations; it eliminates competition among students by creating a homogeneous look; and it prevents students from distracting each other by dressing inappropriately. Opponents of school uniforms maintain that it inhibits students’ freedom of expression; it increases financial burden on parents; and it does not promote creativity or individual style. The debate aside, the style of school uniforms in South Korea has changed over time. Today, the typical Korean school uniform for elementary, middle, and high schools is made up of a top, bottom, a blazer, and a school shield badge. For male students a white shirt and black pants are required, and female students are required to wear a white blouse and black skirt. Additionally, there is a full range of optional accessories such as neckties, white gloves, and lanyards. It was only recently that neckties and lanyards for female students became mandatory. In addition to the clothing, students are also provided with school hats. For males, the standard hat design is the same throughout the country, while some variations exist between female students in different parts of the country. The design also often varies between elementary, middle, and high school. It is also common for backpacks and musical instruments to be color coded with the students' school colors or in the case of musical instruments with the student's school emblem. Today, school uniforms are seen as a contributing factor in creating a sense of unity and community in South Korea's public and private educational system. Despite the debate, these uniforms have mainly been accepted as a positive aspect of Korea's education system, helping to promote intelligence and hard work among students.

Paul II Šubić of Bribir (c. 1255–ch. 1312), was a Croatian nobleman in Medieval Croatia, and a member of the illustrious House of Šubić, who ruled from Bribir. His reign was from c. 1263–1274, and witnessed the zenith of Šubić power in Croatia. Paul II was born in Bribir, the son of Croatian counts Paul I and Ana Karlović. Born in 1255, he succeeded his father Paul I in 1263, at the age of eight. His mother acted as his regent until he came of age, supported in the confirmation of her regency by the ban of Croatia, Ivan Babonić. Paul II is considered one of the strongest rulers in the House of Šubić due to the fact that during his rule, the family obtained immense power and wealth. After assuming control of the government in 1263, Paul II increased the family's influence further, by marrying off his brother Mladen to Bosnia's queen, Jelena Šubić. He also acquired the castle of Brelato, a strategic stronghold on the sea-route from the Adriatic to the Mediterranean. Unlike his father, Paul II successfully protected the southern borders of Croatia from expansion by the Bulgarian Tsars from the House of Asen and the Athonite monk Florentius. Between 1263 and 1271, Paul II conducted a successful and aggressive campaign against the Bulgarian Tsars. By 1272, the Šubić family acquired Dubrovnik, a port city which helped increase the family's wealth and power. Paul II's reign, however, faced its own struggles. In 1274, tensions arose between the Šubićs, and the Croatian and Bosnian provincial lords over the composition of the Bosnian government, which resulted in a war between the two sides. This eventually led to Paul II's death in 1302, ending the House of Šubić's control of Croatia, and brought on the era of King Vladislav II's rule. Paul II's legacy and accomplishments as ruler of Croatia still stand to this day. His exploits in war, advocating for Croatia's interests and protection of the country's borders, and matrimonial alliances which bolstered the family's influence and wealth are credited for the rise of the Šubić family. He is remembered as one of the strongest rulers in the House of Šubić.

Makoto Yoshimori is a Japanese composer and arranger best known for his work in the anime and video game industries. He has composed many soundtracks for shows such as Haikyuu!!, Fruits Basket, Re:Zero − Starting Life in Another World, and mobile game Fate/Grand Order. Yoshimori was born on April 7, 1980, in Tokyo. He graduated from the Tokyo National University of Fine Arts and Music with a degree in music composition in 2004. Before attending music school, he had been playing the keyboards and piano since he was a child. During the mid-2000s, Yoshimori began arranging music for various genres, including hip-hop and jazz. He debuted in the anime industry in the 2007 TV series Dogs: Bullets & Carnage. He then arranged music for several other anime, including Blassreiter, Moyashimon, and Nogizaka Haruka no Himitsu. In 2017, Yoshimori composed the soundtrack for the popular anime series Fruits Basket, as well as the critically acclaimed Haikyuu!!. He also worked on the hit smartphone game Fate/Grand Order, composing music for the game's events and cinematics. In addition to composing music for television, video games and anime, Yoshimori occasionally performs publicly. He has performed at anime conventions such as Anime Expo and Comiket in Japan. Yoshimori has received much acclaim in his career, winning the prestigious Japan Academy Prize for Best Music in 2019, as well as Tatsunoko Anime Music Grand Prix Prize. Recently, Yoshimori has been collaborating with various musicians from across the anime industry, including a song intending to help people with feelings of isolation as part of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, and a song performed with other composers working on the TV anime series, Re: Zero. He was also nominated for an Annie Award for his music from the 2020 anime series Sarazanmai. Throughout his career, Yoshimori has maintained a passion for music and has become an inspiration for many budding composers and arrangers.

The II Riigikogu was the Second Estonian parliament, seated from 17 to 19 January 1919. It was composed of 112 members and represented a broad spectrum of political parties and platforms, mainly local peasant or worker associations. It declared the independence of Estonia on 24 February 1919, and continued to act as the parliament of Estonia until 20 April 1920, when it was replaced by the Third Riigikogu. The II Riigikogu was elected following the chaotic events of 1918, when the Russian Empire began to disintegrate, and Estonia declared its intention to set up its own parliament. The elections to the Second Riigikogu were held on 17 November 1918 and Elections to the Second Estonian Constituent Assembly were held to fill seats in the Estonian Parliament (Riigikogu). The parliament was partly based on the previous Estonian Provincial Assembly, and half of its seats were filled with candidates of the former assembly. The first meeting of the II Riigikogu, chaired by Konstantin Päts, was held on 17 January 1919 in Toompea Castle, Tallinn. The parliament was overwhelmingly dominated by the Estonian Nationalists led by Jüri Uluots and Konstantin Päts. The Nationalists wanted to follow the Swedish-Finnish model of self-determination and secure as much autonomy from Russia as possible. The majority of the II Riigikogu was also in favour of signing a peace treaty with Soviet Russia and creating an independent Estonia. Despite being only 112 members strong, the Riigikogu was able to form several committees and create a number of laws. It managed to pass several important laws, such as the Law on Naturalization, the Fundamental Law of the Autonomous Republic of Estonia, and the Law on Education. The Riigikogu also declared a ten-year armistice with Russia on 4 March 1919, which, although never ratified, allowed Estonia to take a firmer stand in the peace negotiation process with Russia. It was during the term of the II Riigikogu, on 24 February 1919, when the Act of Independence of Estonia was declared. This proclaimed the country an autonomous and democratic republic. The members of the Second Riigikogu then formed a Provisional Government, which had to coordinate the work with Soviet Russia in order to execute the March 4 armistice agreement. The II Riigikogu held its final meeting on 20 April 1920, when the Estonian Constituent Assembly elected the Third Riigikogu. The II Riigikogu left a strong legacy and is remembered as the chamber that declared the sovereignty of independent Estonia and created a foundation for its statehood.

Whitefield, Oklahoma is an unincorporated community in southwestern Texas County, Oklahoma, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the population of Whitefield was 475. The town was founded in 1895 by Tom Whitefield and was originally called Whitefield Settlement. It was part of Greer County, Texas until the Panhandle was assigned to Oklahoma in 1896. Whitefield was made a post office on March 15, 1898 and was the county seat of Greer County before it was transferred to Oklahoma. In 1907, Whitefield was moved south to a location on the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway line. Whitefield is one of the largest towns in Texas County and serves as a regional center of commerce. The town is home to several businesses, including a grocery store, hardware store, and farm supply store. The Whitefield Public Schools, which serve grades pre-K through 12, are located in the town. The Whitefield Museum is housed in the historic Whitefield Church building. The museum features artifacts and displays from the area's past, many of which were donated by area residents. Whitefield is home to the Old Texas County Courthouse, which was built in 1909. It has been featured in several movies and television shows, including the TV series Dallas. The courthouse is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Whitefield is near several recreation areas, including the Black Mesa State Park and Wildlife Management Area, which features over 10,000 acres of hiking trails and camping facilities, as well as a ski area. The nearby Optima National Wildlife Refuge, which is managed by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, is also a popular destination for birdwatchers and nature lovers. Whitefield is also home to the Whitefield Rodeo and Stock Show, which is held annually in June. The event draws competitors and spectators from several states and includes events such as calf-roping, bronc riding, sheep riding, and team roping. Whitefield is a quiet town with a big heart and a stalwart community spirit. The town's slogan is "Where the West still lives".

Ulfert Wilke (1893-1978) was a German entomologist and entomophile who was a pioneer of the study of fly genetics. He is best known for his work on the domestication of Drosophila melanogaster, a species of fruit fly that has become one of the most widely used laboratory models in genetics. Born in Berlin, Wilke studied zoology and botany at the University of Berlin. In 1927 he was appointed professor of zoology at the University of Greifswald and later professor of zoology at the University of Kiel (1932–1933). While at Kiel, Wilke undertook research on the genetics of fruit flies. He then accepted a position at Würzburg University, where he applied the principles of Mendelian genetics to fruit fly populations and was able to induce genetic variability by serving different food sources to fruit fly colonies. Wilke's major contribution to the field was the recognition that fruit flies are capable of being domesticated in the laboratory. This work, which was performed over several years, enabled researchers to control the genetic composition of laboratory populations. In 1940 he was appointed professor of zoology at the University of Greifswald. Over the next decade he continued to study genetics, but also became interested in the biogeography of fishes, including a study of sturgeon. He later held posts at the universities of Hamburg and Kiel, and died in 1978. Wilke is remembered for his pioneering and influential work on fruit fly genetics, for which he was awarded a Darwin Medal in 1966. He also wrote a number of books and propagated the study of entomology among the general public. In particular, he was proud of his text ‘The World of Animals’, published in 1937, which traced the development of zoology in Germany and Europe. Although not as prominent in the scientific community as his contemporary Hermann Müller, Ulfert Wilke left an indelible mark on the fields of genetics and entomology. His research laid the foundations for today’s understanding of the genetics of fruit flies, and the domestication of insects in the laboratory. He remains a key figure in the history of evolutionary genetics, and his work continues to inspire new generations of entomologists.

The Northeast Coast Campaign of 1745 (otherwise known as the New England Expedition of 1745) was an attempt by the French to capture colonial settlements in New England during the War of the Austrian Succession (1740-48). The campaign was spearheaded by French Rear Admiral Jean-Baptiste-Nicolas-Roch de Ramezay, and included a fleet of five warships, three of which were French while the other two were supplied by Spain. The fleet was under the overall command of the Duc d'Anville. The campaign began in June 1745, when the fleet sailed from Cape Breton, Nova Scotia and headed south towards Acadia, where the French forces would then be ready to proceed further south towards New England. The main objective of the campaign was to capture the major ports of Boston and New York City, which would gain France control of the lucrative North American fur trade. To this end, the fleet was well-equipped and carried a large contingent of troops, including French regulars and Native American allies from the Mi'kmaq and Abenaki nations. En route to New England, the French forces suffered a string of navigational mishaps. The worst of these occurred when a storm damaged the flagship and forced it to dock near the heavily forested island of Sable, located off the coast of present-day Nova Scotia. The delay caused by this setback provided the British with time to prepare a new expedition to protect their settlements in the region, led by Admiral Edward Boscawen. When the French fleet finally arrived off the coast of what is now Massachusetts in August 1745, they were met by a stronger British force and forced to retreat. The French navy caused some damage to several coastal settlements before withdrawing. While the French were unable to achieve any of their large-scale objectives, their presence did cause considerable panic in New England and helped to bring the region closer to the rest of the English colonies. Overall, the Northeast Coast Campaign of 1745 was a failure for the French. They suffered heavy losses in both men and ships before ultimately being forced to retreat. Despite this, the campaign was an important turning point in the War of the Austrian Succession, as French presence in continental North America continued to be a major concern for the British throughout the conflict.

Fred Alan Wolf (born December 3, 1934) is an American quantum physicist, author, and lecturer. He is known for his work on the physics of consciousness and has written several books on the subject, most notably Taking the Quantum Leap (1981) and The Eagle's Quest (1991). Wolf was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He attended Temple University and then the University of Chicago, where he received his B.A. in physics in 1959 and his Ph.D. in theoretical physics in 1962. After leaving the university, Wolf worked as a research scientist at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center and at the Max Planck Institute for Applied Physics in Stuttgart, Germany. Wolf's major works focus on the relationship between modern quantum physics and consciousness. He is best known for his book Taking the Quantum Leap (1981), which introduced the idea of "quantum consciousness" - the notion that consciousness can influence physical reality. He has since written several other books exploring the implications of quantum physics for our understanding of the world. Wolf also gave public lectures and seminars on his work, including one given at the Esalen Institute in 1978. He has appeared in numerous documentaries and media programs, including the Skeptics Society's podcast and the film What the Bleep Do We Know!? He has been a guest speaker at the Fetzer Institute and the Temenos Academy. In addition to his work in the field of quantum physics, Wolf continues to write and lecture on topics ranging from spirituality and philosophy to pop culture. He lives in San Diego, California and remains active in the scientific and philosophical communities. He also writes regularly for New Realities and writes a bi-weekly column for Fearless Planet magazine. Wolf's latest book, Quantum Fitness: Harnessing the Power of Consciousness and Quantum Physics, was published in 2015. Wolf has remained active in public life and is a frequent guest speaker and panelist at universities, science and spiritual gatherings around the world. He has contributed to numerous radio and television programs, including the History Channel's The Universe, Beyond Human, and the Discovery Channel's When Darwin Met Einstein. He has also contributed to popular magazines such as The Atlantic, Psychology Today, Popular Science, and New Realities. Wolf's life and work have strongly influenced the fields of quantum physics and consciousness. His books, public appearances, and media presence have helped popularize the ideas of quantum physics and consciousness and make them accessible to a wider audience.

The Cubic Honeycomb is a three-dimensional honeycomb structure in which all of the cells are cubes. It is one of the main honeycomb patterns studied in the field of topology, as well as in mathematics and physics. It is also referred to as the cubic lattice, cubic tiling, or dual octahedral lattice in crystallography. The cubic honeycomb is a space-filling lattice structure that is composed of cubes arranged in a three-dimensional grid. Each cube is connected to its neighbors in each of the six directions of the Cartesian coordinate system. This makes it a topologically unique honeycomb, as all of its cells (cubes) are adjacent to each other in three dimensions. The cubic honeycomb also has the distinction of being isotropic, meaning that all directions of the lattice look the same. The cubic honeycomb was first studied extensively by Leonhard Euler in the mid-18th century. In particular, Euler studied it for its connections to the Platonic solids. He used the cubical lattice to generate the octahedron, the cube, the icosahedron and the dodecahedron. Euler also used it to develop a new system of notation for describing polyhedra, the Euler notation, which is now standard in many mathematics texts. The cubic honeycomb is most commonly used to construct systems of three-dimensional crystals, as it is one of the simplest lattices used in such systems. Its use in these types of applications stems from its ability to define a cubic space in which certain materials can stack without introducing strain on the structure. It is commonly used in the fabrication of metals, alloys, compounds, polymers and other materials. The cubic honeycomb also has a variety of applications in mathematics, particularly in topology. It is a fundamental structure of three-dimensional topology, as it is composed of cubes, the simplest unit of measure used in the field. It is used in the study of homology, which studies the topological features of different shapes, and in knot theory, which studies how two or more strands interact. Finally, the cubic honeycomb is used in physics, especially in models of higher dimensions. It is often used in the study of particle physics, such as in the four-dimensional spacetime of string theory, as well as in the study of cosmology. In short, the cubic honeycomb is an essential structure in the fields of mathematics, physics and engineering. Its use in describing patterns, constructing lattices and modeling systems makes it a crucial part of many branches of research.

Arend Glas (born June 29, 1965) is a Dutch entrepreneur and business executive. He is the founder, CEO, and sole shareholder of Glas Vision, a leading intelligent automation solutions company with offices in Amsterdam, London, New York and Toronto. Glas Vision offers automated solutions that help businesses streamline operational processes, increase competitiveness and reduce complexity. Glas was born in a small village in the north of The Netherlands. He grew up on a farm and learned the importance of hard work, diligence and responsibility at a young age. After completing high school, he joined the Dutch Navy and served for four years. During this time, he devoted himself to information technology, developing a strong interest in digital development. After his time in the Navy, Glas founded his own company, Glas Vision. Glas saw an opportunity to apply automation technologies to the operations of companies, which was not yet widely done at the time. His vision was to develop a simple, reliable and powerful automation platform that could benefit businesses in a vast array of industries. The company was an instant success and quickly gained recognition, culminating in Glas being featured in Forbes magazine as one of the “Most Innovative Leaders in Automation”. Glas himself was praised for his bold vision and impeccable execution. Glas Vision continues to be one of the leading technology companies in the industry, and has a strong focus on social responsibility and ecological sustainability. Its solutions are actively used in more than 100 countries worldwide and are employed by companies of all sizes, from start-ups to multinationals. It is credited for having helped its clients improve their efficiency, saving them millions of dollars annually. Arend Glas is a highly respected figure in the technology industry and a passionate advocate for the use of automation to improve business processes. Throughout his career, he has worked to make automation solutions accessible to all businesses, and has played a major role in propelling the industry forward.

Lansing Charter Township (also known as Lansing Township) is a charter township of Ingham County in the U.S. state of Michigan. The population was 13,365 at the 2010 census. Most of the township is within the Lansing–East Lansing metropolitan area, and borders the City of Lansing and Eaton County. Geography Lansing Charter Township is located in southern Ingham County, bordered by Eaton County to the south and the City of Lansing to the north and east. The Kalamazoo River forms part of the township's southern border, with the City of Lansing to the east. The northern and eastern portions of the township are part of the greater Lansing metropolitan area. Demographics The population of Lansing Charter Township was 13,365 in 2010. The racial composition of the population was 79.4% White, 13.2% African American, 3.3% Hispanic or Latino, and 4.1% other. Economy Lansing Charter Township is home to a variety of businesses, from retail stores to manufacturing plants. The township also has a number of parks and recreational facilities, including the Lansing Township Community Center, which offers programs and activities. Education The Lansing Charter Township Public Schools system provides elementary, middle, and high school education to residents. The system consists of one high school, one middle school, and three elementary schools. Transportation Lansing Charter Township is served by several bus routes operated by the Capital Area Transit Authority (CATA). The township also has easy access to major highways, including Interstate 496, US127, and M99. In addition, the Lansing Capital Regional International Airport is located in the township, just south of the City of Lansing. Government Lansing Charter Township is governed by a five-member Board of Trustees and a Supervisor. The trustees are elected from five wards within the township. The board is responsible for making laws, policies, and setting the annual budget for the township. In addition, the board has the power to appoint a Township Manager, who is responsible for day-to-day operations. Lansing Charter Township also has a Circuit Court and several parks, including the Lansing Township Community Center, which is a multi-purpose facility offering a variety of programs and activities for the community. The township also provides public safety services, including police, fire, and EMS services. The Lansing Township Fire Department operates three fire stations, yielding coverage throughout the township.

Real-time text (RTT) is a technology allowing people to type and send text messages as they would normally type and send an email or instant message. It is also known as “right now text” or “immediate text”, as messages appear almost immediately on the receiver’s screen. Real-time text can be used by individuals with a hearing impairment, as sign language interpreters are not necessary and the message can be sent and received instantly. Real-time text is used in various modes such as: * Telephone: It is used when two individuals use a telephone to communicate with each other. In this scenario, both individuals type their messages on the phone keypad and view the other person’s messages on their telephone screen. * Computer: Computer-based programming systems can also be used to communicate in real-time text. This can be beneficial for situations such as online job interviews where the prospective employer and the applicant are in two different locations. * Internet: The most common form of RTT is through the use of the internet. This allows people to type and send text messages to each other through an online chat platform such as Google Hangouts, AIM, or Skype. There are several advantages to using real-time text. By providing immediate feedback and communication, RTT helps to increase collaboration, aid in decision making and enable faster resolution of issues. Since RTT is a text-based, non-intrusive mode of communication, it can be used in environments such as doctor-patient consultations, business meetings, etc. Furthermore, the technology is relatively easy and relatively cost-effective to implement compared to other real-time communication tools. However, there are also some drawbacks of RTT. Since the use of RTT is limited to text-based communication, it does not replace other forms of communication such as audio and video calls which can be more effective for certain purposes. There also is a potential for misunderstandings and misinterpretations due to typing errors. Finally, RTT protocols are still in development, so there is not a standard way of using the technology, which can cause confusion among users. Overall, real-time text is a useful technology, especially when audio and/or video calls are unavailable, impractical or inappropriate. It is ideal for situations such as email conversations, group chats and long-distance communications. While RTT is not a perfect solution and does have some drawbacks, it does provide an efficient, text-based mode of communication for those who need it.

Young Israel of Flatbush, officially known as Congregation Shomrei Torah, is an Orthodox synagogue located in the Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn, New York. Founded in 1949, it was the first Orthodox synagogue in the area. The congregation provides educational and religious services for families and individuals in the local community. Young Israel of Flatbush consists of two separate synagogue buildings. The larger of the two, located at 1501 Avenue J, was built in 1956. In 1977, the synagogue building at 1501 Avenue J was sold off to another organization and the congregation of Young Israel of Flatbush subsequently occupied its present building at 1414 Avenue J. This building, which provides services for both men and women, was dedicated in 1983 and has been the primary congregation for the synagogue. Young Israel of Flatbush services adhere to Orthodox standards and tradition. Orthodox standards require that worship services be done in Hebrew, and prayer books are available to those who are unfamiliar with the language. Services are held daily, including morning, afternoon and evening services, with special attention paid to important holidays such as Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, as well as the High Holidays of Sukkot, Chanukah and Passover. The congregation is led by Rabbi Yehuda Kalmanowitz, who was appointed as spiritual and executive leader in 2007. In addition to providing religious services and education, Young Israel of Flatbush serves its local community with many charitable giving programs, community meals, and other activities. The synagogue has been a member of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America since 1981. Through its association with the union, Young Israel of Flatbush participates in the National Conference of Synagogue Youth and the National Council of Young Israel. Young Israel of Flatbush continues to be an important part of the Jewish community of Brookyln. The congregation provides an atmosphere of understanding, support and brotherhood, and is dedicated to the goals of fostering and supporting a vibrant Jewish life in its community.

Charles Spinola was an American businessman who was active on Wall Street for more than 50 years. He was born in New York City in 1814, and he came from a humble background. Spinola began his career as a clerk in 1831, working for the Bank of the Manhattan Company. He earned a reputation as a hard working and reliable employee, with an eye for investments and finance. By 1839, he was promoted to president of the bank, and oversaw the completion of its merger with the Bank of the United States. Over the course of his career, Spinola went on to hold important financial positions in a number of banks and brokerages. He was a powerful voice on Wall Street and helped to modernize the banking industry in the United States. He founded several banks and brokerages and was an influential investor in the railroad industry. In 1852, he helped to finance the Chicago and North Western Railway. He also had influential stakes in what would become the Pennsylvania Railroad and the Union Pacific Railroad. Spinola was involved in numerous business ventures, including the formation of the Atlantic Refined Oil Company. He was a successful investor and speculator, amassing a large fortune through his investments and his banking activities. Spinola was highly respected for his acumen, and respected by his peers. He was well known for his philanthropic contributions to many charities and educational institutions. He was a generous donor to St. Patrick's Cathedral and was a major supporter of New York University. Charles Spinola died in 1888. Today, he is remembered as a prominent figure in the history of American finance. His legacy lives on in the banks, brokerages, and other organizations which he founded, and in the contributions he made to charities and educational institutions.

Multiprotocol Encapsulation is a method of transporting multiple protocols over a single medium. It is commonly used for communication between nodes on different networks or for connecting multiple networks together. Multiprotocol encapsulation allows for the transmission of different protocols over the same network medium. In networking, a layer of data is added by an encapsulating protocol (IP, Ethernet, etc.) above the application data. This layer helps to provide a standardized format for transmitting data from one network stack to another. The encapsulating protocol is able to process received data and break it into its component parts for transmission to the appropriate protocols. Multiprotocol encapsulation requires knowledge of how to interpret each protocol as well as how to encapsulate them. This is typically done through packet encapsulation. In packet encapsulation, one protocol's header data is used to encapsulate part or all of the other protocol's header and data fields. This process is necessary to ensure that each protocol is transmitted according to its corresponding protocol specifications. In most cases, an encapsulating protocol will add some of its own data fields in between the encapsulated fields. These fields may contain information about the encapsulated data’s type, length, or source. The encapsulating protocol may also include a CRC sum number to verify data integrity. In addition to saving bandwidth, multiprotocol encapsulation can also improve the performance of a network. By allowing multiple protocols to run over a single network medium, multiprotocol encapsulation allows packets to take the most direct path through the network and be routed quickly and efficiently. This improves network performance because the network is no longer bottlenecked by the individual protocols. Multiprotocol encapsulation also helps to reduce the number of errors that occur on a network. By providing a common interface for all protocols, multiprotocol encapsulation helps reduce the amount of translation that must be done. This helps devices more easily interpret the received data and correct any errors. Multiprotocol encapsulation is important for interoperability in Internet of Things (IoT) applications. By allowing devices from different manufacturers speaking different protocols to communicate, multiprotocol encapsulation helps ensure a wide range of devices can communicate with one another in a secure and efficient manner. In summary, multiprotocol encapsulation is a powerful tool for improving the efficiency and reliability of modern networks. By allowing multiple protocols to coexist on the same network medium, multiprotocol encapsulation can save bandwidth and improve network performance. Additionally, multiprotocol encapsulation helps to reduce the number of errors in a network and can be used to ensure interoperability between different devices.

SS Minnesota was a steamship built in 1903 in Glasgow, Scotland, by the John Brown & Company shipbuilding company. It was built for the Atlantic Transport Line of Liverpool, and was originally intended to be used as a cargo and passenger ship. The Minnesota was initially registered in Liverpool, but was later registered in London. The SS Minnesota was a four-masted steel steamship, 403.5 feet long by 56.1 feet wide and had a gross tonnage of 9,084. It was propelled by a four steam-cylinder triple expansion engine and a single screw, and was also fitted with three masts for sailing purposes. Its maiden voyage was from London to New York City on April 14, 1904. The Minnesota was popularly known as the "Queen of the Atlantic." It was named after both a state in the United States and a Dakota Sioux Tribe. It was the flagship of the Atlantic Transport Line, and the most luxurious ship of its time, featuring the first heated pool on an ocean liner, as well as four elevators, Turkish baths, gymnasium, and lovely saloons. Many of the original furnishings, decorative woodwork, hand-painted glass panels, and a bronze fountain with four cherubs still survived in the ship until shortly before its demolition in 1981. The SS Minnesota served as an immigration ship during World War I, carrying thousands of soldiers to the front in Europe. After the war, it returned to its original purpose as a cargo and passenger ship, making regular trips to New York, Boston, and Philadelphia. In 1927, its passenger service was suspended, and it became solely a cargo vessel until its retirement in 1960. The SS Minnesota's final voyage was to Rotterdam, Netherlands in 1960. In 1981 the ship was sold to a Dutch scrapyard, and was subsequently dismantled and scrapped. Much of the furniture, decorations, and other items originally on the ship were salvaged and taken to the Netherlands Maritime Museum. The Minnesota was a remarkable ship whose luxurious and advanced features set the tone for modern ocean liners.

Sheikh Aftab Ahmed (born 1951) is a prominent Pakistani politician who belongs to the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) party. He was a member of the National Assembly of Pakistan from 2008 to 2018, representing the NA-111 constituency in Sialkot. Sheikh Aftab was born in Sialkot in 1951. He has a master’s degree in Political Science from University of the Punjab, and has been very active in politics since the late 1970s. He served as a member of the National Assembly from 1985 to 1988, representing the Sialkot constituency. During the 1990s, he moved to Canada but returned to Pakistan in 2002 and was elected to the National Assembly of Pakistan in 2008 as an independent candidate. He then joined the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz party, and was re-elected to the National Assembly in 2013. He was among the prominent PML-N candidates in the 2018 general elections, but he was defeated by PTI candidate Ghulam Bibi Bharwana, who received 76,376 votes and Sheikh Aftab Ahmed who received 70,461 votes. Throughout his career, Sheikh Aftab has advocated on behalf of the oppressed sections of society, and has highlighted the issues faced by women and children. He has been praised for his efforts to promote education and healthcare in Pakistan, as well as his commitment to egalitarianism. He has also been a strong backer of improving Punjab's infrastructure and has strongly supported the construction of a modern railway line. In recognition of his outstanding services to the people of Pakistan, Sheikh Aftab was awarded the Pride of Performance award in 1997 and the Hilal-e-Imtiaz award in 2011. In 2016, he was appointed as the Deputy Speaker of the National Assembly. He currently serves as a senior leader of PML-N and continues to advocate for the rights of the people of Pakistan.

Archie Devine (born August 26,1992) is a Canadian professional basketball player who currently plays for the Toronto Raptors of the National Basketball Association (NBA). Devine attended Canada Prep Academy in St. Catharines, Ontario and then went to play college basketball at the University of Toronto from 2010-2014. In his freshman year, Devine averaged 14.2 points, 5.7 rebounds and 2 assists per game. In his junior and senior years at the University of Toronto, Devine started all 33 games and averaged a career-high 19.3 points, 7.8 rebounds and 3.5 assists per game. Following his collegiate career, Devine was selected in the second round of the 2014 NBA Draft by the Minnesota Timberwolves. He was traded to the Toronto Raptors during his rookie season and went on to become the first Canadian-born player to win an NBA title with the Raptors in 2019. As part of the championship run, Devine averaged 8.1 points, 4 rebounds and 2.6 assists per game in the playoffs. In the 2019-20 season, Devine led the Raptors to their third consecutive appearance in the playoffs, averaging 9.4 points, 4.7 rebounds and 2.3 assists per game, including a career-high 26 points and 9 assists against the Denver Nuggets on December 3, 2019. Devine is known for his all-around game, which showcases his ability to shoot from range and finish at the rim, as well as his athleticism, defensive intensity and leadership. Off the court, he is a passionate advocate of basketball in Canada, showcasing the game in a variety of ways through camps, clinics and other events. He has become a popular figure among Canadian basketball fans, and his potential, presence and contributions to Canadian basketball have earned him the nickname "Canada's Basketball King". As of June 2020, Devine has been featured in the NBA All-Star Weekend Rising Stars Challenge four times and was named the Most Valuable Player in 2019.

Automba Township is an organized township in Carlton County, Minnesota, United States. As of the 2010 census, the township had a population of 290, making it the least populous township in Minnesota. The township was organized in 1891 and named after the Ojibwe chief Automba. The area was primarily a logging community and was the last to be settled in the county. Logging remained the primary economic activity in Automba until the late 20th century. The unincorporated community of Automba is located in the township. The mainly residential community contains stores, a post office, a hills Chapel, and a Baptist church. A single school serves local students. Today, Automba Township is a somewhat rural community. It is mostly composed of farms and woodlands, with a few small commercial establishments. There are two lakes in the township; Automba Lake, which is the largest lake in the county and Lake Bigfork. Both lakes are popular with visitors, offering fishing and recreational opportunities. Automba Township is governed by a three-member board of supervisors. They are responsible for maintaining roads, enforcing zoning regulations and licensing hunting and fishing. The board also approves budgets and other local initiatives. Automba Township generally supports the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party. The township is represented in the Minnesota House of Representatives by Rob Ecklund (DFL). The township has a fire department, which is staffed by volunteer fire fighters and provides fire protection for the community and its surrounding area. The Automba Township Fire Department is a member of the Northern Minnesota Firefighter's Association. Automba Township is located in a region of Minnesota known as the "Northland." The area is known for its strong sense of community, its abundance of natural resources, and its tight-knit community.

The Brattain–Hadley House is a historic residence located in Portland, Oregon, United States. The house was built by Charles B. Brattain and wife Charlotte in 1902. It is a two-story frame house, with a gable and two stories with an attic with two dormers. The design of the house is an example of the Queen Anne style of architecture, popular in the early 20th century. The two story house sits on a large irregularly shaped lot, with a large wrap-around porch and a one-story gabled wing. The exterior of the house is painted in a combination of white and light yellow colors. Decorative shingles, patterned siding and large wrap-around porch complete the architectural design. The house has been home to many generations of the Brattain and Hadley families and is one of the few remaining historic residences in Portland. The house is considered a local landmark, and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. A unique feature of the house is the original brick foundation which is visible in the basement and under the main floor of the house. In addition, the house is surrounded by a small shrub-lined lawn, creating a pleasant and cozy environment. The interior of the house features high ceilings and grand windows with transom windows, which allow immense amounts of natural light to flow in. The house also features fireplaces, a built-in pantry, and original hardwood floors. Today, the Brattain–Hadley House is owned by the Historic Preservation League of Oregon, who acquired the house in 1977. It is privately owned, and not open to the public. The house is used as a reminder of Portland’s rich architectural history and is an important part of the community.

Things and Other Things is a philosophy developed by Stephen Katz and others which seeks to provide a framework for understanding the relationship between particular subjective entities and the collective and infinite "otherness" of objects and events. It is mainly concerned with the concept of "substantive identity" in which a particular being is constituted of a single essence, often referred to as a "thing". This philosophy was developed in the late twentieth century, and originally presented to the public in the book "Things and Other Things: A Study of Substantive Identity" (1989). The book looks at the various questions of identity that arise when attempting to unify seemingly disparate parts of reality. Questions such as “in what sense an entity is the same as something else, or in what way is it distinct” are explored and discussed in great detail. The heart of the philosophy is the concept of substantive identity which asserts that each thing is composed of two distinct parts – the individual and the universal. Thus, each particular thing has its own identity based on its component parts, yet in some sense can still be seen as a part of something larger – the collective and infinite “otherness” of objects and events. This is often referred to as the “infinitely divisible identity” of things, or the “ontological puzzle of inter-particular relations”. In addition to the notion of substantive identity, Katz and his colleagues also discuss a related concept of “extrinsic difference”. This relates to the idea that each thing is not only intrinsically different from all other things, but it is also inextricably linked to all other things through its “other”. Thus, each individual object or event is intrinsically different, yet cannot exist independently, but must exist in relationship with all other things or events. Katz and his colleagues stress that rather than seeing things as existing independently, or existing in relation to the collective, we should consider them as existing in a dual relationship – both connected to and distinct from the universe of things and other things. Thus, in their view, the concept of “things and other things” helps us to understand the complexities of reality, and better understand the relationship between the particular and the universal. In conclusion, the philosophy of “Things and Other Things” provides a distinct framework for understanding the complexity of existence, and offers an alternative to more rigid philosophical conceptions of identity. By showing how each particular thing is linked to the greater whole, Katz and his colleagues demonstrate how we can better comprehend our relationship to the irrational and the infinite.

Cindy Shih (born 1984) is an American businesswoman and entrepreneur. She is the co-founder and CEO of TsuiShoe, a children's shoe company based in San Francisco. Shih was born and raised in California and attended college at UC Berkeley where she studied economics. After college, she began her career in finance and worked with venture capital and private equity firms. In 2011, she left the corporate world to pursue her entrepreneurial dream of starting a business and founded TsuiShoe with her partner in 2012. TsuiShoe is a children's footwear company that offers fun, stylish and affordable shoes for kids from ages 0 to 8. Its products are designed and produced in California and include comfortable and supportive shoes for toddlers, first walkers, casual sneakers and dress shoes. The company sells its products through its e-commerce website, as well as through online retailers, department stores and specialty boutiques. TsuiShoe has earned several awards for its innovative design and has been featured in notable press outlets such as Teen Vogue, Elle and Fortune. In addition to TsuiShoe, Shih is also involved with several non-profit organizations, including the San Francisco Ballet School and the San Francisco Asian Art Museum. She was included in Forbes magazine’s 2015 30 Under 30 list, which recognizes emerging business leaders in the U.S. Today, Shih lives in San Francisco and works to inspire young entrepreneurs to pursue entrepreneurship. She is a frequent participant at entrepreneurship events and regularly speaks with aspiring business owners. Shih is continuously looking for new ways to expand her business while advocating for gender and social equality.

Orlando Peçanha (born 15 December 1907) is a Brazilian engineer and politician who served as the Governor of Rio de Janeiro from 1950 until 1954. Peçanha was born in Rio de Janeiro to military officers of the Brazilian Imperial Army. He studied engineering at the Imperial School of Engineering at Rio de Janeiro, graduating in 1931. He married Maria da Conceição Lousado in 1933, with whom he had four children. Peçanha initially found success as an engineer, working on several public works projects around Brazil, such as the São Francisco River dam and the Belo Horizonte airfield. He also served in several public positions, including advisor of the President of the Bank of Brazil and the Head of the National Department of Public Works. In 1950, Peçanha was elected Governor of Rio de Janeiro state. As Governor, Peçanha implemented a broad range of projects aimed at modernizing the state, including a plan to improve sanitation and public health, the establishment of the Sugar Loaf Cable Car, and the creation of the Sambódromo, a permanent venue for the yearly Rio Carnival parades. Peçanha also made significant investments in the agricultural sector, particularly in the cultivation of coffee and oranges. Peçanha's four-year term as Governor of Rio de Janeiro ended in 1954, and in 1956 he was nominated to the Chamber of Deputies of the Brazilian Parliament. He remained a member of the Chamber until 1959. After he left his post as Deputy, Peçanha moved to the city of São José dos Campos, where he devoted himself to the agricultural development of the region. Peçanha was a strong advocate of education and public infrastructure. He personally funded the building of the Taquaral Hospital, located in São José dos Campos, and supported the creation of the Technical University of São Paulo. In 1993, Peçanha was awarded the Order of Merit of Rio de Janeiro for his outstanding contributions to the development of the state. In 2001, he was posthumously inducted into the Brazilian Order of Merit. Orlando Peçanha died on 15 August 1975, at the age of 68. He is remembered as one of the most influential politicians and engineers of his time.

L.C. Gordon is an American entrepreneur best known for creating the innovative pet food company, Pawsitively Natural. His professional history highlights his work as a leader in developing pet nutrition products that are both healthy and affordable for pet owners. In 2002, Gordon created Pawsitively Natural as a way to provide pet owners with a more natural and nutritious variety of dog and cat food. His vision was to use natural ingredients to create a food that offered more in terms of nutrition and flavor than "standard" pet foods. He developed products that not only encouraged good pet health but also provided customers with a product that was cost-effective. The company has been widely successful since its inception, and many pet owners continue to rely on L.C. Gordon's products. In addition to the successful line of nutritious and affordable pet food, Gordon has also produced innovative health supplements and foods designed to help ease digestive issues in pets. His products have earned the praise of veterinarians and pet owners alike, and the company has seen continued success since 2002. Today, Gordon continues to lead the company and focus on creating innovative pet products. He and his team are dedicated to providing pet owners with the highest quality and safest products on the market. With a passionate work ethic and unparalleled devotion to their craft, L.C. Gordon and the team at Pawsitively Natural has set a standard for pet care and nutrition. Gordon is also a philanthropist and conservation advocate. He spends much of his free time volunteering for organizations such as the California Coastal Providers and the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. His love of animals and passion for the environment drive his dedication to making a positive impact on local animal welfare. L.C. Gordon is an innovative entrepreneur who has dedicated his life to providing pet owners with the safest and healthiest pet food alternatives. His commitment to quality and affordability has made Pawsitively Natural a go-to source for pet owners looking to keep their beloved animals healthy.

Alan Simpson (born 14th November 1925) is an English theatre director and former artistic director of the Birmingham Repertory Theatre from 1972 to 1988. Simpson's long career spans over five decades and his directorial work also includes Holby City and Eastenders. Simpson was born in St. Helens, Lancashire and studied at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art. He began his career as an actor and worked for a decade before taking up the post of Assistant Director at the Birmingham Repertory Theatre. During his time, Simpson re-dramatised classic plays from the past and recreated them for the modern stage. In 1972, Simpson became the artistic director of the theatre and during his tenure, he was credited with expanding the theatre's artistic and programming portfolio and introducing more new work by British playwrights. He was also a driving force behind the theatre’s annual autumn festival, highlighting new plays and contemporary productions. The Birmingham Repertory Theatre became a regional leader in modern theatre practice and its exposure to the public a lot during Simpson's tenure. Recognising it as the “largest and most influential regional theatre” in England at the time, the British Endowment for the Arts made a significant investment into the theatre. This played a major role in the theatre’s continued success and presence on the cultural landscape. In addition to his work at the Birmingham Repertory Theatre, Simpson has since gone on to direct a variety of other productions over the years. These include plays such as ASMS at the Lyric Theatre in London and Romeo and Juliet at the Old Vic Theatre, as well as television series such as Holby City and Eastenders. Throughout his career, Simpson has been highly commended for his directorial work within the theatre industry. In 1988, he was awarded the Order of the British Empire for his contributions to the arts and in 2019, he was the recipient of the Arts Council Leadership Award for his achievements in the field of theatre direction. He is also a prolific writer and has published several books on his works, including his autobiographical tome, "My Life in the Theatre". As of 2020, Simpson continues to work as a respected and celebrated director within the theatre industry. Throughout his long career, he has helped bring forward the importance of theatres across the UK and provided a great contribution to the theatre landscape.

Ferdinand Johann Adam von Pernau (1685-1750) was a Prussian military officer from Prussia’s former Monastic State, who rose to prominence in the Prussian Army during the War of the Spanish Succession (1701-1714). Born in then-Prussian territory, Pernau was raised in a military family, and quickly rose through the ranks of the Prussian military framework. He was involved in most of Prussia’s engagements during this period and was influential in development many administrative regulations in the Prussian Army. In 1716 he was named Major General of the Prussian Army and was appointed to oversee strategic planning. He also served as adjutant to the Prussian Soldier, Frederick Wilhelm I. This gave him considerable influence in military circles, and his military innovations and strategic plan were a great part of Prussian success during the War of the Spanish Succession. He was also a prolific writer, publishing on a variety of military and administrative topics for the Prussian Army. After the War of the Spanish Succession, Pernau blossomed as a military tactician and theorist. He published several works on military topics, such as “Passionate Enemy – A Dialogue on Military Affairs” in 1721. His writings and adaptations of the European military model were read and appreciated far outside of Prussia’s boundaries, and many European countries consulted his works while reforming their own military systems. In 1719 Pernau was appointed Field Marschall and made in 1730 a Count of the empire. Pernau was a devout Lutheran and deeply involved in Prussia’s reform of administration and other public services, including public education. Pernau was instrumental in the development of contemporary Prussia’s administrative and bureaucratic structure. At the outbreak of the War of the Austrian Succession, Pernau was recalled to the Prussian army and served under the command of King Frederick II during the campaign in Silesia from 1744-1745. He also played a key role in the negotiations of the Treaty of Dresden, signed in 1745. This treaty transferred Silesia to Prussia and was a crucial victory for the Prussian state. After the Treaty of Dresden, Pernau returned to Berlin and was made an Armaments Councilor in 1749. On October 9, 1750, he passed away due to a sudden stroke. This ended an influential career in Prussia's military, which helped shape the Prussian Army during the 18th century. Today, his work is still considered influential and renowned in military, administrative and political circles.

New Jersey Route 183 is a 3.37-mile-long (5.42 km) state highway located in Salem and Cumberland counties in New Jersey, United States. The route runs from an intersection with U.S. Route 40 (US 40) in Upper Pittsgrove Township to an intersection with New Jersey Route 77 in Pittsgrove Township. Route 183 was designated as part of the 1927 New Jersey state highway renumbering. The route was maintained by the Pennsylvania Department of Highways until it was included as part of the state highway system in 1945. The route runs through mostly rural areas, serving mostly local traffic. Route 183 begins at an intersection with US 40 in Upper Pittsgrove Township. From here, the route heads northward, passing by a gas station. Route 183 then intersects Whitesville Road and turns to the northwest, entering Pittsgrove Township. In Pittsgrove, the route passes through forests before intersecting BR454 (Cedars Road). The route then continues for another 2 miles (3.2 km) before ending at an intersection with NJ 77 in Pittsgrove Township. Route 183 is an undivided two-lane road for its entire length and carries an annual average daily traffic (AADT) of 7,800 vehicles. No route direction is signed along the entirety of Route 183. The entirety of Route 183 is part of the National Highway System, a network of roads important to the nation's economy, mobility, and defense.
