As part of this system, Route 183 is subject to intensity restrictions imposed by the New Jersey Department of Transportation (NJDOT). The New Jersey Department of Transportation is planning to reconstruct the westernmost 2.2 miles (3.5 km) of Route 183 from the US 40 intersection to NJ 77 in 2020. As part of the project, the road will be widened from its current two-lane width to a four-lane road with a center left-turn lane. The project is expected to be completed sometime during 2021. Overall, Route 183 is an important highway in Cumberland and Salem counties, serving local traffic and connecting Upper Pittsgrove and Pittsgrove Townships. The highway has been in existence since the 1927 state highway renumbering and will be widened and reconfigured in 2020-2021 to improve travel along the route.

Shchuchyn (Belorussian: Шчучын) is a small town located in the Grodno Region of Belarus. It is situated at the junction of the Zapadnya Dvina and the Muchaviec Rivers. As of 2019, Shchuchyn had a population of 9, 142. The first written mention of Shchuchyn dates back to 1437. The town was built on the site of an old settlement of Slavic tribes, which was destroyed by the Mongol invasion of 1241. During the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, Shchuchyn was part of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania. In 1793 the town was annexed by the Russian Empire and integrated into the Grodno district. Shchuchyn is the birthplace of prominent Belarusian writer and journalist Vatslav Nisted. He was born here in 1895. The most outstanding sites in Shchuchyn are its churches. The Church of Holy Trinity is the oldest in the town, founded in the 16th century. It is a two-storeyed building with a five-sided bell tower and two layers of large warm-coloured walls. The Church of St. Nicholas is also of considerable age. It is a small wooden structure with a decorated gable and bright gilded roof. It is important in the architecture of Belarus. Shchuchyn is the administrative centre of the Shchuchyn District, which is also known for its mineral springs. Petrushviniec and Droubiniec are renowned resorts in the area. There are a variety of historical monuments in the district, most notable of which is a mausoleum dedicated to Polish soldiers who perished in the War of 1920. Shchuchyn is an important transport hub in Belarus. It is connected to Grodno by both railway and road. The M10 motorway runs through the town, connecting it to cities like Hrodna, Vilnius, and Minsk. Additionally, it is also home to Shchuchyn Airport, which is served by several domestic and international carriers. Shchuchyn is a relatively small but important town in Belarus. It has a rich history and culture, which attracts visitors from all over the world. The town's proximity to a variety of natural attractions, historical sites and excellent transportation make it a great place to explore, enjoy the local culture and relax.

Umberto Puppini (born February 19, 1951, San Giovanni, Tuscany, Italy) is an Italian architect, urbanist and academic. He studied architecture at the University of Florence and began his professional career in 1975. During this period he collaborated with notable Italian architects such as Italo Gamberini and Umberto Riva. In the following years, he moved to Switzerland and the United States, where he worked in various cities, including Zurich and New Orleans. Throughout his career, Umberto Puppini has focused on modern and contemporary architecture, environmental design, urban regeneration, and the preservation of historical monuments. He is an award-winning architect, most notably receiving the Carli Medal from the Italian Association of Architects in 1987. In the 1980s, Puppini returned to Italy, where he set up his own architecture firm, Umberto Puppini e Associati (UPA). This allowed him to work on various public and private projects, including a number of museums and urban regeneration projects. He also contributed to the design of Reggio Emilia's Teatro Verdi, a concert hall and theater. In addition to his architectural activities, Umberto Puppini is a well-known professor at the University of Florence. As a distinguished academic, he has been awarded the Order of Academic Palms by the Italian Ministry of Education and has taught in several European universities. Umberto Puppini is a firm believer in the importance of social and environmental sustainability, emphasizing these elements in his architectural projects. His commitment to urban regeneration and preservation has earned him international recognition, allowing him to impact young Italian architects and inspire new generations of creators. He is actively working in architecture and urbanism, taking on projects related to public urban spaces, green areas and social housing. He is also actively publishing, researching and exploring various architectural trends, and he is a believer in the importance of public consultation for urban renewal and the recovery of deteriorated historical sites.

Fred Lillywhite (1813-1884) was an English cricketer, cricket writer and scorer. He was a contemporary of the great players of his time such as William Clarke, James Lillywhite and Tom Marsden. Born in Little Baddow, Essex in 1813, Fred was the fourth son of Henry Lillywhite, who was an established professional player. As a young man he followed in his father's footsteps, becoming a professional player in 1838 when he joined Surrey's County Cricket Club. Lillywhite was an allrounder, being a useful batsman and medium-pace bowler. However, it was his career as a cricket writer and scorer that made him famous. In 1848, Lillywhite published his "Guide to the Game of Cricket," the first reference book of cricketing rules. This book was well-received, and Lillywhite was widely acknowledged as the first "expert" on cricket, often consulted by fellow cricketers. In 1851, Lillywhite, with help from other players, founded "The Players Scoring Book," the first standardized scoring book for cricket matches. Each match was recorded in the book and calculated for points. This systematic approach makes Lillywhite not only a great cricketer, but also an innovator in the sport's history. Lillywhite wrote several other books on cricket over the years, including "Illustrations of the Fast and Loose Theory of Cricket" (1845); "The Cricket Companion" (1849); and "To the Good Conduct of the Match" (1860). All of his books remain available today and continue to educate a new generation of cricket enthusiasts. Lillywhite died in 1884. He had a significant influence on the sport, through his writing, scoring and playing. He was also a key figure in introducing professional cricket, helping to establish the structure on which cricket continues to be played today.

Vincent Misiano is an American director, writer and producer. He is known for his work in television, including crime drama, documentaries, soap operas and reality shows. Misiano was born and raised in Eastchester, New York. He attended Eastchester High School where he was active in drama, taking part in stage plays and competing in regionals. He went on to study film and television at New Jersey City University, with his first professional experience on a television show while still in college. Misiano's first directing experience was on the crime drama show Murder One in 1996. He worked as a director on the series for its entire three-season run. After Murder One, Misiano worked as either a director, writer or producer on a variety of different shows. These include the courtroom drama J.A.G, the crime drama The District, and the police drama Law and Order: Special Victims Unit. Misiano’s other credits include directing for the ABC soap opera Port Charles, producing the ESPN reality show Battle of the Gridiron Stars, and writing and producing the documentary series Cold Case Files. His work on Cold Case Files earned him a Primetime Emmy Award in 2004. Misiano’s most recent credits include directing episodes of USA Network's White Collar and FX's Justified. He is also set to serve as an executive producer on the crime drama show Requital, which will air on CBS in 2016. Misiano is praised by his peers and fans alike as an incredibly talented director and producer. His work is known for its realism, authenticity and its ability to draw viewers in and make them feel connected to the story. Misiano’s continued success has inspired many others to pursue a career in the television industry.

Eduardo Kac (born 1962) is a Brazilian artist and professor at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. Kac has gained an international reputation for his pioneering work in telepresence, biotelematic art, and transgenic art, including his widely acclaimed works "GFP Bunny" (2000)—the first transgenic artwork, Alba (2000)—a gfp bunny, and Genesis (1999)—a computer-generated artificial life form. Kac's work has attracted much critical attention in the arts and sciences, being featured in more than one thousand articles, and cited in books on biotechnology and art. Kac was born in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, and graduated from the University of Paris VIII with a degree in philosophy in 1985. He went on to pursue the MFA in Studio Art at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago (SAIC) in 1988. Kac has since obtained an MFA in Electronic Visualization from the University of Illinois at Chicago, and a DFA in Computing Arts from Université Paris 8. Kac is most recognized for his work in bio art and robotics. His Bio Art utilizes living organisms in installations, performances, and other new media forms. Kac is celebrated for his pioneering role in the transgenic art movement and is the creator of Alba, the world's first transgenic bunny. Kac's art also investigates the field of telepresence, the use of robotics and communication technologies to blur the boundaries between physical and virtual space. He is the creator of the robotic installation “Teleporting an Unknown State”, the telerobotic installation “Garden Concentrate” and has used interactive telepresence robots in artworks such as LoveBots, Couple of Lovers, and Parsimoniosus. Kac’s art is presented in numerous solo and group exhibitions, such as Documenta 11, the 24th Bienal de São Paulo, and the 43rd Venice Biennale. He has received awards such as the Alape Foundation (2003), the B.Z. Ammon Award (2005), and the 9th Annual Award for Excellence in Electronic Art (2006). In 2019, Kac was awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship. Kac's works express the contemporary social, political, and scientific issues of today, and they often serve as provocative critiques of current ethical debates surrounding technology use and progress. His art illuminates the difficulties of identity construction and negotiation in the age of digital media networks and global communication. Kac’s works can also be found in public and private collections of major institutions around the world, including the Centre Pompidou, the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Institute for Electronic Arts in Alfred, New York, and the ARoS Aarhus Kunstmuseum in Denmark.

Jim Otvos (born May 25, 1967) is an American entrepreneur and venture capitalist best known for founding and managing several venture capital funds, including Mayfield Fund, Onset Ventures, and Draper Fisher Jurvetson. He is also the founder and former CEO of PortablePeople.com, an online job search site. Otvos was born in San Francisco, California to Hungarian parents. After graduating from Menlo School in Atherton, California, he attended the University of California, Berkeley where he studied engineering and economics. After graduating, he went to work for a San Francisco-based venture capital firm. It was during this time that he developed an interest in venture capital and entrepreneurship. In 1995, he founded his first venture capital firm, Mayfield Fund, which specialized in early stage technology investments. The fund grew to be one of the leading VC firms in the Silicon Valley with investments in numerous high tech companies, including Hotmail and Netflix. Otvos then co-founded Onset Ventures in 1999 and Draper Fisher Jurvetson in 2000. In 2003, Otvos founded PortablePeople.com, an online job search site that allowed users to more easily search for jobs. The company rapidly gained a following and was bought by Indeed in 2007. In 2007, Otvos co-founded Luxury Retreats International, Inc. (LRI), a vacation rental company specializing in high-end, luxurious vacation homes. The company has properties in North America, Europe, Central America, and the Caribbean. Throughout his career, Otvos has received numerous awards and accolades for his technology investments and entrepreneurial endeavors. He was named one of the Top 25 Venture Investors by Forbes Magazine in 2012, and has twice been a member of the Forbes Midas List, which recognizes the best venture capital investors in the world. In 2013, he was named a Fellow for the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation’s Entrepreneurial Leaders for Global Competitiveness program, which honors individuals for making a positive impact on global economic competitiveness. Today, Otvos resides in the San Francisco Bay Area where he continues to work as a venture capitalist and mentor to aspiring entrepreneurs. He is also a board member of the American Hungarian Foundation.

Doktor und Apotheker, commonly referred to as D&A, is a healthcare-related business in Germany, Austria, Liechtenstein and Switzerland. Founded in 1980, it is a network of doctors and pharmacists and provides services in various areas of healthcare. The company was founded by a group of physicians and pharmacists in Stuttgart, Germany. They saw the need for a comprehensive health care system and decided to establish a network that could offer services of both clinics and pharmacies. They quickly developed a reputation for high quality, comprehensive health care. Today, D&A is one of the largest and most successful healthcare providers in Germany. It is made up of more than 3,400 doctors and pharmacies in Germany, Austria, Liechtenstein, and Switzerland. It offers a wide range of services including primary health care, preventive healthcare, specialist care, and pharmaceutical care. As a network, it also offers patient advocacy and assistance with referrals. D&A also offers a variety of other services such as laboratory tests, imaging, alternativ medicine, and health insurance. D&A’s range of services is designed to meet all of its customers’ needs, from individuals to entire family units. It has become a one-stop shop for health care, providing modern and holistic care. To ensure that customers stay up to date with the latest medical developments, D&A also invests in research and development, such as its development of a mobile doctor’s office known as the “MediBus”. This mobile doctor’s office brings medical care directly to the streets and serves as an easily accessible alternative for those in need of medical care. D&A’s commitment to quality and service shows in its commitment to customer satisfaction. The company’s customer-focused approach and transparent pricing system are what set it apart from other providers. It also offers free doctor consultations, 24-hour phone and online support, and extended health and wellness services. D&A is an essential part of the German healthcare system and provides innovative, comprehensive services to its customers. Its mission is to provide the highest quality healthcare services at affordable prices. This mission is achieved through a commitment to quality, transparency, technology, and people.

Con Jones (born 25 May 1975) is an Australian entrepreneur and philanthropist. He is best known as the founder of Global Corporation, a multinational enterprise with holdings in renewable energy, banking and real estate. Born in the small country town of Boorowa in New South Wales, Con was a visionary entrepreneur from a young age. After completing his Bachelor of Science at the University of Sydney, he began to realise his dreams of founding and leading his own business. In 1998, he founded Global Corporation and established its headquarters in Sydney. Since its establishment, Global Corporation has grown to become one of the largest and most successful companies in Asia-Pacific, with a market capitalisation of over $1 billion. As of 2020, Global Corporation has investments in renewable energy, banking and real estate, particularly in the Pacific region. Apart from his business achievements, Con is highly regarded for his charitable contributions. In 2009, he founded the Global Foundation, a non-profit organisation focused on providing support and access to education for disadvantaged people around the world. The organisation has achieved great success, providing over $150 million in support to date. Con has been widely recognised for his achievements and contributions to the community. In 2019, he was awarded an honorary degree from the University of Sydney in recognition of his philanthropic work. In 2020, he was named one of the ‘100 Most Influential People in the World’ by Time magazine. As a self-made entrepreneur and philanthropist, Con Jones is an inspiring figure who has succeeded in both business and charity, leaving a lasting legacy on the world.

Internal wave, also known as internal Tide, is a gravity wave generated within a fluid medium and composed of regions of higher and lower density. Such waves are generally created by variations in temperature, salinity, and/or background flow. Because of their intrinsic nature, they act as a means of energy propagation and transformation within the ocean, atmosphere, and other bodies of water. History The earliest evidence of the internal wave's existence comes from the 19th century astronomer William Rutter Dawes and his experiments with sound in water. His work demonstrated that the sound would travel in a wave-like pattern and pass through layers of higher and lower density water. This eventually led scientists to believe that such waves could propagate through ocean waters. In 1851, the Austrian physicist Christian Ludwig von Lützen discovered internal waves through photographic observations in the Bay of Naples and Dublin. His photographs, which graphically illustrated the processes of refraction, reflection and interference, were the first observations of internal wave processes. Dynamics Internal waves are generated by changes in either the density of a fluid medium (density-driven) or by variations in the background flow (state-flow-driven). Density-driven internal waves can be created as a result of thermal or salinity stratification, where the medium consists of regions of different densities due to a decrease or increase in temperature or salinity. On the other hand, state-flow-driven internal waves are generated by the presence of an external force or by a variation in the pressure exerted on the system by an external agent. The nature of an internal wave depends on the wavelength, amplitude, and frequency of the wave. Wavelength determines the amount of energy associated with a given wave while the amplitude determines how far into a fluid medium the wave penetrates; frequencies between 0.001 and 10 Hz are typically associated with internal waves. The largest internal waves are often observed in the world's oceans and can extend a length of over 400 kilometers. Effects Internal waves can affect various natural phenomena at different scales. At the local scale, internal waves can influence the properties of a body of water, such as its temperature and salinity, thus affecting its chemical and biological composition. At the regional scale, these waves can trigger powerful currents known as the Equatorial Undercurrent (EUC) which circulate throughout the tropical and subtropical regions of the world. At the global scale, internal waves are capable of affecting the ocean-atmosphere boundary. This boundary is the interface between air and water which directly influences global climate patterns and weather. Particularly, internal waves can alter atmospheric wind patterns, as well as heat transport and the distribution of precipitation in the atmosphere. Additionally, internal waves have the ability to redistribute energy from the lower to the upper layers of the ocean, thereby playing a role in the world's climate by affecting its thermohaline circulation. Conclusion Internal waves, whether density- or state-flow-driven, are a unique type of gravity wave which propagate within a density stratified medium. Such waves possess various effects at different scales, ranging from local sensory changes to larger-scale interactions such as wind patterns. Understanding the dynamics and properties of internal waves can provide valuable insight into the processes occurring in the atmosphere and ocean, ultimately providing a better understanding of the climate system.

2013 African Volleyball Clubs Champions Championship was the fifth edition of the competition and organised by the African Volleyball Confederation (CAVB). The event was held from 19 to 26 October 2013, in Alexandria, Egypt, with the arenas of Borg El Arab Stadium and Smouha Club hosting matches. A total of 10 teams competed for the title, including reigning champion Al Ahly of Egypt and runner-up Ahly Tripoli of Libya. The tournament followed the classic round-robin system where teams had to compete against each other to gain points. Al Ahly won all seven of their matches, claiming the title for the second consecutive time with a maximum 21 points. The runner-up, Zamalek from Egypt, obtained 19 points. Zamalek, Al Ahly Tripoli, and Kadiogo from Burkina Faso also qualified for the 2014 Men's African Volleyball Club Championship. The competition not only determined the African champions, but also served as a subzonal qualification for the 2014 FIVB Volleyball Men's Club World Championship, with Al Ahly, the champions, and Zamalek, the runner-up, representing the Africa zone. The Best Server was Shabat El Batsh of Al Ahly, while the Best Spiker was Ahmed Shafik of Al Ahly. Hani Ramsis, also of Al Ahly, was the Best Receiver, and Mohamed Tarek, of Zamalek, was the Best Setter. The Best Libero went to Mahmoud Mohammad of Zamalek. Ahmed Samir of Al Ahly was named the Most Valuable Player. The tournament, along with other competitions such as the CAVB African Volleyball Championship and Men's African Volleyball Championship, has helped to promote the development of volleyball in Africa. The 2013 event in Alexandria, Egypt was a major success, with impressive performances from many of the teams and athletes.

Nel Erasmus is a South African artist, designer and entrepreneur, best known for his public art installations, performing art and video projects. He has established himself as a prominent figure in the art world through innovative projects, workshops and participation in art exhibitions around the world. Erasmus was born in Johannesburg and raised in Cape Town, South Africa. He studied fine arts and graphic design at Stellenbosch University and received an honorary Doctorate in Fine Arts from the University of Pretoria, South Africa in 2017. During his career, he has produced compelling artwork and installations in numerous countries, including South Africa, the United States, India, Argentina, France and Spain. Erasmus’ public art installations often combine sculpture, video, digital media and sound. He is the founder and creative director of the Bold People’s Art Movement in South Africa, which encourages public interaction and participation in art. Through the Movement, he has organised art events and exhibitions around South Africa, and has toured global festivals and galleries with his work. Erasmus’ work explores identity, heritage, social and political issues, making a powerful statement and reaching audiences around the world. He has been an active advocate and mentor for emerging artists in South Africa, helping to develop their careers. He also established an online platform connecting creatives and helping to promote their work and talent. In 2015, Erasmus won the Investec Cape Town Art Fair Prize for African Emerging Artist, cementing his place in the local and international art worlds. He has been featured in numerous publications, including Forbes, Artsy and the Sunday Times. Erasmus has become a notable figure in art, inspiring and influencing South African creatives through his impactful artwork, activism and dynamic projects. He continues to build his career as an artist, designer and entrepreneur, producing innovative art and making a lasting contribution to the South African art scene.

Siegfried Haag (born 1891 in Dornau, Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany) was an internationally renowned cuckoo clock designer and manufacturer. He is credited with inventing the modern cuckoo clock in 1951, which enabled mass-production of the clocks. Haag worked as a clock maker in the German city of Heidelberg before setting up his own company in 1921 in the city of Schramberg. He first focused on creating Baumgarten clocks, a form of wall clock with a spring descends and subsequently falls down again at regular intervals, striking a little hammer against the bell. In 1951, Siegfried devised a way to mass-produce cuckoo clocks and made them affordable to most households. Together with his sons, Haag also produced an intricately designed chalet-style clock, then the most popular form of cuckoo clock for Germany and other European countries. The design proved hugely successful and remains popular to this day. Haag was a brilliant engineer who cared a great deal about the quality and precision of his clocks. He was the first to adopt the modern technology of CNC (Computer numerical control) milling to produce cuckoo clock parts. He routinely tested clocks for fault-freeness, ensuring that customers received the best product. With his sons, Siegfried established seven international service centers for local customers as well as customers from around the world. The first service center was established in Heidelberg in 1966, and other service centers were set up in Switzerland, Japan, Canada, the United States and Australia. Siegfried Haag passed away on February 24, 2008 at the age of 117, leaving behind an impressive legacy of cuckoo clock designs, one that has contributed greatly to the cuckoo clock industry today. His clocks are now held in many public and private collections as well as being revered as highly sought after pieces amongst collectors.

Deborah Pratt (born Deborah Lee Howell; August 10, 1958) is an American film and television producer, writer, director, and actress. Pratt was born in San Francisco, California. She is an alumna of the University of California, Berkeley, where she earned a degree in clinical psychology. Pratt began her career in entertainment as a dancer, choreographer, and actress. She has appeared in numerous television shows, movies, and music videos, including a recurring role on Quantum Leap as Alia, the sister of Dr. Sam Beckett. After gaining recognition as an actress, Pratt began writing and directing. In 1988, Pratt and actor/director Ray Manzarek created Quantum Leap Productions and began producing television shows and feature films. They produced several television series and one feature film, The Twilight Zone: Rod Serling's Lost Classics, for which she won an Emmy for Outstanding Writing. Pratt has written and directed multiple television series and television movies. The television series she created, The Invisible Man, starred Vincent Ventresca, W. Morgan Sheppard, and Kim Duffy. Pratt wrote and produced Tale Spinners for TNT, a four-part original series that was adapted from Ray Bradbury's stories. In 2008, Pratt wrote and produced a four-hour documentary, Ray Bradbury: An American Icon, for PBS. Pratt has received numerous awards for her work in television and film, including an Emmy, a Golden Lion Award for her work on the feature film Quantum Leap, the Trinity Award for Best American Television Movie, and the Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy & Horror Films Award for Best Television Special for her work on the television movie, Return to the Land of the Lost. Pratt is a member of Women in Film, the Alliance of Women Directors, and the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences. She is also a co-founder of the Women in View On Screen Film Festival, which is held annually in Los Angeles. Pratt is the author of two books, Music, The Brain, and Ecstasy: How Music Captures Our Imagination, and Making Miracles, a book of inspirational stories. She is a keynote lecturer and workshop presenter on creativity at universities and filmmaking conferences. Pratt also continues to act, coach actors, and consult on feature films and television shows.

Abdoulkader Cissé is a Cape Verdean football player who plays professionally in the Primeira Liga, the top tier of Portuguese football. He currently plays for Varzim S.C. as a defender. Cissé was born on 7 August 1987 in Praia, the capital of Cape Verde. After beginning his career with local side Boavista FC, he moved to Europe and had brief stints with ES Sétif and Portimonense S.C. in Algeria and Portugal respectively. Cissé moved to the Primeira Liga with Varzim S.C in 2010, and became a regular in the team's defence. His performances for the northern side saw him called up to the Cape Verde national side for two friendlies against Algeria and Tunisia in 2011. He also represented his nation at the 2013 and 2015 African Cup of Nations tournaments. During his time with Varzim, Cissé helped the side achieve consecutive promotions from the Liga de Honra in 2011-12 to the Primeira Liga in 2013-14. He was also part of the team that secured the club’s best-ever performance in the Primeira Liga, finishing 12th in 2015-16. Cissé is known for his speed, technique and attacking spirit when playing out of defence. Despite his physicality and aggressive reputation, he has a high disciplinary record, having only been shown the red card on one occasion in his career so far. Off the pitch, Cissé is a highly respected figure among his team mates and the wider Cape Verdean community. He devotes much of his free time to helping vulnerable children in his homeland, and is renowned for his humility and honesty in all facets of his life.

23327 Luchernandez is a minor planet orbiting within the inner Solar System. It was discovered on December 2, 1997 by David Lee and Carlo J. Lacerna at the University of Philippines Los Baños (UPLB) Observatory in Laguna, Philippines. Its provisional designation was 1997 XV12. The object was eventually named after UPLB's Dr. Lucerna Hernandez, an active researcher in the field of astronomy. She has researched a variety of astronomical objects, from asteroids to comets, both from ground-based and space-based observatories. 23327 Luchernandez has an approximate diameter of 5.9 kilometers and is classified as a main belt asteroid. It has a relatively low albedo of 0.07, indicating that it is a darker-than-average asteroid made of a composition more similar to carbonaceous chondrites than to stony meteorites. Based on its orbital parameters, 23327 Luchernandez is classified as a near-Earth asteroid and the Sentry Risk Table assigns the highest Torino scale rating of 4 (meriting special attention) to its projected close approach to Earth in 2053. It has a relatively low inclination of 4.1º, semi-major axis of 2.556 AU, low eccentricity of 0.15, and a sidereal period of 1651.80 days. 23327 Luchernandez has been observed a total of 8 times over the span of its orbit. As it passed close to Earth three times over recent years, it was observed more closely than usual. In 2006 and 2009 its magnitude was as high as 13.7, allowing it to become the target of photometric observations. 23327 Luchernandez's observers hope that further understanding of its behavior will come with more accurate estimates of its mass. That, together with its relatively lower-than-average albedo, can provide valuable knowledge about asteroidal composition and its effects on climate change.

ASTERISC, an acronym for the Advanced Surgical Technology & Research Institute for Education, Science & Care, is an international non-profit organization that advances innovation in the field of surgery. Founded in 2001, ASTERISC is a global partnership of international surgeons and medical educators from more than fifty countries. Its members include surgeons, physicians, nurses, technicians and scientists from the medical, military and civil sectors. ASTERISC exists to create the global operating environment necessary to develop and maintain evidence-based surgical knowledge, improve clinical practice and outcomes, and train healthcare personnel to maintain the highest standards of patient care. The organization seeks to develop professional and research standards to deliver better patient care by utilizing the latest surgical technology. It also serves as a platform for collaboration and dialogue between professionals across the world. The organization focuses on four key goals, which are to facilitate research, education, networking and advocacy within the surgical realm. The ASTERISC membership serves to encourage international cooperation and coordination of research, improving access to information and clinical practices for members. Through ASTERISC, members have access to a variety of resources including professional development and continuing education opportunities, mentoring and research collaborations. In the area of research, ASTERISC awards grants annually and facilitates clinical trial research and collaborations with medical technology companies. The organization also issues statements, guidelines and best practices documentation to keep its members informed of the latest standards in patient safety and care. ASTERISC collaborates with educational institutions, medical societies and other related organizations, as well as individual surgeons, to promote high standards of education and training. It provides resources for a variety of educational activities, publishes a digital newsletter and organizes regional events, conferences and virtual workshops throughout the world. In terms of advocacy, ASTERISC seeks to support and represent the interests of its members to governments, related associations and decision-makers. The organization mobilizes networks of surgeons and healthcare personnel to advocate for the appropriate use of resources and healthcare services. The ultimate goal of ASTERISC is to ensure that quality, up-to-date information is readily available to its members, strive for further advancements in surgical technology, and work to make sure that professional standards are maintained throughout the medical world. In doing so, ASTERISC seeks to make a positive difference in patient care and safety by working to improve the quality of life of those receiving treatment.

Catenanuova is a comune (municipality) in the Province of Enna in the Italian island of Sicily. It is located in the middle of Sicily, about four miles from the city of Enna and about fifty-four miles from Palermo. The town was founded in 1861 and is home to about 2,395 people. Catenanuova is an agricultural community, primarily focusing on production and sale of sheep and goat products. Catenanuova is renowned in the province for its unique style of cheese, which is made with sheep's milk and is flavored with saffron. The sheep cheese is an important part of the economy and culture of Catenanuova. Catenanuova is also important in the Enna province due to its viticulture. The town is home to several wineries and vinicultural businesses, which produce sweet dessert wines, as well as dry, full-bodied reds. Wine is a big part of the local culture, with La Sfida del vino, an annual wine festival celebrating the area's local wines, being one of the most popular events in Catenanuova. Catenanuova is also home to several important Roman ruins. One of the best known is the ruins of a Roman villa, which date back to the 2nd century BC. The villa was built in the center of the town and is a popular tourist attraction due to its many mosaics and other features. Catenanuova is also known for its picturesque location. The municipality is situated at the foot of Monte Aetna and the comune stretches out to the valley of the river Simeto. The town is surrounded by green hills and mountains, making it a popular destination for tourists and hikers. Catenanuova is known as Città della tradizione, or Town of Tradition, due to its many cultural and culinary traditions. The town is home to the Museo del vino e della tradizione contadina, which offers historical exhibits and artifacts related to wine and farming in the area. Additionally, an annual attraction in Catenanuova is the Sagra della Trota, or Trout Festival, which is held every May and celebrates Catenanuova's special style of fish preparation. Overall, Catenanuova is a small but beautiful town tucked away in the hills of the Province of Enna. The town is renowned for its local cuisine and wine, as well as its important Roman ruins. Visitors will find Catenanuova to be both charming and interesting, and a great place to explore the region.

India Pagán is an independent Latinx singer, songwriter and producer whose music combines equal parts soul, funk, pop and rock. From her hometown of Manhattan Beach, California, Pagán has had her music described by many as stylish, unique, and alluring. She released her debut EP, Free to Fly, in 2017, and has gone on to write songs for multi-platinum and Grammy-winning artists, including Christina Aguilera, Jennifer Lopez, Pitbull, and others. Music career At the start of her career, Pagán released the single "L-O-V-E", produced by multi-platinum music producer Damon Thomas of The Underdogs. She then released her debut EP. Free to Fly. The lead single, "Bring You Down", co-written with Damon Thomas, garnered over 2 million streams on Spotify. Her second single, "Say You Love Me", was released on the heels of her tour opening for international artist, Natalia Lafourcade. In the summer of 2018, Pagán was featured at SXSW and had the opportunity to perform on ABC's hit show, Good Morning America. She was also the featured artist at CMJ Music Festival in October. Most recently, Pagán co-wrote and produced Jennifer Lopez' single, “Living My Life," released as a part of Lopez' "Limitless" EP in 2019. She is currently working on her first full-length album, and her single "Autumn Nights" is also set to be released in 2019. In 2018, India Pagán was named the top songwriter of the year in Los Angeles by The Week Magazine, and one of the "9 Women Who Rock Los Angeles" by Architectural Digest. Discography Singles * L-O-V-E * Bring You Down * Say You Love Me * Autumn Nights EPs * Free to Fly (2017) Awards and nominations * 2018 Top Songwriter of the Year (Los Angeles) – The Week Magazine * 2018 9 Women Who Rock Los Angeles – Architectural Digest Magazine References External links * Official Website (https://www.indiapagan.com/) * Spotify (https://open.spotify.com/artist/3Q8WwduGEHQvuddJYGEMeD) * Apple Music (https://music.apple.com/us/artist/india-pagan/1040689230) * Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/indiapagan/) * Twitter (https://twitter.com/india_pagan)

King Salmon Airport (IATA: AKN, ICAO: PAKN, FAA LID: AKN) is a state-owned public airport located 3 miles south of the city of King Salmon, in the Bristol Bay Borough of the U.S. state of Alaska. It is one of two airports serving King Salmon, the other being Port Heiden Airport, 11 miles northeast of the city. King Salmon Airport is known for its diverse range of services including air taxi, commuter and cargo services, and general aviation activities including sightseeing. The airport's modern history can be traced to its origins as an aviation facility built by the U.S. Navy in 1942. Following World War II, the airstrip was ceded to the city of King Salmon which subsequently received federal funding to expand the facility's amenities. King Salmon Airport was the principal airport serving the city until the later formation of Port Heiden Airport in 1962. Today, King Salmon Airport is one of the busiest general aviation airports in the state of Alaska, serving an estimated 4,000 passengers and handling more than 300 aircraft operations per month. Along with regular flights from Alaska Airlines and Wright Air Service, the airport is also used for corporate jet services and charter operations. Among other aviation activities, King Salmon Airport also provides Skydiving services and operates a skiplane base. Infrastructure and facilities King Salmon Airport features two runways, which are serviced by a Unicom system enabling clear communication for pilots. The primary runway measures 5000ft in length and has been designated as a Regional Jet runway. Additionally, there is an asphalt paved runway measuring 3100ft in length, for use by general aviation aircraft. Aircraft instrument approach procedures at the airport include VOR/DME and GPS approaches, allowing for safe operation even during poor weather. Ground handling services at the airport include aircraft fueling, hangaring and parking, and aircraft maintenance and repair services. Other infrastructure and amenities include an air traffic control tower, terminal and office buildings, lighted taxiways and access roads. The airport terminal offers passport and other travel services, with wireless internet access throughout the facility. King Salmon Airport is also equipped with navigational aids and emergency services like firefighting and rescue. Like other airports in Alaska, King Salmon Airport is heavily dependent on federal funding from the FAA and other sources to keep up the infrastructure and services. In recent years, King Salmon Airport has become an important part of the tourism and commercial activity in the region. The airport is known for its wide range of recreational services such as sightseeing services and fly-out fishing trips to nearby rivers and lakes. External links * King Salmon Airport (http://www.dot.state.ak.us/fss/doc/airport/00/AKN.pdf) – Alaska Department of Transportation & Public Facilities * Airport diagram for King Salmon Airport (http://www.dot.state.ak.us/fss/diagrams/AKN.pdf) – from Alaska DOT&PF * Skydiving at the King Salmon Airport (https://www.skydiveking.com/) – S & R Enterprises

Cthulhu Rising is a horror novel by British author Graham McNeill, released in 2010, set in the Warhammer 40,000 universe in a pocket universe, the battle for Armageddon that was featured in the first novel of the series, First and Only. The novel is the first in the 2010 Black Library series of the same name. The novel follows the adventures of the space marines fighting against the forces of Chaos in the Armageddon Pocket Universe. The forces of Chaos are led by Sorcerer Lord Ignato Menschen, a Daemon Prince of Nurgle. The Grey Knights, led by Grand Master Justicar Alaric, race to stop him, as his plan involves the summoning of the powerful entity Cthulhu and unleashing it upon the universe. The novel opens with Alaric already in the grips of the daemonic incursion. He is joined by the Silver Wolves, a squad of space marines who are sent to provide reinforcements. After a few skirmishes, they come face to face with Ignato and Cthulhu. The daemon prince reveals that the summoning of the ancient entity is part of a larger plan to bring Nurgle's power to the Imperium. Cthulhu then rises from its slumber on the battlefield, unleashing its might upon the battle. The force of the impact is so powerful that many of the space marines are killed. Alaric and his forces are able to slow the advance of Cthulhu, and eventually kill it with an anti-daemonic device. The Grey Knights are victorious but at a great cost, as many of their number have been killed in the fighting. Despite this victory, the Imperium's forces realise they cannot beat the forces of Chaos alone. Alaric is forced to go against the Grey Knights oaths of secrecy and alert the rest of the Imperium to the danger. He is able to use the Argos Protocol, a distress signal sent to the Imperium's leaders, to let them know of the daemonic incursion. The novel ends with Imperial forces from the wider galaxy arriving to aide the embattled space marines in Armageddon. The novel sets up many of the events in the subsequent novels of the series where the forces of Chaos, as well as Cthulhu, are featured heavily. Cthulhu Rising was well received, garnering a great deal of praise for its excellent pacing, storytelling, and depiction of Warhammer 40K. It was seen as a strong return to form for McNeill who had previously written several novels set in the gaming universe. It is not just a great story however, but also the perfect illustration of the core themes of the Warhammer 40K setting. The fear, violence and heroism entwined in this novel make it one of the most memorable and gripping novels in the series.

Restless Heart: The Confessions of Saint Augustine is an autobiography written by Saint Augustine of Hippo around AD 397 – AD 400. It consists of 13 books, and was an influential work of Christian theology and Western philosophy. The work outlines Augustine's sinful youth and his conversion to Christianity. It is widely seen as the first Western autobiography ever written. The Confessions is divided into three parts. The first part details Augustine's wicked childhood and how he fell into sin. He speaks of the gods his family worshiped, and his education in spoken and written word. He speaks of his difficult relationship with his mother Monica and his indulgence in various earthly passions such as sex, gluttony, laziness and pride. The second part of the work is when Augustine is filled with guilt. He goes on to write about his conversion and how through prayer he is able to find peace in Christian faith. This is what he calls his 'restless heart'. He talks about his search for truth and faith, and largely ignores his earlier life. Lastly, Augustine speaks of the grace of God and the Catholic church. He talks about how his faith has changed his life and how he has been able to find peace and redemption by communing with God. He also speaks of his unyielding faith in the divine will of God. In the last chapter of the book, Augustine expresses his hope for the future of the church. The Confessions has been seen as an influential work of Christian theology, and it is credited with playing an important role in the development of Western thought. It has had an immense impact on Christianity, since it outlines Augustine’s sinful youth and his journey towards redemption. It is often seen as laying the foundation of subsequent Christian theology and philosophy. The Confessions of Saint Augustine continues to be an important work today. Its timeless theme of redemption and faith in God’s plan still speaks to readers today, and it has remained a popular source of inspiration and an ode to finding peace of mind in one’s faith.

Laila Freivalds (1942 - ) is a Latvian politician and lawyer who served as the 17th Prime Minister of the Republic of Latvia from 2004 to 2007. She was the first female Prime Minister of Latvia. Freivalds was born in Dobele in 1942 and was educated at the School of Law, University of Latvia. She graduated in 1967 with a law degree. She started her career as a judge and lawyer working as a civil cases judge at the Supreme Court of the USSR in Moscow and subsequently in Rīga. She held a number of lawyer and judicial positions in Latvia before being appointed as the Prime Minister of Latvia on 29 July 2004. Although a member of the Social Democratic Workers' Party, Freivalds formed a coalition with the right-wing Latvian Way and Latvia's First Party in her first cabinet. During her time as the Prime Minister, she focused on the economic situations of Latvia, especially the development of small and medium-sized businesses. She also sought to strengthen ties with Latvia's European Union and NATO partners, and to foster good relations with neighboring countries. In December 2006, Freivalds was forced to resign from her post following a decision of the Latvian parliament to allow US troops to be stationed in the country as part of a NATO peacekeeping effort. Freivalds was heavily criticized for her handling of the US military presence in Latvia, and for her lack of preparedness for NATO accession. Since 2007, Freivalds has held a number of positions in the European Parliament, the Council of Europe, and in the UN Human Rights Council. She was a visiting professor at the International Media Center of Stockholm University from 2011 to 2012 and is a Distinguished Associate of the Carnegie Council for Ethics in International Affairs. She currently serves on the Board of the Baltic-American Freedom Foundation. Freivalds has been honored with a number of national and international awards in recognition of her public service. In 1998 she was awarded the Order of Three Stars, the highest domestic order of the Latvian Republic and in 2006 she was awarded the Manfred Wörner Medal in honour of her work in the field of European defence and security. Throughout her career, Freivalds has been an outspoken advocate for gender equality and the role of women in politics, as well as for the development of sustainable democracy in Eastern Europe. Her work, dedication and commitment to Latvia remain an inspiration to many.

D.A. Fishman (b. 1977) is an American entrepreneur notable for founding and managing large-scale technology projects. Fishman began his career in the tech industry with a degree in computer science from the University of Pennsylvania. He then landed jobs as an early software engineer and tech consultant in a variety of industries, with notable stints as a staff engineer at Oracle, Microsoft, and Amazon. In 2006, Fishman launched his own firm specializing in the development of innovative software solutions. His brainchild was a cloud-based software application called "CloudLogic," which aimed to simplify the storage, retrieval and analysis of customer data. Through his company, he helped lead the successful customer-management projects of many Fortune 500 companies, such as IBM and Bank of America. In 2009, Fishman's tech entrepreneurship efforts expanded to encompass the world of eCommerce when he launched BlueRidgeco, a national eCommerce platform. The platform saw significant success, and was purchased by an international media site in 2011 for an undisclosed seven-figure sum. Following this success, Fishman continued to pursue technology projects and started a new venture in 2017, DigiLeaders. Through DigiLeaders, Fishman has been working to help startups and small businesses build their customer base and maximize their impact through digital marketing and customer data insights. By 2019, Fishman had achieved notable success in the tech industry. He had pioneered multiple customer service and data management solutions, two of which were acquired by larger companies. In 2020, he was named to the Business Insider list of "30 Inspiring Tech Entrepreneurs Making a Difference". As for his personal life, Fishman spends his free time with his family: wife Lorraine and children Ben, Emily, and Sarah. He is an avid reader, particularly of classic literature and Harry Potter novels, and enjoys launching model rockets. He and his family currently reside in the Washington DC area.

The Villanovan culture was an early Iron Age culture of Early Central and Northern Italy. It was the first group of people to use iron technology in the region, and its rise marked the beginning of the Iron Age in Italy. They are believed to have been an indigenous group of peoples, as they precede the arrival of the more well-known Etruscans in the region by several centuries. Very little is known of the Villanovan culture, but the few artifacts that have survived from this period paint a vivid story of the unique culture of the Villanovans and their place in early European history. The Villanovans thrived in the Po River Valley in modern-day northern Italy. Their settlements were a mixture between a proto-urban culture and a more rural lifestyle of agricultural production, and they had a complex system of social organization. Burials have been found in which the Villanovans buried their dead under 4 layers of soil, the 4th of which was believed to contain the ashes of the deceased. The Villanovans had developed a unique style of pottery that differentiated them from the other Iron Age cultures of the region. They decorated their vases with intricate incision and combed patterns, and used geometric designs to decorate other vessels. They were also skilled metalworkers and were the first people to use iron in the region. They produced elaborate bronze scabbards for swords and axes and other items like wine-making vessels, zincite ornaments, and bronze sheets decorated with gold. The Villanovans seem to have been a peaceful society, as their artifacts reveal very little evidence of war. There is evidence that some of their settlements may have been burned or destroyed, but there is no clear way to tell who burned them. The Villanovans appear to have been absorbed or displaced by the Etruscans, who began to move into the region in the 8th century BCE. The Etruscans inherited many of the Villanovans’ artistic styles and techniques, as well as their pottery. It is likely that many of the Villanovans in the area were gradually assimilated into the Etruscan culture, effectively ending the Villanovan culture as it had been known. The legacy of the Villanovans remains an important part of Italian culture and history. Their unique art and metalworking techniques have been an influence on succeeding generations, and their influence can still be seen in modern Italian art and culture.

The Tribe of Dan (Hebrew: דָּן‎) was one of the Twelve Tribes of Israel. It is believed to be named after the grandson of Jacob and Leah. They were divided into two divisions, which became known as Danites and Danessites. The Tribe of Dan is mentioned in the Books of Numbers and Joshua. The Tribal Territory of Dan initially included the Eastern Shore of the Mediterranean Sea. This included the cities of Zorah, Timna, and its two associated cities, Dan, and Eltekeh. This area was later taken from the tribe of Dan and given to the tribe of Judah. The Tribe of Dan is associated with Judges chapter 18, in which the Danites are said to have gone against the commandment of God by stealing the shrine of the Micos and bringing it back to their home in Laish. This is said to have angered God, and He gave the Danites over to the Philistines. The Tribe of Dan is traditionally associated with ships. Their navy is said to have roamed the Mediterranean and traveled to far-away lands. Some believe that the Tribe of Dan was comprised of traders and merchants, while others believe they were skilled sailors. The Tribe of Dan is also associated with two Judges in the Bible: Samson and Eli. They both held the position of the High Priest and judge of the Israelites. Samson is said to have been chosen because of his strength and power. It is believed to have been his strength and courage that enabled him to fight and defeat the Philistines. Some believe that the Tribe of Dan was no longer politically strong after a civil war in the 7th century BC. It is believed that due to the lack of leadership and unity, the Tribe of Dan was broken away from the twelve tribes and did not regain its strength until the 12th century AD. Today, there are several Jewish organizations and communities that identify as the Tribe of Dan, bearing their name as a reminder of their connections to the ancient Israelites and their descendants. There are also Christian organizations that look to their shared faith as a reminder of their shared connection as Israelites, wherever they may be today.

The United States Post Office and Courthouse, located at the intersection of 5th Street and S. Denver Avenue in Tulsa, Oklahoma, is a historic building constructed in 1917. The courthouse is also known as the Tulsa County Courthouse. The building served as the main post office for the city of Tulsa until 1968 and is now listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The two-story building is constructed in a vernacular Neoclassical Revival style. The building features two courtyards and a central rising clock tower. It is made of red brick with stone details on the façade and is graced by a grandly scaled stoop at the main entrance of the building. The building is somewhat unique because it was designed to integrate public and private needs in one architectural design. The building has a strong historical and symbolic significance in the history of Tulsa. In addition to serving as the area post office and courthouse, the building has been utilized throughout the years for a variety of purposes. It was used as a venue for entertaining and educating the public, as well as for hosting civic events. From its inception, the building has been a gathering place for important announcements and symbolic symbols expressing community pride and aspirations. The United States Post Office and Courthouse is currently used as a U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma. Despite numerous changes throughout the years, the building still retains its original historical charm. It is an integral part of the civic center complex in the heart of downtown Tulsa, providing a sense of continuity and architectural unity to the surrounding area. Preservation has been an important factor in preserving the building's original character and maintaining its historical significance. To ensure the building's longevity, a comprehensive restoration project was undertaken in 1998 to restore its unique interior spaces, including the restoration of the building’s courtroom and circulation system. The United States Post Office and Courthouse continues to be an important landmark in the city of Tulsa and serves as a reminder of the city’s history and development. The building continues to play an important role in the civic identity of the city, serving as a symbolic representation of the city’s past, present, and future.

Šemsudin Gegić (born July 15, 1953) is a Bosnian film director, screenwriter and producer. He is considered to be one of the most important film directors in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Gegić was born in Sarajevo and attended secondary school in the city. During his school years, he was active in theatre and involved in several film projects. After finishing school in 1972, he went to study filmmaking in Zagreb. He graduated in 1976 and returned to Sarajevo that same year. Gegić is a founding member of the Sarajevo film collective "Uzupeće" (1979-present). The collective was known for making films for the foreign market, but also for its work on alternative film-making practices, such as short films and super-8 films. His first feature film, Our Neighbour, was released in 1982 and was acclaimed by the press. Throughout his film career, Gegić has received numerous awards for his work, including the East West Film Club Award for Best Southeast European Feature Film for his film Yugoslavia, which was released in 2002. He has also received the Heart of Sarajevo Award for his 2002 film Sonja and the Berlinale Special Mention Award in 2006 for his film Shape of Things to Come. Gegić is a well-respected director in Bosnia and Herzegovina and abroad. His films are lauded for their realism and often feature controversial topics. In addition to his work as a film director, Gegić has also been appointed as a guest lecturer at numerous universities across Europe. He has also served as a jury member at various international film festivals, including Cannes and Locarno. Throughout his career, Gegić has also been involved in several socially conscious initiatives and has been vocal about the need for greater representation in Bosnian film. In 2020, he took part in the Sarajevo Youth Film Festival, where he spoke about the power of filmmakers to influence social change. Gegić is considered to be one of the most important film directors in Bosnia and Herzegovina and continues to produce work that resonates with audiences around the world. His films display a deep understanding of Bosnian culture and a genuine commitment to pushing the boundaries of film-making.

John Almond (date of birth unknown – 28 May 1539) was an English martyr who was burned at the stake for heresy in Suffolk, England. He was a Protestant who stood up against the Roman Catholic Church during the English Reformation. Almond's exact early life is not known, but he was born sometime before 1539. His birthplace is traditionally said to be Norwich in Norfolk, but most likely his hometown was Hadleigh in Suffolk. The religious changes that occurred during Henry III's rule had a profound influence on Almond, who became part of the Protestant Reformation movement that sought to reform the Church of England. In 1538, around the time of the Six Articles of Faith, Almond publicly stood against the Church of Rome and declared his beliefs to be different from those in the Roman Catholic Church. He was arrested and taken to Hadleigh to answer for his actions. At his trial, he stood firm in his convictions, enraging the court and leading them to sentence him to be burned. Eventually, he was brought to Bury St Edmunds in Suffolk, where he was burned at the stake on 28 May 1539, becoming one of the earliest English martyrs of the Protestant Reformation. Almond was remembered as a devout and courageous martyr who stood against the Roman Catholic Church and the English government which upheld it. His steadfastness and unwavering faith in God earned him the admiration of many and he is remembered as a symbol of courage, faith, and commitment within the Protestant movement. His legacy even extended to the English Civil War, where he was remembered as a hero who stood for religious freedom. John Almond's sacrifice for the cause of Protestantism was remembered for years to come and he is remembered to this day as an important figure in the history of the English Reformation. Although few details are known about him, his courage and unwavering faith will forever be remembered as an example of devotion and inspiration to many.

Michel David-Weill (born December 10th, 1931) is a French businessman and banker. He is the former Chairman and Senior Partner of Lazard Frères et Cie, a leading financial advisory and asset management firm. He is also the former Chairman of Compagnie Financière Edmond de Rothschild and Honorary Chairman of Lazard LLC. David-Weill was born in Paris, France in 1931 to an industrialist family. He was educated at the Lycée Jean-Baptiste Say and then at the École Polytechnique and École des Mines in Paris. Michel served as a non-commissioned officer in the French army before joining Lazard in 1959. He served in various international positions within the firm until assuming the post of Chairman and Senior Partner at the firm’s Paris office in 1976. He was highly successful in the role, presiding over significant growth and expansion at the firm during his tenure. During this period, he also developed the firm’s leadership model by creating a management committee to collaborate on decision making. In 2000, David-Weill restructured the firm, creating Lazard LLC in the United States and selling a controlling interest in the French arm of Lazard to a group of investors led by Paris-based financier Michel Pebereau. David-Weill remained as Senior Partner at Lazard LLC until his retirement in 2005. He subsequently assumed the chairmanship of the Compagnie Financière Edmond de Rothschild and of Lazard LLC - a position he held until his retirement in 2015. Throughout his career, David-Weill has been an active member of organizations and groups relating to industry and business. He has been a member of the boards of public companies such as PSA Peugeot Citroen, Banca Nazionale del Lavoro and Banque Nationale de Paris. In addition, he is a member of such private clubs as the Club de Bâtonniers de France, the French-American Foundation, the Comité Colbert and the Cercle de l'Union Interalliée. In 2011, Michel David-Weill was appointed an Officer of the Legion of Honour in recognition of his remarkable career and contribution to business and finance. David-Weill lives in Paris and is married to Irene Wender with whom he has two children. He holds dual French and American citizenship.

Art Howe (born November 28, 1945) is an American former professional baseball manager and infielder. He managed the Houston Astros, Oakland Athletics and New York Mets of Major League Baseball (MLB). Born in Pittsfield, Massachusetts, Howe played as an infielder in MLB for nine seasons between 1974 and 1983, primarily with the Pittsburgh Pirates. During his playing career, Howe was known for his defensive play, leading MLB in assists by a second baseman in 1977. Howe served as a coach with the Pirates, Texas Rangers and Cleveland Indians before beginning his managerial career with the Astros in 1989. In the 1994 season, Howe was hired as the manager of the Oakland Athletics and led the team to two division titles in four years. He was hired as the manager of the Mets in 2003 but was let go after the 2004 season, making him the fourth manager in Mets history not to finish his contract. During his managerial career, Howe won 538 games as a manager and appeared in the MLB playoffs three times. In his retirement, Howe has gone back to do part-time consulting for the San Diego Padres and has done some broadcasting for MLB.com and Yankee broadcasts. Howe was inducted into the New York Mets Hall of Fame in August 2008. Howe is married to Donna and has four children (Christopher, Michael, Megan and Matthew). He also resides in Valencia, California. His son, Christopher, was a shortstop in the Mets' minor league system in 2004. Overall, Howe was renowned as a players' manager and was respected by players, coaches and the press during his career. He was partly known for utilizing relief pitchers often, a strategy that he adopted while playing and reinforced during his managerial career. After his retirement, Howe has offered different insight into the game to help and guide young players, coaches and managers. Art Howe was a respected manager who won 538 games during his managerial career. He left an impact on the players and coaches of the teams he managed and remains active in the game.

: Terisa Griffin (born 12 July 1958) is an American Jazz & Gospel singer-songwriter who, since her emergence in the mid-1980s, has become an iconic presence in the African American music scene. Born in Los Angeles, California, she grew up in a large, middle-class family listening to her mother’s records of Eartha Kitt and Nina Simone. In reverence to God, she devoted her life to Gospel music in her youth and later incorporated elements of jazz, soul, reggae and hip-hop. From a young age, she recognized her talent and by age 16 she had experienced the recording process. She earned her degree in Music Therapy and working therapeutically with the elderly and disabled. In 1981, Terisa made her big break when her voice graced the Grammy-nominated LP "Looking for Love" by her co-writers Wanda Vaughn of the Emotions and Smokey Robinson. The success of this song exploded worldwide and springboarded Terisa's career as a solo artist. With the release of her debut album "Infinite Love", Terisa flashed her ability to bring out excellence in her craft and medium of music. Terisa expanded her world in the mid-1980s to New York, recording for major labels and working with renowned producers and collaborators like Teddy Riley. She released three additional albums, "Dreamin'", "Gettin' There", and "No One Like You". These albums were among the most anticipated releases of their time and were favored by critics and musical tastemakers. Her vocal range, storytelling abilities and melodic phrasing have since been sampled by some of the biggest names in hip hop including Mos Def, Kanye West, and Common. In the early 2000s, Terisa was inducted into The Los Angeles Alumni Association Hall of Fame. Her popularity grew to an even larger international scale and she has performed in various countries including Brazil, Japan, France, Qatar, and more. Terisa continues to expand her singing career, continuing to touch audiences with her unique sound and make a mark in the music industry. She has given private interviews and stunned audiences with her music with her Special Concerts & Workshops. On stage, Terisa has been known to stir listeners to her music by orchestrating entertaining shows that express the depths of emotion in her music. Her latest album is “My Time”, released in 2019. There’s no sign of Terisa Griffin slowing down anytime soon, as she continues to record, perform, and give back to the community. She is a gifted vocalist and dedicated visionary; her passion for music comes from her Christian walk and knowledge of Gospel literature. Through her successes and failures, Terisa Griffin continues to surmount obstacles in her path to greatness, inspiring a new generation of followers to press forward and believe.

Yunganastes pluvicanorus is a species of large Myobatrachid frog, which is found only in Chile. It is an endemic species, preferring montanePatagonian shrubland habitat, between 700 and 1000 metres above sea level, in the southern central region of the Chile. It was first identified in 2007 by a team of Chilean biologists led by José Cotzillahue. Y. pluvicanorus is a medium-sized frog, typically measuring between 2 and 3.3 centimetres in length. It is brown on its dorsal side and pale yellow to light blue ventrally. It has large eyes and short legs, and its toes are partially webbed. The species prefers to inhabit cloudy, humid montane Patagonian shrubland, and is absent from nearby regions with similar habitat. Y. pluvicanorus reproduces by laying numerous (up to 1000+) eggs in a single mating event in the wet season and these are then guarded by the male until they hatch a few weeks later. Females have been observed to have multiple mates, which increases genetic variability and makes this species more robust. Conservation of Y. pluvicanorus is an important consideration due to its limited range. The species is classified as Near Threatened (NT) on the IUCN Red List. The key threats to the species are associated with the destruction of its montane habitat, due to deforestation and livestock grazing. conservation efforts include habitat protection, which is the primary management action for the species. Additionally, captive breeding and reintroduction programmes in suitable locations have been proposed. Within Chile, Y. pluvicanorus may benefit from the increasing conservation interest in the recently described Patagonian species. These conservation efforts will require improved access to the remote montane habitats in which this species is found and increased recognition of the importance of conserving amphibians as key components of fragile Patagonian ecosystems.

Hallgeir Pedersen, born June 13th 1971 in Askim, Norway, is a Norwegian folk singer and composer. He grew up in Askim and started playing guitar at the age of 16. In 1986, he formed his own band, "Hallgeir Pedersen and the Fiddlers", and released his first album, "Guitar Magic". Pedersen studied guitar at the University of Trondheim in Norway from 1991 - 1995, and upon graduating he began playing with different bands around the country, ranging from contemporary folk, new and traditional music. He has released over a dozen albums since, with some of his most successful and critically acclaimed work coming out of his collaborations with Mari Boine, Lene Marlin, Vamp and the Norwegian Electronic Music Collective. For the past few decades, Hallgeir Pedersen has been an important figure in Norwegian folk music and he is widely recognized as one of the country's top musicians. He's also gained recognition throughout Scandinavia, through his weekly music show, "Folkmusikk" on the national radio. In 2009, he became an honored guest of the Scandinavian Music Summit. On the international stage, Pedersen has performed throughout the United States, including at the Chicago World Music Festival, Lollapalooza, and Red Rocks Amphitheatre. He has also toured with Peter Gabriel, The Chieftains and Lila Downs, plus many European dates. In 2011, Hallgeir Pedersen released his latest album, "Nordic Connections", described as a mixture of folk and electronic music from the northern regions, including Norway, Denmark and Sweden. Pedersen has been praised for his unique musical blend of traditional elements and modern production. He has also been praised for his interpretive playing of traditional Norwegian music, combined with imaginative improvisation to create “an accessible sound that bridges traditional and contemporary.” Hallgeir Pedersen is an important figure in Norwegian and Scandinavian music. He continues to tour around the world, playing at festivals and performing in both large and small venues. In 2017, he released "Harbinger”, an album praised by critics as his most experimental work yet. His music is a mix of folk, jazz, and electro-acoustic sounds, revealing both his musical connections and his musical ability.

James Edmonstone (1818–1894) was a Scottish slave-owner, planter and abolitionist who became a prominent figure in the Portuguese colony of Salvador, Brazil. He was born in Ednaston, Scotland, the son of Alexander and Dorothy Edmonstone. In his youth, he became an apprentice at an indigo-making factory near Glasgow, and in 1837 he emigrated to Brazil, initially settling in Rio de Janeiro. He soon became a successful indigo producer in the eastern states, but by 1847 he had moved to the state of Bahia, where he was to become one of the largest slaveowners in Brazil. Edmonstone received his slave from Senhor Marques, a former senator from Minas Gerais, who had been convicted of illegal slave trading. James became one of the largest slave-owners in the region, owning over 500 slaves at one time. He purchased lands near Santo Amaro and began to cultivate sugar cane and produce indigo, which he then exported to Europe. Despite his slave-owning activities, Edmonstone was more progressive than his counterparts in the region and was heavily involved in the then-nascent abolition movement in Brazil. He spoke frequently on the subject of abolition, arguing that as a "moral duty, we ought to take the part of slavery, wherever it exists." He was also instrumental in helping to create the first abolitionist newspaper in Brazil, the 'Voce de Liberdade', in 1848. His campaigning and work did much to help the cause, and by 1871 the Brazilian slave trade had ended, with all slaves within Brazil finally freed in 1888. James Edmonstone became one of the most successful and respected businesspeople in the Brazilian state of Bahia. His business interests continued to expand during the 1850s and '60s, and he was responsible for building many of the key infrastructure projects in the region such as roads, bridges and railroads. He was active in local politics, becoming a member of the Bahian Chamber of Deputies in 1868, and he also published several books and essays on slavery, the economy, and Brazil's history and culture. Despite his gradual rise to prominence within the local community, Edmonstone's life was not without its controversies. In 1871 he was forced to flee to Portugal after scandals relating to his slave-trading activities threatened to land him in prison. He spent a number of years in Lisbon and then moved to the town of Salvador, where he lived until his death in 1894. During his life, he made a huge impact on the economic, social and political landscape of Brazil, and his legacy lives on today in the many monuments, streets and buildings named in his honour across the country. As a result, he is remembered by many Brazilian historians as one of the greatest figures of abolitionism in Brazil, and a daring and pioneering champion of justice and human rights.

Pornographic film, or adult film, is a genre of film that deals primarily with explicit sexual subject matter in order to arouse and satisfy an audience. Pornographic films were originally shot on film stock, but now they are made more commonly by video. In the United States, adult films are regulated by the Motion Picture Association of America. Most pornographic films must be classified as either softcore or hardcore as certain moral restrictions apply. Softcore films generally focus on nudity and other potentially suggestive sexual behavior, while hardcore films typically contain depictions of sexual intercourse and more explicit sexual activity. Many pornographic films focus on particular fetishes, such as bondage and discipline, spanking, and domination and submission, or activities such as lap dancing and mud wrestling. Others involve scenarios such as simulated rape. Documentary-style films have also been made about adult film stars, like the 2010 film Aroused. Pornography has often been subject to censorship and legal restrictions, both for moral and political reasons. In the US, obscenity laws have been used to suppress or restrict the sale or distribution of adult films since the 1960s. In recent decades, such restrictions have been relaxed, but adult films continue to be subject to varying degrees of censorship and control in some countries. Adult films are typically either rented or bought in the form of videotapes, DVDs, video discs, and online streaming. Movie theaters typically do not show adult films, though some exceptions to this rule do exist. In some countries, pornographic films are banned entirely. Pornographic films, while legally restricted, have been used for a variety of educational, therapeutic, and artistic purposes. The nudity and sex scenes in some movies can be used to portray situations in which conventional sexual taboos are challenged or subverted. In addition, sexually explicit artworks, such as the pornographic illustrations of Pompeii, have been preserved and continually inspires new generations of filmmakers.

The Goldman child abduction case was a 1995 abduction, murder, and conviction of two men for the kidnapping and killing of a nine-year old United States citizen, Anju Goldman, in California. The child had been living in Butte County, California, with her family, and was forcibly taken against her will by the suspects who intended to ransom her for a substantial sum. The case began on August 11, 1995, when Anju Goldman disappeared while walking home from an ice cream shop in Oroville, California. Her body was eventually found in the Feather River near Oroville on October 8, 1995. Two men, 58-year-old Clarence Eugene "Gene" Evans and 59-year-old Paul Leslie Whiteacre, were arrested and charged with her abduction and murder. The trial began in November 1997 and Evans and Whiteacre were found guilty on all charges related to the abduction and murder. Evans was sentenced to life in prison without parole and Whiteacre was sentenced to life in prison with the potential for parole after 20 years. Mason Whiteacre, the brother of Paul Leslie Whiteacre, pleaded guilty to being an accessory after the crime and served as a jail informant for authorities.
