The case drew national attention, due in part to the involvement of then-California Governor Pete Wilson, who called for a total of five million dollars from public and private organizations to fund the search for Anju. It also received media attention due to its grisly nature, as the suspects had planned to ransom the young girl before eventually killing her and disposing of her body in the Feather River. The case was seen as a wake up call to organizations, such as the Amber Alert, that are focused on finding missing children. It led to the introduction of tougher laws in California, making it easier to convict abductors and murderers of children. The Goldman case serves as an important reminder of the threats to children, and the need to remain vigilant in order to protect them.

Cast King is a professional Fortnite esports team. Founded in 2020, it currently fields teams in the European region. The organization is based in the United Kingdom, and operates globally. Cast King was founded in 2020 by a group of professional Fortnite players. The team is an endeavor to assemble a current roster of players from the European region. Cast King is focused on creating an environment for its players that encourages growth, professional competition and a strong community. The Cast King roster currently consists of 8 main players: Ella, Fliss, Refect, Revo, SoaR_Bubu, Zodd, Ownage, and Funkzombies. All eight players have a range of competitive experiences that make Cast King one of the strongest teams in Europe. When it comes to competitive play, Cast King has performed well in tournaments and events. In the 2020 WSOE Invitational Series Final, the team placed 4th overall. As of April 2021, the team has won four Cash Cup Series tournaments, and placed 2nd in four other tournaments. In addition to competitive play, Cast King also promotes and actively participates in many charity events on behalf of their players, raising money for important causes all over the world. This includes, but is not limited to, their “Donate For Change” campaign, through which they have donated over $7,000 to causes such as animal rescue, fighting world hunger and education reform. The players of Cast King are all part of a larger community that consists of both fans and professional esports players alike. As such, the players of Cast King receive support from their growing fan-base, and are always open to conversations with other members of the community. The team is also very committed to creating content and engaging with their fans, creating weekly streams and high-quality video content on their YouTube channel. Through their hard work, dedication and commitment to the craft, Cast King is slowly becoming one of the premier Esports teams in Europe. With their talented roster, passionate fan-base and commitment to charity, Cast King is poised to become a major force in the world of competitive Fortnite.

The Academy of Saint Joseph was an independent all-girls Catholic secondary school located in Brentwood, New York. The school was founded in 1910 and was dedicated to serving the needs of young women through holistic education, teaching embracing the teachings of Ignatian spirituality, social justice, and service leadership. The Academy of Saint Joseph was celebrated for its religious traditions, service-oriented curriculum, and academic excellence. In its heyday, the school was renowned for its diversity and for attracting students from many religious backgrounds. Students of all faiths participated actively in the academic, spiritual, and social life of the Academy. The school opened its doors in 1910 in a building on Suffolk Street in the Brentwood community. The first class had only 12 students and tuition fee was $25 a year. The school quickly outgrew its location and moved three more times before its final move to a larger building on Fifth Avenue in 1932. Academy of Saint Joseph emphasized the importance of holistic learning and adopted a curriculum which combined rigorous academic courses with broader opportunities in the arts, spiritual development, and hands-on service learning. Classes were small, allowing each student to be given the opportunity to develop and grow in her own way. The school boasted several successful alumni, including Nancy Pelosi, the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, U.S. Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor, and the actress and singer Whoopi Goldberg. The school also had a service-oriented spirit, providing a variety of outreach opportunities for their students both on campus and around the world. In 2018, the school was forced to close its doors due to the financial strain of increasing tuitions and donations. Many former students and alumnae of the Academy were dismayed and saddened by the news. Although the closure of the Academy of Saint Joseph was a major loss, the core values and spirit of the academy continue to live on.

Peter William McOwan (born 4 December 1959) is a British computer scientist and professor of computing science at Queen Mary University of London. McOwan is the Co-Director of The Centre for Creative Collaboration, a research group focused on understand the creative process in real world scenarios. McOwan was educated at the University of Birmingham where he obtained a Bachelor of Science in computer science, followed by a PhD on the same subject. After working at Oxford University as a research associate, he moved to Queen Mary in 1994. McOwan works in the fields of artificial intelligence, computer animation, computer games, programming education, and robotics. Specifically, his research interests are embodied artificial intelligence and machine learning. He has published works concerning learning by imitation, affective robotics, computer animation, physical understanding of text, artificial creativity, animation interaction, programming education and user interfaces. McOwan also has a strong interest in public engagement and science communication, and takes part in many outreach activities. He has appeared several times on BBC television and radio, and has given presentations at the Royal Institution and at the Cambridge Science Festival. McOwan is a Fellow of the British Computer Society and is a member of the Royal Institution's Creative Computing Forum. He is alsoa Trustee of Bletchley Park and the founder of the Education Network for Technological Engagement. In 2009 McOwan was awarded the British Computer Society Admiral Grace Hopper Award for Services to Women in Computing. This award recognises roles in supporting and inspiring women in computing. McOwan has written over 250 scientific articles, co-edited six books and presents regularly at scientific events. He is seen as a leading expert in his fields and has an h-index of 56.

Paul McCartney is a former member of the Beatles and one of the biggest solo performers in music history. Over the years, he has embarked on a number of successful concert tours and performances. This is a list of Paul McCartney's concert tours and appearances from 1970 to the present. 1970–1972: The McCartney Tour The first solo tour by Paul McCartney, “The McCartney” tour, ran from July 1970 to June 1972. Spanning 72 concerts and reaching various cities in Europe, Japan, and the United States, this tour featured an array of solo material as well as some select Beatles songs. 1989: The World Tour The World Tour ran from September 1989 to August 1990 and was McCartney’s most successful and longest running tour to date. Sprawling across four continents, the tour featured 117 performances and 7 million fans. 1993–1994: New World Tour The New World Tour was McCartney’s next endeavor. Boasting over 130 performances, this tour featured stops in Australia, South America, Europe, and North America. During the tour, McCartney premiered his single “Hope of Deliverance”, which was the first single from his next album. 2002–2003: Driving USA World Tour The Driving USA World Tour kicked off in the United States and spanned from May 2002 to April 2003. This tour visited over 23 countries and featured over 120 live performances. 2008–2009: Up and Coming Tour The Up and Coming Tour was Paul McCartney’s first extended tour following his knee surgery in 2006. Spanning from March 2008 to June 2009, the tour included 90 performances and featured songs from his 2009 album Good Evening New York City. 2010–2011: On The Run Tour The On The Run Tour was McCartney’s first tour to make use of a 360-degree revolving stage and light show. This extensive tour included 59 shows in 20 countries; performances featured songs from his 2006 album Chaos and Creation in the Backyard. 2013: Out There Tour Paul McCartney’s Out There Tour encompassed 73 shows across Europe, North America, and South America. This tour was McCartney’s most worldwide tour yet, spanning 24 countries and 5 continents. 2017-2018: One On One Tour The One On One Tour was composed of 42 shows that spanned Japan, Europe, Latin America, and North America. This tour was McCartney’s first since the Fatal Accident to feature visuals from the Beatles era. There were also behind-the-scenes videos and a full-height 360-degree video screen. 2020-2021: Freshen Up The Freshen Up Tour, McCartney's 50th tour, began in May of 2020. The tour was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic and features more recent songs with a few classic Beatles tunes. The tour includes stops in North America, Australasia, and Europe. Paul McCartney has performed around the world for over five decades. His tours have reached nearly every corner of the globe, delighting audiences and giving music lovers an opportunity to experience the best of this legendary singer-songwriter's music.

Sempronius Densus (born c. 361 AD) was a Roman soldier and part of a military unit known as the Protectores, who served the Roman Empire during the 3rd and 4th century AD. Densus is known for being the only member of his unit to survive the Battle of Adrianople, in which the Romans were defeated by the Goths in 378 AD. Densus was from the ancient city of Spalatum on the Adriatic coast of modern-day Croatia. He was part of the Protectores, a unit formed from Constantine's bodyguard, the Scholae Palatinae. Densus rose to prominence in the reign of Constantine I (306-337 AD). His unit was an elite, professional force that rode to battle in wagons, and wore white cloaks in battle, which served as a psychological deterrent. In 378 AD, the Roman army, under Emperor Valens, was defeated at the Battle of Adrianople, by a large army of Goths. Valens himself was killed leading the charge. Only Sempronius Densus and another soldier, Himilco, managed to survive the battle. It is believed that both men made their escape by hiding in a chariot and merging with the victorious Goth army. After the battle, it is believed that Densus and Himilco went their separate ways and no more is known of their ultimate fate. Densus appears to have survived long enough to be remembered in the writings of Ammianus Marcellinus, who mentions that he escaped the Battle of Adrianople and tells the story of how Densus and Himilco saved themselves. Densus’s courage and bravery were widely praised for centuries. As late as the 6th century AD, this courageous soldier was remembered as an example of courage and faithfulness to the Roman Empire. He was not just praised for surviving the battle, but was also respected for his courage and loyalty in a desperate situation. Today, Densus is remembered as a heroic figure, an example of bravery and true Roman spirit in a very dark period of history. He is an inspiration to everyone who faces a seemingly impossible task and is a reminder of the determination and courage that can enable a person to overcome even the most unfavourable circumstances.

Barend Dircksz (also known as Abraham and Adriaen Barendse, 1622–1698) was a 17th-century Dutch painter from Amsterdam who was best known for his portraiture and still life. He was born in Amsterdam, the son of a miller, and likely apprenticed for three years in the early 1640s with a local painter, although there have been no sketchbooks attributed to him. He married Marie Jacobsdr in June 1650 and the couple had two daughters and two sons. Dircksz is known to have produced small-scale portraits along with groups of three to five people, including those of the wealthy families of Amsterdam such as van der Hoeffs, Hartmannses, and De Ruyters. He often painted exclusively in brown tones as seen in his Portrait of Jan van Oostrum (1652). Favorite objects of his that featured in many of his paintings include musical instruments, books, maps, and vases. Among his still life works the 'Catalogue of Fruit and Dead Animals' stands out since it was done with a new technique in Southern Netherlands first introduced by Carel de Moucheron and Daniel Vorsterman. Dircksz was good friends with the other notable Amsterdam portraitists of the time, Govert Dircksz Camphuysen, Evert Jansz, and Adriaen Hanneman. All four created harsh images in comparison to the earlier Dutch painters who favored a more benign style of portraiture. In 1660 he was accepted into the Guild of St. Luke's, which was Amsterdam's Artist's Congregation, and in the same year he became a witness to the Treaty of The Hague between France and the Seven United Provinces. Barend Dircksz is widely considered one of the first innovators in the Dutch Golden Age of painting, and he had a great influence on the painters who followed him. One such painter was his student Adriaan Backer who created his own style of painting and the two collaborated on a piece together called Allegory of Vanity and Death (1664). His work is featured in many major Dutch art collections, including those of the Rijksmuseum, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the Amsterdam Museum. The legacy of Barend Dircksz cannot be underestimated. His work was praised by critics throughout his lifetime and he remains one of the most important Dutch painters of the Golden Age. His innovative style and various portraits, still lifes, and allegorical pieces leave us a vivid depiction of Dutch life and the people who lived it.

Formula One coverage on ITV is the long-running television coverage of the FIA Formula One World Championship shown on ITV in the United Kingdom. The backbone of the coverage is provided by the free-to-air broadcaster, ITV4, which has broadcast the majority of the sport since 1997, when Sky Sports' coverage of the sport was moved to the new channel. The coverage is based around world feed coverage of the races and post race analysis, originally presented by Steve Rider and Jim Rosenthal. In 1997, Steve Rider took the lead role in providing the coverage, including commentary, interviews and reporting on practice and qualifying sessions. Rider retired in 2004, and was replaced as presenter in 2005 by Jim Rosenthal and Louise Goodman. Commencing in 2007, the race day programmes were presented by Ted Kravitz alongside Mark Blundell. Martin Brundle was the lead commentator, with David Croft and Jonathan Legard providing analysis. Ted Kravitz and Louise Goodman provided expert insight into the technical aspects of each race. Steve Rider continued to provide features and interviews at the races, whilst Blundell provided commentary. In 2013, ITV Sport lost the rights to the BBC. As a result, the ITV commentary team was disbanded and the network began to rely on the Formula One Management for all broadcast output. Presenter responsibilities now vary, with all pit lane coverage being provided by the FOM. For the 2017 season, the coverage on ITV returned with Simon Lazenby as the main presenter, and Martin Brundle and David Croft providing commentary. Lazenby introduced each race from the ITV F1 studio, from where the pre-race and post-race shows -- which can last up to two hours -- were presented. Formula One on ITV4 is one of the longest-running sports programmes in the United Kingdom, and continues to provide an unrivalled coverage of the world's oldest, and often most glamorous, motorsport championship.

A muzzleloader is a type of firearm that is loaded from the muzzle, or front end of the gun, as opposed to other types of firearms that are loaded from the chamber or magazine. Muzzleloaders were the first type of firearms ever used, dating back to the early 1500s when black powder was first used for gunpowder. Since then, muzzleloaders have gone through several advancements and are now used by hunters, muzzleloading enthusiasts, and historical re-enactors. Muzzleloader firearms use a wide range of projectile and powder charges, from .22 caliber to .50 caliber and black powder, Pyrodex, and substitutes like Triple Seven, Canadian Blackhorn 209, and 777. Muzzleloaders range from single-shot shotguns, to the traditional long guns (smooth and rifle barrels), to modern in-line rifles with internal magazines. Some muzzleloaders have composite stocks, like a rifle, while others are more traditionally styled with wooden stocks and other features. Muzzleloader pistols are also available and can be used both recreationally and in historical reenactments. Traditionally, muzzleloaders were traditionally loaded with loose black powder and round lead balls, with a few drops of lubricant applied over the balls to aid in loading. Muzzleloader projectiles now range from round lead balls, to conical and sabot-style bullets, and even Saboted Light Armor Piercing (SLAP) ammunition. Traditionally, muzzleloaders were ignited by a flintlock or percussion cap, although newer models are now available with an electric ignition system. Muzzleloaders can be used for target practice, hunting, and competition shooting. As with other types of firearms, muzzleloading firearms require a certain amount of knowledge, skill, and caution for proper and safe usage. Rules and regulations vary from state to state, so it is important to become familiar with the laws in your area. Muzzleloader firearms have been around for centuries, and have provided much enjoyment to hunters and enthusiasts alike. While they are not as powerful or accurate as modern firearms, they are still able to provide a unique and interesting shooting experience with their classic appearance and operation. So if you're looking for a great way to get back to the basics, a muzzleloader can provide you with a great way to get started in the shooting sports.

The 1982 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team represented the University of Notre Dame during the 1982 NCAA Division I-A football season. The team was led by fourth-year head coach Gerry Faust. In his fourth and final season, Faust's Fighting Irish posted an 8–4 record and accepted the invitation to play in the Liberty Bowl. In the second quarter of their regular season game against Georgia Tech, Notre Dame sophomore quarterback Steve Beuerlein threw a 45-yard Hail Mary pass to freshman tight end Gary Godsey, giving the Fighting Irish a 17-14 lead. The play became known as the "Pass to Win" moment and is remembered by many as one of Notre Dame's greatest football highlights. The Fighting Irish started their season with a pair of victories over Purdue and LSU. Three consecutive losses to McGrath scored by junior Jerome Heavens, Michigan, and Air Force however quickly turned the season sour. Notre Dame bounced back with victories over Colorado, Boston College, and Navy to hold the record at 5-3. Victories over Virginia Tech and Georgia Tech at home before Notre Dame squared off against USC in what would be Gerry Faust's last game as head coach at Notre Dame. Down 18–17 late in the fourth quarter, Notre Dame missed out on the opportunity for a 24-yard field goal and lost the game. The Fighting Irish finished the season with a record of 8-4 and their fourth consecutive bowl appearance. They went on to lose the Liberty Bowl to North Carolina 10–9, in what would have been the first ten win season for Notre Dame since 1974. In the end, the 1982 Fighting Irish football season would be the last loss in Gerry Faust's tenure, and the final season with the assistant coach Lou Holtz, who assumed head coaching duties in the following season. With a victory in the Liberty Bowl, the Fighting Irish would have finished the season ranked eleventh in the final AP Poll. Instead, they finished the season unranked with an 8-4 record and ended the year tied for twentieth in the final AP Poll with two consecutive losses.

The 2019–20 Arizona Wildcats women's basketball team represented the University of Arizona during the 2019–20 NCAA Division I women's basketball season. The Wildcats, led by head coach Adia Barnes, played their home games at the McKale Center and were a member of the Pac-12 Conference. The Wildcats finished the regular season with a 17–12 (10–8 Pac-12) record and had the No. 7 seed in the 2020 Pac-12 Conference Women's Basketball Tournament. The Wildcats were defeated in the quarterfinals by Cal. On March 12, 2020, the NCAA Tournament and all remaining winter and spring NCAA championships were cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Seniors Aari McDonald and Jemeryn Proby led the Wildcats. McDonald led the Pac-12 in scoring and was fourth in the nation at 21.6 points per game. On January 20, 2020, McDonald became Arizona's all-time leading scorer, passing Dave lloyd with 2,132 career points. Proby led Arizona in rebounds and blocks, averaging 12.2 rebounds and 1.9 blocks per game. Other key players on the team included Cate Reese, a sophomore forward averaging 13.3 points and 6.7 rebounds, and 6–2 guard Helena Pueyo, who averaged 8.7 points and 3.2 assists per game. Arizona earned their first-ever NCAA Tournament win on March 24, 2019, upsetting 6th seeded Buffalo in the first round of the 2019 NCAA Women's Basketball Tournament. The win marked the program's first appearance in the NCAA Tournament since 2005. With a 2021 recruiting class ranked 15th by ESPN and freshman phenom Jordan Horston, the Wildcats were expected to make another NCAA tournament run in 2020. The team got off to a strong start, winning eight of their first nine games, but struggled with consistency as the season progressed. The 2019–20 Arizona Wildcats women's basketball season would prove to be a successful but ultimately disappointing one for Arizona. The team showed promise, but never truly reached their full potential due to the COVID-19 pandemic cancelling the NCAA tournament.

Oliver Beer (born in 1983) is a French British contemporary artist known for his multimedia works featuring a range of media, including sound, sculpture, performance, installation, and film. Beer studied Fine Art at Goldsmiths College, London and later obtained his Masters in Fine Art from the Royal College of Art in London. Beer's works often explore abstract concepts and consider the subjective experience of space. Through his work, Beer attempts to create a "continuum of sensory awareness". He is interested in decay and transformation and his works often center around considering the same phenomena from multiple perspectives. Beer has been widely exhibited internationally, including exhibitions at the Whitechapel Gallery in London, Documenta 14 in Athens, and the Palais de Tokyo in Paris. He was awarded the 2018 Prix Lafayette and was shortlisted for both the 2019-2020 Prix Marcel Duchamp and 2019 Turner Prize. Beer has used sound to transform spaces and explore the physical and psychological effects of sound. His installations often span multiple rooms, and various sounds are layered upon one another to form complex, site specific pieces. Some of his best-known works include ‘Vessel Orchestra’ at the BALTIC Centre for Contemporary Art in Newcastle, ‘Voice Resonance Chamber’ at the Tate Britain, and ‘Collapseland’ at the Fridericianum in Kassel. In 2019, Beer participated in an Antarctica Expedition with Cape Farewell, a non-profit organization working to increase awareness and action around climate change. The expedition wanted to explore the relationship between the human experience of an extreme environment and the natural world, and during the expedition Beer composed an album of the sounds he experienced and recorded. Outside of his visual art practice, Beer has works as a composer, singer and music producer with releases on labels such as Warp Records. He has collaborated with many artists and was commissioned by the Royal Albert Hall and Ballet Black to create original music for 'The Concealed' performance in 2019. Beer is currently based in London and continues to explore new ways of working and materials. His work has been widely reviewed in publications such as Frieze, Art Monthly, and The Guardian.

The 1983–84 United States network television schedule is a list of the official primetime schedules and corresponding time periods for each of the four American television networks, ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox. This was the first season in which Fox broadcast a full slate of programming, as the newly created network launched on October 9, 1983. ABC ABC's schedule was very strong in 1983–84 and featured the return of The Love Boat, the introduction of Remington Steele, the revival of Family Feud, and the spin-off of "The Little House on the Prairie" series, Little House: A New Beginning. ABC's highest rated show of the season was the police procedural "T.J. Hooker". Other notable ABC shows included: Hart to Hart, Hotel, Matt Houston, Dynasty, Too Close for Comfort, Benson, and Three's Company. CBS CBS' 1983–84 lineup was loaded with hits and featured the hits "Magnum P.I.", "Dukes of Hazzard", and "Simon & Simon", as well as Monday Night Football, the detective drama "Jake and the Fatman", the revival of "The Waltons", and the anthology series "The Twilight Zone". New shows included: "Airwolf", "Dallas" spin-off "Knots Landing", "Newhart", "Flamingo Road", and "Call to Glory". NBC NBC launched “The Cosby Show” during this season which quickly became NBC’s highest-rated show, along with its two spin-offs “A Different World” and “Cheers”. "The A-Team" was also a major hit for NBC, along with "Hill Street Blues", "St. Elsewhere", "Knight Rider", "Fame", "Family Ties", and "Miami Vice". Other notable NBC shows included "The Golden Girls", "Highway to Heaven", "It's a Living", and "Facts of Life", and the made-for-TV movie "The Burning Bed". Fox The fledgling network launched with its Wednesday night lineup of "The Late Show with Joan Rivers", "Duet" and "Studs". Other notable Fox shows during the 1983–84 season were "The New Adventures of Beans Baxter" and the made-for-TV movie "The Day After". Overall, the 1983–84 US network television season was a strong one, with strong shows on all four networks. It was a competitive season, with each network aiming to capture the attention of viewers.

The List of France national Rugby Union team records comprises the records of players who have represented the French national Rugby Union team since the national team was founded in 1906. France first took part in an international Rugby Union match in 1906, against New Zealand. The French have since become a major force in the game, taking part in all 8 of the Rugby World Cups, and being crowned champions on one occasion. This list details the highest and lowest records that have been set by the French national team in its history. Highest Records • Most wins: 46, against the USA. • Longest unbeaten run: 24 matches between November 2008-June 2010. • Most points scored in a match: 109, against Namibia, at the 1999 Rugby World Cup. • Most tries in a match: 17, against Japan, at the 2007 Rugby World Cup. • Biggest winning margin: • 77-14 against Japan, in 1991. Lowest Records • Fewest wins: 2, against South Africa and New Zealand. • Longest losing streak: 5 matches, twice, against New Zealand and Australia. • Fewest points scored in a match: 0, against New Zealand and South Africa. • Fewest tries in a match: 0, against South Africa, in 2009. • Biggest losing margin: 67-31, against Wales, in 2001. France has also set a number of individual records including the most capped forward Didier Camberabero who made 31 appearances for the team over a 13 year period. Overall, the French national team have achieved a great number of records in the game, making them one of the most successful rugby nations in the world.

Buffalo Springs National Reserve (BSNR) is a protected area in the Eastern Rift Valley region of Kenya, located close to the town of Maralal in Samburu County. It is a contoured, 9,000-hectare national reserve which hosts one of the most biologically diverse habitats in the region, including grassland, woodland and bushland, which are home to numerous species of flora and fauna. BSNR is home to a wide selection of animal species, including antelopes, wildebeest, elephants, lions, cheetahs, and giraffes. The area is also renowned for its numerous bird species, such as guineafowl, hornbills, starlings, waxbills, and sunbirds. One of the reserve's most important predators is the African Wild Dog which is listed as an endangered species by the IUCN. Buffalo Springs National Reserve was established in 1989 and forms part of the Samburu-Buffalo Springs-Shaba ecosystem, which stretches over some 350,000 hectares. The reserve is managed by the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS) and is run in partnership with the Northern Rangelands Trust, which works with the local communities to ensure the sustainable use of the area's natural resources. The main natural attraction for visitors to Buffalo Springs National Reserve is its abundance of wildlife. The area also provides a number of activities for visitors to enjoy, such as bird watching, game drives, and guided hikes. There are a number of accommodation options for visitors which include tented camps, lodges and self-catering cottages. In addition to wildlife attractions, Buffalo Springs National Reserve is home to a number of archaeological sites, which provide evidence of human settlements dating back to the late Stone Age. There are also a number of archaeological sites located within the reserve, including rock shelters and mounds that are believed to be graves. The reserve provides an important habitat for many species of flora and fauna, and as such, it is a crucial part of conservation efforts in the region. The area is being developed as a national ecotourism destination in order to promote the conservation of the area's natural resources and to ensure the long-term sustainability of the area. Overall, Buffalo Springs National Reserve is a stunning region within Kenya's Eastern Rift Valley. The area provides visitors with access to a diverse array of flora and fauna, with plentiful wildlife and archaeological sites, making it a popular destination for visitors to explore and enjoy.

The 2018–19 Florida State Seminoles men's basketball team represented Florida State University during the 2018–19 NCAA Division I men's basketball season. The Seminoles, led by 20th-year head coach Leonard Hamilton, played their home games at the Donald L. Tucker Center on the university's Tallahassee, Florida campus as members of the Atlantic Coast Conference. The 2018–19 Seminoles finished the season 29–8, 12–6 in ACC play to finish in a tie for third place. As the No. 5 seed in the ACC Tournament, they defeated Virginia Tech in the first round before losing to Duke in the quarterfinals. The Seminoles received an at-large bid to the NCAA Tournament as the No. 4 seed in the West region. There they lost to Gonzaga in the second round. The team was led by Mfiondu Kabengele, a sophomore forward who averaged 13.2 points, 5.9 rebounds, 1.5 assists, 1.0 steals and 1.5 blocks per game and was named to the All-ACC third team. Senior guard Terance Mann averaged 11.7 points, 6.4 rebounds and 2.5 assists per game and was a member of the All-ACC second team. The team was a disruptive defensive team, leading to its success in the season. It led the ACC in defensive turnover percentage (24.8 percent) and it finished third in defensive efficiency and assists per game (13). The Seminoles were led by junior guard Trent Forrest and graduate guards CJ Walker and David Nichols. Walker and Nichols played their first year with the Seminoles after transferring from Ohio State and Albany, respectively. The 2018–19 season was one of the best in Florida State history. The Seminoles returned to the NCAA Tournament for the third year in a row after having not made it since 2012. The Seminoles also achieved a number of school milestones, such as reaching their third consecutive Sweet 16, winning the NIT, the most wins in school history, the most ACC wins and their first win over Duke since 2009. The 2018–19 season was one of the best in Florida State basketball history and the team achieved success both on the court and in the community. A model of success, the team was seen as a team that other teams in the ACC could learn from. In 2019, the team was honored with the Silver Anniversary Award by the State of Florida for their accomplishments on and off the court. The Florida State Seminoles men's basketball program will look to continue their success in 2019–20 and beyond.

She Knows Me Too Well is a song by the American rock band The Beach Boys, released in 1965 on the album The Beach Boys Today!. Written by Brian Wilson and Tony Asher, the song is an up-tempo ballad about a young man's dilemma in that his lover knows everything about him, including his flaws and shortcomings, and the potential difficulty of hiding them. Wilson's creative ambitions instilled into the track an unusual musical structure and an assumed influence of a symphonic-like sound. The track is a fusion of rock style instrumentation and classical aspects, with the inclusion of strings and a baroque-style harpsichord playing. It centres around a chord progression of F major, G minor, and C major, around which the rest of the instrumentation derives its tonal construction. The track features various Beach Boys layered vocal harmonies ranging from bass harmonies to falsetto, that accompany the lyrical themes of humiliation and vulnerability. The track was generally well-received, with American music writer and critic Bruce Eder writing “it was an incredible song, with an ethereal violin line adding an intense contrast to the bright major-key melody line.” It has been cited by various writers as a favourite recording of the band’s, with Joseph Lanza referring to the track as “Brian’s first adult song with a dramatic lyric”. The song has been included on various compilations and compiles of the band’s work, such as Stack-o-Tracks in 1968, Endless Summer in 1974, and Made in USA in 1986. The song has been used in various films and other media such as the Stanley Donen musical Two for the Road. In 1975, The Beach Boys performed the song on Welcome Back, Kotter, and a live version was included on their Beach Boys Live in Concert in 1976. The song continues to be included in the setlist of live tours of the band, with a live performance of the track being included on the band’s Live in London album, released in 2009.

Pseuduvaria beccarii is a species of plant in the Ancistrocladaceae family. This species is found in Brunei, Sumatra, Malaysia, and Borneo. It was first described by the Italian-born Dutch botanist Odoardo Beccari in 1887. P. beccarii is a small tree or shrub, reaching heights of up to 15 meters with dark gray bark. The leaves are alternate, with three leaflets and a length of 8-15 cm. The leaves are dark green, glossy on top and paler on the underside. The flowers are bisexual and have petals of yellow or pale green. The fruits are fleshy drupes, approximately 5 cm in diameter, with a single seed. The species typically grows in lowland dipterocarp forests, at altitudes of up to 600 m, where it is an important component in the canopy layer. It is often found near rivers and streams, where soil moisture is high. P. beccarii is threatened by habitat loss due to logging and deforestation, as well as the collection of plants for medicinal uses. Its natural habitat is being destroyed at a rapid rate, with recent estimates showing that nearly 50% of its original range has been lost since the species was discovered. Despite its threatened status, there has been some success at conservation of P. beccarii. Several areas in Brunei and Sumatra host protected populations of the species, while in some areas, local botanic gardens work to propagate the species and reintroduce it to areas where it has been lost. Overall, P. beccarii is considered a vulnerable species. It is listed on the IUCN Red List and is also protected under the Convention on International Trade on Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna (CITES). Increased awareness and conservation efforts are needed in order to ensure that this species does not disappear from the wild.

Paul Wheelhouse (born 7 October 1970) is a British politician who has been the Member of the Scottish Parliament (MSP) for the South Scotland region since 2007. He is currently the Minister for Environment, Climate Change and Land Reform in the Scottish Government. Wheelhouse was also the Scottish Minister for Business, Energy and Tourism from 2014 to 2016. Wheelhouse was born and raised in Kilmarnock and graduated from the University of Strathclyde in Glasgow with a degree in public policy and public law. He joined the British Army in 1993 and served for 10 years, stationed in Northern Ireland and Bosnia, and was Honorably discharged in 2003. Wheelhouse returned to Scotland and worked for charities such as SCIAF, Oxfam and Save the Children, as well as for South Ayrshire Council. He was then elected as a Member of the Scottish Parliament (MSP) for the South of Scotland in 2007. He was re-elected in 2011 and 2016. In the Scottish Government, Wheelhouse has held several ministerial positions. He was a Junior Minister in the Scotland Office from 2009 to 2010, Minister for Community Safety and Legal Affairs from 2010 to 2011 and Minister for Housing and Transport from 2011 to 2014. In April 2014 he was appointed Minister for Business, Energy and Tourism and held this position until the reshuffle in May 2016, where he was appointed Minister for Environment, Climate Change and Land Reform. Wheelhouse is committed to creating a safer, fairer and more prosperous Scotland. He has been active in promoting policies related to climate change, environmental protection and renewable energy. He has led the charge in creating more than 250,000 jobs from green sources, improving energy efficiency and establishing Scotland's first fuel poverty strategy. Wheelhouse has pushed for stronger public involvement and transparency in policy making and co-chairs the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Scotland's Decarbonisation Pathway. Wheelhouse is also a keen supporter of early years education and has worked to develop and expand Scotland’s childcare and Early Years service. Most recently, Wheelhouse conducted a nationwide consultation on Scotland’s Land Reform Bill and introduced the Scottish Land Commission Bill, which proposes to create an independent body that will oversee the management of Scotland’s lands. The bill was passed unanimously in Parliament on the 5 May 2021. Wheelhouse remains a passionate advocate for creating a more prosperous, equitable and sustainable society and is a leading voice in Scotland’s efforts towards achieving zero net emissions.

Carl Wagner (1925-2006) was an American abstract expressionist painter, sculptor, and printmaker. He is best known for his large-scale paintings and sculptures, which were inspired by his travels throughout the United States, Latin America, and Europe. Wagner was born in San Francisco, California. He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from University of California, Berkeley, in 1945 and later attended the University of California, Los Angeles, where he received an Master of Arts degree in 1947. In 1948, Wagner moved to New York City to pursue a career as an artist. Throughout his career, Wagner created works in various media, including oil and acrylic paints, metals, concrete, and wood. His paintings were often abstract and brightly colored, often featuring circles and other geometric shapes. His sculptures ranged from small figures to large-scale abstract forms. His series of painted aluminum sculptures, “Twilight Trees,” was installed on the grounds of the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College in 1977 and continues to be featured there today. Wagner's creations were exhibited in numerous solo and group exhibitions throughout the United States, including at The Museum of Modern Art, Whitney Museum of American Art, Contemporary Arts Museum Houston, Los Angeles County Museum of Art, and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. He was awarded a National Endowment for the Arts grant in 1987, and his work is featured in the permanent collections of several important American museums. Throughout his life, Wagner was active in the art community. He served as a professor at Hunter College and The Cooper Union in New York City, and his students included artists Ross Bleckner and Elizabeth Murray. He also wrote about art for Arts Magazine, Art News, and other publications. Wagner died in 2006 in his home in Water Mill, New York. His work continues to be featured in a number of exhibitions and retrospectives in the United States, including a major retrospective at the Heckscher Museum of Art in 2007. He is remembered for his powerful and innovative contributions to the development of abstract expressionism in the United States.

East Kew railway station is a railway station on the Hurstbridge railway line in Victoria, Australia, located in the Melbourne suburb of East Kew. It is located between the Inner Circle railway line to the north and the Ringwood railway line to the south. East Kew station was opened in 1887 and was built as part of the larger suburban rail network. The station consists of two side platforms, with access to the surrounding East Kew area as well as Carlton North and Ivanhoe. The main entrance is located opposite Elgar Road. The main line travelling through East Kew consists of up to three tracks. This line connects the Hurstbridge, Caulfield and Sunbury lines at Macaulay and the Ringwood, Belgrave and Lilydale lines at Ringwood. The station services both the metropolitan and interstate passenger rail networks, with the 22:20 service from Flinders Street arriving at East Kew. The entire station has been upgraded in recent years. In 2010, the station's platforms were upgraded, and new CCTV installed. This allowed for a better view of the station and its surroundings for travellers and station staff. The station is serviced by the eastern side suburban rail network, and is served by Metro morning and evening peak services to Hurstbridge, and V/Line ballarat and Bendigo services in the daytime. It is also served by both light and heavy rail facilities, with the latter providing passengers with wheelchair access. The station is located in a convenient spot for accessing other areas, in particular East Kew shops and cafés. It is also conveniently located near East Kew's main bus routes. East Kew station has recently become part of the Myki ticketing network, allowing passengers to purchase a ticket before travelling. The station is well connected, and is easy to navigate. With both suburban and regional services, it is an important connection point for many Melburnians.

Mary Jeffries (born November 22, 1963) is an American actress and writer, best known for leading roles in Broadway and regional theater productions. She studied acting at the Juilliard School and National Theater Institute, and has been praised for her work in critically acclaimed plays like The House of Blue Leaves, Blithe Spirit and Cat On a Hot Tin Roof. Born and raised in New York City, Mary Jeffries attended the School of the Arts as a teenager and earned her Bachelor of Arts degree in theater from Juilliard. After graduation, her career took off quickly and she soon found success in local theater companies and Broadway shows. She made her Broadway debut in 1999 in the critically acclaimed revival production of The House of Blue Leaves, for which she earned a Drama Desk Award nomination for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Play. Throughout her career, Jeffries has been lauded for bringing life to real, hard-hitting roles. She worked with the Tony Award-winning director, Jack O’Brien, on productions of Blithe Spirit, Macbeth and Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, all of which were highly acclaimed. She also starred in regional theater productions including Topdog/Underdog, Doubt and Steel Magnolias. Jeffries has also appeared in a handful of television shows and films. She began her onscreen career in a guest role on Law & Order, and has since appeared in TV shows like The Good Wife, White Collar and Blue Bloods. She also made appearances in the films Beyond and People I Know, and starred in the independent feature, St. Ann’s Summer. Jeffries currently serves on the board of directors for the non-profit organization, New York Women in Film & Television. She is an outspoken advocate of women’s rights, especially within the entertainment industry. She has been quoted as saying, “Women can do anything they want—but they should be supported and given the resources to do it.” In 2021, Jeffries will be returning to the stage in the musical adaptation of the classic novel, Little Women. She will be playing the character of Marmee, and is expected to reprise her role for the first time since 2013. The production is scheduled to open in October and will be co-produced by the Goodspeed Opera House and Prospect Theater Company. Overall, Mary Jeffries has found success in both stage and screen. With her expansive knowledge of the industry and her passionate dedication to the craft, she is an invaluable asset to the entertainment world and a role model to aspiring actors and actresses.

Pokémon the Movie: Secrets of the Jungle is a Japanese animated film directed by Tetsuo Yajima and produced by OLM, Inc. and distributed by The Pokémon Company. It is the 22nd Pokémon movie and was released in Japan on December 25, 2020. The movie is set in the Sinnoh region and follows the story of a young boy named Hirota, who travels to the jungle in search of a mysterious Pokémon that is said to have amazing powers. Meanwhile, the evil organization Team Galactic plan to harness the power of the mysterious Pokémon to further their own goals. The movie features the voice talents of Mayuki Makiguchi as Hirota and Yuki Kaji as the voice of the mysterious Pokémon. Other cast members include Unsho Ishizuka as Professor Rowan, Megumi Hayashibara as Cynthia, Mayuko Omimura as Dawn, and Nana Mizuki as Lucario. The movie follows the usual Pokémon formula of its protagonists traveling the region and battling bad guys and Legendary Pokémon. In the climax, Hirota and his friends face off against Team Galactic and their attempt to control the mysterious Pokémon. The movie has been well-received by both fans and critics alike, praised for its animation, exciting storyline and likable characters. The movie was nominated for Best Animated Feature Film at the 2021 Academy Awards. Secrets of the Jungle is the first Pokémon movie to be released in Ultra HD Blu-ray format, and the first Pokémon movie to feature Dolby Vision HDR. The movie was also released in Digital HD, making it the first Pokémon movie to be available digitally. The digital version of the movie was released on February 19, 2021. Overall, Pokémon the Movie: Secrets of the Jungle captivated audiences with its dynamic storyline, beautiful animation and heart-warming characters. The film received critical acclaim for its ambitious rewrite of the traditional Pokémon formula and is a powerful representation of the series’ spirit of adventure.

Rondout Creek is a 44.3-mile long tributary of the Hudson River in Ulster and Sullivan Counties, New York. It is one of the Hudson River's largest and most important tributaries, providing over two thirds of the river's fresh water supply. The Rondout is fed by the waters of several other streams, beginning high in the Catskill Mountains and flowing south and east before emptying into the Hudson River near Kingston. The mayor of Rondout Creek was discovered in 1609 by Henry Hudson while searching for the Northwest Passage. The creek was subsequently used as a transportation route by colonial pioneers and eventually connected to the Erie Canal. The creek also provided critical transportation to industries located along its route. An important center of anthracite coal mining and related industries, the creek was the site of the great anthracite rail boycott of 1902, a major landmark in American labor history. Today, Rondout Creek is a major recreation destination for kayaking, canoeing and fishing. The creek was designated an "Outstanding Water Resource" in 2009. The most popular sections for kayaking and canoeing are the sections from the Sam's Point Preserve to its confluence with the Hudson River. The creek is also home to a variety of fish and other aquatic life, including brown trout and largemouth bass. In addition to being an important recreational asset for the region, Rondout Creek also serves many environmental functions. The creek is home to numerous species of aquatic life, including the endangered dwarf wedgemussel. It also provides recreational opportunities to local communities, while also supporting a healthy and productive riparian ecosystem along its banks. Rondout Creek is part of America’s industrial history, and its winding route is also a sign of its enduring importance to the Hudson Valley region. As an important recreational resource and environmental asset, Rondout Creek helps to bring life and vitality to the communities that surround it.

Jorge Lagües is a Chilean-American actor and producer. He has starred in various films and TV Shows in both countries. Lagües was born in Valparaíso, Chile in 1987. He attended primary, middle and high school in the same city. Since an early age he developed a deep passion for the performing arts and film which eventually led him to pursue a professional career in Los Angeles, US. Before settling in the US, Lagües graduated from the University of Valparaiso in film production. He moved to Los Angeles and finished his studies in screenwriting at the New York Film Academy. Lagües started his career in 2012 with small film roles before getting his first main role in 2017, in the independent film "Coming of Age" which was produced by his own production company. That same year he guest-starred in an episode of the American TV show "Rise". In 2018, Lagües was cast as the main villain in the Chilean movie "Sombras Oscuras" which was nominated for several awards. He then went on to play the lead role in several Chilean TV shows and films. In 2020 Lagües once again returned to his home country to produce and act in the short films "Nunca dejar de Correr" and "Los Marqueses de Valparaíso", which were later released on the film festival circuit. On the US side, Lagües has had small roles in big budget films such as "Alita: the Battle Angel" and "Men in Black: International". In 2021, Lagües will make his debut as a voice-over actor, lending his voice to a character in the animated series "Doomsday Elementary". Lagües currently resides in Los Angeles and continues to actively pursue his careers in both the US and Chilean film and television industries. He is also involved in philanthropic activities, raising awareness for social causes such as Human Rights and environmentalism.

George Washington Carroll (July 10th, 1856–July 11th, 1932) was an American businessman and philanthropist. Born in Troy, Mississippi, he was the oldest son of James Madison and Harriet Carroll. Carroll left home at an early age and moved to Kansas, where he worked in the grain business. After a few years of invaluable experience in the grain trade, he moved to Atchison and established a grain commission house. This business allowed him to become very wealthy, buying large tracts of land and becoming one of the largest owners of such land in the county. He was a member of the Masonic Lodge, the Free and Accepted Masons. He also contributed to various orphanages and charities, as well as sponsoring a number of public works projects in and around Atchison. During his lifetime, Carroll contributed significantly to the city of Atchison, and he was honored multiple times for his philanthropy. He created the first library in Atchison and was a major donor to what eventually became the University of St. Mary. He also provided financial support for the creation of parks and playgrounds in the city. Carroll was also a successful businessman and investor. His largest single venture outside of Atchison was in the purchase of the Troy and Leake County Rail Company. He operated this line until the turn of the twentieth century, when it was sold to the Chicago and Alton Railway. Carroll was married twice during his lifetime. He was a strong supporter of education, and founded the Atchison Free School Movement, which sought to provide free education to children in his city. He was also one of the Executors of the will of Alexander Augusta, a large landowner in Atchison. In 1932, Carroll died in Atchison at the age of 76. Upon his death, the Atchison papers ran a three-part series to honor his memory and contributions. He was cited for his “unswerving loyalty to his community, his philanthropic spirit, and his business ability.” The Carroll Memorial Library, built in 1936 and still in operation, stands in his honor in downtown Atchison. Several other institutions and landmarks in his hometown also bear his name, including a major hospital, and a bridge crossing the Missouri River.

Annie Wersching is an American actress. She is best known for her roles as FBI Agent Renee Walker on the American television series 24 and Nora Special Agent Huxley on NBC's Timeless. Annie Wersching was born in St. Louis, Missouri in 1977. She attended Lindbergh High School in St. Louis and graduated with honors. She then went on to earn a living in community theatre, performing in plays such as Anything Goes and Kiss Me Kate, before attending the University of Missouri in Columbia, Missouri, studying theatre and art. She attended the University of Missouri until 2000 when she graduated with a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree. In 2002, Wersching made her television debut on the soap opera The Guiding Light. She then went on to guest star in several shows, including Strong Medicine, Becker, Charmed and Cold Case, before getting her big break in 2006 when she was cast in the role of FBI Special Agent Renee Walker for the seventh season of the TV series 24, opposite Kiefer Sutherland. Her performance on the show gained critical acclaim and earned her an Emmy nomination for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Drama Series. In 2011, Wersching starred as agent Nora Special Agent Huxley on NBC's science fiction drama Timeless. The show was canceled after two seasons and Wersching moved on to a new series, Bosch. She stars as attorney Honey Chandler in the Amazon Prime Video series and has received positive reviews for her performance. In addition to acting, Wersching is involved in several charitable endeavors. She donates her time and money to several charities, including the Red Cross, the Make-A-Wish foundation and St. Jude's Children's Hospital. Wersching is married to musician Stephen Full and they have a son, Ozzie, who was born in June 2013. She resides in Los Angeles with her family. Annie Wersching is an accomplished actress and philanthropist who has established herself as a leading lady in both television and film. After making her mark in the highly acclaimed TV series 24, she has maintained a steady career in television and has become an integral part of the Amazon Prime Video original series Bosch. In addition to her acting career, she is dedicated to charitable work and family. She continues to be a strong voice in the entertainment industry and is a reminder of the power of hard work.

Kanreki dohyō-iri is a Shinto ceremony in Japan to mark a person's 60th birthday. The word “Kanreki” is a combination of two characters: “reen (憐)” and “kei (慶)”, meaning “sympathy and joy.” It is a time of reflection and celebration as the person marks the end of their sixth 10-year cycle and the beginning of the next. This ceremony is rooted in the Buddhist tradition of celebrating one's 60th birthday as significant and marks the sixth cycle of the traditional Japanese life expectancy (20 to 80). The term is frequently used to describe other Japanese ceremonies associated with reaching a certain age. At the beginning of the ceremony, a congratulatory rice cake is presented, representing the milestone achieved. A paper called “Shichi-go-san” (seven-five-three) is also given and consists of characters written with a specific brush and ink. The characters signify the intended wishes of happiness and health for the recipient. The celebrant then performs the dohyō-iri. The dohyō-iri is a symbolic gesture of ascending the steps to the top of a mountain shrine and the traditional costume of bright red and white clothing is worn for the ritual. Incense and sake are then offered to the gods as part of the purification of the soul. The celebration ends with the cutting of a 60th birthday cake in the shape of the kanji character for “old”. Kanreki dohyō-iri is practiced by many Japanese people, as a way of celebrating their passing of life’s stages. It has also been adopted by non-Japanese people who have embraced the traditional Japanese way of life. Kanreki dohyō-iri is an important part of Shinto tradition and is still observed by many families today, albeit in a modernised way. It is a time of renewal and joy and symbolises the start of a new cycle of life.

Danny Lewis (born Jul 1, 1979) is an American professional basketball player who currently plays for the Kansas City Kings. He attended the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, where he was named Horizon League Player of the Year in 2002. After university Lewis was drafted by the Atlanta Hawks in the 2003 NBA Draft, but was quickly traded to the the Kansas City Kings. He has been with the Kings ever since, and is one of the most respected and longest serving players in franchise history. In 13 years with the team, he has appeared in 899 regular season games and averaged 10.2 points, 3.2 rebounds, 1.8 assists, and 0.9 steals per game. Lewis is widely respected as a team leader, both through his play on the court and by his off-court activities. He is a regular participant in team youth basketball clinics, and is often a presence in the stands at Kings games, cheering and supporting his teammates. In addition to playing for the Kings, Lewis is a devoted philanthropist who, over the years, has provided financial support and guidance to charity organisations in his hometown of Moorestown, New Jersey. From 2007-12 he founded and ran the Danny Lewis Basketball Academy for young people aged 10-14, offering free basketball lessons and mentoring. In 2013 Lewis was named to the Kansas City Kings Hall of Fame, an honour bestowed upon players who have made a significant contribution to the team. He remains an active and influential member of the locker room, continuing to provide his veteran wisdom to the team and guide the younger players. In 2016, Lewis was awarded the NBA's prestigious Community Assist Award, recognising his numerous off-court charitable activities and community service. Lewis is a loved figure both in Kansas City and in his hometown of Moorestown. He is considered one of the classiest players in NBA history and is respected on and off the court.

The First Reading of the Emancipation Proclamation of President Lincoln was a historic event that took place on September 22, 1862. The proclamation declared that all persons held as slaves within the Confederate states would be declared free. This document was the legal precursor to the Thirteenth Amendment, which officially abolished slavery throughout the United States. The Emancipation Proclamation was drafted by President Abraham Lincoln and later shared with his Cabinet members. At the time, the attention of the country was largely focused on the Antietam Campaign, which was seen as a potentially decisive battle in the Civil War. Lincoln, however, wanted to issue a document that would make clear the United States’ intention to abolish slavery. On September 22, 1862, Lincoln delivered the first reading of the Emancipation Proclamation to the Cabinet. Present were the Secretary of State, William Seward; the Secretary of the Treasury, Salmon P. Chase; the Secretary of the Navy, Gideon Welles; the Secretary of War, Edwin M. Stanton; and the Attorney General, Edward Bates. The First Reading of the Emancipation Proclamation was a dramatic and emotional moment for Lincoln and the other members of the Cabinet. Lincoln stated that “in giving freedom to the slaves, we assure freedom to the free — honorable alike in what we give and what we preserve.” He also read an excerpt of the document, saying that “all persons held as slaves within any state, or designated part of a state, the people of which shall be in rebellion against the United States, shall be thenceforward and forever free.” Although it would take some time for the Thirteenth Amendment to be ratified, the First Reading of the Emancipation Proclamation was a monumental event in American history. It was the first action taken by the federal government to begin the process of abolishing slavery, and it ultimately paved the way for the passage of the Thirteenth Amendment. Despite the delay in ratification, it demonstrates that the President, and the country more broadly, wanted to take action in order to end the nation’s “peculiar institution.”

Per Magnus Johansson (b. March 17, 1958 in Helsingborg, Sweden) is a Swedish mathematician, specializing in analytic number theory and actor. He is a professor of mathematics at Lund University. Johansson received his PhD from Uppsala University in 1984 under the supervision of Prof. Lars Holm and Prof. Folke Lind. He held postdoctoral positions at Northwestern University, Uppsala and Lund before becoming a full professor of mathematics at Lund University in 1996. Johansson's research is mainly in analytic number theory and its applications in theoretical computer science. He is well known for his work on character sums, sieve theory and additive number theory. He has also researched complex analytic number theory and harmonic analysis related to prime numbers. He has written over 50 articles and two books on number theory and related topics. Johansson is committed to making mathematics more accessible to the general public. He has held a number of public lectures and seminars on mathematics, and hosted the television show "Matematik och Music", which aimed to make mathematics more popular. In addition to his accomplishments in mathematics, Johansson has also had a successful career as an actor. He has had roles in a number of Swedish television series and movies and also founded a theater group at Lund University. Johansson has been the recipient of numerous awards, including the Tir n’an Ogam of Excellence Award from the Irish Academy of Letters in 2010, the Fredrik Box Prize in 1996 and the Gro Wallin Prize in 2011. Johansson is married to Maria Watson and they have two children, Joshua and Miriam. He is an avid reader and enjoys travelling with his family.

The Jackson State Tigers basketball team is a college basketball program that represents Jackson State University in Jackson, Mississippi, United States. The Tigers compete in the NCAA Division I and are members of the Southwestern Athletic Conference (SWAC). The program has its origins in 1937 when, under the guidance of coach Robert "Gip" Gipson, the university's basketball program became the first African-American college basketball team in the country. The Tigers have appeared in the NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament four times, most recently in 2019. The team made its first major postseason appearance in 1980 when it reached the semifinals of the NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament. The Tigers have won four SWAC regular season championships and three SWAC Tournament championships. Notable Jackson State alums include Hall of Famers Bobby C. Watson and Lenny Wilkens. Watson was a member of the 1972 United States Olympic basketball team, which won the gold medal at the Munich games. Wilkens had a long and distinguished playing and coaching career, including a stint as head coach of the NBA's Atlanta Hawks. He was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1998. The current head coach of the Jackson State Tigers is Lewis Jackson. Jackson became head coach in 2013 after a nine-year stint at Saint Louis University as an assistant coach. In his four years as head coach of the Tigers, Jackson has led the team to two SWAC regular season titles and two SWAC Tournament championships. He was also named the 2015 SWAC Coach of the Year. Under Jackson's guidance, the Tigers have become one of the premier teams in the SWAC and have made three straight appearances in the NCAA Tournament. The team has also earned recognition nationally with numerous players receiving postseason awards and honors throughout Jackson's tenure. The Jackson State Tigers have established themselves as one of the top men's basketball programs in the Southwestern Athletic Conference and will continue to strive for excellence as they look to increase their on-court success in the coming years.

Huis Honselaarsdijk is a former castle, now it is a stately home and National Heritage Monument in the municipality of Woudrichem, in the province of North Brabant in the Netherlands. The building is situated at the Honselaarsdijk, a dike which is part of the Hollandse IJssel. The castle was built in the first half of the 16th century by Dirk van Honselaer and was initially used as a residence for the Van Honselaer family. The castle is surrounded by a moat, complete with a drawbridge and summer house. The castle has an irregular shape with four towers at the corners and a gatehouse in the middle. Its design and components make it a unique example of fortified Neoclassical architecture. The building has an overall height of 15 meters and a ground area of 680 square meters. It has three floors and five chambers. The ground floor is used as the entrance hall and the first floor contains the living and repose quarters. Huis Honselaarsdijk is still owned and maintained by its original family since the 16th century. It is registered in the inventory of the National Heritage Agency. The building and the park are open to public, without fee, during June and July. During these periods activities like guided tours and crafts workshops are organized. The castle also has a rich history of tactical battle engagements during the 80-year war and the Nijmegen campaign which makes it a popular destination among history and war buffs. Also in the past the castle had an interesting story about the Duke of Adriaan van Honselaer whom was the leader of the Geuzen forces during the Dutch war of independence from Spain. The castle is known for its gardens and the terraces that have been laid out before the castle. There is also a pontoon boat moored at the bank of the canal for which tourist can rent for a boat trip on the river Hollandse IJssel. These gardens and terraces have been awarded with the European Garden Award of Excellence in 2003. The stately home and its gardens form a unique setting for receptions and events. In 2014 Huis Honselaarsdijk was restored by TRD Systems and the gardens by Gabriels Groendesign. In 2015 Huis Honselaarsdijk was awarded a National Heritage Monument award by the organisation Monumenten.nl. Huis Honselaarsdijk is an important part of the history and culture of North Brabant and it serves as a symbol of hope, resilience and strength.

Sumner, Illinois is a small village in White County, Illinois, located along Illinois Route 1, which is four miles east of Carmi, the largest city in White County. The population of the village was 537 at the 2010 census. The area near the town was first settled in 1818. The village was named for an early settler, Jesse Sumner. Sumner is a predominantly agricultural community. It is home to several businesses including Sumner Locker and Meat Processing, Sumner Produce, Sumner Country Store, and Sumner Meat Processing. The village also features a small post office and park. The village is part of the Carmi-White County school district. There are four schools within the district, including two elementary schools, a middle school, and a high school. In addition, there are two private Christian schools, Cornerstone Baptist Academy and Carmi Christian Academy. The main festivals and events held in Sumner are the Sumner Festival, held in late May, and the Sumner Fair, held in late August. The Sumner Festival includes food, music, and games for all ages. The Sumner Fair is a two-day event featuring crafts, agriculature, and a 4-H exhibition. There are several churches in Sumner, including First Baptist Church, St Michael Catholic Church, and Big Prairie Church. The area surrounding Sumner is also home to several recreational parks, including White County State Park and Tunnell Hill Wildlife Area. Both parks offer numerous opportunities for camping, fishing, and other outdoor activities. Sumner is a small, friendly, rural community that is proud to be part of the greater southern Illinois region. It’s many festivals and recreational parks make it a great place to call home.

New Brunswick is the 8th largest province in Canada with a population of 777,811 as of 2019. It is the only constitutionally bilingual province in the federation. Due to its coastal location, the composition of New Brunswick's population is very diverse and has been impacted by different migrations throughout its history. The majority of the population (77.5%) is of European descent, including 39.5% French, 33.3% English, 8.7% Irish, 5.2 % Scottish, and 1.1% German. Additionally, about 5% of the provincial population is of Aboriginal descent, including the Mi'kmaq, Maliseet and Wolastoqiyik First Nation's Nations, and 3.2% reported mixed Aboriginal and European origin. Almost the entire province has a French-speaking majority. The main linguistic divide is between Acadian French-language speakers in the northeast and anglophone speakers in the southwest. New Brunswick is the only constitutionally bilingual province in the federation. This bilingualism has provided the province with unique influences. The province has several large cities and interesting cities as well. Saint John is the largest city, with a population of 115,000. It is the centre of business and industry in the province. Other major cities include Moncton, Fredericton, and Bathurst. These cities contain the majority of the province’s population, and their proximities to each other have made them integral in the development of the province’s economy. Outside of the major cities, there is an abundance of smaller communities and villages scattered throughout New Brunswick. These serve as important cultural hubs for the communities residing in the province. New Brunswickers are known for their warm hospitality and have a deep passion for their home which has been shaped by the province’s history. New Brunswick has both a rich cultural heritage and vibrant present-day art and culture. New Brunswick is a beautiful land of natural beauty, with coastal views and rolling hills, and is the ideal place to live and work. Immigrants looking to start a new life in Canada would do well to consider New Brunswick as their next home. In a province full of small towns and large cities, New Brunswick revolves around the people that call it home. Its rich and diverse population provides the backbone of the province, driven by an appreciation for the land and an impressive commitment to their home.

James V. Schall, S.J. (born January 3, 1928 in Walla Walla, Washington) was an American Jesuit priest and political philosopher. He was called one of the "most influential Catholic political theorists of the 20th century." He received an undergraduate degree from the University of Portland, graduating magna cum laude, followed by a master's degree from Gonzaga University. In 1952, Schall entered the Society of Jesus, where he studied at the Jesuit seminary St. Andrew’s Hall at Gonzaga and in 1955 was ordained a priest. He earned a Master of Arts and a Ph.D. from Georgetown University in political science. Schall taught political philosophy at Georgetown for thirty-five years, retiring in 1995, and is known especially for his work on classical political philosophy. His books include The Mind That is Catholic (1984), Another Sort of Learning (1988), On the Unseriousness of Human Affairs (1994), The Regensburg Lecture (2003), and A Student’s Guide to Liberal Learning (2004). Schall's works range widely over many areas and topics, such as reflections on the nature of liberal learning, discussions of the relationship between politics and morality, as well as studies of the ideas of Plato, Aristotle, St. Augustine, St. Thomas Aquinas, Edmund Burke, and John Courtney Murray, among others. Despite his vast knowledge of different minds, he opted for wide-ranging criticism of his modern age, instead of providing new positive doctrine. Schall was a consultant to the United States Department of State and a consultant to the 1995 Synod of Bishops of the Catholic Church, and was a member of the American Catholic Philosophical Association. He wrote on topics including the nature of liberal learning, philosophy of science, theological aesthetics, ancient and modern political philosophy, transnationalism and international relations, and globalisation and the loss of cultural identity. Along with his academic works, Father Schall served the Society of Jesus and the Roman Catholic Church. He received The Roman Award of the Order of St. Sylvester in 2005, conferred by Pope John Paul II and Pope Benedict XVI. Father Schall published fourteen books and over nine hundred articles in a variety of scholarly journals. He resided at the Jesuit Community of Georgetown University until his death on April 26, 2020. He was buried at the Jesuit Cemetery in Wernersville, Pennsylvania.

Castillo de San José, also known as Fort San José, is a historic fort located on Corazón de Tierra Island in the La Paz municipality of the Mexican state of Baja California Sur. The fort was built by the Spanish in 1705 to protect the territory of La Paz from invaders and pirates, who were a constant threat to the area at the time. The fort is made up of two parts: the land-side fort, which consists of an outer stone wall and an inner brick wall, and the sea-side fort, which consists of six bastions and protected the beach where ships would anchor. The walls of the land-side fort were constructed with locally-made mortars and bricks, while the sea-side fort was built with good stone. The fort was designed to house up to 400 soldiers, in addition to the cannons, guns, and artillery that defended the fortress. Inside the land-side fort, there were barracks, officers' quarters, a parade ground, and even a chapel dedicated to St. Joseph, from whom the fort derives its name. The fort served its purpose for over two centuries, although it fell into disrepair in the 19th century. In 1965, the fort was declared a Historical Monument of Mexico and efforts began to restore it to its former glory. Today, the fort is one of the most visited sites in La Paz, and tours are available to visitors who want to explore the fortress and learn about its history. The fort serves as a reminder of the importance of La Paz and its role in protecting the territory of Mexico during its colonial period. It also stands as a testament to the resilience of the local people against invaders and pirates. Castillo de San José is listed as part of the city's Historic Center, which is also a part of the Cultural Heritage of Humanity.

Richard Hounslow (born 1949) is a British flutist, conductor and educator. Born in London, Hounslow studied the flute at the Royal College of Music in London, where he was a student of Geoffrey Gilbert, and received a Bachelor of Music degree with honours in 1975. He has performed and recorded as a soloist with many renowned orchestras and ensembles including the London Symphony Orchestra, Academy of St. Martin in the Fields, Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, New Philharmonia Orchestra, London Sinfonia, English Baroque Soloists, and the BBC Concert Orchestra, among others. He has appeared on many recordings and at major festivals throughout Europe and the United States. As a chamber musician, Hounslow has performed in many notable venues including London's Wigmore Hall and the BBC Proms. Hounslow has been active in teaching for many years, beginning in 1975 when he joined the staff of the Royal College of Music in London. He has also lectured at Eton College, given master classes at universities across the United States and in South America, and served as a jury member for the BBC Young Musicians' Competition. In 1996, Hounslow was appointed Professor of Flute at the Royal College of Music. As a conductor, Hounslow worked with several orchestras including the Chamber Orchestra of Europe, London Chamber Orchestra, and English Chamber Ensemble. He has also worked as musical director for musical theater productions at the Royal Academy of Music, Royal College of Music, and on London's West End. He has made several critically acclaimed recordings with orchestras and ensembles, including Britten's A Ceremony of Carols, Elgar's Sons of Light, The Magic of Pan, and many others. Since 1997, Hounslow has been the director of music of the Barnet Youth Symphony Orchestra. Through this orchestra and his work in the community, he is committed to sharing the joy and power of music with young people and inspiring a wider audience for classical music. He was awarded an OBE for this and his long career of commitment to music in 2006. In addition to his career as a muscian, Hounslow is also a published author. He has written many works focused on performance, repertoire, and the history of music. His books include Flute: A Guide to the Repertoire, Flute Fingering Advances (co-authored with David James), The Art of Practising the Flute, Beginner's Guide to Flute Playing, and many others. Richard Hounslow is widely acknowledged as one of the foremost performers and teachers of the flute in the classical music world today. His career has seen him perform and conduct throughout the world, inspiring countless young musicians and introducing the joy of classical music to audiences of all ages.

The Ministry of Justice (Libya) is an administrative government body responsible for the administration of justice in Libya. It is headed by the Minister of Justice, who is nominated by the Prime Minister. Since Libya’s independence in 1951, the Ministry of Justice has served as the national legal body responsible for the enforcement of justice, adjudication of matters of law, and the administration of legal proceedings. The Ministry of Justice enforces domestic and international laws within Libya, and serves as the supervisory legal body for all other courts and agencies within the country.
