The Ministry of Justice is responsible for the formulation of legal regulations, and also for the supervision of their implementation. It ensures that all laws are respected, and holds authority over various governmental and private organizations and departments. The Ministry of Justice is responsible for the ensuring that the laws are enforced, and for providing effective access to the justice system for Libyan citizens. The Ministry of Justice drafts and maintains the laws of Libya and administers legal proceedings, forms the courts and chooses their staff, regulates the functions of the courts, and sets the legal dues, fees, and expenses. It also regulates the protection of civil rights in Libya. The Ministry of Justice comprises several divisions and departments, such as the Civil Affairs Department, the Criminal Affairs Department, the Personal Status Department, and the Economic Departments. The Ministry of Justice also issues pardons and provides opinions on legal matters to the government and Parliament. The Ministry is also responsible for the appointment and dismissal of judicial officials, including judges and court staff. The Ministry of Justice is charged with the implementation of the judicial and legal reforms undertaken by the government. In this regard, the Ministry is responsible for ensuring that the justice system responds to the needs of the citizens and provides a speedy and secure access to justice, when necessary. The Ministry of Justice works together with the Supreme Court and the Special Court of Appeals to ensure the rule of law and the protection of civil liberties. It is also the central institution charged with ensuring access to the justice system, including providing legal assistance and representation to citizens in court. The Ministry of Justice also oversees the implementation of international treaties and conventions, and works with governmental and non-governmental organizations to strengthen Libyan laws. The Ministry also coordinates international legal cooperation and exchanges with other countries. The Ministry of Justice publishes a number of legal periodicals and reports, as well as other legal documents of relevance to the citizens of Libya. The Ministry of Justice is the highest legal body in the country and serves as the main administrative and judicial authority in Libya.

Zu was an ancient Sumerian thunder god, as well as the god of weather, sky, and storms. He was often depicted holding a double edged axe and a bow, identifying him as a warrior god. He was associated with Erra, Ishum, and Adad. In addition, Zu was also sometimes given the epithet “king of the mountains”, implying that he controlled the power of the mountains. Some of Zu's primary roles were to protect the gods in their palaces and bestow rain upon the city of Nippur so that the land could be fertile and productive. During the Sumerian epic known as The Lament for Ur, Zu was condemned for stealing the Tablet of Destiny from the gods, resulting in them losing control of humankind. In Sumerian mythology, Zu was a powerful figure. He was known as the king of the birds and the protector of the divine kingship. He was sometimes considered to be the messenger of the gods, responsible for delivering the decrees of the gods to mankind. In some stories, Zu was said to have had a magical weapon, called the zicar, which was said to have the power to strike down evil at the behest of the gods. Zu was also said to have had divine attributes and powers, such as being able to raise up armies, grant oracles and be an avenger of the gods. He was described as a furious god, often unleashing great storms upon mankind. Some ancient religions also attributed creation and destruction to his power, suggesting that he was a powerful force for balance and justice. In art, Zu was often depicted alongside goddess Inanna, denoting their shared roles as warriors and leaders. He was occasionally depicted with the wings of a storm bird and the head of a lion. This form was used to illustrate his apocalyptic powers. As a cultural figure, Zu was a source of veneration and celebration in Sumerian culture. He was sometimes considered the enemy of Marduk, the chief god of Babylon. In some stories, he is cursed by Anu, the chief god of the Sumerian pantheon, for stealing the Tablet of Destiny and causing the Sumerian gods an immense amount of grief. Zu is often seen in modern media, particularly in popular fantasy works. He is sometimes depicted as a powerful figure or deity and is seen as an emblem of storm, chaos and destruction. Zu's image has become iconic among some fantasy fans, and his legacy continues to inspire wars and popular literature to this day.

. The National Register of Historic Places listings in Sullivan County, Indiana, document the history of the county and its many structures, sites, and districts. Established in 1966, the National Register of Historic Places is the United States federal government's official list of districts, sites, buildings, structures, and objects deemed worthy of preservation and recognition. The listings in Sullivan County, Indiana, include sites, buildings, structures, and objects located in the county. Sullivan County was organized in 1844, and many of the sites listed are associated with the earliest history of the county. These listings include places reflecting the diverse experiences of both rural and urban neighborhoods, from Indian mounds to the town square. Sullivan County also has rich railroad and agricultural history, and many sites associated with those industries are listed on the National Register as well. Of the 35 sites listed in Sullivan County, 28 are houses. These range from a Greek Revival farmhouse built in the 1840s to a modern ranch built in the 1950s. In addition to the houses, there are two churches, a cemetery, three barns, an office building, and a school. The listings also include cemeteries, Indian mounds, and the town square of Sullivan, the county seat. Of particular interest is the Patton Schoolhouse, built in 1884 and listed in 2001. The school is an example of an one-room rural schoolhouse, with its original wood frame construction, recessed door, and central chimney. Sullivan County’s architectural heritage is also documented through its two historic districts. The Carlisle Homeplace Historic District is one of the oldest districts in the state, dating back to the pre-Civil War era. It features a large collection of mid-nineteenth century homes along the Wabash River. The Sharon’s Corner Historic District preserves the history and architecture of a small community north of Sullivan. It features buildings from 1853 to the present and showcases a variety of vernacular, Italianate, and Greek Revival-style buildings as well as many contributing outbuildings and historic elements. The National Register of Historic Places in Sullivan County provides an important way to understand the history of the county and its people. The listings recognize and commemorate the various experiences, contributions, and landscapes of this rural Indiana community.

Megalopalpus zymna, also known by its common name, the yellow-headed beer moth, is a species of moth belonging to the family Crambidae. It is found across much of the Palearctic ecozone, ranging from parts of Europe to Central Asia and Siberia. It is particularly common in Central Europe, most notably in Germany and Austria. M. zymna moths typically measure between 14 and 18 mm in length, and feature a distinctive yellow head and base of the antennae. Their wings are a rich orange chestnut color, marked with some darker shading around the edges. On either side of the wings, a white, "L-shaped" pattern is visible, but more prominent in the males than in the females. The larvae of M. zymna feed on a variety of grasses and cereals, although they are most commonly found on barley and wheat. Additionally, they can be found on the leaves and stems of other cereal plants, such as oats, rye and maize. In Germany, the larvae are an important pest species, and considerable damage can be done to agricultural fields and grain stores. Adult M. zymna are typically active between June and October in most regions, although they can sometimes be found earlier in the season in southern parts of their range. After mating, the females lay their eggs on the leaves and stems of cereal plants, and the larvae emerge after around two weeks. They feed for approximately six weeks before pupating, developing into adult moths shortly afterwards. The larvae are subject to natural predators, including the predaceous midge Tanytarsus lateralis, which feeds exclusively on M. zymna larvae. Additionally, a number of parasitoid wasps, such as Oomyzus sokolowskii and Microplitis mediator, have been identified as natural enemies of the species. As a result of such natural control, large-scale population outbreaks of M. zymna are relatively rare. The species has also been known to be controlled through the usage of chemical pesticides, but more often by the destruction of crop residues and good hygiene practices, such as the removal of infested plant material from the fields. Biological control has also been employed in some areas, with various species of Trichogramma wasps being released to reduce the population size of M. zymna. In addition to its agricultural pest status, M. zymna is also regarded as an important pollinator species in many parts of Europe, pollinating cereal crops such as barley and wheat.This valuable role in crop production is generally overlooked, due to the species' status as an agricultural pest. Today, Megalopalpus zymna continues to be an important species in many areas across the Palearctic ecozone, with its agricultural pest status tightly intertwined with its role as a valuable crop pollinator. Despite the potential damage it can cause to cereal crops, the species remains an invaluable part of the region's ecosystem, and should be respected accordingly.

The Monroe Civic Center is located in Monroe, Louisiana and is an entertainment and convention center which hosts various events in the region. The Civic Center was opened in 1971 after the city of Monroe received funds from several sources, the chief being the U.S. Housing Agency. The original design was provided by architect Maxwell B. Moore and consisted of a 2,000-seat main auditorium, two 1,100-seat auditoriums, a conference and exhibit hall, a ballroom, and three cafeterias. The Monroe Civic Center holds events year-round representing many different types of entertainment and activities. Some of the events held here include trade shows and conventions, concerts, theatre productions, graduations, civic functions, and sporting events. The Civic Center has hosted a variety of musical acts such as Elvis Presley and ZZ Top, and comedians such as Jerry Seinfeld and Dave Chappelle. Various components have been added to the center over time to enhance its offerings, the largest of these being a $15 million renovation in 2008. This renovation increased the number of seats in the auditoriums and added a new dressing room and stage area. The renovation also added an arena addition which features bandshells, basketball courts and an event space with a capacity of over 4000 people. Today, the building is managed by SMG and is considered the main entertainment venue of the Northeast Louisiana area. The Monroe Civic Center continues to expand its offerings, hosting a variety of events in not just the main auditorium, but in the arenas, ballrooms and cafeterias as well. From trade shows and conventions, to graduations and sporting events, the center gives locals and visitors of Monroe a variety of entertainment choices.

Edward Curr (1798-1850) was an English-born Australian pioneer and landholder. He was born in Hipperholme, near Halifax, West Yorkshire, England. He migrated to Van Diemen's Land (now Tasmania) in 1824, to capitalize on the free grants of land available to emigrants. Curr was the eldest son of Richard Curr and his wife Elizabeth, née Crabtree. Curr was very active in the early development and growth of Australia's fledgling pastoral industry, and established successful runs in Victoria and South Australia. He made numerous journeys around Victoria and New South Wales, and was one of the first English explorers to cross overland from Van Diemen's Land to the mainland. In 1835, Curr explored the country south-west of Port Philip (now Melbourne) and named the area Western Port district. Curr's explorations generally involved scouring the countryside for suitable land for sheep grazing. As well as exploring and developing land for Australia's wool industry, Curr saw the potential for capitalizing on the Trans-Australian railway in the early 1830s. He leased and purchased several large land properties in the Port Phillip district, and established a successful trading post in the region. This post specialized in supplying produce and wares to remote settlements in the area. In 1836, Curr was appointed gunner of Port Fairy and, later, of Portland district. He also successfully managed a number of properties that he had acquired in the region. Curr was the driving force behind the establishment of a sawmill at Port Fairy, and is credited with introducing the first barley and potatoes to the area. In addition to his profitable venture in trading and land acquisitions, Curr was a leading figure in the development of education in the region. He established and endowed a school for boys and girls in Port Fairy in 1856. In 1845, his wife, Mary, established the Edward Curr Children's Home in Rupanyup. The Catholic order of St. Patricks, which ran the home, provided a midpoint between the convict settlements and the frontiers of the new colonies. In death, Curr left a considerable estate, which included grazing and dairying properties, sawmills, and country store businesses. He is remembered as a pioneer and capitalist who played an important role in the development of early Australian pastoralism. He was honoured in the naming of Victorian towns, including Currie, a township in the Wimmera Region in Victoria. Curr died in Portland, Victoria on 13 December 1850. He was survived by his wife and seven children.

Josh Ginnelly (born October 5th, 1996) is an English professional football player who plays as a winger for Floriana F.C. in the Maltese Premier League. Born in Stourbridge, West Midlands, Ginnelly began his career with Wolverhampton Wanderers before signing a professional contract with League One side Shrewsbury Town in 2013. Ginnelly made his debut for The Shrews in a 1–1 draw with MK Dons on 15th August 2015. Ginnelly helped the club gain promotion to League One in the 2016/17 season, during which he scored 8 goals and provided 8 assists in 50 appearances. He also scored the winner in their 4–3 win over Northampton Town on 17th February 2017, a goal which was ultimately nominated for the Sky Bet League Two Goal of the Season. Ginnelly left Shrewsbury in July 2018, transfer to Preston North End, who had been tracking his progress since his Shrewsbury debut. He was a regular in the Preston side over two seasons and was part of the team which reached the play-off semi-finals in 2020. In August 2020, Ginnelly moved abroad for the first time, joining Maltese Premier League side Floriana F.C on a two-year contract. Ginnelly scored on his debut in a 2–1 win over Tarxien Rainbows in November 2020, and he scored again in a 2–0 victory over Gzira United in February 2021. He has become an important player in Cristiano Lucarelli's squad, providing width and attacking threat to the team. Away from his football career, Ginnelly has also been involved in charity work. In October 2020, he raised money for The James Wilkie Ginnelly Foundation which was set up in memory of his cousin who died in a house fire in 2019. The charity aims to raise money to buy and install smoke alarms in homes. Ginnelly is currently injury free and looking forward to helping Floriana finish the season strongly. He will be hoping to pick up his fifth promotion from the fourth tier in 2021-22.

Cambodia–India relations refer to the bilateral relations between India and Cambodia. Diplomatic ties between the two countries date back to a friendly cultural and trade exchange through the 1st century AD, when Cambodian troops aided King Ashoka in his battles. India recognized Cambodia's independence from France in 1953 and established diplomatic relations in the same year. India has provided small-scale economic and military assistance to Cambodia, while economic relations between the two countries are minimal. India was one of the first countries to set up a diplomatic mission in Cambodia during the post-independence period. The then Minister, Pran Nath Thapar, opened the India-Cambodia diplomatic mission in 1954. This diplomatic mission was an expression of India's trust, friendship and cooperation with the newly independent Cambodian nation. The then Prime Minister of India, Jawaharlal Nehru and Chief of State Norodom Sihanouk made exchanges during 'Festival of India' held in the year 1959 in Phnom Penh. India is considered a major supporter and friend of Cambodia in the international arena. It supported the inclusion of Cambodia in ASEAN and was also a major participant in the United Nations Transitional Authority for Cambodia (UNTAC) which administered the 1993 elections in Cambodia. India is currently the second largest provider of financial assistance to Cambodia since the formation of the government in 1993. It has contributed US$ 3 million since 1993 and a further US$ 4 million in 2010 for Cambodia's development projects. The Government of India is also actively promoting investment by Indian companies in Cambodia. India increased its aid to Cambodia as a gesture of friendship and goodwill to focus on education, health and agricultural sectors. A Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) has also been signed between India and Cambodia. India also provides assistance in capacity building in the fields of agriculture, rural development, IT and communications. Dialogues between India and Cambodia are focussed on strengthening bilateral cooperation. The two countries discussed cooperation in areas such as energy, health, education, agricultural development, tourism, and culture, among others. India is also helping to train Cambodian personnel in India's research and educational institutions, especially in the field of IT. There is also close political and defense cooperation between India and Cambodia. India and Cambodia also have close cultural ties. Buddhism is a major cultural connection between the two countries. Both countries have major Buddhist sites that attract thousands of pilgrims from around the world. From time to time cultural exchange programmes between the two countries are organised to strengthen the bilateral relationship. Cambodia–India relations are strong and growing. Both the leaders from both sides have shown strong commitment to consolidating and deepening the ties. There is potential for much greater bilateral engagement, especially in the fields of trade, investment and tourism.

Kue cubit, also known as Kue pancong, is a traditional Indonesian snack originating in the city of Jogjakarta. It is a type of deep-fried cake made from rice flour, water, coconut milk and palm sugar, featuring a light sweet taste with a crispy golden-brown crust. The name "Kue cubit" literally translates as "fingers cake". It derives from the way it is traditionally eaten; diners using their fingers to break the small cubes of cake into smaller pieces and dip them into a liquid accompaniment. Kue cubit is enjoyed as a dessert or snack throughout Indonesia, although it is most popular in Yogyakarta and the eastern Java region. It is usually sold as a street food, especially in tourist spots and night markets. The most popular accompaniment to kue cubit is a dark black syrup made from palm sugar and pandan extract, giving the cake a fragrant and subtly sweet taste. Other accompaniments range from rich condensed milk to spicy sambal or savory seafood toppings. Kue cubit remains a common snack item in most areas of Indonesia. It is commonly served during festive occasions such as Eid al-Fitr, and is often served as part of a buffet spread. The cakes can be purchased ready-made from individual vendors, or freshly made via a kue cubit machine; a specialized device consisting of two hot griddles on which a premade paste of the ingredients is pressed into thin cubes. Kue cubit is thought to have evolved from the traditional Chinese youtiao, a deep-fried savory snack, which was previously popular in parts of Indonesia. It is believed to have been influenced by the Dutch colonization of the archipelago, with the introduction of palm sugar, leading to the cakes being crafted with a sweeter flavor profile become more prominent. Today, there are many variations of kue cubit around Indonesia, from sweetened to savory, with fillings such as egg and cheese, chocolate, and durian. Kue cubit can be eaten for breakfast as well as for dessert, and adapted for a wide range of occasions. With its delicate sweet flavor and crisp texture, kue cubit is an integral part of Indonesian food culture.

Jody McCrea (July 6, 1934 - August 15, 2009) was an American actor, best known for his roles in 1950s Westerns and his connection to his father, actor Joel McCrea. McCrea was born in Los Angeles, California. He was the only child of actors Joel McCrea and Frances Dee. He served briefly in the United States Navy, before beginning his acting career in 1950, appearing alongside his father in the film These Wilder Years. He appeared in a number of westerns over the next few years, including The Missouri Traveler (1958), Summer and Smoke (1961), Gunfight at Comanche Creek (1963), Ride Beyond Vengeance (1966). He became a professional stuntman in 1968, and worked on a number of movies and television shows. McCrea was well known for his Westerns, often playing roles of cowboys and gunslingers. He was featured in several episodes of the classic western Gunsmoke, and made a number of guest appearances on other programs, including The Virginian and Rawhide. He also appeared in the television movie A Man Called Sledge (1970). In addition to his acting career, McCrea had a lifelong interest in flying. In 1975, he became the owner and operator of Jody McCrea Aviation, a passenger service providing trips in his Cessna 140 airplane. Throughout the 1990s, he flew people to a variety of destinations, including an annual fly-in to Catalina Island, California. In 2009, McCrea died at the age of 75. He received a memorial service at a Santa Monica, California cemetery and his ashes were scattered into the Pacific Ocean near San Clemente island. In 1989, he was inducted into the Hall of Great Western Performers of the National Cowboy & Western Heritage Museum. His son Derryl McCrea, who works in aviation, continues the McCrea family tradition.

The 1926–27 Clarkson Golden Knights men's ice hockey season was the 4th season of play for the program. The Golden Knights were coached by Harry Easler and played their home games at the Memorial Arena in Potsdam, New York. The team posted a 6–1–1 record and finished second in the first ever conference standings. Clarkson compiled a 3–0–1 mark against conference opponents which included a win over the Rensselaer Engineers, who captured the first conference championship. The Golden Knights played their first game to a 4–4 tie against the Toronto Marlboros hockey club on December 14, 1926. Clarkson then captured their first win the following night against Ottawa Collegiate. The squad earned two victories and a tie against their opponents from outside of the conference for the season, including a thrilling come from behind victory on the road against the Syracuse Athletic Club. The game finished with a score of 5–4 which featured four goals from Clarkson in the final twelve minutes of the third period. The team was led by All-American Johnson who had only just transferred to the school from Hamilton. Johnson was joined by stalwart defensemen Harold Hill and "Shorty" Hall, who both contributed to the team's success. The Golden Knights would end the season on a successful note with a 2–2 tie to the Sault Ste. Marie Greyhounds. Clarkson's performance during the regular season had earned them an invitation to participate in the 1927 annual tournament in Troy, New York. The Golden Knights were unable to capitalize on the opportunity however, managing only a single tie and two losses in the tournament. The memory of the 1926–27 campaign lived on in the years that followed, with many of those involved, such as Johnson and Easler, going on to become important figures in the hockey community. The success of the Golden Knights during the season helped put Clarkson hockey on the map and was a starting point for further accomplishments by the program in the years to come.

Rosemont College is a private liberal arts college located in Rosemont, Pennsylvania. Founded in 1921 by the Sisters of the Holy Child Jesus, Rosemont is part of a network of 25 independent Catholic colleges and universities across the United States. Rosemont offers more than 40 undergraduate majors and minors, as well as nine graduate and doctoral programs. The college offers seasonal study abroad programs in countries such as Italy, Mexico, and Spain. Rosemont's main campus consists of 51 acres in Lower Merion, Pennsylvania, just outside of Philadelphia. The core campus includes four academic buildings, all organized around an open quadrangle. Along with traditional, on-campus housing, the college also offers a variety of non-traditional housing options, including themed residencies, and supplemental housing for graduate students. The college has a strong commitment to social justice and service. Rosemont sponsors a number of service learning projects each year, as well as seven service trips to different countries every summer. Its robust extra-curricular activities include a wide range of student clubs, honor societies, athletic teams, and student government. Its service organizations include Amnesty International, the Red Cross Club, and the Humane Society Club. Rosemont's Career Development Office helps students with career exploration, job shadowing, internships, and other professional opportunities. The office also has a job board with over 600 job postings. Rosemont partners with a variety of employers to connect its students with career-oriented experiences. Rosemont College has a vibrant alumni network that provides opportunities for social and professional networking. Alumni have gone on to serve in positions of leadership in industry, government, education, health care and other fields. They provide a support network for graduates, offering networking possibilities, internships, and job postings through their LinkedIn group. Rosemont College prides itself as a strong community with a diverse student body, excellent faculty, rich history and traditions, and a commitment to academic excellence.

Roseland Cottage is a historic home in Woodstock, Connecticut owned by Henry Bowen, a successful entrepreneur and philanthropist. Built in 1846-47, it is one of the finest examples of Greek Revival architecture in the country, and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The home was designed by architect Henry Dudley, who specialized in Greek Revival architecture. The home was completed in 1847 and cost Bowen, who was a banker and merchant, the then-astronomical sum of $25,000. A contemporary chronicler said the house was "the most ornate and perfect specimen of architecture that probably ever existed in New England". Roseland Cottage has a total of 20 rooms, spread across 11,060 square feet. Several of these rooms have been restored and have distinctive features from the Greek Revival style, including bay windows and Greek columns. On the first floor, the parlor features a marble Carrara mantelpiece, which is believed to have originated in Italy in the 1850s. The home is meticulously maintained and has been the recipient of several awards, including the Connecticut Historical Society's Katherine Grandjean Award and the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation Award. Henry Bowen was a successful businessman who lived in the home until his death in 1899. During his life he was an active philanthropist, setting up educational funds, endowing a church, and restoring other historic sites in the area. Today, Roseland Cottage is not just owned by the National Historic Landmarks Program. It is also operated as a museum and park. Visitors to the home can enjoy tours, educational programs, and special events, such as an annual holiday program that celebrates the history of the home and of Henry Bowen and his family. Roseland Cottage is a classic example of Greek Revival architecture and a standout landmark in Woodstock, Connecticut. Its meticulously maintained interior and exterior remain much the same as it was when Bowen first moved in all those decades ago.

Flags of Norwegian subdivisions refers to the various flags which are specifically used to represent the Norwegian subnational entities of the country. Norwegian subnational entities consist of the country's 19 administrative regions and 430 municipalities. The majority of these flags, especially for the administrative regions, belong to the Nordic Cross style. The usage of flags for the Norwegian subnational entities started off with simple banners, emblems and logos. As the usage of flags began to slowly spread, more advanced designs were adopted with intricate symbols and colours. The current flags used for the administrative regions all consist of the Nordic Cross style pattern. The colours used in these flags are inspired by the national colours of Norway, while the symbols normally depict regional characteristics, such as mountains and other local features. The Norwegian Flag Law of 1980 established a set of regulations and guidelines for the use of flags for the municipalities in Norway. It required municipalities to register any flag designs with the police before being allowed to use it officially. According to the law, all municipal flags must have the municipality's name written below the Nordic Cross style and the colours must not clash with those used in the country's flag. Additionally, a municipal banner can only be used officially if it has been approved by the municipality. The law also placed several restrictions in the context of the use of banners, including the banning of any religious symbols. This resulted in the banning of the flags of traditional Norwegian Sami communities as they normally include symbols of Norse paganism. Despite being guided by the same regulations and having similar design styles, each municipality's flag is unique to its particular area. The range of elements differ depending on the region, with some showing the country's national colours along with their own and others displaying specific patterns, such as criss-crossed lines. Today, flags of Norwegian subnational entities are used in a variety of settings such as on front doors, car windows and public buildings. They represent the country's diverse regions and provide a visual representation of Norwegian identity and culture. References 1. An Introduction to the Flags of Norwegian Subregions. https://knowingnorway.com/culture/flags-of-norwegian-subregions/ 2. The Flag Law of 1980. https://lovdata.no/dokument/NL/lov/1980-05-30-14/KAPITTEL_2#KAPITTEL_2 3. Flag Laws and State Arms in Norway. http://www.fotw.net/flags/no-law.html

William N. Roach is an American artist and educator. He is best known for his work in the painting medium as an Abstract Expressionist and as an author of numerous books about the history of painting and art education. Roach was born in 1917 in Brooklyn, New York. He graduated from Pratt Institute of Technology in 1965 and from Columbia University in 1969. He has lived in Santa Fe, New Mexico since 1967. From 1971 until his death in 2001, Roach served as a professor at the Southwest Campus of the California College of the Arts in Oakland, Califomia. Roach was a professor at numerous colleges and universities in the United States and abroad, including Schule für Gestaltung Basel in Switzerland, Kyoto University in Japan, and the Rhode IslandSchool of Design. Throughout his career, Roach had a diverse creative practice, including works in painting, drawing, printmaking and sculpture. His work is characterized by bright, saturated colors and bold mark-making. In the early 1970s, he developed a mechanical painting technique similar to stamping, which he referred to as the “ink master.” He is best known, however, for his Abstract Expressionist paintings, which he began producing in the 1980s. Roach was the recipient of numerous awards and honors for his work, including grants from the National Endowment for the Arts, the New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Japanese/American Friendship Commission, as well as the Merit Award from the National Endowment for the Humanities. In 1999, he was honored with a retrospective exhibition at the Triton Museum of Art in Santa Clara, California. In addition to his paintings, Roach wrote numerous essays and books, including “Artistic Criticism: A Guide to Reading and Understanding,” “Painting Materials and Techniques,” and “Understanding Creation: The Basics of Art and Art History.” Roach is widely recognized as an influential educator, whose influential works in painting and writing have been studied by generations of artists and art educators. He was an important early ambassador of Abstract Expressionism and is remembered as one of the originators of this seminal art movement. William N. Roach passed away in 2001 in Santa Fe, New Mexico.

The Gender Equality and Family Development Select Committee is a committee of the National Assembly of Thailand. The committee is chaired by Rangsima Rodrasamee, a member of the Pheu Thai Party. The committee was established on 18 August 2020 to serve the functions of reviewing policies related to the gender equality and family development. This includes monitoring and formulating laws, policies, and regulations, as well as conducting research, surveys and studies in order to propose legislative measures aimed at promoting gender equality and family development. The committee also works to promote gender equality in society and to prevent and protect people from violations of gender equality and related laws and regulations. Through policy guidance and recommendations, the committee hopes to create an environment conducive to family Unity and stability. The committee’s activities are focused on implementation, legislative and economic support for the objectives of the national gender equality and family development policy. This includes the provision of education and training, financial support, and a range of services to empower women, including social protection and access to health care. In addition, the committee’s activities are focused on preventing and resolving family problems and protecting vulnerable persons, such as women and children. The committee works in accordance with the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women and the Convention on the Rights of the Child, as well as national legislation. The committee consists of 18 members. It meets at least once every two months. The Gender Equality and Family Development Select Committee of the National Assembly is instrumental in creating a stronger, more equitable society for all. By advancing the rights of vulnerable persons, including women and children, the committee is helping create a more inclusive and just society.

Yury Dud (21 March 1946 – 11 April 2021) was a Russian film director, screenwriter, and producer. He was known for his work on the cult classic television series Vojna i mir (1977–1978) and the film Ubit prezidenta (1982). Born in the city of Kostroma, Russia, Dud graduated from the Moscow Literary Institute in 1969 with a degree in philology and later graduated from the Moscow All-Russian State Institute of Cinematography (VGIK) in 1973 with a master's degree in directing. During his career, Dud worked as a production designer, assistant director, and director on various Russian and Soviet feature films. His first project was the 1976 film, Devochka po Komsomolsku, which won Best Young Director Prize of the Christina Award. In 1977, Dud was hired to direct and write the script for the war epic, Vojna i mir, which was adapted from Leo Tolstoy's novel War and Peace. The project aired as a 16-part television miniseries in the United States, Canada, Europe, and Japan, and won numerous awards, including the Prize for Best Television Series at the 1980 Moscow International Film Festival. Dud's other notable credits as director include the 1982 comedy Ubit prezidenta, and the 1989 drama Daynik. For the latter, Dud was nominated for the Best Director / Best Screenplay Oscar at the 1991 International Academy of Television Arts & Sciences. In 1994, Dud was honored with the Russian State Award for Cinematic Arts, a prestigious prize that is only awarded to the most outstanding filmmakers of their generation. In 1999, Dud founded Prostranstvo-Film, a production and distribution company that would go on to produce and finance a number of successful feature films, as well as the popular 2007–2008 web series, The Adventures of Yury Dud. Yury Dud passed away on 11 April 2021 after fighting a long illness. He was 75 years old.

An Inconvenient Tax is an economic tax policy idea proposed by renowned economists Steve Fazzari and William Gale in 2017 as an alternative to both traditional tax cuts and the basic health care and national safety net programs. An Inconvenient Tax is the concept of increasing taxes on people with higher incomes, such as those earning more than $250,000 or $500,000 annually. This increase would offset some or all of the cost of providing health insurance and national safety net programs. The idea of An Inconvenient Tax is to create a tax structure better configured to support necessary social and economic policies, including health care, education, and job training. It would also put more of the tax burden on wealthier households, despite their smaller amounts of taxable income, in order to increase revenues and reduce income inequality. Supporters argue that An Inconvenient Tax would be more effective at increasing revenue, reducing inequality, and increasing funding for key social services than traditional tax reform policies. Moreover, they contend that the new tax structure would be more equitable and would help alleviate poverty and its associated problems. Additionally, they suggest the tax structure would make it easier to finance public investment such as infrastructure projects that could potentially boost the economy. Critics worry that implementing the An Inconvenient Tax would cause wealthy households to reduce their spending, resulting in decreased investment and fewer job opportunities. Additionally, it may be difficult to track how much money wealthy households actually owe to the federal government. Despite concerns over implementation and impact, the idea of An Inconvenient Tax continues to gain attention from policy makers and economists. They argue that it could be an effective means of helping fund social services, reducing income inequality, and providing more market assurance to middle and lower income households. The policy though will require careful implementation if it is to be successful.

Arengo and Freedom is a project born out of the belief that freedom of speech should not be limited to any gender, race, class, or nationality. This project encourages constructive dialogue and diverse perspectives from both sides of the debate. It promotes mutual understanding and an appreciation of the necessity of both personal freedoms and the rule of law. The project was founded in 2018 by two women in the United States: Natalie Williams and Leah Long. They saw that while much public discourse dealt with socio-economic and political issues, there was a lack of open debate and dialogue on themes related to personal freedoms. This led to the creation of Arengo and Freedom. The project focuses on three main ideas: a free space for dialogue, responsible free expression, and democratic action. It encourages people to engage in open and honest conversations, regardless of political boundaries, in order to find common ground, even when there are disagreements. Arengo and Freedom provides a platform for both heated debates and thoughtful exchanges. There are Facilitated Conversations, Debates, and Workshops. Facilitated Conversations focus on generating understanding through respectful dialogue, and Debates provide a platform for a structured argument. Workshops are based on the principles of energy democracy and collaborative democracy, aiming to creating a culture of mutual learning and respect. Arengo and Freedom also works to build collaboration between civil society organizations, governments, and other groups. Currently the project is funded by private donors and it is planning to work with the public sector in order to increase the project’s capacity to reach a wider range of social actors. Arengo and Freedom has been featured in international and domestic publications, including Huffington Post, The Guardian, and Medium. It is seen as a champion of freedom of speech and a platform to challenge conservative culture and power structures. The mission of the project remains to create a vibrant space for meaningful conversations, respectful dialogue, and the expression of diverse ideas. As stated by one of the project’s founders, Leah Long: “The Arengo and Freedom project focuses on creating a positive, inclusive space for free people to have memorable conversations and take action. People learn more when they talk to each other, rather than about each other.”

MS Cruise Roma was a cruise liner built in 1972 in the Netherlands and operated until 2014. It was owned and operated by German company G & P Cruise Line, which also operated other vessels in the Mediterranean. The vessel was Sea going, equipped with 20 cabins and could accommodate up to 40 passengers. Its length was 28.5 meters and it had a beam of 5.6 meters. It was powered by a single four-cylinder diesel engine and carried two paddle-wheels for propulsion. During its time in the Mediterranean, MS Cruise Roma sailed all year round from port-to-port as regular avantages and special events including cruises to Sicily, Sardinia and Corsica. Its regular route was from Genoa to Civitavecchia, Italy. The ship was well-maintained throughout its life and was equipped with a variety of amenities such as restaurants, bars, lounges and an observation deck. It also provided cable TV and fitness services, with an enclosed pool and spa deck. The ship crisscrossed the Mediterranean Sea, carrying passengers to some of the most beautiful destinations in the region. Some of these destinations included Palermo in Sicily, Calvi in Corsica, and Genoa in Italy. In addition, it also made regular stops at other Mediterranean ports such as Naples, Cannes and Marseille. Due to its smaller size, the ship offered a more intimate cruise experience to its passengers, being able to access many ports that larger vessels could not enter. In 2014, the vessel had its last voyage and the G & P Cruise Line sold it soon after. Since then, the MS Cruise Roma has disappeared from the Mediterranean waters where it spent its last days giving passengers a unique experience.

Hurricane Harvey was one of the most destructive and powerful hurricanes to affect the United States in recorded history. It was a Category 4 hurricane on the Saffir–Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale that made landfall near Rockport, Texas on August 25, 2017. It then weakened as it moved back out over water and ended up making a second landfall near Cameron, Louisiana on August 30. Harvey caused an estimated US$125 billion in damage, making it one of the costliest natural disasters in U.S. history. In total, the storm damaged or destroyed more than 203,000 homes and other structures and disrupted the lives of more than 13 million people. The storm’s impacts began before it made landfall, as Harvey lingered in the coastal waters off the Texas coast for almost a week, bringing torrential downpours and flooding in its wake. This extended period brought an estimated 30-40 inches of rainfall to portions of the Houston-Galveston region over a four-day period. Over the course of just five days, some areas of Houston recorded more than 50 inches of rain. The impact was almost universal, as flooding damaged or destroyed homes and other infrastructure throughout much of southeastern Texas and western Louisiana. Over 50 counties and parishes declared disasters in the wake of the storm, and the damage to the energy sector extended to oil refineries, pipelines and offshore oil platforms. In the end, Hurricane Harvey had dropped a record-breaking total of more than 60 inches of rain near Nederland, Texas, making it the wettest tropical cyclone on record in the continental United States. This, combined with the estimated 214 billion gallons of rain that fell in the state, resulted in wide-scale and lasting damage throughout Texas. In response to the disaster, government entities, businesses and charitable organizations provided aid to both individuals and communities affected by the storm. A number of celebrities also donated to those in need and held fundraising events. Moving forward, officials are now considering changes to building codes and infrastructure in order to reduce the impacts of future storms.

Johnny Wright (born January 21, 1984) is a retired professional boxer from Brooklyn, New York. He competed in the Light Middleweight division, and held several regional titles throughout his career. Wright began boxing at the age of twelve and had his first professional fight in 2001 when he was seventeen years old. He won his first fight by a unanimous decision and went on to fight a total of sixteen times in his first year as a professional. During the course of his career, Wright had a total of thirty-five fights, compiling a record of 25 wins, 8 losses and 2 draws. At the beginning of his career, Wright was known for his good hand speed, power, and aggressive style. He was quick to overwhelm his opponents with an impressive flurry of punches. As his career progressed, he developed into a more balanced boxer and was known for being able to out-box his opponents and win on points. Wright held several regional championships including the U.S. Boxing Association (USBA) light middleweight title, the International Boxing Council (IBC) light middleweight title, the World Boxing Union (WBU) light middleweight title, the World Boxing Organization (WBO) middleweight title, the WBA International Super Middleweight title, and the WBC Silver Super Welterweight title. In his last fight, Johnny Wright took on a young WBO World Champion Demetrius Andrade. Despite his valiant effort, Wright ended up losing the fight on points. After this final loss, he decided to retire from boxing in 2008. He has remained in the sport, however, as a trainer and mentor. He is best known for his work with his father "Bubba" Wright, one-time light welterweight champion of the world, and his son Joseph Wright, the current WBC Continental Americas Super Lightweight Champion. Wright has been inducted into the Brooklyn Boxing Hall of Fame due to his contributions to the sport and his local community. He is known in Brooklyn for his mentorship of local youth and his community outreach works, helping to promote boxing in different areas of the city. Johnny Wright has remained an integral part of the boxing community. He is currently an active mentor and trainer of boxers, aiding in the development of some of the best young fighters in Brooklyn, New York.

The 154th meridian west is a line of longitude that approximately passes through the U.S. states of Colorado, Kansas, and Oklahoma, as well as the countries of Mexico and Canada. It forms a great circle with the 126th meridian east. The meridian 154° west of Greenwich is a line of longitude that passes through the following areas: Mexico: Baja California Sur United States: Colorado, Kansas, Oklahoma Canada: Alberta In the United States, the meridian defines the western boundaries of the cities of Limon, Colorado; Liberal, Kansas; and El Reno, Oklahoma. In Canada, the meridian marks the northern boundary of the Foothills Natural Region of Alberta. It is 30 minutes of arc and 1500 statute miles in length. To the east, the line passes through the eastern borders of the states of Colorado and Kansas, crossing the lower portions of the Oklahoma panhandle. To the west, the meridian intersects the Mexican states of Baja California Sur and Sonora. In Canada, the meridian intersects the province of Alberta, passing just east of the city of Calgary. The 154th meridian west is the basis for measuring time zones in parts of Canada and the United States. In these areas, the time is based on the local mean solar time at the meridian. In the United States, these time zones are known as Mountain Standard Time for areas near the Rocky Mountains, and Central Standard Time for other states. In Canada, the time zone at the meridian is known as the Mountain Time Zone. In aviation, the meridian is the divider of high altitude airspace between the two countries, with flights at or above this altitude needing to request clearance from the controlling agency of the country they are flying into. The 154th meridian is also the divider of International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) flight information regions between the U.S. and Canada. The 154th meridian is located to the east of the Rocky Mountains, and to the west of the Great Plains. It follows the course of the lower portion of the Arkansas River, and it intersects the Rio Grande near El Paso, TX. The 154th meridian is also close to the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail, which passes through parts of the states of Kansas, Oklahoma, and Arkansas. The 154th meridian passes through several national parks, such as Big Bend National Park in Texas and Rocky Mountain National Park in Colorado. It also intersects the Wichitas National Forest in Oklahoma.

Benjamin Franklin Tracy (July 14, 1830 – July 22, 1915) was an American politician, statesman, and lawyer from New York. A member of the Republican Party, he served as Secretary of the Navy in President Benjamin Harrison's cabinet from 1889 to 1893. He also played a major role in the Spanish–American War. Born in Stanwich, Connecticut, Tracy was educated at Union College in Schenectady and graduated in 1852. He subsequently studied law and began a practice in New York City. He served in the Union Army during the Civil War and was a brigadier general by July 1865. Tracy was an early member of the Republican Party and was elected to the House of Representatives in 1876. He was a Patrick Henry-style states' rights Democrat until 1877, when he joined the Republican Party. He served in the House until 1881, when he was elected to the Senate. In 1889, President Benjamin Harrison appointed Tracy as Secretary of the Navy. During his tenure in the Navy Department, he was responsible for the transformation of the fleet from sail to steam, the introduction of new ordnance, and the expansion of the Reserve Force. In 1891, Tracy was instrumental in successfully mediating a controversy with Great Britain over the seal fisheries on the Pacific Coast. Under Tracy's leadership, the Navy Department also helped establish a military academy in the Philippines. Tracy's tenure as Navy Secretary was also noted for his efforts during the Spanish–American War of 1898. Under his command, the U.S. Navy was quickly organized and mobilized, and achieved great success in the early battles at Manila Bay, Santiago Bay, and Caput Island. All three battles were major victories for the United States and solidified the nation's supremacy in The Philippines. Tracy left the Navy Department in 1893 and resumed the practice of law in New York. He retired from public life in 1902 and died at his home in Brooklyn on July 22, 1915. He was buried in Prospect Hill Cemetery in Glens Falls, New York.

Sophronia primella is a species of moth belonging to the family Oecophoridae, which was first described by Möschler in 1860. The species is widely distributed in the Caribbean, parts of the United States (Arizona and Florida, for example) and feeds on the larva of the witchhazel leaf beetle and other small-sized insects. The adult moths are most active from April to June and can be found hovering near shrubs during the night. The wingspan of the species spans from 10 to 12 mm, with the overall appearance of the moth being yellowish or buff colored. The bodies of Sophronia primella are very small and slender, with the antennae being highly visible. Their wings are dark brown with white and yellow transverse lines, and the Hindwings being darker brown than the forewings. The size of the moth also makes it an ideal candidate for biocontrol of the witchhazel leaf beetle and other small-sized beetles. The caterpillars of the Sophronia primella feed on the leaves of a wide range of host plants, such as elm, ash, maple and hawthorn. This can cause extensive damage to the trees, which is why the caterpillars are sometimes used as a form of biocontrol to minimise their impacts on trees. Inspecting and controlling populations of Sophronia primella is necessary in order to prevent any economic or environmental damage to host plants, as well as any other damage caused by the caterpillars. The adult moths may be collected using light traps, while the caterpillars can be easily identified and controlled with various insecticides. In addition to its control use, Sophronia primella has been increasingly receiving attention from the scientific community due to its potential application in biomedical and biotechnological research. Research is ongoing on the potential uses of the species’ extract for drug delivery and medical device coatings, as well as its development for enzyme inhibition and cell biology research. Sophronia primella is an interesting and important species due to its wide geographic distribution and potential use in research, as well as its use for controlling the populations of other beetle species. Controlling its populations is necessary to prevent any further damage to host plants, as well as increasing awareness on the potential uses for the species in biotechnology and medicine.

A Brush With Fame is a British television series which originally aired on Channel 4 from 1995 to 1997. It was presented by the comedian Jack Dee and featured celebrity guests in a variety of amusing scenarios. Guests appeared in sketches set in a variety of different surroundings, such as a grand reception, an office, a garden or an old battered car. These situations were designed to make the celebrities uncomfortable and usually ended with them being relieved when the sketch was over. During the sketch some of Dee's team members would make observations and give advice to the guest. The programme also features guests answering questions from the audience as well as revealing some aspects of their private lives. This could include discussing their relationship status, or embarrassing moments from their past. Dee present the show with a dry wit and a strong sense of irony. This helped to make the show unique from other celebrity driven series of its time. The show was a huge hit in the UK when it aired and was one of Channel Four's most highly rated shows in its timeslot. It spawned two series and a book based on the show was also published. A Brush With Fame was praised for its smart, funny and often irreverent take on celebrity culture. It featured many prominent celebrities from the worlds of film, television and music, and allowed viewers a chance to see them in a different light. Although the show ended in 1997, its influence can still be seen in many of the modern celebrity driven shows. Today, Jack Dee is remembered as a presenter who had a unique ability to make celebrities look foolish while also entertaining his audience. A Brush With Fame was an innovative and often hilarious look at the British celebrity world.

Ghetto Kids, also known as Ghetto Dance, is a street dance originated in the early 1990s by a group of inner-city youth in Chicago, Illinois. The style of dance is associated with a number of hip-hop music genres, including hip-hop, jazz, funk and soul. Ghetto Kids is characterized by unique body movements, such as popping, locking and waving, and the dancing isnavigably performed in an improvisational and often competitive style. Ghetto Kids is considered the foundation of today's current dance movement and has been regarded as one of the most significant street dance styles to influence the hip-hop community. The style has been most famously featured in the popular MTV program, America's Best Dance Crew. In the early 1990s, hip-hop dancers from Chicago's South Side created Ghetto Kids in an effort to provide a positive and creative outlet for inner-city youth. The dancers developed the distinct style of dance by integrating elements from jazz, funk and soul, as well as incorporating their own individualized body movements. Ghetto Kids can easily be recognized by its improvisational and highly competitive stylings. The dancers are often characterized by quick and drastic body moves, and frequently incorporate body waves and popping into their routines to emphasize the competitive nature of the dance form. In recent years, Ghetto Kids has been featured in performances, music videos and television programs, including music videos by Baby Bash, John Legend, Fat Joe and Chingy. Ghetto Kids has also made appearances in movie dance-offs, commercials and print ads. Today, Ghetto Kids is considered an influential and popular dance style, and is widely practiced in urban communities worldwide. Many aspiring dancers are attracted to Ghetto Kids because of its unique and improvisational nature. The style also continues to heavily influence hip-hop culture, making it one of the most culturally significant street dance forms.

Net material product (NMP) is an economic measure of the value of material commodities produced in an economy during a period of time. It is calculated by subtracting the value of material inputs (material consumption) from the total value of output (net output). The NPM measures material production excluding the value of other production factors, such as labour and capital. NMP is seen as a key measure of an economy's material intensity, which can be used to assess an economy's overall sustainability. NMP is used in economic analysis and policy evaluation, such as economic development, health, and environmental analysis. NMP is calculated as the difference between total net output and total material inputs in an accounting period. It includes both materials and energy inputs and excludes capital inputs, labor inputs, and services. NMP is characterized by its coverage of inputs, output, and changes in material stocks. It also captures the flow of inputs and outputs across time and between areas. NMP can be used to measure the performance of a nation or region over time and to compare the performance of different nations or regions. The NMP measures the total value of materials that are used in a production process and excludes the intangible factors that are used to create a product, such as research and development costs. This measure helps to identify the amount of labor, energy, and resources used to create a product as well as how much value has been added to a product during the production process. NMP is calculated in two ways. The direct method is based on the value of physical outputs and the value of materials inputs. The indirect method estimates NMP by subtracting the value of the downstream inputs from the value of the upstream outputs. NMP is a useful measure for assessing an economy's material efficiency and productivity. It provides a simplified way to measure the output and efficiency of an economy and can be used to compare different nations or regions over time. It can also be used to understand the amount of material that is used in the production of a good, and how this impact the local and global environment. NMP is also seen as an important tool for monitoring the potential negative impacts of globalisation on resource use and sustainability. It has been used by governments and international organisations, such as the World Bank, to assess the sustainability of a country’s economic development. It can be used to determine the level of resource efficiency and identify potential areas of improvement in the production process.

Paul of Taranto (died 941) was a Lombard prince who succeeded his father Arduin of Italy as the margrave of the March of Taranto from 924. He is also sometimes referred to as Paul-Arduinus. He was born in Italy, the son of Arduin of Italy and a daughter of Berengar I, King of Italy. At the time, the Lombard power in southern Italy was in decline, and the southern regions were under the influence of the Byzantine Empire. In 924, upon the death of his father, Paul succeeded him as the margrave of the March of Taranto. Despite his position as the official leader of the duchy, Paul spent much of his reign under the influence of other Lombard lords, including Adalbert I of Benevento. During his reign, Paul's authority was largely limited to southern Apulia and, by 935, Basil II of the Byzantine Empire had gained control of nearly all of Lombard Italy. Despite this, Paul was able to maintain a degree of independence for the Taranto region. To consolidate his position, he married a daughter of Sico I of Benevento in 926. Paul died in circa 941 and was succeeded as margrave by his brother Giselbert of Ratchis, husband of Willa, daughter of Guy II Tenebrion of Liguria. Paul was an able administrator and appears to have kept the March of Taranto in a relatively stable state during his reign, despite the chaotic situation in the rest of Lombard Italy. He is briefly mentioned in several contemporary sources and is credited with founding the Church of Santa Maria in 922. He is remembered today as a capable leader with a strong sense of duty. He is commemorated in the form of a statue in the town of Taranto.

Niña de mi corazón (English: "Girl of My Heart") is a Mexican pop/rock-influenced ballad by singer Thalía, released in 1999 as part of her eponymous album. The song was co-written by the singer herself and composer Marcello Azevedo, who has written other songs for several Latin artists including Chayanne, Jennifer Lopez and Paulina Rubio. The ballad recounts the story of a woman in love, describing her tumultuous relationship with her partner. She expresses her hope for a better life, asking for guidance from a higher power as she makes decisions regarding her relationship. The singer showed her melancholy side with this song and the accompanying music video features her singing in front of a moonlit window, surrounded by her memories of her former love. The song was released as the second single from the album and it was well-received. In Mexico and some Latin American countries, the single reached the top spots on the music charts; some of them such as Peru and Venezuela certified the song Gold for sales and airplay. In Mexico, Niña de mi Corazón topped the 40 Principales chart, and charted in France, where it peaked at #19, becoming Thalía’s third and last chart entry in the country. The song won the Lo Nuestro Award for Pop Song of the Year in 2000 and it was nominated for an International Viewer’s Choice Award at the 2000 MTV Video Music Awards Latin America. The music video directed by Gustavo Garzón earned the artist a nomination to the MTV Video Music Awards Mexico in the category of Pop Video of the Year. Thalía performed “Niña de mi Corazón” on several television shows. Notably, during her New Era Tour in 2002, Thalía performed the song with her then-husband, Tommy Mottola, in San Cristobal de Las Casas, Mexico. The performance was broadcast in September 2002 all over Latin America through television special “En Vivo desde Chiapas”. Today, the song remains one of Thalía’s most beloved singles. The song endures as a fan favorite and concert staple, a tribute to the singer's success in recording an emotional ballad full of memorable melodies, vivid lyrics and a powerful delivery. Niña de mi Corazón is not only considered one of Thalía’s best works, it is also one of her most enduring hits.

Wesley O. Smith (sometimes referred to as Wesley O. Smith Jr.) (born July 16 1975) is an American entrepreneur, business executive and software developer. He is the founder and CEO of internet-based software development company W&O Corporation. Smith grew up in Harris County, Texas. He attended the University of Texas at Austin where he majored in Computer Science. After graduating in 1998, Smith launched his first startup, a website development company. The company was successful, but did not get the attention that he wanted. In 2002, Smith founded W&O Corporation, a software development and design company specializing in web application development and mobile app creation. The company was an instant success and quickly grew to become one of the leading software development companies in the country. Since its founding, W&O has completed hundreds of projects for clients including search engine giants Google and Microsoft, global health care leaders Allergan and Cincinnati Children's Hospital and retail brands such as Lululemon, Staples, and Williams-Sonoma. In 2011, W&O was named one of Inc. Magazine's fastest growing companies, and has been featured regularly in the New York Times and other international publications. In addition to leading W&O, Smith is an active investor and advisor to several technology companies. He is also an advocate for workforce diversity and the use of technology in the classrooms. In 2017, Smith returned to academia and joined the faculty at the University of Houston to teach software engineering. Smith is also a keynote speaker and has spoken at several tech industry summits worldwide. Smith is a firm believer in giving back and dedicates a portion of his time to philanthropic causes and volunteer work. He has served in leadership roles on the board of directors at NPower and Houston Food Bank, two organizations which provide technology services and meals to those in need. Wesley O. Smith is a highly successful entrepreneur and respected business leader. His work at W&O Corporation and commitment to philanthropic causes has established him as a leader in the software development industry and a role model for entrepreneurs around the world.

Sašo Mijalkov (born 26 August 1969) is a Macedonian businessman, the owner and a former CEO of Makedonski Telekom, one of the largest Macedonian companies. He was the director of the Macedonian Intelligence Agency from 2008 to 2011. Mijalkov was born on 26 August 1969 in Ohrid, Macedonia. He graduated from the Faculty of Electrical Engineering at St. Clement of Ohrid University in Skopje in 1992. He then earned a degree in Business Administration from Ss Cyril and Methodius University in 2006. Mijalkov started his business career in 2002 when he joined Makedonski Telekom as CEO and later as chairman and major shareholder in 2004. Under his leadership, the company increased its market share from 2% in 2002 to over 60% by 2010, becoming one of the most successful companies in Macedonia. At the same time, Mijalkov was appointed director of the Macedonian Intelligence Agency in 2008. He resigned from that position in 2011. Outside of his professional activities, Mijalkov is a keen sportsman. He is a member of the National Soccer Association and the National Basketball Association, and participates in various local tournaments. He is also an active philanthropist and a patron of several charity organizations in Macedonia. In recognition of his contributions to the success of Makedonski Telekom, Mijalkov was given the Skopje Award in 2010. He is regarded as one of the most successful entrepreneurs in Macedonia, and is often called upon to give lectures and keynote speeches at business conferences and universities.

The Kraichgau Railway (German: Kraichgau-Bahn) is a short, but of major importance, railway line in the German state of Baden-Württemberg, running from Heidelberg via Sinsheim, Wiesloch-Walldorf, and Zaberfeld to Bretten and connecting to the Mannhei–Stuttgart line near Auerbach. The Kraichgau Railway follows the Kraichgau, the region southwest of Heidelberg, which was already served by steam trains at the end of the 19th century. It is 108km long and is one of the most important and heavily used north–south lines in Germany, with a total of 55 trains per hour. It is part of the geocentric principle of railway construction and also improves the public transport connection in the densely populated area. The line was electrified in 1908 and was fully double-tracked in 1933. Before the Second World War, a maximum of 1,000 freights per day were handled on tracks and bridges. After the war, the entire railway was reconstructed and the line became an important regional railway. In the 1950s and 1960s, the Kraichgau Railway line saw the introduction of new rolling stock, such as the VT98 and VT98a – DMUs (Diesel multiple units), as well as the more recent Desiro ML and Vario D50 EMUs (Electric multiple units). In 2007, between Zaberfeld and Güglingen, the now-defunct Kraichgaugleise ("Kraichgau Tracks") were opened. They were used by freight trains and limited passenger services between Weinheim and Hockenheim. The Kraichgau Railway is operated by DB Regio AG and is served by DB Regional-Express and Regionalbahn service. The line is the main rail connection between Heidelberg and Heilbronn and is a major route for commuters between the two cities. Furthermore, it connects the region north of Heidelberg with Mannheim and Stuttgart, as well as to Karlsruhe. In December 2008, the renovation of the track and station facilities of the Kraichgau Railway was completed. This renovation included a refurbishment of the track and the replacement of signalling systems. In 2013, a modernisation of the railway was announced by the Deutsche Bahn. The project was planned to include the conversion of the line from Wiesloch-Walldorf to the double-track starting point at Heidelberg-Schlierbach and the construction of a new station at Wiesloch-Hohensachsen. The modernisation of the Kraichgau Railway is part of the 'HomeRail Region' project, which is the German federal government's initiative to modernise the railway network and infrastructure in Germany. This investment will improve the service for passengers and freight services and provide direct access to the Mannheim–Stuttgart high-speed railway. The modernisation project was completed in June 2016 and is now in full operation. The new line enables more direct travel times and increased capacities. The Kraichgau Railway is an essential artery of the regional railway network and plays an important role in providing efficient public transport for the densely populated area.
